Neither is it a lament, a sorry saga of chewed slippers and toys, of a three- year failure at housebreaking, of the budget-breaking effect of top-of-the- line canned dogfood.

Mr. Lukens, a career member of the Foreign Service, replaces Kenneth Brown. Mr. Lukens has been director of the State Department's Office of Analysis for Western Europe since 1982.

But almost everyone involved was stunned by the swift, overwhelming Congressional approval of a bill sent to the White House last week that would reduce Federal highway construction funds to states that failed to enact a minimum drinking age of 21.

description: BECAUSE the price of the same wine at different restaurants in the county can vary by more than 35 percent, searching out bargain bottles makes good sense. A careful choice will often allow the savings on wine to help pay for the food.

title: OPENING THE BOOKS ON CENSORSHIP

title: All-Star CoachesManagers
description: Paul Owens of the Philadelphia Phillies and Joe Altobelli of the Baltimore Orioles have announced their coaching choices for the All-Star Game July 10 in San Francisco. Owens, the National League skipper, appointed Tom Lasorda of the Dodgers as his first-base coach and Chuck Tanner of the Pirates to coach at third. Altobelli named Sparky Anderson of the Detroit Tigers to coach at first base and Tony LaRussa of the White Sox to coach at third.

title: WHEN WOMAN IS IDEALIZED WITHOUT RESTORING TO CLICHE
description: In her husband Harry's photographs, Eleanor Callahan does not appear beautiful in any conventional sense of the word. She is too thick limbed and heavy hipped to fit the stereotype of a photographer's mannequin; her features are too sharply etched to be called delicate. But while neither her figure nor her face conform to any mold of the male imagination, her statuesque bearing and placid countenance conspire to create an iconic presence that has a novel, powerful beauty all its own. Mr. Callahan's pictures of Eleanor are among the extremely rare breed of photographs that can truly be called mythopoeic.

description: PAUL HOFMANN is the author of ''O Vatican! A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See.'' (Congdon & Weed).

title: STAGE:THE TRIAL OF LEO FRANK

title: RESPITE CO-OP CARES FOR DISABLED
description: LAST spring, Donna had an opportunity to vacation in Hawaii. But she could not just take off. Her teen-age daughter has cerebral palsy, and before any pleasure trips could be planned, the girl's welfare at home had to be assured.

title: THE VHS MAKES A LIGHTNING LEAP INTO THE REALM OF QUALITY SOUND
description: Even before the doors opened at the Consumer Electronics Show - the gigantic electronics trade fair held in Chicago last month - it had been anticipated that video cassette recorders (VCR's) would dominate the event. After all, the popular appeal of these devices has exceeded all expectations. According to the latest available figures, more than twice as many VCR's were sold in the first five months of this year than in all of 1982, and an estimated 13 million such gadgets are now whirring away in America. If the pace keeps up, VCR's may soon be regarded as a standard adjunct to a television set, just as audio cassette recorders - once considered an optional extra - have become integral to any stereo system.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BEFORE one settles down to a picnic and, as the sky turns dark, watches the first blast of fireworks, a July Fourth afternoon suffused with American history is in store for those who drive over the border to the Bronx for a 2 P.M. concert in a cemetery.

title: THE WORDS OF MUSIC
description: Donal Henahan is The Times's music critic. William Safire is on vacation.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SCOTT AND AMUNDSEN, by Roland Huntford. (Atheneum, $12.95.) In the struggle to reach the South Pole first, men and dogs battled geography; technical support was scant - there was no ''mission control'' - and national honor was involved. Britain's Robert Falcon Scott and Norway's Roald Amundsen were the competitors. Roland Huntford, a former London Observer correspondent in Scandinavia, has interwoven each competitor's biography - detailing the diametrically opposite personalities - with a heavily researched account of Arctic and Antarctic exploration. Writing in The Times, Walter Sullivan called ''Scott and Amundsen'' ''a remarkably vivid picture of the agonies and feuds, as well as joys, of polar exploration.'' WAYWARD REPORTER: The Life of A. J. Liebling, by Raymond Sokolov. (Creative Arts, $10.95.) A 1980 biog- raphy of The New Yorker's press critic who also served it as a war correspondent and trenchant profile writer. Liebling was also called a melancholy boulevardier, poseur, womanizer, gourmand and legendary figure among journalists. Wilfrid Sheed, in these pages, said there are gaps in ''Wayward Reporter'' that Raymond Sokolov has filled ''with much good Liebling prose, the best possible substitute for a real biography. Mr. Sokolov's shrewd excerpts also bring out (Liebling's) versatility, his perfect matching of tone to subject and his eye for the one detail - the piece of flapping underwear - that makes a scene live.''

title:
ART;
CELEBRATING 25 YEARS OF AN 'ATMOSHPERE OF CREATIVITY'
description: THE solitary life of an artist becomes an issue of discussion from time to time, but rarely do we hear of artists working as a group. Participants in A.I.A. (Artists Involvement in Art) are enthusiastic, however, praising the studio rooms, gallery and workshop space they share on two floors of a centrally located commercial building in Great Neck.

title: BOOK LOVER EASES TOIL ON MARK TWAIN'S RIVER
description: The young deckhands stood under the light by the bow, ready to tie up their string of heavily laden barges in the lock for the six-foot drop to the next level of the Mississippi River.

title: Data Bank; July 1, 1984
Miss Muldowney Hurt
description: Shirley Muldowney, the three-time National Hot Rod Association champion, was listed in stable condition yesterday following six-hour surgery at Montreal General Hospital for injuries suffered Friday during a qualifying drag race at St. Pie de Batot, Quebec. Miss Muldowney was injured after her dragster blew a tire at 247 miles an hour, flipped and disintegrated when it hit the ground.

The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Minor F. H. Gouverneur at his home in Goshen, Conn.

Two enterprising, self-appointed artistic directors have come up with the concept of a ''script-in-lap'' reading, under the banner Summer Solstice Theater Conference, which begins in East Hampton on Thursday and goes on twice a week until Aug. 31.

title: Italian Ice Cream
description: To the Editor: How can Henry Kamm do this to us? In his informative piece ''What's Doing in Rome'' (Travel, May 6), he tells us about the fabulous tartufo at Tre Scalini, which I knew about, and frustrates us by saying that the people who are really in the know when it comes to ice cream go to the two establishments on the Via di Tor Millina. He described the street but failed to give the names of the two places.

title: TOP STATE COURT BARS BENEFIT CUT IN PENSION LAW
description: The Court of Appeals has unanimously overturned two key provisions of a pension law adopted last year for state and municipal public employees. The intent of both sections was to reduce government costs.

title: U.S. GENERAL TO END TROOPS' CIVIC AID IN LATIN AREA
description: The commander of United States forces in Latin America, Gen. Paul F. Gorman, intends to cancel medical and other humanitarian aid being provided by American troops in the region because of a recent ruling by the General Accounting Office, Defense Department officials said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch last Sunday on the campaign platform drafted by a Democratic committee misstated its position on national health insurance. It said, ''We reaffirm our commitment to the long-term goal of comprehensive national health insurance.''

title: ; THE MAKING OF A SPORTS HERO
description: Today, when athletics have become so specialized that swimmers can't ski and skiers can't swim for fear of pumping the wrong set of muscles, the decathlon is a sort of last stronghold of true physical culture: the perfecting of the whole body in a balanced and harmonious manner (''The Making of a Decathlon Champion,'' by Skip Rozin, June 3). This is something that American children should be exposed to, and Daley Thompson, with his difficult childhood and his amazing perseverance and strength of character, has all the makings of a classic sports hero.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE REWARDS OF HOMEWORK
description: What more challenging a way to spend a few hours than planning your next vacation? You may ultimately decide to have a travel agent make the detailed arrangements, but many vacationers have found that the more homework they do themselves, the better those arrangements are likely to be.

description: A MUSEUM and research center devoted to the culture and history of the Hudson River School of Painting has been proposed for a site in Hastings-on-Hudson now occupied by the village's Department of Public Works.

title: DOCTORS FIND COST-CUTTING RULES HARD TO ACCEPT
description: Dr. Gilbert R. Clark, a 58- year-old pathologist at St. Francis Hospital, retired this spring partly, he says, because too many people were telling him how to practice. ''If you ask most doctors why they became medical doctors back in the 40's and 50's, it was not money,'' he said. ''It was a way of life and a thing they wanted to do. They were free-thinking individuals who wanted to take care of people. Now suddenly, everybody else is in their office - the insurance companies, the third-party people - telling them how to run it.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
THOSE SUMMER ATHLETES
description: SOON after we put in our inground swimming pool, I knew it was a terrible mistake. It took only a couple of social get-togethers to realize that many friends and relatives who gather poolside are not content to merely slather their remarkably unfit bodies in suntan oil and doze peacefully within arm's reach of the potato chips.

title: CITY OPERA AT 40-YOUNG AS EVER

A major test of his premise was the New York City Opera, which opened its doors on Feb. 21, 1944 and will reopen them - for the 40th year - on Friday.

title: JACKSON TESTS MONDALE'S POLITICAL WITS
description: WASHINGTON AS the Rev. Jesse Jackson flew home last week with 48 American and Cuban prisoners from Fidel Castro's prisons in tow, what should have been a moment of personal triumph was overwhelmed by a roiling political furor at home that threatened not only his standing in the Democratic Party but Walter F. Mondale's chances against President Reagan.

title: Arbour Headed Back?General Manager
description: Bill Torrey of the Islanders said that indications that Al Arbour would return as coach next season were a lot better than they were when the season ended.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW YORK'S ASCENDANCY AS AN AUCTION CAPITAL
description: Two mid-June sales have underscored New York's status as the auction capital of the numismatic world. On June 13 and 14, Stack's sold the Floyd T. Starr Collection of U.S. large cents and half cents for a total of nearly $1.28 million. Less than a week later, on June 18 and 19, Bowers and Merena Galleries Inc. sold the final portion of U.S. coins from the Virgil M. Brand Collection for more than $1.4 million.

The Rev. Thomas Huntington Chappell performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Pequot Chapel in New London.

title: MONITORING THE STUDENT-ATHLETE CAUSE
description: Northeastern University will officially begin a program tomorrow that will mark the first time that an institution of higher education has addressed the questions of the exploitation of student-athletes and their educational rights on a nationwide scale. The Center for the Study of Sport in Society will focus on athletes in high schools, colleges and even in the pro ranks, where there are the comparative few who were lucky enough to beat the 12,000-to-1 odds that say a high school athlete will never legally receive money for playing sports as a career.

title: Rosie Jones Leads at Hershey
description: Rosie Jones, seeking her first victory in three years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot a 3-under-par 69 today to take a two- shot lead in the Lady Keystone Open.

title: OPENING THE BOOKS ON CENSORSHIP
description: Had I known that Barbara Ehrenreich's ''feminist's view'' of the new man is in reality a severely prejudiced and subjective view, I would have declined to be interviewed and photographed for the article (''A Feminist's View of the New Man,'' May 20). The fact that the substantive discussion points in my interview with Miss Ehrenreich's assistant, which lasted approximately two and a half hours, were blatantly ignored in favor of 20 seconds of trivial chitchat strongly suggests that Miss Ehrenreich is more interested in tailoring the facts to suit her own purpose than in presenting the truth.

title: Superpower Pas de Deux
description: How deliciously Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan have combined to confound the Kremlin. President Carter spent three years pursuing detente until, heading into the 1980 election, the invasion of Afghanistan caused him to disrupt all contacts. President Reagan, having virtually frozen relations during his first three years, is using his re-election campaign to plead for a resumption of cultural exchanges and other civilities.

title:
DEVELOPER: BENJAMIN DUKE HOLLOWAY;
EQUITABLE'S PLAYER IN THE REAL ESTATE SWEEPSTAKES
description: BENJAMIN DUKE HOLLOWAY does not have the high profile - or the familiar name - of such real estate moguls as Donald Trump and Harry Helmsley. There are no buildings named after him, no magazine cover stories, no nationwide advertising campaign featuring his wife.

title: Police Fire Tear Gas at Rally After Year of Copper Strike
description: The police, saying they were attacked with a Molotov cocktail, fired tear gas canisters into a crowd at a rally today marking the first anniversary of a copper strike.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES

The first of its l3 one-hour episodes, ''Roots of a War,'' tracing the history of Vietnam through the end of World War II, will be shown on channels 13 and 49 on Tuesday at 9 P.M.

In the first phase of redevelopment, the ground floor of the former ski lodge - an A-frame building that also houses a police station - has been converted to an art gallery, and the second phase calls for the construction of an outdoor amphitheater in the little valley at the base of the former ski run.

title: FIRST OPERAS, OFTEN FLIMSY, HAVE THEIR ATTRACTIONS
description: How many first operas can you name that have made the grade? Let's rule out ''Fidelio,'' ''Pelleas et Melisande'' and ''Wozzeck,'' please. Those solitary masterpieces by mature artists fall into the one-and-only category, not to be confused with the first-of-many efforts of composers who went on to add great things to the operatic repertory. Beethoven engaged in a famous struggle for 10 years to produce his opera, which began life as ''Leonore'' and evolved into ''Fidelio.'' Debussy was 40 when he wrote ''Pelleas.'' Berg took five years to deliver himself of ''Wozzeck,'' at age 37. These three were fastidious, self- critical composers in the modern style, reluctant to publish a page that did not represent them to posterity at their mature best. They did not conduct their opera educations in public, as did the Verdis and the Donizettis.

It sounds idyllic, and was, for a while; but I am getting tired of my own backyard.

title: SAN FRANCISCO
description: Lacey Fosburgh, author of the novel ''Old Money,'' lives in San Francisco. By Lacey Fosburgh SAN FRANCISCO IS ONE OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL cities in the world and a remarkably pleasant place to live, but when the Democrats arrive in two weeks for what promises to be a tumultuous national convention, the city they will see is one whose history of controversy and unconventionality marches right up to the present. Perhaps some cities, like some people, can put away their idiosyncrasies when guests come to call, but San Francisco has never been one of these. A billboard 15 feet high near Moscone Center, where more than 30,000 delegates, alternates, family members and media representatives will gather daily for the convention proceedings, will proclaim the local homosexuals' welcome. The homosexuals - possibly the most controversial of all the country's special-interest groups - as well as many more people with many more causes are scheduled to march outside the hall in what is expected to be one of the most demonstration-filled political conventions in American history.

title: A NEW PROGRAM HELPS THE ELDERLY KEEP HOMES
description: Fifteen months ago Irene Hoffman was about to lose her house. The slender 70-year- old widow had fallen behind on her utility bills and owed more than $2,000 in back taxes. The only way out, she thought, was to sell her beloved two- story house with the slate-green shingles that had been her home for the last 13 years.

title: CONFLICTS OVER LATIN AMERICA REFUSE TO BE PUT ON HOLD
description: AS President Reagan approaches his re-election campaign, his advisers would like to keep in place all the military, diplomatic and economic strands of his policy in Central America without raising new political storms. They would prefer to put the emphasis on diplomacy and negotiations and play down controversies over the mining of Nicaraguan harbors, Congressional refusal to finance Nicaraguan rebels, and fears of American military involvement and casualties. But neither the Democrats nor forces in the region are cooperating.

title: REPAIRING CRACKS IN CONCRETE ON WALKS AND DRIVEWAYS

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
ON THE NEED FOR A LAW TO FIGHT COMPUTER FRAUD
description: THE computer is the essence of our technological age. We shout its praises for saving us incredible amounts of time and effort, accomplishing in a few minutes complex, tedious calculations that would take months or even years to complete without it. But we also fear its potential for invading our privacy and destroying our freedom by collecting and storing vast amounts of personal data. Like any tool of man, it can be both used and misused. Unlike most other tools, its potential benefits, as well as its potential harm, are almost unlimited.

title: DAVID RABE EXPLORES A DIFFERENT KIND OF JUNGLE
description: David Rabe's ''Hurlyburly'' is set in an all-male household somewhere ''in the Hollywood hills.'' So the program at the Promenade Theater tells us, so the dialogue of the play itself confirms. But if you look through the panes of glass that serve as the back wall of Tony Walton's set, you actually see nothing but leaves, stems, rushes, grass, a wild tangle of green thickly straggling out to the wings, up to the flies, and (so you feel) out into the dressing rooms behind the stage. It could be part of some Amazonian rain-forest. It could be a slice of jungle in the country which did so much to shape Mr. Rabe and his earlier work: Vietnam.

title: A KEY ISSUE IN SPACE ARMS: HOW TO DEFINE THEM
description: If the United States and the Soviet Union meet this year to outlaw antisatellite weapons, the major points of technical difficulty will be how to define such weapons and how to verify whether they have been deployed, an Administration official said today.

title: THIS TIME, THE SHUTTLE IS BITTEN BY BUGS
description: Like any machine, the space shuttle can be cantankerous. A computer falters without warning and a launch is canceled. Everything is humming along in the next day's countdown when the three main engines, which are supposed to ignite in split-second sequence, don't. A fuel valve fails to open on first command. The mission is aborted four seconds short of liftoff and postponed indefinitely.

description: SUMMER survival strategy usually includes eating light, and few cuisines are better suited to hot, humid weather than Japanese. A welcome addition to a corner of the county until now deprived of Japanese eating spots, Momiji in Harrison offers iced sashimi and sushi, cool, smooth tofu and quick-grilled specialties just right for this season. The kitchen has improved significantly since its opening 18 months ago, and although Momiji is not without flaws, they crop up more in the decor than in the food.

title: International
description: Moscow's new arms proposal is puzzling the Reagan Administration. A White House official said the Administration was trying to find out whether the proposal was a shift in Moscow's attitude toward dealing with the Administraiton or was aimed at embarrassing the President. Mr. Reagan was said to be prepared to stress the seriousness of the Administration's desire to hold wide-ranging arms control talks at a meeting today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin. (Page 1, Column 6.) John N. Turner was sworn in as Prime Minister of Canada in a private ceremony in Ottawa. He pledged a more''business-like'' Government and announced the departure of 13 Cabinet ministers who had served the outgoing administration of Pierre Elliott Trudeau. (1:4.)

title: FEART AND SKEPTICISM ACROSS THE BORDER
description: If illegal Mexican immigrants and the people who study them are correct, the immigration legislation now being considered by Congress would not regain control of the United States border so much as it would offend nearly everyone south of it. The Mexican Government has had little officially to say about the legislation, which was approved last week by the House of Representatives. In a statement, the Foreign Ministry merely warned that the measure could ''seriously undercut and injure the human and labor rights of Mexican workers.'' But business, labor and peasant organizations have been unanimous in condemning the proposed law. It has been called racist, repressive, economically devastating and another instance of the wealthy and omnipotent United States turning its back on less fortunate neighbors.

title: ARGENTINA AVOIDS THE BRINK AGAIN
description: Argentina on the Move. Less than a week after a group of Latin American debtors called for a united front, Argentina appeared to be bowing to pressure from American banks and the International Monetary Fund to maintain its status as a borrower. Barely meeting American banks' quarterly reporting deadline, Argentina late Friday announced it would immediately pay about $350 million in interest that was 90 days past due - $225 million from its own coffers and $125 million from new loans. The payment kept the way open for future loans, including an I.M.F. loan if agreement on an austerity plan can be reached. Earlier in the week, after months of saying his people had suffered enough, President Raul Alfonsin said they should be prepared for more hardships if Argentina is to overcome its $45 billion foreign debt.

title: THE NOVELIST AND THE NORMAL WORLD
description: FICTIONS used to be neighborly tales, even when they took place in ancient times or imaginary places. That was a long time ago, before everyone started going around saying God and the novel were dead. In those days, writers advertised their familiarity with worldly matters. On the jackets of their books young novelists and poets reported that they had been to work or to war, to Skid Row or Connecticut, and that they had served as carpenters, sailors, salesmen, clerks, doctors, ditchdiggers, lawyers or banjo players.

title: MUSIC VIDEO IS HERE, WITH A VENGEANCE
description: After a couple of decades of frustration, commercial television is taking to pop music with a vengeance. The new phenomenon of ''music video,'' which began pulsating in earnest on cable's ''Music TV,'' is spawning its inevitable imitations and variations, whether on network schedules or in syndication. At present in the New York area, for instance, the daily afternoon TV schedule includes ''Hot'' on WNEW/Channel 5 at 4:30, ''Great Record Album Collections'' on WOR/Channel 9 at 5:30 P.M., and ''Solid Gold Hits'' on WPIX/Channel 11 at 6 P.M. Meanwhile, NBC has ''Friday Night Videos'' going on once a week at 12:30 A.M. and ABC is currently offering ''ABC Rocks'' as a limited series on Fridays at midnight. And there will undoubtedly be more entries as the armies of duplicators rush to squeeze the last ounce of profit from the new programming toy.

title: HARTFORD LOOKS HARD AT BRIDGE INSPECTORS

title: WASHINGTON AND MOSCOW STEP UP THE PEACE COMPETITION
description: WITH little else being discussed between the two countries and official exchanges at low ebb, the Soviet Union and the United States each tried last week to draw the other into a negotiation on its favorite topic. Moscow proposed that talks start in Vienna in September on banning space weapons, where it is supposed to have a momentary edge. It suggested a moratorium on testing and deployment of such weapons pending the establishment of a formal treaty.

description: Gary Jobson of the United States and Harold Cudmore of Britain each sailed to three victories yesterday in the inaugural Liberty Cup Regatta, a match-racing series pitting eight of the top skippers in the world in identical 30-foot sloops with a crew of four in waters off Staten Island.

title: TAKING STOCK OF AMERICA'S DANCE INFLUENCE ABROAD
description: There are many ways to celebrate a 50th anniversary. You can cut your cake and eat it, too, looking back upon the glorious past. And certainly the American Dance Festival, a fountainhead of creativity in modern dance, has that past. The Festival, conceived at Bennington College in 1934, long resident at Connecticut College and now based at Duke University, is nonetheless marking its golden anniversary this summer in a number of unexpected ways. It is looking

title: THREE-WAY RACE AVOIDED IN CONTEST FOR PERONE'S SEAT
description: FOR a long while there seemed to be three candidates poised to run for Assemblyman John Perone's seat along the Sound Shore - Ronald C. Tocci, Democrat; Guy Parisi, Republican; and Dr. Francis X. Judge, Conservative - and they all knew each other.

title: INNOVATIONS IN EYE TREATMENT
description: -year-old medical doctor, is a new breed of ophthalmologist. In the hands of today's young doctors, new types of lasers have replaced ordinary scalpels during certain surgical procedures. Computers help detect more precisely any blind spots in the visual field of their patients. It takes seconds rather than minutes to fill a prescription for lenses.

title: MORE FUN AND GAMES FOR COLLEGE FOOTBALL
description: AS it has to many other big businesses, deregulation came to college football last week. The Supreme Court ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 33-year control over the televising of games, calling the organization a ''classic cartel'' whose power to set prices and limit appearances was an ''unreasonable restraint of trade.''

title: Paul Hennessy Is Wed To Patricia Ann Casey
description: Patricia Ann Casey, a senior development officer at Boston College, was married yesterday to Paul James Hennessy, director of communications at Boston College, The Rev. William B. Neenan, dean of arts and scientists at Boston College, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the school's chapel in Newton, Mass.

title: Stockbroker in Denver Marries Jane E. Rubin
description: Jane Elizabeth Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Rubin of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Martin Colden Hoffman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoffman of Ligonier, Pa. Municipal Court Judge Cyrus Allen 3d of Vail, Colo., performed the ceremony at the Westin Hotel there.

title: Sewanee
description: To the Editor: Thanks very much for Alan Cheuse's refreshing article on Sewanee (Travel, May 6). As a stu

title: THE NATION
description: Unions WinOn BankruptcyLaw Revisions

title: Key West Police Department Called a 'Criminal Enterprise'
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, charging that the Key West Police Department was ''a criminal enterprise,'' arrested three high-ranking officers and several other people Friday on racketeering and drug charges.

title: City Junk
description: Country Junk One sign of the season in northern Vermont is the truckloads of furniture and bric-a-brac wending north from New York's suburbs and Connecticut. There are ''city antiques'' and ''country antiques,'' and the latter are more valuable, as an upcountry dealer we know explains it.

title: A MEMORIAL TO LITTLE MISS 1565
description: REPRESENTATIVES of a florists association are to continue a 40-year tradition this Friday by placing flowers on the grave of Little Miss 1565, one of six unidentified victims of a circus fire in Hartford July 6, 1944, the worst single disaster in the history of Connecticut.

title: DICARLO WIPES OUT AN OLD U.S. RECORD
description: A week ago, the two oldest American swimming records belonged to Brian Goodell. No more.

title: Kathleen E. O'Brien, D'Amato Aide, Weds
description: Kathleen E. O'Brien, assistant press secretary to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas B. Ham, a staff member of the Surface Transportation subcommittee of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, The Rev. Thomas Mulvanerty performed the ceremony at St. Boniface Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: THE WISDOM OF FOLLY
description: Garden follies are the stuff of architectural dreams - a frivolous kind of 18th-century ornament designed for no particular reason other than as a romantic spot in which to enjoy the view or sit in solitary contemplation. These eccentric structures, which adorned the landscapes of many a European country house, often resembled fantastical visions such as miniature Gothic castles, hermits' caves or even secret grottoes.

title: TOWNS SUING STATE ON REVENUE SHARE
description: THE Brookhaven and Islip Town Boards have voted to join 20 other upstate towns in a class-action suit against New York State, charging that the state is still using 1970 census figures to distribute revenue-sharing funds among its municipalities. Consequently, many towns in Suffolk County, including Brookhaven and Islip, which have grown in population from 1970 to 1980, have been losing a substantial amount of revenue-sharing funds since 1980, when the new census was taken.

title: FOOTBALL'S PLACE UNDER THE SUN
description: Michael Janofsky is a sports reporter for The Times. EVERYTHING ABOUTthe scene was unlikely. On a hot and sticky Sunday in May, with baseball winding up and basketball winding down, it was midseason for two professional football teams mauling each other all over Legion Field in Birmingham, Ala.

title: WORKSHOPS FOR TEACHERS PROVE POPULAR
description: SO many teachers signed up for the state's first professional- development workshops that participants had to be chosen by lottery. Nearly 3,000 teachers applied to attend the summer workshops that will focus on improving writing, basic skills in reading, mathematics and science, early childhood education and supervision of instruction.

title: Marilyn Seibel Weds John Matthew Tomich
description: Marilyn Gladys Seibel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Alfred Seibel of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to John Matthew Tomich, a son of Mrs. Matthew Tomich of Westport, Conn., and Washington and the late Mr. Tomich. John H. Sauders, a retired judge of the Los Angeles County Court, performed the ceremony at the Athenaeum at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, where the bride is a staff scientist in the biology department and the bridegroom is a senior research fellow in molecular biology in the chemistry department.

title: Yanks Trade Rawley for Phils' Bystrom
description: The Yankees and the Phillies, two teams in search of pitching, today exchanged pitchers who are in search of their old form.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'll try to remain silent for most of the rest of this year. It depends on how provoked I get.'' - Pierre Elliott Trudeau. (4:2.)

title: NEW BID TO CURB DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: Encouraged by Congressional passage last week of legislation aimed at forcing states to adhere to a minimum drinking age of 21, crusaders against drunken driving say they will immediately begin to press state officials for tougher laws.

title: FEMALE LAWYERS WEIGH 'GAME PLAN'
description: Although spokesmen for the state's major law firms say they are hiring female lawyers in record numbers, few have more than one or two as partners.

title: TRUDEAU ERA ENDS
description: John N. Turner was sworn in today as the 17th Prime Minister of Canada in a private ceremony that ended a 16-year-long political era dominated by Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: Bird Declines
description: Indiana State University's most famous alumnus, Larry Bird , says he does not want the university to rename the Hulman Civic University Center in his honor. In a letter to the editor published in The Terre Haute Tribune-Star today, the Boston Celtic star asked that the center maintain its original name because ''I respect the Hulman family and know that had it not been for their initial commitment, we probably would still not have a facility like this in Terre Haute.

title: ILLNESS NO BARRIER TO OARSMAN
description: Bob Reininger, a Coast Guard lieutenant who was informed in November 1982 that he had lymphatic cancer, moved one race closer to a ''lifelong dream'' today. His boat, the Penn Athletic Club's No. 2 entry, produced the fastest time in qualifying for the fours with coxswain final in the Olympic rowing trials.

title: GENERALS ELIMINATED BY STARS, 28-7
description: The Philadelphia Stars caught up with the New Jersey Generals today at the right time, in a playoff game, and thrashed them, 28-7.

title:
GARDENING ;
THE EFFICIENT VEGETABLE-GROWER
description: ONE of the advantages of the various approaches to intensive vegetable gardening, such as the ''square- foot'' method, is the potential for producing a significant quantity of produce in a relatively small space. To obtain maximum productivity, however, one must keep every bed of space filled during the growing season. As soon as one crop has been harvested, another should be ready to take its place.

title: WHERE TO TURN FOR ASSISTANCE IF PROBLEMS DEVELOP
description: Following is a summary of the consumer protections and remedies in the metropolitan area that are available to a new owner if problems develop with a new house or apartment and the builder will not make repairs:

title: AT WEEKEND GATHERINGS, MARINATED FISH,, CHICKEN, OR MEAT
description: VERY often the most enjoyable meals are unplanned. This is frequently the case in the country over a weekend. After tennis, swimming or a cocktail party, the guest list for lunch or dinner can suddenly swell, without leaving much time to prepare the food.

ART;
'STREET PAINTERS' OF NEW YORK IN SUMMIT
description: SUMMIT '' STREET PAINTERS,'' a floor-to-ceiling spectacle on view at the Summit Art Center through July 29, contains the work of seven artists who have banded together since 1977.

title: GUATEMALA PICKS ASSEMBLY TODAY
description: An 88- member Constituent Assembly is to be elected Sunday in what the nation's military leaders say is a step toward democracy. But many citizens appear skeptical that the regime is taking the first step toward permitting civilians to come to power.

title: HEADLINERS
description: No Such Place Some of the folks in Wasco County, Ore., apparently just don't cotton to gurus, at least not when followers of same want to set up their own local government. Adherents of an Indian guru, Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh , who have battled area natives for several years in an attempt to incorporate their own city in Wasco County, lost the latest round last week.

title: ROADBLOCKS PART OF HOLIDAY STRATEGY
description: S TATE police throughout Connecticut began setting up roadblocks Friday evening as part of a statewide effort to limit traffic accidents this holiday weekend. Troopers from the state's 12 barracks will man the roadblocks near entrance ramps at interstate highways until midnight on Wednesday, said Lieut. Kenneth Kirschner, a public information officer for the state police.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
SURPRLUS BUDGET AN OPPORTUNITY TO AID SCHOOLS
description: THE WINDFALL budget surplus announced recently by Governor Kean was good news. The state's diverse economy is moving forward, and its revenue flow now offers some freedom of choice to meet public needs and aspirations, as well as obligations.

title: 'GROCERS' DISPUTES' STILL IMPENDING EUROPEAN COOPERATION
description: About 10 minutes after the European Common Market countries resolved their five-year-old budget dispute last week, the where-do-we-go-from-here and what-have-you-done-for-us lately questions began again. They had a special undertone: With Europe seemingly rid of its budget millstone, the questions suggested there were no more excuses for failing to move toward political unity and the kind of cooperation that would involve citizens, rather than governments, in creating European integration.

title: FASHION

description: No one is ''more deserving'' than Ronald Reagan of becoming the fifth President to have his likeness chiseled on Mount Rushmore, says Frank Fahrenkopf Jr., the chairman of the Republican Party.

title: OPENING THE BOOKS ON CENSORSHIP
description: By suggesting that indifference to poetry and what Herbert Marcuse called ''repressive tolerance'' are in any way equivalent to censorship, Richard Bernstein adds to the semantic confusion which surrounds the word. He also cheapens the suffering which many writers, editors and publishers have undergone in imprisonment, banishment and even death in other countries. Such punishments should not be compared to the mental anguish, however real, suffered by those who can publish their thoughts at any time, and are faced with nothing more than indifference or ridicule.

title: Dutch Hold a Zambian Envoy
description: A 40- year-old Zambian diplomat, J. B. Chiwende, was arrested and accused of drug smuggling at Schiphol airport Wednesday night after 13 kilograms of heroin were found in his luggage, the Dutch state police said. Mr. Chiwende, who is second secretary in the Zambian High Commission in Kenya but lacks diplomatic immunity here because he is not accredited to the Netherlands, denied any knowledge of the heroin, according to a spokesman for the police.

description: ''A guy should be able to make a living working hard at what he knows best, shouldn't he?'' Jim Riordan said a year ago in Boone, Iowa. What he knew best was farming, and to survive at it, he was leading two lives.

title: RESEARCH PROVIDES A SOLUTION TO THE LOUD-SOFT DEBATE
description: How loud or how soft a record should sound has long been a matter of lively debate. But with the advent of CD's - the laser-scanned Compact Disks - the debate has become heated and acerbic. The reason is that the CD makes it possible to render the whole dynamic range of music, from the loudest to the softest sounds, in their natural proportion.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
HOW CAN WE PAY FOR HEALTH CARE FOR THE POOR?
description: HOSPITALS and the poor are not new acquaintances. Students of hospital history know that the first hospitals primarily were places for poor people to die. People of means did not go to hospitals, since there was little that could be done for patients except to provide basic sustenance and comfort. The charitable origins of hospitals reflected the concern, especially of religious groups, to provide shelter for the disadvantaged of our society.

title: CONGRESS TAKES ON SMALL STEP ON DEFICITS

This un-American attitude may derive in part from my failure to emerge a winner in any such event, but I also believe that sport fishing's greatest reward is the relief it affords from the hurly-burly of the workaday world. Why blur its magic with the tension of the marketplace?

description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Wendy Carol Weiler, vice president- marketing for TempsAmerica Inc., an employment service in New York, was married to Donald Ellsworth Chappell, vice president and portfolio manager of Sheldon Clark & Staniford Inc. in New York. title: STUFFED MUSHROOMS
description: WE ARE OFTEN asked about how a food column originates. Do you, some wonder, spend time each week plotting what will appear the following one? No. What appears here is, for the most part, spontaneous. If, for example, one of us sees an item in a store that seems particularly toothsome, we make a mental note of it. Pierre telephones me at 8:45 A.M. each working day, and one or the other of us says, ''The mushrooms (or the cauliflower or the ducks or the salmon or whatever) look especially good.'' Over the phone, we detail a shopping list, foods we instinctively know will be compatible with the main ingredient. Within minutes of Pierre's arrival with the foodstuffs, he is at the stove and I am at a typewriter perched on an island in the kitchen. And then the improvisation starts. There is no longer any such thing as a consummately original, shake-the-foundations recipe. That is not to say new recipes are not developed. It is to say that the foundations of cookery have all been laid down and what the most creative among us do is to make variations of something that has gone before. When we start, we decide the form the food will take. As the day progresses, we make the choice for the major basic ingredient, the ground meat for a meat loaf, say. Then we decide on flavors. Perhaps a bit of marjoram. And we proceed from there with the bread crumbs, beaten egg and so on.
