description: Richard Margolis is a columnist for The New Leader. ALTERNATIVES

title: TEMPLE STUNS YALE AT HENLEY
description: -ON-THAMES, England, June 30 - In what Coach Gavin R.White of Temple described as a ''great victory for a blue-collar university over the Ivy League,'' the Owls' heavyweight crew defeated Yale's varsity lightweight eight today at the 135th Henley Royal Regatta.

title: ABOUT CARS ; A LINCOLN BECKONS AGAIN
description: My taste in cars has always been a bit eclectic, which is to say that I've driven some pretty funny vehicles from time to time.

title: WHERE IS HOLDEN CAULFIELD NOW?
description: To the Editor:

title: RISING RATES MAKE THE BANKS JITTERY
description: Usually when the prime rate is raised, as it was last week, there is at least quiet joy within the banking community. For bankers, a rise in the prime rate is very much like a hike in the price of steel for steel producers.

title: IS ANY WOMAN NO. 1 ON THE LIST FOR NO. 2
description: When Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro joins Walter F. Mondale's parade of prospective Democratic Vice Presidential nominees tomorrow, she will no doubt be able to offer an array of reasons why she should be his choice.

title: Margaret Boles Is Boston Bride
description: Margaret Borden Boles, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Russell Sage Boles Jr. of Osterville, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Patrick Fitzgerald, a son of the late Maurice Francis Fitzgerald of Waterville, Quebec, and the late Nancy Nutter Fitzgerald Smith of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Richard Holloway performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston, Mass.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: T HE prospect of New Jersey losing nearly a fifth of its natural-plant species has begun to move officials of the state's Department of Environmental Protection and the Pinelands Commission.

title: SEWANEE
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME IS RUNNING OUT AT MCKINNON'S C.A.B.
description: THE end of the line is near for the

title: Tour Starts For Women
description: Another Tour de France race, the first for women, began today with Mieke Havik of the Netherlands earning a footnote to bicycling history by winning the sprint finish.

title: SALVADOR SAYS IT HAS SUSPECT IN PLOT TO KILL ENVOY
description: El Salvador's highest-ranking police official said this week that ''an individual'' was under preliminary investigation here for plotting to assassinate the United States Ambassador.

title: WHERE IS HOLDEN CAULFIELD NOW?
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD TOTAL TO AID 51 ARTS GROUPS
description: IN galleries, theaters, studios

title: A POOR 2D QUARTER FOR STOCKS
description: Stock prices on most major foreign exchanges followed the downward path of American equities in the second quarter.

title: MONDAY, JULY 2, 1984 International
description: Moscow rejected a U.S. offer to join in talks on banning weapons in outer space, proposed by Moscow this weekend, if other subjects were discussed as well. Soviet leaders said the United States response was ''totally unsatisfactory,'' but the offer to open negotiations in September to prevent ''the militarization of outer space'' remained open. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow's rejection was regretted by the Reagan Administration, but it restated its willingness '' to sit down with the Soviets at a meeting in September as the Soviets have proposed.'' The Administration said Moscow had misread the intention of its statement Friday. (A1:6.)

title: BRIEFS;  Debt Issues ;  Common Stock
description: Pacific Gas and Electric Co. has filed for $250 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds, series B4B, due 1994, through Morgan Stanley. Audio/Video Affiliates Inc. has filed an amended statement for its offering of 1.4 million shares.

title: MANAGUA TRIES ABSENT REBEL CHIEFS
description: The Government has placed 27 leaders of the United States-backed insurgent movement on trial in absentia, according to Government officials and lawyers involved in the proceedings.

title: Poll Shows Hunt Leads In Carolina Senate Race
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., the Democratic candidate, has a slight edge over Senator Jesse Helms, the Republican nominee in North Carolina's United States Senate race, according to a poll published today by The Charlotte Observer.

title: 9TH FOR DARLING
description: Neither rain nor fog nor gloom of night kept the Mets from playing yesterday, or from breaking their four- game losing streak, which they did by sweeping a doubleheader from the Atlanta Braves by 2-1 and 3-2.

title: CONCERT: TANGLEWOOD OPENS WITH BEETHOVEN
description: Tanglewood, perhaps the most regal and sumptuous of America's outdoor summer music festivals, formally opened its 1984 season this afternoon with music by Beethoven. Rudolf Serkin, who is in the process of recording the Beethoven concerto literature with the Tanglewood's resident orchestra, the Boston Symphony, was the pianist. Seiji Ozawa conducted the orchestra.

title: GILLESPIE LEADS JAM SESSION
description: DIZZY GILLESPIE and the cohorts he brought to the jazz festival's all-star jam session at Carnegie Hall on Friday are such seasoned, savvy improvisers that they can delight a crowd with tried-and-true phrases, clever quips and sheer stage presence. But on Friday, there was a special electricity in the air when Mr. Gillespie, the alto saxophonist Benny Carter, and the trombonist J. J. Johnson, the session's featured soloists, emerged from the wings. The musicians ignited the audience by aiming to impress the most demanding listeners of all - the musicians with whom they shared the stage.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Brands Inc. has elected Thomas C. Hays a vice president and promoted Charles H. Mullen to senior vice president-sales of its American Tobacco Co. division.

title: MARKET WINNERS AND LOSERS
description: Takeover fever moved many of the big gainers, and financial woes plagued most of the top losers in an otherwise weak second quarter on the nation's three major stock exchanges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Satirical Notes From the Underground

title: Reagan's Schools Policy Attacked by Union Head
description: The president of the nation's largest teachers' union said today that low teacher salaries were a ''disgrace.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Soggy Craftsmen Endure Foul Days for a Fair

title: Bridge: American Contract League Gets a New Executive Chief
description: In half a century, the American Contract Bridge League has had four professional heads: William McKenney, Alvin Landy, Easley Blackwood and Richard Goldberg. They have all been fine administrators and highly knowledgeable about the game.

title: Newark Suspends Head of Schools
description: The Newark Board of Education has suspended its Executive Superintendent of Schools for ''a series of actions that he has taken in direct violation of board policies and procedures,'' according to Charles A. Bell, a board member.

title: DIXON'S BID FAILS IN 10,000 RUN HERE
description: During the rain-drenched New York City Marathon last year, New Zealand's Rod Dixon staged one of the annual race's most stunning finishes. After trailing throughout, he called on a reserve that most people thought had been exhausted and surged past Geoff Smith with less than 370 yards to go and won.

title: MIGRANT WORKERS ORGANIZE A BOYCOTT OF CAMPBELL
description: In upstairs rooms in an old building in the Hispanic section of town, festooned with posters and slogans that smack of the radical 1960's or even of an earlier unionism, labor activists are conducting a spirited fight against the Campbell Soup Company.

title: WRITER IN LIBEL SUIT FACES JAIL ON ARTICLE'S SOURCES
description: Richard Hargraves, a 34-year-old newspaper editorial writer in St. Louis, is due to find out early this week whether he must go to jail rather than disclose the identities of his sources for an editorial that criticized an elected county official.

title: NORMAN WINS BY 2
description: Greg Norman made up four shots on the front side and went on to beat Jack Nicklaus by two strokes today for the Canadian Open championship.

title: DIRECTORS BOARD REJECTS CONTRACT OFFER
description: The National Board of Directors of the Directors Guild of America voted unanimously this afternoon to recommend that the final contract offer by the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers be rejected. Negotiations had broken off at 5 this morning as prospects of a strike by Hollywood's 7,300 directors and production managers grew.

title: 'CAGNEY & LACEY,' POLICE SERIES ON CBS
description: ONE of the more unusual television stories of the past few seasons has swirled around ''Cagney & Lacey,'' the series that currently can be seen on CBS at 10 P.M. on Mondays. The show lost one of its original leads when, according to assorted reports, the actress playing Christine Cagney wasn't ''feminine'' enough to suit audience researchers. Then the series was actually canceled.

title: FOR DAVE WINFIELD, HIS HOTTEST DAYS OF SUMMER
description: In the second inning, Dan Petry threw

title: THE GREAT CANDY CAPER LEAVES ALL JAPAN ATWITTER
description: Over the weekend, supermarkets put back candies and other sweets that they had removed from their shelves six weeks ago. That event, small though it was, may have signaled the end to one of the stranger crime sprees in Japan's postwar history.

title: McCann Deal in Spain
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide, which is already a presence in Spain, announces that it has acquired Clarin Publicidad e Iniciativas, billing about $28 million in offices in Madrid, Barcelona and Valencia. It will continue to operate under its old name and service Coca-Cola and Nestle, clients it shares with its new parent. McCann is one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Philippine Communist Gets Ordeal Softened
description: The Supreme Court today ordered the reputed leader of the Communist Party of the Philippines removed from the solitary confinement he has endured for more than six years, calling it ''cruel and unusual'' punishment.

title: Ramsey Traded
description: The St. Louis Cardinals today traded the veteran utility infielder Mike Ramsey to to the Montreal Expos for the shortstop Chris Speier. In addition, the Cards demoted the right-hander John Stuper to Louisville of the American Association.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SENATOR MOYNIHAN'S REPORT
description: Following are excerpts from a study of the relationship between the Federal Government and New York State conducted by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan:

title: SIBLINGS WHO HELP DISABLED
description: ''I MAY have passed up marriage a

title: A FAIR HYDROPOWER SHARE FOR DOWNSTATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cronin of Ireland Buys New York Shop
description: Stand back, Saatchi & Saatchi of London. Here comes Brian Cronin Associates of Dublin to do a little acquiring of its own.

title: Express Is Groggy Survivor
description: After the longest game in professional football history Saturday, the Los Angeles Express players limped off the field with a 27-21 victory in overtime against the Michigan Panthers.

title: 'WHEN IT'S YOUR GUY'
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Warner-Tramiel Talks On Atari Sale Reported
description: Warner Communications Inc. is negotiating to sell much of its Atari subsidiary to Jack Tramiel, a computer entrepeneur, according to a newspaper report.

title: KOCH, ON TV, CRITICIZES JACKSON
description: Mayor Koch yesterday likened Louis Farrakhan to a Nazi leader and said he was not satisfied with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's disavowal of the statements by the leader of a Black Muslim sect.

title: Sears Changes Logo
description: The new Sears, Roebuck & Company logotype, its third in 98 years, made its first appearance yesterday in retail advertising.

title: Professor Says Economy Will Not Aid Democrats
description: The economist Lester Thurow said today that he did not think the Democrats would be able to use the economy as a campaign issue against President Reagan this year.

title: ARAFAT SAYS P.L.O. RIFTS ARE HEALED
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, says that the guerrilla movement has overcome rifts in its ranks and is again a force to be reckoned with.

title: NEW ERA BEGINS IN THE SEARCH FOR INTELLIGENT LIFE IN SPACE
description: The search for intelligent life elsewhere in the universe, a quest that began 25 years ago, is about to enter a new era.

title: LUCILLE CAPRA
description: Lucille (Lu) Capra, wife of the retired Hollywood film director and producer Frank Capra, died yesterday in a La Quinta, Calif., hospital.

title: YOUNG CANCER PATIENTS SHARE EXPERIENCES
description: ''Did you ever doubt that you would get better?'' How much of the chemotherapy do you remember?'' ''Was it hard to have spinal taps and bone marrow aspirations when the chemotherapy ended?'' ''Did you prefer that people know you had cancer or did you choose not to talk about it?'' ''Did you have problems in school?'' ''Are there residual effects from the medicine?'' ''Do you feel different from other kids?''

title: No Headline
description: Eddie Murray and Wayne Gross hit home runs, and Mike Young got a key triple as the Baltimore Orioles scored an 8-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

title: ; NEW IDEAS ARE DOING OLD ENGLISH PUBS IN
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. IN 4-WAY TIE
description: The United States, Australia, Britain and Sweden ended the second day of the Liberty Cup regatta yesterday in a tie with 7-1 records.

title: MRS. LLOYD IS RECONCILING ROLE OF NO. 2
description: Chris Evert Lloyd purses her lips and furrows her brow with determined concentration. She is sitting in the nearly deserted players' tea room, with dusk settling on the manicured lawns of the All England Lawn Tennis Club and the first week of Wimbledon play drawing to a close. A testing fourth-round match awaits her on Monday, against West Germany's Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, but for now Mrs. Lloyd is considering, with characteristic honesty and thoroughness, the troubling juncture she has reached in a distinguished career.

title: New Kodak Film
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will introduce an improved Kodacolor VR disk film called ''Generation 3.''

title: 8-Year-Old Charged In Slaying of Officer
description: An 8-year-old was charged Friday in the shooting death of an off-duty policeman who shared an apartment with the boy and his mother. A police spokesman said the child was apparently upset because the officer was going to leave them.

title: JACKSON LEADS A MARCH INTO MEXICO
description: A crowd of about 2,000 people joined the Rev. Jesse Jackson today for a march across the Mexican border to demonstrate in favor of making the Western Hemisphere a ''war-free'' zone.

title: OUTDOORS: WHEN THE HUNT IN A TOURNAMENT IS FOR SHARK
description: BAY SHORE,L.I.

title: DOMINICANS, YIELDING TO I.M.F., PLAN TO RAISE GASOLINE PRICE
description: The Government has decided to increase the price of gasoline after months of resisting demands that it do so from the International Monetary Fund, officials here say.

title: Liechtenstein Women Win Right to Vote
description: In a referendum today, the men of this constitutional monarchy narrowly granted women the right to vote.

title: MONDALE'S BEST CO-PILOT
description: It is now generally agreed that Walter F. Mondale does not have a chance. The politicians say it, the public opinion polls confirm it and the public's gut reaction supports it. There is nothing on the horizon to indicate a dramatic swing of support to Mr. Mondale.

title: RAINS AT KENNEDY STRAND THOUSANDS
description: Thousands of weary and frustrated travelers were stranded at Kennedy International Airport yesterday as New Yorkers pumped out from a weekend deluge that dropped four to seven inches of rain on the metropolitan area.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FESTIVAL This is the festival season for music, a season of wrap-ups, usually hardy perennials that flower in the hot weather, wafting cool airs that flow more erratically at other times over sweltering audiences.

title: The U.N. Today July 2, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. SWIM TEAM IS STRONGEST EVER
description: Rowdy Gaines, its senior citizen, had no doubts.

title: THE DIRTY DOZEN FROM NEW ORLEANS
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival's annual boatride on the Hudson was scheduled to be a bit different this year: Instead of the Dixieland bands and old New Orleans traditional bands that usually play on the ride, there would be a blues band for the first time and a young New Orleans band that does unexpected things with the New Orleans traditions.

title: Madiot of France Wins Tour Stage
description: Marc Madiot of France won the 155-mile second leg of the Tour de France cycling race today, and Jacques Hanegraaf of the Netherlands moved into the overall lead.

title: Topics Giving Directions
description: El Camino Real

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Judge Sees No Harm In Sharing a Good Name

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Party leaders are no longer prophets. They are all managers, and your reaction to a manager is different to that of a prophet.''

title: STRIKE BY NURSES APPEARS SETTLED
description: Negotiators for nurses who have been on strike for a month reached tentative agreements in two sets of talks today.

title: PALMER LOSES BY 2 TO BARBER IN OPEN
description: Miller Barber, who recommends that no one swing a golf club the way he does, withstood the pressures of Arnold Palmer and his Army today and won the fifth annual United States Senior Open by two shots in an exciting two- man duel over the Oak Hill Country Club West Course.

title: State to Start Issuing Photo Driver Licenses
description: New York State today joins the other 49 states in requiring drivers to carry licenses showing their photographs.

title: ROYAL PREROGATIVE (1)
description: A Supreme Court decision written in dry lawyers' language may nevertheless, on rare occasions, signal a transforming change in the Court's view of the American system. That happened last week in a case called

title: SACRIFICES OF MANY YIELD TWO UNTRADITIONAL PLAYS
description: The easiest way to tell ''Balm in Gilead'' is 20 years old is by the crowd onstage at the Circle Repertory. These days, the playwright who creates a 29-character play, as Lanford Wilson did in ''Balm,'' is usually condemning it to death. Rare is the theater that can afford to pay such an ensemble.

title: Jillian Richman Marries G. Eduardo Silva Dreyer
description: Jillian Henree Richman, a daughter of Irene Briller Mayer of Los Angeles and the late Joseph Richman, was married yesterday to G. Eduardo Silva Dreyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ismael Silva Fuenzalida of Caracas, Venezuela. Judge Lawrence Rubin of the Santa Monica, Calif., Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the Los Angeles home of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Mayer, the mother and adoptive father of the bride.

title: GENERAL PROMISES TO PUNISH SIKH MUTINEERS
description: The chief of staff of the Indian Army, Gen. A. S. Vaidya, said today that Sikh soldiers who mutinied and deserted to protest the army siege last month of the Golden Temple, Sikhdom's holiest shrine, would be severely punished.

title: Futures/Options; Credit Risk And Ways Of Hedging
description: ECONOMISTS may debate whether interest rates will rise or fall, but professional traders of financial futures are far more concerned with the risks being assumed by today's lenders, rather than what they charge borrowers.

title: TREASURY SALES DOMINATE SCHEDULE
description: The Treasury's note and bond financings dominate the credit markets' week, which will be shortened by the Fourth of July Holiday on Wednesday. Tomorrow, the Treasury will auction $5.5 billion in seven-year notes, followed on Thursday by a $4 billion auction of 20-year bonds.

title: REAGAN'S AIR, WATER POLICY: FOUL
description: President Reagan claims ''great progress in cleaning up the air and water.'' Since when is failure to lead ''great progress''?

title: WOMEN MAY FIGHT FOR TICKET SPOT, NOW'S LEADER SAYS
description: Judy Goldsmith, president of the National Organization for Women, said today there would probably be a floor fight at the Democratic National Convention if Walter F. Mondale failed to choose a woman as his running mate.

title: No Headline
description: Quaalude Restriction Gets Reagan Signature

title: JacquelineW ed To
description: Jacqueline M. Laks, an editor for the Macmillan Educational Company in Manhattan, and David J. Gorman 3d, a doctoral candidate in comparative literature at Columbia University, were married yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu- El in New York.

title: Grants Awarded to 8 Dance Troupes
description: The National Choreography Project has awarded $250,000 to eight repertory dance companies to support collaborations with eight choreographers, in grants ranging from $10,000 to $50,000. The winners are: the Boston Ballet, for a collaboration with Elisa Monte; Chicago Repertory Dance Ensemble, Ze'Eva Cohen; Dance Theater of Harlem, David Gordon; Jose Limon Dance Company, Heinz Poll; Louisville Ballet, Lynne Taylor-Corbett; North Carolina Dance Theater, Nina Wiener; Oakland Ballet Company, Tandy Beal; Pennsylvania Ballet, Merce Cunningham.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 2, 1984: MONDAY Carolina FreightNevada Power TUESDAY None reported

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With the bases loaded and none out, the batter lines to the right fielder, who makes an outstanding catch, then throws the ball to the shortstop covering second base to double the runner there. The shortstop fires to first base before that runner can retreat, completing a triple play. Meanwhile, the runner from third has crossed the plate. Does the run count?

title: U.S. VOICES REGRET AT SOVIET POSITION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it regretted the apparent negative Soviet response to its offer to discuss all aspects of arms control, including limits on space weapons.

title: French See Slow Growth
description: The rate of growth of the French economy is likely to slow to 1.2 percent next year from a 1.6 percent rise in 1984, a private forecasting organization said Friday. The Institute of Economic and Financial Forecasting for Corporate Development said French growth will continue to trail that of its main trading partners - West Germany, the United States, Britain and Japan.

title: OLYMPIAN RALLY TOPS N.B.A. TEAM
description: The professionals, taking time from their summer of leisure, seemed to be having a good time. A practice of sorts had been held, but the complete team of National Basketball Association players had not gathered on the court until the warmup period this morning before the game against the United States Men's Olympic team.

title: DE FRANCO AND GIBBS
description: THE use of two jazz clubs, Fat Tuesday's and the Blue Note as adjuncts to the Kool Jazz Festival has given the festival an added dimension, enabling groups that do not appear frequently in New York and are not part of the festival's regular programming to be heard during the festival.

title: DEVELOPMENT CREW IS UPSET
description: A group of self-styled ''rejects'' representing the Penn Athletic Club and the Vesper Boat Club upset the Men's Training Camp four with coxswain crew today to highlight the United States Olympic rowing team qualifying finals.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Rangers, at Texas, 8:35 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) White Sox vs. Detroit Tigers, at Chicago. In case of rain, the backup game will be the Chicago Cubs- Padres in San Diego. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.)

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.76

title: BAHRAIN, ARAB FUN SPOT, FEARS SAUDI CRACKDOWN
description: The new moon was sighted over the Persian Gulf over the weekend, signaling the end of Ramadan, the Moslem month of fasting and prayer.

title: OF HOMOSEXUALS, RELIGIOUS BODIES AND SOCIAL JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Barbara Saidel a Bride

title: A Correction
description: An answer to a golf question June 11 involving a ball being knocked into the hole by an opponent's ball on the putting green was partly incorrect. According to the United States Golf Association, the player is required to replace his ball at its original position and the opponent must play his ball from its new position. In match play, there is no penalty to either player; in medal play, the opponent is penalized 2 strokes.

title: No Headline
description: Trivializing the Right to Travel The Reagan Administration's Supreme Court victory in the Cuban travel case was narrow in every sense. The margin was 5 to 4. It turned on the most technical reading imaginable of a law meant to limit Presidential power and expand citizen rights. And the ruling, nominally in support of efforts to isolate Fidel Castro, isolates Americans instead.

title: JORGE DALTO GIVES RECITAL ON PIANO
description: THERE was relatively little of anything that might be considered jazz in the one-hour solo piano recital that Jorge Dalto gave at Carnegie Recital Hall late Friday aftenoon even though it was part of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: Chase Completes Lincoln Purchase
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, completing its $308 million purchase of Lincoln First Banks Inc. of Rochester, became operator of the largest bank branch network in New York.

title: SOUTHEAST INTERSTATE BANK TIE
description: Sun Banks Inc. of Orlando, Fla., and the Trust Company of Georgia, based in Atlanta, will announce the Southeast's first regional interstate bank merger at a news conference Monday morning, according to a report published in today's issue of The Miami Herald.

title: STUDY URGES 5% INCREASE IN PAY FOR CITY WORKERS
description: A civic group said yesterday that the wage increases New York City is negotiating with its unions should not exceed 5 percent a year.

title: MOYNIHAN SAYS NEW YORK'S ECONOMY IS SHORTCHANGED ON DEFENSE WORK
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, in his annual stock-taking of the relationship between the Federal Government and New York State, said yesterday that the state's economy has been shortchanged by shifts in Reagan Administration military spending.

title: 'NIGHT OF PERCUSSION' AT IRVING PLAZA
description: fashioned showing off made for a razzle-dazzle concert Friday at Irving Plaza's ''Night of Percussion.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Equimark's Chief In Chairman's Post
description: William E. Bierer has resigned as chairman of the boards of the Pittsburgh-based Equimark Corporation and its subsidiary, Equibank, the eighth-largest bank in Pennsylvania. James D. Lowry, who joined the company in May as president and chief executive officer, will add the chairman's title.

title: KANSAS IS OFFERING AMNESTY TO TAK CHEATERS FOR 3 MONTHS
description: A three-month amnesty offer will give Kansas tax cheaters their first chance to pay up without being exposed to heavy penalties.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME?
description: When Claudio Gentile, the star defender of Italy's World Cup soccer champions, recently played in the United States, it was noted here that his name in Italian means ''kind, nice, soft,'' but that his tactics were anything but kind, nice, soft. Ralph Slovenko, a professor at Wayne State University in Detroit, noted that ''gentile'' also means ''heathen, foreigner, non-Jewish, Christian,'' in Italian.

title: Washington Watch; Broker Funds Still at Issue
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH a surprise court decision late last month was a severe setback to moves by Federal banking regulators to restrict the use of brokered funds by banks and thrift institutions, the effort is by no means over.

title: AT 75, THE BRONX'S GRAND CONCOURSE TRIES TO BE GRAND ONCE AGAIN
description: Her husband died four years ago, and most of their original neighbors have long since moved to Riverdale, Co-op City or the suburbs. But at age 72, Theresa Lato, who says she never considered joining the exodus, is still living in her apartment on the Grand Concourse, the boulevard that was once widely proclaimed as the Champs- Elysees of the Bronx. It was about 20 years ago that Mrs. Lato became alarmed at how badly the garden beside her six-story, brick, palazzo-style building - the Majestic Court - had deteriorated. ''I mentioned it to Ray, the elevator operator,'' she said. ''He said, 'Oh, they ought to pave it all in.' That shocked me - this dismissal of a once-beautiful garden.''

title: Tonga's Team
description: The Olympic awards orchestra would do well to practice the national anthems of some of the world's smaller countries before the Games begin July 28 in Los Angeles. An example is the anthem of Tonga, a nation of 107,000 in the South Pacific.

title: David H. Appel, 74, Is Dead; An Author and Former Editor
description: David H. Appel, a former features and book editor of The Philadephia Inquirer and the author of several children's books, died of a heart attack yesterday in Philadelphia. He was 74 years old and a Philadelphia resident.

title: Argentina and British Banks
description: Bad-debt provisions by British banks, which have lent some 1.7 billion pounds to Argentina, could have a marked impact on profits for the first half of the year, according to a study by the stockbroker W. Greenwell. Translated at a current exchange rate of $1.35 to the pound, the Argentine loans amount to about $1.25 billion.

title: No Headline
description: The Worm in a Greening Apple In the fiscal year that started yesterday, New York City will be spending $500 million to shore up decaying roads, bridges and tunnels, more than five times what it spent in 1975. But the planning for these huge disruptions of traffic has been appalling, and the emergency relief measures are pitiful.

title: Cassette Tax Approved By French Assembly
description: The French National Assembly Friday approved a bill under which blank cassettes would be taxed to compensate performing artists and producers whose work is copied from radio, television or phonograph records.

title: SLEW O'GOLD TO MAKE '84 DEBUT TODAY
description: Slew o'Gold, last year's champion 3-year-old, is scheduled to make his belated 1984 debut today in the first race at Belmont Park. His handlers are not just being sportsmanlike when they say it doesn't matter whether he wins or loses.

title: Dr. Joseph Zuckerman Is Wed to Miss Rivkin
description: The marriage of Janet E. Rivkin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Rivkin of Hewlett, L.I., to Dr. Joseph D. Zuckerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Zuckerman of Hicksville, L.I., took place yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Chaim Etrog performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET CONDEMNS U.S. REPLY TO BID ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: The Soviet Union today rejected as ''totally unsatisfactory'' a statement by the United States that it was willing to join Moscow in talks on banning weapons in outer space but wanted to discuss other subjects as well.

title: AFTER ONE FINAL BATTLE, LEGISLATURE GOES HOME
description: The State Legislature went home for the summer early this morning after voting to allow Suffolk County to raise its sales tax by one quarter of a percentage point - an issue that sparked a clash on the Assembly floor and divided lawmakers from different parts of the county.

title: Three Inmates Escape From Tennessee Prison
description: Three state prison inmates jimmied the locks on their cell doors in a medium-security unit and escaped by scaling two fences in dense fog early today, the Correction Department said.

title: TEXAS COUPLE FIGHT IN COURTS TO AVOID TESTIFYING ON SON
description: The parents of a teen-age murder defendant are trying to set a legal precedent to keep from testifying against their son.

title: ;  President Is Selected By U.A. Cablesystems
description: The United Artists Cablesystems Corporation said that Marvin Jones, a senior vice president in charge of cable operations, will replace Robert M. Rosencrans as president of the company.

title: Topics Giving Directions Cardinal Virtue Just after Father's Day, a Brooklyn birdwatcher began training her binoculars on some incessant fussing in the backyard, where a father cardinal was supervising the in-flight training of two chicks. The father spent hour after hour overseeing the timid, awkward hop- flights. He was ready to assist when they teetered on their perches, steadily encouraging the gawky gray youngsters to higher ground, a higher fence, a higher branch. He rewarded each reluctant flyup with food, moving from one chick to the other, as they wobbled and trembled in fear.
description: A little book work confirmed that cardinals practice co-parenting, mother and father sharing in the upbringing of as many as four broods each summer.

title: HIC
description: Some have suggested that Congress's decision to raise the minimum drinking age to 21 is a timid measure - that the lawmakers haven't aimed high enough or far enough. Whimsically and wistfully, the critics have advocated a minimum drinking age of 37. Or 38. Or 40.

title: MISS BURR WINS SHOW JUMP TRIALS
description: Leslie Burr of Westport, Conn., won the final United States Olympic show jumping trials aboard Albany today in the Almaden Vineyards Grand Prix, the closing event of the 15th annual Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: Work Begins to Separate Engine From Shuttle
description: Kennedy Space Center workers began today to disconnect the main engine blamed for halting the maiden launch of the Discovery space shuttle.

title: 2 MUMPHREY HOME RUNS LEAD ASTROS TO 13-1 ROUT OF PHILLIES
description: Jerry Mumphrey twice hit home runs and drove in six runs, and Joe Niekro pitched a six-hitter for his sixth consecutive victory today as the Houston Astros trounced the Philadelphia Phillies, 13-1.

title: Rangers Acquire Noles From Cubs
description: The Texas Rangers today acquired the Chicago Cubs' pitcher Dickie Noles for a player to be named or cash, team officials announced.

title: BROWN TRIUMPHS IN FINAL AT HENLEY
description: Norman Hildes-Heim

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JULY 2, 1984

title: OF HOMOSEXUALS, RELIGIOUS BODIES AND SOCIAL JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable TV Trade
description: Storer Communications Inc. and the Times Mirror Company said they had agreed to an exchange of several cable television systems involving 446,300 homes, divided about evenly between the companies.

title: 2 Boys Killed by a Train While Crossing a Trestle
description: A 12-year-old boy carrying a 4-year-old friend across a railroad bridge Saturday tripped and fell as he tried to outrun a train and both boys were killed, the authorities reported.

title: A GRAND YEAR FOR THE PEOPLE WHO MAKE OLD GLORY
description: Come Wednesday, the Fourth of July, the nation will be awash in marching bands, fireworks and lemonade. And flags. Big flags flying from tall steel poles, small flags waving from handheld wooden wands, tiny one-inch flags stuck in cupcakes.

title: Rate Request By Venezuela
description: Venezuela will propose to its creditor banks that its $34 billion foreign debt be rescheduled at fixed interest rates, the country's Planning Minister, Luis Matos Azocar, said today.

title: AUSTERITY IS NEW TO VENEZUELANS
description: Flaunting large cars, imported clothes, expensive liquor and consumer gadgets of all kinds, and protected by the oil earnings of a spendthrift state, Venezuelans have long been viewed as almost caricatures of the new rich of Latin America.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ON THE YANKEE STATION. By William Boyd. 217 pages. William Morrow and Company. $12.95.

title: KENNY BURRELL ON SOLO GUITAR
description: CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL became one of the city's most intimate rooms during last Thursday's solo guitar concert by Kenny Burrell. He approached a set of standards, blues and bossa novas - mostly ballads - as if he were letting the audience share his pleasure in the way one chord led to the next.

title: No New Talks Set In Garbage Strike
description: Members of Local 945 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were expected to set up picket lines in northern and central New Jersey Monday after rejecting a contract offer by 50 trash-hauling firms serving about 200 communities in nine counties.

title: SIMULCASTING VOTED
description: The State Legislature has voted to allow the live broadcast of horse races to Offtrack Betting parlors, theaters and tracks across the state.

title: NASSAU PROSECUTOR TO CLIMB SOVIET PEAK
description: Burton Ryan, an assistant Nassau County district attorney who plans to scale Communism Peak, the highest mountain in the Soviet Union, reaches back 700 years for his inspiration.

title: FRUSTRATIONS OF FORECASTERS
description: Economics, George Meany used to say, is the only profession in which one can rise to eminence without ever being right.

title: NON-GAMBLERS' OPTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Bonner Reported Seen
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and dissident, has been seen buying bread daily in Gorky, indicating that she has called off her hunger strike, Keston College said today.

title: ;  Air Florida Appoints New Financial Officer
description: Air Florida System Inc., the financially troubled Miami airline, has appointed William C. Miesch senior vice president for finance.

title: SOVIET REPLY TO U.S. STAND ON WEAPONS
description: Following is the text of a Government statement issued today in translation by the official press agency, Tass, on the United States response to a Soviet proposal to begin talks on a ban on space weapons:

title: No Headline
description: Elizabeth Philip Weds

title: TRYING TO FIGURE OUT THE FED
description: Investors and traders alike are having a difficult time these days figuring out the exact state of Federal Reserve monetary policy. Many say they are especially baffled by fluctuations in overnight interest rates, which normally provide a good sign of the central bank's intentions.

title: MUSIC: CARAMOOR GROUP
description: The rain finally let up late Saturday afternoon, and so the Caramoor Music Festival opened on drenched ground, but under clearing skies. A small, determined congregation gathered on the lawn of the festival's outdoor Venetian Theater to relax, enjoy the summer evening, and, not so incidentally, watch John Nelson lead the Caramoor Festival Orchestra through music by Mozart, Beethoven and Ellen Taafe Zwillich.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ; ;  Treating the Elite
description: What can baseball and football players learn from skiers? One logical answer to that question might be: How to get rehabilitated after a serious injury.

title: OFFICIALS TEST BEACHES IN NEW YORK REGION FOR HEALTH PERILS
description: Along the Jersey Shore, environmental officials in helicopters are swooping over the ocean waves looking for the rosy tint of the capricious red tide.

title: ART DONORS FACING STRICTER TAX RULES
description: ART collectors who donate their possessions to museums and other nonprofit institutions will face stricter rules when they try to take tax deductions next year, as a result of provisions of the new tax bill approved last week by Congress.

title: IRAQIS SAY JETS SANK FIVE SHIPS, DOWNED A PLANE
description: Iraq said today that its air force had destroyed ''five naval targets'' in the northern Persian Gulf and also shot down an Iranian F-14 jet.

title: REAGAN TO BYPASS UNION LEADERS IN HIS QUEST FOR MEMBERS' VOTES
description: As former Vice President Walter F. Mondale prepares to claim the Democratic Presidential nomination, President Reagan's campaign chieftains are laying plans to chip away the bedrock of Mr. Mondale's political support, the voters who belong to labor unions.

title: FIRST ANNIVERSARY OF COPPER STRIKE IS MARKED BY A NIGHT OF VIOLENCE
description: State police officers in riot gear posted sharpshooters on hills and lined the main highway of this strike-torn copper town today as they cleared away smoldering barricades after a night of violence.

title: TAX SOUGHT ON CASSETTES AND HOME RECORDERS
description: EVER since the Supreme Court ruled last January that home taping of television programs is legal, Hollywood studios, which opposed such taping, have developed an alternate strategy: They now seek a royalty tax on home video recorders and blank cassettes to be added to the retail price.

title: WRANGLERS OVERCOME GAMBLERS
description: George Allen, regarded in some quarters as football's best defensive coach, came up with a grand design to stop Jim Kelly, the Houston quarterback, and the Gamblers' run-and-shoot offense.

title: Raid on a Nebraska Church Held to Be Unconstitutional
description: The police acted unconstitutionally when they dragged worshipers out of a Nebraska church in a dispute over a religious school that did not comply with state law, a Federal court here ruled Friday.

title: No Headline
description: E.P.A. to Halt All Use Of Larvadex Pesticide

title: ;  A Busy Week
description: The Don Owen family of Cleburne, Tex., had a strenuous reunion early last week in Chicago. Owen, a used- car dealer and his wife, Margie, made the trip to watch their sons play baseball - 26-year-old Dave for the Cubs in the daytime at Wrigley Field and 23-year-old Spike at night for the visiting Seattle Mariners at Comiskey Park.

title: Sequel to a Salvador Plot
description: When the far right in El Salvador wants to eliminate a problem, it tends to do just that. One problem has been Thomas Pickering, the American Ambassador, who has spoken out strongly against one instrument of elimination: death squads. So it is wholly plausible that Mr. Pickering was recently marked for removal, especially since he was at pains to distance the United States from Roberto d'Aubuisson, the extreme-right candidate who fortunately lost last month's presidential election.

title: OF HOMOSEXUALS, RELIGIOUS BODIES AND SOCIAL JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sugar Pact Plan Collapses
description: An attempt by sugar consumers and exporters to reach a new price-stabilizing agreement for the depressed sugar market collapsed Friday when three key producers rejected terms of a proposed compromise. Jorge Zorreguieta, the Argentine president of the three-week International Sugar Conference, expressed ''extreme disappointment.''

title: ZORINSKY ON JUKEBOXES: A MIGHTY WURLITZER
description: His colleagues may be specialists on arms control, taxation or energy issues, but Senator Edward Zorinsky has developed an expertise that is novel for Capitol Hill, and far less known.

title: PAY PHONE USERS PUT IN THEIR 2 BITS
description: It may still be a penny for your thoughts, but it is now a quarter for your voice. The cost of a paytelephone call in New York State rose from a dime this weekend, and at city phone booths, callers reacted with surprise, resignation and some disgust to the price increase.

title: BRIEFING
description: Curbing the Ex-Presidents

title: THE IMMIGRATION BILL'S MELTING POT
description: The politics of immigration make strange bedfellows, and nothing better illustrates that fact than the growing relationship between Representative Kent Hance, a conservative Texas Democrat, and Arnoldo S. Torres, executive director of the League of United Latin American Citizens.

title: Carolyn Wise Married To Michael Allan Fox
description: Carolyn Judith Shira Wise, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis W. Wise of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Allan Fox, a son of Mrs. Jerrold B. Feuerman of Denver and Martin S. Fox of Los Angeles. Rabbi William B. Horn performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: Shira Burnstein and Dr. Avram Abramowitz Wed
description: Shira Burnstein, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Melvin Burnstein of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Avram Abramowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Abramowitz of Brooklyn. Rabbi Dr. Benjamin W. Helfgott of the Jewish Center for Wakefield and Edenwald in the Bronx, the bride's grandfather, and the bride's father performed the ceremony at LePerville in Brooklyn, assisted by Cantor Yochanan Burnstein, the bride's brother.

title: Identity Problem
description: Before the game, Jon Koncak, the 7-foot center from Southern Methodist, was introduced as Joe. . . . Vern Fleming of Long Island City had 6 assists, 3 steals, 7 rebounds and 8 points in 17 1/2 minutes. . . . Knight's first technical foul with the Olympic team occurred today, 2 minutes 13 seconds into the second half of the third exhibition game.

title: Christine B. Lalonde Becomes Bride Of Austin Chilton Hearst, Executive
description: Christine B. Lalonde, the sales and marketing vice president of Reeves Teletape, a division of the Reeves Communication Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to Austin Chilton Hearst, assistant director of operations for King Features Entertainment in New York. Town Judge Ralph Mackin of North Salem, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Snow Hill Farm, the North Salem home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Jr., who also have a home in Manhattan.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Clients Added by Chiat, Muller and Deutsch
description: Last week ended with new business announcements from Chiat/Day, Muller Jordan Weiss and David Deutsch Associates.

title: A Vietnamese Discusses The Missing Americans
description: A senior Vietnamese official says continuing United States unfriendliness toward Vietnam after a war that ravaged the civilian population has hurt Hanoi's efforts to get villagers to cooperate in searching for missing Americans.

title: Horse Bolts Near Princess
description: A runaway horse charged through a crowd today, injuring a woman a few yards from the Princess of Wales, who is expecting her second child in September. The Princess, who was 23 today, and her husband, Prince Charles, were watching a polo match in Cirencester in western England.

title: DESPITE FINAL LOSS, TRUMP IS SATISFIED
description: Donald Trump, the man who pays the bills, was satisfied even though his team, the New Jersey Generals, had lost to the Philadelphia Stars in Saturday's playoff game, 28- 7.

title: THE FOREST INDUSTRY IS FORESTS' FRIEND
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.L.U. Calls Curbs by U.S. On Travel Abroad a 'Disgrace'
description: The American Civil Liberties Union asserted in a report today that what it called Government efforts to manipulate the flow of ideas by curbing travel abroad by citizens and denying visas to foreign visitors were a ''national disgrace.''

title: ANNIVERSARY FETE ALSO HONORS FAMILY'S SUCCESS
description: The celebration, a rich rainbow of family, friends and love, was in honor of the 25th wedding anniversary of Dr. Harold C. and Shirlee Haizlip. In a larger sense, it paid tribute to the striving souls of black people.

title: TRIBUTE TO BASIE PERFORMED
description: A TRIBUTE to Count Basie was performed and received with great affection at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening as the climactic concert of this year's Kool Jazz Festival. More than 20 one-time members of Mr. Basie's orchestra, along with three nonmembers who were never admitted to that circle because the piano chair was permamently occupied by Mr. Basie - the pianists Dick Hyman, John Lewis and Hank Jones - took part in a program that touched on important segments of Mr. Basie's career and saluted some of the remarkable musicians who played with him.

title: PURCHASERS CITE SLOWER GROWTH The economy continued to advance in June, but its growth is losing momentum, according to the monthly report released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management.
description: The trade group's survey of 250 purchasing managers showed that those executives who buy materials and services for the nation's largest corporations believe all the economic indicators remain positive, but the days of robust expansion are over.

title: BRITON STARTS A MOSCOW VISIT AND HOPES TO EASE TENSIONS
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, arrived in Moscow today for two days of talks with Soviet leaders.

title: AUTO MAKERS SPUR PUSH FOR NEW TYPE OF STEEL
description: The auto industry is working with the steel industry to produce better steel for auto body panels and other components, and in the process a new line of domestic steel is emerging.

title: Market Place; Still Cautious On Technology
description: JUST one year ago, when technology stocks

title: Metro-North Rider Dies During Arrest
description: An unidentified passenger who refused to pay his fare died yesterday after a scuffle with two police officers aboard a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train in Westchester County, officials said.

title: Dr. Janet Maurer Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Janet Frances Maurer, a daughter of Dr. Anne Estrin Maurer of East Hills, L.I., and the late Dr. Murray L. Maurer, was married yesterday to James Robert Goldstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Solis B. Goldstein of Melrose Park, Pa. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, L.I.

title: DANCE: URBAN BUSH WOMEN TROUPE
description: IT isn't often that a loft dance

title: INSURANCE FOR QUAKE CAN'T WAIT
description: For years Californians have been chided for paying too little attention to the powerful seismic stresses that geologists say are building in the earth beneath them and will inevitably be released in a major earthquake.

title: Jimmie Daniels, Singer, Dies; Performed in New York Clubs
description: Jimmie Daniels, a nightclub singer who participated last week in the Kool Jazz Festival's ''Evening of the Music of Harold Arlen'' at Carnegie Hall, died Friday in St. Clare's Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SOME TURN A DEAF EAR TO MUSLIM LEADER
description: R. SHIPP

title: Delaware Cuts Its Taxes For All Income Brackets
description: A package of legislation to reduce state income taxes was approved early today in the final hours of the 1984 General Assembly.

title: BOLIVIAN COLONEL CALLED LEADER OF PLOT
description: Government authorities said today that a rightist army colonel was believed to have directed the conspiracy that led to the kidnapping Saturday of President Hernan Siles Zuazo.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Six-Day Madness

title: MUSIC: SARAH WALKER GIVES RECITAL
description: THE lovely Garden Court at the Frick Collection is not an ideal setting for a song recital; only the handful who sit round the central fountain have a proper frontal view of the singer. But Sarah Walker, the mezzo-soprano who is in town for performances of Britten's ''Gloriana'' with the English National Opera, gave a recital there Wednesday afternoon that was worth hearing any way one could.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A jury awarded $10.1 million Saturday to a couple whose 11-year-old daughter was killed when a Pan American World Airways jetliner crashed into their home in the second worst air disaster in United States history.

title: Caribbean Nations To Meet July 4
description: Leaders of the English-speaking Caribbean nations are scheduled to meet here July 4 in their first summit meeting since the United States invasion of Grenada.

title: MOVE BY HONDURAS ON REBELS?
description: Honduras has ordered Nicaraguan exiles to shut down their guerrilla command center, a high-ranking military official said today.

title: A SILENT BEGIN CASTS SHADOW ON ISRAELI VOTE
description: Mina Zemach, a well-known Israeli pollster, bumped into her office maid the other morning and could not resist asking her who would get her vote in Israel's approaching election. Without hesitating for a moment the maid responded, ''Begin.''

title: YANKEES LOSE, 8-0, AS ROYALS SWEEP
description: The way the Yankees are playing is so unspirited that Don Baylor said, ''This is exasperating, this is ridiculous,'' and Don Mattingly said, ''The only thing to do now is play for yourself. There are no team goals.''

title: U.S. Steel Layoffs
description: The United States Steel Corporation laid off 700 union workers in June at the Fairless Works in Bucks County and plans to eliminate 150 management jobs by the end of July, according to David Hankins, a company spokesman.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CLOSING SHOP IN ALBANY
description: A collective sigh went forth from here at 1:41 this morning. That was the time when the State Legislature achieved one of its most elusive goals: the end of session.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Chess by Satellite: 1 Faces 10

title: A FRENCH WIDOW SUES OVER SPERM
description: A French widow has gone to court to obtain the sperm deposited in a sperm bank by her husband so that she can try to conceive a child.

title: ANDRETTI WINNER IN PRIX
description: Mario Andretti, who said afterward ''when I get lucky I really get lucky,'' gambled successfully on the weather today and drove away with the first Meadowlands Grand Prix for Indianapolis cars.

title: Advertising; Magazine Start-Ups Stressed
description: HISTORICAL TIMES INC., which six times a year since 1960 has found new things to publish in a magazine about the Civil War, is probably going to begin mining the vast lore of World War II for a new magazine early next year.

title: OLYMPIC FESTIVAL FEATURES THEATER
description: The greatest risk taken by the organizers of the 10-week-long Olympic Arts Festival this summer has, so far, reaped the greatest reward. The festival is loaded with foreign-language theater, despite predictions that such a course would mean commercial disaster.

title: THE INTRICACIES OF BANK ACCOUNTING
description: The international debt crisis and the recent multibillion dollar effort to save the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company from failure have focused attention on the banking system and its accounting practices. Following is a discussion in question-and-answer format of how banks account for profits and losses.

title: ROMANCE WRITERS FEAR MARKET GLUT
description: Unlike the breathlessly happy heroines of their passion-filled novels, whose worries are usually confined to finding and marrying Mr. Right, more than 300 authors heard warnings this weekend that they might not live happily ever after on their royalty checks.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: ORDERS TO FACTORIES REVERSE DECLINE
description: Orders to factories climbed 1.9 percent in May, reversing a sharp decline in April, the Commerce Department said today.

title: No Headline
description: While it is true that Olympia provided a suitable site for the ancient Olympics, these modern Games would be better served by Switzerland.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: ASTRONOMERS in California have begun a systematic search for a star that is thought to orbit the Sun and cause mass extinctions on the Earth every 26 million years.

title: Directors Guild Head Rules Out a Strike
description: The president of the Directors Guild of America said tonight there would be no strike against movie studios and television networks.

title: Vatican to Release Galileo Trial Notes
description: The Vatican announced today it will publish secret records of the 17th century trial of the astronomer Galileo Galilei, who was charged with heresy for claiming that the Earth revolved around the sun.

title: BONN CHARGES TWO EX-AIDES
description: The Bonn district court officially confirmed corruption charges today against Otto Lambsdorff, who resigned last week as Economics Minister in anticipation of the move. It also upheld indictments against Mr. Lambsdorff's predecessor and a senior official of the Flick holding company.

title: GAS AND OIL PRICES UNEXPECTEDLY FALL
description: Gasoline and oil prices are unexpectedly dropping, with retail gasoline prices at their lowest Independence Day levels in five years.

title: Workers Replace Shuttle Engine
description: Workers replaced one of the space shuttle Discovery's three engines today, as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported that loose insulation on a super-cold fuel line may have been a factor in the ship's aborted liftoff in what was to have been its maiden flight.

title: RATES: FURTHER RISE EXPECTED
description: After watching interest rates climb to unexpected heights this spring, many investors and economists are convinced that rates will continue to rise in the second half, although not so much as in the first half.

title: Debt Issues
description: Mo"et-Hennessy, the French champagne and cognac maker, is raising $50 million through a 15-year convertible Eurobond, the co-lead manager, Morgan Grenfell & Company, said.

title: Q&A Q.
description: Why is it that when one observes an accelerating, rotating object - such as a fan when it is first started or the spokes on the wheel of an accelerating car - it first appears to spin in the right direction, then appears to reverse itself and then reverses again to the original direction?

title: NEW RULE ENFORCER FOR NEW YORK FED
description: Frederick C. Shaddrack is just what one would expect of a central banker. Conservative. Studious. Precise. And his mien was rewarded yesterday when he was named senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in charge of supervising many of the world's biggest and most powerful commercial banks.

title: ;  Accounts
description: * Manhattan, inc., a magazine, to Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle.

description: b-Net loss.

description: IN our rapidly changing world,

description: b-Includes $401,000 for reduction in carrying value of equipment for the quarter and year. c-Includes $340,000 cost of facility restructuring and closing. d-Net income

title: South African Calls Angolan Talks Useful
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa said tonight that his talks with senior Angolan officials here had helped to settle differences about the disengagement of Pretoria's troops from southern Angola.

title: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include revenue from the sale of tax credits of $150,000 for the latest year and $365,000 for the previous year, which increased net income by $129,000, or 8 cents a share, and $178,000, or 11 cents a share, for the latest year and previous year, respectively.

title: Toyota Still Trying On Taiwan Deal
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, has applied to the Government of Taiwan for an extension beyond Wednesday to continue its attempt to iron out the details of a joint venture with local companies, officials reported today.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS HEAD ACCUSES REAGAN OF POLITICKING
description: The chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights has charged that President Reagan is playing politics with civil rights.

title: Required Reading Of Missiles and Fast Balls
description: The President: Our guests today are some of the baseball players who will be in tonight's game. They call them the old-timers. I don't see any old-timers up here. But we're very pleased and proud to have them here.

title: Judge In Detroit Refuses To Halt Ballot Printing
description: A Federal district judge today refused to halt printing of Michigan's Aug. 7 primary ballot, throwing out a request by six maverick Democrats whose names had been removed from the ballot.

title: Cause of Death OfRiderUnknown
description: The results of toxicological and microscopic tests will be needed to learn why a 35- year-old man died on a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train Sunday after a struggle with the police, authorities said today.

title: Art Dealers' Group Criticizes France
description: An international organization of art dealers voted unanimously at its annual meeting in Munich last Saturday on a resolution criticizing the French Government for issuing an arrest warrant June 19 against Sherman E. Lee, the former curator of the Cleveland Art Museum.

title: AM CABLE TV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: MEXICO MOVING TO EXTRADITE EX-POLICE CHIEF
description: Mexico today began seeking the extradition from the United States of Mexico City's former police chief, who is wanted on a wide range of corruption charges here.

title: HEALTH CARE:'MENDING THE MEDICAID QUILT' ISN'T ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $3,575,000 for the latest year and $4,954,000 for the earlier year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ayco/American Express Corp., Albany, a subsidiary of the American Express Co., has named Edward S. Miller a senior vice president.

title: Half a Loaf From Albany
description: The New York Legislature has recessed for a summer of politicking, but its 1984 record is woefully incomplete. It will have to return.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for 12 wks to June 15
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $765,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $718,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months and a gain of $1,914,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from the disposition of property. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $351,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $153,000 from discontinued operations for the 6 months.

title: MILASTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a nontaxable gain of $1,159,000 on reorganization. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $60,000 for the quarter and $406,000 for the year.

title: Bid by Rumasa Ex-Chief
description: Jose Maria Ruiz Mateos, sought by Spanish authorities on fraud charges stemming from the near-collapse of his Rumasa conglomerate, has applied for political asylum in West Germany, his attorneys said today. Fraud charges were filed against Mr. Ruiz Mateos after the Spanish Government nationalized Rumasa, Spain's biggest conglomerate, last year, saying the move was necessary to stave off a financial failure. The attorneys said that the asylum petition cited politically motivated ''persecution'' at home and added that the charges did not warrant extradition.

title: MCI Gets Rights For Laying Cable
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said that it had negotiated agreements with four railroad companies to use their rights-of-way to lay fiber optic telephone cables.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BEYOND THE DILEMMA OF JEWISH VOTERS
description: TheRev. Jesse Jackson has finally broken his silence on Louis Farrakhan and condemned the black Muslim leader's ugly anti-Semitism. His remarks should have come sooner, just as his apology for ''Hymietown'' was late. Nevertheless, the statement he issued - denouncing Mr. Farrakhan's remarks about Jews and Israel as ''reprehensible and morally indefensible'' - is positive and encouraging. His words ought to be followed by action: Mr. Jackson should dismiss Mr. Farrakhan as his surrogate and publicly disavow his support. Only then can he put the issue behind him.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,850,000 for the quarter and $2,400,000 for the 6 months.

title: STAGE:1929'FOLLOW THRU' REVIVED
description: THOUGH the adjective trendy wouldn't be coined for nearly half a century, the topical musical comedies by the team of B. G. De Sylva, Lew Brown and Ray Henderson epitomized what was fashionable and racy on Broadway in the late 1920's and early 30's when they enjoyed six consecutive hit shows.

title: CABLE NETWORKS OFFER 2 NEW SERIES
description: CABLE television, the medium promising endless programming innovations, is slowly beginning to drift into the standard format of the weekly entertainment series, complete with soap operas and situation comedies. Pay cable channels, the so-called premium services, are now preparing to introduce several projects that look suspiciously like old network series except that they are considerably more candid about what were once ''risky'' subjects.

title: U.S. NAVY MAY GET MIG'S FROM CHINA
description: A major American defense corporation has arranged with the Chinese Government to buy Soviet-designed MIG-21 jet fighters that are intended to be used by the United States Navy in combat exercises.

title: No Headline
description: Bolivia Rallies Its Forces Bolivia's comic-opera politics and economic plight have subjected it to much contempt. Last weekend, however, with impressive seriousness, Bolivia shook off what threatened to become its 190th coup and emerged with a modestly strengthened democracy. Rightist officers who kidnapped President Hernan Siles Zuazo were faced down by loyal military commanders, a powerful labor movement and other American democracies, including the United States.

title: FORMER BLOOMINGDALES'S CHIEF
description: James S. Schoff Sr., former chairman and chief executive officer of Bloomingdale Brothers Inc. and a leader in New York business and civic affairs, died Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan and Morrisville, Vt.

title: TRECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $639,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,889,000, or 39 cents a share, for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,784,000, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,845,000 for the year d-After an extraordinary gain from early extinguishment of debt of $2,420,689.

title: MONDALE'S TOUGH CHOICE
description: The rapid acceleration in the drive for a woman as the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate has created a new set of political complications for women who are activists within the party and for the campaign of Walter F. Mondale. Among the activists, these complications are reflected in the intensifying debate on how to promote the selection of a woman without putting destructive political pressures on Mr. Mondale.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SAYS IT WILL SUE U.S. IN SUPPORT OF AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today that it would file a Federal lawsuit to block the Justice Department from using Federal funds to undo local affirmative action agreements.

title: Bridge:Player Must Believe Partner To Make SuccessfulDefense
description: Believing your partner is the key to successful defense. If West had remembered this, he would have been able to prevent the declarer from finding a brilliant way to bring home a slam. The occasion was a recent Norwegian tournament, and the declarer was Harald Nordby, a regular member of the Norwegian international team.

title: AUTO RACE HAILED AS SUCCESS
description: Outside his office in Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the sun was finally shining as workers began yesterday to tear down what Loris Smith had built.

title: EX-AUTO DEALER HEADS BIGGEST OF 10 KEY BANKS
description: It's not often that a car salesman becomes a bank president, but it happens.

title: Hitachi To Export More Car Phones
description: Hitachi Ltd. said that to meet growing demand it would increase its exports of car telephones to the United States to about 60,000 sets in the year ending next March 31, from nearly 20,000 in the last fiscal year. It said it had arranged to supply several American telecommunication companies, including A.T.& T. Technologies Inc., with car telephones for sale in the United States under their own brand names.

title: Officers Making Bid For Ryan Homes
description: Malcolm M. Prine, the chairman of Ryan Homes Inc., and a group of Ryan officers are negotiating a leveraged buyout of the big home building company, it was announced yesterday from the company's Pittsburgh headquarters.

title: Writer Says He'd TakeRS01.8Jail in Libel Dispute
description: Hours after the United States Supreme Court lifted an order preventing him from being jailed, Richard Hargraves, an editorial writer, said today that he would go to jail rather than reveal his sources in a libel suit.

title: Copter Crash Kills 3 Officers
description: A National Guard helicopter crashed this evening while helping in a search for three prison escapees.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $646,000, or 6 cents a share, from the exchange of preferred stock and a note receivable for common stock. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: COURT RULES JERSEY CAN REGULATE CASINO UNIONS
description: The Supreme Court, overturning a decision by a Federal appeals court, ruled today that New Jersey could regulate the labor unions that represented employees in the Atlantic City casinos.

title: GROMYKO SAYS U.S. EVADES SERIOUS TALK ON SPACE
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko accused the United States today of seeking to avoid talks on banning weapons in space.

SONNY ROLLINS AND BAND
description: WHEN Sonny Rollins plays the way he did Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall, he reaffirms his place in the jazz pantheon as the modern tenor saxophonist against whom all others can be measured. His solos were stunning for their harmonic and rhythmic invention and, most of all, for their range of feeling.

title: Marriott Profit Increases 29%
description: - The Marriott Corporation, a lodging and food services company, said today that its profit in the second quarter rose 29 percent over the same period last year on a 21 percent sales increase. The company posted a profit of $36.6 million, or $1.38 a share, for the three months ended June 15, compared with $28.3 million, or $1.02 a share, a year ago.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: The Clean Team

title: JUSTICES RULE THAT MOTORISTS NEED NOT BE ADVISED OF RIGHTS
description: The Supreme Court today ruled unanimously that anyone in police custody and accused of a crime, no matter how minor, must be formally advised of the right against self-incrimination before questioning can begin.

title: REAGAN YIELDS TO THE KIWI LOBBY
description: The little issues really help define a President, and the kiwi fruit may show us what Ronald Reagan really stands for.

title: Jobson of U.S.  Leads Yachting
description: Gary Jobson of the United States took a narrow lead yesterday during the third day of the Liberty Cup Regatta, a series of match races that has been sailed for the last three days between eight of the top helmsmen in the world.

title: Advertising; Canadian Agency for Firestone
description: IN a highly unusual move, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A mandatory death statute simply cannot be reconciled with the scrupulous care the legal system demands to insure that the death penalty fits the individual and the crime.

title: Duren Makes a Pitch
description: He once would have liked to appear in a beer commercial, said Ryne Duren , but now the former Yankee pitching star, a recovered alcoholic, is working for Project SMART (Stop Marketing Alcohol on Radio and Television) on a nationwide petition drive for legislation to ban alcohol advertising or require equal time for commercials on the dangers of drinking. ''It's kind of like we're selling something that's killing us,'' said Duren.

title: THE POKEY PACE OF PUBLIC EMPLOYEE CONTRACTS
description: In 12 years of trying to enforce fair play between workers and bosses as a field examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, Henrik M. Sortun has encountered some incorrigible bosses. But nothing like his current case, he says. This time, he says, he is up against an employer who is a virtual thesaurus of intransigent attitudes: ''Reactionary . . . legalistic . . . imperial . . . paternalistic . . . self-righteous.''

title: MRS. MARCOS TESTIFIES SHE WARNED AQUINO NOT TO RETURN TO MANILA
description: Imelda R. Marcos said today that three months before his assassination, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. had sought her permission to return home from exile, and that she had warned him against it.

title: 2 Fokker Planes Sold
description: Fokker Aircraft N.V. said today that it had received an order for two 50-passenger propjet aircraft from Midstate Airlines of Stevens Point, Wis.

title: Caracas Shifts Interest Stand
description: Venezuela will not be rigid in seeking fixed interest rates while renegotiating its $34 billion foreign debt, Planning Minister Luis Matos Azocar said today.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK TRIMS SIZE TO SIMPLIFY RESCUE
description: Pressed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the management of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago has been rapidly shrinking the bank as part of a strategy to find a long-term solution to its problems.

title: U.S. Arms Aide to Visit China
description: President Reagan's arms control chief, Kenneth L. Adelman, is scheduled to visit Peking this week to explain the United States position on disarmament talks with the Soviet Union, American diplomatic sources said today.

title: WORLD BANK CUTS LOAN RATE
description: The World Bank announced today that it would cut its lending rate for developing countries to 9.89 percent, from 10.08 percent.

title: No Headline
description: Snag Prolonging Strike By Minneapolis Nurses

title: Republic Airlines, Union in Accord
description: Republic Airlines and the Air Line Employees Association today announced an agreement on a wage, productivity and employee stock ownership plan that includes extension of a 15 percent salary reduction through 1985.

description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY, JULY 3, 1984 International
description: President Reagan agreed to explore Moscow's offer to begin talks on limiting antisatellite weapons even before the Administration had decided what its bargaining position would be, officials said. Mr. Reagan's decision was generally seen as reflecting his determination to retain a diplomatic and political initiative. (Page A1, Column 1.) The Navy may use MIG-21 fighters in pilot training. A major defense corporation, the LTV Aerospace and Defense Company, has arranged to buy the Soviet-designed jets from Chinese production lines. (A6:1.)

title: NAUTILUS ENVIRONMEDICAL SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income includng an extraordinary credit.

title: Russians Said to Seize Ex-President of Israel
description: A former President of Israel, Ephraim Katzir, was reportedly arrested Sunday at the home of a Jewish scientist in the Soviet Union. He reappeared in Moscow today and said he was fine, the Israeli press reported.

title: BUILDING SPENDING INCREASED 1.8% IN MAY
description: Spending on construction, led by a surge in industrial building, rose 1.8 percent in May, reversing a one- month decline, the Government reported today.

title: SHOULD MAN MANIPULATE ANIMALS?
description: THE beautiful trumpeter swan retreats from man's presence while the cockroach and mosquito come nearer. Plants and creatures beneficial to humans thrive in remote places but rats and mice infest the cities. To many practical- minded people these facts signify that nature's distribution of plants and animals on the globe is haphazard and often detrimental. As a result man has often taken it upon himself, for a variety of conservation or esthetic reasons, to manipulate wild animal and plant species and their environments.

Chinese Offshore Well
description: The China National Offshore Oil Corporation said today that it had completed a third producing well in the Bohai Sea. According to the official New China News Agency, the well is yielding 155,000 gallons of crude oil and 83,850 cubic yards of natural gas a day.

title: Market Place; Public Funds, Foreign Stocks
description: DESPITE an erratic performance so far this year by mutual funds that invest abroad, brokerage firms are in the process of establishing publicly owned funds that emphasize foreign, rather than domestic, securities.

title: WARNER SELLS ATARI TO TRAMIEL
description: Warner Communications Inc., giving up its 18-month effort to rebuild a business that once flourished with Pac-Man video games and the boom in home computers, yesterday sold nearly all of its troubled Atari unit.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT OF APPEALS RULING ON NEW YORK STATE'S DEATH PENALTY
description: Following are excerpts from the Court of Appeals decision overturning New York State's death penalty statute. The opinion by Judge Judith S. Kaye was joined by Judges Bernard S. Meyer, Sol Wachtler and Hugh R. Jones. The dissent by Judge Richard D. Simons was joined by Judge Matthew J. Jasen. Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke filed a separate dissent.
