title: CSX Profit Rises in Quarter
description: The CSX Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit more than doubled from a year ago because of a surge in coal shipments to electric utilities, a robust economy and an acquisition.

title: INTERTRANS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NEW YORKER EDITOR CALLS REPORTING STYLE WRONG
description: In the wake of the recent disclosures that a writer for The New Yorker invented characters and composed conversations in nonfiction articles, Peter F. Fleischmann, the chairman of the weekly magazine, has sent a memorandum to the staff that quotes William Shawn, the editor, as unequivocally describing the practice as wrong.

title: AGE-OLD HINDU BARRIER FALLS:WOMEN ARE PRIESTS
description: A group of Hindu women here are defying Hindu orthodoxy by chanting hymns and conducting rites that for thousands of years have been the unchallenged prerogative of Brahman male priests.

title: Disney-Gibson
description: The terms of a merger between Walt Disney Productions and Gibson Greetings Inc. have been modified now that the financier Saul Steinberg has dropped his bid to take over Disney, the two companies announced today. The new agreement stipulates that each share of Gibson stock will be exchanged for a half-share of Disney stock, replacing the original variable market formula. Disney will also pay Gibson shareholders about $30 million cash, or about $2.90 a share, said Erwin Okun, vice president of Walt Disney Productions. Mr. Okun said the modified agreement reduces Disney's costs for the transaction, but he was ''unable to put a dollar figure on it.''

title: Comings and Goings The Islanders are expected to announce later this week that
description: Al Arbour will remain as coach next season. . . . The National Hockey League's list of free agents without compensation, which became public yesterday, includes the Rangers' Kent-Erik Andersson, Mikko Leinonen and Bill Baker ; the Devils' Garry Howatt, and several former Rangers and Islanders, such as Rick Chartraw and Pat Conacher (Edmonton), Mike McEwen and Billy Harris (Los Angeles), and Ed Hospodar (Hartford). . . . The Olympic development team in soccer added the former Cosmos stars Rick Davis and Angelo DiBernardo to the 18-man roster for an exhibition game Saturday against the San Diego Sockers. The final 17-man Olympic roster must be submitted July 14.

title: Spot Prices For 45% of Oil
description: Forty- five percent of the trade in crude oil uses spot-market prices, because of oversupply, according to an industry publication here.

title: Hallmark Filing
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. has increased its stake in Binney & Smith Inc., a crayon and art supplies manufacturer, to 1,631,951 common shares, or 38 percent of the shares outstanding, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. From June 14 to June 28, Hallmark bought 146,100 shares at prices ranging from $54 to $54.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. On June 11, Hallmark gained the option to purchase 672,000 shares, or 22 percent of the 3,634,535 shares outstanding, from 15 Binney & Smith shareholders.

title: POLL SHOWS DEMOCRATS FAVOR HART FOR VICE-PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION
description: Senator Gary Hart is well ahead of any competitor as the choice of rank- and-file Democrats for the Vice-Presidential nomination, and if he were on the ticket he would halve President Reagan's current substantial lead over Walter F. Mondale, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

Ships Identified In Persian Gulf Attacks
description: A small Greek ship was attacked Sunday in the Persian Gulf and there were casualties among its crew, Lloyd's Shipping Intelligence reported today.

title: FMC WILL BUY SHARES
description: The FMC Corporation, an agricultural products company in Chicago, began a tender offer yesterday for 6 million of its common shares.

title: Chess:Sovietorld
description: The Soviet Union re-established its dominance of international chess by winning a six-day challenge match against a Rest of the World team on Friday in London. The score of the 10- board, 4-round match was: U.S.S.R., 21, Rest of the World, 19.

title: ALBERT DAILEY, 46, JAZZ PIANIST
description: Albert Dailey, a jazz pianist who worked with Art Blakey, Charles Mingus, Sonny Rollins and other major musicians, and as a soloist around New York City, died of pneumonia June 26 in Denver. He was 46 years old.

title: SLEW O'GOLD ROMPS
description: You can't win them all,'' Mickey Taylor was saying before the first race at Belmont Park yesterday. Taylor is a principal owner of Slew o'Gold, last year's 3-year-old champion, who was making his first start in almost nine months. The point was not so much for the colt to win as to get him back to the races and show he hadn't lost anything over the winter.

title: Drug Raids Net 16
description: Sixteen people at Pompano Park, including jockeys, trainers, owners, grooms and a blacksmith, have been suspended, fined or placed under investigation. The action came after two raids by parimutuel officials last week uncovered suspected illegal drugs and several loaded guns, according to Mike Marr , the chief investigator for the Florida State Division of Parimutuel Wagering. After laboratory reports are completed, he said, ''I suspect we'll be suspending quite a few more.''

title: Scottie Best Ever
description: Ch. Braeburn's Close Encounter, a Scottish terrier owned by Sonnie and Alan Novick of Plantation Acres, Fla., was selected best in show at the Paper Cities Kennel Club fixture in Mosinee, Wis., on Saturday to become the top winner in this country's dog-show history.

title: Torre Re-Signs
description: Joe Torre signed a two-year extension of his contract as manager of the Atlanta Braves yesterday, ending a negotiating process that began more than nine months ago. The contract is believed to be worth more than $425,000. . . . Even though the Milwaukee Brewers are far behind in the American League East, Rene Lachemann is not in danger of being dismissed as manager, according to the general manager, Harry Dalton . ''He has never been in trouble,'' Dalton said, adding, ''As far as I'm concerned, he's still a bright young manager, doing a good job with the talent we've given him.''

title: Chrysler Obtains $1.1 Billion Credit
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it had completed a $1.1 billion revolving credit agreement with 57 banks from the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Japan. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company served as agent for the transaction.

description: A merger agreement announced today between Sun Banks Inc., of Orlando and the Trust Company of Georgia in Atlanta is likely to push other Southeastern banks into similar regional accords, according to bank executives and analysts.

description: A supermarket ''exodus'' from New York City is leading to higher prices and fewer jobs - particularly for the poor, aged and disabled, according to Carol Bellamy, the City Council President.

title: LEARNING TO SERVE BY SITTING
description: MINNEAPOLIS More than two months ago, when Chuck Person was just one of dozens of basketball players trying to survive at the Olympic trials, the Summer Games seemed forever away. Person's hope that first week was not to reach Los Angeles; it was just to stay at the trials. ''My goal was just to make the first 32,'' he said. ''And I did.''

description: THERE are 126 medical schools in the country and the desire of students to gain admission to them is so intense that the creation of each additional school is a major event in the academic world, reopening the debate over how many physicians are needed and focusing anew on the huge expense of medical education.

description: A twin-engine aircraft crashed and exploded on takeoff from this village on Vancouver Island today, killing all nine people aboard, officials said.

description: William C. Norris is best known for having built the Control Data Corporation into a computer giant. Today the company's outspoken 72-year-old chairman is concentrating on long-term policy.

title: Pic 'n' Save Corp.
description: William Zimmerman, chairman and founder of the Pic 'n' Save Corporation, and his family, who control about 22.4 percent of the company's stock and are the largest shareholders, said they are exploring alternatives regarding the family's ownerhip position, including the sale of the family's block of stock. The action follows the recent rejection by the company of a $720 million leveraged buyout offer by Adler & Shaykin, a New York investment fund. Pic 'n' Save, based in Carson, Calif., operates a chain of discount retail stores, mainly in southern California.

title: Execution of Woman Stayed
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today stayed the scheduled Aug. 31 execution of a 51- year-old nurse who has admitted poisoning her mother, a close friend and two other people.

description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, citing her experience as a prosecutor, legislator and mother, paid a long-awaited visit to Walter F. Mondale here today. After a three-hour meeting she said she was fully qualified to be his running mate.

title: OCEANOGRAPHY FOR 'SMARTER' WARS
description: Two priorities of Navy ocean science these days are the southern oceans and the world's strategic straits, such as the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf known as the Strait of Hormuz. title: No Headline
description: A senior African sports official was quoted today as calling for an African boycott of the Los Angeles Olympics, despite assurances that African countries will attend. Henri Zongo, the sports minister of Upper Volta and the chairman of the executive committee of the Supreme Council for Sports in Africa, was quoted by the Ethiopian radio as calling for the boycott at a news conference Saturday in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital.

title: No Headline
description: Of All the Feminist Nerve On one side, Walter Mondale has been hearing some infuriating demands. If he wants to win in November, feminists are saying, he has to nominate a woman to run with him. Otherwise, as Judy Goldsmith, president of the National Organization for Women, said the other day, ''I don't know how we can go out to women and say 'Here's something to work for.' ''

title: Burden Pleads Guilty
description: Luther (Ticky) Burden , the former Knick whose bank robbery conviction was overturned last January, pleaded guilty yesterday to another charge of criminal possession of $400 of the stolen money. Burden, 30 years old, told Nassau County Court Judge Edward Baker the $400 was given to him by Michael Elem , who was also convicted of the holdup.

title: CABLE TV'S SHAME:'GORE-NOGRAPHY'
description: People who make pornograpy are accustomed to all sorts of calumny, from sneers to outright threats, a lot of it connected with the possibility of material intended only for adults falling into the hands of children. It makes no difference that I have always advocated strict control and absolute segregation of sexually explicit material; it is a well-known debate tactic to force an opponent to defend himself against crimes he has not committed, and the foes of the adult entertainment industry indulge in it regularly. But my opinion has never wavered: As a parent and a human being, I am against the sexualization of children, in all its aspects.

title: SRI LANKA STRIFE AND ISRAELI AID
description: The President of Sri Lanka, discussing antiterrorist assistance from Israel, said here today that his Government had asked for the aid after Western nations, including the United States, had rebuffed similar requests.

title: A NEW CASH SOURCE FOR BANKS
description: Major banks are increasingly turning to a nontraditional area of profits: selling their office buildings. The reasons are varied - a troubled bank can use the one-time gain to offset operating losses, while a healthy institution may capitalize on a sale to help expand its basic business.

title: STAGE:MUSIC FESTIVAL IS ON
description: In search of a new vision of American musical theater, an ambitious three-week investigation of its elements, revived, freshly invented or reshuffled, has been begun here this summer.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today July 3, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BACKWARD REELS THE GENDER
description: He is about to propose, but he will not go to his knees to do it, for he is an important man, and important men do not carry on like lovesick youngsters in second-rate melodrama.

title: CHAUNCEY WADDELL, INVESTMENT BANKER AND PHILANTHROPIST
description: Chauncey L. Waddell, an investment banker and philanthropist, died Wednesday at the New York Hospital- Cornell Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HEMLINES: A MATTER OF CHOICE
description: Some hemlines in fall collections bare the knees. Others graze the ankles. On city streets these hot summer days, one can already see women in short skirts alongside women in long ones. The world is not falling apart.

No Headline

Those who said they didn't know who they would vote for or who said they had no opinion are not shown.

title: STEP TO UPGRADE TEACHERS IS TAKEN AT A CRITICAL TIME
description: CONGRESS has taken a first step to turn the clamor for better teachers into a Federally financed action program. On June 20 the House Education and Labor Committee unanimously approved a bipartisan bill, H.R. 4477, to entice some of the best and brightest high school seniors to become teachers and keep some of the ablest young teachers in the profession. Known as the Talented Teachers Act, the measure would provide scholarships for college students in return for a pledge to teach for up to eight years, and it would provide fellowships to able teachers. The bill is expected to be taken up by the House before the end of this month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Double Jeopardy

title: OFFICIALS ADVISE ON COPING WITH THE JERSEY GARBAGE STRIKE
description: Residents and businesses of about 200 municipalities affected by a strike by garbage collectors were advised today to store their household and kitchen wastes in cool, dry places until collections are resumed.

title: SCOUTING;
description: The Quiet Tiger

title: MODERATES LEAD IN GUATEMALA VOTE
description: Preliminary returns today from Sunday's voting for a Constituent Assembly showed two centrist parties leading, and the leaders of both parties said they intended to run for president next year.

title: O'Neill to Insist Surplus Be Saved
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said Monday he would insist that the projected $144.4 million state budget surplus, remain where it's supposed to, in a ''rainy day'' fund.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Finnish Pride

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUTWEST

title: BUREAUCRACY AND BLIGHT IMPERIL CHINA'S PANDAS
description: -shrouded rain forests of the Qionglai Mountains here are scarred with sere brown patches of bamboo that has flowered and withered, creating potential famine for the endangered giant panda.

title: BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: RAWLEY BEATS REDS ON 2 HITS
description: Shane Rawley, newly acquired from the Yankees, allowed only two hits over seven innings as the Phillies defeated the Cincinnati Reds tonight, 4-0. Ozzie Virgil and Glenn Wilson hit home runs.

title: U.S. FEARS COOLING IN HONDURAS TIES
description: The Reagan Administration is concerned that recent political and military developments in Honduras may signal a deterioration in relations with the United States, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Bond Fraud Is Suspected
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said yesterday that it would not honor 36 Eurobond transactions that it believed were part of a scheme to defraud the company. The company said it intended to honor all other trades.

title: A TIME TO REPLAY A MEMORY
description: A man with his 12-year-old son symbolized the blend of baseball generations for tonight's Cracker Jack Old-Timers Baseball Classic here when he asked an old-timer to sign a baseball card that the player had signed three decades earlier.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Koch Picks Head Of Women's Unit
description: Kay J. Wight, a vice president at CBS Sports, was named chairman of the New York City Commission on the Status of Women by Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: On the Record; Hart on the Deficit
description: From prepared remarks yesterday at Columbia University:

title: YANKS BLOW FIVE-RUN LEAD
description: The Yankees cursed their season with strained voices and with bewilderment tonight. Another loss left the clubhouse mood almost unbearable. ''We have an announcement,'' said Don Baylor, gloom underscoring his attempt at humor. ''The Yankees dropped another one.''

title: OLYMPIA IS NO PLACE FOR OLYMPICS
description: To the Editor:

title: A PARTY UNLIKE MOST
description: PUBLISHERS WEEKLY described Susan Mary Alsop's account of the Congress of Vienna as ''titillating'' and ''effervescent,'' and emphasized the ''naughty doings

title: No Barbaro Surgery
description: Gary Barbaro , the New Jersey Generals' free safety who was injured in Saturday's 28-7 playoff loss to the Philadelphia Stars, need not undergo a second operation on his left knee, according to the team's orthopedic surgeon. ''Gary is just going to rest the knee,'' said Dr. Mark Schottenfeld. Barbaro had returned to action after arthroscopic surgery May 8. . . . The Houston Gamblers' rookie quarterback, Jim Kelly , was named the United States Football League's player of the year in a poll of reporters by The Associated Press.

title: GRUNTZ CONCERT BAND
description: AS a postscript to the major events of the Kool Jazz Festival, the George Gruntz Concert Jazz Band, a mixture of 16 European and American musicians led by a Swiss pianist and arranger, made its American debut Sunday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: MCENROE, LENDL AND CONNORS ADVANCE
description: The two top-seeded men reached the Wimbledon quarterfinals today by different routes. John McEnroe overwhelmed Bill Scanlon with a quick display of brilliant shotmaking, and Ivan Lendl survived on his power and nerve in five sets against Scott Davis.

title: Thrift Units' Mortgages
description: The nation's savings and loan associations made loans to home buyers at a record pace in May, closing a total of $16.7 billion in mortgages, the Government said today.

title: Soviet Buys More Wheat
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 550,000 metric tons of wheat - about 20.2 million bushels - for delivery this year under a new long-term accord that took effect Oct. 1, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: RULE ON BROKERED DEPOSITS ADOPTED
description: Warning of a ''significant danger'' to banks that accept deposits from money brokers, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today adopted an emergency regulation that will require about 500 United States commercial banks to make monthly reports disclosing their use of brokered deposits.

title: DRIVERS LINE UP AS STATE STARTS PHOTO PROGRAM
description: It was a day for long lines, widespread confusion and even Buddhist chants as New York became the 50th state to add photographs to its drivers' licenses yesterday.

title: The Worm and the Apple Barreling Bikes and Blind Buses
description: Blowing Whistles

title: World 10,000 Mark Set
description: Fernando Mamede of Portugal set a world record of 27 minutes 13.81 seconds in the 10,000-meter run at a track meet today. Carlos Lopez of Portugal, who was second, also finished under the previous mark of 27:22.4 set by Henry Rono of Kenya in 1978.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Moody's Upgrades M.B.I.A. Issues
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that bonds insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association would be rated AAA.

title: CITY'S VOCATIONAL HIGH SCHOOLS STRIVE TO MEET CHALLENGES DESPITE PROBLEMS
description: At Queens Vocational High School, built more than 60 years ago and never modernized, outside walls are crumbling and inside walls are covered with peeling paint. Students eat in an auditorium.

title: 'Video Jukeboxes' Show Commercials
description: Some entrepreneurs have come up with a gimmick to reach the elusive younger set.

title: BOND MAN NOW RUNS ROWE PRICE
description: In what may be an industry first, T. Rowe Price Associates Inc., one of the nation's leading investment management companies, has named a bond specialist as president and chief executive officer.

title: TEACHERS' GROUP RESISTS CHANGE IN EVALUATIONS AND REWARDS
description: The growing national movement to upgrade the teaching profession by creating career ladders for advancement, leading to such rewards as the title ''master teacher'' and to merit pay, ran into opposition today at the annual convention of the National Education Association.

title: PRICES RISE IN SLOW TRADING
description: Interest rates eased and prices edged higher in very slack trading in the credit markets yesterday.

title: STOCKS SUBDUED AS HOLIDAY NEARS
description: The stock market opened the week on a subdued note yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.32 points. Trading was slower with the approach of the Fourth of July holiday.

title: THE GRANDE DAME OF THE OLYMPICS
description: In a pink dress and a pink hat, Eleanor Holm Whelan stared at the

title: Texaco Sells Unit
description: Texaco Inc. said it had completed the sale, for $1.075 billion in cash, of the Getty Oil Company's Employers Reinsurance Corporation to the General Electric Company. Texaco acquired Employers Reinsurance in its Feb. 17 purchase of Getty Oil for $10.1 billion. General Electric said separately that it had formed a new subsidiary, General Electric Financial Services Inc., as a holding company to facilitate G. E.'s expansion into financial services businesses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JULY 3, 1984

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES
description: Jackson Suggests Parley To Pacify Latin States

title: Soto Appeal Dropped
description: The Cincinnati Reds withdrew their appeal yesterday to the National League on the five-day suspension of Mario Soto .

title: A BIG DAY FOR TWO QUALIFIERS
description: The moment was complete when the 21-year-old qualifier left court 13 a winner from Johan Kriek and thus a Wimbledon quarterfinalist, and heard ''a mysterious little voice'' commanding, ''Paul Annacone, do not move!''

title: INDIA REPLACES KASHMIR STATE'S LEADERS
description: The leadership of the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir was dismissed today after 12 legislators defected from the Chief Minister's faction within the National Conference Party to a rival faction.

title: LEADING DEALS AND DEAL MAKERS IN THE FIRST HALF OF THIS YEAR
description: BASS FAMILY . . . Texas clan, worth over $1 billion, headed by Perry Richardson Bass, 69 years old. . . . Younger generation of four sons led by Sid Richardson Bass, 42. . . . Family company, Bass Brothers Enterprises, is the parent of most of their oil and gas, real estate, and hotel holdings. . . . After what was perceived as a takeover bid for Texaco Inc., the family and a group of affiliates sold back their 9.7 percent stake to the company for some $1.28 billion, a 12 percent profit. . . . In 1981, the family began acquiring large amounts of Blue Bell Inc. stock, in what was seen as a move for control of the jeans maker. . . . In November, they sold back 1.9 million shares, and then this spring they sold back an additional 1.1 million shares, all for about $50 a share, or a total of $144.3 million. . . . Recently have amassed an 11.3 percent interest in Alexander's Inc., the New York-based operator of department stores, and a small interest in a St. Regis Corporation unit. . . . Trace their money back to the legendary fortune of a rich uncle, Sid Richardson, a colorful oilman.

title: SUPERCHIP HERALDS A REVOLUTION
description: QUIETLY, often in secrecy, scientists at dozens of laboratories in Europe, Japan and the United States are racing toward yet another revolution in the speed, size and reliability of computers.

title: JOHN M. CORRIDAN, 73, THE 'WATERFRONT PRIEST'
description: The Rev. John M. Corridan, the Jesuit priest whose crusade against corruption on the docks brought him national attention as ''the Waterfront Priest'' and helped lead to the creation of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Misericordia Hospital Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 73 years old and had lived in a health-care center at Fordham University.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the spinoff of Super Rite Foods Inc. in December 1983 and a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January 1984.

title: BATTLE ON PORNOGRAPHY SPURRED BY NEW TACTICS
description: The Reagan Administration's recent call for a national commission on pornography brings Washington into the battle over the effect of pornography on American society.

title: AVACARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MRS. BURFORD NAMED TO HEAD U.S. PANEL ON THE ENVIRONMENT
description: President Reagan announced today that he would appoint Anne M. Burford, who last year was forced to resign as head of the Environmental Protection Agency, as chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere.

title: GOODEN FANS 12 IN MET TRIUMPH
description: Dwight Gooden dazzled the opposition with another striking performance last night and powered himself and the Mets into the lead on two different fronts.

title: MONDALE-JACKSON MEETING SET UP AS MANY WATCH FOR SIGNALS
description: Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson will hold a private meeting in Kansas City, Mo., Tuesday that is expected to be closely watched by Jewish groups and others for signals on how Mr. Mondale intends to deal with the political problems posed by his rival.

title: JOE BUSHKIN PLAYS AND SINGS
description: JOE BUSHKIN, a pianist who is most at home when he can sit sideways on a piano bench, chatting with his listeners as he plays, zinging out carefully crafted one-liners and occasionally murmuring rhythmically phrased lyrics, turned the formality of Carnegie Recital Hall into his kind of setting for his Kool Jazz Festival recital last Saturday afternoon.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including net gains on the sale of investments of $1,370,000 for the quarter and $2,877,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary tax credits of $617,000 for the quarter and $1,240,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a net gain of $198,000 on the sale of investments. d-Net loss including a net gain of $289,000 on the sale of investments.

title: MURDER SUSPECT RECALLED AS ODD BY HIS FRIENDS
description: People who crossed Michael B. Ross's path in recent years - Cornell fraternity brothers, co-workers on an Ohio farm, fellow agents at the Prudential Insurance Company office in Norwich - said the young man's behavior often seemed peculiar. At a party he could act polished one minute, and then the next speak to a woman in The crudest, foulest terms.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Birthday Party

title: Article 041887 -- No Title
description: When Jacqueline Grayson, an air traffic controller, inquired about renting rooms at the Watergate Garden Apartments in Patchogue two years ago, she thought it was peculiar that the rental agent offered so little information.

title: COURT OVERTURNS DEATH SENTENCE IN NEW YORK LAW
description: Excerpts from opinions, page B4.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Living Section June 6 about the eating habits of dancers in correctly stated the findings of a study of female adolescents who were not dancers. Of the 600 surveyed, 1 percent to 6 percent were found to be anorexic.

title: HIGH COURT LIFTS AN EDITORIAL BAN ON BROADCASTERS
description: The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Federal law barring the broadcasting of editorials by the hundreds of public radio and television stations that receive funds from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Analysts Bearish On Warner Stock
description: Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday, following the sale of most of its Atari unit, that it would now concentrate on entertainment and communications.

title: Top Job Swap At Wal-Mart
description: Two of the top officers of Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's second-largest discount retailer after the K Mart Corporation, are exchanging jobs. David Glass, the 48-year-old vice chairman and chief financial officer, will become president and chief operating officer, while Jack Shewmaker, 46, who has held those titles, will take over Mr. Glass's posts.

title: THE MAKING OF A TURF BATTLE ROYAL
description: Turf wars, those sometimes fearsome clashes between bureaucratic rivals for greater areas of responsibility, have become as much a part of Washington as fireworks on the Fourth of July.

title: DEFENSE CITES DELOREAN'S 'FEAR' OF DRUG DEALERS
description: John Z. DeLorean's attorney said today that new evidence showed he was ''scared out of his wits'' at the idea of doing business with drug dealers and gave up control of his company rather than go through with it.

title: DOMINICANS AWAIT SALE BY G.& W.
description: In the late 1960's and early 1970's, when Gulf and Western Industries was beginning its vast operations in the Dominican Republic, it was widely feared as a greedy multinational company that would exploit the country's resources and give back little to the people.

title: PECESS APPOINTMENT FOR MISS SEGER
description: President Reagan has given Martha R. Seger a recess appointment as a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, theoretically enabling her to serve even though she has not been confirmed by the Senate.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Moscow Bars a Speech On July 4th by Envoy
description: The Soviet authorities refused today to allow the United States Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, to deliver a Fourth of July television address.

title: BREAK IN MAIN CUTS OFF WATER IN JERSEY CITY
description: The major aqueduct serving Jersey City broke yesterday, cutting off water for several hours until after the flow was rerouted through a backup main.

title: Chrysler Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation will convert one of its St. Louis-area assembly plants to increase production of its fast-selling mini-vans, an auto industry journal says.

title: OFT-ABSENT MAYOR'S OUSTER IS SOUGHT
description: In a city less than two square miles in size, where co-workers are neighbors and neighbors are friends, it is hard not to notice comings and goings.

title: JOURNALIST JAILED FOR HIDING SOURCE
description: Saying a free press is essential to democracy, an editorial writer went to jail today to serve an indefinite contempt sentence for refusing to divulge his sources in writing an editorial that led to a libel suit.

title: Democrats to Auction Portraits for Funds
description: The leadership of the Democratic National Committee has figured out a new way to raise money: by selling portraits of the three major candidates at auction.

title: ;  Victory for Youth
description: A 16-year-old harness racing driver from Freehold became the youngest person to win a parimutuel race in New Jersey when she drove One for All to victory in the seventh race at the Meadowlands Monday night. It was the first race in her home state for Susan Looney-Vitale , who became eligible to drive there when the State Racing Commission voted on June 4 to lower the minimum age for parimutuel competitors from 18 to 16.

title: 'Henry V' Opening Delayed
description: The official opening of the New York Shakespeare Festival's ''Henry V,'' starring Kevin Kline and directed by Wilford Leach, has been postponed to tomorrow. The curtain is 8 P.M.

title: SWEDISH SKIPPER WINS LIBERTY CUP
description: Pelle Petterson of Sweden became the first winner of the Liberty Cup yesterday as the four-day regatta of match races off Staten Island ended in controversy and confusion.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Storm Disrupts Power on L.I.
description: Heavy rains and strong gusts knocked out electrical service to thousands of residents of Long Island yesterday, but appeared to cause few problems for the rest of the metropolitan area.

title: Why Unicorns Don't Visit the Zoo
description: Biologists are flirting again with the notion that the earliest forms of life arrived on Earth from space instead of evolving spontaneously from inorganic chemicals. Astronomers, meanwhile, are stepping up the search for life on other planets. The goals of each group, described at a Boston symposium this week, are related, but their premises are contradictory.

title: Consumers Revises Midland Plans
description: The Consumers Power Company today proposed completing both reactors at its beleaguered Midland nuclear plant and raising its electric rates, but an opponent of the project called the plan unacceptable.

title: SUCCESS STIRS BRITISH DISPUTE
description: Inmos International P.L.C., Britain's state- owned venture into manufacturing microchips, has proved a success - so much so that the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher sees an opportunity to sell the company, while the opposition Labor Party argues that it proves the viability of state participation in business.

title: J. LUTHER CLEVELAND, A FORMER CHAIRMAN OF GUARANTY TRUST
description: J. Luther Cleveland, the president and chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company who became chairman of the executive committee of its successor, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Sunday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla., where he had lived for 12 years. He was 93 years old.

title: A.T.&T., Olivetti In Europe Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company said they had formed a venture, Unix Europe, to expand the market in Europe for A.T.& T.'s Unix System V computer operating system.

title: AQUINO INQUIRY HEARS PUBLISHER
description: A Filipino publisher who has been in jail for nine months in connection with articles he published about the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. told an investigative commission today that his imprisonment was part of an official cover- up.

title: Italy-U.S. Tax Treaty
description: President Reagan asked the Senate today to ratify a treaty between the United States and Italy that is intended to prevent double taxation of income of residents of the two countries.

title: AIR FLORIDA FILES BANKRUPTCY AND GROUNDS PLANES
description: Air Florida, once the prime success story of airline deregulation, filed a bankruptcy petition yesterday. The carrier's failure was a result of fare wars and new competition in its markets as other airlines also took advantage of the loosening of Government regulation.

title: WASHINGTON The World On the Fourth
description: A glance at the world on the 208th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence is not reassuring about the condition of liberty or democracy.

title: Hungarians Form Police Unit In a Drive Against Corruption
description: The Hungarian Government has formed a special police unit to fight bribery and black marketeering, the party daily Nepszabadsag said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The street buyers of drugs, the street sellers of drugs, are robbers, are muggers, commit burglaries.

title: GROUP OF BLACK CLERGYMEN BACKS THE RE-ELECTION OF REP. ADDABBO
description: A group of black ministers yesterday endorsed Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens, whose renomination has been challenged by a black Democrat, Simeon Golar.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS PLAN TO MEDIATE CONVENTION
description: The 175 House members who are delegates to the Democratic National Convention plan to convene regularly and work as a unit to mediate any crises that may arise, Representative Tony Coelho of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said today.

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Debt Ratings
description: * Burlington Northern Railroad equipment trust certificates have been raised by Standard & Poor's to AAA from AA; its consolidated mortgage bonds and notes to AA from A.

title: ;  Witness for the U.S.
description: A co-defendant of the former pitcher Denny McLain in a Federal racketeering case has pleaded guilty and agreed to testify for the Government, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office in Tampa, Fla., George Tragos , confirmed yesterday. The co-defendant, Barry Nelson , pleaded guilty June 22 to a racketeering charge that lists bookmaking, loan sharking and drug violations, but the prosecution agreed to drop conspiracy and cocaine-possession charges. McLain and five others named in a Federal indictment in mid-March are scheduled to go on trial beginning Sept. 10.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE FOURTH Lower Manhattan, where the workers declare their freedom from the office for the Fourth of July, will be occupied today by an army of merrymakers and patriotic observers who will see parades, street fairs, lifeboat races and fireworks.

title: Israeli 'Deeply Offended' By K.G.B. Interrogation
description: Former President Ephraim Katzir of Israel said today that his interrogation by the Soviet secret police after he tried to visit a Jewish man might have been a warning to Soviet Jews seeking to emigrate.

title: ; 16 STATE E.R.A.'S: A BOON TO WOMEN AND MEN
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Brazil Loses Steel Ruling
description: The Commerce Department issued a final ruling against Brazilian steel today that could lead to the imposition of penalty duties on some of the country's steel exports to the United States.

title: BRIEFING
description: An Attack or an Ad?

title: CAPTIAL PUNISHMENT
description: NewsAnalysis

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*A Bag of Bags

title: HART IS STILL UNCERTAIN ABOUT VICE PRESIDENCY
description: As Walter F. Mondale stood waving for the cameras outside the brownstone in New York where he and Gary Hart met last week, a photographer who wanted a picture of both men gesturing called out, ''Double wave.''

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $14,072,000 from debt restructuring agreements and a credit of $1,558,000 from a change in accounting. c-Net loss.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Westchester Aide Tops Cuomo's Pay
description: The pay of Westchester County's Hospitals Commissioner has been raised to $105,000 a year, making his salary higher than that of Governor Cuomo.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Grumman Tells Its Side Of the Bus Story

title: SBS Drops a Fee
description: Satellite Business Systems, following the lead of GTE-Sprint and the MCI Communications Corporation, said it was dropping the $16 sign-up fee for its Skyline long-distance telephone service. Skyline customers will now face only one requirement in using the service - a $15 minimum use fee per month. SBS, based in McLean, Va., is a partnership of the International Business Machines Corporation, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company and the Communications Satellite Corporation.

title: Payment By Vatican
description: The Vatican has paid $240.9 million to the foreign creditors of Italy's bankrupt Ambrosiano bank, Vatican sources said today.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'THE LAST SEA'
description: ''THE LAST SEA,'' which opens a two-week engagement today at the Film Forum, is a moving tribute to the illegal Jewish immigrants - Holocaust survivors - who, between 1945 and 1948, overcame incredible hardships to get to Palestine and, by their numbers and presence, helped to make inevitable the birth of the Jewish state.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Dodgers' No. 1 Joins the Greats

title: ;  Too Demanding
description: The Cincinnati Bengals' assistant general manager, Mike Brown , said the team had reached an impasse in negotiations with its two top draft picks - Ricky Hunley , the Arizona linebacker, and Pete Koch , a defensive lineman from Maryland - and was prepared to play the 1984 season without them.

title: West Coast Cleanup Is Urged
description: A panel of local labor and community groups today urged President Reagan to issue an executive order to release emergency money to fight toxic chemical wastes from the northern California electronics industry.

title: ; . . . Georgia Counterpart With a Regional View
description: Robert Strickland, chairman of the Trust Company of Georgia, sees more than just a big merger in the new Suntrust Banks Inc., of which he will be chairman. He says it will give him more opportunity to take his 15- year-old son, Walter, to Disney World.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Cheers and Champagne For the Olympics

title: AMBER WAVES OF GRAIN
description: Dec. 7, 1941: The night of Pearl Harbor. Reporters were huddled under the White House portico. The grim senators who visited Franklin Delano Roosevelt ''came in silent and went out silent,'' wrote Richard L. Strout. ''Behind the iron fence a small crowd . . . made an effort to sing 'America the Beautiful.' It quavered badly. It made me cry.''

title: FRIENDS OFFER TRIBUTES TO LILLIAN HELLMAN AT A SERVICE
description: Jules Feiffer, Patricia Neal, John Hersey and other literary and theatrical colleagues gathered today in the tiny town of Chilmark on the island of Martha's Vineyard to pay tribute to Lillian Hellman.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air 1, a St. Louis-based carrier, said it had completed a $19.6 million sale and lease-back agreement for its Boeing 727-100 aircraft with Ryder Systems Inc.

title: Mitsubishi Net Up 11% in Year
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that brisk sales of electronic products and a 28 percent rise in exports helped raise its profit 11 percent in the fiscal year ended March 31, to a record of $163 million.

title: FOLK-ROCK: STEVE FORBERT AT LONE STAR
description: FIVE years ago, Steve Forbert, a former New York City street singer who had come here from Meridian, Miss., was viewed by many observers as the pop musician most likely to succeed in rejuvenating the folk-rock tradition of Bob Dylan. Mr. Forbert wrote refreshingly open-hearted songs about his journey from Meridian to Manhattan, and his ingenuously raspy singing, with its unforced rock-and-roll inflections made him one of pop's most distinctive new voices.

title:
PLAYS;
VOLLEY CHANGES WIMBLEDON MATCH
description: WIMBLEDON, England

title: HOSPITAL USING NEW DEVICE TO PULVERIZE KIDNEY STONES
description: A device that physicians say will relieve the excruciating pain and debilitating effects of kidney stones without surgery is being tested at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S RETURN URGED
description: The two American members of the International Olympic Committee, in remarks that brought a heated response from the Los Angeles organizers of this year's Games, have spoken in favor of South Africa's readmittance to Olympic competition as soon as possible.

title: RIDGEWAY EXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-After a loss of $31,988 from discontinued operations. The share earnings are less than 1 cent a share.

title: Tobacco Support Prices
description: The Government's support prices for burley and five other kinds of tobacco grown in 1984 will remain at the level of the last two years, the Agriculture Department said today. The level for another kind, Puerto Rican cigar filler, type 46, was reduced because of excessive stocks, said Everett Rank, administrator of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: b-Net income.

title: FOR SOTO, HIS TALENT IS THREATENED BY TEMPER
description: To Darrell Evans, Mario Soto was the best pitcher in the National League last season. Bruce Berenyi is not so restricted in his assessment of his former teammate. ''I think he's the best pitcher in the major leagues today,'' Berenyi, now with the Mets, said, In fact, Berenyi added, ''He's in another league.''

title: United Is Expected To Order Jetliners
description: United Airlines is expected to place an order valued at more than $1.5 billion for passenger jetliners before the end of the year, industry executives and Wall Street analysts said today.

title: TREASURY WANTS MORE FOREIGN DATA
description: The Treasury Department has proposed a broad increase in the power of the Government to collect information about foreign financial transactions, down to such details as the charges made on individual credit cards in other countries.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON RULES FOR CARE IN 'BABY DOE' CASES
description: Members of Congress, hospital officials, civil rights advocates and antiabortion groups have reached agreement on principles for treating severely handicapped infants.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: The Story Behind A Fireworks Crackdown

title: Careers ; A Degree, Yes, but Do You Type?
description: VICTORIA RUSSO graduated

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Wanted Mexican Official Is Sent to Los Angeles

title: TEXAS VOTES FIRST MAJOR TAX INCREASE IN 13 YEARS
description: Legislators ended a 30-day special session today by passing a $4.8 billion tax bill, most of it to finance changes in the public school system.

title: ELRON ELECTRONICS INDUSTRIES LTD (ISRAEL)(O) reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including gains of $1.4 million for the latest year and $7.4 million for the previous year from the issuance of shares by units or affiliates.

title: ;  Torrez in the Minors
description: Mike Torrez , released recently by the Mets, was signed by the Oakland A's yesterday to a contract with Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. The right-hander, who will be 38 on Aug. 28, will report to the Tacoma club in Tucson Thursday. An Oakland spokesman said that Torrez's situation will be reviewed after two minor league starts.

title: IN LOS ANGELES, HIGH-STYLE RESTAURANT FARE
description: LOS ANGELES WHERE but Los Angeles would a restaurant with an unlisted phone number be tolerated or a style of cooking called nouvelle Southwestern be embraced? When it comes to show business, movies aren't the only game in this town. As ticket holders for the Olympics, which start late this month, and other visitors will discover, restaurants here also have a flair for the dramatic.

title: FILM AND TV DIRECTORS APPROVE A 3-YEAR PACT
description: The motion picture and television directors have voted overwhelmingly to accept a new three-year contract, averting the first strike in the 50-year history of the Directors Guild of America. Such a strike would have closed down almost all television and movie production.

title: Bank Rates Rise Again
description: For the second consecutive week following the June 25 increase in the prime rate, annual effective yields on six-month certificates of deposit and on money market deposit accounts climbed nationwide, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's report on the week ended Tuesday.

title: GREECE DENIES U.S. CHARGE IT IS LAX IN FIGHTING TERROR
description: A senior Greek official denied as ''utterly baseless'' today assertions by United States officials that Greece is lax in combating international terrorism.

title: World Loans For Energy
description: The International Finance Corporation plans to commit $500 million to energy programs from 1985 to 1989, Richard Richardson, director of the organization's development department, said today.

title: POP: HANRAHAN-BRUCE
description: -adrenalin concert Monday in the Public Theater by the Kip Hanrahan-Jack Bruce Band, Mr. Hanrahan slouched at stage right, occasionally whispering advice or giving a hand signal. He got top billing, however, because he had co- written most of the evening's songs for two albums he has produced, ''Coup de T^ete'' and ''Desire Develops an Edge.'' Mr. Bruce sang two of his own songs, but his main job was to play bass and sing Mr. Hanrahan's demanding vocal lines.

title: Indiana Fight By Utilities
description: Calling its former partner incompetent and deceitful, the Wabash Valley Power Association is vowing to block the effort by the Public Service Company of Indiana to write off the Marble Hill nuclear plant.

title: ROUND AND ROUND THEY GO
description: Shortly after noon yesterday, the

title: FISHER UNIT BREAKUP COMPLETED
description: The General Motors Corporation took another major step today in the sweeping reorganization of its North American automotive operations by announcing it had completed the breakup of its historic Fisher Body division.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The First of July is quiet and calm, The Second as peaceful as Boise; A cracker or two is heard on the Third, But the Fourth of July is noisy!WILLIAM COLE

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest fourth quarter include operations of Health Systems Inc., acquired Jan. 31, 1984.

title: Philadelphia Workers Reach Pact With City
description: A tentative agreement with no pay increase in the first year was reached today between the city and unions representing 13,600 employees, averting the threat of the first city employee strike in six years.

title: SCOTT'S HOSPITALITY reports earnings for Year to April 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Subway Songs

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
KIRK DOUGLAS TURNING TO TV WORK
description: A veteran of 72 movies, Kirk Douglas is one of the few surviving screen legends, but like other aging stars he has faced some difficulties in finding worthwhile film roles in recent years. Never one to sit back and complain about his lot, Mr. Douglas has turned an increasing amount of attention to television, where his opportunities are more wide-ranging.

title: LUXEMBOURG DRAWS IRE OVER TV SATELLITE PLAN
description: Tiny Luxembourg, a maverick in the tightly regulated world of European broadcasting, is planning on a big role in the multibillion-dollar market now emerging in Europe for commercial television.

title: IN PLAIN LANGUAGE, WHAT COST GOVERNMENT?
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Those waiting for the Lord & Taylor store on Fifth Avenue to open are invited in for a complimentary cup of coffee, which is served by a woman in a starched white apron from a tea cart adorned with one perfect red rose.

title: ;  Goodrich Announces Top Management Shifts
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company announced several top management appointments, but analysts said the changes do not signal a race for corporate succession at the Akron, Ohio, tire and chemical maker.

title: Toyota in Taiwan
description: Taiwan has approved a Toyota Motor Corporation plan to produce subcompact cars in cooperation with 11 Taiwanese companies, Taiwan's Deputy Economics Minister, Li Mo, said.

title: 16 STATE E.R.A.'S: A BOON TO WOMEN AND MEN
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS BACKED ON TAX-EXEMPT STATUS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal appeals court had improperly permitted a group of black parents to challenge the way in which the Internal Revenue Service grants tax exemptions to private schools.

title: Conservative Group Bids Unions Freeze Spending
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee today offered to call off its $12 million drive to re-elect President Reagan if organized labor would cease its activities in behalf of Walter F. Mondale.

title: Seaver Tops Tigers' Morris
description: Greg Luzinski drove in four runs, three with a roof-top homer, and Tom Seaver struck out seven batters to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 9-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight before 42,094 fans, the largest crowd of the season at Comiskey Park.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
AMERICANS IN OLYMPICS
description: WE hear more about the Olympics than we want to. The State Department talks about it at briefings; President Reagan mentions it in the Rose Garden. Products sold on television are now distinguished not by an Olympic endorsement, but by its absence. Then, just when we are sure it is all too much, we see something nice. Consider, for example, ''America at the Olympics,'' a two- hour special on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock tonight. It is uplifting and sentimental without being moralistic and smarmy.

title: HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
AN IDEALIST'S SHORT LIFE ENDS IN A KILLING IN A TOGO VILLAGE
description: Twelve months into her tour as a Peace Corps volunteer, Jennifer Lynn Rubin, a 23-year-old from Oneonta, N.Y., seemed finally to have come to terms with the loneliness of being the sole volunteer in the village of Defale, population 500, in the West African country of Togo.

title: Caterpillar Buys Stake in Robotics
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, in an attempt to stay competitive, has bought 20 percent of the Advanced Robotics Corporation, a maker of sophisticated industrial robots in Columbus, Ohio. Terms were not disclosed.

title: HARTFORD BILLED FOR PHONE CALLS BY AIDE'S FAMILY
description: State auditors said today that an undetermined number of personal long-distance calls had been charged to the state-issued telephone credit card of Connecticut's State Treasurer, Henry E. Parker.

title: A Movie Theater Taking Credit Cards
description: Moviegoers short on cash or weary of waiting in line for a cashier now can use credit cards to buy tickets from an automated-teller machine in a first- of-its kind experiment at a Dallas theater.

title: No Headline
description: Meese Gets New Delay On a Disclosure Form

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Business People column yesterday about the new senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York misidentified him. He is Frederick C. Schadrack.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: DUKE BOOTEE, Chops, Double Edge. These names may not mean much to the average reader or pop music listener. But these musicians - the singer-songwriter and producer Duke Bootee, the horn section Chops and the rhythm section Double Edge - make up the toughest, most inventive and most widely copied funk ensemble of the last several years. They have played as special guests with groups such as the Rolling Stones and the Police, and their ideas shaped some of the biggest rap and funk or dance-music hits of the 1980's, most notably the most innovative of all rap records, ''The Message,'' released in 1982.

title: THE DANCE: INDONESIANS AT AMERICAN FESTIVAL
description: One of the joys of seeing dances from other cultures is that of discovering unfamiliar ways of moving. Yet a presentation by a foreign company may also demonstrate that the dance world is truly one world by including material surprisingly similar to the dances of our own culture, even though the two cultures may not have borrowed from each other directly.

title: Topics Long Lines, Long Words
description: Civility in Dallas

title: RENTAL STORAGE SPACE FOR WINE BY CASE
description: -school yearbooks, ski racks, suitcases, evening dresses and neckties that may someday be back in style, wine is something most New Yorkers lack storage space for. A few cases may fit into the bottom of a closet or the corner of a dining area, but as makeshift wine cellars such locations are far from ideal.

title: A DAY FOR PICNICKING, COAST TO COAST
description: well, as the Fourth of July. This fine old tradition goes back at least to the early years of the 19th century, perhaps even to 1776, when Americans celebrated, with public noise and acclamation, the birth of a nation. There was a time when you could tell what part of the country you were in by the food that was served at the Fourth of July picnic, but that is no longer an entirely reliable indicator. These days, as a recent informal survey of picnicking habits around the country found, there are New England clambakes in the Texas Panhandle, salmon in the Recipes are on page C5. Southwestern desert, barbecues on the shores of Lake Michigan and Southern-style backyard pig roasts in Queens.

title: Doctors Push Ring Ban
description: The British Medical Association, citing the risk of brain damage and other injuries, extended its antiboxing campaign today to amateur matches.

title: 11 ARE INJURED IN SUBWAY FIRE
description: A fire on a subway car, parked on a spur near the stop at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, filled the station with smoke yesterday, injuring 11 people and forcing hundreds to leave the station.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,934,775 from discontinued operations. c-Net income including income of $205,711 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations in connection with the company's former subsidiary, Masters Merchandise Mart Inc.

title: THE REGION ; ;  FiscalPanelClears Plan for Yonkers
description: A state- imposed financial control board unanimously approved a four-year financial plan today for the fiscally strapped city of Yonkers.

title: COURT SAYS STATES CAN FORCE JAYCEES TO ADMIT WOMEN
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 7 to 0, that the all-male Jaycees organization could be required to accept women as members under state laws on discrimination.

title: Circle K Purchase
description: The General Post Corporation agreed to sell its 435 Little General Stores to the Circle K Corporation for about $100 million, the companies announced.

title: THE LONG WAIT FOR TAKEOFF CAUSES FRUSTRATION FOR MANY AT 3 MAJOR AIRPORTS
description: In airline jargon these days, the long line of planes waiting at the end of a runway to take off is somewhat jokingly known as a conga. But to most passengers this summer, the delays caused by the conga are no laughing matter.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Fannie Mae Move Aids Adjustable Mortgages

title: JULY 4, THE BEGINNING OF A PIPE DREAM
description: Today marks an anniversary of special significance for people everywhere who care about plumbing.

title: NEW EXPERIENCE
description: Only three of the players for the Los Angeles Express had any professional football playoff experience when they met the Michigan Panthers Saturday in a United States Football League game at Los Angeles.

title: NOTE AUCTION INSPIRES RALLY
description: Stronger-than-expected interest in yesterday's auction of new seven- year Treasury notes spurred a rally in the credit markets. Prices rose throughout the maturity range in what was described as moderate pre-holiday trading.

title: LONG LINES, LONG WORDS Reductionary A young man we know tried to memorize the dictionary when he was 16 so he'd never again run across a word he couldn't define. Another, less ambitious, read Time magazine with the dictionary at hand, looking up every word that stumped him. Most of us do neither. We try to figure out a strange word or just skip it, cursing the writer as a show-off.
description: Enter I.B.M. to relieve us of all pain. It was given Patent No. 4,456,973 last week for a proofreading system that automatically removes from a manuscript any word exceeding the comprehension of the intended readers and then substitutes an easier word.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
;  Manager Cries Foul
description: In his appeal of a $2,500 fine and one-year probation imposed on him by the New York State Athletic Commission for a June 1 melee in the ring after the Johnny Bumphus - Gene Hatcher bout, Lou Duva , Bumphus's manager, has several complaints. He accuses the commission of holding its hearings without notifying him or hearing his side and of four times telling the news media of its intention to take action against him without first telling him. He also contends that there were various errors by state inspectors, the timekeeper and the weigh-in officials.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Balboni Makes It

title: IRAN-IRAQ WAR IS REPORTED TO INTENSIFY AFTER A LULL
description: United States intelligence analysts said today that military action in the Iran-Iraq war had intensified after a lull of about a month, and they speculated that Iran might be on the verge of a long-expected offensive.

title: Blanton Starts Jail Term
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee entered a Federal prison Monday afternoon to begin a three-year term for extortion and conspiring to fix liquor licenses. Mr. Blanton, 53 years old, had faced a midnight deadline to report to the Maxwell Air Force Base Federal Prison Camp.

title: Kroger to Shut 70 of Its Stores
description: The Kroger Company said today that it would close 70 supermarkets in southeastern Michigan because progress has not been made in negotiations with the Retail Store Employees union on contract concessions.

title: Atlanta Air Terminal Razed
description: The old passenger terminal at Atlanta Hartsfield International Airport was demolished Sunday with 15 pounds of explosives. The 23-year-old terminal, abandoned in 1980 when Midfield Terminal opened, was too close to a fourth runway scheduled to open in October, said the Atlanta Aviation Commissioner, Calvin Carter.

title: Dow Rises by 4.20 After Late Advance
description: Stock prices, bolstered by short- covering and a firmer tone in the Treasury market, advanced moderately late yesterday after lanquishing for most of the pre-Fourth of July session.

title: THE WORTH OF ITALY'S ENRICO BERLINGUER AND THE PARTY HE LED
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 4, 1984

title: White Tigers Born in Zoo
description: Two white tiger cubs have been born at the Henry Doorly Zoo, raising the number of the rare animals there to six, said Director Lee Simmons.

title: GETTY DOMINATES BRITISH SALE OF ART
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif., carried off most of the major prizes at tonight's historic sale of old master drawings from the collection of the Duke of Devonshire.

title: By John Brooks;
description: LORDS, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN: A

title: ANTISATELLITE WEAPONS: WHAT THEY ARE AND DO
description: The possiblity that the United States and the Soviet Union will begin talking in September about a ban against weapons in space and especially antisatellite weapons has focused attention on such weapons and the feasibility of controlling them. Here, in question and answer form, are some of the issues involved.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  WEDNESDAY, JULY 4, 1984 International
description: U.S. acceptance of a Soviet proposal to hold talks on preventing the militarization of space was underscored in a statement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz during a 90-minute talk with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin, according to State Department officials. (Page A1, Column 6.) London chided Moscow for rebuffing an American acceptance of its offer to negotiate a ban on space weapons. Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, ending two days of talks with Soviet leaders, assured them that Washington set no preconditions for such a meeting. (A4:2-4.)

title: G.M. Modernizing
description: The General Motors Corporation has started a $154 million modernization project at its 65-year-old iron foundry after receiving a tax abatement from Saginaw and concessions from the United Automobile Workers union on job classifications. About $39 million will be spent installing a modern production line, said William O'Neill, a G.M. spokesman. Mr. O'Neill said employment, now at 3,300, would drop to about 2,350 during the project. Plans call for it to rise again to 3,000 at the plant, which makes cylinder blocks, brake drums, rotors and camshafts.

title: THE CITY ; ;  F.A.L.N. Witness GuiltyofContempt
description: A 32-year-old woman from Austin, Tex., was convicted yesterday of criminal contempt of court for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that is investigating bombings linked to the F.A.L.N., the group seeking independence for Puerto Rico.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HART DENIES USING SPIRITUAL ADVISER
description: Senator Gary Hart yesterday characterized as ''terribly inaccurate'' a report in a magazine article that an Indian woman was his spiritual adviser, and he said a mystical Indian ceremony described in the same article had been a park dedication.

title: PRISONERS FORFEIT RIGHTS TO PRIVACY, JUSTICES SAY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable search and seizure does not apply to prison cells. The 5-to-4 decision, written by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, came in one of the most bitterly disputed cases of the term.

title: THE CITY ; ;  UnificationChurch Told to Pay Fees
description: A Federal judge ruled in Manhattan yesterday that the Unification Church and one of its members must pay $79,000 in attorneys' fees and legal expenses from a lawsuit.

title: Bridge: Greenberg Team Is Winner Of Von Zedtwitz Knockout
description: A double that appears to be unique was completed at the Cavendish Club here Monday night. The final of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship was won by Alan Greenberg, Jim Cayne, Jim Rosenbloom and Matt and Pam Granovetter.

title: No Headline
description: A two-run double by the pitcher Charlie Puleo sparked a four-run sixth inning tonight as the Cincinnati Reds held on to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-5.

title: CHINA DEFENDS ABORTION IN BIRTH CONTROL EFFORTS
description: Critics of abortion as a means of birth control do not understand the problems that China faces in trying to limit its population growth, a spokesman for the Family Planning Commission said today.

title: Real Estate; Medical Space in Manhattan
description: ALTHOUGH home ownership through cooperatives and condominiums has been a significant part of the residential market in Manhattan for years, commercial condominiums and cooperatives have gained ground more slowly - particularly in the medical and dental professions.

title: The Fourth, at Moses Lake
description: Something special is happening today in Moses Lake, a small town on a big lake in central Washington. Shortly after noon a state police car will drive slowly into sight, lights flashing. The folks clustered along State Highway 17, chatting and playing, will suddenly fall still and reverent. In a moment, what they've been awaiting will appear. They will cheer, maybe even sing of America the beautiful. But not just because this is the Fourth of July.

title: Market Place; Stock Surge In Soft Drinks
description: WHILE the overall stock market continues to languish, soft drink issues are selling close to their 52-week highs.

title: U.S. ASSURES SOVIET IT WILL NEGOTIATE SPACE-ARMS ISSUES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz sent the Soviet Union a message today meant to underscore that the United States had accepted a proposal to hold space-weapon talks in September, State Department officials said.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Bill Wennington , the 7-foot center from St. John's and the Canadian Olympic basketball team, was released from St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan yesterday after suffering a concussion and bruised shoulder in a summer league game last Thursday. . . . The former Met pitcher Rick Ownbey is scheduled to start for the St. Louis Cardinals Saturday, his first major league appearance since being acquired with Neil Allen in the Keith Hernandez trade last summer. Ownbey started this season on the disabled list with a pulled hamstring and had a 2-3 record and a 4.67 earned run average in 7 games with Louisville in the American Association. . . . Bob Bell , the owner of the San Diego Sockers, said poor attendance may force him to fold the franchise for the outdoor season or move it to another city.

title: BALLET: NEW YORK MEDALISTS
description: CHEERS and boos brought the first New York International Ballet Competition to a rousing end on Monday at City Center. The cheers were for Victoria Mazzarelli of the United States, who won the competition's only gold medal. The boos were for the judges, as a silver medal for second prize was announced for Daniel Meja, a flamboyant dancer from France, whom the audience had clearly picked for another gold medal.

title: CAPITOL AIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
METS' HOMERS BEAT RYAN
description: If the Mets are looking for signs that they are a legitimate pennant contender, they may have spotted one last night. They battered Nolan Ryan of the Houston Astros for more earned runs than he had given up in his previous eight starts.

title: 'PERVERSE' OPPOSITION TO AN IMMIGRATION BILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Takeover Reports Cited in Carnation Trading
description: Reports of a possible takeover move yesterday touched off heavy trading in the common stock of the Carnation Company, the large California-based dairy and grocery products company. More than 856,000 of the company's 34.8 million common shares have changed hands in the last two days.

title: TEACHERS SEEK A LARGER ROLE
description: The National Education Association today approved a report on the condition of America's schools that the organization hopes will shift the debate on educational reform to the concerns expressed by teachers.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $69,000.

title: The National Collegiate Athletic
description: Association said today that a meeting of the 190 football-playing schools in Divisions I-A and I-AA would be held in Chicago next Tuesday to discuss a television plan that the association hopes will meet a Federal court's approval. An N.C.A.A. spokesman, Jim Shaffer, said at the organization's headquarters here that a specific plan to present to the Chicago meeting had not yet been worked out.

title: BOSTON U. FACULTY IS RULED UNABLE TO BARGAIN AS UNION
description: An administrative law judge has ruled that faculty members at Boston University are ''managers'' and ''supervisors'' and are thus not entitled to engage in collective bargaining under Federal law.

title: NAMING OF MRS. BURFORD PROMPTS CONFRONTATION
description: A luncheon called by President Reagan to build bridges to moderate environmental groups turned into a heated confrontation today when the environmental leaders expressed outrage at the appointment of Anne M. Burford to a Presidential commission.

title: THEATER: 'SACRAMENTS'
description: FEELING the warmth exuded by the appealing Quaigh Theater production of ''Sacraments,'' by Jo Ann Tedesco, is like going home to the old New York neighborhood for a visit. Everything seems smaller and a little seedier, the intonations in the voices sound as if you are in a foreign country, and nostalgia gives way to compassion.

title: SALVADOR REBELS BEGIN TO CONSCRIPT CIVILIANS
description: A senior Salvadoran guerrilla official said today that leftist rebels had started forcibly recruiting Salvadoran civilians.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline yesterday describing the method used in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll misstated the number of people interviewed. It was 1,593.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of my favorite remarks about food comes from A. J. Liebling, the great authority on boxing and many other things and a man with a remarkably keen and knowledgeable appetite. He was writing about Marcel Proust, whose name is invariably linked with those butter cookies called madeleines. It was supposedly those cookies that set Proust off on remembrances of things past.

title: 'OPTION' PROGRAM GIVES NEW HOPE TO TRADE SCHOOLS
description: In the early 1970's, Clara Barton Vocational High School in Brooklyn was dying. Students were shunning the programs it offered in such trades as cosmetology and dressmaking. Enrollment was plummeting.

title: GROWTH FUNDS LEAD IN GAINS
description: Mutual fund rankings turned topsy- turvy in the second quarter.

title: ;  Foot Fault
description: Put your left foot out, put your left foot back. That's no song and dance to Dave Rozema of the Detroit Tigers.

title: ;  Bobby Knight Speaks
description: If he ran a professional sports franchise, said Bobby Knight , the coach of the United States Olympic basketball team, the first thing he would do would be to dismiss the cheerleaders.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: We've Got the Beer

title: German Auto Lines Restart
description: West German car makers restarted assembly lines today as 25,000 metalworkers in the key Stuttgart industrial area ended a seven-week strike.

title: GARBAGE STRIKE FORCES ACTIONS BY JERSEY TOWNS
description: The scores of municipalities affected by a strike by garbage haulers have devised a variety of ways to cope with the growing mounds of household garbage.

title: 21ST CENTURY ROBOTICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WINE TALK
description: THE outdoors is overrated, at least as a place to eat. To anyone with any sense, the ideal picnic site is a good French restaurant with the windows open. How famous would Manet's ''Dejeuner sur l'Herbe'' be if the women had their clothes on? We Americans swing from one extreme to another - from smoke-filled steakhouses to the wide open spaces.

title: MONDALE AND JACKSON TELL N.A.A.C.P. MEETING THAT REAGAN IS THE ENEMY
description: Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, sounding familiar themes at the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called on blacks and members of other minority groups today to gather their powers to defeat President Reagan in November.

title: BRITON CHIDES KREMLIN FOR REBUFFING THE U.S.
description: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, ended two days of talks here today and chided his hosts for rebuffing an American acceptance of Moscow's offer to negotiate a ban on space arms.

title: BIOGRAPHER FINDS DIFFERENT JEFFERSON
description: He is 92 years old and nearly blind. But Dumas Malone, who completed his masterly six-volume biography of Thomas Jefferson only three years ago, is still writing about the author of the Declaration of Independence and is still as curious as Jefferson was about the springs of human action and the trajectory of American history.

title: CPAC INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
DOLLAR UP SHARPLY IN JITTERY DAY
description: The dollar soared in relation to other major currencies in hectic worldwide trading yesterday, apparently in response to a recent sharp increase in overnight interest rates in the United States.

title: LEBANESE MILITIAS WITHDRAW ARMOR
description: A Government peace plan intended to reunite East and West Beirut, reopen the airport and harbor and end months of factional violence began to be put into effect here today.

title: STRATHCONA RESOURCES INDUSTRIEStr to May 31 reports earnings for 1984
description: b-After a $49,000 special gain. c-Net income after a special gain of $98,000.

title: REGGAE: AT RITZ, STEEL PULSE BAND
description: STEEL PULSE, the reggae band from Birmingham, England, that played for four nights at the Ritz last week, turns a resolute message into assured, dignified songs.

title: Mobil, Superior In Stock Plan
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that the Superior Oil Company had granted it permission to buy more than 9.9 percent of Superior's stock on the open market or in private transactions. A $5.7 billion merger agreement between the two, reached last March, called for Mobil to pay shareholders $45 a share in cash or securities, except for 9.9 percent that Mobil could buy in the market.

title: Lawyer Seeking Control of CFS
description: A Washington lawyer said he was seeking control of the CFS Corporation, parent of the Westport-based County Federal Savings and Loan Association. The lawyer, Arthur D. Mason, said he had agreed to buy CFS stock held by Harvey L. Koizim, its president and largest shareholder. Mr. Koizim owns 20.5 percent of CFS.

title: LED ALGERIA PLOT
description: Gen. Raoul Salan, once France's most decorated soldier, who led an attempt in 1961 to overthrow President Charles de Gaulle and who organized a terrorist group opposed to independence for Algeria, died yesterday in Paris. He was 85 years old.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Death Penalty Bill Is Urged by Koch
description: Mayor Koch yesterday called on the State Legislature to reconvene next week so that it could pass a new death penalty bill.

title: MISS JORDAN AND MISS NAVRATILOVA GAIN
description: Kathy Jordan, who has the cockiness and attacking style to challenge Martina Navratilova, will get her chance in the Wimbledon semifinals as a result of her 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 upset victory over Pam Shriver today.

title: HISPANIC WORKERS SAY HOUSE'S IMMIGRATION BILL DEMONSTRATES INGRATITUDE
description: By his own description, Jose Rodriguez, a retired welder living in the large West Side barrio here, ''drips pride like perspiration.''

title: GENOCIDE'S PRINCIPAL FEE
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholar Sees New Role For Vice Presidents
description: A ''new Vice Presidency'' has developed since the Watergate scandals, a political scholar says, and those who want to be selected by Walter F. Mondale better be ready to give the chief his due, fall in line behind controversial decisions and ''share the dirty work.''

title: CITY CRACKS DOWN ON STREET CRIMES
description: More police officers will be assigned to deal with such ''quality of life'' crimes as prostitution, gambling, drug dealing and vandalism under a reorganization plan announced yesterday by the Police Department.

title: Smaller Rises In Phone Rates
description: Despite complaints about rising local telephone rates, a new industry survey shows the 21.5 million customers of the phone companies not formerly associated with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company experienced smaller rate increases in 1983 than during any year since 1980. The annual survey by the United States Telephone Association found the 1,400 local independent companies that serve 20 percent of the nation's telephone customers were authorized to raise rates by $510 million in 1983.

title: 2 ITEMS, IN SEASON
description: THE variety of fresh fish is at its peak now. A favorite way to prepare fish is to roast it whole with herbs and white wine. Unlike Europeans, Americans have a fondness for fish fillets. While easier to handle and serve, they are, I believe, less flavorful than fish cooked whole.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ed Lynch, fighting a pitching slump after his early-season success, wraps up the series against Houston. The game will be followed by a holiday fireworks display. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Portuguese Wins 5th Stage of Tour
