description: Paulo Fereira of Portugal led a three-man break at the start today, then captured the fifth stage of the Tour de France bicycle race in a sprint finish. His time for the 128.6 miles from Bethune was 4 hours 49 minutes 45 seconds, for an average speed of 26.63 miles an hour.

title: No Headline
description: Muzzled - in Paraguay For most of his 30 years in power, nobody paid much attention to Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, leader of the dusty fiefdom of Paraguay. But change beckons there, and General Stroessner seems perplexed by the attention he's now getting.

title: 11 Charged in Rigging Of Casino Slot Machines
description: Eleven people were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in connection with a ring accused of rigging at least $3.25 million in slot machine jackpots in New Jersey and Nevada

title: TWO GERMANYS SAID TO DISCUSS BROAD ACCORDS
description: In a development that appeared to presage a significant improvement in their relations, the two Germanys were reported tonight to be negotiating an ambitious package of agreements.

title: NOW RESOLUTION MEETING OPPOSITION OF FEMINISTS
description: There were only three dissenting votes when the National Organization for Women adopted a resolution in Miami Beach Sunday urging that a woman be nominated for Vice President from the floor of the Democratic convention if Walter F. Mondale selected a man for that post.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: and American exercise enthusiasts - go out in the noonday sun on days when heat and humidity turn the outdoors into a steam bath. For some the result of their exertion is a heat-induced illness that, in its most severe form, can be fatal.

title: Polygram And Warner
description: An appellate court is considering arguments presented Monday by Warner Communications Inc. and Polygram Records Inc. that their proposed merger could not monopolize the record industry because people who tape music at home keep the market competitive.

title: Key Bolivian Official Implicated in Plot
description: The army high command has dismissed Bolivia's second-ranking defense official and declared him a suspect in an attempted coup against the Government of President Hernan Siles Zuazo, according to an army officer.

title: Sydney Eckman Ahlstrom, Scholar of Religious History
description: Dr. Sydney Eckman Ahlstrom, retired Samuel Knight Professor of American History and Modern Religious History at Yale University, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Union Endorsement Denied
description: The president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers said today that he personally backed President Reagan's campaign for re-election, but he denied that his 40,000-member union had endorsed the President.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co., St. Paul, has appointed William B. R. Hobbs president of its American Crane division.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Grocery Jobs Up, U.S. Official Says
description: The Government's chief labor statistician for the New York area yesterday disputed a statement by Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, that a declining number of supermarkets in the city meant a loss of jobs.

title: Salvador Strike Delays Mail
description: A strike by postal workers in El Salvador is delaying mail to and from that country, the United States Postal Service said today. Mail to El Salvador will continue to be accepted, but it will be held by the Postal Service until regular operations resume in El Salvador.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations.

title: KOREA UTILITY AUDIT CRITICAL OF BECHTEL
description: Auditors for the South Korean Electric Power Company have charged that the Bechtel Group was overpaid $16 million by the Korean utility. The charges were made in an unpublished audit report made available recently by sources in Korea.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT DECISION ON JAYCEE RULE BARRING WOMEN AS MEMBERS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that the all-male Jaycees organization has no constitutional right to exclude women. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the majority opinion.

title: POP: GO-GO'S AT RADIO CITY
description: LIKE much new wave rock, the cheerful pop minimalism of the Go-Go's, the Los Angeles quintet of women who helped initiate the current ''girl group'' revival, has always bordered on parody. Their charming but limited style of rock - sketchy two-and three- chord songs with comic book lyrics - is a conscious reduction of pop form to an unsophisticated rock-and-roll essence.

title: IF A HOST MUST BE A DRUNKEN GUEST'S KEEPER
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Is Set Free After 2 Years in a Cage
description: A woman whose husband kept her locked in a cagelike bedroom was freed after the police received a tip that she had not been seen for two years, the authorities said today. No charges were filed.

title: MONDALE AND JACKSON ARE UPBEAT AFTER MEETING DESPITE DIFFERENCES
description: Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson met today for more than two hours, but they apparently failed to resolve some key differences.

title: ;  Option Offered On Ohio Edison
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment bank with the most experience in convertible adjustable rate preferred offerings, yesterday informed potential bidders on an upcoming issue of a new wrinkle designed to increase its attractiveness.

title: Economic Scene; Views Differ On Tax Effort
description: WASHINGTON IN much of the country, Wall Street and Washington are regarded as not-so-different arms of an

title: WHY JEFFERSON FAINTED
description: Following is an executive summary of a declaration of independence as it has surfaced after having been signed off on by all of the appropriate bureaus, agencies and departments of the Continental Congress.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; A Florida Banker Likes a Battle . . .
description: Joel R. Wells Jr. was fresh out of the University of Florida Law School in 1951 when he took on the Federal Government's use of eminent domain. The Government was trying to buy land at low prices for its missile testing site on Cape Canaveral, later Cape Kennedy. In the end, Mr. Wells won that battle.

title: VIETNAM REFUGEES FACE AN INCREASING SAVAGERY
description: In some ways, May was a relatively good month for those Vietnamese refugees whose small boats completed their voyage across the Gulf of Thailand.

title: Continental Plans Leasing Unit Sale
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation plans to sell its leasing subsidiary, the Continental Illinois Leasing Corporation, the banking company said.

title: Appleton Papers
description: A subsidiary of B.A.T Industries, Appleton Papers Inc., intends to buy the West Carrollton, Ohio, paper mill of the P. H. Glatfelter Company for about $83 million, a B.A.T spokesman said.

title: HELPED DESIGN STRATEGIC PLAN
description: Maj. Gen. Donald R. Morelli, retired, one of the major architects of the United States Army's new fighting doctrine of mobiity and quick counterattack behind enemy lines, died last week of cancer after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

title: BYSTROM IS WINNER IN DEBUT AS YANKEE
description: Marty Bystrom, beginning his American League career, became, at least for a night, the Yankee stopper. He helped the team to a 5-4 victory tonight over the Texas Rangers and put an end to the Yankees' four-game losing streak.

title: Market Place; G.M. Attracts More Interest
description: THE General Motors Corporation's planned

title: NEW YORKERS CELEBRATE A DANDY FOURTH OF JULY
description: It was a day for revelry both wacky and wondrous.

title: CITY CITES MIXED SUCCESS IN CUTTING OVERTIME
description: While New York City's attempts to control overtime have shown ''a lot of success'' in the last two years, Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff said yesterday, the amount of overtime pay going to workers who are eligible for retirement is still ''very troublesome.''

title: RETAILER SEEKS GROWTH WITH A SIMPLE STRATEGY
description: In these days of carefully honed corporate strategic plans, Dillard Department Stores has a simpler plan than most.

title: Police in Kashmir Open Fire on Rioters
description: The police opened fire and used tear gas today to disperse stone-throwing demonstrators as violence broke out after the replacement of the Chief Minister of Kashmir.

title: HERS
description: THE loneliness of separate living, the indignities of legal and financial settlements, the sadness of separate parenthood: I have come through all of them. What is left to separate from is the house.

title: Becker Paribas Picks New Operating Chief
description: Becker Paribas Inc., a Wall Street investment firm that has suffered its share of internal turmoil in the last two years, has a new chief operating officer: Randy A. Harris.

title: No Headline
description: Copper Train Derails; 'Sabotage' Is Blamed

title: 14 DIE AS ROOMING HOUSE IN MASSACHUSETTS BURNS
description: An old, three-story rooming house whose occupants were poor, retarded or former mental patients burned today, killing 14 people and injuring 13. Two people were believed missing.

title: JUDGE ACCEPTS REDUCED PLEA IN FATAL CRASH
description: A driver who was indicted for manslaughter after his concrete-mixer truck crashed into a parked car and killed a woman and her two children last year in Manhattan has been permitted to plead guilty to reduced charges with a promise of no prison term.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JULY 5, 1984

title: Philippine Protesters Reproach U.S. on the 4th
description: About 500 demonstrators paraded outside the United States Embassy today, marked here as Philippine-American Friendship Day, to protest United States bases and Washington's support for President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: RIFT WIDENS AMONG BRAZIL'S RULERS
description: Brazil's civilian Vice President, Aureliano Chaves, ended his bid last night for the governing party's presidential nomination and moved closer to an open break with the departing military regime.

title: NIEKRO RECORDS 3,000TH CAREER STRIKEOUT
description: Perhaps the most intriguing element to Phil Niekro's milestone night was his pre-game comment: ''I'm not always sure of the knuckleball. Sometimes it explodes on me and I don't why.''

title: Change of Scene
description: Most horseplayers welcome, with unrestrained delight, each spring's shift of racing from Aqueduct to Belmont Park. The surroundings are prettier, the racing is classier, and everyone seems in a better mood.

title: Alumni Woes
description: Though Tuesday night may have marked another good performance by the Mets' young staff, it wasn't such a hot evening for their pitching alumni who are scattered around the major leagues.

title: THE BEST PERSON
description: Now that the U.S. has celebrated another birthday, it's a moment to think of what it means to be a year older.

title: WELL-EARNED REST FOR A RESTLESS RUNNER
description: And on the third day, Joe Record

title: Fluke and Bluefish Plentiful
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Bluefish up to 16 pounds and more are being caught offshore with some consistency. Fluke fishing in Margate Bay remains excellent. Barnegat, N.J.: Party boat fishing for medium to large bluefish is excellent. Seaside Park, N.J.: Small bluefish are being taken from the surf and from Barnegat Bay. Fluke fishing in the Bay is good.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 5, 1984 International
description: Changes in a U.S.-Honduran accord will be sought by Honduras in an effort to win more economic and military benefits, according to Honduras military officials. They said a Honduran commission was studying the 1954 military agreement and would ask Washington for such changes as preferential trade arrangements and increased Honduran control over United States military personnel. (Page A1, Column 3.) English-speaking Caribbean leaders opened their first meeting since the United States-led invasion of Grenada last October and raised the question whether their 12-year-old regional organization can survive. Four of the 13 member countries opposed the invasion and others are at odds over economic policies. (A3:1-3.)

title: EX-DIRECTOR OF NAACP LEGAL FUND REFLECTS ON STATE OF CIVIL RIGHTS
description: One day recently, Jack Greenberg reflected on the great strides made by the civil rights movement in his 35 years with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc.

title: FIT TO FIGHT TAKES SUBURBAN
description: Track Barron and Fit to Fight posted easy and popular victories in Grade I races at Belmont Park yesterday to affirm the leadership of their respective divisions in New York.

title: IN THE CITY
description: Watering Street Trees

title: LEBANON'S TROOPS REPLACING MILITIAS
description: Soldiers of the rebuilt Lebanese Army moved foward today in jeeps, tanks and armored vehicles to take over positions from militia units that seized complete control of this city five months ago.

title: SEVERAL BLACK MUSLIMS DENOUNCE FARRAKHAN
description: Black Muslim leaders and Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion, denounced the Rev. Jesse Jackson today for associating with the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, leader of a Black Muslim sect.

title: STEEP DROP IN ORDERS FOR STEEL
description: Orders for steel, which plummeted in the second quarter, are expected to rise in the next few months. But they are expected to remain below the robust levels of early this year.

title: No Headline
description: Permanent Prison Is the Answer For those who believe in capital punishment, Lemuel Smith seemed the perfect person for whom to reactivate New York's electric chair. Already serving long prison sentences for murder, he was convicted of savagely killing Donna Payant, a guard at Green Haven, and dumping her mutilated body in the prison trash. Could some mitigating circumstance possibly argue against his execution? Because the courts had no way to know, New York's highest court struck down the law that made death in such a case mandatory.

title: Fugitive in Prison Deaths Said to Plan Surrender
description: Stephen M. Bingham, a fugitive lawyer accused of smuggling a pistol to a prison revolutionary, George Jackson, before San Quentin's bloodiest breakout attempt in 1971, wants to turn himself in to face murder charges, one of his attorneys said today.

title: REAGAN CONTENDS JACKSON'S MISSIONS MAY VIOLATE LAW
description: President Reagan has questioned the legality of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's missions of personal diplomacy and cautioned against his traveling to Moscow to seek the release of Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist.

title: PONDERING THE SECRETS PHOTOGRAPHS REVEAL;
description: MAYBE I've grown too accustomed to experiencing ideas and people through the medium of written language, but reading Patricia Bosworth's recently published biography of Diane Arbus, I was struck anew by the tantalizingly mute ambiguity of photography. Mrs. Arbus put it well when she said: ''A photograph is a secret about a secret. The more it tells you the less you know.'' In John McPhee's new book, ''La Place de la Concorde Suisse'' - which is a report, in the author's inimitably charming style, on how the Swiss intend to prolong their 500 years of neutrality by remaining armed to the tips of their alps - there is a story that nicely illustrates the degree of photography's ambiguity.

title: No Headline
description: Three Ohio Hospitals In Transplant Accord

title: TECHNOLOGY: THE JAPANESE CHALLENGE ; THE PATENT AS TRADE BARRIER
description: In 1973, the Allied Corporation applied for a patent in Japan covering a new type of material known as amorphous metals.

title: AUTO WORKERS AWAIT REAGAN VISIT
description: In the summer of 1980, after more than a decade of bolting armrests onto automobile doors on one General Motors assembly line or another, Rich Kaltner was laid off. So was Mark Thornberry, whose job was stretching fabric for seat covers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Weighty Mail

title: IN THE COUNTRY
description: Under Control

title: No Headline
description: Mathias Komor Dies; Expert on Antiquities

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Planting the Flag

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Petranoff of U.S. Beaten in Javelin

title: VOCATIONAL SCHOOLS: PROBLEMS AMID INNOVATIONS
description: Faced with rapid changes in the workplace and uncertainty about the skills needed to perform the jobs of the future, vocational high schools in New York City are developing new ways to practice some very traditional educational ideas. In doing so, they are finding that some of their most fundamental problems, such as how to give graduates the flexibility to move from one job to another, are virtually identical to those faced by academic high schools.

title: DISABLED'S ADDED LOAD
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPERIOR BLENDERS OF SOCIAL AND LEGAL STUDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fledgling Sparrows

title: MARTY BYSTROM:RELUCTANT YANKEE
description: Marty Bystrom did not have the Yankee dream. He says that it does not really exist, ''not anymore, not the way people think.''

title: PERU CONSIDERING MARTIAL LAW
description: More than 140 people have died in the last two weeks as a result of growing guerrilla attacks and President Fernando Belaunde Terry may declare martial law, a Presidential spokesman said today.

title: DESIGN FOR TIMES SQUARE:PROBLEMS REMAIN
description: When New York City's Public Development Corporation and the New York State Urban Development Corporation disclosed plans for four immense office towers at Times Square last December, the reaction was mixed at best. There were some cautiously positive responses and some strongly negative ones. What was missing was enthusiastic support, even from civic groups that had supported the master plan for the Times Square area, of which these towers, designed by John Burgee Architects with Philip Johnson, were a part.

title: TO AGREE ON ARMS
description: Washington and Moscow have now exchanged several much-publicized offers to resume arms control negotiations - and in each case the other side dismissed the offer as propaganda almost as soon as it was put forward. President Reagan has repeatedly declared his readiness for talks and for a real reduction of nuclear arms. But his policies have not matched his rhetoric.

title: DOLLAR RISE IS DEFYING PREDICTIONS
description: The value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets continues to rise, postponing what has been a long-expected decline and confounding many economists.

title: DEVICES THAT TALK AND LISTEN
description: * I'll turn myself off in 59 minutes. Good Night.''

title: TEACHERS' GATHERING HAS THE TRAPPINGS OF A PARTY CONVENTION
description: A visitor stumbling into the annual meeting here of the National Education Association might have mistaken the gathering for a trial run of the Democratic National Convention.

title: INDEPENDENCE DAY FOR THE METS
description: When the Mets celebrated July 4 with fireworks at Shea Stadium last night, they were also celebrating their declaration of independence from ineptitude. Having been in last place three times since 1977 when games of July 4 were concluded, in fifth place twice and as high as fourth place only once, they have emerged as contenders in the National League East again. Which prompted a question for Keith Hernandez.

title: Briton's Moscow Visit Criticized by Laborites
description: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, who returned Tuesday from Moscow, was branded here today as an election-year cheerleader and messenger boy for President Reagan.

title: Coast Fire Destroys Offices Of Group Doubting Holocaust
description: Offices of the Institute for Historical Review, an organization that contends the genocide of Jews during World War II is a myth, were destroyed today in a fire believed set by arsonists, the authorities said.

title: IN GREECE, NUDIST PLAN MEETS CHILL
description: The Government's efforts to introduce nudist resorts in Greece on a large scale this year to foster tourism have failed because of a lack of public support.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm going to have more, God willing.'' - Maria Gon,calves Moreira, of Rio de Janeiro, after the birth of her 10th set of twins. (A2:4.)

title: MCENROE, CONNORS, LENDL IN SEMIFINALS
description: Two engaging young qualifiers, who went further than they had dared to expect in reaching the Wimbledon tennis quarterfinals, were routed on Centre Court today by two champions who have won a total of 23 Grand Slam titles.

title: FOR SOME ATHLETES, IT'S HARDLY A HOLIDAY
description: While millions of people in the metropolitan area used the Independence Day holiday to relax in a variety of ways, more than 500 hardy souls celebrated by straining their muscles in athletic competitions designed to lead to exhaustion.

title: All-Star Voting
description: Final results of the fan balloting for the 1984 American League All-Star team: FIRST BASE 1, Rod Carew, California, 1,219,420 votes; 2, Eddie Murray, Baltimore, 1,128,745; 3, Darrell Evans, Detroit, 662,213; 4, Cecil Cooper, Milwaukee, 427,630; 5, Willie Upshaw, Toronto, 395,483; 6, Bill Buckner, Boston, 312,008; 7, Kent Hrbek, Minnesota, 251,150; 8, Tom Paciorek, Chicago, 221,783. SECOND BASE 1, Lou Whitaker, Detroit, 1,341,177; 2, Bobby Grich, California, 588,897; 3, Damaso Garcia, Toronto, 493,670; 4, Julio Cruz, Chicago, 445,297; 5, Willie Randolph, Yankees, 434,833; 6, Jim Gantner, Milwaukee, 379,859; 7, Frank White, Kansas City, 372,577; 8, Rich Dauer, Baltimore, 240,360. THIRD BASE 1, George Brett, Kansas City, 1,594,542; 2, Doug DeCinces, California, 880,441; 3, Wade Boggs, Boston, 563,149; 4, Buddy Bell, Texas, 415,525; 5, Vance Law, Chicago, 222,383; 6, Carney Lansford, Oakland, 202,581; 7, John Castino, Minnesota, 137,292; 8, Toby Harrah, Yankees, 120,213.

description: Chile Withdraws Its Soccer Team

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BLOOD OF HIS SERVANTS. By PietMalcolm C. MacPherson. 310 pages. Times Books. $16.95.

title: SALVADOR INSURGENTS SAY CHURCH FAVORS THE RICH
description: Leftist rebels, in what is believed to be their first such denunciation of Roman Catholic Church leaders, have said that the church has begun favoring the rich over the poor.

title: CONCERT:JAMES RICHMAN
description: IT is the business of the concerto

title: Cubs and Sutcliffe Top Padres SAN DIEGO, July 4 (AP) - Rick Sutcliffe pitched the Cubs into sole possession of first place in the National League East and doubled in a run as Chicago defeated the San Diego Padres, 2-1, tonight.
description: The crowd of 52,134 was the largest to see a baseball game in San Diego, helped by the opening of San Diego Jack Murphy Stadium's new right- field stands.

title: WITH A 'SIR' AT STAKE, FLORIDAN WINS THE DAY
description: To hundreds who have not actually met him, he is the frail, white-haired steward who on a Saturday or Sunday once showed them to a seat in Canterbury Cathedral. He has been a banker and a British Army officer. In childhood, his mother introduced him as ''the little baronet.''

title: JAZZ:PASTORIUS LEADS SEXTET
description: IN the sextet that Jaco Pastorius

title: THE YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY WITH CONGRESS
description: A little- noticed episode in the final days before the Congressional recess last week sheds considerable light on the difficulties President Reagan has had getting his legislative program enacted this year.

title: RARELY USED STATUTE BARS POLICY DEALINGS BY CITIZENS ABROAD
description: Legal questions about the Rev. Jesse Jackson's diplomatic activities focus on an 185- year-old law that forbids American citizens to interfere in the foreign policy of the United States, according to Government and private lawyers.

title: INCOME TAX LAW ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CHILDREN'S SERIES
description: NICKELODEON, the Warner Amex cable service that tries to be ''devoted to children without being childish,'' is bringing a new 52-episode animated series to its schedule this week. ''Belle and Sebastian'' will be shown Mondays through Fridays at 8 A.M. and 3:30 P.M. (In Manhattan, the service is carried on Group W's Channel J and Manhattan Cable's Channel K.)

title: Ellis E. Paul, 83, Supervisor OfMajorBridgeConstruction
description: Ellis E. Paul, a bridge engineer who was a partner in the firm of Howard Needles Tammen & Bergendoff in Manhattan, died Sunday in a hospital in Tucson, Ariz. He was 83 years old and had lived in Tucson since his retirement in 1966.

title: Veeck's Hip Fractured
description: Bill Veeck , the 70-year-old former owner of the White Sox, fell and fractured his right hip while grocery shopping Tuesday in Chicago and was listed in stable condition yesterday at Illinois Masonic Hospital. His wife, Mary Frances , said that Veeck, who lost part of his right leg while serving with the Marine Corps in World War II, had slipped on the contents of a jar that had fallen from a shelf and broken. A hospital spokesman described Veeck as ''fine'' and added, ''He's talking on the phone, and he has visitors.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CHINESE AND INDIANS The celebration of 200 years of trade with China that has been making the rounds of several New York museums this year arrives today at the Museum of the American Indian, at Broadway and 155th Street (283- 2420), on Audubon Terrace - that classic uptown enclave that is home for a clutch of great institutions.

title: No Headline
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified the company that has agreed to sell its Little General Stores to the Circle K Corporation. It is the General Host Corporation.

title: Mechanix Illustrated To Phase In New Name
description: Within the next two years CBS Publications' Mechanix Illustrated, founded in 1928, will have changed its name to Home Mechanix, which will better reflect the subtitle - Helps You Manage Your House & Auto Better - and the editorial side's new direction.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR EASIER GARDENING
description: A SELECTION of versatile gardening equipment particularly useful for elderly and disabled people is available through the Smith & Hawken Ltd. catalogue.

title: N.C.A.A. SUBMITS MODIFIED TV PLAN
description: One week after the Supreme Court voided its exclusive control of college football telecasts, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has given a Federal judge here specific proposals on how it might be allowed to exercise reduced control.

title: ROOMS TO AID LIBRARY
description: -FIVE interior designers - from the established to the fledgling - volunteered to put their personal stamps on rooms in the Irving Town Houses on First Neck Lane in Southampton, L.I. The show, which benefits the Rogers Memorial Library in Southampton, is well worth a detour. High points include Zajac & Callahan's splendid yellow room, above left; David Barrett's trompe l'oeil storage, above, and lots of not-to-be- missed spaces - particularly the small, serene room by Ronald Bricke and Austin Chinn, with paneling in the style of Mackintosh; Albert Hadley's oversize collage; J. Allen Murphy's Swiss chalet-like room, and Tim Romanello's room with antique bathtub, left.

title: FAKED MORGUE PHOTOGRAPH HELPS SNARE SUSPECT IN PLOT
description: A contractor going through a divorce and child custody dispute appeared to be grief-stricken when sheriff's investigators showed him a photograph of his wife on a morgue slab, the authorities said Tuesday.

title: THEATRICAL GAMBLES PAY OFF FOR THE GUTHRIE
description: In the mid-1960's, an American theater critic described the Old Vic as England's version of the Guthrie Theater here. If he erred - the Old Vic predating the Guthrie by 145 years - the mistake was in some respects forgivable.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Top Murdock Aide In Biggest Deal Yet
description: Raymond F. Henze 3d was prospecting for loan customers for Citicorp when he signed his first deal with David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles financier, in 1975. It was the start of a relationship that has propelled Mr. Henze, now 31 years old, onto center stage in many major corporate dramas.

title: 23 PROMINENT WOMEN TO SUPPORT MONDALE EVEN IF HE PICKS A MAN
description: A delegation of 23 women, many of them well-known feminists and politicians, urged Walter F. Mondale today to select a woman as running mate. But they made it plain they would work actively for Mr. Mondale's candidacy if he chose a man.

title: Indian Group Occupies Wisconsin Bingo Hall
description: Dozens of dissident Winnebago Indians put down their pistols and clubs today but vowed to continue occupying a bingo parlor while awaiting a decision from Federal officials in a tribal leadership battle.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Tint for Ferry

title: WINFIELD VOTED TO ALL-STARS
description: Dave Winfield, the major leagues' leading hitter with a .374 average, led American League outfielders in fan voting for the 55th All-Star Game next Tuesday at Candlestick Park in San Francisco. He was the only Yankee chosen in the fan balloting, the results of which were announced by the commissioner's office yesterday.

title: ROYAL PREROGATIVE (2)
description: The Americans who rebelled against a King 208 years ago feared concentrated power. They doubted that even democratic elections were enough of a safeguard against that threat, and so they wrote a Constitution that hedged power in and divided it among branches of government. By those ''auxiliary precautions,'' Madison said, they hoped to preserve liberty.

title: U.S. PRESSING EFFORTS TO AIRPLANES AGAINST WIND SHEAR
description: The Federal Government is stepping up its efforts to combat the problem of wind shear, which has emerged as one of the worst safety hazards bedeviling the aviation industry.

title: Petty Posts 200th Victory
description: Richard Petty outdueled Cale Yarborough and coasted to his 200th career Grand National victory, winning the Firecracker 400 today before a crowd of 80,000 and President Reagan, who had signaled the start of the race via radio from Air Force One. Petty, who celebrated his 47th birthday Monday, took the checkered flag under the third caution period and completed the 400-mile event in 2 hours 19 minutes 59 seconds at an average speed of 171.204 miles per hour.

title: Reagan Aide Sees Error In Appointment Timing
description: President Reagan's chief campaign strategist today acknowledged the controversy over the naming of Anne M. Burford to head a new environmental study and called the timing of the appointment a mistake.

title: HUMANS AND INSECTS APPEAR TO SHARE FRAGMENT OF GENE
description: Researchers in the United States and Switzerland have identified a fragment of a gene that appears to be common to human beings, flies, earthworms, chickens and frogs.

title: Hart and Mondale Plan Joint Effort to Pay Debts
description: Senator Gary Hart said today that he and Walter F. Mondale had agreed to ''joint efforts'' to help each other erase their campaign debts after the Democratic National Convention.

title: NEW MUSIC:FESTIVAL MARCHES ON IN HARTFORD
description: In 1979, a loose alliance of experimental-music composers and presenting organizations banded together at the Kitchen in New York to stage a weeklong festival called New Music New York. Since then, under the title New Music America, the festival has become an annual event. The sites vary from year to year, with each year's program reflecting the local coloration.

title: Mondale to Help Party In Quest for $25 Million
description: Walter F. Mondale is hoping to help the debt-ridden Democratic Party raise $25 million by November in its quest for the White House and control of Congress, an aide said today.

title: CHIEF OF N.A.A.C.P. ASSAILS PRESIDENT
description: The executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today condemned the policies of the Reagan Administration as a ''virus'' that, if not checked, could set back the rights of blacks and other minority groups for generations to come.

title: Tigers Lose 4th Game in Row CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) - Richard Dotson checked Detroit on three hits over eight innings tonight, leading the Chicago White Sox to an 8-2 victory that sent the Tigers to a four-game losing streak for the first time this season.
description: Dotson (11-4) walked two and struck out two before giving way to Al Jones to start the ninth.

title: Susan Klein Married To Solomon Warhaftig
description: Susan F. Klein and Solomon L. Warhaftig, cum laude graduates of the Harvard Law School who practice in New York, were married yesterday at Congregation Shearith Israel (the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue). Rabbi Solomon Gaon, director of the Sephardic studies program at Yeshiva University and former chief Sephardic rabbi of the British Commonwealth, and the Rev. A. Lopes Cardozo, a cantor, officiated.

title: THE APPEAL OF BRONX LIVING
description: a loan officer with the Chase Manhattan Bank - lived in a studio apartment on the Upper East Side that she gradually outgrew. She looked for something larger on the Upper West Side, then in the East 30's, but could not find an apartment with the space she needed at a price she could afford.

title: A PUSH TO SET STANDARDS FOR 'FINANCIAL PLANNERS'
description: Dorothy Fiedler got upset when her husband, an engineer, received an unsolicited letter inviting him to try his hand at becoming a ''financial planner.''

title: Bridge:Odd Explanation of a Loss In Jersey Knockout Match
description: Players who lose a team match against opponents whom they ought, on paper, to defeat have a wide variety of explanations available to them. Commonest are the complimentary, ''They played very well,'' the contrite, ''We played badly'' or the sour, ''They were lucky.''

title: Technology; An Electronic O.E.D. Edition
description: SINCE the first edition was published 100 years ago, the Oxford English Dictionary has stood as the last word on the English language. From that first volume - which covered the language from ''A'' to ''Ant'' and was edited by James Murray, a Scotsman who dropped out of school at age 14 - it has grown to more than 500,000 entries. Today there are 13 volumes and three supplements, more than 20,000 pages of definitions, etymological history and literary allusions.

title: U.S. Bond Sale
description: A Market Test

title: WORKERS TO VOTE ON TRASH WALKOUT
description: The leaders of 1,400 striking garbage haulers said today that they and the struck companies had accepted a proposal under which the haulers would return to work while a new contract was negotiated.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Belgian Captures 6th Stage of Tour

title: NETWORKS CUT CONVENTION COVERAGE
description: At the 1948 Republican National Convention, which was not the first televised convention - 1940 was the landmark year - a very hot Edward R. Murrow sat with two colleagues, looked through the camera lens and said: ''It must be the heat. Here are three reporters. We've been here 10 minutes and all we've said is that nothing much happened today, or, if it did, we don't know about it.''

title: MONDALE, CHAMPION OF THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: On the major economic issues that will likely dominate the next four years, Walter F. Mondale parts company from the Washington establishment. While many of our leaders think it is time for the nation's middle class to make economic sacrifices, he says the average American deserves a break.

title: Nebraska a Disaster Area
description: President Reagan declared a major disaster in Nebraska today in response to tornadoes, severe storms and flooding that began June 11.

title: HONDURANS ASSERT THEY SEEK CHANGE IN MILITARY PACT
description: The Honduran Government plans to ask for revisions in a 1954 military agreement with the United States in an attempt to win more economic and military benefits, according to Honduran military officials.

title: INVENTED PSYCHOLOGICAL TEST
description: Starke R. Hathaway, co-developer of the world's most widely used psychological test, died here today after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: NICARAGUA ARRESTS AMERICAN AS AGENT FOR C.I.A.
description: The official newspaper Barricada said today that an American citizen was arrested in May on charges of being a C.I.A. agent.

title: Iraq Reports Clashes On Front Near Basra
description: Iraq said its helicopters and tanks fired on Iranian troops near Basra today, killing five soldiers, and Iran said its forces had shot down an intruding Iraqi helicopter.

title: Deutsche Bank Names Supervisory Chairman
description: Hans L. Merkle, who is to retire this month as chief executive officer of Robert Bosch, the electronic and automotive parts company, has been named supervisory board chairman of the Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest and most profitable commercial bank.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has named A. Clark Johnson chief executive officer of its Union Texas Petroleum subsidiary.

title: Blizzard Protest
description: Clive Toye , president of the Toronto Blizzard, has filed a protest with the North American Soccer League and has demanded the dismissal of Dilvo DiPlacido and Phil Bryan , two officials who worked the club's game in Toronto last Sunday against the Vancouver Whitecaps. The Whitecaps won the game, 2-1, in a shootout, and Toye said his protest was based on two incidents.

title: The U.N. Today July 5, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Helms Drive Accused Of Advertising Violation
description: North Carolina's Democratic chairman has accused Senator Jesse Helms's re-election committee of violating Federal campaign laws in an advertising campaign by seeking to tie the Republican's opponent, Gov. James H. Hunt Jr., a Democrat, to homosexual rights activists.

title: Royal Treatment For a Princess
description: With the Princess of Wales looking on from the Royal Box and two callow qualifiers playing on Centre Court, yesterday was a day for lessons in curtsying and bowing at Wimbledon.

title: SPORTS TODAY Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The National League starters for the All-Star Game next Tuesday are to be announced today, and Darryl Strawberry appears a cinch to be among them. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. Ron Guidry opens a four-game series in the home-run haven of the Metrodome. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Diving

title: A LINGERING SENSE OF BEING OUTSIDE LOOKING IN
description: In the early 1960's, the first black diplomats representing newly independent African countries began arriving in Washington. They found a capital with a large black population of its own but a decidedly small-town, Southern orientation. Conditions were such that the Office of Protocol added a staff to work with these new Washingtonians to overcome discriminatory housing and employment patterns, restaurants that would not serve them and country clubs that did not welcome them.

title: Closed Doors, Closed Minds
description: It bears saying again: Americans are the losers whenever a politically controversial foreigner is denied a visit to the United States. Americans were the gainers when the Reagan Administration reversed itself and finally admitted Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist.

title: No Headline
description: Kennedy-King Tapes To Be Released Today

title: FURNITURE REVEALS THE ARTIST'S TOUCH
description: PEOPLE who work their way through ''Artists Design Furniture,'' a book just out from Harry N. Abrams Inc. at $29.95, are likely to end up with some general ideas about furniture and contemporaneity. For furniture - new furniture, that is - has much to tell us about not only the way we live now but a lot of other things too.

title: MISS WYLAND LEADS DIVING
description: Wendy Wyland, the world champion women's platform diver, performed consistently on every dive today to finish first in preliminary 3-meter springboard competition as the United States Olympic diving trials began.

title: A BILL DESIGNED TO CURB LEGITIMATE PUBLICATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Arbour's Return Seen
description: Any day now, the Islanders are expected to announce that Al Arbour will return as head coach for yet another season instead of taking the front-office job that is his any time he wants it. At the same time, Lorne Henning , his assistant, is expected to be assigned to coach the Springfield (Mass.) farm team.

title: QUARRELING CARIBBEAN NATIONS MEET
description: The leaders of English-speaking Caribbean countries met today for the first time since the United States invasion of Grenada and raised the question whether their 12-year-old regional grouping could survive internal strife.

title: COMMUNISTS IN FRANCE DEBATING FUTURE AFTER AN ELECTORALSETBACK
description: After its worst election performance in 60 years, the French Communist Party is showing signs of an internal struggle about its direction and leadership.

title: Nordiques Get Sevigny
description: The Quebec Nordiques announced yesterday that they had signed the veteran goaltender Richard Sevigny , who played out his option with the Montreal Canadiens last season. Because he was a free agent, and because Montreal had not made a formal written offer to him by June 30, no compensation is required from the Nordiques to the Canadiens.

title: AIR FLORIDA IN BID TO FLY AGAIN
description: Dozens of stranded passengers holding useless Air Florida tickets wandered through the holiday crush at Miami International Airport today, one day after the debt-ridden carrier had stopped flying and filed for court protection from its creditors.

title: Mrs. Dole Confronts the Air Bag
description: Automatic air bag restraints could spare thousands of lives each year in auto crashes. But to some Americans they have become a symbol of overregulation, of Government meddling too much in technology and forcing safety upon reluctant consumers. That feeling runs especially high in the Reagan Administration, whose Secretary of Transportation, Elizabeth Dole, is now having to decide whether to make this proven technology available to all Americans.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN SATIRIST'S APARTHEID
description: Pieter-Dirk Uys, South Africa's leading white satirist, took part the other day in a radio phone-in show, the kind of presentation that permits listeners to unburden themselves of concerns that range from trivia to profundity.

title: WHAT A $120 GIFT TO THE G.O.P. WILL BUY
description: To the Editor:

title: DOBRYNIN BEARING MESSAGE TO SOVIET
description: Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, said here today that the United States and the Soviet Union were ''negotiating'' about whether to start space weapons talks this fall.

title: ALLIGATORS MAY HAVE A PEOPLE PROBLEM, BUT ISLANDERS HAVE PROBLEMS, TOO
description: There is growing talk here this summer about this island's alligator problem, although there are those who argue the problem isn't really the alligators. It's the people. ''The problem is that people feed the alligators,'' said Laird Hills, the wildlife supervisor for the Sea Pines Plantation, a private development at the southern end of this island, which lies just off the South Carolina coast. ''So now instead of being afraid of man, the alligators come out of the water looking for a free handout.''

title: OUR TOWNS
description: The woman, young daughter in tow, has come in to buy a pair of thick-soled boat moccasins for her husband. She writes a check, smiles at her daughter and is about to leave when Neil Dowd decides to give her a little something extra to carry through the day.

title: Rapid Recovery
description: A week after a serious concussion in a summer-league basketball game left him hospitalized, Bill Wennington, the center for St. John's and the Canadian Olympic team, says he is almost at full strength again.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HERE are some new products to ease home maintenance and improvement for the do-it-yourselfer:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Bridge Goes Hollywood

title: BALTIMORE RECYCLES BUILDING SALVAGE
description: -In April 1975 the Baltimore Salvage Depot opened its doors on East Pratt Street near the harbor, the first such city-owned enterprise to recycle old building components at low prices to residents.

title: THOUSANDS IN CITY ARE COLLECTING DOUBLE WELFARE PAYMENT FOR RENT
description: New York City will spend about $35 million this year to cover the overdue rent and utility bills of tens of thousands of families who have already got welfare money for those purposes, according to city welfare officials.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CALENDAR:ON JEWELRY
description: Meet the Artist, International Paper

title: Land Deal for Dolphins
description: Joe Robbie , the owner of the Miami Dolphins, has taken another step forward in his ambitious plan to build a $90 million football stadium complex in northwest Dade County. The county commissioners unanimously agreed Tuesday to accept 160 acres near Calder Race Course donated by two brothers, Emil and Lawrence Morton , and the commission will lease the land back to Robbie at $1 a year for 99 years.

title: THE CASE OF BBC'S NEW-FOUND ORWELL LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Thai Communists Seized in Purported Plot
description: The police have arrested 16 high- ranking officials of the outlawed Communist Party implicated in a plot to overthrow the Thai Government, officials said today.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Bayi Triumphs In Atlanta Race

title: METS DEFEATED BEFORE 51,010
description: The fireworks came after the game. The duds that did the Mets in came at three stages during the game.

title: TOWN WITH FEW RULES DRAWS MANY ALASKANS
description: ''The first thing they do is grow a beard,'' said Harold Newcomb, describing the evolution of new arrivals here in the Matanuska Valley northeast of Anchorage.

title: Judge Jails Parents For Pupil's 137 Absences
description: A couple whose 9-year-old son attended only 43 days of classes in the past school year were ordered Tuesday to spend 10 days in jail by a judge who called them ''irresponsible.''

title: 2 OUTBID THE GETTY AT LONDON SALE
description: A pair of American private collectors outbid the J. Paul Getty Museum for the two most valuable drawings sold Tuesday night by the Duke of Devonshire, it was disclosed today.

title: MUSIC:BRUBAKER, SOLO HORN
description: E.SCOTT BRUBAKER, a horn player in the Metropolitan Opera orchestra, gave his first New York solo recital last Thursday in Merkin Hall. By the end of it, in some pleasant music by Reinhold Gli ere and Alec Wilder, he was playing with technical assurance and an attractive naturalness of phrasing that had eluded him earlier.

title: TOO STRICT RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: ; JUSTICE:VALUES IN THE DISTINCTIVELY AMERICAN WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; TV Trends For Next Season
description: THE television networks get very

title: FINDING FEMINIST POWER
description: A year ago this week, Judy Goldsmith led a lonely band of feminists demonstrating outside the White House to back the failing proposal for an equal rights amendment.

title: Dolphin Drunk In Fatal Crash
description: David Overstreet, the 25-year-

title: Woman or Black Seen On G.O.P. Ticket in '88
description: If this year's Democratic Presidential candidate does not choose a woman or black running mate, the Republicans might surprise some people by doing so in 1988, Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, says.

title: JACKSON'S COUNTDOWN BEGINS
description: The heavily loaded semitrailers have been rumbling into town since last Friday, carrying 375 tons of equipment, including the costumes and special effects whose description has been as much a closely guarded secret as some national security matters.

title: Two Libyan Students Found Slain in Athens
description: Two Libyan students were found shot dead in a downtown apartment today in the third attack in as many weeks on Libyan residents in the Greek capital.

title: Dollar, Gold Up in Europe
description: The dollar rose today in Europe after falling in Tokyo. Gold also rose.

title: BRIEFING
description: Grenada Rumor Persists

title: No Headline
description: Laboratory Confirms Existence of Top Quark

title: WOMEN IN THE BOARD ROOM ARE STILL THE EXCEPTION
description: A CERTAIN awkwardness still pervades corporate board rooms when it comes to women directors - and the constraints are not vanishing as quickly as it once seemed they would.

title: CITY TO HELP PURCHASERS PAY FOR FIXING AUCTIONED HOUSES
description: Some people who buy small buildings from New York City will be eligible for city assistance in borrowing the money needed to rehabilitate the structures, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said yesterday.

title: THOSE WHO SUED JAYCEES ON BIAS CELEBRATE
description: Kristie Smith's brother warned her last week that Minnesota's pending suit before the United States Supreme Court to force the Jaycees to accept women as members was a lost cause.

title: Cavalier Aide Quits
description: The coaching shortage grows more severe for the Cleveland Cavaliers. Ed Badger , an assistant, resigned yesterday, reportedly to take a coaching and scouting position under K. C. Jones with the Boston Celtics.

title: Catching Up to a Jackpot
description: The 58-year old assistant high

title: Guilty Verdict in Killing Of Bloomingdale Figure
description: A former talent agency clerk was convicted today of the first-degree murder of Vicki Morgan, the reputed mistress who once filed a multimillion-dollar suit against the estate of Alfred Bloomingdale, a Presidential adviser.

title: BROADWAY;
description: Some enchanted evenings in store for 'South Pacific.'

title: JESSE JACKSON'S PROPER INITIATIVE AND STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ADVERTISING ; ; Simac Account Goes To McCann-Erickson
description: The Simac Appliances Corporation, which imports such exotic machines as pasta makers, ice cream makers and cappuccino and espresso makers from its parent company in Italy, has assigned its advertising account to McCann-Erickson.

title: ART: ABSTRACTIONISM'S LOST YEARS, AT THE WHITNEY
description: So bedazzling was the power and glory secured for American art with the development of Abstract Expressionism in the 1940's that not until fairly recently have we started looking seriously at the art of the decade that preceded it. The tendency was to dismiss the 30's, dominated by social realism and regionalism, as not much more than a dreary prelude to the talent explosion by which New York replaced Paris as the art world's vital center.

title: MOON CHURCH'S FLOTILLA STRIKES A REEF
description: A flotilla of 83 never-launched fishing boats owned by the Unification Church, each perched high and dry on a trailer, has come to grief a second time in three years, this time in a weed-filled parking lot beside the Elizabeth River.

title: Salan, 1961 Plotter, Is Given Full Honors in French Funeral
description: France gave full military honors here today to Gen. Raoul Salan, leader of the 1961 uprising, who died Tuesday in a military hospital at the age of 85.

title: Mariner Balks
description: A year after he made the American League's all-star team as a rookie, Matt Young is resisting the Seattle Mariners' attempt to send him back to the minors. Young, who has a 13.63 earned run average in his last 6 starts and is 4-6 with a 7.66 e.r.a. over all this season, has invoked a clause in baseball's basic agreement that prevents a team from sending down an injured player.

title: Yonkers to Lose FundsforHousing
description: The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development will cut off $3.5 million in housing funds for Yonkers Friday because the City Council rejected a proposed site for low-income housing, Charles Freeman, a department administrator said today.

title: LEBANESE RIP OUT CIVIL WAR BARRIER
description: The Lebanese Army today began tearing down the Green Line, the five miles of barricades that divided the Moslem and Christian sectors of Beirut and seemed a symbol of the long civil war.

title: NORMAN STAYS HOT WITH 68 AT WESTERN
description: Greg Norman, the long-hitting Australian, remained the hottest player on the PGA Tour today, shooting a 68 in the first round of the 81st Western Open at the Butler National Golf Club. But hot or not, he was in a group of seven players one stroke behind Loren Roberts and Dan Edwards, who shared the lead with five-under-par 67's.

title: AT 72 HOURS, SOME COAST, SOME SKID
description: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, Tony Rafferty, looking like the last guest at a loud and boozy party, stepped off the Downing Stadium track. His eyes were bleak and seemed to be hours past their last reasonable focus.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, twilight-night doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, 5:35 P.M. Ron Darling, who has won six games in his last six starts, goes for his 10th victory of the season. (Television - Channel 9, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 5:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. The Yankees oppose Frank Viola, the former St. John's star, whose three shutouts have him tied for the American League lead in that category. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Boxing

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
Vilas Out of Action
description: Guillermo Vilas will not be a member of the Argentine Davis Cup team that will play quarterfinal matches against the United States in Atlanta next week because of a pulled groin muscle. Jose-Luis Clerc , Robert Arg"uello , Martin Jaite and a junior player, Horatio de la Pena , have been named to the Argentine squad, according to a statement issued through Georgia Tech, which is handling public relations for the matchup. The American team will be made up of John McEnroe , Jimmy Connors , Peter Fleming and Jimmy Arias . . . . Yannick Noah , still suffering from an abdominal strain that kept him out of Wimbledon, will miss France's Davis Cup matches against Czechoslovakia.

title: U.S. BOND SALE BRINGS 13.76%
description: Interest rates rose slightly in very light trading in the credit markets yesterday. The Treasury Department auctioned $4 billion worth of 20-year, one-month bonds amid weak retail interest in the new issue.

title: LAWYERS IN POLL DIVIDE ON ISSUE
description: Split decisions by the Supreme Court yesterday, giving more latitude for evidence from police search and seizure, reflect a similar split among the nation's lawyers, according to a poll sponsored by The American Bar Association Journal.

title: Economic Scene; Adding Power But No Plants
description: THE news about power plant construction is almost all unfavorable. Nuclear reactors are

title: NUCLEAR PANEL MEMBER SWORN IN AFTER BYPASSING SENATE HEARINGS
description: Lando W. Zech Jr., a retired vice admiral who commanded the Navy's first nuclear submarine, took a seat on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today without going through the usual process of Senate confirmation.

title: Poll Finds Agreement On Abridging Campaign
description: The American public says Presidential campaigns drag on too long, cost too much and should be restricted, according to a Media General-Associated Press Poll.

title: A POLITICAL DECISION
description: To me, the big news of the summer is that the trout aren't biting in the White River - not at anything I've offered them anyway. But the rest of the nation seems to be concerned mostly with whether Walter Mondale will choose a woman as his running mate.

title: News Service Is Started By the Aga Khan
description: The Aga Khan, spiritual leader of 20 million Ismailian Moslems in the Middle East, has started a news service to report on events and trends in developing countries for clients in those countries and in the United States, Europe and Japan.

title: Plans for Jackson Rally Canceled After Talks
description: A Jesse Jackson rally scheduled on the eve of the Democratic National Convention will not be held because of a change in Mr. Jackson's strategy.

title: 3 Mets Named All-Stars
description: Three of the rising stars the Mets have been encouraging fans to catch this year became all-stars yesterday when Darryl Strawberry, Dwight Gooden and Jesse Orosco were chosen for the National League squad that will meet the American League in the All-Star Game next Tuesday night.

title: Getting Even
description: England is a country mesmerized by tennis during Wimbledon.

title: No Headline
description: Jobless Claims Gained In Third Week of June

title: REAGAN TELLING CROWDS '84 IS 'WONDERFUL TIME'
description: With observations that God's existence is doubted less and the flag is respected more, President Reagan's opening message on the 1984 campaign trail could not be more basic. ''This is a wonderful time to be alive,'' he is telling the voters in his first extended political trip of the summer.

title: DON ELLIOT, 57, JAZZ SINGER, VIBRAPHONIST AND COMPOSER
description: Don Elliott, a jazz vibraphonist, singer and composer who was featured with George Shearing and Benny Goodman and had his own production company making television commercials for more than 20 years, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 57 years old.

title: TOP STATE COURT RULES TRUMP IS ENTITLED TO TAX BREAK FOR MODTOWN TOWER
description: The New York Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that under a state law designed to encourage housing construction, the developer Donald Trump is entitled to a 10-year tax abatement for the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue.

title: ; Turner brings $10 million.
description: A shimmering seascape by the great English colorist J. M. W. Turner, once described by Lord Clark, the art historian who came to own it, as ''the finest painting in the world,'' was sold at auction today to a private collector for $10,023,200.

title: WBAI Boat Ride
description: A boat ride sponsored by radio station WBAI-FM will leave tonight at 8 from the Circle Line Pier on West 43d Street.

title: INDIAN JET CARRYING Z264 HIJACKED TO PAKISTAN, REPORTEDLY BY SIKHS
description: An Indian Airlines jet carrying 255 passengers and a crew of nine was commandeered by hijackers Thursday and forced to land in Pakistan.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Frozen Foods Head Named at Conagra
description: Nicholas A. Rago has been named president of a new combination of the Banquet Foods Company and the Armour Frozen Foods division, both owned by Conagra Inc., the large agricultural and food products company. The combined company, which expects to have more than $700 million in sales this year, will be called Conagra Consumer Frozen Food Companies.

title: BERKSHIRES, WHERE ARTS ARE IN FLOWER
description: The Berkshires, one of America's premier resort centers, can be a lovely drive from the metropolitan area, up the scenic Taconic State Parkway and east on Route 23 through the dairy country of Columbia County, into Great Barrington, Stockbridge and Lenox, Mass. In addition to its magnificent scenery, charming inns and picture-book New England towns, the Berkshires area is a magnet in summer for music, theater and dance fans.

title: Bomb Blasts Phone Booth
description: A pipe bomb exploded and ripped a telephone booth apart Wednesday, but the police said there was no evidence to link the incident to a rash of recent bombings in three states in the Middle West. Fragments of glass flew more than 100 feet from the telephone booth, next to an ice cream bar on Minneapolis' northeast side. There were no injuries reported.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Aetna Life and Casualty Co. , Hartford, has formed a joint venture insurance company called East Asia Aetna Services Co. with the Bank of East Asia Ltd., Hong Kong.

title: Final All-Star Voting
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday NEW LONDON SAIL FESTIVAL

title: 'BITTERSUITE,'' A REVUE THAT MADE IT BY SHRINKING
description: The perpetual problem writers and composers for the musical theater have in getting their work seen and heard has taken Michael Champagne and Elliot Weiss down an unusual path. In February, their musical revue, ''Bittersuite,'' a two-act cycle of songs dealing with the efforts of the American middle class to come to grips with reality, had a showcase run at the Quaigh Theater in the Diplomat Hotel. That engagement was so well received that an Off Broadway production seemed imminent. But instead of going onward and upward or getting bigger ''Bittersuite'' has become smaller - trimmed its running time, cut its cast - and moved neither up nor down, theatrically, but sideways into the cabaret world at Michael's Pub.

title: Passenger Slashed In Subway Attack
description: A Queens man was slashed in the neck with a knife aboard a subway train at Times Square early yesterday.

title: ART: IN MUSEO DEL BARRIO, INFLUENCES ON A CUILTURE
description: For those jaded by the hard sell in art, the very title, ''A Humble Vision,'' is enough to pique curiosity, and the show of that title at El Museo del Barrio goes a long way toward satisfying it. All the same, prospective visitors should not go expecting undiscovered geniuses, for this is a motley sampling of the museum's collection, ranging from a piragua - a homemade snow-cone cart mounted on stroller wheels - to ultrarealistic still lifes. Moreover, the names, except for Rafael Ferrer's, are unlikely to ring bells with a non-Hispanic public.

title: Gone Fishing
description: Alexis Arguello retired last September from a 17-year professional boxing career that included the capture of three world titles but that ended with two knockouts at the hands of Aaron Pryor. In March, his fans were excited to hear that Arg"uello was considering a comeback.

title: Crash Kills 4 in Cortege
description: Four police officers leading a procession of cars to the funeral of a slain state trooper died today in a collision with a truck just south of here in southwest Arkansas, the authorities said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Belco Petroleum Corp. announced that Paul Bellamy had joined the company as vice president, finance.

title: Fire in Massachusetts Characterized as Arson
description: A fire that killed at least 14 people in a rooming house for alcoholics, transients and discharged mental patients was arson, officials said today.

title: BUSH WOMEN OF DANCE
description: Light dims in the long room, then rises a little to reveal a woman bathing in an imaginary river, all sinuous, glowing in that airy space. More women enter, to form, at first, a singing work chain, and then a gang of playful little girls. A mother combs her daughter's hair. A conjure- woman, half witch, half healer, works her magic. Suddenly, a child dies and is silently mourned.

title: Money Fund Assets Decline
description: Assets of the nation's 332 money market mutual funds fell $726.6 million, to $174.05 billion, in the week ended Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The decline followed a $759.1 million rise in the previous week.

title: G.M. PLANS EXPANSION IN CANADA
description: General Motors of Canada is expected to announce today that it will invest more than $1 billion (Canadian) to modernize and increase capacity at its Oshawa, Ontario, plants.

title: Dining Out Guide: Country Dining, Part 1: Connecticut
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: SIKH'S MOOD: INSULTED, HURT AND OUT FOR REVENGE
description: Interviews with Sikhs in Amritsar and the surrounding countryside indicate that the Indian Army's attack last month on the Sikhs' holiest shrine has, as many officials feared, radicalized many formerly moderate Sikhs.

title: Bush Predicts VictoryFor Republicans in Fall
description: Vice President Bush came here Wednesday to enlist blue-collar support for the Republican Presidential campaign, predicting a close race that he said would be won by his party.

title: Air Florida Ruling
description: United States District Judge William Hoeveler agreed to allow Air Florida to pay up to $6 million in salaries and other administrative expenses after the airline said failure to do so would jeopardize its plans to return to the air. Air Florida filed on Tuesday for permission to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: CHIEF OF I.M.F. URGES AUSTERITY BY ARGENTINA
description: Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, indicated today in Geneva that the I.M.F. would resist making any further loans to Argentina until the big debtor makes deeper spending cuts to curb its 560 percent annual inflation.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Neatnik Press

title: SCREEN: 'REPO MAN,' CARS AND CALIFORNIA
description: ''Repo Man,'' the first feature to be written and directed by a bright new film maker named Alex Cox, is a most engaging reprieve from Hollywood's general run of laid- back comedies of simulated nastiness and half-baked nonchalance.

title: POET RECALLS 21 DARK YEARS IN CUBA
description: In one breath, Andres Vargas Gomez said he would rather forget the psychological and physical torture he says he endured in 21 years of imprisonment in Cuba and talk about his plans to lead a tranquil life of teaching and writing at St. Thomas University here.

title: PLAN ON USED CARS BACKED BY FLORIO
description: Representative James J. Florio has charged that used-car buyers would be ''left at the mercy of the unscrupulous'' if the Federal Trade Commission canceled a proposal that known defects be posted on used automobiles.

title: Salomon Is Leader In Underwritings Salomon Brothers Inc. registered an impressive victory over rival investment banks during the first half, according to a recent survey of underwritings for debt and equity securities. The survey was conducted by the Securities Data Company, a financial data-base service.
description: In the first six months of 1984, the survey shows, Salomon Brothers acted as lead underwriter for 85 debt and securities offerings valued at $9.66 billion.

title: GUYANA IN PACTS WITH COMMUNISTS
description: The leader of Guyana said today that he had concluded trade agreements totaling more than $250 million with North Korea, China and Bulgaria.

title: MURDER SUSPECT TAKEN TO COURTS IN MORE KILLINGS
description: A 24-year-old insurance agent who was accused last week of murdering a 17-year-old high school student was charged today with the murders of five more young women in eastern Connecticut since 1982.

title: Shorter on WBGO
description: Wayne Shorter, the saxophonist in Weather Report, will be heard in a rare recent performance leading his own group as part of the American Jazz Radio Festival, broadcast on station WBGO (88.3 FM), tomorrow at 10 P.M. Mr. Shorter was recorded with a group including Kirk Lightsey on piano, Rufus Reid on bass and Steve Bagby on drums.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Offer for Continental Unit
description: The Security Pacific Corporation has offered to acquire Continental Illinois Ltd., the London merchant banking arm of the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Richard J. Flamson, chairman of Security Pacific, said today.

title: MOSCOW REJECTS COMMITTEE SETUP AT STOCKHOLM PARLEY ON SECURITY
description: The Soviet Union refused today to accept a compromise plan on how the European security talks here should be organized. The talks will therefore adjourn Friday for the summer without a formal committee structure.

title: Mr. Jackson's Prisoner Dealing
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's burgeoning traffic in prisoners from dictatorships is not, as President Reagan suggests, a prosecutable crime. But neither is it, as Mr. Jackson asserts, a moral enterprise. It is political opportunism in reckless disregard for American diplomacy. It is collaboration with the enemies of democracy in embarrassments of the Government of the United States. That a few individuals incidentally benefit from this showmanship does not relieve its cynicism.

title: U.S. ENVOY LINKED TO FOILING OF BOLIVIA COUP
description: The United States Ambassador here played a key role in preventing a military coup against Bolivia's elected President while the leader was abducted for 10 hours last Saturday, according to American and Bolivian officials.

title: PROD PUERTO RICO
description: Britain has its persistent Northern Ireland problem and Canada its perplexing Quebec puzzle. The United States has Puerto Rico to contend with. Like Rubik's Cube, there is no easy answer. Perhaps the United States should now take the initiative and help prod Puerto Rico along to a resolution of its obsessive and enervating political-status dilemma. That might be necessary because Puerto Rico is adrift in a whirlpool of conflicting political whims and desires, none of which commands overwhelming support among the 3.2 million residents of this island commonwealth, which enjoys ''free association'' - however unsatisfactory - with the United States. Washington's official, and commendable, policy toward the question of statehood or independence or improved commonwealth status is that the whole thing is something Puerto Ricans themselves, as United States citizens, must resolve through internal self- determination. But such a policy, while technically correct, nonetheless perpetuates, however well-intentioned, a debilitating stalemate that is eating away, like a cancer, at a once vibrant island that had a distinct sense of purpose, forcing it to skew its priorities and to misdirect its considerable creative energies. Instead, perhaps Washington ought now to spell out to Puerto Rico exactly what it is prepared to offer in terms of possible statehood or independence or - maybe best of all - a ''culminated commonwealth'' status (granting even more autonomy to the island) that would be a credit to America's daring and innovation. Otherwise, Puerto Rico - once so promising, once such a model for the third world - will simply muddle along, trying its best to cope with horrendous structural unemployment and poverty (according to the 1980 Census, 62.4 percent of Puerto Rico's population lives under the Federal poverty level) while enduring more trauma on the question of its political status.

title: DEMOCRATS PONDER MONDALE'S VICE-PRESIDENTIAL QUANDARY
description: For Democratic political professionals, the question of the week involves Walter F. Mondale's interviewing of potential running mates.

title: President is Becoming Chief of Coast Savings
description: -year-old president of Coast Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles yesterday was also given the title of chief executive. He succeeds Ross M. Blakely, 65, who remains chairman of the board and of the executive committee.

title: GTE Leaseback
description: The GTE Corporation said it had completed the sale and leaseback of all 24 transponders on its Spacenet I satellite.

title: PICTURES OF LIBERTY MARK CENTENNIAL
description: On July 4, 1884, a colossal statue called ''Liberty Enlightening the World'' was presented to the United States as a gift from France. The statue, encased in scaffolding, remained in Paris until the following year. A century later, that same Statue of Liberty is again surrounded by a makeshift cage. In a $39 million, two-year renovation, the National Park Service plans to return the statue to the vision of its sculptor, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi.

title: KOCH FAULTS MONDALE SEARCH
description: New York's Mayor Koch stepped up his criticism of Walter F. Mondale last night, saying that Democratic Presidential contender was making a mistake by ''trooping'' too many people to Minnesota for interviews before selecting a running mate.

title: PANEL WILL HEAR PENTATHLON DISPUTE
description: Only three weeks before the Olympic Games open, a panel of sports officials is to hear charges Friday that a member of the American modern pentathlon team won his place by having friends purposely lose their fencing matches with him during the trials.

title: AT OXFORD, HALCYON DAYS OF 'COMMENS'
description: ''What in the world's happening at your college?'' Sebastian Flyte asks Charles Ryder in ''Brideshead Revisited.'' ''Is there a circus? I've seen everything except elephants. I must say the whole of Oxford has become most peculiar suddenly.''

title: Frederic Auguste BartholdiWould Have Been Proud
description: ''It's a pilgrimage in the footsteps

title: INFRARED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary income of $138,000.

title: Mamiya Receivers
description: The Tokyo District Court has appointed two officials as receivers for the Mamiya Camera Company and its three subsidiaries, which plan to reconstruct themselves under court supervision. The four companies applied for receivership last March because of business difficulties resulting from the failure of Mamiya's export agent, J. Osawa & Company. One of the receivers, Akio Yamamoto, said the companies would submit reconstruction plans to the court by July 4, 1985.

title: HART IS EDGING MRS. FERRARO IN DELEGATE POLL ON NO.2 SPOT
description: Delegates to the Democratic National Convention narrowly prefer Senator Gary Hart over Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro as a running mate for Walter F. Mondale, a survey by The New York Times shows.

title: ARGONAUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a gain of $4,930,000 on the sale of oil and gas properties.

title: LATE JUNE AUTO SALES UP 10.9%
description: New car sales by the major American auto makers continued strong in the last 10 days of June, finishing 10.9 percent ahead of robust sales at the same time last year, the companies reported here today. The selling rate during the period was the highest since 1978.

title: THE SWISS KNOW HOW TO CONTROL BORDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: DeLorean Tape Impact Is Cited by U.S. Agent

title: Swissair to Buy 12 New Aircraft
description: Schweizerische Luftverkehr A.G., known as Swissair, said it would buy 12 new aircraft at a cost of about 550 million Swiss francs, or $231 million.

title: HART VISITS CHICAGO IN MOVE TO WOO FAVORITE-SON SLATE
description: Senator Gary Hart came to this city today, aiming to bolster his delegates' resolve and to urge Mayor Harold Washington to release his 35 favorite-son Illinois delegates to support Mr. Hart's continuing bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Peace Groups Set Up Festival for Democrats
description: A delegation from China, a wind-powered automobile and a handmade quilt destined for Leningrad are part of a peace festival set to coincide with the Democratic National Convention.

title: IRAN SAID TO DEVELOP REFLECTOR THAT FOOLS EXOCETS
description: Exocet missiles, the French weapons used by Iraq against shipping in the Persian Gulf, appear less effective than they did in the Falkland war because Iran has apparently developed countermeasures to throw off the missiles' radar-guidance systems, a Western military expert said today.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL II reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets. The year-earlier period's inception was Sept. 1, 1983.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS TO SIGN UP WOMEN
description: Linda Richardson, a 21-year-old law student who has not voted before, says she will probably vote for the Democratic nominee in the November Presidential election.

title: Concord to Join Network Tryout
description: Concord Data Systems Inc. said it would participate with six computer and automated factory equipment manufacturers in the General Motors Corporation's demonstration of the first local area network that meets a standard agreed upon by some major manufacturers and trade groups.

title: NAVY HALTS MISSILE DELIVERY, CALLING WORKMANSHIP POOR
description: The Navy said today that it had halted deliveries of its newest air-to-air missile because of poor workmanship at the Hughes Aircraft Company.

title: No Headline
description: Discovery Might Harm Cancer Therapy Hunt

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; 3 Big Eurobond Issues
description: Three large United States corporations have priced large Eurobond offerings this week, in spite of the likelihood that the 30 percent withholding tax on foreign purchases of American corporate debt issues will soon be repealed.
