CABARET SONGS
description: Although Juanita Fleming has a tendency to over-dramatize some of her songs at Sweetwater's, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, where she is singing through tomorrow, she has hit on a device that seems to help her bring them into better balance.

title: WESLEY A. WILLIAMS
description: Wesley A. Williams, the first black lieutenant in New York City's Fire Department, died Tuesday at Physicians Hospital in Queens.

title: Reagan on U.S. Mood on the Record
description: From remarks yesterday at the dedication of a General Motors plant in Lake Orion, Mich.:

title: BROOKLYN TEEN-AGER FATALLY SHOT WHILE VIEWING FIREWORKS
description: A teen-ager was shot and killed Wednesday night while sitting outside watching fireworks with two of her friends in a Brooklyn housing project where they lived, the police said yesterday.

title: Former Nigerian Official Kidnapped in London
description: A former Nigerian Cabinet minister who is a leading opponent of his country's six-month-old military Government was kidnapped here today. Two British television stations said later that the former official, Umaru Dikko, was found drugged but alive in a crate labeled ''diplomatic baggage'' in an airport cargo terminal.

title: HARLEM COMPLEX CLINGS TO RENTAL BASIS
description: In the 58 years since John D. Rockefeller Jr. developed the Dunbar Apartments as a cooperative in Harlem, the world outside the sprawling five-acre complex has changed greatly. Inside, the Dunbar's grassy, tree- lined courtyard suggests that the past has survived.

title: SAATCHI'S IDEAS FLOW TO M. & m.
description: While McCaffrey & McCall seems to be flourishing under the hands-off ownership of Saatchi & Saatchi of London, it is not above borrowing a good idea from its parent. That idea is having a permanent new business executive on staff - not a retrained creative executive or a retrained account executive - but a dyed-in-the-wool sales executive. Someone who can go out and sell the agency with all the optimistic resilience of the breed.

title: Crowd Mark Set
description: The National League announced yesterday that it set a single-day attendance record Wednesday when 245,192 fans, led by 52,134 in San Diego, showed up for holiday games at the league's parks. The previous record was 242,167, set July 31, 1982.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 16
Pa No New York Hospital
description: Pat Nixon was ''resting comfortably'' yesterday in the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where the former First Lady was being treated for a pulmonary infection, a spokesman for former President Richard M. Nixon said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PARTNERS. Veronica Geng. 184 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $13.95. The least of it is Veronica Geng's skill at mimicry. Here's her voice of ''Your Congressman,'' reporting in a typical newsletter: ''Dear Constituent: As the new year is evidently under way, I am completing a nearly striving-packed decade as your full- time Representative in Washington, D.C. I want you to know how firmly I have urged you to support me, and how deeply I appreciate the authority you have vested in me to exceed my authority.''

title: Compushop Ends Apple Unit Sales
description: Compushop Inc. said it would no longer offer Apple Computer products in is 50 retail stores.

title: German Trade Deficit
description: West Germany's international payments balance lapsed into a deficit of 3.359 billion marks in May, after posting a surplus of 3.3722 billion marks in April, the central bank said today. The May deficit, about $1.187 billion at current exchange rates, was also bigger than the 1.562-billion-mark shortfall in May 1983. The balance of payments measures all of a nation's international dealings, including trade in merchandise and services, as well as transfer payments such as investments.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Denmark's most exprienced international soccer player, Per Roentved , 36, is recuperating in a Copenhagen hospital after an operation for a cerebral hemorrhage that may end his career. . . . Chris Riegel , after failing 24 hours of classes in the last two semesters, will be unable to continue his gymnastics career at the University of Nebraska, Coach Francis Allen said. Riegel was chosen as an alternate for the United States Olympic team, but Allen said the Olympic coaches ''won't use him if he hasn't been working out.''

title: Dorseys in New Haven
description: The Tommy Dorsey Orchestra will open the New Haven Jazz Festival with a free concert on the New Haven Green tonight at 8. Information: (203) 787-8367.

title: JOHN J. S. MEAD
description: John J. S. Mead, a former Republican Assemblyman from White Plains, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Orleans, Mass.

title: BEGGAR'S CHICKEN AND LATE SUPPERS
description: My gastronomic warning lights usually start flashing when a restaurant dish is described on a menu with a long, poignant yarn about how its cute name came about - I've had more Capt'n Nick's platters and rustler's rib roasts than I care to remember. The house special at Tang's Chariot, a smart and comfortable Chinese restaurant at 236 East 53d Street, is called beggar's chicken. The ''legend'' of this dish notwithstanding - something about a beggar who steals a chicken and tries to hide the evidence by concealing it in mud and burying it under some campfire embers, where, of course, it becomes a marvelous creation - beggar's chicken is fun, an exotic item worth trying.

title: Audit Faults State On Disabled
description: The State Education Department should take stronger control of the cost of educating disabled children at private schools, a state audit report said today.

title: GUIDRY IS ROUTED AS YANKEES LOSE
description: Ken Griffey, running on his hobbled knees, barely missed two fly balls tonight that led to the Yankees' undoing in a 5-4 loss to the Twins.

title: A SLUMP IN FARM IMPLEMENTS
description: This summer, as in summers past, farmers' hopes for a prosperous year grow with their crops. But for the makers of farm tractors and combines, the hopes for a turnaround in sales have been dashed, and they are cutting back again.

title: HIGH COURT EASES CURB ON EVIDENCE SEIZED IMPROPERLY
description: Decision excerpts, page B6.

title: Korean Ship Orders Off
description: Foreign orders to South Korea's shipyards fell to 920,000 gross tons in the first half of 1984, down 60 percent from a year earlier, the Korea Shipbuilders Association said today.

title: TEMPLETON FOREIGN FUND reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT OPINION AND DISSENT ON RULE ON EXCLUDING EVIDENCE
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 6-to-3 decision today providing an exception to the exclusionary rule. Associate Justice Byron R. White wrote the opinion. Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun joined in the opinion and filed a concurring opinion. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote a dissent, joined by Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall. Associate Justice John Paul Stevens also filed a dissent.

title: JACKSONS LIST 10 MORE TOUR STOPS
description: Ending some uncertainty about the location of the Jackson brothers' concert in New York, the Jackson tour's promoter announced today that the group would play at Madison Square Garden on Aug. 2, 3, 4 and 5.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Business Day June 23 about the National Bank of Washington, owned by the United Mine Workers of America, incorrectly described the extent of bank ownership by major unions. A second such bank, the Amalgamated Bank of New York, is owned by the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.

title: Loose Oil Rig Towed to Sea
description: A 22,000-ton offshore oil rig that broke free of its moorings and threatened to float into a Bay Area bridge, forcing its closing at the rush hour, was towed out to sea Wednesday. The 720-foot, $200 million rig, ''Eureka,'' ran aground Tuesday 500 yards south of the Richmond- San Rafael Bridge, which was ordered closed for more than an hour when wind threatened to push the rig into the span. A large tugboat, assisted by several smaller tugs, began moving the rig out of San Francisco Bay and into the Pacific early the next day.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: Steelmakers Urge Quotas
description: The United States specialty steel industry said tariffs on imported steel products were not working and asked President Reagan to replace them with quotas.

title: RED SOX WIN ON EVANS SLAM
description: Dwight Evans knocked in six runs, four with a grand slam, and Jim Rice hit a three-run homer tonight as Boston beat California, 12-7.

title: HELIOSCIENCE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: VISITORS GET LOST OR BORED IN NORTH OAKS
description: On the first evening that Walter F. Mondale's senior campaign advisers ventured into this secluded community, the van carrying them got lost. The pizza they had bought for the candidate chilled. Tempers flared.

title: SUMMARY OF MAJOR ACTIONS BY NEW YORK'S LEGISLATURE IN '84
description: The 207th session of the Legislature acted on a range of issues and put off consideration of others. By the time the Assembly recessed at 1:41 A.M. last Sunday, legislators had passed 1,154 bills. Nearly 800 await the Governor's signature or veto.

title: EX-JERSEY JUSTICE
description: John J. Francis, a retired associate justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, died yesterday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: MOLOTOV, AT 94, IS REINSTATED AS COMMUNIST PARTY MEMBER
description: He is one of the last of the Old Bolsheviks, a trusted lieutenant of Stalin, living in obscurity since he fell from power 27 years ago.

title: SHIMMERING CHIFFON BY STAVROPOULOS
description: When he came to this country from his native Athens in 1961, George Stavropoulos was known for his chiffon dresses. Chiffon was on a roll then, but his dresses were different. Instead of being shirred, draped, tucked and gathered, they flowed smoothly around the body. They still do. About a third of the fall and winter dresses he showed recently at the Regency Hotel were made of chiffon - chiffon alone and in combination with satin, velvet, lace or embroidered panels. Layers of the transparent fabric in different colors create unusual tonalities.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: TV WEEKEND ; OLD-BUDDIES COMEDY; LATIN AMERICAN LIFE
description: Floating this weekend amid several situation-comedy pilots that did not make the regular schedule for the fall is ''Side by Side,'' which is liberally stocked with talent but short on workable comedy. Being offered as an ''ABC Comedy Special'' on Channel 7 tonight at 9, the show stars Charles Durning and Ron Leibman as longtime softball-playing buddies now in their 50's. Katherine Helmond, formerly of ''Soap,'' plays Mr. Durning's patient wife.

title: High Court Rejects Appeal by Musto
description: The Supreme Court today rejected the appeal of former Mayor William V. Musto of Union City, two other New Jersey public officials and two building contractors convicted in a kickback-bribery scheme.

description: Street musicians have increasingly

description: ''The internal military situation is perfectly normal. Democracy has in no way even been grazed.''

description: Martin S. Feldstein is packing up, loading such documents as his 1984 ''Economic Report of the President,'' most of which Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan advised the Senate to ''throw away.''

title: RESTAURANTS;
description: A touch of Austria, a light touch.

title: THE VIOLENT DANCERS OF 'DEEP BLUE SEA'
description: He was walking down the street, and someone asked him where he was going; he punched the guy in the nose. Last night, he beat up another man at a party and then - not satisfied with the amount of damage he had inflicted - jumped on his chest with both feet. He left the scene before learning whether he had killed his victim. His co-workers at a truck- loading dock call him ''the beast'' and give him a wide berth. ''I'm jumping out of my skin!'' he says, panicky.

title: A FAILURE AT STUD RETURNING TO TRACK
description: There is one horse galloping in the mornings at Belmont Park these days who just might have a worldly gleam in his eye, a look of experience that no other race horse in New York can wear. He is Laser Light, runner-up in the 1982 Kentucky Derby, who has been brought out of retirement and back to the races after standing one unsuccessful season at stud.

title: Nora Kramer, Writer, Editor And Children's-Book Expert
description: Nora Kramer, author, editor and authority on juvenile books, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: TROUBLE AT TOP OF HEALTHDYNE
description: Healthdyne Inc., a glamour stock that climbed to a high of 40 3/4 just over a year ago only to slide to 6 3/4 today, has work to do on several fronts if it is to regain favor on Wall Street. But the most pressing problem is finding a president.

title: PHILS' HUDSON BLANKS BRAVES
description: Charles Hudson pitched his first major league shutout, a four-hitter through seven innings, as the Philadelphia Phillies edged the Atlanta Braves tonight, 1-0. The game was called after the seventh, following a rain delay of 2 hours 7 minutes.

title: AT THE MOVIES ; ; A Bushman and the clash of cultures.
description: For ''The Gods Must Be Crazy,'' his comic film about the clash of cultures between Botswana Bushmen and South African citydwellers, Jamie Uys (pronounced Ace) needed a Bushman who could act. In a remote part of the Kalahari Desert near Namibia, after a search of several months, he found N!Xau (pronounced EN (click) ow).

title: American Medical
description: The Federal Trade Commission ruled that American Medical International Inc. must divest itself of French Hospital in San Luis Obispo, Calif.

title: ; Executives Appointed At Compton, Ted Bates
description: Nadeen Petersen, 49, will be leaving Warwick Advertising to join Compton Communications as a senior vice president/creative director, reporting to Curt Willinger, executive vice president, creative director.

title: Chairman at Carl ByoirEnding 38 Years There
description: Robert J. Wood, whose public relations career has involved him in such issues as atomic energy and the civil rights movement, will retire July 31 as chairman of Carl Byoir & Associates, the nation's third-largest public relations firm. His successor has not yet been announced.

title: Street Fairs And Festivals This Weekend
description: Most Holy Crucifix Church Feast, Mott Street, between Hester and Canal Streets, tomorrow and Sunday, 2 to 11:30 P.M. Music, food and flea market. Information: 979-1109.

title: HIGH COURT TELLS SCHOOL TO AID THE HANDICAPPED
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that public school systems are required by Federal law to administer a special procedure in school hours to handicapped children who are unable to urinate by themselves. The decision came on the final day of the Court's term.

title: Chile Debt Burden
description: Chile will be unable to repay principal on its $18.6 billion of foreign debt for five years, Finance Minister Luis Escobar said.

title: Kohl's Argentina Speech
description: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl told a joint session of the Argentine Congress today that strategies to promote development were needed to attack the Latin American debt crisis at its roots. Mr. Kohl said foreign debt renegotiations carried out so far by Latin American nations had only helped gain time to deal with the crisis. ''They are a treatment of symptoms, but do not get to the root of the problem,'' he said. ''What is needed are strategies of development that attack the causes of the actual crisis.''

title: OLYMPIAN'S DAUGHTER MAKES DIVE TEAM
description: While Megan Neyer wept, Kelly McCormick and Chris Seufert whooped and hopped around the edge of the pool in a bearhug tonight after the two had made the Olympic team in three- meter springboard diving, the event in which Miss Neyer is the world champion.

title: A FEDERAL MEDIATOR ENTERS TALKS AT PRIVATE HOSPITALS
description: A Federal mediator entered negotiations yesterday between New York City's private voluntary hospitals and the union representing 46,000 hospital workers, which has threatened to strike next Friday.

title: Coopers Is Charged by S.E.C.
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, was accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission today of ''unethical or improper professional conduct'' in audits of Digilog Inc., a computer company.

title: A-Bomb B-29 Crewman Dies
description: Joseph A. Stiborik, the radar operator on the plane that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in World War II, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home here. He was 69 years old. Mr. Stiborik was among 11 crew members of the B-29 bomber Enola Gay, which dropped the bomb on Aug. 6, 1945, killing or wounding more than half of Hiroshima's 300,000 residents. After the war, Mr. Stiborik was a maintenance superintendent for the Industrial Generating Company in this small east- central Texas town.

title: ADVERTISING ; USA Network Pushing Cable TV Music Spot
description: The USA Network has begun a tough advertising campaign aimed at luring the young audience away from the popular MTV cable television network and to USA's ''Night Flight,'' another hotbed of rock.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD LINKING OF AID TO DRAFT SIGNUP
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law that makes college men who fail to register for the draft ineligible for Federal scholarship aid. The vote was 6 to 2.

title: Medieval Message
description: The Cloisters, the upper Manhattan

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: FIREWORKS over the East River

title: Lear to Cut 300
description: The Lear Fan Company, which hopes to build an ultralight carbon fiber plane in Northern Ireland, said it is dismissing 300 workers and will close its two factories in Northern Ireland next month. However, the company is still optimistic the plane, which has run into design problems that have delayed the award of a United States air-worthiness certificate, will be a success. The project is running two years behind schedule.

title: Army Intelligence Unit Returning to Honduras
description: The Reagan Administration plans to send an Army intelligence unit with reconnaissance planes back to Honduras next month to gather information on Salvadoran insurgents, Administration officials said today.

title: Transco Plans Special Payout
description: The Transco Energy Company, a Houston-based energy concern, said it would distribute a portion of the partnership units it owns in Transco Exploration Partners Ltd. to shareholders quarterly. The limited partnership has big offshore leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, a Moscow dispatch Tuesday on arms talks omitted attribution of remarks about influences on Kremlin thinking. The passage should have read: '' 'It's 80 percent internal factors, with relatively little influence from outside factors like Reagan,' one senior Western diplomat said. Calling the Politburo 'a conservative bunch,' he said he saw the Kremlin following a careful course in which both foreign and domestic policy would be resistant to change.''

description: Helen VerDuin Palit says she used

JESSE JACKSON'S PROPER INITIATIVE AND STRATEGY

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'REPO MAN,' CARS AND CALIFORNIA
description: ''Repo Man,'' the first feature to be written and directed by a bright new film maker named Alex Cox, is a most engaging reprieve from Hollywood's general run of laid- back comedies of simulated nastiness and half-baked nonchalance.

title: U.S. Seizes $6.8 Million Cash In Houston Drug Complaint
description: The Justice Department has seized $6.8 million in what Attorney General William French Smith has described as ''the largest single seizure of cash bank accounts in any drug case in the history of Federal law enforcement.''

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Financial Corp. Sets Swiss Offices
description: The Financial Corporation of America, Los Angeles, plans to open two Swiss representative offices, Charles W. Knapp, chairman, said. In a presentation to bankers, he said a Zurich office would open in about one month, and a Geneva office in about a year.

title: Utility Signs Uranium Pact
description: The Energy Department, trying to save its $2 billion-a-year uranium enrichment business, signed a $2.7 billion contract with the nation's largest nuclear utility today.

title: Swiss Charge Bond Trader
description: A Geneva magistrate brought a charge of fraud today against Peter Buer, former head of bond trading at the London office of Bear, Stearns & Company. The magistrate said the charge was lodged following complaints by both Union Bank of Switzerland and Bear, Stearns.

title: Debt Issues
description: CP National Corp. , a San Francisco telecommunications and energy service company, completed a $20 million private placement of 11 7/8 percent convertible subordinated notes due June 30, 1999, with a group led by Prudential Insurance.

title: The U.N. Today July 6, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Quality of Mercy
description: The kickoff time for tomorrow's United States Football League Western Conference championship game between the Arizona Wranglers and Los Angeles in Tempe, Ariz., was shifted yesterday from 12:30 P.M. to 8:30 P.M., Arizona time, because of high daytime temperatures that Coach John Hadl of the Express said could kill someone. The change was announced by the Wranglers' owner, Dr. Ted Diethrich , during a news conference at his Arizona Heart Institute in Phoenix.

title: JACKSON SAYS ATTACK BY REAGAN CLOAKS FAILURES IN FOREIGN POLICY
description: Statement by Jackson, page A9.

title: MOLOTOV'S LIFE AND TIMES
description: For three decades, from 1926 to his disgrace in 1957, a member of the Soviet Union's ruling Politburo . . . Served as Prime Minister and as a First Deputy Prime Minister, and concurrently as Foreign Minister . . . Born March 9, 1890 in Kukarka (now Sovetsk) on Vyatka River . . . A revolutionary in his teens, he joins the Social Democratic Party, forerunner of the Communist Party, in 1906 . . . Named acting editor of the Bolshevik daily, Pravda, in 1912 . . . After 1917 revolution, begins climb to inner circle of power as a protege of Stalin . . . On Lenin's death in 1924, supports Stalin against Trotsky . . . By 1930, when named chairman of the Council of People' Commissars, or Prime Minister, he is known as ''the voice of Stalin'' . . . In 1939, he also assumes the post of Foreign Minister and negotiates a pact with Nazi Germany . . . When Stalin assumes the post of Prime Minister in 1941, at the time of the German invasion, Molotov becomes First Deputy Prime Minister, remains Foreign Minister and becomes a central figure in the war-production effort . . . Orders production of antitank inflammable-liquid bottles that became known as ''Molotov cocktails'' . . . Yields Foreign Ministry in 1949 to Andrei Y. Vishinsky, but resumes post on Stalin's death in 1953 . . . Dropped from leadership positions in 1957 by Nikita S. Khrushchev for being member of an ''antiparty'' group seeking to unseat Khrushchev . . . Given ambassadorship in Mongolia and then sent in 1960 to represent the Soviet Union in the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna . . . In 1962, Khrushchev sends him into retirement and has him ousted from the party . . . Has since lived in obscurity, but not in complete disgrace, being honored with a biographical entry in official Soviet encyclopedias . . . Was married in 1920 to Pauline Zhemchuzhina, who died in 1970 . . . Molotovs adopted a daughter, Sonia, in 1929 and a year later Mrs. Molotov gave birth to daughter, Svetlana.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Reagan Race Phonograph
description: Strange utterances about civil rights have been emanating from Washington lately. Clarence Pendleton, chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, accuses his boss, President Reagan, of playing politics with race. Mr. Pendleton feels that by inviting a group of black appointees to the White House to tout his civil rights record, Mr. Reagan is not ''working toward a race- and gender-neutral and color-blind society.''

title: STUNNING VICTORY FOR MRS. LLOYD
description: Instead of getting mad, Chris Evert Lloyd got even. She had spent the better part of a fortnight listening to her fellow competitors dismiss her as a has-been, no threat to beat Martina Navratilova in the Wimbledon final, and not even a sure bet to get there.

title: ANALYSTS DIFFER ON A.T.&T.
description: ON Monday, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was included by Shearson Lehman/American Express among ''Ten Uncommon Values in Common Stocks'' that the brokerage firm said it envisaged as ''strong performers over the coming year.''

title: SECRET KENNEDY TAPES ECHO THE RIGHTS BATTLE
description: Nearly 10 hours of secretly recorded White House tape recordings made public today show an earnest President Kennedy cajoling mayors, governors and Congressmen to accept integration in the South and support his civil rights programs.

title: FLAGER BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CANADA'S RELATIONS WITH US
description: For most of the past 16 years, Canadians have been dominated by Pierre Elliott Trudeau as perhaps no other people have been by a leader since the French under Charles de Gaulle. He provoked them, he enraged them but he also saved them at a time when their country was threatened with fragmentation over the Quebec separatist issue. And he gave them a strengthened sense of national identity by returning their Constitution from Britain, where it had rested for more than a century since Canada's confederation in 1867.

title: Enstar Dissident Paid to Step Aside
description: The Enstar Corporation agreed yesterday to pay Roy Huffington, a dissident stockholder and director of the Houston oil and gas concern, $3 million to end his efforts to block a merger with the Unimar Company.

title: Required Reading Epizootics!
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, speaking on the Senate floor in opposition to a bill appropriating $31.3 million for the National Endowment for Democracy, June 20:

title: Bartender Slain; Customer Seized
description: A bartender in a midtown bar was stabbed to death yesterday by a customer during an argument, the police said.

title: SUPPLIERS JOIN HONDA IN OHIO
description: When Japan's Honda Motor Company came to Ohio, it did not come alone. Some of its Japanese-based suppliers are also establishing plants in the state.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
CAMACHO GIVES UP 130-POUND CROWN
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho, finding that his championship belt no longer fits, resigned yesterday as the World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, according to his manager, Billy Giles.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER OUSTS ARMY CHIEF, 3 OTHER GENERALS
description: President Raul Alfonsin has dismissed the army Chief of Staff and three other generals in what was said to be an effort to quell dissent inside the army over prosecutions of military men for past human rights abuses.

title: SUBWAY DISASTERS THAT AWAIT THE DISABLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Wind Shear Looked At As Cause of Jet Mishap
description: A downdraft may have caused an American Airlines jet to run off a runway while landing at Stapleton International Airport, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Calypso Concert
description: There will be a calypso concert tonight at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at East 15th Street, featuring Lord Nelson and Designer, both from Trinidad. The music will begin at about 10 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: No Headline
description: Mortgage interest rates soared in June to their highest levels in about two years, the Government reported today.

title: DOW DROPS BY 9.72 IN SLOWER TRADING
description: Stock prices, continuing to reflect concern over the outlook for interest rates, moved lower yesterday in light post-holiday trading.

title: STAGE: 'HENRY V' TAKES FIELD IN CENTRAL PARK
description: With all due respect to Joseph Papp, it's now Kevin Kline who really rules the New York Shakespeare Festival's annual alfresco outings in Central Park. Mr. Kline is our king for all summers - or, at least, three of the last five.

title: STRAWBERRY SLAMS 10TH AS METS WIN
description: It wasn't ''divine intervention,'' said Dave Johnson, the manager of the Mets. It was just a two-hour rain delay in the top of the ninth inning, with the Cincinnati Reds batting and trailing the Mets by one run.

title: IRANIAN JETS DAMAGE JAPANESE TANKER
description: Iranian planes attacked and damaged a Japanese-owned supertanker today in evident retaliation for Iraqi attacks, shipping sources reported.

title: More Met Viewing
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has added 6 1/2 hours a week in viewing time. New hours are 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M., Wednesday to Sunday; 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. on Tuesdays, and closed Mondays. The change results from negotiations between the museum and Local 1503 of District Council 37, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, representing the museum's security and maintenance staff and departmental technicians.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JULY 6, 1984

title: Sugar Prices Not in Pact
description: A United Nations conference today adopted an international sugar pact without measures to raise depressed prices on the world market.

title: For Children
description: Central Park Fun ONE GOOD MEAL DESERVES ANOTHER, stories about turtles and fish, and a demonstration of how to make a lake-creature kite, Saturday at 1 P.M. (reservations required: 772-0210), at Belvedere Castle, 79th Street, south of the Great Lawn. Free. THE MUPPETS TAKE MANHATTAN: An Exhibition, gives a backstage view of the costume designs, set models, puppets and props from the film ''The Muppets Take Manhattan,'' with scenes from the film shown continuously, Tuesdays through Sundays until Sept. 3), 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., at the Central Park Dairy, 64th Street, east of the carousel, north of Wollman Rink. Free. Information: 397-3156. THE FLYING TRUNK, a story by Hans Christian Andersen, told by Marica Lane, and 6,000 ALARM CLOCKS by Miles Macourek, told by Teresa Miller, Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Andersen Statue, near Fifth Avenue and 72d Street in Central Park. Free.

title: Rolls Engine Order
description: State-owned Rolls-Royce Ltd. said it had won a $:34 million order, equivalent to $45.6 million, for its Tay engines to power eight Fokker jetliners ordered by Swissair. Deliveries are to start in 1987. A Rolls-Royce spokesman said the engines would be used in the Fokker 100, a short-to-medium- range airliner with about 84 seats.

title: TV WEEKEND ; Latin American Life, 2 Intimate Glimpses
description: Two intimate but very different glimpses of Latin American life and thought at the ordinary-person level make up this week's ''Independent Focus,'' Channel 13's showcase for the films of independent film makers, Sunday night at 11.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ALBANY PAS DE DEUX
description: The 207th regular session of the State Legislature, which wound up business last Sunday, may best be remembered for what it did not do.

title: JACKSON'S REMARKS ON LEGALITY OF TRIPS
description: Following is the text of a statement by the Rev. Jesse Jackson today on his trip to Cuba and Cental America:

title: No Headline
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which suffered its first setback in the consumer market when sales of its PCjr home computer fell far below expectations, appears to be facing a similar problem again - this time with the portable version of its Personal Computer.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split on May 30, 1984.

title: Yachts Under Wraps
description: Developers of two American 12- Meter yachts for the 1987 America's Cup challenge are on a getting-even keel. In a virtual replay of the secrecy that surrounded the 1983 cup winner, Australia II, and her radical winged keel, the two yachts are under covers during construction at Newport, R.I. Workers at the Williams and Manchester Shipyard have boarded up windows to hide the progress of America II, which is being entered by the New York Yacht Club.

title: PHILADELPHIA POLICE FEEL TAINTED BY INVESTIGATION
description: Capt. Harvey L. Crudup of the Philadelphia police was proud to receive the two silver stars to signify his elevation to Deputy Commissioner. But the job that came with the honor last week, heading the uniformed police, promises a share of a burden greater than most past police commands here have had to bear.

title: Ancient Vases at Met
description: The Greek and Roman Treasury, made up of 50 eastern Greek vases and utensils, and more than 100 other objects, has gone on permanent display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. Hours are Wednesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 10:45 P.M.; Sunday, 11 A.M. to 4:45 P.M., and Tuesday, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Admission is pay-what-you- wish. Information: 879-5500.

title: LEARNING TO CAST, AND OTHER MATTERS
description: Four years ago L. L. Bean of Freeport, Me., one of the top outdoor-

title: INDUSTRIAL POLICY'S PROBLEM
description: Whatever happened to ''industrial policy?''

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $424,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The share earnings and shares outstanding for both year-earlier periods were adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective August 1983.

title: Ouster of Judge Urged by Panel
description: A special judicial panel recommended today that a suspended Superior Court judge be permanently removed from the bench for unethical conduct.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Werner Michel has joined Kenyon & Eckhardt as senior vice president and director of corporate network broadcast services.

title: CUOMO DENIES ANY CONFLICT IN HIS RELIGION AND HIS JOB
description: In one of his rare speeches outside New York, Governor Cuomo declared tonight that there was no conflict between his religion and his public service.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 6, 1984 International
description: Beirut's Green Line is being razed by the Lebanese Army. Troops using earth-moving machines began demolishing the five-mile-long barricades that have separated the Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital and seemed symbols of the nine- year civil war. (Page A1, Column 1.) Raul Alfonsin has dismissed the Argentine Army's Chief of Staff and three other generals in what was said to be an effort to quell dissent in the army over the prosecutions of military men for past human rights abuses. Officials in Buenos Aires said that President Alfonsin had ordered the dismissals to assert clearly the civilian Government's control over the armed forces. (A1:4.)

title: IMAGES HINT AT MAGNETIC FORCE IN MILKY WAY
description: Astronomers recording radio waves emitted from the core of the Milky Way galaxy have detected enormous structures there suggesting the presence of unsuspected magnetic fields of great strength.

title: Free Rock in Brooklyn
description: The Celebrate Brooklyn festival will present free rock concerts this weekend at the Prospect Park bandshell, Ninth Street at Prospect Park West. Tonight, the rap group Divine Sounds will perform, and tomorrow Patty Donahue and the Waitresses and the group Urban Blight will play. Sunday, the Jive Five and the Capris, two doo-wop groups, will perform. All concerts begin at 8 P.M.

title: BRAZILIAN DEBT CRISIS DAMPENS A CORNER OF NEW YORK
description: Jaime Felzen recalls ''the Brazilian miracle'' years in New York. His electronics store, Brasil Som, stayed open until midnight, catering to Brazilians flying in from Rio de Janeiro on shopping sprees.

title: TV Plan Is Explained
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has proposed a football television plan that would give major networks exclusive rights for games during a three-and-a-half-hour period on Saturdays, but would allow Division I-A schools to sell games to any regional and local broadcaster at any time outside the designated period. The plan, which would be in effect for the 1984 football season only, will be voted on Tuesday at a meeting of schools in Chicago.

title: ADDENDA
description: * D'Arcy MacManus Masius has acquired the Danish advertising agency of Ipsen & Parmo in Copenhagen.

title: Aquino's Widow Refuses Request for Exhumation
description: A Philippine investigative commission has requested the widow of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. to consent to the exhumation of his remains to resolve doubts on the official version of how he was assassinated.

title: Bridge: Through 120 Clubs
description: The most remarkable bridge odyssey ever attempted came to an abrupt end a week ago. Yvan and Rolande Pageau of Montreal, who had planned to play in almost 400 clubs and every accessible state and province in the course of a year, reluctantly abandoned their project when their camper lost a wheel in Steindach, Manitoba.

title: ALTERNATIVE TO 'ELITIST' SELECTION OF JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPITALISTS ARE GOOD FOR YOU
description: The prevailing theory of capitalism suffers from one central and disabling flaw: a profound distrust and incomprehension of capitalists.

title: JESSE JACKSON'S PROPER INITIATIVE AND STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: A REBUKE OF FARRAKHAN JACKSON CAN'T AFFORD
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Ronk at Folk City
description: Dave van Ronk, the folk singer, comes to Folk City (254-4437), 130 West Third Street, tonight at 8 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $8.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend in 1983.
