description: Top 10 Works Sold at Auction

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: New England Storms Cut Power to 25,000
description: Tornadoes and thunderstorms temporarily knocked out power to 25,000 customers in Connecticut and Massachusetts yesterday, Northeast Utilities spokesmen reported.

title: Strike Cancels BMW Profit
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke's stock tumbled today after the West German auto maker said it had failed to earn a first-half profit because of the recently ended strike by metalworkers. The remark caused BMW shares to tumble by the equivalent of $7.30 a share, to $130 on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
The Police Blotter
description: Richard Cottingham, 38 years old, serving a life sentence for two murders and on trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan for three other murders, slashed his left forearm with a razor at about 12:30 P.M. yesterday before startled jurors, authorities said. He was not seriously injured and the trial continued later in the day. . . . Robert Page, 43, a jewelry salesman from Massachusetts, surrendered to the police at 8:30 A.M. after holding his 12-year-old son, Sean, hostage in the Edison Hotel in Manhattan for an hour because he believed that the boy's mother, Helen Sanders, planned to rob him. . . . Chester Franco, 38, of Queens was killed at 5:30 A.M., when the truck he was driving slammed into a wall after he was cut off on the Van Wyck Expressway by another vehicle. . . . Benjamin Lopez, 48, shot and killed his son Mark, 25, in a dispute at 2 A.M. and then committed suicide. . . . Mario Larracuente, 23, was stabbed to death, and Pedro Moyet, 23, was seriously wounded in an argument in a Lower East Side schoolyard at Rivington and Norfolk Streets at about 1:25 P.M.

title: CPAC INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $62,000 for the latest year and a loss of $9,000 for the previous year from the company's 50- percent owned Profit Recovery Systems Inc. venture.

title: SHULTZ SEEKS TO ASSURE ASIANS ON CHINA ARMS
description: In advance of the expected sale to China of antitank and other military equipment, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, plans to reassure other Asian countries that the United States will not provide Peking with any weapons that might jeopardize their security, a senior State Department official said today.

title: ACTON, THE ETERNAL ESTHETE, TURNS 80
description: Sir Harold Acton, last of the once-flourishing English-Florentine colony of moneyed literati, art collectors and private scholars who proudly continued to call themselves esthetes even while the term fell into disrepute for suggesting an inadequate social conscience, celebrated his 80th birthday today.

title: EDITORIAL WRITER LEAVES JAIL AFTER SOURCE SUPPORTS HIM
description: Richard Hargraves, who was jailed for refusing to identify his sources of information for an editorial in which he called a public official a liar, was freed today because a county official acknowledged being one of the sources.

title: PUBLISHING: COVERS THAT SELL BOOKS
description: A book's lasting value is obviously determined by the quality of its contents, but attractive packaging can help stimulate sales. This is especially true of mass-market paperbacks, where much time and attention are given to the cover, on the assumption that the typical customer will glance at it for only a few seconds before moving on.

title: TRASH DRIVERS VOTE TO CONTINUE STRIKE
description: Sanitation workers in nine northern New Jersey counties voted today to reject a proposed 30-day extension of their old contract and continue their five-day-old walkout.

title: 23 Hurt in Balcony Collapse
description: A balcony at a San Fernando Valley home collapsed Wednesday night, injuring 23 people who fell 15 feet, after 50 partygoers crowded onto it to watch a Fourth of July fireworks display. One of the injured suffered a fractured vertebra and another may have a broken neck, medical officials said. Five remained hospitalized today.

title: Apparel Group Losing Leader
description: Kurt Barnard said yesterday that he would resign as executive director of the Federation of Apparel Manufacturers to form his own business. Mr. Barnard has held the post seven years, since the formation of the federation.

title: JAZZ:JOHN HICKS AND SEXTET
description: The jazz pianist John Hicks has a big band that is rehearsing and biding its time until an opportunity to get in front of an audience comes up. Meanwhile, Mr. Hicks can usually be heard as an accompanist to singers, as a piano soloist or as the leader of a trio.

title: Times Co. Magazine
description: The New York Times Company yesterday completed the acquisition of Cruising World, a monthly recreational-boating magazine with a circulation of about 113,000. Terms of the transaction were not announced.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS SOCIAL SECURITY FACES A SQUEEZE
description: President Reagan, in an interview made public today, expressed doubts about future financing of Social Security.

title: DRYSDALE OFFICER GETS JAIL TERM
description: A top officer of the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation, which collapsed in 1982, was sentenced to eight years in prison yesterday for his part in a scheme that cost two banks $290 million.

title: N.A.A.C.P. URGES RAPPORT WITH JEWS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called today for continued close relations with the Jewish community.

title: ;  Damaging Testimony
description: In a hearing in San Antonio, Tex., one of his competitors testified that Rob Stull of Damascus, Md., had admitted to one of his coaches that he cheated during fencing trials for the Olympic modern pentathlon team. Bob Neiman said that Mark Joiner , the swimming coach, told him that Stull admitted that three other competitors had allowed him to win fencing matches during the Olympic trials. Neiman came in fifth in total points for the four-man team.

title: SCHULMAN, A. INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings and the shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split paid in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend on Nov. 30, 1983.

title: VIRGIL TROFIN
description: Virgil Trofin, a former Deputy Prime Minister and once a close aide of Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, has died, it was reported today.

title: POP:'VICTORY' ALBUM ECHOES JACKSONS' TOUR
description: The eagerly awaited tour by the Jacksons has finally begun in Kansas City, with a summer of auditorium and arena dates to come, including New York City's Madison Square Garden, Aug. 2-5. As recently as a few days ago, tales and rumors of dissension among the Jacksons and their platoon of advisers had some observers wondering whether there was going to

title: A WILDERNESS OF COURTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Providence Mayor Is Ruled Ineligible
description: The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled today that the Providence City Charter made former Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. ineligible to run in a special election to fill the remainder of his term.

title: ARTICLE STIRS NEW CHARGES IN CAROLINA SENATE RACE
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. threatened today to file a libel suit against a weekly newspaper that has strongly supported his opponent, Senator Jesse Helms, over an article that alleged the Governor might have had a homosexual relationship with a young boy.

title: KOCH APPROVES BILL REGULATING BICYCLE MESSENGERS
description: Bicycle messengers, who have been accused of recklessness by city lawmakers, will be regulated for the first time under a bill signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE REGION ; ;  Slain Youth Found; 2 Suspects Held
description: The mutilated body of a 17-year-old East Northport boy has been found, and two youths from the North Shore were held without bail today in what a prosecutor called a ''sadistic, satanic ritual murder.''

title: SOVIET LINKS TALKS ON SPACE WEAPONS TO A BAN ON TESTS
description: Text of statement, page 5.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
No Headline
description: DiBernardo Ends His Sojourn

title: THE QUESTION OF SIMULCASTING
description: The New York State Legislature passed a bill

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: Discoveries of 2 Fruit Flies Termed No Threat to Citrus
description: Two more Mediterranean fruit flies found in the ''Little Havana'' section pose no new threat to Florida's $1 billion citrus industry because they were found in a quarantined zone, agriculture officials say.

title: All-Star Rosters Filled
description: The first basemen for both the Yankees and the Mets, Don Mattingly and Keith Hernandez, were named to the teams yesterday as managers for the American and National Leagues filled out their squads for Tuesday night's All-Star Game. Mattingly, second in the American League in batting with a .339 average before the game last night, will be making his first appearance as an all-star.

title: FLOODS LEAVE CROPS IN RUIN AND BRING FINANCIAL WOE TO FARMERS
description: Last year it was the drought. This year it was the rain.

title: Shiny Name Tags a Problem
description: An official at the Texas State Bar convention asked members to remove their name tags before President Reagan arrived today, saying the Secret Service had made the request ''for technical reasons.'' A White House spokesman later said the request came from the White House Communications Agency, which handles lighting and sound equipment for the President. The laminated name tags were reflecting into the Teleprompter, the device from which Mr. Reagan reads his speeches.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a strike by sanitation workers in New Jersey misstated the union vote on a contract extension. The proposal was rejected, 209 to 158.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
Ex-Im Bank Raises Loan Rates 1.2 Points
description: The Government's Export-Import Bank announced today an increase of 1.2 percentage points in the subsidized interest rate it charges on loans to encourage other countries to buy goods made in the United States.

title: PATENTS ; A Way to Restrict Use Of Computer Program
description: A method of preventing unauthorized use of computer programs was patented this week for Penta Inc. of Baltimore.

title: Purity Supreme
description: The Supermarkets General Corporation said it had executed a definitive agreement to acquire all the outstanding stock of Purity Supreme Inc. for $79.3 million in cash. Supermarkets General operates 132 Pathmark supermarkets and 20 drugstores, principally in the New York and Philadelphia metropolitan areas. Purity Supreme operates 28 Purity Supreme supermarkets and 14 Heartland warehouse stores in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Maine and Connecticut.

title: SOUND OF AVANT-GUARDE FILLS HARTFORD STREETS
description: On a sunny afternoon downtown on Constitution Plaza, Skip LaPlante set out his instruments - dented pots and pans, rusted iron pipes, scraps of sheet metal - and invited passers-by to help make music.

title: CONVICTS IN A CHINESE JAIL ARE FREE TO MAKE MONEY
description: When Hu Zuoling was sent to the Canton Prison for robbery, he disobeyed the rules and balked at work assignments, feigning illness.

title: Eight Cities Considered For Presidential Debates
description: The League of Women Voters has announced that it is considering eight cities as sites for Presidential debates this fall.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS
description: Corn, Soybeans Mixed; Wheat Prices Advance

title: No Headline
description: Who Bargains for Justice? After a concrete-mixer truck he was driving in New York City crushed a young woman and her two baby daughters to death, Frank Healey pleaded guilty to criminally negligent homicide. For that, shouldn't he go to prison?

title: Collapse of Prison Security Blamed in Virginia Breakout
description: Investigators have attributed the largest death row escape in United States history to a collapse in security, saying they found no credible evidence of criminal conduct by guards.

title: Soviet Warns Youth on West
description: The Soviet leadership today ordered the country's Communist Youth Organization to step up efforts to stamp out Western influence among young people and to exert more control over their free time. A decree by the party Central Committee said youth officials were not doing enough to eliminate ''blind imitation of Western fashions'' and should put more effort into ideological education.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MONDALE FEELS THE PRESSURE TO CHOOSE A RUNNING MATE
description: A little more than a week before the start of the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco, Walter F. Mondale says he is under increased pressure from leading Democrats and some senior aides to name a running mate before the convention opens.

title: Coal Parley Continues As British Miners Clash
description: The National Coal Board and leaders of Britain's 180,000 miners held a second day of talks Thursday on ways to end the four-month strike that has paralyzed two-thirds of Britain's coal industry.

title: PEACHTREE SOFTWARE'S WIDE LINE
description: John P. Imlay Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Management Science America Inc., pointed to his competitors in explaining why M.S.A.'s Peachtree Software Companies subsidiary had recently introduced 25 new products at once - an introduction known inside the company as the ''big bang.''

title: No Headline
description: Fissures in the N.R.A. Bedrock For years it's been the bedrock policy of the National Rifle Association to oppose all attempts to keep guns from criminals as a threat to the rights of hunters, target shooters and collectors.

title: Rates on Loans Up in Britain
description: Major British commercial banks raised their base lending rates today to 10 percent, from 9 1/4 percent, despite a warning by the Bank of England that an increase in interest rates was not needed.

title: ;  Steinbrenner to Rescue
description: The Portobello Thistle Soccer Club of Edinburgh, stranded in Land O' Lakes, Fla., when Air Florida filed for bankruptcy and halted operations, will be flown home next week courtesy of George Steinbrenner , the Yankee owner's daughter said yesterday. ''We want these young people to have a good feeling about the United States and about Florida in particular,'' Jenny Swindel was quoted as saying in The Tampa Tribune.

title: PATENTS ; An Electrical Alarm For Protection of Art
description: An antitheft device to be mounted on the back of a painting was patented this week by Henry E. Frankenberg of Sarasota, Fla.

title: TEXT OF SOVIET STATEMENT ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: Following is the text of the Soviet statement on space weapons, as distributed in translation today by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: THE REGION ; ;  Third Suit Filed In Fire Fatal to 8
description: The family of a 17-year-old killed with seven other teen-agers in a fire at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park filed suit today against the park, its owners and other individuals connected to it.

title: EROSION IN BONN:BUILDING BLOCKS OF COALITION COME UNSTUCK
description: Signs have appeared in recent days that the building blocks of West Germany's 20-month-old center-right coalition Government are coming unstuck, but by a process of erosion rather than upheaval. Taking office in the autumn of 1982, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's alliance of Christian Democrats and Free Democrats sounded resonant pledges to revive the sagging West German economy and to strengthen NATO and the American connection, which it did by arranging the deployment of Pershing 2 missiles over loud protests.

title: Koch to Debate Chief Of Amsterdam News
description: Mayor Koch and Wilbert Tatum, chairman and editor in chief of The Amsterdam News, said yesterday that they would meet in a debate on race relations and other issues.

title: WILLIAM H. BOWE
description: William H. Bowe, treasurer of the New York City Central Labor Council, died at St. Luke's Hospital Wednesday.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES 2 U.S. ENVOYS
description: The Soviet press agency Tass accused two American diplomats today of receiving materials from a Soviet citizen that were ''of interest to American intelligence and centers for ideological sabotage.''

title: Argentine Trade Gain
description: Argentina had a $2.3 billion trade surplus in the first five months of 1984, up 52.8 percent from $1.5 billion in the 1983 period, the Economy Ministry said today.

title: DEBATE ON AUTO SAFETY DEFECTS AND RECALLS
description: With American car manufacturers making new promises about quality controls that meet or beat foreign competition, many buyers are wondering what has happened to the tedious recall ritual that, perhaps more than anything else, made drivers skeptical about American-built cars in the 1970's.

title: Baby for Kennedy Son
description: Kyle Frances Kennedy, a 6-pound, 8-ounce girl, was born today to Victoria Gifford Kennedy, the wife of Michael Kennedy, at George Washington University Hospital. Mr. Kennedy, 26 years old, is the son of former Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Ethel Kennedy. Victoria Kennedy is the daughter of Frank Gifford, the sports commentator. The birth was announced through the office of the father's uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachussetts.

title: More Federal Payments Approved for Candidates
description: The Federal Election Commission has approved $215,588 in matching funds for the campaign of Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, $90,299 for the Rev. Jesse Jackson and $64,990 for Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: HART TELLS N.A.A.C.P. HE BACKS HIS PRINCIPLES
description: Senator Gary Hart, whose Presidential campaign appearances included few black organizations and only general references to civil rights concerns, today assured members of the nation's largest civil rights organization that his new ideas did not mean an ''abandonment'' of their principles.

title: A WAR ROOM PROJECT GOES PUBLIC
description: In a drab office of a Government agency in downtown Washington, casual visitors have been able since Thursday to examine the specifications and 41 detailed drawings of a project to ''Upgrade Emergency Power'' for the computers, communications gear and other sensitive equipment in the Pentagon's war room.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: 'Walk-a-Shrink'

title: SATURDAY, JULY 7, 1984 International
description: Moscow offered again to hold talks with the United States on banning arms in space, but appeared to add a precondition, calling for a mutual moratorium on testing. A Government spokesman said that such talks, which the Soviet Union has proposed for September, would be ''incompatible'' with the continued testing of space weapons. A White House spokesman called the Moscow announcement ''good news'' and said ''so far as we're concerned the meeting will take place.'' (Page 1, Col. 4.) Nigeria detained a British airliner in Lagos after British antiterrorist police in London freed a kidnapped Nigerian exile who has been described as the Nigerian Government's ''most wanted man.'' The exile, Umaru Dikko, a former Government official, was found drugged and unconscious in a crate ready to be loaded on a plane at Stansted Airport. (1:1.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Book Banter

title:
PATENTS;
ELECTRONIC SECURITY FOR MAIL
description: WASHINGTON

title: Club in New Orleans Keeps Ban on Blacks
description: Members of the prestigious New Orleans Athletic Club voted tonight to continue their ban on blacks, which dates back to the club's opening in 1872.

title: Money Supply Is Up $1 Billion
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $1 billion in the week ended June 25. Credit markets were buoyed by the report, since the rise was smaller than the $2.5 billion increase many Wall Street economists had predicted.

title: FRESH BASIL: HERB FOR ALL SEASONS
description: The day I learned that fresh basil could be frozen meant that I would no longer have to use it in the dry form. Some herbs dry well and have almost the same fragrance and taste as fresh herbs. But not basil. There is no comparison.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Ex-Hartford Chief Sues Over Ouster
description: A former Hartford police chief filed a $5 million lawsuit today to regain his old job, saying his ouster was a result of a conspiracy among black city officials.

title: A DAY CAMP FOR CHILDREN OF HOMELESS
description: Balloons in hand, they ran noisily through the courtyard of a building at 150 East 45th Street that houses the Children's Aid Society, which plans to begin a day-camp program Monday for about 30 children from the Carter Hotel, on 43d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. This is the first time the society has brought the homeless into its summer camps, officials said.

title: J. David Case Bail Remains
description: A Federal magistrate has rejected a request by J. David Dominelli of the bankrupt J. David & Company investment house to have his $5 million bail reduced so that he could leave the Federal jail in San Diego.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Concerts and Commercials

title: Phillies Beaten, 5-0
description: Pascual Perez scattered six hits and struck out nine tonight, and Dale Murphy hit his 20th home run of the season to help the Atlanta Braves to a 5-0 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: SOVIET NAMES ENVOY TO CAIRO
description: The Soviet Union announced this morning that it had reached agreement with Egypt for the exchange of ambassadors for the first time since 1981.

title: EMBRYO FREEZING CITED IN A 2D BIRTH ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 6 (AP) - A Dutch doctor today announced the birth of a child developed from a frozen embryo, the world's second such birth.
description: The baby, an 8-pound, 14-ounce boy, was reported in excellent condition after birth Thursday night at the Dijkzigt University Hospital, said Dr. A. Alberda, a gynecologist who was a member of the medical team in charge of the procedure.

title: WHY JIM QUIT
description: Amid all the foreign wars and domestic politics, the sad news this spring was of the death of my Uncle Jim Cowan, aged 66, in a Pennsylvania veterans' hospital. Jim's passing would ordinarily rate no notice if it were not for the fact that he witnessed and in a mild way participated in what may have been a symbolic turning point in New York's transit history.

title: KANSAS CITY 'BEHOLDS THE KINGDOM'
description: The concert began with symbols that spanned the centuries: the sword and the stone of Arthurian legend, and the laser beams of the space age.

title: HIGH RATES SEND GOLD BELOW $350
description: Gold fell $15 an ounce yesterday in hectic trading, ending the day below $350, its lowest level in nearly two years.

title: Miss Buckley Is Wed to D. R. Suisman
description: The marriage of M. Lee Buckley, a daughter of John W. Buckley of New York and Lakeville, Conn., and the late Mrs. Buckley, to Douglas Robert Suisman, a son of Michael Suisman of West Hartford, Conn., and Mrs. Benedict Viering of San Francisco, took place yesterday. Municipal Court Judge Sherrill D. Luke of Los Angeles performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Turkish Cypriot Accuses Greeks of Arms Buildup
description: Rauf Denktash, the Turkish-Cypriot leader, said today that Greece was engaged in a secret military buildup on Cyprus and that he had asked the United Nations to stop such ''craziness.''

title: FAMILY WITH MISSING RELATIVE PAID FOR TRIPS OF MAN CLAIMING JACKSON LINK
description: A man who said he was acting on behalf of the Rev. Jesse Jackson took expensive trips to Jamaica, Europe and Africa last spring that were financed by a Florida family who believes a relative is imprisoned in Cuba.

title: A WAY TO FIGHT ACID RAIN
description: With Congress gridlocked over reauthorization of the Clean Air Act and the Administration fiddling while the environment corrodes, the affected states are taking the lead in attacking acid rain. The New York State Legislature has just enacted a landmark bill to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions, which are the main source of acid rain. Similar legislation is wending through the Massachusetts Legislature. If Governor Cuomo signs the bill into law, it will become the first legislation in America to mandate reductions in pollution specifically tailored to put a dent in the acid rain problem.

title: Arbour's Return Is Made Official
description: Bill Torrey, the general manager of the Islanders, ended speculation about the future of Al Arbour by announcing yesterday that the 51-year- old coach would return this fall for his 12th season behind the bench.

title: U. S. Rate of Abortions Reported to Be Declining
description: The number of abortions reported nationwide is holding steady, with an actual decrease in the abortion rate, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said today.

title: No Headline
description: Jimmy Connors wore out Ivan Lendl in a comeback victory today and earned the chance, however slim, to topple John McEnroe in Sunday's final at Wimbledon.

title: BRIEFING
description: Salute Across the Aisle

title: REAGAN IS PRESSED TO REPUDIATE PACT
description: Two conservative Republican senators told President Reagan this week that his Administration's compliance with the terms of an unratified treaty on nuclear weapons ''could easily be interpreted as appeasement of the Soviet Union.'' They urged him to repudiate the accord.

title: F.D.I.C. IS SAID TO SEEK NEW CONTINENTAL CHIEF
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is seeking a new chief executive officer for the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, banking sources said yesterday.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LEVEL OF JOBLESS DECLINED TO 7.0% FOR NATION IN JUNE
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell by four- tenths of a percentage point in June, to 7.0 percent, the lowest level in more than four years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: TAXI INDUSTRY DEREGULATION:INVITATION TO CHAOS
description: To the Editor:

title: TRASH STRIKE CAUSES SOME PROBLEMS IN JERSEY
description: Homeowners in many northern New Jersey communities appear to be bearing up well despite six days of accumulated garbage. But restaurants and apartment buildings are beginning to have problems.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN THREE RAPES AT CITY HOTELS
description: A 28-year-old man who was the target of an intensive police hunt over the last three weeks was arrested yesterday and charged with three rapes, an attempted rape and nine robberies in six midtown hotels since April 28.

title: CITY OPERA:'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' OPENS SEASON
description: The New York City Opera, firm in the belief that life begins at 40, opened the first summer season in its history last night with appropriately celebratory flourishes and a new production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia.'' The flourishes included a short, graceful speech by Beverly Sills, the company's general director, and the reading of congratulatory telegrams from President Reagan, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch. The festivities were in honor of a company that began life in 1944 as a ''people's opera'' and continues to serve that constituency, among others. The popular note was struck clearly on this night by the English translations that flashed on the panel above the stage. The subtitles, as the City Opera confusingly calls these supraimposed words, worked well and unobtrusively.

title: Art Blakey Quintet
description: The drummer Art Blakey and his quintet, the Jazz Messengers, will appear tonight at the Village Gate (475- 5120), 160 Bleecker Street, at Thompson Street. The first set begins at 10 P.M., and tickets are $10.

title: CONGRESSIONAL BOOST FOR CIGARETTE SALES
description: To the Editor:

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $65,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,000 for the latest period and $168,000 for the year- earlier 6 months. The share earnings for the year-ago 6 months was restated to reflect 2-for- 1 stock split in January 1984. The increase in sales and earnings for the latest second quarter and 6 months is principally attributable to the Parkwood and Van Express contributions. Vyquest did not own either of the two companies in the 1983 periods.

title: THE NAME OF THE GAME
description: In this dream I am a White House big shot being grilled by Ted Koppel on ABC's ''Nightline,'' only I can't remember Mr. Koppel's first name, and it's terrifying, especially when Mr. Koppel stops mincing words and says, ''Then you admit the charges against you are true, do you?''

title: Breland Earns Spot In Olympic Boxing
description: Mark Breland of Brooklyn, perhaps the best amateur boxer in the world, made the United States Olympic team tonight. Though Michael Tyson of Catskill, N.Y., lost his chance for the Olympics, he showed that he may become Breland's successor as America's most attractive amateur.

title: ;  Andujar to Miss GameThe St. Louis Cardinals said late last night that
description: Joaquin Andujar , their right-handed pitcher, has returned home to the Dominican Republic and will not play in the All-Star Game next Tuesday in San Francisco.

title: Bridge: A Book on Tips Is Revived And Even Costs a Bit Less
description: Many excellent new bridge books have been affected by inflationary price increases, but there is a silver lining: Many excellent old ones have deflated, and are available at substantial discounts.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: Alcon Extends Coopervision Bid
description: Nestle S.A. said its Alcon Laboratories subsidiary had extended its tender offer for all Coopervision Inc. shares at $25 each until July 31.

title: Harte-Hanks
description: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. said it had received approval from the Federal Communications Commission for the proposed leveraged buyout of the company. The transaction, first announced March 28, remains subject to various conditions, including the execution of defintive financing agreements and receipt of stockholder approval, Harte-Hanks said. A group of investors has offered about $445 million in cash and debentures for the newspaper and broadcast group.

title: THE MAYOR OF WEST 85TH STREET
description: When Claire Cosner moved to New York, her parents were excited for her, but also a little concerned, as might be expected of parents back home in Hammond, La. But that was before they came to the city and met George Bassat, who took them up on the roof and showed them the sky.

title: Investor May Bid For Mohawk Data
description: Asher B. Edelman, an investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he may seek to interest other investors in acquiring the Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, a computer and communication services company in Parisppany, N.J.

title: Enstar Proxy
description: The Enstar Corporation said that a dissident shareholder, Roy M. Huffington, and his group had won their proxy contest with management. Mr. Huffington had claimed victory immediately after the meeting had been adjourned on June 21. While reporting the final tally, Enstar said the results had been rendered moot by developments since June 21. Mr. Huffington agreed earlier this week to drop his efforts to end a merger with the Unimar Company in exchange for $3 million.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
U.S. Arms Chief Ends 2-Day Visit to Peking
description: The United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency chief, Kenneth L. Adelman, concluded two days of talks today with Chinese Foreign Ministry and military officials on nuclear disarmament. A United States official said they also discusseed ways of halting the spread of nuclear arms.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Shipyard Concern Leaving Hoboken
description: The company that raised hopes of reviving the shipyards of this once- busy port by buying the old Bethlehem Steel yards 16 months ago said today that it was closing the shipyard and moving to a facility in Bayonne that was half the size.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Parks Puns

title: SIKH HIJACKERS GIVE UP IN PAKISTAN
description: Hijackers identified as Sikhs freed 255 passengers and crew members from a commandeered Indian Airlines jet in Pakistan today, then surrendered to Pakistani authorities.

title: WILLIAM BARBER, FORMER CONNECTICUT JUSTICE
description: William Perry Barber, a former associate justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, was found dead Thursday in his home in Putnam, Conn., an apparent heart attack victim. He was 77 years old.

title: CITY IS TRACKING DOWN MISSING WELFARE CHECKS
description: After an anxious search for hundreds of thousands of dollars in missing rent payments for 1,100 welfare families, City Hall officials said yesterday that they had found some of the money and had resolved the problem - maybe.

title: THE SAILOR LOOK IN SUMMER WHITES
description: Crisp white clothes, as fresh as newly done laundry, have always been a favorite midsummer look. Something has been added this time around: dashing yachting caps, sailor hats and chic variations thereof.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Young and Old

title: ;  Turner Backs Off
description: It's not often that he ducks controversy, but Ted Turner , whose holdings include the Atlanta Braves, the Atlanta Hawks and the Cable News Network, has avoided some problems by rejecting a Soviet offer that CNN televise the Friendship Games, the Eastern bloc's alternative to the Los Angeles Olympics. Turner said that the network would simply give spot coverage to the Friendship Games, ''as we would any other sporting event.''

title: DEBT AND DISASTER
description: DEBT SHOCK: The Full Story of the

title: Television Captioning For Deaf to Increase
description: Federally subsidized captioning for the deaf will be expanded to an additional 14 1/2 hours of television news and public-affairs programs each week, starting this summer.

title: ADMINISTRATION AND JACKSON'S TRIP:LIMITS OF CITIZEN DIPLOMACY TESTED
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's recent mission to the Caribbean is only the latest episode in a history of citizen diplomacy during decades of turmoil and hostility with countries such as the Soviet Union, China, Vietnam, Iran and Syria. Some of these missions have been warmly embraced by the Administrations in power, as was Mr. Jackson's mission to Syria in January when he obtained the release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. of the Navy, and some of these missions have been roundly denounced by the White House, as was Mr. Jackson's latest venture.

title: ARMY COMPLETES BEIRUT TAKEOVER
description: The Lebanese Army completed its takeover of the capital from militia forces today, but the city's port and airport did not reopen as initially planned.

title: CALIFORNIA ASSEMBLY DELAYS DEAL ON HUGHES ESTATE TAX
description: California and Texas have tentatively agreed to split millions of dollars in inheritance taxes from the Howard R. Hughes estate. But a special bill to put the proposed settlement into effect was blocked in the California Assembly today because of objections by Gov. George Deukmejian.

title: SUPPLIES ARE STILL PLENTIFUL
description: Even in a week when both Iran and Iraq have attacked tankers, the price of oil is still in the doldrums.

title: FRANCIS HEISLER
description: Francis Heisler, a decorated veteran of World War I who became a lawyer and defended hundreds of conscientious objectors in three wars, died Thursday.

title: No Headline
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. A showdown between the strikeout aces Dwight Gooden and Mario Soto. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. The Yankees get a look at another young Minnesota player, Ed Hodge, a left-hander with a record of 3-2. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.)

title: Jackson Avoids Answer On Thurmond Challenge
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today requested a Justice Department investigation into this state's Democratic primary for the Senate. At the same time, the Democratic Presidential contender declined to say whether he would run as an independent candidate to challenge Senator Strom Thurmond, a conservative Republican, in South Carolina this fall.

title: Helen Hoover, Nature Writer And Metallurgist, Dies at 74
description: Helen Hoover, the author of seven books and numerous articles on nature and the wilderness, died of peritonitis Saturday in a hospital in Fort Collins, Colo. She was 74 years old.

title: YANKEES CONTINUE SLIDE
description: In their latest travels, the Yankees discovered a team that is rising while they continue their drop from what they have been for much of the last several years - one of the powers in the American League.

title: LAST CHANCE OF SEEING FULL CONVENTION FADING
description: Manhattan, a place where a fair number of people might be interested in seeing the Democratic National Convention in its entirety, will be deprived of gavel-to-gavel coverage unless the borough's cable companies decide to do something about it.

title: FOUR SUBWAY WORKERS KILLED BY TRAINS IN 1984
description: Four subway workers have been killed on the job this year, two of them in the last two weeks, transit officials said yesterday. In past years, there have been two or three such accidents in a year, they said.

title: AMERICAN ECOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESCUE TROPICAL FORESTS
description: Tropical forests are disappearing. So what else is new? Tropical forests lie beyond the horizons of our homelands, generally beyond the horizons of our imaginations. We have other things to worry about besides jungles full of prickly plants and creepy- crawlies.

title: Baldwin to Sell Ambac Indemnity
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, which has been under pressure to generate cash to pay off its substantial debts, said yesterday that it would sell the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, its municipal bond insurance subsidiary, to Ambac's management. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: THE PARALLEL BETWEEN TWO U.S. AOD CUTOFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: CURING THE ILLS
description: New York City's subway system seems afflicted with some incurable disease. Despite larger Federal subsidies, fare increases and growing debt, service continues to deteriorate. Why? One of the system's most intractable problems - if not the root cause of its decay - is the falling productivity of transit workers. We must, if we are going to get the system working again, take steps now to provide incentives for these public service employees.

title: A DIVIDED ISRAEL
description: Modern Israel, now 36 years old, is moving from the generation of its founding into the generation of its maturity without having resolved the most fundamental questions faced since its creation. In essence, they are the issues of what kind of a society this will be: religious or secular, nationalistic or humanistic, Western or Middle Eastern, absolutist or pluralistic. The struggles between these diverse qualities are intense; they are determining the nature of democracy and Judaism, the two key elements of Israel's fate.

title: BL to Limit Jaguar Shares
description: Investors wanting to buy shares in the Jaguar luxury car division of BL P.L.C. will be limited to 15 percent of the total offered, BL said. The limit is part of a plan to prevent another company from accumulating too much of Jaguar's stock, BL, which is run by the state, said in a letter to shareholders.

title: AGENCY CONSIDERS COMBINED MISSION FOR SHUTTLE
description: Space agency officials are weighing a plan to combine into a single flight the primary payloads of last week's aborted space shuttle mission and of the mission that had been scheduled for late August. But no decision is expected to be announced until early next week.

title: Robert W. Parsons, 84, Dies; Banker and Foundation Chief
description: Robert W. Parsons, a foundation executive and retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died yesterday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: PATENTS ; Mittens for Making A Dog's Life Easier
description: Mittens for dogs were patented this week by Tina Marshall of Flushing, Queens.

title: ATARI'S NEW OWNER ORDERS LAYOFFS
description: Jack Tramiel, the new owner of the Atari Corporation, has ordered major layoffs at the computer and video game maker, the company said.

title: St. Regis-Murdoch
description: United States District Judge Maurice Paul has continued until July 20 a suit brought by Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, seeking dismissal of a Florida court order that would prevent Mr. Murdoch from buying more stock in the St. Regis Corporation, a paper and wood products company. The Florida Insurance Commission requested the order, contending that Mr. Murdoch's purchase violated the Florida Insurance Code.

title: Oakland Seeking Raider Injunction
description: The City of Oakland asked the California Supreme Court today to prevent the National Football League champion Raiders from playing home games in Los Angeles this year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Consumer Saturday column on the Style page last week misstated a caution involving the Whistler Glass Tea Kettle made by Gemco Ware Inc. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said that if a kettle and its handle ''show signs of deformation,'' the consumer should stop using it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Fair Warning for Thieves

title: PATENTS ; A Process That Helps The Synthesis of DNA
description: A scientist at the University of Colorado in Boulder, Marvin H. Caruthers, has made his second contribution to the production and purity of DNA, the basic raw material of genetic engineering.

title: HOUSE & GARDEN'S NEW FOCUS
description: One morning last spring two shopping carts full of chilled sparkling wine arrived in the fifth-floor offices of Conde Nast Publications Inc. in midtown Manhattan. Navigating past the editorial offices of Vanity Fair, the carts arrived at the doors of one of Conde Nast's most successful ventures - the revamped House & Garden magazine.

title: Dow Closes Down 1.99; Earlier Losses Pared
description: Stocks ended slightly lower yesterday in slow trading.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DRAWING CARD Summer Saturdays and Sundays do not turn the city into a deserted village, although the population density thins markedly and the pace is slower. It is a felicitous time to browse about town and avoid the jetstream of humanity that inhibits contemplation in spring and fall.

title: JULIUS BLOOM, FORMER HEAD OF CARNEGIE HALL, DIES AT 71
description: Julius Bloom, the former director of Carnegie Hall and a major force in guiding its fortunes from 1960 to 1979, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a possibility - well, probability - that many people, young people now paying in, will never be able to receive as much as they're paying.'' - President Reagan. (1:5.)

title: JOBLESS RATE IN THE CITY RISES FROM 7.6% TO 10%
description: New York ran counter to the national unemployment trend in June as both the city and the state recorded increases in the number of jobless residents.

title: L.I. MAN SLAIN AFTER 5-YEAR FEUD WITH NEIGHBOR
description: A five-year feud between next-door neighbors was blamed by the police today for the shooting death of a Glen Cove High School music teacher in the driveway of his home.

title: MONDALE AS THE 'DEFINITIONAL CONSERVATIVE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Krugerrand Sales Up
description: Krugerrand sales worldwide rose 64.6 percent in June, to 330,547 ounces, from 200,874 ounces in May, the International Gold Corporation said. But that was 18.9 percent less than the 407,579 ounces sold in June last year.

title: JEWISH MUSIC:CHOIR NIGHT
description: The Abraham Goodman House's first Summer Festival of Jewish Music, which began Monday night and continues through next Thursday, is a wide-ranging affair, including not only the great sacred music of the synagogues, but also selections from the American Yiddish theater, Jewish music of Eastern Europe, folk and popular music of Israel, and music from the Near East and the Mediterranean.

title: Plea for Steel Import Curb
description: American steel industry leaders appealed today for Congress to limit steel imports, but an Administration official predicted President Reagan would veto any such legislation.

title: SCOUTING ;
description: In His Element

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: More on 6th Avenue

title: RETIREES VOLUNTEER WEALTH OF EXPERTISE
description: At the Fire Academy on Randalls Island, 83-year-old Dr. Carl Raushenbush shares an office with three captains.

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to April 30
PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net income.

title: Nurses in Minnesota Reach a Settlement
description: Negotiators for 6,300 nurses and 16 area hospitals reached agreement today, ending the largest strike by nurses in American history.

title: ;  Nautical Error
description: Mistakenly thinking she was headed toward the finish line, the last female competitor in a trans-Atlantic yacht race ran her boat onto fog- shrouded rocks at 2 A.M. yesterday less than 15 miles from the end of the 3,500-mile contest and was forced to abandon. Rachel Hayward , a 53-year- old Briton, had lost the satellite navigation aboard her 35-foot monohull and, because of the fog, could not navigate by the stars when she was grounded on rocks near the Point Judith lighthouse off Newport, R.I. Mrs. Hayward said she had thought the lighthouse was the Brenton Reef Tower, which marks the finish line of the Observer Singlehanded Transatlantic Race. The accident, which wrecked her yacht, happened on her 34th day of sailing.

title: NEW RULES ON PHONE CUTOFFS
description: TELEPHONE companies will be

title: THE CITY ; ;  Law to Help City Take Buildings
description: The city will be able to take over more rapidly buildings whose owners owe a year or more of taxes under a bill Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday. The law allows such buildings to be taken over individually.

title: Austria Credit to Soviet
description: Austria's Creditanstalt bank has granted a $105.2 million trade credit to the Soviet Union, the bank said today. The credit will help the Soviet Union buy steel pipe from Voest-Alpine, Austria's national steel company, according to the national news agency A.P.A. The loan was announced after Hannes Androsch, the Creditanstalt chairman, returned from three days of talks in Moscow with Soviet trade officials. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: U.S. STEEL SELLS PLANT TO FORMER MANAGERS
description: The United States Steel Corporation has sold its Johnstown, Pa., specialty products plant to a company headed by three former employees and a private investor, both companies said yesterday.

title: DARLING WINS 7TH IN ROW
description: Ron Darling confessed last night that he was ''disappointed'' that he had not been picked for the all-star team. Then he buried his emotions and the Cincinnati Reds in one of the dazzling performances of his rookie season with the Mets.

title: PLOICY RIDERS ON INSURANCE
description: A rider is a device used by life insurance companies to allow buyers to add other kinds of coverage to their policies. Besides the standard riders that have traditionally been offered by life insurers, a number of newer benefits have been developed in recent years that are also available in this form.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 7, 1984 The Economy
description: The nation's jobless rate fell to a four-year low in June, dropping four-tenths of a percentage point from May, to 7 percent, the Labor Department said. The report, the first broad measure of June economic activity, suggested that growth continued at a stronger pace than the Administration had expected. Martin S. Feldstein, the outgoing chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said he ''would worry'' if the economy ''doesn't slow down further'' in the second half, referring to the threat of increasing inflation. The jobless rate for black teenagers fell sharply, but Government analysts said that may have been a statistical fluke. (Page 1.) In New York, unemployment rose, but in New Jersey and Connecticut, the rate fell. The biggest change was in New York City, where the jobless rate jumped to 10 percent, from 7.6 percent in May. (44.)

title: Letter: On BIDS ; Wasting a Chance to Improve Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Car Quotas, Salaries Are Linked
description: Some Reagan Administration officials are linking continued restraint on Japanese cars sold in the United States after next March with wage and salary moderation in the domestic auto industry.

title: GEARHART IS BUYING AETNA UNIT
description: Gearhart Industries, which has been the object of a hostile takeover bid by Smith International, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's oilfield services subsidiary, Geosource Inc., for 10 million newly issued Gearhart common shares, preferred stock with a liquidation value of $110 million and $50 million in cash. The value totals about $350 million.

title: STORES PROTEST SIDEWALK DISPLAY BAN
description: The banner draped across 13th Avenue in Brooklyn proclaims it ''the Borough Park Street of Values.'' And discount signs in many of the windows attest to the bargain-hunting nature of shopping there.

title: Cambodia Rebels Vow To Press Hanoi Harder
description: The three leaders of Cambodia's resistance coalition ended three days of talks here today and said they had resolved to increase diplomatic and military offensives against Vietnamese occupation.

title: Libya-Japan Car Order
description: Libya's state-run automobile import corporation has placed a package order with five Japanese car companies for a total of 35,000 cars, a spokesman for one of the companies, the Toyota Corporation, said. Delivery of the first batch of about 5,000 cars to the Tibesti Automobile General Company is to be completed toward the end of this year. The four other manufacturers are Nissan, Mitsubishi, Mazda and Honda.

title: LOUGANIS AND MERRIOTT GAIN

title: Uganda Rules Death Penalty For New Crime of Terrorism
description: Uganda's Parliament has passed a law imposing the death penalty for the new offense of terrorism and life imprisonment for cattle rustling, the Uganda radio said today. Up to now, terrorism has not been on the statutes as a crime.

title: A PLUM GOES TO SOUTH DAKOTA
description: The Shrine to Music Museum at the University of South Dakota has acquired the Witten Family Collection, a collection of 16th, 17th and 18th-century Italian stringed instruments, bows, labels, tools and documentary source materials that is widely considered to be the most extensive collection of its kind. The $3 million the museum spent on the Witten Collection came from private donors, who requested anonymity, and is believed to represent the largest sum ever paid by a museum for a collection of antique musical instruments. The announcement of the purchase brings to an end two months of active negotiations, in which several organizations, among them the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, the Germanisches Nationalmuseum in Nuremberg, and the city of Cremona, Italy, attempted to raise the funds neccessary to purchase the collection.

title: GUATEMALA'S VOTERS TAKE A SMALL STEP
description: GUATEMALA WORKMEN were busy last week polishing brass and dusting mahogany desks in the downtown building that housed the Guatemalan Congress until it was dissolved more than two years ago. In a few weeks, the desks will be occupied by the 88 deputies of the Constituent Assembly who were elected Sunday. They will work on a new constitution, Guatemala's fifth in 40 years, that is supposed to lead the country back to civilian rule.

title: MONDALE TOUCHES ALL BASES BUT DOESN'T MANAGE TO SCORE
description: WASHINGTON THE selection of a running mate is traditionally a way to heal a party's wounds. But last week the process itself emerged as a potential threat to Democratic unity and Walter F. Mondale's hopes for a peaceful convention. Throughout the spring, divisions grew naturally out the primary process. But this new strain is mainly of Mr. Mondale's own making.

title: A SURVIVAL FIGHT IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: IN Pratt & Whitney's sprawling machine-tool factory here, an unsettling quiet has set in. Many of the assembly bays in the hangar-like room stand empty, parking spots are easy to come by in the company lot and workers hover over aging equipment that has been dulled by decades of use. Trounced by imports and struggling to fatten an anemic order book, the plant here, like the rest of the machine-tool industry, is grappling with its worst crisis since the Depression. Business should have improved markedly by now in this once-thriving industry, which makes the high-precision metal-cutting tools essential for producing such things as automobile fenders, airplane fusilages and the machines needed by other industries. But the business continues deep in the doldrums, with no letup in sight. As many other industries surge ahead, propelled forward by the country's booming economic recovery, the machine-tool industry is still in crisis. Orders, which analysts estimate could reach about $2.8 billion this year, are stuck at half their 1979 levels and employment, at 67,000 workers, wavers around 30 percent below its peak at that time. While American industry is operating at over 80 percent of capacity, machine- tool manufacturers are treading water at just 60 percent of capacity. Imports have become such a significant factor that they now account for almost 40 percent of the market, double the level of only five years ago. Although there has been a modest rise in orders in the last year, orders remain so weak that executives and analysts are starting to realize that the industry is undergoing a sharp, and perhaps irreversible, contraction.

description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, commander of the National Defense Forces, said Friday that a colonel acting alone had tried to oust him from the military leadership.

description: It was classic political gaffe, constructed of careless staff work and atrocious timing. Last week, on the eve of a luncheon called by President Reagan to make peace with moderate environmental groups, the White House released the news that Anne M. Burford, who was forced last year to resign as head of the Environmental Protection Agency, had been selected to head an Administration advisory group that deals with oceans and atmosphere.

title: Jill Lindsey Betrothed To Rev. T. L. Auman

title: MARROW TREATMENT AVAILABLE IN COUNTY
description: PEOPLE with leukemia and related blood disorders who require a bone marrow transplant - the exchange of some of a sibling's marrow to the patient, whose own bone marrow can no longer fight disease - can now receive this treatment at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla.

The Assembly is to meet in a special session Tuesday. The proposal includes a general salary increase of $28 a month and more increases for low-paid workers.

The event, which was originally shown on Showtime, returns to prime- time cable on Wednesday, when it will be shown at 9 P.M. on WHT (the service will also be presenting the two-hour program at 1:30 that afternoon; in addition, Showtime will rebroadcast the same show later this month.)

title: New Mexico Seeks Geese
description: BOSQUE DEL APACHE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, N.M., July 7 (UPI) - Young Canada geese will be placed in this wildlife refuge about 10 miles south of Socorro, N.M., to try to get the birds to return to the area in the winter. In past years, thousands of Canada geese spent the winter in the central Rio Grande Valley, but recently they have been migrating to Colorado, officials said. Jack Herring, a biologist with the Department of Game and Fish, said two groups of young birds would be placed with 14 adult birds whose wings have been clipped in an attempt to create a bond between the birds and the habitat.

title: AN EBB TIDE FOR JAPAN'S FISHING INDUSTRY
description: The Soviet Union startled Japan last month by announcing that by year's end it would terminate a broad agreement governing fishing rights between the two countries. Officials in Tokyo said last week that they did not fully understand the Soviet action, but they needed no one to explain its impact. Unless a new accord is reached, it will be almost impossible for Japanese fishermen to catch salmon and sea trout in Soviet waters of the northern Pacific.

title: IN THE GRAND TRADITION

It had been hit the day before by an Iraqi missile at Kharg Island, an Iranian loading dock, and was still ablaze. ''The Iraqis destroyed it. It was full of oil,'' he said.

The curfew, from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M., put the Mayor at odds with the Amer- ican Civil Liberties Union, which sued to have it lifted as discriminatory against young people.

title: BEST SELLERS July 8, 1984
description: Fiction1 44 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam, $19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932. 2 37 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The relationship of a mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years. 3

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Everyone loves the Frick Collection, which stands at 1 East 70th Street and can be visited every day except Mondays. It comes top of the list for many a visitor from overseas, and when Prof. Francesco Valcanover, superintendent of the Venetian museums, was asked not so long ago to remodel the Ca d'Oro, a great Venetian town house long closed for repairs, he said that he would do his best to make it ''something like the Frick.''

title: FINAL SIX BOXERS QUALIFY
description: Tyrell Biggs of Philadelphia and Pernell Whitaker of Norfolk, Va., won berths today on the United States Olympic boxing team. Ricky Womack of Detroit, like Biggs and Whitaker a world amateur champion, did not.

title: 300 YEARS OF TREASURES AT CHATSWORTH
description: Driving east from Manchester to Chatsworth, the ancestral home in Derbyshire of the Dukes of Devonshire, one travels along narrow hilly roads through green cow pastures criss-crossed with the dry-stone walls that serve the purpose of dividing the fields, as do hedgerows in other parts of England. Clumps of cowslip, those rare fragrant yellow flowers, indicate the chalky soil below. After Bakewell, the scenery becomes familiar to anyone who has read Jane Austen's ''Pride and Prejudice'' and remembers Elizabeth Bennett's first impression of Pemberly, Fitzwilliam Darcy's country house in Derbyshire: ''They gradually ascended for half a mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable eminence, where the woods ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by Pemberly House, situated on the opposite side of a valley into which the road with some abruptness wound. It was a large, handsome, stone building, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of high woody hills; and in front, a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance.''

title: SHULTZ AGAIN SAYS U.S. WANTS TO DISCUSS SPACE ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States would be ready to negotiate agreements with the Soviet Union on at least some aspects of space weaponry if a formula could be worked out for starting the talks in September.

title: Rust Never Sleeps With Neil Young and Crazy Horse Vestron Video 111 minutes. $29.95.
description: Neil Young, one of rock's most fascinating and inconsistent performers, reached what may be his artistic peak with the arena shows of his 1978 tour. This stereo video cassette documents one of them, a San Francisco concert, from the audience's point of view.

title: 2 CATHOLIC PAPERS MIRROR SPLIT OVER ORDER ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: Differences between the Archdiocese of New York and the Brooklyn Diocese over the city's executive order barring discrimination against homosexuals in hiring have been underscored in articles in their newspapers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The June 17 review of ''Herbie Hancock and the Rockit Band'' incorrectly described the songs on the video cassette. The complete video clips of both ''Rockit'' and ''Autodrive'' are included.

title: INDIAN AIRPORT GUARDS SUSPENDED OVER HIJACKING
description: Authorities suspended a number of security guards at the airport in Srinagar today and questioned others in connection with the hijacking of an Indian Airways jet to Pakistan.

title: THE REGION
description: Trump TowerGets a Break

title: ;  Stallone Hits BackTiger Eye Limited, the boxing promotion company of
description: Sylvester Stallone, has sued Aaron Pryor, charging the International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight champion broke his contract when he retired last fall and then returned to the ring without the promoter's permission.

title: DISCOUNTS ON ADJUSTABLE MORTGAGES
description: those tempting discounts that got millions of people to try living with the uncertainty of variable monthly housing costs - are becoming standard in the mortgage marketplace. But the discounted rates are becoming less tempting because of market and industry pressures.

title: RETIREES CHOOSING L.I. OVER SUN BELT
description: ALBERT STONE and his wife, Frances, who are among the 400,000 residents of Long Island over the age of 60, retired seven years ago. They sold their home in Port Washington and built another in Southold, which they call ''the most beautiful town in the world.''

title: MEN OF BRONZE DEFEAT TIME
description: The two great seas into which Italy dips its toe - the Tyrrhenian and the Ionian - have always been rich sources of legend and adventure. It was, after all, in these waters that Ulysses found himself in Homer's Odyssey, and it was in the cities along their coasts that the world first felt the expansion and surge of the art and civilization known as Magna Graecia: Locri, Caulonia, Scilla, Riace - their names still sound more Greek than Italian.

title: REVERSING A LENDER'S REJECTION
description: HOME buyers often worry that a blot on their credit history could result in the denial of mortgage financing, even if they are not the type of person who intentionally allows bills to pile up.

title: THEATER: TOMI OFFERS 'CRIME AND PUNISHMENT'
description: There can be few artistic ventures more courageous than the attempt to translate Fyodor Dostoyesky's classic ''Crime and Punishment'' from novel to play - especially when it is based on a translation of the novel from Russian to English. It speaks well for the version now offered at the TOMI Theater on West 72d Street that it manages to follow the complex story line reasonably well and maintains interest most of the way.

title: BOLIVIANS SEEK TO BLOCK SALE OF GUEVARA'S DIARIES
description: The Bolivian Government has appealed to British courts to block the scheduled July 16 auction of the diaries of the guerrilla leader Ernesto (Che) Guevara, which it says were stolen from Bolivian military archives.

title: 'PROVOCATIVE' CRUISE MISSILE DEPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Elisabeth Flynn Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Patrick Flynn of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter Elisabeth Carlyn Flynn to Peter Jessop Picot Glass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Toll Glass Jr. of Farmington, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass.

title: MUSEUM HOPPING IN TORONTO
description: Several alternatives are available. You can give the patient blood, stimulate the heart, give oxygen or expand or contract the arteries. If you need more information, press the button marked ''Help,'' and on the screen appears a lesson (in color, with graphics) on the functioning of the heart and circulatory system. Is this an episode starring Dr. Kildare or Dr. Welby? JOANNE KATES is the restaurant critic of The Globe and Mail of Toronto. A simulation model used in medical schools? No, it is the Ontario Science Center, and the exhibit called ''Treat an Emergency Patient'' is the center's way of unraveling the mysteries of the circulatory system.

title: Harriette Shiland To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Gallagher of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of her daughter Harriette Louise Shiland to Francis J. McDonough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. McDonough of Garden City, L.I. An early fall wedding is planned.

title: ELVIS COSTELLO STRIVES TOWARD GROWN-UP POP
description: It had to happen sooner or later.

title: SAILING DAYS AND PEACEFUL ANCHORAGES
description: BARBARA LAZEAR ASCHER is a writer who lives in New York and sails each summer along the New England coast.

title: HAIR-CARE BOOM
description: Coinciding with the trend toward shorter cuts and layered styles is the emergence of some popular new products that add volume and shape to hair and others that are designed to keep it healthy.

title: CO-OPS TIGHTEN STANDARDS FOR BUYERS

title: Peter N. Erdman Married To Maureen Gay Donovan
description: Maureen Gay Donovan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Donovan Jr. of Boynton Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Norr Erdman, a son of Mrs. Leonard Blumberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late William H. Erdman. The Rev. Francis J. Lechiara performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Boynton Beach.

title: Peter Laurence Nixon Weds Carol E. Vogler
description: Carol Eileen Vogler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Vogler of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Laurence Nixon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Nixon of Pittsfield, Mass. The Rev. Harold R. Dean performed the ceremony at the Morristown (N.J.) Unitarian Fellowship.

title: TRAPPED VICTIM FEARED IT WOULD BE A 'LIFETIME'
description: Judith A. Loriaux was on her way with four friends from Washington to Montreal early this morning for a bicycling trip when their Amtrak passenger train derailed. The 42-year-old woman was trapped in her sleeping compartment for about the next seven hours.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: CITY OPERA: :BARBIERE' OPENS SEASON
description: The New York City Opera, firm in the belief that life begins at 40, opened the first summer season in its history Friday night with appropriately celebratory flourishes and a new production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia.'' The flourishes included a short, graceful speech by Beverly Sills, the company's general director, and the reading of congratulatory telegrams from President Reagan, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Court CurbsFreedom ofEditorialist

title: WORKERS ARE OFTEN A HAZARD TO THEMSELVES
description: After 12 years working in a Florida battery recycling plant, George Mount has lead coursing through his bloodstream. Doctors have told him that, at age 32, he has serious kidney damage from exposure to the poison.

title: GOVERNOR HUNT GETS APOLOGY
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. received an apology today from a South Carolina publisher who printed what he acknowledged were unsubstantiated rumors about Mr. Hunt's sex life.

title: AIR FORCES'S ALASKA PILOTS AWAIT CALL TO INTERCEPT SOVIET CRAFT GALENA AIR FORCE STATION, Alaska (AP) - When Capt. Billy Bob Wimberly's F-15 jet fighter shrieks off the runway at this tiny air base near the Yukon River, he knows that within minutes he may be eye to eye with a Soviet military pilot.
description: Captain Wimberly, a taciturn 30- year-old from Muleshoe, Tex., has intercepted Soviet aircraft heading toward Alaska three times in 13 months in international airspace over Arctic waters.

title: LEGAL SCHOLAR DISPUTES LITIGATION BOOM
description: A legal sociologist has taken issue with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and other critics of the American legal system, saying a ''litigation explosion'' depicted by them may not exist.

title: Pentathlon Athlete Cleared of Rigging
description: Rob Stull was acquitted today of charges that he conspired with his competitors in the modern pentathlon Olympic trials to rig fencing bouts.

title: MUSIC: 6 JAZZ ARTISTS IN A DIXIELAND PROGRAM
description: A group of longtime performers in various areas of traditional jazz have been brought together as the New York City Dixieland Jazz Ensemble to play a series of Monday-night engagements at the Orpheum Theater, Second Avenue at St. Marks Place.

title: Nancy Barger Is Bride Of Capt. E. A. Seadler
description: Nancy Ruth Barger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Barger of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to Capt. Einar Austin Seadler, U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Seadler of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Bernard Bloomstone performed the ceremony at Sinai Temple in Springfield, Mass.

title: COMPOSER SEEKS NICHE OF HIS OWN
description: ROBERT Griffin does not play in hotel lounges. His songs will never make it onto MTV or the top 40, which is fine with him.

title: MADISON TO VOTE ON TOLL-FREE CALLS
description: MADISON has cleared its last regulatory hurdle for a vote on toll-free telephone calls to New Haven.

title: 3 KILLED AS TRAIN FALLS INTO RAVINE IN VERMONT HILLS
description: An Amtrak passenger train with 278 people aboard derailed while crossing a washed-out culvert this morning, killing at least three people, injuring more than a hundred and trapping passengers in a crushed sleeping car. The train was bound from Washington to Montreal.

title: Paris Assembly Rejects School Bill Referendum
description: The French National Assembly has rejected a Senate proposal to put to a referendum a bill that would revise the nation's private schools.

title: LAG IN STATE COMMUNICATIONS FOUGHT
description: TRENTON THE PACE of legislative action in the capital has not quickened much over the years, as witnessed by the most-recent rush of bill passing by state lawmakers anxious to leave on their summer vacations.

title: PUSHING FOR WEAPONS THAT WORK
description: THERE are few ways more brutal to treat a complex machine than to slam it down regularly on the heaving deck of a ship at sea, as the Navy does with its carrier-based jet fighters. The repair bills for these aircraft are astronomical and the planes spend far more time in below-decks maintenance than in the air.

title: A EUROPEAN DEBUT FOR L.I. SINGER
description: these are Nadia Pelle's twin preoccupations. They are with her while she works, most recently singing in Peter Brook's controversial adaptation of Bizet's ''Carmen'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center.

title: LET'S HAVE LUNCH
description: Don't call the cafeteria at General Foods corporte offices... well, don't call it a cafeteria. ''The word has a very bad taste in our mouths,'' said Ludwig Schmitz, general manager of Daka, which handles food services for the company. ''We refer to it as the servery or as our self-service dining room.''

title: BUNGLING AND SURMISES
description: IN GOD'S NAME. An Investigation into the Murder of Pope John Paul I. By David A. Yallop Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Rainy Day 5 for 6-Day Run
description: A nine-hour rainstorm yesterday ''broke the monotony'' for the leader of the New York Six-Day Run and caused the top female runner to feel more at home. But the weather also left the competitors' sleeping tents flooded, the outdoor kitchen ''submerged'' and phones out of order as the fifth day of the run was completed at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: A 5-YEAR DECLINE IN LAUNDRIES
description: The number of laundries and dry cleaners in the United States declined with the increase in popularity of polyester clothing and a restructuring of the coin-laundry business.

title: MAJOR FOOTBALL COLLEGES AWAIT SIGNALS FOR A NEW TV PLAN
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.

description: John Gruen is a senior editor of Dance Magazine.

description: The world fast-pitch softball championship got under way Friday night, and pitching was dominant.

title: Express Owner, Sued, Cannot Sell the Team
description: J. William Oldenburg, owner of the Los Angeles Express, has been restrained from selling the team after a savings and loan institution filed suit Friday against him and two of his companies charging fraud and breach of contract.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY:AROUND SOUTH AMERICA;TOURS FOR HEARING IMPAIRED; From Panama
description: To the Strait Of Magellan A little bit of the romance of the seas is about to vanish forever. Delta Line is phasing out the Santa Maria, the Santa Magdalena and the Santa Mariana. Each accommodating fewer than 100 passengers, the vessels - built in 1964 by the Grace Line for cargo and luxury travel - earned high repute on voyages that circumnavigated South America, passing through the Panama Canal in the north and around the Strait of Magellan in the south.

title: BASEBALL'S SECRET WEAPON
description: It was only the 1st of June, but in Detroit the mood was already World Series. The world champion Baltimore Orioles were in town for their first meeting with the league-leading Tigers, who had begun the season sensationally, with a 35-3 record. The habitually slow-starting Orioles had lost 10 of their first 12 games but had pulled to within 11 1/2 games of the Tigers, who were still leading the American League's Eastern Division. Both clubs were primed for the series. Detroit fans held a pep rally downtown. Local newspapers put out special supplements. The press box was packed.
