title: Possible Canadian Vote Is Said to Annoy Queen
description: A Buckingham Palace spokesman said today that Queen Elizabeth II was ''annoyed'' over the possibility that her planned two-week visit to Canada next week might have to be canceled if the new Canadian leader, John Turner, called elections for this summer.

title: Major Asbestos Work Set
description: Officials have decided to remove asbestos at the Martin Luther King High School ''in one continuous job'' this fall, forcing the school's 2,700 students to attend classes elsewhere until the work is done. A deputy schools superintendent, Frederick B. Wookey, said officials were going to have some of the material removed but decided ''it would not be wise to wait longer'' in taking out all of the asbestos when it was found to be deteriorating faster than expected.

title: PICKING FILM NITS
description: To the Editor:

title: SURVEY SEEKS DATA ON COMMUTER-LOT CRIME
description: A STATE TROOPER last year responded to a call about the theft of gasoline from a self- service station on Route 32 in Willington. A few minutes later, he stopped a car on Interstate 86 that matched the description given by the station owner. The trooper found out that the man driving it was not the car's owner.

title: Andretti Sets a Record, Wins Pole in Cleveland
description: Mario Andretti set a track record of 126.393 miles an hour today to win the pole position for Sunday's Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix.

title: A Correction On Scarsdale History
description: Betsy Brown's article (''Ossining Villages Weigh Secession,'' June 24) had (a) date wrong.

title: FESTIVAL'S PROGRAM OF MUSIC IS VARIED
description: THE Hudson River Museum has its jazz, one finds glorious chamber music at Caramoor and the orchestral concerts continue at Lyndhurst - the musical arts are being uncommonly well served in the county this summer. Now, with Pepsico's Summerfare '84, the feast becomes even more abundant. After four years of concentrating more on dance and drama, the festival on the State University of New York campus at Purchase has made music an equal partner and has scheduled events that cover the entire spectrum.

title: AN ANCIENT THEATER OF HUMAN COMEDY
description: The lady is grieving, weeping at the announcement that her husband must leave on a business trip. Her tears look real, but she has been furtively dipping her fingers in a tiny cup of water and dampening her cheeks. The household manservant suspects the deception and slips ink in the cup, with obvious results. Furious at being found out, the wife pursues her husband and his servant, and inks their faces, too.

title: EMIGRES SEE MERITS AND FLAWS IN SOVIET SESEARCH
description: Research in the Soviet Union, often regarded as a rival of the United States in science and technology, is aided by a strong educational system, but is hampered by a lack of innovation and inadequate communication within Soviet society, recent surveys of Soviet emigre scientists have found.

title: A BLUE-CHIP COMPLEX
description: FIFTEEN years ago Albert D. Phelps Jr., a real-estate developer, began acquiring land on Route 7 in Norwalk. He paid about $850,000 for 46 acres of gas stations, used-car lots, billboards, an abandoned factory and assorted debris. It was situated just north of the juncture of Route 7 and Exits 39-40 of the Merritt Parkway and overlooked the Norwalk River.

title: CONSERVATIVES ON SUPREME COURT DOMINATED RULINGS OF LATEST TERM
description: The conservatives on the Supreme Court dominated the term that just ended to a degree unmatched in the Court's recent history.

title: Peer H. Munck Is Married To Jennifer A. Shachner
description: Jennifer Aleta Shachner, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Shachner of Brooklyn, and Peer Henrik Munck, a son of Fredrik and Tove Munck of Oslo, were married yesterday at the Pierre in New York, where the Rev. Cameron Allan, a Lutheran minister, and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz officiated.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: While studies may show that dead-tired interns are able to perform routine mechanical tasks, anyone with a modicum of common sense knows that a person who has not had any sleep for 36 hours is not thinking straight, and patient care invariably suffers. What adds insult to injury is the fact that many of these tasks could easily be performed by people with little or no medical training if hospital administrators were willing to expend the small amount of money needed to hire such personnel.

title: Cathy J. Brown Plans A September Wedding
description: Maj. Gen. Donald D. Brown, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Brown of Scott Air Force Base, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cathy J. Brown to Alvin K. Peinhardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Peinhardt of Hanceville, Ala.

title: Miss McCormack Marries Professor
description: Mary McCormack, an investment banker in the corporate finance department of Advest Inc. in Hartford, was married in Wellesley, Mass., yesterday to Dr. Steven Rosenthal, an assistant professor of Middle Eastern history at the University of Hartford. Rabbi Samuel Umen and the Rev. Brian Manning, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College.

title: Barbara Margon Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Margon of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jane Margon, to Mitchell Jeffrey Nadler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Nadler, also of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for November.

title: THE LIFE LESSONS OF AN OLYMPIC CYCLIST
description: When I was 18 years old, all I wanted to do was race my bicycle. I had felt that way since sometime before 1964 when, at the impressionable age 15, I had watched the United States Olympic cycling trials at Kissena Park in Flushing, Queens.

title: HYDROPOWER LINE BACKED IN REPORT
description: Two administrative judges of the Public Service Commission have recommended approval for the construction of a 345-kilovolt, 184-mile power line through central New York State. If built, the line would be a key link in bringing relatively inexpensive Canadian hydropower to the New York metropolitan area.

title: Miss Kligman Engaged To Andrew J. Shechtel
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Kligman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter Raquel Kligman to Andrew Jay Shechtel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Shechtel of Bowie, Md. The wedding is planned for October.

title: Robin Tilghman Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Austin Tilghman of Fairfield, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Shiland Tilghman to Byam Kerby Stevens 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens Jr. of Jericho, L.I. The wedding is planned for September.

title: GIANTS BEAT CUBS TO END SLIDE
description: Mike Krukow held Chicago to six hits over eight and two-thirds innings and drove in the go-ahead run with a sacrifice fly today to help the San Francisco Giants end a four-game losing streak with a 7-2 victory over the Cubs.

title: PLAIN AND FANCY
description: Many bridge organizations have had to face various forms of the following problem: What action is appropriate when a player, pair or team refuses to play against particular opponents? Should those who balk in such circumstances be subject to disciplinary penalties that go beyond loss of points on the deal or match concerned?

title: Korean Jet Sequel
description: After a Soviet fighter pilot shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 last September with the loss of 269 lives, the United States demanded in a diplomatic note that the Soviet Union pay compensation to the families of the 61 Americans who died. But the Soviet Embassy refused to accept the note, contending that the jetliner had been on a spying mission off Siberia and that the United States had been responsible for sending it.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ; Matz, on Last Promise, Triumphs in Jumpoff
description: Michael Matz of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., won today's intermediate jumpoff on Last Promise at the seventh annual I Love New York horse show. The 7-year-old bay gelding was timed in 33.415 seconds, beating the 35.058 turned in by Henri Prudent of Nancy, France, on Kim du Soultrait.

It consists of one musical, ''Side by Side by Sondheim,'' and two plays, ''Gingerbread Lady'' by Neil Simon, and ''Fifth of July'' by Lanford Wilson, about the Vietnam war.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: It now appears that when the county's 400-member chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers gave the Norden Bombsight a tricentennial honor role last year by naming it as one of 10 outstanding Westchester engineering accomplishments, it erred by some 25 miles. The device, famous during World War II, was developed not on Westmoreland Avenue in White Plains, as had been thought, but on Varick Street in Manhattan.

title: Harry Weyher 3d And Anda Gailitis Wed in Newport
description: Anda Gailitis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Janis Gailitis of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to Harry Frederick Weyher 3d, the son of Mr. Weyher and Mrs. Alan K. Gage, both of New York. The Rev. Tyler Johnson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; 'War Tax' Battle
description: When Alice Drefchinski, a nurse in Franklin, La., filed her 1982 Federal income taxes, she took a $5,082 ''war tax deduction,'' citing religious convictions against supporting the military. The Internal Revenue Service cited the 1982 Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act.

title: ROSALIND CROSS TO BE MARRIED
description: James Eliot Cross of Gulf Stream, Fla., and Meridith Morgan Homet of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosalind Morgan Cross, to Yves Dujardin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Dujardin of Paris. The wedding is planned for Sept. 22.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL

description: Gaye Randolph Symington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harrison Symington Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Martyn Lacy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lacy of Lebanon, Ohio. The Rev. Robert Buckwater of the First Congregational Church in Williamstown, Mass., performed the ceremony in Williamstown.

title: FISH DISHES AND SEAFOOD SALADS ENHANCE SUMMER MEALS
description: LIGHT dishes based on fish and seafood are particularly appealing in summer. Salads of combined fish or seafood with vegetables can be devised almost endlessly, using either leftovers or freshlyprepared ingredients. Quiche- like tarts with seafood fillings are another category of dishes that are suitable to serve for a summer lunch, a picnic or as a first course for a more elaborate dinner in warm weather.

description: A boutonniere is a small bloom or nosegay that fits neatly into the buttonhole of a jacket and rides like a jewel against the heart. Once popular with every well dressed gentleman, the boutonniere is making a comeback today with both sexes.

title: NORMAN LEADS BY A SHOT IN WESTERN
description: Greg Norman, who beat Jack Nicklaus by two shots for the Canadian Open title last Sunday, this time faces a challenge from Tom Watson and Larry Nelson in his quest for a second victory in a row and third in six weeks.

title: BATTER GETS A BIRD, FIELDER GETS THE BALL
description: With one out in the fifth inning of the second game of a double- header victory by the Oakland A's over the Milwaukee Brewers Friday night, Rickey Henderson of the A's hit a routine fly ball to center field. Rick Manning positioned himself under the ball and was ready to make the catch, when the ball hit a bird.

title: Jewish Group Supports Closer Ties With Blacks By United Press International
description: The American Jewish Congress yesterday threw its support behind a call by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to renew historical ties between the black and Jewish communities.

title: CATERER SIGNS UP
description: Built in 1859 by a couple who ran a boarding school there, the stately three-story structure at 236 Second Avenue, near 15th Street, served as a private home for a succession of merchants, as a nursery school and as the headquarters for the Jewish Ministers Cantors Association. It has long been known as Rutherford House, in honor of a former owner of the land.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: I was surprised to find no recommendations for change in the article on residents. Why not alter the antiquated system to make the first six months of the residency less exhausting, increasing the demands as the doctor gains skill and confidence? A more open system would allow residents at various levels to assist one another more freely in the interest of the main tasks: patient care and physician training.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Making Ends Meet As Arturo Durazo Moreno built and ostentatiously furnished a $2.5 million estate during his six years as Mexico City's chief of police, people began to wonder how he did it on a salary that never exceeded $65 a week. Few suspected it was frugality.

title: No Headline
description: Cold Comfort From the Court The Supreme Court ended its 1983-84 term with a pile of important decisions that seem disastrous for civil liberties, civil rights and even respect for law. The current majority continues to reach out awkwardly, even injudiciously, to open loopholes in the Bill of Rights. For all the restraint preached by conservatives, the final week alone brought three decisions that increase governmental power over innocent and guilty citizens alike.

title: U.S. To Downgrade Status of Snail Darter
description: The snail darter, a tiny fish that stalled construction of a multimillion- dollar Federal dam for two years, is to be removed from the endangered species list next month, officials have said.

title: ORDERLY CROWD OF 45,000 CHEERS JACKSON CONCERT
description: After all the yearning and all the waiting, the verdicts were finally in on the opening performance of the Jackson brothers' four-month, 13-city tour, and they ran the gamut.

title: ARE THINGS REALLY BETTER AFTER 4 YEARS?
description: ARE Americans better off now

title: WEIGHT LIFTER GIVEN HEARING ON SUSPENSION
description: Attorneys for the weight lifter Jeffrey Michels asked a United States Olympic Committee advisory panel today to allow Michels to compete at the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles.

title: UNDAUNTED BY FLOODS, 8 FARMS IN STATE TO HAVE OPEN HOUSES
description: DESPITE the early June flooding that washed out farms around the state, the Connecticut Farm Bureau is going ahead with plans for open houses at eight farms in seven counties next Saturday and Sunday.

title: MADNESS THROUGH A KALEIDOSCOPE
description: THE CEREMONY

title: A Correction
description: In The Week in Review last Sunday, a caption with a picture of the Rev. Jesse Jackson in Managua incorrectly identified the Nicaraguan official with him. He was Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra, brother of the junta coordinator, Daniel Ortega Saavedra.

title: GETTING TO KNOW CALZONE
description: It is remarkable how one dish can capture and hold the imagination of food enthusiasts. In the United States, at least, one of the most recent of these entries is an Italian specialty that had its beginnings perhaps a century or more ago, a filled bun or turnover - call it what you will - known as calzone.

title: 15 OF THE WORKS IN A STOLEN TRUCKLOAD OF ART ARE RECOVERED
description: On May 22, thieves stole a truck loaded with more than 70 works of art valued at over $1 million during a brief stop in Manhattan. The theft, on Columbus Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets, occurred while the driver was making a telephone call.

title: AFGHANS HERE BATTLE ODDS
description: '' EVERY Afghan,'' said the 16th-century poet Khushan Khatak, ''is a poet-warrior.'' Their country, with a history of noncompromise, individuality and national pride, has been unconquered since the time of Genghis Khan, and it kept its borders closed until after World War II.

title: SOCIAL REALISM LINKS TWO SMALL EXHIBITIONS
description: REGINALD MARSH and Les Levine make an unlikely pair but brought together by the exigences of reviewing, as they are here, each proves to be a Social Realist of a kind.

title: Magician Drowns in Stunt
description: A magician drowned Friday morning at Winona Lake while rehearsing an escape trick in which he was handcuffed and chained before jumping into the water, the authorities said. The victim was identified as Jeff Rayburn Hopper, 23 years old, of Eckerman, Mich.

title: FOR SHIRLEY KNIGHT, TO ACT IS TO RISK
description: ONCE labeled a promising Hollywood starlet, Shirley Knight made it clear that she was more interested in substance than stardom. Choosing a detour from movie glamour, she opted for taking risks, personal and professional. After marrying the controversial English playwright John Hopkins in 1968, she lived in London, but kept returning to her real roots - the theater, in classical and contemporary roles, on Broadway and in regional playhouses. She became known for her artistic convictions and concern for causes, rather than her interest in commercialism.

title: 11 ARE KILLED AS BOAT CAPSIZES ON TENNESSEE RIVER
description: Eleven people were killed yesterday when a triple-decked riverboat, buffeted by a sudden squall with winds of 70 miles an hour, capsized on the Tennessee River near Huntsville, Ala.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
MY DEARS, IT WAS NEVER BORING
description: THE article was small and nestled in the midst of full- page ads in the local Sunday newspaper. I read it once and read it the second time, fighting off the wave of defensiveness that surged within me and tried to be objective, remembering the years we had spent in the community bringing up our own four children. Was Farmingdale really such a wasteland? And why hadn't I noticed it?

title: THE NATION
description: AppointmentsIn the Recess

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: HIS DEATH GAVE LIFE TO HIS LENGEND
description: JAMES AGEE

title: M.F. Loehr Weds Deborah Brower
description: Deborah Willetts Brower, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Prentice Willetts Brower of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Mark Frederick Loehr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond C. Loehr of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: THE REGION
description: Double PaymentsCut City's Losses

title: MaryF.Counihan,Lawyer, Is Wed to D. D. Livingston
description: Mary Fawley Counihan, an assistant counsel with the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston, and D. Dunbar Livingston, an assistant district attorney for Essex County, Mass., were married yesterday at St. George's School Chapel in Middletown, Mass.

title: REACTIONS VARY ON BUILDING MORATORIUM
description: -month moratorium on development that was declared last month by North Salem, a 22-square- mile town - the same size as the island of Manhattan - with a population of 4,100.

title: SETTING THE STYLE
description: Does anyone care how the last-place finisher in a tournament did it? Does anyone speculate on whether he was overmatched, unlucky or out of form? Whether he went around making excuses or continued to hold his head high as his opponents collected the points?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BLAIR'S NIGHTMARE. By Zilpha Keatley Snyder. 204 pp. New York; Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: CLASS PLAY, $11.80, CAPTURES OAKS
description: Class Play, making only her seventh career start and her second on the dirt, benefited from a shrewd ride on the rail by Jean Cruguet to post a mild upset over Life's Magic and Miss Oceana in the $229,200 Coaching Club American Oaks yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: CITY JOBS INCREASE MAINLY FOR SUBURBANITES
description: For months, New York officials had been crowing over the the city's job statistics, and with good reason. In May, there were 3.4 million jobs in the city, 80,000 more than a year ago and a 10-year record. Such numbers reflected the strength of the city economy and, perhaps, Mayor Koch's prospects as election year loomed.

title: MISS ROLLER IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Christine Roller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton S. Roller of Summit, N.J., to Richard Steven Emerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Emerson of Wilton, Conn., took place yesterday. Msgr. Harold A. Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: A.T.& T. UNIT PICKS SITE IN SOMERSET
description: A. T. & T. Technologies, which occupies several facilities throughout New Jersey, including one it shares with Bell Communications Research in Piscataway, will consolidate and move late next year to a new building in Warren Township, Somerset County, that is being built by Bellemead Development Corporation.

title: Whitestone Co-op
description: To the Editor:

title: Rep. Mikulski Is Picked To Lead Mondale Drive
description: Representative Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland was named Friday to be the national co-chairman of Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign.

title: 'WE SHALL MISS THE PLEASURE OF THEIR COMPANY'
description: THREE major creative talents from the East End of Long Island have died in the last few months - the artists Lee Krasner and Jimmy Ernst and the writer Irwin Shaw.

title: Rains Kill 14 in South Korea
description: Torrential rainfalls in the south over the last four days killed at least 14 people, left 23 missing and made 1,866 people homeless, the Disaster Relief Headquarters said today. Floods washed away bridges and roads, isolating villages and forced schools to close.

title: ONCE UPON A TIME, IN THE TROUBLED LAND OF PG...
description: The place is Fairlawn, U.S.A., an idyllic middle- class suburban community where Steven Spielberg might like to make a horror movie. Gathered in the pine-panelled game room of this modest, $750,000 home, one of 20 just like it on their street, are the members of the handsome Doppler family - Dad and Mom, who are in their late 30's, Josh (17) Patty (14), Debbie (12) and Seth (8). Through the windows that look onto the backyard patio, we can see the last rays of the setting sun, the usual barbecue equipment and an above-ground swimming pool, which leaks. The children seem bored, anxious to get on with their own affairs. Dad and Mom, sitting side by side on the cowhide loveseat, underneath an absolutely awful Utrillo print, look tense.

title: WARSPEAK
description: ''We are doing to the English language what the European tribes did to Latin,'' says Ned Conger, a retired Navy captain. ''Most of us can still speak classical English, but in our working lives we are creating new languages - speaking jargon and acronymese.''

title: HEADLINERS
description: Could It Be Envy? As one of the founders of the West German Green Party five years ago, Petra Kelly used her talent for attracting publicity to bring in votes for the Greens, then a little- known collection of ecologists, pacifists, neutralists and feminists. The party went on to win 26 seats in the Bundestag and to displace the Free Democrats as the country's third largest vote-getters, at least in last month's elections for the largely powerless European Parliament.

title: PRO RACES RETURNING TO GLEN
description: It was the fall of 1981 when Rick Mears won the last professional auto race at the Watkins Glen grand prix circuit. A few weeks later, plagued by indebtedness from an expansion program, the track operators declared bankruptcy. Since then the upstate New York race track, home to the United States Grand Prix for nearly two decades, has been inactive, save for an occasional amateur sports car race.

ART;
CLOTHING AS AN EXPRESSION, NOT AS SOMETHING TO WEAR

title: Charlotte Streeter Goodhue Is Married
description: Charlotte Streeter Goodhue, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thayer Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Edward Krakoff, a son of Dr. Irwin H. Krakoff of Houston and Miriam Krakoff of Burlington, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Wintle performed the ceremony at First Church of Christ, Unitarian, in Lancaster, Mass.

title: MALE MYSTIQUE
description: So now we have the new man. You read about him in the magazines. You see movies about him. People appear on television to talk about him, and sometimes he comes on television to talk about himself: ''I am the new man, nothing at all like the previous man. . . .''

title: MARINERS END SLIDE AND HALT BLUE JAYS' STREAK, 8-4
description: Al Cowens clouted a three-run homer and Jim Presley hit a two-run double as the Seattle Mariners ended a six- game losing streak with an 8-4 victory today over the Blue Jays.

title: THE BEST INTRODUCTION
description: I know it's unfashionable, even unspeakable in the most sophisticated circles,

title: A
description: Arthur McClure Boal, a specialist in international maritime law and a former Mayor of Pelham, N.Y., died yesterday at his home in Pelham. He was 95 years old.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BUYING ANTIQUES? ALL DEALERS DO NOT OPERATE A SHOP
description: MORRISTOWN MANY dealers of fine antiques do not maintain shops; instead, they sell exclusively at shows or by appointment. Unless one attends antiques shows regularly, this valuable source may remain inaccessible to the average collector.

title: MISS MITCHELL SETS RECORD IN DIVING
description: Michele Mitchell said she knew she had a good chance to make the United States Olympic diving team on the 10- meter platform tonight, but she never dreamed she would make it in such stunning fashion.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: A's 8, Brewers 2
description: Steve McCatty, after pitching a perfect game for six and one-third innings, stopped Milwaukee on six hits in recording the victory for Oakland. McCatty (6-6) didn't allow a walk and struck out two.

title: BOLSHEVIKS ON MARS
description: RED STAR

title: THE JAPANESE CHALLENGE
description: Shoulder-high partitions separate the researchers, most of them in their early 30's, and the atmosphere is casual - dirty sneakers across from button- down shirts. Workers make their own hours, and the place abounds in youthful irreverence with jokes scribbled on the shiny white panels that now serve for blackboards. That scene would be old hat in any of a dozen hubs of technological creativity in California's Silicon Valley, but it is set in Japan, and that makes it downright revolutionary.

title: SCOTT DIERKING, FORMER JET, WEDS ERIN FRANCES PHELAN
description: Erin Frances Phelan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Phelan of Kingston, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Scott Edward Dierking, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dierking of West Chicago, Ill.

title: DEMOCRATS MAKE PLANS TO AVOID 'BIG SPENDER' LABEL
description: They won't propose billion- dollar programs to create jobs, although there will be assurances of help for workers in fading industries. They will endorse child-care programs for working mothers, but in collaboration with churches, employers and other private groups. They would expand the nation's pool of housing for the poor, but first they would rehabilitate the housing they have already built. Support of a national health care system used to be the acid test of a true Democrat, but not in 1984. They would leave the benefits alone and curb the inflation in doctors' and hospital fees.

title: AILEY COMPANY TO OPEN AT THE MET
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which opens a two-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow, will be the first black modern dance company to appear there. Mr. Ailey, who does not need much to make him anxious about a forthcoming season, is exuberant at the prospect.

title: STATE PUSHES ROLE AS A SET FOR MOVIES
description: THE New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Development Commission promotes the state's landscape as being so rich in variety that it can provide a suitable filming location for almost any script.

title: Barbara Blair Engaged To Stuart S. Randall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David William Blair of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Barbara Anne Blair to Stuart Spalding Randall, a son of Mrs. James Hughes Cannon of Edgartown, Mass., and the late Donn Spalding Randall. The wedding is planned for September.

title: OLD BEARS AND NEW What New York Needs Everyone knows that New York City needs subways that won't drive passengers to tears and roadways that will be kinder to buses and cars. It also needs more teachers, more police, more low-income housing, more comfort stations, more flowers, trees and sunny days. A daily garbage pickup wouldn't be bad either.
description: But until Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper, who's in China right now, announced what he hopes to have among his souvenirs, how many of us realized how much the city needed a pair of pandas?

title: THE MAN WHO WOULD BE BEST AT EVERYTHING
description: SAN ANTONIOMike Storm says that a good pentathlete has to be built with the speed and efficiency of a Maserati, have the endurance and strength of a swimmer, must achieve absolute mental self-control for the shooting and still be able to make a horse move like a Nureyev. ''It's a total challenge,'' Storm said. ''No other sport demands all that.''

title: CHILDHOOD PAIN SHAPES A POIGNANT FILM
description: Whispers . More whispers. ''Shh, was that him? Did he call out?'' Resumption of the whispering undertones as steady and continuous as a faucet left running. In the next room a 6-year old boy lies rigid in bed, presentiments of doom in his heart.

title: THE STATE LEGISLATURE'S WORK IS NEVER DONE EITHER
description: ALBANY BEFORE it recessed last weekend, the 207th session of the New York State Legislature passed 1,154 bills, nearly 800 of which await the signature or veto of Governor Cuomo. Even so, the lawmakers left plenty of unfinished business to keep them occupied in the fall. With all 211 Statehouse seats to be contested in November, the legislators looked for issues they could campaign back home on, while putting off action on those that might pose political problems. Among the former were some ''get-tough'' criminal justice measures reducing access to trials in misdemeanor cases and allowing prosecutors to seize property used in drug dealing or certain other crimes. The lawmakers also adopted the nation's first program to curb acid rain, mandated seat belt use and moved to bail out struggling state banks by permitting them much broader leeway in investing their money. But it was generally accepted that before the end of the year the lawmakers will return to the Capitol at least once and maybe more often. Among the items they are likely to take up:

title:
DINING OUT;
STEAK HOUSE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: ALTHOUGH its name seems to echo the many variations on the familiar fish, beef and booze theme, and despite the fact that a healthy half-dozen places share the name, Scotch 'n Sirloin is not a chain, Larry Cohen, owner of the White Plains restaurant, likes to point out. Many owners within the franchise were associated with the original Binghamton restaurant, where, it is said, in 1963 the first East Coast wedding of salad bar to steak house took place.

title: 'EMPEROR JONES' TO BE A HIGHLIGHT OF SUMMERFARE
description: WHERE last year the theatrical portion of Pepsico's Summerfare was instantly identifiable - musicals based on aspects of Americana - this year's festival, which begins Friday and continues through Aug. 12, defies categorization and aims to redefine theater. An expansive view is offered: in form, theater envelops or overlaps dance and music; in scope and in origin, it is international.

title: QUALITY OF LIFE BECOMES A CAMPAIGN ISSUE IN JAPAN
description: Japan's nascent campaign for Prime Minister has spurred fresh debate over the quality of life here.

title: Local Theater: A Cue or Two
description: It was with great pleasure and enthusiasm that I read the June 17 article (''A Small Playhouse Is Returned to Use'') concerning the Julie Harris Theater in Scarborough, and the encouraging response of the Clearview School to be flexible with reference to fees; i.e., ''. . .whatever is affordable. . .'' Clearly, the Clearview School wants the theater used by community groups and is actively seeking to do so by (its) philosophy of establishing rental contracts at rates that community groups can bear.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK COMPUTER music has begun to take root in the American culture in a way that could revolutionize the older, more traditional ways of making music.

description: A teen-ager charged with slaying and mutilating a 17-year-old Long Island boy in what authorities said was a ritual carried out before followers of a satanic cult was found hanged early yesterday in his cell at the Suffolk County Jail.

title: TALKS ON SECURITY END IN STOCKHOLM
description: The Conference on European Security has adjourned for the summer, ending six months of speechmaking that, on the surface, accomplished little.

title: FORSYTHE'S STAFF CLOSING UP SHOP By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON EMPTY boxes and stacks of folders line the hallway outside the new office of New Jersey's 13th Congressional District, thus announcing the relocation of Representative Edwin B. Forsythe's staff since his death from cancer at his Moorestown home on March 29.

title: MONDALE'S AIDES, SPLIT OVER HART, FIND 3 MAYORS GAIN FOR NO. 2 SPOT
description: Aides to Walter F. Mondale are divided over the prospect of Senator Gary Hart as Mr. Mondale's running mate, and they say the Mayors of three major cities have emerged as serious contenders for the job.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE regulars are starting to come back to Fonti's Luncheonette on Main Street in Hackensack, but their return follows a bittersweet battle to relocate the mom-and- pop business, a traditional meeting place in the city's Fairmount section.

Elbert Dempsey Jr., an elder, performed the ceremony at the Ridgewood Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Kansas City, Mo.

title: REGULATIONS EYED FOR ANIMAL SHELTERS
description: AMID continuing controversy and legal maneuvering involving the Hamptons Animal Shelter, legislation to regulate private animal shelters is being considered by the Suffolk County Legislature and the Southampton Town Board.

title: Arizona Boxing To the Sports Editor:
description: Michael Katz's article about Billy Collins (''Cruelest Punches Follow Fighter's Final Ring Loss,'' The New York Times, June 17) reported that Luis Resto asked John Branca, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, if he could fight in Arizona, where there is no state commission.

description: ''I WAS RAPED,'' the woman said, her voice almost a whisper. ''Are you safe now?'' asked the volunteer on the rape ''hot line,'' her voice just as quiet.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 1 on some of the political effects of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's candidacy incorrectly described the way Representative Katie Hall of Indiana won her seat in Congress. She was elected.

description: Up and down Main Street, residents of this village expressed stunned disbelief today at the report that local youths had been involved in the slaying and mutilation of a 17-year-old boy as part of a satanic ritual.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Bruce Berenyi, acquired in a trade with the Reds last month, makes his fifth start for the Mets but his first against his former teammates. Charlie Puleo, the starter for the Reds, used to be a member of the Mets and is 1-1 against his former team. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.)

title: COURT REFUSES DAMAGES TO STOLEN BABY'S MOTHER
description: A Queens woman whose infant was kidnapped from a hospital shortly after birth cannot recover damages from the hospital for her emotional distress caused by the abduction, the state's highest court ruled last week.

title: AUDITS CATCHING MORE ERRORS IN HOSPITAL BILLS
description: A patient in a Virginia hospital last year was given one unit of albumin intravenously. But somewhere in the accounting procedure a computer key stuck, and the patient's insurance company was billed for 111 units at $56 each.

WESTCHESTER OPINION ;

title: Pelham Center: Where to Park?
description: To one who has observed the Pelham Art Center's growth over the last nine years it was of interest to read (Westchester Journal, June 10) of its proposed physical expansion. However, the article and perhaps the sponsors seem to have overlooked a potential flaw in said expansion.

title: COWARD'S WITH CARRIES THIS 'DESIGN FOR LIVING'
description: Noel Coward had his very bullish times and his very bearish times, and was never particularly confident of his status in the stockmarket of taste. What he called his ''deep Christian subconscious'' told him that he was ''a jester, a foolish, superficial, capering lightweight with neither depths nor real human understanding.'' At the same time he felt he had, again in his own words, written several comedies which ''mirrored, without over-exaggeration, a certain section of the social life of the time.'' But either way, he darkly suspected that ''immediately after my death, if not a long while before, my name will be obliterated from public memory.''

title: JERSEY TRASH HAULERS END STRIKE AND RESUME WORK
description: Striking New Jersey sanitation workers ended a weeklong walkout yesterday, voting 435 to 85 to return to work for 30 days while contract negotiations continue.

title: DALLAS SEEKS GLAMOUR IN GRAND PRIX
description: When 25 Formula One racing cars begin whizzing past the Cotton Bowl and the State Fair Food and Fiber Pavilion Sunday in the first running of the Dallas Grand Prix, it will be more than an automobile race.

title:
FACE OF THE COUNTRY;
BUBBLES BY THE GLASS IN BARCELONA'S BARS
description: Whether you call them champanerias, as do most Spaniards, or xampanyeries, as would any self-respecting Catalan, champagne bars have spread faster in Barcelona than any vogue in wine and food since ''nova cuina catalana'' - nouvelle catalan cuisine - invaded the city's fashionable restaurants over five years ago.

title:
ANTIQUES;
CHAIRS MADE FOR SENATORS
description: -era furniture made for the use of early legislators, is now on view at the Old State House Museum, 800 Main Street, Hartford.

title: DID THE 1960'S DAMAGE FICTION?
description: BEFORE the 1960's, pundits say, the economy and foreign policy made sense; afterward, chaos. Before the 60's, education was looking up; afterward, schools collapsed. Before the 60's, family was a value; afterward, the family became a time-study problem. So it went with everything American in the aftermath of the killer decade, according to consensus - finished, ruined, to hell in a handbasket.

title: Dr. Holly Anne Leather, Veterinarian, MarriesKelsey,
description: Dr. Holly Anne Leather, a veterinarian, and Dr. Peter Baker Kelsey, a physician, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Richard Shimpfky performed the ceremony.

title: CAN TROUBLED TRILOGY FULFILL ITS DREAM?
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.

title: ABOUT MEN ; RIGORS OF THE ROAD
description: Many men think traveling for a living is glamorous and exciting, but not those of us who do it. We can tell you about nights in musty motels in Missouri or west Texas, sad ''gourmet'' dishes served by ''Continental'' restaurants with paste-on Spanish medieval decor, about napping on airport benches, mental and physical weariness, loneliness. Traveling makes for a scattered, dislocated life.

title: A STARTLING DROP IN UNEMPLOYMENT
description: A sharp drop in the unemployment rate, to 7 percent in June, was good news on the surface. But the four- tenths of a point drop from May worried some economists, who said an economy that is expanding so fast as to account for such a big drop is an economy headed for a fall. Nevertheless, the rate was at a four-year low, and, combined with the persistently low inflation rate, is sure to lift President Reagan's re-election hopes.

title: MY MOTHER'S MURDER:THE KILLER AND OTHERS RESPOND
description: Nicholas Gage recently received the Royal Society of Literature Award in London for ''Eleni,'' cited as the most original creative writing of 1983. He is a former New York Times correspondent.

title: COMPUTER SYSTEM SORTING INFORMATION FOR FARMERS
description: THE First Universalist Church at 16 Grove Street in Putnam looks much the same as it did in a picture taken 90 years ago. There are still the same stained- glass windows, the same white clapboard exterior and, of course, the steeple.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FARMERS and environmentalists continue to drift apart over a controversial bill that seeks to limit the use of pesticides in New Jersey and protect the state's farm workers. The rift was evident on a television program last weekend on which State Senator Raymond Lesniak, Democrat of Elizabeth and sponsor of the proposed measure, engaged in heated debate with farming interests.

title: Sounder Starring Paul Winfield, Cicely Tyson, Kevin Hooks; directed by Martin Ritt, 1972 Paramount Home Video 105 minutes. $59.95
description: Playing a family of sharecroppers in rural, Depression-era Louisiana, the principals give the warm, moving performances that made ''Sounder'' an early 1970's sentimental favorite.

title: CONSUMER RATES
HIGH-TECH PLUGGING INTO NEW ENGLAND
description: The closing last month of an old Schrafft Candy Company factory in Charlestown, a section of Boston, looked like another painful step in the decline of the industrial Northeast. But within two weeks a real estate developer announced plans to recycle the plant into a high-technology research and manufacturing center employing more people than the 800 who worked at the factory. That is typical of the remarkable redevelopment of New England through a decade's growth in high technology and service industries.

title: WILL BRITAIN'S ECONOMY STALL AS NORTH SEA OIL RUNS OUT?
description: Oil companies and the large corporate investors that finance offshore exploration are preparing for another round of the British version of petroleum poker, sifting through geological data and sounding out prospective partners for the ninth round of exploration since the North Sea adventure began in 1964. Bids are not due until Dec. 17, but the process is so complicated and risky that participants have little time left to plan their strategy.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: Too many years in nursing have inured me to such comments as ''interns learn to be good nurses,'' as in ''doing scutwork.''

title: KEYNES IS BACK, THANKS TO REAGAN
description: Outside of a handful of economists, hardly anyone took note back in 1972, when Richard M. Nixon told the American public, ''We are all Keynesians now.'' Some may have wondered what that meant. But most people who knew what the economist John Maynard Keynes had come to stand for - an expanded economic role for Government deficits to moderate recessions - probably agreed that his Depression-born view of economics had become part of the conventional wisdom.

title: LIBERTY PARK: NEW SHOWCASE FOR STATE ARTS
description: JERSEY CITY

title: SEEKING THE SOUL OF DERBYSHIRE
description: To be appealing, landscape should have a mixture of soulful subtlety that comes about through the thumbprints of human activity, and visual grandeur produced by the growing pains of an infant earth that had no one to control its geological tantrums. There is no possibility of exploring Derbyshire and being bored, for it has both of these qualities. Byron assured us that there are things in that county ''as noble as in Greece or Switzerland.'' Though poets exaggerate, much like everyone else, I would tend to endorse his opinion.

title: EAST VILLAGE HOTEL
description: Excavation recently began for a 140-room hotel in an area of Manhattan not known for hotel development - the east blockfront of Third Avenue between Ninth and 10th Streets, in the East Village. The hotel, being developed by Coronet Properties, will rise 16 stories on a site that had been a parking lot.

title: PORTRAIT OF MASSON
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 ACCUSED IN DEATH OF GRENADA PREMIER SEEK A COURT RULING
description: Attorneys for 20 people accused in the death of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, which was followed by the United States invasion of Grenada last October, have asked for a ruling on the validity of the court system.

title: ; D-DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCH WEIGHS FAMILY FILM SERIES
description: MOVIES these days are ''far too explicit for family consumption'' when it comes to sex and violence, Douglas L. Carver believes. So he, the father of two young children, has suggested a way that his Methodist church can attack the problem: ''Show films the church feels are more wholesome than we find in the community.''

title: FOR NEWCOMERS TO AUDIO, A FEW HINTS ON SHOPPING
description: My friend Kathy called the other day. She had walked into her neighborhood discount store to buy some sound gear I had recommended. Instead of giving her the equipment asked for, the salesman told Kathy that she had made a very poor choice. Badgering her with a barrage of numbers, the salesman tried to talk her into buying something entirely different. Kathy said she'd think about it and called me.

title: TAKING STEPS TO CONTAIN TERRORISM
description: Terrorism is having yet another periodic revival as a major political issue.

title: KEEPING OLYMPIC TORCH ON SCHEDULE
description: If the Olympic torch relay, now two- thirds of the way across the country, falls behind schedule, a computer in a small office in White Plains can suggest faster runners, shorter routes and flatter terrain to speed the flame along.

title: International
description: Britain and Nigeria agreed to allow each other's aircraft to return home, ending a two-day diplomatic standoff caused by the attempted abduction from London of a wealthy Nigerian politician in exile. The British authorities prevented the kidnapping. (Page 1, Column 5.) The U.S. would be ready to negotiate agreements with the Soviet Union on at least some aspects of space weaponry if a formula could be worked out for starting the talks in September, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. (3:3.)

title: ;  Artificial SurfTemple University will open its home football schedule Sept. 22 at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia with a game against Pitt and a concert by the
description: Beach Boys. ''I think this market's ready for it,'' said Mike Fetchko , an assistant to the Temple athletic director.

title: 'TIGER' 'ZOO STORY' SHAREDOUBLE BILL
description: uf912

title: CASINO RULING SETS UP A NEW BATTLE
description: New Jersey officials say that while last week's United States Supreme Court ruling permitting state regulation of casino unions was a ''major'' victory, it has temporarily left the state with no means of enforcing those rules.

title: ALL-STAR DEBATES PERSIST
description: More than 100 million votes have been cast since baseball's All-Star Game was ''returned to the fans'' 14 years ago. But as the National and American Leagues prepare for the 55th game in their rivalry Tuesday evening in San Francisco, nobody still seems to know who should get the votes: red-hot players or famous players.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Kubin a Bride

title: A LEADING ACTRESS IN BRITAIN
description: Dame Flora Robson, one of Britain's leading actresses who also won acclaim in the United States, died Saturday in a hospital in the English seaside resort of Brighton. She was 82 years old.

title: UNIONS FACE EXPULSION AT SOME COLLEGES
description: In May 1975, faculty members at Boston University, angered at what they viewed as the ''arbitrary'' and ''high-handed'' manner in which their institution was being run, joined what was then a growing trend in private colleges and universities and voted to form a union. Within three weeks, John R. Silber, president of the 28,000-student university, took legal steps to challenge the union's right to exist.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: There are a number of reasons why the residency-training system has not changed.

title: JOVIAL RADIO SHOW PLANS TO REDO ITS OLD THEATER
description: Here is the news from Lake Wobegon, the little town that time forgot but that is the delight of Saturday night radio: The infielders on the baseball team complained that they have not had enough to do during the team's recent streak of almost-no-hitters. And nobody can understand why thousands of people crowded into downtown St. Paul Friday night wearing red-and- white buttons that said, ''I Saved the World (Theater).''

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IS PINELANDS PLAN A SUCCESS? EVEN DISINTERESTED SYA IT IS
description: MORE than three years have passed since the adoption of a regional land-use plan for New Jersey's Pine Barrens, a million acres of forests, farms and scenic towns in the middle of the Washington-to-Boston megalopolis.

title: LILCO BALKS AT STATE ORDER TO SAVE ENERGY
description: THE New York Public Service Commission has taken the first steps toward requiring utilities to assure future supplies of electricity through conservation, instead of through the construction of expensive new plants.

title:
SPORTS;
TRIATHLONS FIND NICHE ON THE ISLAND
description: FOR many Long Island sports fans, the term triathlon conjures up an image of quasi- bionic participants spending agonizing hours swimming, biking and running across miles and miles of land and sea, with only a handful of survivors able to drag their tortured bodies across a finish line.

title: MUSIC: SOUNDS OF AFRICA
description: Mikata is one of the rhythm-and- dance bands that play regularly at Sounds of Brazil - a dozen percussionists, singers and dancers who occasionally switch to melody instruments. In its opening set Thursday, Mikata offered a kinetic sampling of African and neo-African rhythms and song styles, from Nigerian Afro-beat to Brazilian samba to something approaching disco and salsa.

title: DOG DAYS, WHEN THE AIR DOSEN'T WORK
description: SUMMERTIME, and the living is

title: State of Washington Begins Child-Identification Program
description: The nation's first statewide identification program to fight the problem of missing children has begun here.

title: WHY TV COVERAGE SHOULD BE GAVEL TO GAVEL
description: The television networks are preparing to show us the Democratic and Republican National Conventions, only not as they have in the past - gavel to gavel - but with excerpts and probably a good deal of analysis. The networks will show us what they judge to be newsworthy or entertaining, leaving out those parts that presumably are of no concern or interest. They have every right to do this, of course; a free press is as free not to report as it is to report. At the same time, the decision not to show us a convention in its entirety implies that a convention isn't really important. The networks have made the wrong decision; the political process is the loser.

title: A NEW SHINE ON MONEY MARKET FUNDS
description: WHEN the nation's banks and thrift institutions began offering high-yield money market deposit accounts in the fall of 1982, they drew billions of dollars out of the money market funds. But the funds hung on, and according to Steven Norwitz, vice president of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, ''the money market funds are coming back this year.'' The decline in their assets bottomed out about a year ago, and since 1984 began, Mr. Norwitz noted, money market fund assets have risen to $175 billion from $160 billion.

title: NEW MUSEUM FOR ALASKA
description: The misconceptions that surround Alaska are as vast as the Great Land itself. People think of it as a landscape of perpetual snow, of polar bears, Eskimos and igloos. Never mind that the 49th state - one-fifth the size of the rest of the country - includes temperate zones as well as frigid ones, several distinct groups of native peoples and no igloos at all, not if the word (which means ''house'' in the Inupiaq language) connotes a dwelling built of snow blocks. Truth is, Alaskan Eskimos traditionally built their homes of sod, driftwood or sticks and skins. To set the record straight and to present an overview of Alaska's people and natural resources is the primary purpose of the new University of Alaska Museum in Fairbanks.

title: NATO WORRY: SOVIET IN EAST MEDITERRANEAN
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is moving to review its defense arrangements in the eastern Mediterranean region, where some NATO officials and military analysts believe Warsaw Pact forces could pose a significant air and naval threat. Italy's Minister of Defense, Giovanni Spadolini, said recently that the region, which embraces the eastern Mediterranean, Italy, Greece and Turkey, is exposed to Soviet-bloc forces that could blockade sea routes throughout the area, including tanker routes, and neutralize NATO forces and bases.

title: Saving Farms May Be a Mistake
description: I am writing in reference to the article ''Two Measures to Save Farm Land'' (June 3).

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
STATE ECONOMY: AN OVERVIEW
description: CONNECTICUT is nearing the peak of its recovery from the most recent recession and will continue to make gains in employment and real income. But the unemployment rate should fall to 4.1 percent by the end of 1984, and this will create a shortage of experienced and skilled labor that will keep Connecticut companies from sharing in the national boom.

title: Weighty Issue at Belmont
description: Belmont Park stewards are continuing to compile statistics on the apprentice jockey Harry Vega, who apparently rode with an incorrect weight allowance for six days last week, which may cause at least 11 horses to be disqualified from purse money. The stewards discovered Friday that Vega had been riding with a seven-pound apprentice allowance, instead of the five-pound allowance he was actually entitled to, for at least six days.

title: MINIMALLY DISTRACTIVE MOBILE TELEPHONES
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Emma Lazarus, the poet whose sonnet ''The New Colossus'' is affixed inside the base of the Statue of Liberty, died in 1887 at 18 West 10th Street in Manhattan. Who was the owner of the house then and subsequently? Is it the same house at that address today? . . . M. U. S., Manhattan

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINON;
PASSAIC FLOODS: ADDITIONAL INPUT BY PUBLIC URGED
description: THE Passaic River has special meaning to the people of North Jersey. Many of us work or live near the river, and many of us also use it for recreation.

title: WOMAN STILL FIGHTING TO BE A SCOUTMASTER
description: CATHERINE POLLARD of Milford has custody of four grandsons, teaches music in the Bridgeport public schools, plays the bugle for a volunteer fire department, helps Boy Scouts prepare for merit badges, grows vegetables in her backyard and rides a motorcycle.

title: FINE CASTS IMPART STRENGTH TO THE FIRST 'RING' ON CD
description: The first complete Wagner opera to appear on compact disks turns out to be four operas - the entire ''Ring des Nibelungen,'' no less, on 18 imported Eurodisc CD's, available in major classical-music record stores.

title: COURT LEANS TO THE RIGHT ON CRIMINALS
description: THROUGHOUT its 1983-84 term, the Supreme Court had often come down firmly on the side of expanding police powers. Last week, in a decision quickly applauded by President Reagan and law enforcement officials, the Court said evidence seized with a search warrant that proves to be defective doesn't always have to be thrown out.

title: Cabanas Gives Cosmos 2-1 Victory in Seattle
description: The Cosmos used Roberto Cabanas's goal from 10 yards out to give them a 2-1 exhibition soccer victory over the F.C. Seattle team Friday night.

title: CZGOWCHWZ! SIMPLY CZGOWCHWZ!
description: KAYE WAYFARING IN ''AVENGED''

title: WRIGHT FIND RECALLS HIS INFLUENCE ON A COMMUNITY
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT did not believe in basements. He considered them unnatural, useful only for people who needed a place to store onions and potatoes or to hide from the Indians.

title: THE WORLD
description: Honduras SeeksA Better Deal

title: HELP FOR SUFFOLK DRUG ABUSERS
description: OLD eyes watch out of young faces. The youths in their jeans, seated on comfortable old sofas, resemble any gathering in a college dorm except for the eyes, which make them appear at least a decade older than the early 20's they all admit to.

title: Prisoner Who Killed Guard Is Transferred
description: The inmate convicted of killing a female prison guard has been transferred from ''death row'' at Green Haven state prison to the Great Meadow prison in this Washington County community, according to state officials.

title: FREEZE THAT BLARNEY
description: The Administration is plunging ahead with President Reagan's ''Star Wars,'' even as it prepares for possible talks with the Russians on space weapons in September. But the rhetoric is changing.

title: Former Top Boxer Is Held in Shooting
description: Frank (The Animal) Fletcher, a junior middleweight once ranked No. 2 by the World Boxing Association, was charged today with shooting a Philadelphia man, the police said.

title:
DINING OUT;
UNUSUAL DISHES ON STATEN ISLAND
description: FRANK PULEO, a young chef from Staten Island who says he is a Florentine at heart, opened a restaurant on the island two and a half years ago. It is called Framboise, and Mr. Puleo, who frequently studies in Tuscany with Giuliano Bugialli, the well-known cooking teacher, comes up with new ideas for dishes never before dreamed of in the Greater West Brighton area.

title: THE RESIDENT's ORDEAL
description: Doctors and hospital administrators seem to think that keeping up some poor soul for 36 hours, making decisions, helps make better doctors. Would these same doctors ride in an airplane where the pilot hadn't slept for 24 or 36 hours?

title:
STAMPS;
WETLANDS CONSERVATION
description: A new commemorative from the United States marks the 50th anniversary of the ''duck stamp'' program. It rescued American waterfowl from extinction by preserving their habitats and establishing refuges. The new issue reproduces the first stamp.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: No Headline
description: Lack of a Visa Blocks D'Amato's Soviet Trip

title: Wrong Corner
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE sun has been streaming in the window this morning. Some sort of bird was whistling out in the patio. I couldn't make out the tune or the brand of the little fellow, but he and the sun conspired to get me out of bed and so to work. I don't mind getting up in the morning, most mornings, anyhow, and I am reasonably cheerful, perhaps because I am not an early riser.

title: No Headline
description: Repairs Curtail Service OnD,E,FandMLines

title: D-DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: MINIMALLY DISTRACTIVE MOBILE TELEPHONES
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadians Get Bid
description: True North, the Canadian syndicate seeking the America's Cup, has had its bid accepted for the 1987 competition by the Royal Perth Yacht Club of Australia. Donald M. Green of Hamilton is chairman and chief executive officer of the syndicate, with Steve Killing of Midland, Ontario, as designer.

title: CARIBBEAN GROUP EASES FEUDS AT TALKS
description: The leaders of the English-speaking countries of the Caribbean, who ended four days of talks here today, appear to have eased their feuding over political and economic matters.

title: Hangman Dies in Pakistan
description: Tara Masih, the official executioner who hanged ousted Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in 1979 and an estimated 5,000 other people over 25 years, died Friday of heart disease in Pakistan's northern city of Lahore, jail officials said today.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Depression Dregs
description: Every time a bank failed in the United States in the Great Depression of the 1930's, the Comptroller of the Currency took over the assets for safekeeping. A half century later, the Federal office found itself still storing the contents of thousands of safe-deposit boxes and other property unclaimed by 22,000 bank customers.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: SO STRONG was the New Jersey presence at the recent convention of the American Booksellers Association in Washington that at one news conference the following proposal came forth:

title: Singapore Aide Is Convicted Of Distributing Official Data
description: A top Singapore Foreign Ministry official was convicted today of passing minutes of Washington economic meetings to a local businessman.

title: Data Bank; July 8, 1984
HARLEM MARKS 20TH YEAR OF PREP-SCHOOL PROGRAM
description: In the beginning, the naysayers said it could not be done. Edouard E. Plummer and a handful of teachers at Wadleigh Junior High School in central Harlem could not, they said, take children from the neighborhood and get them into the nation's most prestigious preparatory schools and then on to Ivy League colleges.

title: Daphne Bradley LeFeaver Married To Christopher Russell Ball, Lawyer
description: Daphne Bradley LeFeaver, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. LeFeaver Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Christopher Russell Ball, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Ball of Palo Alto, Calif. The Rev. Francis H. Wade performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Torvill & Dean: Path to Perfection Thorn EMI Video/Thames Video 52 minutes. $29.95
description: A winner all the way, this documentary centers around the 1984 Olympic ice-dancing champions from Britain, Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean. These two extraordinary performers are interviewed revealingly off the ice by a British newscaster, Simon Reed, and are seen in their dazzling routines of the past six years.

title: FOR 110, A HOME
description: Michael J. Lazar, a real-estate investor and former City Taxi Commissioner, plans to build a 110-unit residential condominium project in an area of Brooklyn that has not seen new private development in decades. On a parcel he owns at 111 Prospect Park Southwest, he said, he will build a 12-story condominium with mostly one- and two-bedroom apartments, which are expected to sell in the range of $75,000 to $110,000. Mr. Lazar expects to receive an Urban Development Action Grant of $15,000 a unit through the New York City Housing Partnership, which would make the project economically feasible. He hopes to break ground in the fall.

title: FOUR DEMOCRATS FOCUS ON DRIVE FOR OTTINGER SEAT
description: FOR three months earlier this year, six Democrats campaigned vigorously in the 20th Congressional District to gain their party's designation as the candidate in November to replace Representative Richard L. Ottinger, who is giving up his seat.

title: THE WORLD
description: British CustomOfficials Open aPandora's Crate

title: ;  N.B.A. Stars Out
description: A disappearing act by Magic Johnson and other National Basketball Association stars has disappointed University of Iowa officials who were expecting them for a game today against the United States Olympic team. Johnson, Ralph Sampson, Isiah Thomas and Fred Brown were not, as advertised, going to appear at the sold-out game.

title: PRECINCT TRIES FIXED SHIFTS TO CUT STRESS
description: When Police Officer James Gonzalez volunteered for the 115th Precinct in Queens, he was feeling the strain.

title: MEMORIES ARE MADE OF THIS
description: WHEN Tapestries opened in Greenwich in late 1982, its many attractive attributes gave promise of better things to come.

title: IRAN PROFITS IN SHIP INSURANCE
description: A director of Iran's state-owned Bimeh Insurance Company asserted today that his country was making a profit on war insurance for ships prepared to risk Iraqi air attacks in the Persian Gulf, and was looking into ways of attracting more insurance business.

title: UCONN HOLDS WORK OF POET
description: CHARLES OLSON, to the University of Connecticut scholar cataloging and managing his legacy, was America's last great poet.

title: POP CONCERT: ROAD SHOW OPENS IN KANSAS CITY
description: The first show of the Jacksons' Victory Tour, a summer road show that is being touted as the most spectacular and potentially the most profitable tour in pop music history, got under way Friday soon after dark at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Mo. And the show's opening minutes certainly were spectacular.

title: Bomb Detonated Near Abortion Facility
description: A bomb exploded outside a building housing a Planned Parenthood office today.

title: WATERFRONT'S MAIN ASSET NOW IS THE VIEW
description: Thirty years ago, the Rev. John M. Corridan quoted from Scripture to memorialize the countless lives and careers that had been sacrificed to purge New York's waterfront of labor corruption. '' 'It is one man that soweth and another that reapeth,' '' said the priest, who was immortalized in ''On the Waterfront.'' ''That's always true. A good many people have to sow seeds in their lives and be content if they never see the harvest.''

title: TEXAS PRISON REFORMER SEES INCOMPETENCE BEHIND WALLS
description: Ray Keller is a conservative Republican who represents the town of Duncanville, near Dallas, in the Texas Legislature - hardly the kind you might expect to be campaigning for prison reform. Yet when Mr. Keller, as chairman of the House Law Enforcement Committee, began to see reports of mismanagement and waste by the Texas prison system, he became enraged. And then when he toured prisons and saw what he calls the ''incredible conditions'' under which inmates were confined, he became something of a crusader.

title: SITUATION COMEDY PURSUES A NEW AUDIENCE
description: The situation comedy, long a staple of broadcast television until a recent decline, may be headed for a new life on pay cable. The emergence of the ''sit-com'' on cable represents the latest stage of pay TV's evolution from an all-movie service.

title: No Headline
description: Twenty years ago, the Off Off Broadway movement was beginning to come into its own; and such young writers as Lanford Wilson, Sam Shepard, John Guare, Megan Terry, Paul Foster, Maria Irene Fornes and Jean-Claude van Itallie all shared an exciting new world - a world in which improvisation was as much a way of life as it was a theatrical technique. Although some of these writers would later emerge as America's preeminent playwrights, they worked, in those days, as hotel clerks and waiters and short-order cooks to support their aspirations. They were young then and passionate about the theater, and they not only saw everything their friends did at the Caffe Cino and La Mama, but also shared with one another all their discoveries and plans.

title: No Headline
description: Tigers 5, Rangers 2

title: FROM FRENCH TO AMERICAN RUSTIC
description: THIS season, Carol's in Southampton has made a 180-degree turn and, instead of serving an elaborate selection of luxurious French dishes, has become Carol's Great Hampton Chicken and Rib Co. Gone are the terrines and galantines, the mignonettes and mousses. The new, elementally rustic menu consists of chicken and ribs, to eat in or take out.

title: IS BAUSCH'S VISION TRUE TO LIFE?
description: The Germans really are a strange lot,'' Goethe said in 1827. ''They make life unnecessarily difficult for themselves by looking for deep thoughts and ideas everywhere and putting them into everything. Just have the courage to give yourself up to first impressions . . . Don't think all the time that everything must be pointless if it lacks an abstract thought or idea.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
HIS NAGGING DID REAGAN A GOOD TURN
description: MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN this week returns to Harvard after his scheduled two years of duty as economic adviser to President Reagan. His stock with the academic community, already high when he surprised economists by taking the post of chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has been bolstered by the experience.

title: THE WORLD
description: SubcontinentalUps and Downs

title: Hart and Mrs. Ferraro Rated Equally by A.D.A.
description: Americans for Democratic Action ranked Senator Gary Hart and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro ''equally acceptable'' today but said other prospective Democratic Vice-Presidential candidates rated higher on a liberal scale.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHY JUST TWO STORIES HIGH?
description: FOR more than a decade, public housing has been the subject of great controversy in Nassau County. Even housing for the elderly, an exception that enjoys widespread public support elsewhere, has been accepted slowly and with begrudging reservations.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: Residency programs almost universally give excellent technical training but with little regard to the cost of diagnostic procedures or therapeutic regimens. Because of this, we, as physicians, never learn to take into consideration the financial constraints of a patient, family or society in our attempts to cure disease. Is it any wonder that, last year, health expenditures in the United States averaged $1,500 for every man, woman and child and that unpaid medical bills were the No. 1 cause of personal bankruptcy? JEFFREY BROWN, M.D. Denver

title: DETERRENCE WITHOUT THE BOMB
description: THE ABOLITION

title: ;  Coach Tries TV
description: He didn't like all the traveling because he said ''90 percent of the job is recruiting,'' so Doug Collins resigned as assistant basketball coach at Arizona State to work as a television commentator for CBS. The 32-year- old former Philadelphia 76ers star, whose eight-year N.B.A. career was cut short by injuries, said the television job ''will open a lot of doors.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Reality and Producer Prices

title: COONEY'S NEXT 3 MINUTES - MAYBE
description: When last seen in the 13th round that night in Las Vegas, Nev., more than two years ago, Gerry Cooney, his gloves at his side, was stumbling backward as Larry Holmes measured him for another punch. While the referee Mills Lane peered into Gerry Cooney's eyes, suddenly a fourth man was in the ring. Victor Valle threw his arms round Gerry Cooney, protecting him from the undefeated heavyweight champion the way a father would protect his son.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FAIR SEASON STARTS

title: A GARDEN CENTER WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: IT is tough to get a doctor to

title: An Initiation Fee?
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Winner To the Sports Editor:
description: After enduring the Dark Ages of M. Donald Grant, Joe MacDonald and Lorinda DeRoulet, I feel an inner glow whenever I read of the Mets' position atop the National League East. Whenever the opportunity arises, I loudly remind all Yankee fans within earshot that my team, not theirs, is No. 1 in New York..

title: POPE CONDEMNS SOUTH AFRICAN RACIAL POLICIES
description: Pope John Paul II today condemned the forced displacement of black Africans from their homes in South Africa and demanded the speedy establishment of South-West Africa as an independent nation.

title: MISS PETERSON IN FRONT BY 3
description: Lauri Peterson came inches of an ace worth $5,000, shot a women's course record of seven-under-par 65 and assumed a three-stroke lead over Nancy Lopez today in the third round of the Jamie Farr Toledo Classic golf tournament.

title: Susan Eubank Bride In Darien Ceremony
description: Susan Eubank, the daughter of Kenneth Eubank of Dallas and the late Winifred June Eubank, was married yesterday to Thomas Putze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Putze of Ligonier, Pa. The Rev. Kevin Bean performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn.

title: ARMY SET TO OPEN 3 BEIRUT CROSSINGS
description: The Lebanese Army, which took over control of Beirut this week from militia forces, announced today that three more crossing points between the predominantly Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital would be opened to civilian traffic Sunday.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDALISTS' WORKSHOP
description: A month-long series of special events centered around medallic art will begin next week at the Pennsylvania State University. On July 16, a three-week International Medallic Art Workshop will open. On the same day, the university will unveil a major new exhibition, ''The Resurgent Art Medal: An International Selection.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Ansel Adams, who died in April at the age of 82, got to be the most popular photographer of our time largely because of his voluptuous, dramatic landscapes of Yosemite and other wilderness preserves. Ask any man or woman on the street to name an Adams photograph, and the answer you'll most likely get will be ''Clearing Winter Storm,'' ''Mt.

title: U.S. AND HONDURAS ARE STILL PLAYING GAME ON NICARAGUA REBELS
description: In full view of the Honduran Foreign Minister's office here is a white stucco house. It serves as the headquarters for the leaders of a group of United States- backed insurgents who are trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: NEIGHBORS OPPOSE SCHOOL'S EXPANSION
description: THE tranquil setting of the North Shore Hebrew Academy's Cherry Lane School in a valley amid forest, marshland and stately homes in Kings Point belies the long-running conflict over the school and its plan for expansion, which has embroiled the affluent North Shore community over the last five years.

title: THEATER: 'LAUGHTER'
description: ''Even in Laughter,'' a new drama by Lee and Marilyn Nestor at the Intar Theater, on West 42d Street, has a fundamental and fatal premise: that writers are especially interesting people in person. That's about the only laugh in this play, which is the stage equivalent of a vanity-press book.

title: Mary Anne Reiser and Walter J. O'Donnell Marry
description: Mary Anne Reiser and Walter Joseph O'Donnell, graduates of Holy Cross College, were married in the St. Joseph Memorial Chapel on the college campus in Worcester, Mass., yesterday. The Rev. William J. O'Malley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: JANE SCHMEISER TO MARRY AUG. 25
description: Jane Marian Schmeiser and Andrew Charles Power plan to be married Aug. 25.

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: Haven't we heard enough about how hard it is to be a medical student? It is hard to be many things in this life. At least medical students choose their hardship and are amply rewarded for it, both socially and financially, before very long. Why doesn't somebody write about how hard it is to be a patient, not only feeling miserable but being physically handled and regarded as a learning aid by self-important young men? LYNNE SHARON SCHWARTZ New York City

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN East Hampton, or ''Bonac,'' vernacular,

title: Photo of Prudence Goodman; Prudence Goodman Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Goodman Jr. of New York, Salisbury, Conn., and Kennebunk, Me., of the engagement of their daughter Prudence Anne Goodman to Peter Ernst Simson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Simson of New York and Amagansett, L.I. An early fall wedding is planned.

description: Death PenaltyIs Struck DownIn New York

title: DID MUSIC HIT ITS PEAK WITH MOZART?
description: This week, for the 18th summer in a row, the Mostly Mozart Festival is starting up in New York. The man died in 1791, and we're still listening to him. Why? He probably never imagined such a thing; certainly he wasn't much concerned with composers who died in 1491.
