title: Raas of the Netherlands Wins Tour's Ninth Leg
description: Jan Raas of the Netherlands took the ninth leg of the Tour de France bicycle classic today.

title: ;  Cover ChangeWhen the University of Illinois' star safety,
description: Craig Swoope, was indicted on Federal cocaine charges, he apparently lost his place on the cover of the school's 1984 media guide.

title: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE SOCIAL TRANSFORMATION OF AMERICAN MEDICINE, by Paul Starr. (Basic Books, $11.95.) This book by a sociologist at Harvard describes the evolution of America's health care system and how doctors took control of every aspect of health care. Published in 1982, it was called ''a monumental achievement'' by our reviewer, H. Jack Geiger, a physician, who added, ''For all its scholarship, it is intensely readable and graced with style.'' ''The Social Transformation of American Medicine'' won the 1984 Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction, the 1983 C. Wright Mills Award in sociology and the 1984 Bancroft Prize in American history. THE MADNESS OF A SEDUCED WOMAN, by Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. (Bantam, $3.95.) The heroine of Susan Fromberg Schaeffer's fourth novel, ''The Madness of a Seduced Woman,'' is a beautiful woman whose passion and self-revulsion lead her to murder her rival for a man's love. Rosellen Brown wrote in The Book Review that the 578-page story is ''an enormous, engrossing feast for those who hunger for the fiction of extreme emotion'' and ''an absorbing, wonderfully inventive psychological tale of a woman imagined as we would never dare, or want, to be.''

title: A VICTIM OF BULGARIA
description: THE TRUTH THAT KILLED

title: NIGERIA STANDOFF WITH BRITAIN ENDS
description: Britain and Nigeria ended a two-day diplomatic standoff today that had grown out of the bungled abduction of a wealthy Nigerian exile politician. ending

title: THE VOICE OF ENGLAND'S PAST
description: ''Kid'' or ''Squire'' is what Mr. Gaunt the butcher calls you when you buy his sliced ox tongue, a squashed-pea paste called mushy, or shoulder pork baked in a pastry case. ''Kid'' is informal, implying perhaps that meat can keep you young. ''Squire'' is for when he is feeling a bit subserviently medieval, though in a mutinous way. He will even say ''sir'' or ''madam'' with a rich man's leer under his Ronald Colman mustache, but his most outrageous mode of address is ''darling,'' popped at either sex with a mixture of sang- froid and prankish insolence befitting a stand-up comic.

title: A FLIGHT OF FRENCH PROVINCIAL FANTASY
description: This was once a perfectly plain cottage nestled into a hill on a wooded Connecticut site. ''Hardly a distinguished piece of architecture,'' recalls its owner, Howard Kaplan. Yet the surrounding landscape was unspoiled and a 500-foot driveway made the property a secluded little enclave. ''I spent years looking for an old country house, but repeatedly came up against two problems,'' says Mr. Kaplan. ''Most of them are set right on public roads and the rooms are too small, not the proper scale for my collection of French country furniture.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the most serious accident I can recall in 30 years here. It's pretty gruesome.'' - Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont. (1:6.)

title: HERE'S ONE 'RIGOLETTO' THAT WALKS A VERY FINE LINE
description: I went to the opera the other evening and heard people

title: THEATER IN REVIEW ; A ROUSING 'ONE MO' TIME'
description: IN a startling comeback, following last summer when it was

title: CHINA PURGING RADICALS AND BUNGLERS
description: China's Communist Party has embarked on a new phase in a drive to clean up its ranks by re-educating or expelling members who are radical, corrupt or incompetent.

title: Coping With All That Good News
description: The economic news is remarkably good: Unemployment has fallen to 7 percent, the lowest rate in four years, while inflation holds steady at a modest 4.6 percent. Naturally, President Reagan hastens to take credit. His Administration, he says, ''is the first in two decades that has reduced unemployment and inflation at the same time.''

title: August Wedding Is Set By Diane G. Masumian
description: Mr. and Mrs. George J. Masumian of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane G. Masumian, to Bruce E. Wiacek, a son of Mr. and Adolf E. Wiacek of the Bronx. The wedding is to take place next month.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS July 8, 1984Fiction1
description: THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Warner, $4.95.) Murder in an Italian monastery. 2 HOLLYWOOD WIVES, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $3.95.) The struggle for money and power in Tinseltown. 3

title: Jennifer Thorpe Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Jennifer L. Thorpe of Old Saybrook, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Lisa Ellen Thorpe, to Elliott Scott Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Brown of Little Falls, N.J. Miss Thorpe, daughter also of Robert L. Thorpe of Farmington, Conn., and her fiance graduated from St. Lawrence University. The wedding is planned for next month.

title:
GARDENING ;
INSECTS AND THE DAMAGE THEY CAN DO
description: TWO of the most despised insect pests approached the low point of their population cycle this spring. While an occasional spring cankerworm dangled by a silken thread to grasp the clothing of a passerby, little damage was done by these leaf-devouring insect larvae to the foliage of the trees. The dreaded gypsy moth had just begun to show up when the heavy rains arrived. When the weather cleared, few were apparent.

title: CHOOSING THE RIGHT GLUE OR ADHESIVE FOR A SPECIAL REPAIR JOB
description: -stocked hardware store or home center to look for an adhesive is bound to be confused by the tremendous assortment of products on display - many claiming to be ''all-purpose'' glues or adhesives that will bond almost anything to anything (the terms ''glue'' and ''adhesive'' are used almost interchangeably nowadays).

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Ehinger
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Weisz Ehinger to Thomas Wells White has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Ehinger of Summit, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Norman E. White of Sea Island, Ga., and Ann Wells White of Atlanta.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Television has not distinguished itself by either the intensity or the intelligence of its own self-criticism, although occasionally it makes exceptions. Some of the most notable have taken place on ''Viewpoint,'' a splendid ABC program that is now seen five times a year.

title: CUBAN EXILES JOIN ON FILM TO INDICT CASTRO'S REVOLUTION
description: Annette Insdorf, an Associate Professor at Yale and Columbia, is the author of ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: THE SWEET SMELL OF SUMMER HAY
description: THE hand sickles, scythes and pitchforks are all gone, but the smell of freshly mowed hay fills the midsummer nights. The first cut still comes in early summer. If the weather is good, there could be second-cut hay in August, but the first cut is always the best.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Bridgeport's Zoo Is Getting Better When you have shared the excitement and experienced the satisfaction of being part of the recent changes that have taken place at Beardsley Zoological Gardens in Bridgeport, you can't help but be angered by the article ''State's Only Zoo Looks to Better Days'' (June 3). Why? Simply because the ''better days'' have already begun.

title: SPONTANEOUS OBSESSIONS, IMPOSED RESTRAINT
description: A VERY PRIVATE EYE

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHY SHOULD WOMEN NEED A MAN'S PERMISSION TO SUCCEED?
description: AS a working woman and wife, I've had my share of tactless remarks about the importance of my career versus my husband's career. Perhaps I've had more than my share, for I am a freelance writer and many people assume that a wife who writes is just playing at a hobby, indulged by her tolerant husband. Both men and women want to know my husband's opinion of my work, but no one ever asks me what I think of my husband's job or if I approve of what he does.

title: AT MIDSEASON, A SHIFT IN FORTUNES
description: Baseball has reached midseason, and whatever happened to Tom Seaver? Tom who? Showing brashly the difference a few months can make, the Mets have made everyone forget about the Seaver snafu by rushing unexpectedly toward the top of the National League East behind a corps of youthful pitchers.

title: Don't Take My Wave Away To the Sports Editor:
description: Now that Met fans have something to cheer about, namely a winning team, don't take their ''wave'' away. The Mets deserve the enthusiasm it brings to their fans.

description: John House is an assistant editor of Vanity Fair. THE AMERICAN BLUES

title: No Headline
description: Government to Offer Computerized Job Aid

title: THE SORCERY OF WAR
description: In ''The Sorcery of War'' (About Men, June 3), Nelson Bryant wonders why ''the few months of actual combat in Normandy . . . mean more to me than the ensuing years of college and work, happiness, sorrow and love, marriage and children.'' Surely, he exaggerates.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CHARMING BOOKS WITH PRACTICALITY
description: The first of the Audubon Society's field guides to natural

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Auto-Parts Sale To Benefit Disabled Five years ago, when an all-volunteer effort established a center for post-stroke camaraderie on a year- round basis, St. Matthew's Lutheran Church in White Plains offered its premises as a wheelchair-accessible site. Subsequent anniversaries have been marked by one-day fund-raising sales of donated merchandise, but this year part of the ''Fifth Anniversary Sale-A-Bration'' has been extended through July. For the rest of this month, auto parts can be purchased at below the wholesale dealer price through stores in Mount Kisco, Hawthorne and North White Plains, with a clipping of this article.

title: SHULTZ, HELP EAST TIMOR
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz visits Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, this week, he must not ignore the plight of East Timor, where the Indonesian military has waged a war of extreme brutality, with little respite, for nearly nine years. While this conflict may seem remote from American concerns, the unfortunate facts show that the United States, through military aid and diplomatic support for Indonesia, is deeply involved in the tragedy of East Timor, my native land. In his meetings with the Indonesian leadership, Mr. Shultz has an obligation to address the situation.

title: MUSIC: DIRT BAND HOEDOWNS
description: The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, which has survived for 17 years, was an early prototype of the harmonized country-rock that was subsequently popularized by groups ranging from the Eagles to the current kings of country harmony, Alabama. The group, which has recorded urban folk and rock by the likes of Steve Goodman, Bruce Springsteen and Marshall Crenshaw, has always eschewed the musical formulas of Nashville. Thursday, at the Lone Star Cafe, it offered a program that touched half a dozen different stylistic bases.

title: No Headline
description: White Sox 4, Indians 2

title: Jennifer Anne Freund Wed To M. W. Pardee, Teacher
description: Jennifer Anne Freund, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron E. Freund of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Ward Pardee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Ward Pardee 3d of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Josselyn M. Shore, grandparents of the bride, in Kings Point, L.I.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: New Wave forKidney Stones

title: THE RESIDENT'S ORDEAL
description: In ''The Ordeal: Life as a Medical Resident'' (June 3), Michael Harwood has succeeded in describing the emotions, exhaustion, fears, challenges and rewards through which house officers evolve during their medical training.

title: EVER SEE A XOLOITZCUINTLE? RARE DOGS AT JAMESBURG
description: JAMESBURG PERUVIAN Inca Orchids, Chinese Cresteds and Xoloitzcuintles will be on view Saturday and Sunday at the horse show grounds in Thompson Park here.

title: NEWEST YANKEE LEADS ROMP
description: It was a night of self-congratulations for the Yankees, and understandably so. All night long, between the innings, in the dugout, on the field, the players shook hands with one another. They came out hitting and kept it up all game.

title: HIS BRAINCHILDREN: LITERARY SIBLINGS
description: '' MY life is divided into two parts,'' said Norman Kiell of Long Beach. ''In terms of my professional work, while at Brooklyn College I dealt with therapy with young adults and the obese. I continue my work with the obese, but on the adult level. The other half of my life - the extracurricular activity, as it were - is concerned with the relationship between psychoanalysis and literature.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: CELEBRATING July 4 as this country's Independence Day sparks fireworks from a history buff from Englewood, Robert A. Clogher. He says the holiday should be two days earlier.

title: Topics Old Bears and New
description: The Oldest Bolshevik

title: LETTERS
description: KILLER BICYCLES

title: MANILA TROOPS OPEN BIG DRIVE ON REBELS IN NORTH
description: A military official said today that the Philippine Army had begun a major offensive against leftist guerrillas in the mountains of the northern Philippines.

title: TO THE POLES, CONSPIRACY IS NO THEORY
description: Just as a Frenchman might say with pride that he was in the resistance in World War II or a Norwegian might recall his days in the underground, a Pole will simply say, ''I was in the conspiracy.'' In few nations is there such a deep-rooted respect for clandestine political activity and few governments are as troubled by it as that of General Wojiech Jaruzelski.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LOS ANGELES
description: After years of preparations, the Olympic flame is scheduled to be lighted atop the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum on July 28, signaling the start of 16 days of competition by athletes from around the world.

title: NOTES ON THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: As tenpins tumbled and clattered, Walter F. Mondale emerged from a press conference in the bar of the Whitestone Lanes in Queens one evening during the New York primary to bowl a frame for the cameras. While he threaded his way to a lane, the crowd sent up a loud cheer. It wasn't inspired by Mondale, but by the words that came dryly over the public address system: ''The lounge has now re-opened.''

title: Stars-Stallions Not Expected to Draw
description: The United States Football League's two strongest teams, the Birmingham Stallions and the Philadelphia Stars, will play today, beginning at 2:30 P.M., for the Eastern Conference championship at Franklin Field in Philadelphia. But not many people seem to care.

title: Cynthia F. Robins Weds in Bedford
description: Cynthia Ford Robins, a computer support manager for Wang Laboratories in Stamford, Conn., and Bartlett Hoyle McGuire, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert G. Hetherington performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: LUXURY LIVING ON THE HUDSON WATERFRONT
description: BUILDERS have taken to calling them ''dockominiums,'' and over the last two years, these waterfront condominiums have become some of the hottest new projects along the New Jersey shore.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Dean Steinkuhler , an all-America tackle from Nebraska who won the Outland and the Lombardi trophies last season and the second player chosen in the National Football League draft, signed with the Houston Oilers yesterday. . . . Glen Sudhop, a 7-foot-2-inch center from North Carolina State who played in the Continental Basketball Association last season, was cut by the Phoenix Suns. . . . Teo Fabi of Italy has been released from his Indianapolis-car ride with the Forsythe Racing Team so he can concentrate on his Formula One ride with Brabham on the Grand Prix circuit. . . . According to documents filed in San Mateo County (Calif.) Superior Court over his divorce settlement, Joe Montana , the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback, owes $40,000 in back Federal income taxes. . . . Dave Stalls, who played for the Los Angeles Raiders in the last National Football League Super Bowl and then played for the Denver Gold of the United States Football League, has announced his retirement. The 28- year-old defensive lineman plans to enter veterinary school at Colorado State next month.

title: FUN (2 WORDS)
description: Stuart Berg Flexner, editor in chief of The Random House Dictionaries, is the author of ''I Hear America Talking'' and co-author of The Random House Thesaurus, which will be published in August. ACROSS AND DOWN

description: SPREAD gracefully over 10 square

title: 25 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 25 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: WOMEN, DEMOCRATS UNDERCUT
description: The campaign of some feminist leaders pressing Walter F. Mondale to select a female running mate promises to undermine, rather than enhance, the future clout of the women's movement within the Democratic Party, even as it hurts the party's chances of defeating President Reagan in November.

title: A DEMOCRAT WHO SPEAKS OUT, OFTEN
description: JANE PERLEZ

title: Coghlan Out Of Olympics
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, the world champion in the 5,000 meters, said today that he would not compete in the Los Angeles Olympics because he has not recovered from a stress fracture of the right leg.

title: 'TORNADIC WIND SHEAR' CITED IN OVERTURNING OF RIVERBOAT
description: A ''tornadic wind shear'' was blamed today for capsizing a three-deck riverboat on the Tennessee River, killing 11 people, including four children.

title: No Headline
description: Dividend Meetings

title: ISRAELI POLITICIANS COURT LONG-IGNORED ARAB VOTERS
description: -ZARQA, Israel, July 4 - Shimon Peres scans the eyes of the Arab voters in this tiny village, a grave look comes over his face and he asks the crowd in his somber baritone: ''Is there anyone here who wants the Likud?''

title: Goals Are Set For Caribbean
description: Leaders of the 13-nation Caribbean community agreed to try to revive regional trade and pursue structural adjustments of their economies. A communique issued at the end of their fifth summit conference on Saturday said the Caribbean heads of state had ''determined to undertake an immediate and urgent program aimed at visibly restoring and increasing intraregional trade.''

title: PHILLIES' KOOSMAN SHUTS OUT BRAVES
description: Jerry Koosman, backed by Von Hayes's three-run homer, pitched a four-hit shutout as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Atlanta Braves, 7-0, today.

title: Inquiry Reported On Jersey Boxing
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agents have conducted a sting operation in an investigation of suspected corruption in New Jersey boxing, The Newark Star-Ledger reported today.

title: GOTHIC CATHEDRAL IS KNOWN FOR STAINED-GLASS WINDOWS
description: York Minster, the largest Gothic cathedral in Britain, dominates the city of York. It was started in Norman times by the archbishop, Thomas of Bayeux, and was not completed until the 15th century.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Name-Calling

title: Pope Offers Cheer To Czech Catholics
description: Pope John Paul II offered words of encouragement today to Roman Catholics in Czechoslovakia after talks last week on improving strained church-state relations in that Communist nation.

title: NUCLEAR PROLIFERATION AND WASTE: ONE SCIENTIST'S 'CLEVER' SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Sikhs Reported to Call For Punjab Agitation
description: NEW DELHI, July 8 (Reuters) The Press Trust of India reported today that the Sikh Akali Dal party has decided on a new round of agitation in Punjab next week by sending unarmed squads to try to force Indian Army troops to leave the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

title: SEAFARERS' TRAINING SCHOOL RUNS AT QUARTER-SPEED
description: The campus is 90 waterfront acres, shaded by pines and patrolled by peacocks. It houses a new $26 million resort hotel and workshops full of technological amenities that would evoke envy at many universities. The fleet of training vessels moored in the Potomac River includes President Kennedy's favorite yacht.

title: U.S. Official to Go to Turkey For a Look at Human Rights
description: The United States Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, Elliot Abrams, is scheduled to make a five- day visit to Turkey starting Tuesday. He is to assess human rights conditions in this country, which is frequently accused of human rights abuses.

title: Baltazar Takes Close Decision
description: Tony Baltazar won a unanimous 10- round decision today over Roger Mayweather, the former World Boxing Association junior lightweight champion.

title: Report Says Angola Troops Killed 72 Rebels in Late June
description: Angolan Government soldiers killed 72 guerrillas fighting for the pro-Western Union for the Total Independence of Angola during the second half of June, the Portuguese state radio reported today.

title: ;  Visicorp Marketer Joins Interactive Systems
description: Interactive Systems Corporation, a leading supplier of Unix-based software for computers, has named Ronald D. Fisher president and chief operating officer.

title: Canada Elections Seen After a Visit to Queen
description: Prime Minister John Turner flew home today from London, where his consultations with Queen Elizabeth II reportedly cleared the way for national elections in Canada this summer.

title: THE REGION ; ;  CleanupContinues After Trash Strike
description: Sanitation workers worked yesterday to dispose of garbage that had languished in transfer stations and on streets in northern and central New Jersey during their weeklong strike that ended Saturday.

title: OIL DOWNTURN ENDS BOOM IN TRINIDAD
description: This country's oil industry, which in the past decade brought prosperity, economic expansion and high expectations, is experiencing a downturn. The decline has spurred increasing talk of belt-tightening, but, to Trinidadians, it is all a matter of degree.

title: Mondale Continues Convention Preparations
description: Walter F. Mondale continued his preparations for the Democratic National Convention by meeting today with Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: OPENING OF NEW BEIRUT CROSSINGS IS THWARTED BY KIN OF THE MISSING
description: Moslems determined to learn the fate of missing relatives thwarted Government plans today to open more crossing points between the predominantly Moslem and Christian sectors of this city.

title: Austria Tightens Guard At Pakistani Embassy
description: The Austrian authorities tightened security at the Pakistani Embassy today, two days after seizing a nine-man gang who they said they believed had planned to kidnap a diplomat.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Pope & Talbot Aide Named Realty Chief
description: Pope & Talbot Inc., the Portland, Ore., producer of wood products, tissue paper and pulp, named a leader during the weekend for its newly separated real estate subsidiary.

title: 2-YEAR-OLD WINS FIRST IN A STAKES AT BELMONT
description: Beat Me Daddy, who had finished third in his only previous start, scored a 4 3/4-length victory in the $66,900 Tremont Stakes for 2-year-olds yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: ISRAEL, JORDAN AND MOSQUITOES
description: Mosquitoes in neighboring port cities in the Gulf of Aqaba have brought Israel and Jordan into direct contact despite the state of war that has existed between them since 1948, an Israeli newspaper and a Government official said today.

title: DISMAL SECOND QUARTER FOR BROKERS
description: With major Wall Street firms poised to report dismal second-quarter earnings, analysts are looking to the last six months of 1984 for a boost in securities industry profits.

title: USA Today's New Edition
description: USA Today will begin selling an international edition in parts of Europe and the Middle East on Tuesday, the newspaper announced today.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.69

title: BY JAMIE UYS, 'GODS MUST BE CRAZY'
description: ''THE GODS MUST BE CRAZY'' starts off looking like a work of anthropology, albeit rather a silly one. A group of bushmen are seen in Botswana, living a life extolled by an unseen narrator as a simple, happy one. They are entirely self-sufficient, he explains, and they know no greed or violence or envy. They live in an absolutely arid part of the Kalahari desert, extracting water from roots and arranging leaves at night to collect the dew.

title: San Francisco Prepares For the Mentally Ill
description: Fearing the effects that the power struggles and excited atmosphere of a national political convention might have on mentally ill people, city officials are lining up extra beds in area psychiatric hospitals as the Democrats prepare to meet here July 16-19.

title: Kuwait Says It Will Try To Buy Soviet Arms
description: Kuwait will send its Defense Minister, Sheik Salem al-Sabah, to Moscow for a week starting Monday in an effort to buy Soviet arms to protect its oil shipping from attacks in the Iraq-Iraq war, the Kuwaiti press agency said today in a dispatch monitored here.

title: Sullivan Triumphs
description: Danny Sullivan outlasted Bobby Rahal during the second half of the Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix today, winning the 220-mile race by two laps when Rahal's car stopped six laps from the end, apparently because of transmission problems.

title: MUSIC: CITY OPERA PRESENTS PUCCINI'S 'BOHEME'
description: ''LA BOHEME'' Saturday evening suggested that the New York City Opera has on hand the basic ingredients for successful Puccini, which is a good thing to know, since a third of the company's summer performances will be of his operas. And there is a fine new tenor on the roster, which is a good thing to know any time.

title: PREMATURE WHIFFS OF AFTER-DINNER CIGARS
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY FINDS LIFE EXPECTANCY IN U.S. AT A HIGH, 74.2 YEARS
description: Life expectancy of Americans is at a high, and the age-adjusted death rate at a low, new Government statistics show.

title: Rangers 9, Tigers 7
description: Texas built a seven-run lead and survived a pair of costly errors to edge Detroit.

title: OPEC STILL DIVIDED AS TALKS NEAR
description: The 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries who will meet beginning tomorrow in Vienna are split into uneasy factions amid an oversupply of oil and increased fighting in the Persian Gulf.

title: Bumpers Says Party Could Be Weakened
description: Senator Dale Bumpers said today that the Democratic National Convention is likely to be divisive and could weaken the party for the fall campaign.

title: Lawyer Married To Karen Gantz
description: Karen Gantz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Gantz of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Jeffrey Zahler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zahler of Boynton Beach, Fla. Rabbi Joseph Speiser performed the ceremony at the Gantz home.

title: Broadcasting Union Rejects Latest Pact Offered by NBC
description: A union that would be instrumental in the NBC News coverage of this summer's political conventions has rejected the network's latest offer for a four-year contract, a union spokesman said Friday.

title: UTAH TO OFFER NO-CERTIFICATE BONDS
description: New issues in the debt markets this week will be highlighted by a sale of what is likely to be a harbinger of things to come: the paperless municipal bond.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on Thursday incorrectly described the availability of the Satoki talking wristwatch. Ohrbach's will sell it beginning July 16.

title: KOHL ASKS ARGENTINE AUSTERITY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany left here today after a four-day visit in which he was friendly but firm in telling Argentines that they must settle with the International Monetary Fund before industrial nations will help the country solve its debt crisis.

title: California Has a Mild Quake
description: A mild earthquake was felt here early today, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology said. The quake, centered three miles southeast of Long Beach, registered 2.6 on the Richter scale,

title: Hong Kong Gold Price
description: Gold dropped the equivalent of $2.18 an ounce on the Hong Kong market today, opening at $348.67.

title: APPOINTMENT OF WHITE SPARKS A RIGHTS DEBATE
description: Mayor Donald M. Fraser's nomination of a white feminist to be the director of the Minneapolis Civil Rights Department has angered some black and Hispanic leaders, who have accused him of racism and of reneging on the city's commitment to civil rights.

title: Watson Triumphs in Playoff
description: Tom Watson, the world's premier golfer in the last decade, beat Greg Norman, the premier golfer in the last month, on the third hole of a sudden-death playoff in the 81st Western Open today.

title: AIR FORCE FINDS INDUSTRY LIMITED IN ABILITY TO SUPPLY ARMS FOR WAR
description: A new and comprehensive Air Force inquiry has concluded that American industry would be unable to accelerate to the high rates of production of aircraft, missiles and other arms that the Air Force says would be needed in the event of a large-scale war.

title: Worker at Mall Festival Hurt as Tank Explodes
description: One man was seriously injured today when fire in a barbecue grill spread to a tent at the Smithsonian's American Folklife Festival and a propane tank exploded.

title: RULING ON DRAFT DISAPPOINTS COLLEGES
description: College and university officials in the New York metropolitan area have expressed disappointment and resignation over last week's decision by the United States Supreme Court upholding a three-year-old Federal law that links scholarship aid to draft registration.

title: Marilyn Sue Spracker Marries in Milwaukee
description: The marriage of Marilyn Sue Spracker and Frederic David Tannenbaum, 1981 graduates of the University of Wisconsin Law School, took place yesterday at the Fleur de Lis restaurant in Milwaukee. Rabbi Barry Francis Silberg officiated.

title: HIGH TIME TO CANCEL THE 'RENTER PENALTY'
description: To the Editor:

title: TWIN MISSES SIGN, BEATS YANKS IN 10TH
description: In what amounted to a state-of-the-team address at midseason, Yogi Berra said today, ''Our first mission will be to reach .500.'' But the Yankee manager will have to wait until after the All- Star Game break to start toward that goal.

title: Michelob Tests
description: It became known a month ago that Anheuser-Busch, the nation's largest brewery, was testing Michelob commercials made by Ted Bates Worldwide and Needham, Harper & Steers, already one of its agencies. Asked Friday whether there had been any decision on the future of the brand, Fleischman-Hilliard, St. Louis, the brewery's public relations firm, said, ''No comment.''

title: 20 Rebels Said to Die in Peru As Troops Step Up Offensive
description: At least 20 Maoist guerrillas have been killed in a clash with a combined army and marine force during a stepped-up offensive in a remote area of the Andes, the state-owned television channel said today, quoting a Government source.

title: WESTERN EUROPE SEEKS TO STEM TIDE OF ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Harried by overextended welfare budgets, fear of crime and a whiff of xenophobia in the political atmosphere, the Governments of Western Europe are struggling to turn back a tide of illegal immigration.

title: SOUL MUSIC: BOTTOM LINE OFFERS 2 ACTS
description: THE farther what used to be called soul music recedes into history, the more pronounced its characteristics seem to be. Both Darlene Love, the lead singer on a number of Phil Spector-produced records from the early 60's, and Sam and Dave, the duo who recorded some memorable soul standards in Memphis, sing pop with a full-voiced intensity and an optimistic fervor that is just one step away from gospel.

title: Please Name the Quarterback
description: When the Giants and the Jets report to training camp next weekend, the identity of each team's preferred quarterback would seem to be obvious. Phil Simms has been liberated from having Scott Brunner peek over his shoulder in the Giants' huddle. Ken O'Brien, although a virtual rookie, is the reason the Jets traded Richard Todd to the New Orleans Saints.

title: Saturday Review's Plan
description: The new owners of Saturday Review hope to raise as much as $2 million in a limited partnership offering, a venture seldom used in publishing but popular in real estate syndications, a business journal has reported.

title: Washington Watch; Bonds Tailored For Foreigners
description: WASHINGTON

title: BLACKS TOLD TO AWAIT 'SIGNAL'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has urged his supporters not to blindly back the Presidential nominee of the Democratic Party, saying they should wait for a signal from him that such support is warranted.

title: AUTO MAKERS TURN TO KOREA
description: American auto makers are again looking to the Far East to find a nation that offers low labor costs, a well- educated and hard-working labor force and a government that encourages big business. But it is not Japan that has drawn their attention this time, but South Korea.

title: Suzanne Nutt Is Bride Of Stephen B. Yablon
description: Suzanne Nutt, a daughter of Lorna Anshen Nutt of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Robert Lee Nutt of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Barry Yablon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Yablon of Charleston, S.C. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Record Caps Lonely Journey
description: The rest of the world, the ones who did not run for six days and who could not necessarily understand why anyone would, began appearing at Downing Stadium to watch as the week wore on. By Saturday, some were spending the night.

title: Good Deal for Horse
description: Rita's Deal, New Jersey's 1982 claiming horse of the year, is a 7-year-old gelding with bad legs who is heading for prison, and a life of ease.

title: A FESTIVAL CELEBRATING AMERICAN ARTS IS PLANNED FOR BRITAIN
description: Last year, it was the ''Britain Salutes New York'' festival. Next year, America will return the compliment.

title: Dead Heat Marks Half-Marathon
description: Europe's top two female marathon runners, Ingrid Kristiansen and Grete Waitz, ran stride for stride to a dead heat in a half-marathon today through the streets of this city.

title: Transactions
description: SATURDAY BASEBALL

title: AIRPORT TICKET MACHINES GAIN
description: Ten minutes before the Eastern shuttle's hourly departures at La Guardia Airport, the last-minute passengers arrive. And like many of them one recent morning, Lou Ulsch of West Milford, N.J., sprinted, billfold in mouth, over to one of the five self-service ticket machines.

title: INDIA POLITICS: TIME OF FURY
description: It appears unlikely that India will hold a general election before late September, but events of the last month suggest the campaign has already begun.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: United States Olympic Team vs. N.B.A. All-Star Team, at Indianapolis. A crowd of more than 70,000 may gather in the Hoosier Dome to watch a doubleheader. The men's team will play its fifth game against an assortment of N.B.A. stars, and the contest will be on cable television. The United States women's team will also face a group of former college and professional stars, including Nancy Lieberman and Carol Blazejowski, in a game that will not be televised. The men's team is coming from Iowa City, where it played an N.B.A. team yesterday. The record crowd for basketball in the United States is 61,612 at the N.C.A.A. Final Four in 1982 in the New Orleans Superdome. (Television - SportsChannel, 9:30 P.M. live.) Golf

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SOMETHING OUT THERE. Stories by Nadine Gordimer. 203 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: Roxana Sobie Is Married to Robert M. Tetenbaum
description: Roxana Sobie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sobie of Miami Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert M. Tetenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Tetenbaum of New York and Taconic, Conn. Rabbi Herschel Cohen performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York.

title: DOG SUMMONS GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; The Art Of Selling Nothing
description: DO you suppose that the ultimate in the practice of advertising is using it to sell nothing?

title: LOUGANIS, KIMBALL GAIN DIVING SPOTS
description: Greg Louganis and Bruce Kimball easily outdistanced the other 10 competitors today to make the United States team on the 10-meter platform, the final event of the Olympic diving trials.

title: THE KING OF THE SCREWBALL
description: FIFTY years ago tomorrow, in baseball's second All-Star Game, Carl Hubbell of the New York Giants got in trouble when the first two batters reached base. Using his marvelous left-handed screwball, Carl Hubbell then struck out, in order, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Jimmy Foxx, Al Simmons and Joe Cronin - five eventual members of the Hall of Fame.

title: Schools Ask Loan Ceiling Rise
description: The nation's graduate schools asked the Reagan Administration over the weekend to increase the ceiling on federally guaranteed student loans to $8,000 a year from $5,000 a year.

title: Toledo Golf Is Won By Lauri Peterson
description: Lauri Peterson made a 10-foot birdie putt on the 14th hole to break a tie with Nancy Lopez today and win the $175,000 Jamie Farr Toledo Classic.

title: THE POWER THAT LURKS IN A RECESS BY CONGRESS
description: A political debate has been rekindled in this town that involves the appointive powers of the Presidency, the perquisites of the Senate and the politics of an election year.

title: PSYCHOLOGISTS EXAMINE APPEAL OF MICHAEL JACKSON
description: Why such an outpouring of adulation for Michael Jackson?

title: Radiation at French Test Site Found Below World Average
description: Radiation levels on Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific, where France has conducted more than 60 nuclear tests, are lower than the world average, according to a scientific study made public here today.

title: Stephen Marcus Wed To Renee R. Matalon
description: At Young Israel of Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, Renee Riva Matalon, the daughter of Sara Limon Matalon of Forest Hills and Maurice Matalon of Miami, was married to Stephen Howard Marcus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Marcus of Kingston, Ontario. Rabbi David Algaze performed the ceremony.

title: MCENROE OVERWHELMS CONNORS
description: With his serve booming like a Rich Gossage fastball, John McEnroe made quick work of Jimmy Connors in the Wimbledon tennis final today, giving up only four games in 80 minutes to a man known for his battling spirit.

title: FOR PROUD COLOMBIA BIKERS, TOUR DE FRANCE IS STRANGE RACE
description: To most people associated with the Tour de France, Greg Lemond is ''the American,'' but to a sizable bloc, he is ''el Norte Americano,'' the North American, accent on ''North.''

title: JAZZ: 4 CLARINETISTS PLAY AT THE PUBLIC
description: JUST about every sound four unaccompanied jazz clarinetists could make, separately and as a group, was heard Saturday at the Public Theater. The clarinetists John Carter, Alvin Batiste and Jimmy Hamilton reconvened the Clarinet Summit first heard at the Public in December 1982; Hamiet Bluiett replaced David Murray on bass clarinet.

title: LAND OF INCREASINGLY BETTER AND BETTER-PAID JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: NIGERIA HINTS ABDUCTION WAS FAKED
description: A Government spokesman suggested today that a former Nigerian Cabinet minister might have been arranged his own kidnapping in London to gain international attention.

title: Judy Milkie Wins
description: Judy Milkie of Anaheim won the women's division of the Western States 100-mile endurance run early today in 20 hours 4 minutes. The men's winner was Jim King of Newport Beach, Calif., who finished Saturday night in a course-record 14:54.

title: People
description: * William B. Singer has been promoted to senior vice president and treasurer of Ingalls Associates, Boston.

title: Monty Python Star To Appear for Compaq
description: John Cleese, Britain's gift to insanity, will next appear in TV commercials on behalf of the Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston and most likely he'll be as funny as he was for American Express, Kronenbourg beer and Callard & Bowser candy.

title: 'AMAZING' COORDINATION CITED IN SAVING TRAIN RIDERS' LIVES
description: ''Extraordinary'' coordination among rescuers and hospital workers carrying out a local plan for coping with disasters was credited today by a Federal official with saving lives when an Amtrak passenger train derailed Saturday morning.

title: Greece's Takeovers Stir Fight
description: The hard feelings between the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and Greece's business community were further embittered recently when the Government fined the Halyvourgiki Steel Company $82 million, roughly twice its total assets.

title: DALLAS WONDERS IF ITS GROWTH IS TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING
description: In a city that has never doubted the virtue of robust, untrammeled growth, the current debate here seems distinctly out of place.

title: WRANGLERS GAIN FINAL
description: Coach George Allen said his Arizona Wranglers' playoff victory over the Los Angeles Express Saturday night was anything but a fluke.

title: Letter: On Senate Politics
description: Misgivings on the Scope of Civil Rights

title: Who'll Pay the Bills for Baby Doe?
description: Just how much and what kind of care a severely handicapped infant should get is a question that's been agitating the nation ever since the death of one called Doe in 1982. Baby Doe, born with Down's syndrome, died of starvation after his parents, supported by the Indiana courts, chose not to feed him. The Federal response to the public outcry was an ill- advised attempt to create a spy system in hospital nurseries.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Strike Idles 1,400 At Brass Factory
description: The second strike in three years at the state's largest brass company has idled 1,400 workers, prompting Gov. William A. O'Neill to intervene.

title: REV. LINCOLN CATCHINGS
description: The Rev. Lincoln Maynard Catchings, a Congregational minister and a former president of the Montclair (N.J.) Board of Education, died of cancer last Wednesday at Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: Spain Honors John Brealey
description: John Brealey, head of the department of conservation at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has received one of Spain's most prestigious awards, the Gold Medal for Achievement in the Fine Arts. The award commemorates the conspicuous success of his recent cleaning of ''Las Meninas,'' the great painting by Velazquez in the Prado, Madrid. The medal was given to Mr. Brealey Wednesday by King Juan Carlos at a ceremony in the Prado that was attended by many leading figures in the arts in Spain.

title: CITY OPERA: 'BUTTERFLY,' BY PUCCINI
description: MUSIC'S most celebrated lepidopteran fluttered blithely across the stage of the New York State Theater yesterday afternoon. ''Madama Butterfly'' has been in the repertory of the New York City Opera since 1946; yesterday's presentation - the first of the summer season - found Puccini's gentle heartbreaker preserved in immaculate condition.

title: The Beat Goes On
description: He was finally at the top of the hill, but looking down, and Rick Bozeat wasn't sure how glad he was. For 20 years, the Juilliard School graduate from Cedar Grove, N.J., had been trying to make it as a drummer. Now, atop the last peak of his first long-distance bicycle race, after taking up the sport to (a) condition himself for drumming and (b) have ''several hundred miles for time to think,'' it was all downhill and he knew he was going to win the $500 first prize.

title: DiGiacomo & Partners Gets New Jersey Nets
description: Frank DiGiacomo's new agency, DiGiacomo & Partners, has received a creative-only assignment to do the ads for the New Jersey Nets basketball team.

title: Rockwell Contract
description: The United States Energy Department's San Franciso operations office said it had approved a $200 million, five-year contract with the Rockwell Internationad Corporation.

title: AWARDED 1969 PULITZER PRIZE
description: George Oppen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, died Saturday in the Idlewood Convalescent Home in Sunnyvale, Calif. He was 76 years old and suffered from Alzheimer's disease.

title: JACKSON (CANDIDATE) CALLS ON THE JACKSONS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson briefly turned from the role of campaigner to that of fan, friend and spirtual adviser to the singing Jackson brothers.

title: TV SERIES TO BE BROADCAST IN STERO
description: One of the technical breakthroughs planned for television as it moves toward the 21st century is the regular broadcasting of TV programs in stereo sound. And one of the first dramatic shows to move into this area is ''Miami Vice,'' a new police melodrama being produced by Universal Television for airing on NBC on Friday evenings beginning this fall.

title: CABARET: AT PAPER MOON, SONGS FROM 3 DECADES
description: THE cabaret revue called ''From High Above the Altoona Motor Hotel,'' which has moved into the Paper Moon Cabaret, 82 West Third Street on Thursday and Friday nights, is a continuation of a similar ''musical romp through the 20's, 30's and 40's'' that was performed during 1981 and 1982 at the Third Avenue restaurant called Once Upon a Stove.

title: BROOKLYN HTS. TOWER PLAN IS DISPUTED
description: The Jehovah's Witnesses have asked the city for permission to build a 34- story residential tower just outside the Brooklyn Heights Historic District, a project some residents say would disturb the character of the neighborhood.

title: U.S. COURTS ARE JAMMED BY CASELOAD
description: Besieged by sharply higher caseloads, a shortage of judges and, in some areas, crowded quarters, the Federal District Courts in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are struggling to keep up with their calendars, court officials say.

title: Accounts
description: * Chibret International, a division of Merck Sharp & Dohme, International, to Rolf Werner Rosenthal for an image campaign.

title: Time, the Pope and Galileo
description: One kind of time is told by the clock, another by the psyche. The latter flies or drags or disappears entirely.

title: CONFUCIUS'S LESSON TO LITIGANTS
description: I recently returned from a visit to Japan to study its legal system with an idea about what we can do to relieve our terribly congested courts: import Confucianism.

title: FEDERAL STUDY FINDS RATE OF EXECUTIONS IS RISING
description: Nearly 4,000 convicts have been executed in the United States since 1930 and two- fifths of the death sentences were carried out in five states, according to a Justice Department study released today.

title: Air Florida's Financing Plan
description: Air Florida, in an effort to resume partial operations, will go to a bankruptcy judge on Monday to ask for permission to collect and spend up to $27 million it is owed in accounts receivable, company sources said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, named four group vice presidents: Harold S. Evans, international; Clyde R. Gillespie, engineered products; Ronald R. Hoffman, flat rolled products, and Vincent R. Scorsone, primary metals. The company also named Richard L. Fischer, Donald R. Whitlow and James W. Wirth senior vice presidents.

title: REAGAN'S VERSION OF TRUTH
description: ''But jest 'fore Christmas I'm as good as I kin be''

title: TECHNICAL FACTORS PREVAIL
description: Technical factors rather than economic fundamentals are likely to dominate trading patterns in the credit markets this week, according to analysts, with participants looking for signs of a tightening in monetary policy from the Federal Reserve in advance of the meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee next week on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Market Place; Tootsie Roll's Stock Surge
description: A MANHATTAN stockbroker with 20 years of experience was asked last week what he knew about Tootsie Roll Industries. ''Is that a listed company?'' he replied.

title: The U.N. Today July 9, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NEW ROCHELLE IS CRACKING DOWN ON GRAFFITI
description: Graffiti, long the bane of the New York City subway system, are becoming an increasing problem for this tidy Westchester County suburb, which takes pride in being known as the ''Queen of the Sound.''

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH REBUFF TO GREECE BY DENYING PLANES
description: State Department and Pentagon officials said today that the Reagan Administration was nearing a decision to deny a request from Greece for surplus aircraft, largely in reaction to Athens's recent handling of incidents involving terrorist activity.

title: JAZZ: BILL KOMAIKO'S GROUP
description: A JAZZ sound out of the 1950's could be heard from time to time last weekend at the Angry Squire, Seventh Avenue at 23d Street. It was the strong, springing, repeated bass figures and the sibilant sound of brushes on drums that the pianist Ahmad Jamal used as background for his solos then.

title: Chairman's Title Added By G.R.I.'s President
description: David R. Rubin, president of the Chicago-based G.R.I. Corporation, has been appointed to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Maurice H. Bronner, who has resigned for reasons of health.

title: IN NEWARK'S IRONBOUND, DIOXIN REMAINS AND SO DO THE WORRIES
description: Last year, men wearing protective white suits and gas masks barricaded railroad tracks, posted warning signs and vacuumed streets after dioxin was discovered in the Ironbound section here.

title: OLYMPIC BOXER IS HIS OWN BIGGEST FAN
description: Robert Shannon of Edmonds, Wash., is 21 years old, 5 feet 5 1/4 inches and 119 pounds. As one of the 12 survivors of the box-offs here Friday and Saturday, he will represent the United States in the Olympics starting in three weeks in Los Angeles.

title: Bolivia Labor Federation Calls Off General Strike
description: Bolivia's Communist-led Workers' Confederation, which controls virtually all unionized labor, called off a general strike today and said it had won from the Government concessions that included a pledge to suspend indefinitely foreign debt payments to commercial banks.

title: Better Late
description: Usually, spectators who are coming to a popular sports event are advised to get there early to avoid traffic jams. But the new 61,000-seat Hoosier Dome opens officially tonight with a warning from the Indianapolis Police Department to the expected 71,000 fans to do just the opposite. Deputy Chief Paul Annee said reverse logic has to apply to the downtown facility that helped lure the National Football League Colts out of Baltimore.

title: OUTDOORS: A CASE FOR FISHING WITH BAIT
description: THERE is a growing tendency among sport fishermen to regard those of their ilk who angle with bait as clods. This attitude derives in part from the flood of spinning rods, reels and lures that have emerged since World War II. It is now possible to purchase spinning equipment that will cast lures ranging from a hefty four ounces to an eighth of an ounce, a range of choices that enables one to go after all but the truly large saltwater species and most of the freshwater fishes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: MOZART AL FRESCO The Mostly Mozart Festival, a Lincoln Center staple for 17 years, comes up for the 18th time today. It will resound beneath the ceiling of Avery Fisher Hall through Aug. 25, but first, it will have its moment in the sun, weather permitting.

title: Olympic Problem
description: Many of the best eligible players will not be on the United States Olympic soccer team. The head coach, Alkis Panagoulias, would like to have as many as six or seven of the Cosmos' professional American players on his 17-man Olympic roster. But the Cosmos' president, Rafael de la Sierra, says he cannot release so many players - and will not release one or two because ''you should do it right or not do it at all.''

title: Loan Offer to Colombia
description: The United States Export-Import Bank has offered Colombia a $200 million loan to finance heavy machinery and transport equipment for the El Cerrejon coal mine, according to a Finance Ministry spokesman. The offer was made by the bank's president, William Draper, who arrived in Colombia on Thursday and met President Belisario Betancur and Finance Minister Edgar Gutierrez Castro.

title: PERSIAN GULF BANKING SLOWS
description: Some of the glitter has been wearing off Persian Gulf banking.

title: Irish Terrier Best
description: Edward Jenner's Irish terrier, Ch. Tralee's Rowdy Red, was best among 1,458 dogs today at the 34th Wallkill Kennel Club show for his third victory in three days.

title: SMALL BUSINESS JOINS THE BOOM IN CONNECTICUT
description: Four years ago, Magoo was just another bird in a pet-shop window. Today, he gets invited to some of the fanciest corporate gatherings in town.

title: 'JESSE OWEN STORY,' A TWO-PART MOVIE ON WPIX
description: TONIGHT at 8 on WPIX/ Channel 11, ''The Jesse Owens Story,'' introduced as ''A Special Presentation From Paramount,'' takes one of this century's greatest athletes and puts him in the kind of inspirational entertainment package beloved of sports movies. While hardly any sensitive or possibly embarrassing questions are ignored, few are answered definitively. What finally emerges, made all the more convincing by Dorian Harewood's compelling performance in the title role, is a portrait of a good and almost hopelessly naive man whose sheer dignity helped him survive. The second part of the four-hour movie will be shown Wednesday at 8.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A player for Team A in the National Basketball Association intercepts a pass and is breaking downcourt for an unimpeded layup. In an effort to have a foul called that will prevent the basket from counting, a Team B player tackles a Team A player not involved in the play. What is the ruling?

title: Futures/Options; Comex Tie To Unit of Big Board
description: EVEN before the New York Futures Exchange was born on Aug. 7, 1980, its parent, the New York Stock Exchange, knew it had created a problem.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Jerseyans Return HomeAfterFloods
description: Most New Jersey residents who were forced from their homes by flooding Saturday returned yesterday and cleaned up after a day of record rainfall. About 50 families were evacuated in Somerset and Hunterdon Counties, the state police said.

title: ;  One Dies as Plane Crashes Off L.I.
description: A small airplane crashed into Gardiners Bay 800 yards east of Shelter Island last night, the Coast Guard reported.

title: THE STRAIN OF SCHOOL IN SUMMER
description: Friends have gone off to tennis

title: BRIEFING
description: Stop Campaigns Abroad

title: 18 Injured Before Bob Dylan Concert
description: Rioting music fans set cars on fire, stoned a police station and clashed with baton-wielding officers today before a Bob Dylan concert in this Irish village.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Touching Bases With Their Youth

title: 5-GAME SWEEP FOR METS
description: The Mets ended the first half of their season yesterday, in first place and in their best position ever at this point in the season. Putting together their second straight surge of power, the Mets, who scored 14 runs Saturday night, scored 7 more yesterday to defeat Cincinnati, 7-3, before a crowd of 48,916 at Shea Stadium.

title: Ramsay Signs
description: Jack Ramsay has signed a three-year contract to continue coaching the Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association. The 59- year-old Ramsay has coached the team for eight seasons.

title: Pair Sought in 4 States After Toledo Killings
description: Alton Coleman and the woman accompanying him are the object of a four- state hunt after two weekend slayings. Officials said today that the two probably fled Toledo in a car stolen from a couple who called Mr. Coleman ''an extremely pleasant type of guy,'' officials said today.

title: MONDAY, JULY 9, 1984 International
description: Greece's request for surplus aircraft will probably be turned down by the Reagan Administration, according to State Department and Pentagon officials. They said the Administration was near a decision to reject the request, largely in reaction to Athens's recent handling of incidents involving terrorist activity. Greece has been seeking to obtain 16 F-5 interceptors from Norway, which received them free of charge from the United States a decade ago. Norway has declared the aircraft to be surplus, but the United States retains control over further transfers. (Page A1, Column 6.) Illegal immigration in West Europe has reached the point where the Governments are trying to turn the immigrants back, but they have not been particularly successful, with the possible exception of Britain. Tamil tea pickers from Sri Lanka, Kurds from Beirut, Ashantis from Ghana, teen- agers from Iran seeking to avoid the draft and Pakistani drug pushers are seeking refuge. (A1:3.)

title: HINGSEN PUSHING TOWARD DECATHLON DUEL
description: KREFELD, West Germany

title: HAIL THE STATE!
description: The power of the modern state strains the central premise of American democracy, the belief that freedom requires limits on government. For the levers of power available to government today - economic, technological, physical - would amaze not only Jefferson but Franklin Roosevelt.

title: BUSINESSES' USE OF HELICOPTERS INCREASES HERE
description: Corporate executives with offices in the suburbs around New York City are increasingly relying on helicopters to get into the city and to other locations in the Northeast.

title: Switch to G.O.P. Is Official
description: Representative Andy Ireland has officially abandoned his long affiliation with the Democratic Party in favor of the Republican Party, which he said is closer to the philosophy of his district. ''The GOP philosophy is more in tune with my constituents,'' Mr. Ireland said as he signed documents Thursday at the local courthouse to change his party registration. He also announced he would seek re-election to a fifth term.

title: LEBANESE IN AFRICE: TALE OF SUCCESS (AND ANXIETY)
description: Some 30,000 Lebanese have found a haven in this tiny West African nation, where, unlike the people in Beirut, they live peacefully, prosperously and as quietly as they can.

title: Sometimes Square
description: Times Square is the town square of New York and in some ways of the nation, too: the central space, the spot to which people turn when a New Year begins, when a great war ends. But with the rise of porn, drug dealing, peddling, mugging and the city's use of nearby hotels for desperate homeless families, the square's decline has become precipitous. If it is to be saved as town square, this year may be the last real chance. Yet even those now working boldly to save it do not always understand. Lights and signs, they say. Tack on neon, lasers. They miss the point.

title: Miss Habousha Becomes Bride of Edward B. Cohen
description: Farha-Nadine Habousha, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hayim V. Habousha of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Edward B. Cohen, the son of Herbert S. Cohen of New York and the late Arline W. Cohen. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: California Brush Fire Sweeps 3,000 Acres
description: A rapidly spreading brush fire burned across 3,000 acres of rugged terrain that included parts of Sequoia National Park today.

title: SHULTZ DISCUSSES FUTURE OF HONG KONG
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said tonight that although the United States was not a party to the negotiations between Britain and China over Hong Kong's future, Washington had a ''deep interest'' in insuring that the final agreement preserved the crown colony's ''stability and prosperity.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JULY 9, 1984

title: AT REUNION, ACTORS REAFFIRM THEIR COMMITMENT TO CHICAGO'S STEPPENWOLF
description: R. SHIPP

title: Leona Jaglom Married to Robin Hirsch
description: Leona M. Jaglom, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology, and Robin Hirsch, an adjunct professor of literature and theater, both at New York University, were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Milo in Greens Farms, Conn. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MAGIC FLUTE' IS PRESENTED
description: THE New York City Opera continued its young summer season Saturday afternoon with Mozart's ''Magic Flute.'' It is a production with worthwhile qualities, and friends of the City Opera - and of Mozart - should try to see it.

title: Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
description: First Federal of Michigan International is issuing $75 million of five- year Euronotes with a 13 1/4 percent coupon through Banque Paribas. Fitchburg Gas and Electric Light Co.'s senior debt has been rated BBx by Standard & Poor's and its preferred stock BB-, with both removed from Credit Watch; the actions affect $30.5 million of securities of the Canton, Mass., utility.

title: Midwest Journal Angry Fan Sues Colts On Tickets
description: R. SHIPP

title: A WOMAN ON THE TICKET: SOME POLLS AND HUNCHES
description: There are few political subjects around that provoke as many contradictory certainties as the idea of a woman as Walter F. Mondale's running mate.

title: Article 049166 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Antismoking Drive Goes to Dawson, Johns
description: The antismoking program of the United States Department of Health and Human Services has been assigned to Dawson, Johns & Black, a small Chicago agency.

title: LESSONS FOR EXECUTIVES PUT EMPHASIS ON STYLE
description: Representatives from some of the top firms on Wall Street were there, as well as from some of the biggest banks and corporations in America. Sitting at large conference tables, they scribbled notes furiously. Suddenly, on cue, everyone turned to the next person and shook hands.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: TBS Gets Offer to Cover Alternative Olympics
description: Turner Broadcasting System officials said they had received an offer from the Soviet Union to provide cable-television coverage of the Communist alternative to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: JACKSON BELTS 492D HOMER
description: Mike Easler's bases-loaded single with one out in the bottom of the 10th inning today lifted the Boston Red Sox to their fifth straight triumph, a 3-2 victory over the California Angels in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: MUSLIM SECT LEADER APOLOGIZES AS AIDES DETAIN 3 REPORTERS
description: Aides to the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, leader of a Black Muslim sect, detained several reporters who were covering Mr. Farrakhan's speech to the Indiana Black Expo Saturday after the reporters refused to give up their press passes.

title: EFFECTS OF 22-YEAR-OLD COAL-MINE FIRE ARE STUDIED
description: State Health Department investigators are conducting interviews here in a new study to measure the health effects of a mine fire that has been raging beneath this town for 22 years.

title: Matz Rides Chef To Show Victory
description: Michael Matz, the leading money winner in Mercedes Grand Prix history, added to his totals by riding Chef to victory in today's $50,000 Mercedes I Love New York Grand Prix, the grand finale of the seventh annual I Love New York horse show.

title: TRAIN WRECK LAID TO VERMONT RAINS
description: A train wreck that left five people dead and 153 injured was apparently caused by heavy rains that washed out an old stone culvert and then undermined an earth embankment over which the train ran, a Federal official said today.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney division said that Swissair and Muse Air had placed orders worth more than $50 million for JT8D-200 series engines to power new McDonnell Douglas MD-80 twinjets. Swissair, whose formal name is Schweizerische Luftverkehr A.G., has ordered four new planes for delivery beginning in early 1986. Muse Air has ordered six new aircraft for delivery from May 1985 through April 1987.

title: Bomb Charges May Change
description: Federal charges against a former mental patient suspected of planting pipe bombs in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois in May will be dismissed so the states can prosecute, a newspaper reported today. Quoting an unidentified source, The St. Paul Pioneer Press said in a copyrighted story that the Federal indictment against Earl Steven Karr, 24 years old, would be dismissed Monday because prosecutors expected him to plead insanity. State standards for proof of insanity would make state prosecutions more desirable, the source said.

title: Whitecaps Beat Cosmos by 2-1
description: Frans Thijssen booted a spectacular goal in the 38th minute tonight to break a tie and give the Vancouver Whitecaps their fourth straight victory, a 2-1 decision over the slumping Cosmos.

title: Books: A Peruvian's Dream
description: PASSAGE THROUGH EL DORADO. By Jonathan Kandell. 312 pages. William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: Woman Flung to Death From Roller Coaster
description: A woman was flung 20 feet to her death from a new stand-up roller coaster ride Saturday. Her husband discounted the explanation of the amusement park and said he was considering a suit.

title: Olympic Squad Wins
description: Alvin Robertson scored a game-high 17 points and Michael Jordan and Chris Mullin added 16 each today to lead the United States Olympic basketball team to a 92-79 victory over a National Basketball Association all-star squad. It was the Olympians' third straight victory over an N.B.A. squad.

title: LAWYERS SHARE JOBS FOR MORE FAMILY TIME
description: ''Here I was - woman, lawyer, wife and mother,'' said Vida M. Alvy, recalling the time a year ago when, as a New York State assistant attorney general on maternity leave, she contemplated returning to work full time. ''I felt my child's toddlerhood would be very short, and I didn't want to miss it. But I'd been lawyering for six years, and I didn't want to give that up either.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Faces at the Gateway

title: LEADING BLACK REPUBLICANS ASSAIL REAGAN RIGHTS AIDE
description: Many black Republican leaders who support President Reagan say they sharply disagree with the civil rights policies of his Administration, and some have urged Mr. Reagan to dismiss the Justice Department official in charge of civil rights.

title: THE LAND WHERE BASEBALL THRIVES LIKE SUGAR
description: SAN PEDRO DE MACORIS, D.R. ON one side of the main square, overlooking the royal palms and the thick mahoganies, is a steamy bar with slowly revolving ceiling fans called the Dugout.

title: A NUN BRINGS POOR YOUNGSTERS INTO COMPUTER AGE
description: Sister Dorita Clifford's touch is apparent from the moment a visitor walks into St. Leo's Elementary School here. In the entry lobby stands a statue of the Virgin Mary and a sign saying ''Join Our Computer Club.''

title: Vacationer Finds Home Has Burned and Dies
description: A man died on returning to find his house destroyed by the latest suspicious fire in this Boston suburb, the authorities said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All week I was seeing the ball as big as a basketball and today I couldn't find it.'' - Jimmy Connors, loser to John McEnroe in Wimbledon final. (C1:6.)

title: JUNE SALES UP 4.1% IN NEW YORK STORES
description: Sales at New York City's major department store chains rose a small 4.1 percent in June over the year- earlier month, a spot-check found late last week. The retailers blamed high temperatures and heavy rainfall for the drop in traffic.

title: HOW THE VATICAN'S ART TREASURES WERE PRESERVED DURING U.S. TOUR
description: ROMEThe Vatican is not an institution that shows doubt to the outside world. Consequently, last March it remained outwardly placid at a time when any other organization would have heaved a sigh of relief heard all over town.

title: A WILD GRAND PRIX IN DALLAS
description: While 102-degree weather baked a new track, Keke Rosberg of Finland kept cool today and won the first Dallas Grand Prix for Formula One cars. It was a wild race.

title: STARS ADVANCE TO FINAL, 20-10
description: In defeating the Birmingham Stallions today, 20-10, the Philadelphia Stars continued their relentless drive for the goal they just missed a year ago, the championship of the United States Football League.

title: No Headline
description: Frederick W. Hall, 76, FormerJustice inJersey

title: Nazi War Criminal Suspect Renounces U.S. Citizenship
description: Anatoly Hrusitzky, accused of being a Nazi war criminal, has renounced his American citizenship and left the United States, the Justice Department said Friday.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: Tokyo Tournament Is Spur For College-Level Matches

title: No Headline
description: Leslie Rubin Is Married

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: U.S. RESTRICTS GOVERNMENT TRAVEL TO BULGARIA
description: The State Department has banned nonessential Government travel to Bulgaria.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Fire Burns 7,000 Acres In the Sequoia Forest
description: A fire raged out of control for the third day today in the Sequoia National Forest, where it has consumed nearly 7,000 acres and caused $250,000 damage.

title: FUTURE BRIGHT FOR WIMBLEDON WINNERS
description: In a Wimbledon that was predictable in every way except for the balmy weather and John McEnroe's sweet temper, two champions defended their singles and doubles titles in such commanding fashion that it seems likely they will embellish their records on the Centre Court for years to come.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Advance Circuits Inc., a printed circuits board company in Minnetonka, Minn., said it had agreed in principle to acquire the multilayer printed circuit manufacturing operations of Multaplex Corp. for about $15 million cash and $3.2 million in securities.

title: 5 RESIGNATIONS SHAKE ARTS IN BOSTON
description: Boston's arts world, in the midst of a major revival, has been thrown into disarray recently by the resignation of five prominent figures.

title: ALBERT H. bLUMENTHAL DIES AT 55; EX-MAJORITY LEADER OF ASSEMBLY
description: Albert H. Blumenthal, a former majority leader of the New York State Assembly and one-time candidate for Mayor of New York, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
New Hampshire Ball Bearings
description: New Hampshire Ball Bearings Inc. said it had received a $65-a-share offer from the Minebea Company of Japan. Based on New Hampshire Ball Bearings' nearly 1.7 million shares outstanding, the offer would be valued at about $110.5 million.

title: The Right Road in Trenton
description: For years New Jersey has cut maintenance funds in every budget crisis. That's a sure recipe for decay, as proved by the sorry condition of the state's bridges, roads and mass transit systems.

title: Four Bolivians To Compete
description: President Hernan Siles Zuazo late today reversed an earlier decision and authorized a team of Bolivian athletes to participate in this month's Olympics in Los Angeles, a presidential spokesman said.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Proposal to End Busing In Norfolk Is Approved
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Norfolk School Board's plan to end nearly 13 years of crosstown busing in the elementary schools is constitutional.

title: Institute Names Director
description: Dr. Thomas H. Lee, a physicist who is the director of the Laboratory for Electromagnetic and Electronic Systems at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been appointed director of the International Institute for Applied System Analysis, near Vienna.

title: YANKS MAKE RIJO COLUMBUS STARTER
description: Jose Rijo, the youngest player in the major leagues, was demoted by the Yankees to Columbus yesterday so that he could ''get more work on a regular basis,'' according to Bill Bergesch, the team's vice president for baseball operations.

title: Continental Illinois
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said it had agreed to sell a mortgage servicing unit to the First Family Mortgage Corporation of Lisle, Ill.. Neither Continental nor First Family would disclose the price.

title: NDW HOPE FOR EYE DISEASE VICTIMS
description: HONOLULUAn estimated 10 million Americans are victims of macular degeneration, an incurable, progressive retinal disorder that is a leading cause of blindness. Most have have received the same distressing message from eye specialists: ''Nothing can be done.''

title: KIN OF KIDNAPPED SHUT DOWN BEIRUT IN GENERAL STRIKE
description: Beirut was paralyzed today as protesters demanding action to free kidnapped relatives blocked roads and crossing points between the Moslem and Christian sectors.

title: SUBWAY SYSTEM REMOVES CARS FOR INSPECTION
description: The New York City Transit Authority has removed 125 subway cars from service because of a recent rash of fires in electrical equipment beneath cars, transit officials said yesterday.

title: TERMINATING PENSION PLANS
description: MOST employees think of their pensions as something immutable, something that will grow and grow until they retire and start collecting monthly checks. But lately, many large corporations are thinking of pension funds more as a source of ready cash - and that is leading them to terminate their employees' pension plans.

title: Steel Output Off in Week
description: Steel production fell to 1.665 million tons in the holiday-shortened week that ended last Saturday, a drop of 6.7 percent from the previous week's 1.785 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

title: Home in Indiana The Baltimore Colts may now be the Indianapolis Colts, but otherwise it seems just like old times, with the players having a hard time coming to agreement with the front office and vice versa. Coach
description: Frank Kush said yesterday that, with the opening of training camp only four days away, about half the players remained unsigned.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Ex-Mayor of Augusta Sentenced in Kickbacks
description: Former Mayor Edward M. McIntyre was sentenced today to five years in prison for his extortion conviction in a scheme to receive kickbacks from developers interested in city property.

title: No Headline
description: Minnesota's Hospitals Reopening After Strike

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary net charge of $130,000 for redemption and cancellation of notes.

title: 4 IN OPEC URGE CURB ON OUTPUT
description: An advisory group for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries urged today that the 13-nation group fight off a predicted oil price drop by reining in production.

title: Stock Program At Chrysler Ends
description: The Chrysler Corporation said its employee stock ownership plan had expired with Chrysler workers owning 16 percent of the company's common shares. Chrysler said its final contribution, for the year ending June 30, came to $40.6 million worth of stock.

title: People
description: * Alan Pando was named a partner in Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: McLain Is Named By Co-Defendant
description: A defendant who pleaded guilty today to possessing cocaine implicated Denny McLain, the former major league pitcher.

title: 100 YEARS OF MONUMENTALITY
description: In a city known for massive, classical architecture crouched low against the horizon, the Washington Monument is a lone vertical triumph, a starkly elegant finger of marble pointing skyward.

title: CHILDREN IN DISMAL BUT COSTLY SETTINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
John McQuillan, 85, Engineer Ora
description: John McQuillan, a communications engineer who took part in the first trans- Atlantic radio conversation, died of pneumonia Sunday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: THE SCOURGE OF TELEPROMPTERS
description: Television viewers in the United States have become so accustomed to flawless newscasters and smooth-talking politicians that they forget how much make-believe is required to create these carefully-sculpted images of spontaneity.

title: BOSTIC'S 68 LEADS STATE OPEN BY SHOT
description: Joe Bostic, head pro of the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn., took a one- stroke lead today in the first round of the Michelob New York State Open. His 68 was three under par for the Big G Course at Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club.

title: Soviet Director Is Said To Be Seeking Asylum
description: The Soviet film director Andrei Tarkovsky has decided to seek political asylum in the West, a Roman Catholic organization announced today.

title: Birch Society Members
description: Three players on the San Diego Padres say they are members of the John Birch Society, the arch-conservative political group, it was reported over the weekend.

title: A BOOM IN SALES OF JUDAICA
description: About two weeks ago, Isaac Pollak spent $176,000 on a book. It was, of course, no ordinary book: It was an 18th-century ''Haggadah,'' the book of Jewish stories, sayings and songs traditionally read at Passover, that was hand-written by a Hebrew scribe and filled with dozens of miniature drawings of biblical scenes.

title: Mays Irked, Skips Game
description: Willie Mays, his feelings hurt, will not be at Candlestick Park for the All-Star Game on Tuesday. It will be the first time he has missed the game since 1954.

title: Chess: Patrick Wolff Is the Winner Of the Junior Championship
description: Patrick Wolff, 16 years old, of Belmont, Mass., won the 1984 United States Junior Championship, which was held at Happy Valley School in Ojai, Calif. Wolff scored 8 1/2-2 1/2 in the annual invitational tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, the American Chess Foundation and the Piatigorsky Foundation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has named Thomas E. Screiber vice president-plant operations for its Packaging Sector's food and specialty packaging unit.

title: BRAINTECH INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-The company had no revenue in fiscal 1983.

title: ALLIES, MISTRUSTFUL OF GREECE, SAID TO BYPASS IT IN DECISIONS
description: In the three years since Andreas Papandreou became the Prime Minister of Greece, the Western alliances have developed a wariness about Greece's often antagonistic role on security matters and antiterrorist policy.
