title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Connecticut Senator To Offer Hart's Name
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut will give the Presidential nominating speech for Senator Gary Hart at the Democratic National Convention next week, the Hart campaign announced today.

title: FAITHS' COMMON ROOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TIMES/CBS POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 23-28 with 1,593 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,154 said they were registered to vote.

title: WINN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $209,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $541,000 and extraordinary income of $823,000.

title: Millar, a Briton, Wins Stage 11
description: Robert Millar of Britain powered his way to victory today in the 11th stage of the 23-day Tour de France, the first stage through the country's mountain regions.

title: Cayuga Tribe Accepts 8,500-Acre Settlement
description: The Cayuga Indians have agreed to accept nearly 8,500 acres of land in Cayuga and Seneca Counties, providing ''a basis for a final settlement'' of their land claim, Representative Frank Horton, Republican of Brighton, said today.

title: Penn Central Bid To Buy Sparkman
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire all of the securities outstanding of the Sparkman Energy Corporation for about $90 million. That includes paying $15.25 a share for Sparkman's 4.5 million common shares outstanding.

title: APPLE TO INCREASE MACINTOSH OUTPUT
description: Apple Computer Inc. plans to double the manufacturing capacity for its new and highly successful Macintosh computers by the end of this year, its president said yesterday.

title: JOSE CARDINAL QUINTERO
description: Jose Humberto Cardinal Quintero died here Sunday after a long illness.

title: DOW UP 11.48 POINTS IN LATE RALLY
description: Stock prices rallied late in the session yesterday, bolstered by a strong rally in the bond market.

title: U.S. Denies a Visa To an I.R.A. Politician
description: The Reagan Administration has refused to grant an entry visa to Gerry Adams, head of Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing, because of his support of violence, United States officials here said today.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including income tax refunds of $1,126,000 for the latest quarter and $1,964,000 for the year-ago quarter.

title: No Headline
description: John F. O'Connell, 73, Ex-President of Bechtel

title: TransCanada
description: Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. said it had acquired another 4 million common shares of TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. at $17.50 (Canadian) each, raising its stake in the company to about 47.2 percent. The transaction was arranged by Daly Gordon Securities. Bell Canada said it had no plans to buy additional shares of TransCanada, but would continue to participate in that company's dividend reinvestment plan.

title: Baryshnikov and Model Start Work on a Movie
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Ingrid Bergman's daughter, the model Isabella Rossellini, begin work this month on a dance film about a Soviet defector back on home soil after a 10-year absence.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chairman Retiring At American Hoist
description: The American Hoist and Derrick Company, an old-line manufacturer of large cranes and other heavy equipment, said yesterday that the retirement of Robert P. Fox, its chairman, would complete a management transition that had begun nearly two years ago.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: All-Star Game, National League vs. American League, at San Francisco. Darryl Strawberry, the first Met elected as a starter since Dave Kingman in 1976 leads his team's delegation to Candlestick Park.

title: Topics Novelties, Old and New
description: Sociology China's eagerness to absorb Western ways continues to puzzle. Its latest great leap into alien life styles is great indeed: It has agreed to let Club Med establish one of its carefree vacation villages on the South China Sea.

title: Acquisition by Bowater
description: Bowater P.L.C., the British paper maker, said today that its freight services unit had acquired Imperial Air Freight Service of New Jersey, paying $7 million, with further payments to be keyed to future performance.

title: STATES SLOWING PHONE DEREGULATION
description: Unfilled orders for business telephone installations grew 16% in June, A.T.&T. said. Page D6.

title: Poland's Coal Exports Strong
description: Poland has exported more than 23 million metric tons of coal so far this year, which if sustained will make 1984 a record year for coal sales abroad, the official P.A.P. press agency said today. The agency said 14.5 million metric tons had been sold to buyers paying in hard currency.

title: CONCERT: A FESTIVAL OF MOZART
description: They go together like peaches and cream, like moon and June, like the Fourth and fireworks. By now, as Mostly Mozart enters its 18th summer, it is difficult to think of the festival without thinking of Alicia de Larrocha. So, what could be more apt than that the Spanish pianist should be the soloist on the opening program of the season at Avery Fisher Hall? Miss de Larrocha, in splendid form as usual, appeared last night in Mozart's ''Coronation'' Concerto, a work that is really not out of the composer's top drawer but sounded surprisingly rich and solid in her poised performance.

title: PRESIDENT FINDS NO EVIDENCE JACKSON BROKE LAW IN CUBA
description: President Reagan, modifying his criticism last week of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, said today that he did not think there was any evidence that Mr. Jackson had violated the law by traveling to Cuba and helping to arrange the release of Cuban and American prisoners.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The U.N. Today July 10, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SCHOOL SECURITY DIRECTORS CONFER ON CRIME, GANGS AND LEGAL ISSUES
description: Security officials from 200 schools around the country gathered at the World Trade Center yesterday, greeting old friends, shopping for uniforms and exchanging views on safety.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Senator Tower to Teach At Southern Methodist
description: Senator John Tower, retiring from the Senate after four terms, said today that he would become a distinguished lecturer at Southern Methodist University, but he did not rule out a return to Government service.

title: BRIEFING
description: NCPAC Loves Reagan

title: C. Conrad Schneider Is Dead; FormerBergenCountyJudge
description: C. Conrad Schneider, a former Bergen County judge in New Jersey and the founder of the Bergen County Community Blood Bank, died of a heart ailment Thursday at his home in Hackensack, N.J. He was 76 years old.

title: A NEW YORK PROGRAM IN RELIGIOUS SCHOOLS IS RULED TO BE ILLEGAL
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that a New York City program that sends public school teachers into religious schools to provide remedial instruction was unconstitutional.

title: Europe Electronic Data
description: Revenues of the European electronic data industry totaled $700 million last year, up from 1982's $532 million, Business International S.A. estimated today. It predicted growth of 25 to 30 percent a year, compared with 23 percent expected for the American industry.

title: Debt Issues
description: Alberta Municipal Financing Corp. , a Crown corporation that provides financing to municipalities in Alberta and British Columbia, has begun a $150 million (Canadian) five-year debenture offering through Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. The 13.5 percent debentures due 1989 were priced at 99 1/4 to yield 13.71 percent.

title: AT YORK'S CATHEDRAL, WINDOWS ARE CHIEF GLORY
description: York Minster, England's largest medieval cathedral and formally known as the Cathedral Church of St. Peter, can trace its origins to a simple wooden church founded in 627 by Edwin, the Anglo-Saxon warrior king of Northumbria.

title: MUCH ACTIVITY IN MCA STOCK
description: ON a typical day on the New York Stock Exchange, trading volume in MCA stock is 100,000 shares. Since January, however, volume in MCA, one of the nation's leading entertainment companies, has consistently been so much higher than that as to suggest that someone has been accumulating the stock.

title: SCHOOLS DEBATE UPSETS TEACHERS
description: MINNEAPOLISIn sponsoring the report ''A Nation at Risk,'' the

title: A UNITED STATES VICE PRESIDENT'S IMPORTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVE FOR VOTERS ORDERED BY CUOMO
description: New York State employees will conduct drives in motor vehicle offices, unemployment lines and social service offices to register voters in time for the November elections, under an executive order signed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: GREECE ACCUSES U.S. OF INTERFERENCE AND WARNS ON MILITARY BASES
description: The Greek Government accused the United States today of interfering in its domestic affairs and of seeking to strengthen Turkey at the expense of Greece.

title: CABLE TV LEGISLATION THAT UNDERCUTS CITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: HARSH CHARGES AGAINST COMPUTERS
description: Education by computer may create a ''a culture of psychopaths.'' Teaching young children via computer will impoverish their imagination. Turning high school students into programmers prepares them for a meager job market.

title: James Bond Car Is Sold For $80,000 at Auction
description: James Bond's Aston Martin, minus the machine guns and ejector seat, has been sold at auction for $80,000.

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLACK DEMOCRATS IN A POLL PREFER MONDALE TO JACKSON AS NOMINEE
description: President Reagan said he did not think the Rev. Jesse Jackson violated the law in arranging for release of prisoners in Cuba. Page A16.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain on refinancing of $332,699.

title: Bridge: Crowded Bidding May Yield Clue When Slam Is at Stake
description: In general, a crowded auction makes slam bidding more difficult, but it can provide a useful clue. On the diagramed deal played recently in Salzburg, Austria, the East-West bidding permitted North to diagnose spade shortage in the South hand and continue to six clubs.

title: LEA AND STEIB NAMED ALL-STARS STARTERS
description: Canada won the first honors today when Charlie Lea of the Montreal Expos and Dave Stieb of the Toronto Blue Jays were named the starting pitchers for baseball's 55th All-Star Game.

title: JACKSON'S HISTORIC CAMPAIGN
description: Having worked in the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign for nearly a year now, I have become accustomed to the contradictory responses that our candidate has evoked. Most people are aware that Mr. Jackson has been making news - by what he has done and said, and even by what he has not done or said (for example, his trips to Syria and Cuba and the attendant release of prisoners; his insensitive reference to Jews; his unwillingness, after condemning Louis Farrakhan's greviously anti-Semitic statements, to say more). But most people have failed to notice that while Mr. Jackson has been making news he is also making history.

title: INVENTOR'S GOAL: ARTIFICIAL GILLS FOR PEOPLE
description: Artificial gills for humans, a dream of swimmers from time immemorial, seem to be on the horizon.

title: Thrift Units' Deal
description: The Fortune Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Florida Federal Savings and Loan Association said they had signed a letter of intent for Florida Federal to acquire six Fortune Federal branch offices.

title: 2 LILCO UNIONS, FACING CUTS IN PAY FOR 3,900 WORKERS, SET STRIKE FOR TODAY
description: Two unions representing 3,900 employees of the Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday that they would begin a strike at 4 P.M. today.

title: ADVERTISING ; Health-Care SpecialistOpens His Own Shop
description: After working for four advertising agencies in the health-care field, William Mecca, age 40, last week struck out on his own with Mecca Communications in Suite 1201 at 60 Madison Avenue.

title: BLACKS PRESS FOR CONTROL IN SELMA ELECTION TODAY
description: A deep- voiced refrain of ''Freedom Now! Freedom Now!'' rose in a crescendo from Ward Chapel Church Sunday night, seeming to ripple the delicate pink flowers of the mimosa trees outside.

title: CHINA, AFTER TALKS IN SOVIET, SAYS HALCYON DAYS ARE GONE
description: The official Beijing Review charged today that the Soviet Union still wanted to control China and warned that it was ''unrealistic and impossible'' to return to the relationship of the 1950's.

title: A Sweet 16
description: Susan Looney was exceptionally happy last week after she had driven One for All, a 3-year-old pacer, to victory at the Meadowlands. The triumph made the 16-year-old the youngest driver to win a parimutuel event in New Jersey, which last month lowered the minimum age for parimutuel competitors from 18 to 16.

title: Shiras Advances In Grass Tennis
description: Leif Shiras of Milwaukee defeated Greg Holmes of Danville, Calif., 6-4, 6-4, today in the first round of the Miller Hall of Fame grass-court tennis tournament.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Results are for 13 weeks to the latest period and 14 weeks for the year- ago period.

title: 67,596 SEE OLYMPIANS IN HOOSIER DOME
description: The feeling did not occur to Cheryl Miller right away. It has come a little bit at a time as the United States women's Olympic basketball team has prepared to compete for the gold medal it is now favored to win.

title: Variable Notes Planned by Mesa
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of $300 million worth of principal amount of subordinated exchangeable variable-rate notes.

title: Detroit Bonds
description: The City of Detroit said yesterday that the Detroit Tax Increment Finance Authority would be asked to issue today $60 million worth of tax increment bonds. The city said the bonds would be used to pay a major portion of the debt owed to the Federal Government for Detroit's central industrial park. A spokesman for the city said that the bonds would be funded by tax revenues generated within the park.

title: ST. REGIS SAYS MURDOCH LINES UP FUNDS FOR BID
description: The St. Regis Corporation said yesterday that while Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher, was saying publicly that he had ''no present intention'' of trying to take over the company, he was secretly negotiating with a group of banks, including the Midland Bank of London, to raise $750 million for a possible acquisition of the big forest products company.

title: Reagan Gives Citizen's Medal To U.S. Aide Slain in Namibia
description: President Reagan today awarded the Presidential Citizen's Medal posthumously to Dennis W. Keogh, a foreign service officer who was killed in a bomb explosion in Namibia in April.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, JULY 10, 1984

title: Required Reading; ;  Oh, West Virginia
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, in remarks to the Senate, June 20:

title: COMPOSED WORKS FOR CHORUS
description: Randall Thompson, a composer, conductor and teacher known for choral works that evoke a folksy, patriotic vision of American history and heritage, died yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old.

title: DO DREAMS REALLY CONTAIN IMPORTANT SECRET MEANING?
description: Ever since Freud first proposed that dreams were the ''royal road to the unconscious,'' it has been standard clinical practice to assume that dreams bear meaningful psychological messages, though often in bizarre disguise.

title: PHONE INSTALLATION BACKLOG GROWS 16%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that, despite emergency efforts to relieve a huge backlog in phone installations for businesses, unfilled orders grew more than 16 percent last month.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $270,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of a franchise.

title: Ex-G.&W. TreasurerAppointed at Hi-Shear
description: Norman R. Forson, a former senior vice president and treasurer of Gulf and Western Industries, has been named senior vice president, treasurer and chief financial officer of Hi- Shear Industries, a producer of fasteners and advanced technology systems for the aerospace industry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We intend to restore it.'' - Canon Ralph Mayland of the cathedral of York Minster. (A1:1.)

title: AMF, Reltron
description: The Reltron Corporation said it had signed a contract to acquire certain assets - principally inventory and fixed assets - of the Voit and Whitely divisions of AMF Inc. Reltron, a Rochester-based maker of sporting goods and operator of bowling centers, said it had obtained a license to use the AMF trademark in conjunction with the purchase of the Voit and Whitely product lines.

title:
PLAYS;
SHORT GAME BRINGS WATSON LONG WAY
description: Connell ''I've had confidence in my short game this year,'' Tom Watson said Sunday after winning his third Western Open title, ''while my long game has been a struggle all year.''

title: No Headline
description: Teamster Local Settles Western Union Strike

title: Telesis Vice President To Head Racal-Redac
description: Racal Electronics P.L.C. of London yesterday named Gene Robinson president of its United States subsidiary, Racal-Redac Inc. of Westford, Mass. Mr. Robinson, 41, had been a marketing and sales vice president of the Telesis Systems Corporation of Chelmsford, Mass.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Summer in the City

title: 'PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS'
description: ''The Pursuit of Happiness'' isan ambitious attempt to show how six people exercise one of the ''unalienable rights'' mentioned in the Declaration of Independence. The six - a Roman Catholic peace activist and her husband, the warden of a prison and his wife, and two prison inmates - pursue, or at least try to pursue, happiness. The cinema verite documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Q & A
description: Q.

title: Boesky Reports Stock Purchases
description: A group controlled by Ivan Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds stakes in Continental Group Inc. and SCA Services Inc. The group said it had acquired 3.3 million common shares of Continental, or 7.7 percent of the total outstanding. The group said that it had bought the shares recently for investment purposes and that it had paid about $162.2 million for them.

title: Funds Sought For E.E.C.
description: The European Economic Community Commission asked the trade bloc's 10 member nations today for extra emergency funds to fend off bankruptcy.

title: SHUFFLING THE DECK FOR A SECOND TERM
description: ''You've gotta start at the top, with who is going to replace Jim Baker as chief of staff,'' a key Administration official said, rising to the question of who will get the plum jobs in a possible second Reagan Administration.

title: MALAYSIA, SEEING A THREAT, URGES U.S. TO STOP BUILDING UP POWER OF CHINA
description: Malaysia's Prime Minister told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that the United States was unwittingly endangering the security of Southeast Asian countries by its enthusiastic support for China's program of economic modernization.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; 1982 U.S. Abortion Total Shows Small Decline By United Press International
description: Abortions in the United States decreased by 3,400 cases in 1982, the first annual decline since the Supreme Court legalized abortion in 1973, a research group said yesterday.

title: Jersey Police Sued On Retirement
description: The Federal Government sued the New Jersey state police today to win reinstatement and back pay for six troopers who were forced to retire at age 55 under a law the state had been warned was unconstitutional.

title: FALSE IDENTITY EASY FOR ALIENS TO BUY
description: Eighteen-year- old Hector Z., a quiet man with a shy smile, says he was born in the United States, in Rio Grande City.

title: A UNITED STATES VICE PRESIDENT'S IMPORTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: -ASHBURY. A History. By

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
Latin Arms Shipments By C.I.A. Are Reported
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is using small private airlines to fly guns and other military supplies to United States-backed forces in Central America, and false flight plans are sometimes filed to cover up the shipments, CBS News reported Sunday night.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Coast Prosecutor Argues Convicted Man Was Sane
description: Marvin Pancoast was legally sane when he murdered Vicki Morgan, the mistress of Alfred Bloomingdale, a department store heir, according to a prosecutor's argument today to the jurors who convicted the former talent agency clerk last week.

title: CHESAPEAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
Citibank Gives Business To Penchina, Selkowitz
description: The word is out that Penchina, Selkowitz Inc. has joined Citibank's agency lineup.

title: A Defense Against the Trump Tax
description: Because existing law demands it, the New York State Court of Appeals has again ruled that affluent Donald Trump, no matter how needy everyone else, must be given a $50 million real estate tax abatement on the luxurious tower he's built on Fifth Avenue. Perhaps offsetting this annoying loss will be the study of all realty taxes that the Legislature has finally ordered. For the ultimate way to avoid unnecessary or unseemly incentive payments is a system that taxes land at higher rates than improvements on the land.

title: Playland Ride Shut After Accident
description: An accident on one of the new rides at Playland Amusement Park injured six people Sunday night, and the ride was shut down indefinitely today while state and park officials tried to determine the cause.

title: U.S. BOARD STUDYING DERAILMENT QUESTIONS PROCEDURES OF RAILWAY
description: Federal safety officials today questioned whether the Central Vermont Railway had taken adequate precaution in the early morning hours before a passenger train derailed Saturday, killing five people and injuring more than 140.

title: VIDEODISK FOR NATIONAL GALLERY'S ART
description: A generation ago, Andre Malraux, the French critic, novelist and sometime adventurer, commented on the accessibility of great paintings through reproductions. Printing techniques had reached new levels of refinement at the time, and to Malraux a well-crafted art book was a ''Museum Without Walls.'' What might he have said of the latest video venture, which presents virtually all the major paintings at the National Gallery in Washington on a single videodisk?

title: No Headline
description: Minnesota's Hospitals Reopening After Strike

title: Needham, Harper GetsCampaign for Sandoz
description: Needham, Harper & Steers/New York has been named to do the first domestic corporate advertising campaign for Sandoz Inc. of East Hanover, N.J.

title: PROTEST CAMP: FRON CONFLICT TO COMMUNE
description: Last summer, more than 1,000 women from as far away as Europe gathered at the new Women's Peace Encampment near here to protest the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Cowboy Ultimatum
description: Gary Hogeboom of the Dallas Cowboys, the No. 2 quarterback who wants to be No. 1, has told Coach Tom Landry that his willingness to wait for a chance at the starting position will expire Aug. 14. That is the day the Cowboys break training camp, and before then Landry will choose between Hogeboom, who has performed brilliantly when given playing time, and Danny White, the incumbent starter.

title: SUMMER: MAKING FASHION FUN
description: It's summer, which means that most of us would rather be on a beach applying layers of suntan oil while someone, preferably a stranger, brings us iced drinks. We'd rather be gardening or, better still, watching someone do the gardening while we give good-natured suggestions about the proper mulch for Queen Elizabeth roses (wood shavings and peanut shells). Or even dancing a few slow steps on a terrace.

title: ANGLICANS PLAN TO RESTORE CATHEDRAL AT YORK
description: A fire early this morning severely damaged the ancient cathedral of York Minster, particularly its 13th-century south transept, but authorities said damaged areas would be restored and expressed relief that treasures elsewhere in the church had been spared.

title: Addendum
description: * Hill & Knowlton has acquired Hetu & Lukstat, a Washington, D.C., public relations firm.

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'JULIO WHO' CLOSES GAP
description: Gloria VAnderbilt plays his tapes driving to the Hamptons. Diane Keaton listens to him on a Walkman. Judy Green thinks he's in a league with Yves Montand or Rod McKuen. Lydia Biddle says he reminds her of ''a more sophisticated John Davidson.'' Barbara Sinatra and Nancy Reagan are fans. Princess Stephanie of Monaco raves about him. Regine, the disco queen, has him to dinner.

title: New Nasdaq Indexes
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is scheduled to introduce two indexes today based on the stocks in its National Market System.

title: Suspect Arraigned In Mass Slaying
description: In a 60-second arraignment in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday, a 34-year-old Bronx man pleaded not guilty to an indictment accusing him of shooting and killing 10 people, including eight children, in a Brooklyn apartment last April 15.

title: $11 Million Pact In Birth-Care Suit
description: A 6-year-old Queens boy who suffered brain damage at birth was given an $11 million damage settlement before a trial was to start yesterday in State Supreme Court in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Mozambican Guerrillas Report Military Gains
description: Right- wing Mozambican rebels said they killed 143 Government soldiers, wounded 119 and captured 37 in operations between June 22 and 30.

title: GUATEMALANS IN MEXICO: NOT WHERE THE HEART IS
description: Horacio Perez and his family arrived here today to settle reluctantly into their second home in as many years.

title: CBS TO HALT MAKING OF VIDEODISKS
description: The videodisk industry received more bad news yesterday as CBS Inc. announced that it would stop making its sound-and-picture records because of diminishing consumer demand and growing orders for conventional records and cassettes.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, George Vecsey's column in some copies of SportsMonday yesterday omitted the last part of a quotation from Carl Hubbell. The last two sentences of the quotation should have read: ''Knowing that, I pitched accordingly. The screwball did the rest.''

title: NONSTOP ATLANTIC RUNS BY TWIN JETS WEIGHED
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is circulating a proposal that would permit two-engine airliners to begin scheduled nonstop service across the Atlantic by next summer's travel season.

title: SYNDROMES THAT AGE THE YOUNG ARE STUDIED FOR CLUES TO AID THE OLD
description: Cockayne's syndrome is a rare, incurable, hereditary disorder that, like progeria and Werner's syndrome, is believed to caricature the aging phenomenon.

title: Outlaws Plan Move Within Oklahoma
description: The Oklahoma Outlaws are looking for a new home, one not too far away.

title: Town Clears Wreckage Of Bob Dylan Rioters
description: Villagers cleared the wreckage today after rioting by young people attending a Bob Dylan concert Sunday afternoon at an ancient battle site.

title: DON'T HELP GUATEMALA
description: Guatemala may not, as its Foreign Minister claimed last week, be interested in a renewal of United States military aid. That is all to the good, but Washington must be careful not to make too much of either that rejection or the elections held last week. Neither should be seen as conclusive evidence of the Guatemalan military's commitment to democracy.

title: TGC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $826,367 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Bank Links Set in North Carolina
description: North Carolina has become the fourth state in the Southeast to enact a law allowing bank mergers in any emerging interstate banking region.

title: Hold the Toasts to Nuclear Trade
description: The Administration is having welcome second thoughts about the agreement on nuclear trade that was initialed and toasted by Mr. Reagan in China last April. It is delaying submission of the agreement to Congress while seeking further assurances from Peking. If there's to be any serious prospect of slowing the spread of nuclear weapons around the world, Congress needs to insist that the agreement with China be a model, not a mockery, of safe nuclear trade.

title: Whitney Show Postponed
description: ''The Feminine Gaze: Women Depicted by Women, 1900-30'' will not open at the Whitney Downtown Museum today as scheduled. A spokesman for the museum, at 26 Wall Street, said that the air-conditioning system was not working and that it was not possible to give a date for the show's opening.

title: CLAUDIO SANCHEZ ALBORNOZ, A FOE OF FRANCO
description: Claudio Sanchez Albornoz, a Spanish historian and politician who became a principal leader of anti-Franco Republicans in exile, died Sunday after a heart attack in Avila, Spain, where he had been undergoing treatment at a clinic for a respiratory ailment. He was 91 years old.

title: NASA Supplier Sentenced
description: George Thomas Straza, the president of Jet Air Inc., which illegally subcontracted work on National Aeronautic and Space Administration projects, was sentenced to six months in prison today. He could have received a maximum of five years in prison and a $10,000 fine. Under a plea bargain, Mr. Straza agreed to pay NASA $690,000 plus interest over five years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hot Dogs and Art

title: FALCONS ACHIEVE SURPRISING RECOVERY IN THE EAST
description: Twenty-one pairs of peregrine falcons have been sighted at nesting sites in the Eastern United States this spring, and 18 of the pairs have already produced eggs, the Peregrine Fund at Cornell University has reported.

title: LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $849,000 for the quarter and $1,169,000 for the 6 months.

title: PETER HURD, PAINTER OF SOUTHWEST
description: Peter Hurd, an American artist whose dramatic portraits of southwest America have appeared in galleries, public buildings, museums and popular magazines for nearly a half-century, died yesterday from complications of pneumonia at St. Mary's Hospital in Roswell, N.M. He was 80 years old.

title: BROAD GAINS ARE REPORTED IN RESEARCH ON HERPES
description: Scientists are making steady progress in a wide range of studies designed to cope with genital herpes, an incurable sexually transmitted disease that has already afflicted millions of Americans and is claiming several hundred thousand new victims each year.

title: FUGITIVE IN 5 PRISON DEATHS SURRENDERS AFTER 13 YEARS
description: Stephen M. Bingham, a member of a prominent Connecticut family, surrendered to the authorities today, ending 13 years of flight from prosecution on five murder charges stemming from an escape attempt by a black militant at a California prison.

title: New Zealand Prices Up
description: New Zealand's consumer price index rose 2.2 percent in the second quarter, the Government said today, for the first full quarter since a 20-month price freeze ended March 1.

title: Yugoslav Court Convicts A University Lecturer
description: A district court today convicted a suspended university lecturer of counterrevolutionary activities and sentenced him to eight years in prison.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Cab Encounter

title: Jersey's Law Office Takes Over Boxing
description: A deputy attorney general has taken over the day-to-day operations of the State Athletic Commission as Federal and state investigators study the New Jersey boxing industry and the conduct of the acting head of the commission, officials said today.

title: SHAMIR WOULD SEEK COALITION WITH LABOR PARTY IF ELECTED
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that if his Likud bloc won the elections on July 23, he would try to form a national unity government with the opposition Labor Party to deal with economic problems.

title: Moody's Lowers Suffolk Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Services Inc. yesterday revised downward, to BAA from BAA-1, its rating of a current issue of $276 million worth of Suffolk County general obligation refunding serial bonds.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $20,199 for the quarter and $119,500 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $90,000.

title: COONEY COMEBACK STOPPED BY INJURY
description: Gerry Cooney's comeback fight, which had been scheduled for Dallas 10 days from now, was postponed indefinitely yesterday because of rotator-cuff damage in his left shoulder.

title: Smith Extends Gearhart Deadline
description: Smith International Inc. said it is extending to July 20 the expiration date and proration period for its $31-a-share offer for 3.7 million shares of Gearhart Industries. Smith also said that as of Friday approximately 7 million Gearhart shares had been tendered and not withdrawn.

title: Court Decision On Air Florida MIAMI, July 9 - A Federal
description: Bankruptcy Court here has decided to allow Air Florida,

title: Bank Rules in Australia
description: The Government set strict rules today in allowing foreign banks to operate in Australia. They must stimulate Australian industry, and 50 percent Australian ownership of the banking units will be sought.

title: Jockey Badly Hurt
description: Patti Barton Brown, one of the nation's top female jockeys, is in serious condition at a hospital in Belleville, Ill., because of numerous injuries suffered during a pileup at Fairmount Park on Sunday. The 39-year-old Mrs. Brown was hurt when she was thrown from her mount, All Chrome, and then trampled by trailing horses. According to Jack Weaver, the track's general manager, Mrs. Brown suffered a slight brain hemorrhage, broke her clavicle and right wrist and was bruised on her face and neck. Mrs. Brown and her 20-year-old daughter, Leah Barton, make up thoroughbred racing's first mother- daugher jockey tandem, and her 17- year-old son, Jerry, is an apprentice at Louisiana Downs.

title: Burroughs Project
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it would invest as much as $40 million in a new headquarters building here. The 250,000-square-foot building is scheduled for completion in 1987, the maker of data-processing systems said. The project is contingent on Federal approval for financing assistance and general improvements in the area, such as upgrading of streets and utility connections, Burroughs said.

title: GUATEMALA UNIONS WATCH PLANT FEUD
description: A bitter labor confrontation at the Coca-Cola plant here, which has dragged on for six years and is believed to have resulted in the death of several union organizers, may be close to a settlement, according to officials on both sides.

title: ENVOY'S PLEA WAS OPPOSED
description: Senior Justice Department officials attempted to stop William A. Wilson, the United States representative to the Vatican, from intervening with the Attorney General in 1982 on behalf of Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the Vatican banker, according to a source familiar with the case.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $179,700 for the latest quarter and $67,000 for the year-ago quarter.

title: One More Season
description: Rocky Washington, a wide receiver whose 4.36-second speed in the 40- yard dash enabled him to make the Penn State football team as a walk-on two years ago, has received a favorable ruling on his appeal filed with the National Collegiate Athletic Association and will be allowed to play this season. The reversal does away with the need for a Federal suit that Washington filed against the N.C.A.A. after the association had originally ruled against him.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Ms.' as an Option

title: FLORIDA FARES CUT BY EASTERN
description: Eastern Airlines touched off a fare war yesterday among major carriers in the New York-Florida market.

title: OPERA: PUCCINI-ALFANO 'TURANDOT'
description: Last season, the New York City Opera took Beni Montresor's 1975 production of ''Turandot'' and added to it - in its entirety - the ending Puccini never lived to write.

title: INCREASE IN COST OF HEALTH CARE DROPS TO 6.3%
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that the rate of increase in the cost of health care had slowed dramatically. She asserted that the Reagan Administration deserved credit for the change.

title: PENTAGON HALTING SPARE PARTS SALES
description: The Defense Department disclosed today that the military services had been ordered to stop getting rid of supposedly excess spare parts and other material until flaws in the disposal system were corrected.

title: GIRARD COMMENTS WITH WIT
description: Jerry Girard on the evening news on WPIX (Channel 11)

title: MONDALE HAS PRAISE FOR MRS. FERRARO
description: Walter F. Mondale warmly praised Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro today and denied that he had been disappointed after interviewing the Queens Democrat as a potential running mate.

title: Emery And B.& B. Separate
description: Emery Worldwide, the freight shipper based in Winton, Conn., confirmed yesterday that it had split with its agency of three years, Benton & Bowles.

title: HELIX CIRCUITS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FEW VISIT JERSEY BEACH OPENED IN ACCESS CASE
description: The soupy, clammy weather of summer has departed. The sun was brilliant, the sky was deep blue, and the beach on the Atlantic glistened and beckoned today.

title: Music Director Retires At Dancer Fitzgerald
description: Arnold Brown has been involved in the selection of some of the century's most-often-heard melodies as music director for Dancer Fitzgerald Sample since 1967.

title: 2d Body Is Found After Plane Crash
description: Divers today found the body of a passenger of a small plane that crashed Sunday into Gardiners Bay, the police said. They said the body of the pilot, the only other person aboard, had been recovered Sunday night.

title: Nielsen Says Cable TV Is in 42.5% of Homes
description: Using three systems of compilation, the counters at the A. C. Nielsen Company have come up with household penetration statistics for cable television in May.

title: SPACE ARMS: DEBATE OVER VALUE OF A TREATY
description: A dispute within the Reagan Administration over whether an antisatellite weapons pact with the Soviet Union can be verified appears to be clouded by two factors: the parties to the argument within the Government are talking about different kinds of treaties, and they are governed by different motives.

title: S.E.C. Weighs Foreign Rule
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking comment on tightening the regulation of foreign investments made in United States securities markets, John S. R. Shad, chairman of the commission, said yesterday.

title: A WASTEFUL DIVISION OF POLICE SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Kill 2 Workers In Clash Outside Manila
description: Riot policemen firing automatic rifles and pistols today battled striking factory workers armed with darts, rocks and clubs.

title: E.P.A. HANDLING OF TOXIC CHEMICALS IS CRITICIZED
description: The public is inadequately protected from the dangers of hazardous chemicals as the law on toxic substances is now administered by the Environmental Protection Agency, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: GETTING TELEPORT ON TRACK
description: After repeated delays, project officials say that construction is proceeding on the Staten Island Teleport, a $200 million satellite communications center under joint development by the City of New York and private business.

title: NEW YORK AND PEKING TO EXPAND TRADE TIES
description: A New York City delegation signed a memorandum of understanding with Peking officials Sunday designed to promote greater commercial, educational and cultural ties between the two cities.

title: DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RUTGERS PLAN TO LEASE VACANT LAND TO BUILDERS STIRS OPPOSITION
description: Some students and teachers at Cook College of Rutgers University are upset about plans by the university to lease to developers two tracts of university land.

title: School District 15 Criticized by State
description: A Brooklyn school district did not effectively use the 1,000 teachers in its 25 elementary and junior high schools, according to a state audit released yesterday.

title: 2 Explosive Traps Found
description: The Authorities investigating after an anonymous tip over the weekend found two explosive poison-loaded animal traps near campgrounds along the Boulder River, bringing to five the number of such traps discovered. Officials have posted signs warning that the area in southwest Montana may hold more of the illegal traps, which they say contain enough cyanide to kill a human in five minutes.

title: A Surplus for Sweden
description: Sweden's current account posted a $362 million surplus in the first quarter, swinging from a $205 million deficit in the first quarter of 1983, the central bank said today. The current account measures a nation's international trade in merchandise and services, such as tourism and shipping.

title: Dailey Office To Marschalk
description: umbrella of the Interpublic

title: TUESDAY, JULY 10, 1984 International
description: A general strike in Beirut and protests by families of kidnapped Lebanese paralyzed the capital and forced the closing of the city's international airport a few hours after it had been reopened. (Page A1, Column 6.) A national unity government in Israel would be formed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir if his Likud bloc won the July 23 elections. Mr. Shamir said he would try to form a coalition with the opposition Labor Party in order to deal with Israel's mounting economic problems. (A4:1.)

title: Killer of 2 Is Guilty Of 3 More Slayings
description: A man who is serving 200 years for the murders of two women in New Jersey was convicted yesterday in New York of killing three more women, whose mutilated bodies were found in Manhattan hotels.

title: A PROFIT OF $24 MILLION REPORTED AT CATERPILLAR
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, after posting seven consecutive quarterly losses, reported yesterday that it had a second-quarter profit of $24 million, or 25 cents a share. The company, the nation's largest maker of earth-moving machinery and equipment, lost $92 million in last year's second quarter and suffered a loss of $109 million in the first three months of this year.

title: Olympians Wi
description: The United States Olympic baseball team opened a series against a team of college stars from Japan with an 8-0 victory today in Candlestick Park.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: The weather wouldn't cooperate.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORP (MET LEBANON, PA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: A television review yesterday of ''The Jesse Owens Story,'' on Channel 11, misidentified the movie segment to be shown tomorrow. Part I of the four-hour movie, first shown yesterday, will be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Part 2 will be shown Monday at 8 and repeated July 18 at 8.

title: AT THE FRONT, IRAQIS ADAPT TO THE WAR
description: This port city, near the front lines of the Persian Gulf war, is up to its ears in sandbags.

title: DANCE: ALVIN AILEY OPENS SEASON
description: It was the high-kicking, high-

title: Jersey's Workers Get 1.5% Pay Raise
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today that gives more than 60,000 state workers a 1.5 percent increase in their salaries, a total of $18 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: NO NOH, KYOGEN Americans have come to know noh, the traditional Japanese drama form, but few have made the acquaintance of kyogen, another aspect of Japanese stagecraft, one whose forte is comedy. The Nomura Kyogen Theater is about to make the New York scene, playing tonight through Friday at 8:30 o'clock in free, outdoor torchlight performance in Lincoln Center's North Plaza, before moving indoors for five days at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street.

title: HONG KONG'S SHARED FACTORIES
description: The banner must seem a little strange to the 200 Chinese who work beneath it every day in the cramped factory housed in a building that looks more like an apartment house than a manufacturing center.

title: Southwest Forest Questions Deal
description: Southwest Forest Industries said it intends to terminate discussions with the Jefferson Smurfit Group Ltd. on its purchase of Southwest unless certain questions about Jefferson Smurfit's financing arrangements are satisfactorily answered.

title: BETTER DAYS FOR ALL-STAR
description: ''To put it bluntly, it's probably the worst exhibition of pitching you'll ever see. And I couldn't have picked a worse spot for it, either. My first All-Star Game, and in front of all these people. I have no excuses.''

title: Segura's Niche
description: Pancho Segura, who began playing tennis at age 7 in Guayaquil, Ecuador, and taught himself the game until he entered the University of Miami at 18, will be among five inductees joining the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I., on Saturday.

title: WHEN CABS ARE RARE, TRAVELERS SUMMON THEIR INGENUITY
description: Facing the bank of bumpers and windshields at a red light on Fifth Avenue, Jeff Van Order searched the horizon for an empty cab.

title: BRITAIN WANTS TO QUERY NIGERIA ENVOYS
description: Britain asked Nigeria today to allow its diplomats in London to be questioned by the police about the kidnapping of a wealthy Nigerian exile politician. There was no immediate reply.

title: REAGAN ISN'T TOO OLD FOR A SECOND TERM
description: To the Editor:

title: BONDS POST BEST GAINS OF THE YEAR
description: Bond prices posted their best daily advance yesterday since the start of the year, as a number of factors contributed to a shift in market psychology and turned sellers into buyers.

title: METS IN MOVES TO BOLSTER DRIVE
description: The Mets made a series of moves yesterday to ''fine-tune'' them for the second-half pennant race, and in the process cleared the way for the delayed debut of Sid Fernandez as the newest rookie on their pitching staff.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ; Gold Recovers in U.S.,Halting 4-Day Slump
description: Gold prices recovered strongly yesterday, ending a four-day slump that saw bullion at its lowest level in two years, as the dollar hit new highs against European currencies.

title: A Real Grabber Hayward (Calif.) State, whose athletic teams now are called the Pioneers, is considering a nickname that will grab the fans by the throat: the Vampires. ''We'd be going from the comatose, nondescript Pioneers to an active, aggressive mammal that strikes fear into the heart,'' said
description: Dennis Lavery, the university's public relations director. ''We tried to think up something native to Hayward, but all we could think of was Zucchinis.'' Lavery said he hoped the new name could be approved in time to order capes for the basketball season.

title: SHOOTING THE BREEZE AT CANDLESTICK
description: SAN FRANCISCO All this talk about the wind at Candlestick

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Sallie Mae Sets Price Of Floating Notes at Par
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association announced that it had priced $200 million worth of floating-rate notes yesterday.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Utah Governor Says He Has a Cabinet Offer
description: Gov. Scott Matheson of Utah said today that he had been promised a Cabinet post if Walter F. Mondale won the Presidency and that he had decided to support Mr. Mondale for the nomination.

title: PRODUCTION PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT FOX STUDIOS
description: Twentieth Century-Fox studios has lost its second head of production in the last 18 months. Joe Wizan, president of 20th Century-Fox Productions, resigned today and will be replaced by Lawrence Gordon, the producer of such movies as ''48 Hours,'' ''Xanadu,'' ''Streets of Fire,'' ''Paternity'' and ''Hooper.''

title: 9 Hurt by Pamplona Bulls
description: Nine men suffered minor injuries today on the third day of the running of the bulls here, the police reported. The bulls' charge from the corrals to the bullfighting ring is part of the festival of San Fermin, which began Saturday.

title: MR. MONDALE'S CHANCE
description: Who says Walter Mondale can't win? Virtually everyone, it seems. But little is certain in politics, as Harry Truman fans can testify, and in a Presidential campaign the cliche just happens to be true: Anything can happen.

title: USA Today Price Rise
description: The Gannett Company said today that it would raise the price of USA Today to 35 cents, from 25 cents for single copies. It also said the weekly subscription rate for delivered papers would rise to $1.75, from $1.50. The changes take effect Aug. 27.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Manhattanite Bikes Into Games
description: Nelson Vails, a self-described ''bicycle nut'' who gave up three- wheelers for a two-wheel bicycle when he was 6 years old and living on West 115th Street in Manhattan, took a long step toward his drive for an Olympic medal over the weekend when he qualified for the United States cycling team. At Los Angeles, the 23-year-old gold medal winner in last year's Pan American Games will race in the individual 1,000-meter sprint.

title: PHYSICISTS PRODUCE NEW ELEMENT
description: Researchers in West Germany have for the first time produced element 108, according to The CERN Courier, the journal of the European Laboratory for Particle Physics in Geneva.

title: PRIESTS IN NICARAGUA PROTEST
description: The Archbishop of Managua led Roman Catholic priests in a church- sponsored protest march today to show support for a priest accused by the leftist Government of aiding rebels.

title: SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE SPREAD SHEET MOVES INTO THE EXECUTIVE SUITE
description: One of the more intriguing events in the rapidly changing field of personal computerization is the evolution of whole new categories of software. Only a few years ago, for example, there were no such things as computerized spread sheets, though it seems hard to believe now.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Heart Disease Deaths Found Lower in West
description: Heart disease remains the nation's leading killer, but people who live in the Western United States are least likely to die of it, according to a study released yesterday.

title: President Seeking Rest of Guardian
description: The president and chief executive of Guardian Industries said yesterday that he intended to offer $24 a share to acquire the remainder of the company's stock. William Davidson already owns 42.4 percent of the company's approximately 22.1 million shares outstanding.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture Saturday, identified by United Press International as that of Umaru Dikko, a kidnapped former Nigerian official in London, was incorrect. It showed his brother Yahaya Dikko, a former Nigerian oil minister.

title: EXERCISE PRESCRIPTIONS FROM 'DR, SPORT'
description: O.K., so they called you a klutz back in the sixth grade when the softball kept rolling between your legs. You were not a ''natural athlete,'' they said, and you were always one of the last ones chosen for every team. Discouraged, you eventually gave up sports.

title: S-P DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
ONE TIMES SQUARE, ITS FUTURE UNSURE, IS SOLD AGAIN
description: While planners and developers debate the future of the odd, 26-story tower at the heart of the $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project, the building, from which the New Year's Eve ball has been dropped since 1907, has been sold again.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
CORRECTION
description: A music review on Monday, on the duo that appeared Friday at the Bottom Line, misidentified a member. He was Sam Daniels.

title: ARCHDIOCESE CLARIFIES STORY ON O'CONNER AND POPE
description: The Archdiocese of New York said yesterday that, contrary to the impression given by a report in its own newspaper last week, Pope John Paul II has not endorsed Archbishop John J. O'Connor's refusal to sign a pledge required under a city order barring job discrimination against homosexuals.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Total income figures for the latest periods include land sales of $153,000 for the quarter and $1,649,846 for the 6 months and rentals, royalties and other income of $1,740,257 for the quarter and $3,425,002 for the 6 months. Year-ago total income figures include land sales of $361,001 for the quarter and $1,736,548 for the 6 months and rentals, royalties and other income of $1,783,087 for the quarter and $3,747,965 for the 6 months. Share earnings are per sub share.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $1,579,000 for the quarter and $2,782,000 for the 6 months from the Kaydon Corp. unit which was spun off on April 5, 1984. c-Including income of $791,000 from the Kaydon Corp. unit. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on June 29, 1984.

title: FUNDS FOR CITY SCHOOLS DENIED IN DISPUTE OVER BUDGET CUTS
description: In a rare display of public anger, City Council members yesterday denied a routine budget request and refused to give the Board of Education $36 million to balance its books for the last fiscal year.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Record
description: Japan posted a $13.53 billion trade surplus in the first half of the year, its largest six-month surplus ever, the Finance Ministry said today. The surplus featured a sharp increase in exports to the United States.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Michelle and Denise Silber open tonight on Broadway. The 21-year-old twins, who sing and strum guitars, will play the Astor, adjacent to Shubert Alley at Broadway and 44th Street - the Astor Parking Garage.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
Test Failure Complicates Space Flight Schedule
description: The failure of a rocket nozzle in a test in St. Louis has complicated the space agency's decision on when to reschedule the aborted launching of the space shuttle Discovery, officials reported today.

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I came to this country in the late 1930's I was unfamiliar with American-style barbecue. In France I had seen a good deal of grilled and spit-turned foods such as poultry, but the concept of using a basting sauce made with ketchup and brown sugar, among other ingredients, was new to me. One of the first ''barbecued'' dishes I can recall was basted with a mixture of soy sauce, honey, garlic and ginger, and that formula, or variations of it, have always been appealing.

title: Afghanistan Rocket Hits U.S. Embassy Entrance
description: A rocket hit the gate of the United States Embassy in Kabul last week in the first attack on the mission since Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan in 1979, a Western diplomat said today.

title: JACKSON CHARGES HE WAS IGNORED FOR THE NO. 2 SPOT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today assailed Walter F. Mondale for failing to consider him as a running mate and accused Jewish leaders of attempting to ''distance'' Mr. Mondale from him.

title: Unlike Father
description: ''Like father, like son,'' is an adage important to racing's multimillion- dollar breeding industry. Horsemen spend a lot of money because they believe that the mating of a champion sire with a speedy mare is likely to produce a colt or filly with the racing quickness that wins big purses.

title: ON THE FATE OF COLLECTION OF HEBREW BOOKS
description: To the Editor:

title: STRICTER RULES FOR BANKS PROPOSED
description: Federal banking regulators have proposed new rules that could make about 700 of the nation's approximately 15,000 commercial banks raise hundreds of millions of dollars in new capital.

title: No Headline
description: The Duty to Disabled Children A 1975 law required that states give handicapped children a ''free appropriate public education'' in conditions as near to normal as possible. But how far school districts must go to provide such education remains a vexing question.

title: NU HORIZONS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
NATIONAL STARS WIN ON 11 STRIKEOUTS, 2 HOMERS
description: In a game dominated by strikeout pitchers, including 19-year-old Dwight Gooden of the Mets, the National League reasserted itself tonight and defeated the American League, 3-1, in baseball's 55th All-Star Game.

title: Pierce Reports Holdings
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., has listed more than $800,000 in assets on his financial disclosure report for 1983, including stocks held by himself and his wife in 65 different companies. Only a few of his holdings were directly related to housing or urban development. These included limited partnerships in two real estate investments, neither of which were related to the department.

title: ;  Dart & Kraft Names Tupperware Chairman
description: From batteries to kitchen plastics might be considered an unusual step for a corporate executive. But not for William L. Jackson, a group vice president of Dart & Kraft Inc., the diversified consumer products company. Mr. Jackson, who is president of the company's Duracell Inc. unit, which makes batteries, has been named chairman of the company's Tupperware International unit.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,372,000 for the quarter and $3,740,000 for the 6 months.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: READING FOR THE PLOT. Design and Intention in Narrative. By Peter Brooks. 363 pages. Knopf. $17.95.

title: THREE NBC PROGRAMS WIN HUMANITAS PRIZES
description: ''Choices of the Heart,'' an NBC television movie based on the death of American nuns in El Salvador, and episodes of ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''Family Ties'' have been awarded the Humanitas Prize for the 1983-84 television season.

title: No Headline
description: 13 Synanon Members Answer an Indictment

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Belgian to Head Settlements Bank
description: Jean Godeaux, governor of the National Bank of Belgium, has been elected president of the Bank for International Settlements, the bank announced today. Mr. Godeaux succeeds Fritz Leutwiler, the president of the Swiss central bank, who steps down as head of the B.I.S. at the end of this year.

title: Blue Jay Bonus
description: The crowd that saw the All-Star Game at Candlestick Park in San Francisco last night included 20 female front-office employees of the Toronto Blue Jays. As a fringe benefit each year, the Blue Jays create an extra paid vacation for their female employees by sending them to the All- Star Game.

title: Bankruptcy Law Is Signed
description: President Reagan signed into law today a major overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy system but complained that it contained unconstitutional restrictions on his power to appoint new bankruptcy judges. One of the key provisions of the measure limits employers' ability to use bankruptcy to nullify union contracts.

title: DALMYS CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
Economic Scene; I.B.M.'s Battle In Europe
description: THE end may be in sight for the European Economic Community's marathon antitrust case

title: UNITED BANCORP ALASKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Editorial Notebook; The High Court's Long Reach
description: The Supreme Court enjoys supreme discretion. Unlike lower courts, which usually must decide whatever cases come their way, the high court can choose from thousands of petitions and appeals and shape most of the issues it wants to decide.

title: Dog Kills Burglary Suspect
description: A police dog attacked and killed an unidentified burglary suspect early today with a single bite to the man's throat, the authorities said. Joe Casey, the Metro Police Chief, said K-9 Officer Ronnie Barnes, who was investigating a break-in at Superb Motors, unleashed the dog, a German shepherd, after shouting several warnings. The suspect, who had no identification, was dead when medics arrived.

title: $1 Billion Shelf Filing by Texaco Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering proposed offerings of up to $1 billion worth of debt securities of Texaco Capital Inc., a subsidiary.
description: Texaco said the securities would be guaranteed by the parent company. The securities will be offered directly or through underwriting syndicates on terms determined by market conditions at the time of sale, Texaco said.

title: ST. REGIS LOSES BID TO STALL MURDOCH
description: A Federal judge today denied a request from the St. Regis Corporation for a temporary order blocking the publisher Rupert Murdoch from increasing his 5.6 percent stake in St. Regis common stock.

title: THE DEMOCRATS ARE ALSO WARNED
description: Jewish leaders criticized Jesse Jackson yesterday for portraying himself as their victim. The American Jewish Congress said that continued support for the Rev. Jackson by the Democratic Party is a ''partnership that can only lead to disaster.''

title: A Prison Called East Timor
description: While visiting Indonesia this week, Secretary of State Shultz has a chance to demonstrate the United States' evenhandedness in opposing unjust colonial wars. Everyone knows where Washington stands on Afghanistan and Cambodia, nations occupied by Communist neighbors. But Indonesia's occupation of East Timor has been passed over by three Administrations with shamefully vague murmurs of the kind Americans scorn in United Nations declarations.

title: Eastern Gas-Nueast Tie
description: Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates of Boston said yesterday that it had acquired sole ownership of the Nueast Mining Corporation.

title: Holding Company Buys Cigar Unit
description: MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc. said it had acquired Consolidated Cigar Holdings Ltd.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $16.8 million from the sale of land in Maine. c-Including a pretax gain of $15.7 million from the sale of land in Florida. d-Including a pretax gain of $63.5 million from the sale of timber in California.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 11, 1984 International
description: The world's population may double to 10 billion by 2050, with most of the increase in poorer, developing countries, whose economic growth may be held back, according to a forecast by the World Bank. The organization urged intensification of Government- sponsored population control programs. (Page A1, Column 3.) Beirut's crossing points were open and activity at the seaport and the airport resumed in the first day of real calm since a Government peace plan took effect a week ago. Traffic flowed freely through four gateways leading to the Moslem and Christian parts of the capital. (A3:4.)

title: TRAVELERS' BOTTLENECK:5TH AVE. PASSPORT OFFICE
description: The Manhattan Passport Agency, with the heaviest traffic in passport applicants in the country, drew more than 1,000 hopeful travelers yesterday to its office at 630 Fifth Avenue.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RULING FAVORS DAYCO OVER EX-SALES AGENT
description: The Dayco Corporation appeared yesterday to have finally won its tangled, two-year-long legal battle with a former sales agent, Edith Reich, after a Federal judge dismissed Mrs. Reich's charges against the company's chairman, Richard J. Jacob, and other executives.

title: REGINALD STEWART, PIANIST, DIES AT 84
description: Reginald Stewart, the Scottish-born conductor and pianist, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: TASKS FOR THE DEMOCRACY ENDOWMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG WAITS CITED ON ARRAIGNMENTS
description: Thousands of people arrested in New York City are being held in custody for two days or more awaiting their first court hearing - a situation described by some officials as illegal and inhumane.

title: Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
description: Rehab Hospital Services Corp. of Mechanicsburg, Pa., filed a $15 million offering of convertible subordinated debentures due in 1999 through Drexel Burnham Lambert. Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corp. senior debt was downgraded to BBBx from A- and its subordinated debt to BBB from BBBx by Standard & Poor's.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (COLO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EUROPEANS PLAN NEW JET FIGHTER
description: The Defense Ministers of five Western European countries have agreed in principle on joint development of a new fighter plane, for service in the mid-1990's.

title: At Ceremony for New Park Memories of Old Park
description: Nostalgia wafted over the Coney Island Boardwalk yesterday as officials broke ground for an 11.5-acre park at the site of the old Steeplechase Park, an indoor amusement area built in 1897 and torn down in 1965.

title: People
description: * Lynda Bardfield has rejoined Foote, Cone & Belding Communications as senior vice president, regional creative director, in the Multinational Business Group.

title: BONDS FALL IN PROFIT TAKING
description: Bond prices fell in light trading in the credit markets yesterday, as participants engaged in profit taking in the wake of Monday's heady rally.

title: An Olympic Smog Plan
description: Amid the worst smog ever for

title: RETURN OF JAMES BROWN
description: JAMES BROWN is back. And since he has always insisted that everything he does he does to death, he is back on several record labels, back with some of his oldest music, some of his greatest, and a soon-to-be-released single that is his most exciting new disk in years.

title: THE TOAST TRADE-OFF
description: Forty years ago every other person you saw at the swimming pool had a big scar on the right side of the abdomen where the surgeons had gone in and plucked out an appendix. Doctors at that time loved to do appendectomies. One of the terrors of childhood was a bellyache, because you could be fairly certain that if your mother told the doctor about it you would be whisked into a hospital, etherized and sliced open, and wake up with your appendix gone.

title: Hockey Players Hurt
description: Al Iafrate , the first selection of the Toronto Maple Leafs and the fourth over all in the National Hockey League draft last month, was scheduled to appear in court today on a careless-driving charge after a single-car accident Saturday in which he and another player, Mike Vellucci , were injured. Iafrate, an 18-year-old from Livonia, Mich., and a standout as a defenseman with the United States Olympic team, suffered 14 cracked ribs and a head wound that required 12 stitches.

title: Air Florida Plans Flight to London
description: Air Florida plans to resume Miami-to-London service with a DC-10 and crews leased from World Airways, the grounded airline's bankruptcy lawyer said. Air Florida, which suspended operations July 3 and filed to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws, did not set a date to resume service.

title: SOVIET NAVAL BLAST CALLED CRIPPLING
description: An authoritative British military publication said today that an explosion at a Soviet naval base in May crippled the fighting capacity of the Northern Fleet, the strongest of the Soviet Navy's four high-sea fleets.

title: HART, BEFORE SOUTHERN AUDIENCE, ASSERTS: 'I'M IN THIS RACE TO STAY'
description: Senator Gary Hart brought his Presidential campaign back to the South today, firmly declaring: ''I'm in this race to stay. I do not quit. This campaign is going to the convention.''

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of June 30
description: The latest figures reflect the payment of a dividend of $3.05 a share. Asset figures represent net assets.

title: ENERGY ASSETS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Poisson Captures 12th Leg of Tour
description: Pascal Poisson of France won the 12th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, a leg that ended here after 69 miles in which the competitors battled a strong sidewind.

title: SHELBY WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ITT, IN PROFIT SLUMP, CUTS DIVIDEND
description: The ITT Corporation, the telecommunications conglomerate, slashed its quarterly dividend yesterday by more than half and said it would report sharply lower earnings for this year's second quarter.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHICAGO'S BASTILLE DAY:ACCENT ON FOOD
description: With elaborate dinners, outdoor buffets and a potpourri of street performers, a number of this city's French restaurants are planning what they believe to be the biggest Bastille Day celebration in the United States.

title: Falwell Opens Campaign For Christian Voters
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, hoping to offset black voter registration efforts by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, today began a drive to sign up two million conservative Christian voters.

title: Stake in Circle K
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl Lindner, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company had reduced its holdings in the Circle K Corporation to the equivalent of 5,431,173 common shares, or 33.8 percent of the total.

title: BANKERS TRUST OF SOUTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.D.L. IS 'ANTI-ANTI-AFFIRMATIVE ACTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET DIRECTOR ASKS REFUGE, CITING RESTRAINTS ON WORK
description: Andrei Tarkovsky, the Soviet film director, announced in Milan today that he would seek political asylum in the West because his country did not allow him to work.

title: CARTER: GREAT TAG AND GOOD ADVICE
description: Fernando Valenzuela and Dwight Gooden broke Carl Hubbell's record for consecutive strikeouts in an All-Star Game tonight, and Gary Carter broke Gabby Hartnett's record for catching consecutive strikeouts.

title: 3 TIE IN STATE GOLF OPEN
description: Brisk winds and difficult pin placements combined today to elevate scores in the second round of the Michelob New York State Open golf tournament, with the result that only three players completed 36 holes under par. The three, tied for the lead at 141, were Jeff Grygiel, Darrell Kestner and Joe Bostic.

title: ATVS-First Data Deal
description: ATVS Systems Inc. of Santa Ana, Calif., has announced that First Data Resources Inc. of Omaha has acquired its field service arm. The manufacturer of computerized cash register systems said Monday that the total ''cash yield'' from the sale would exceed $14 million in immediate and deferred payments and royalties.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN DELOREAN CASE
description: The Government rested its case today in the trial of John Z. DeLorean, the former automobile magnate who is charged with conspiring to distribute 55 pounds of cocaine in 1982 when his sports car company was nearing insolvency.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE TAKE-A- -DEFECTOR-OUT-TO-LUNCH BUNCH
description: A certain air of international cat-and- mouse surrounds a new enterprise set up here to help defectors from the Soviet bloc make the difficult transition to American life.

title: TO GET WORKERS WORKING
description: The American economy has been limping since the mid-1960's, hobbled by increasingly sluggish productivity growth - a problem that has persisted stubbornly despite the current recovery.

title: What Social Security Is and Isn't
description: President Reagan is surely right when he says that some young people now paying into Social Security will ''never be able to receive as much as they're paying.'' What Mr. Reagan did not say, though, is that Social Security was never meant to deliver a fixed return to individuals. Nor, on reflection, would many Americans want to alter the system to make that possible.

title: WESTERN UNION DROPS SATELLITE-TO-HOME TV PLAN
description: The Western Union Corporation yesterday became the second major communications company in two weeks to abandon a proposed satellite-to-home television system, saying that there was insufficient programming available.

title: GROUP SEES POOR COMPLIANCE ON TOXIC SUBSTANCES
description: Compliance with the nation's laws to protect the public from toxic substances has ''collapsed,'' according to a study of Government records issued today by a group of environmental and public health experts.

title: Advertising; Mixing Ethics and Politics
description: the country's

title: SECT PARENTS IN HEATED TOWN MEETING
description: Leaders of the Northeast Kingdom Community Church, which has been the subject of an investigation on charges of child abuse, called a public meeting here Monday night and told angry townspeople that a ''lost generation'' would result unless youngsters, even babies, were ''properly spanked.''

title: Reagan Says He Still Backs U.S. Ambassador to Vatican
description: President Reagan said today that he still had confidence in William Wilson, the United States Ambassador to the Vatican and a longtime friend, despite criticisms of Mr. Wilson's intervention in an international criminal case.

title: U.S. SET TO REQUIRE AIR BAGS OR OTHER RESTRAINTS FOR CARS
description: The Reagan Administration is prepared to require automobile makers to install air bags or mandatory restraints in cars if states do not pass seat belt laws of their own, Administration sources said today.

title: Stocks Retreat, With Dow Off 7.17
description: The stock market resumed its decline yesterday after a late rally Monday.

title: UNITED STATES HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCIAL CORP.'S BIG GAMBLE
description: Rising interest rates have caused most thrift institutions to turn cautious, but the high-flying Financial Corporation of America is continuing to chase rapid growth.

title: TWO WHITES SEIZED IN '77 KILLING OF A BLACK STUDENT AT FORDHAM U.
description: Seven years after a Williams College honors graduate was shot to death in the Bronx early Christmas Day, two men were arrested yesterday and charged with his murder.

title: Continental Settles Suit
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation has tentatively settled a shareholders' lawsuit charging that it failed to disclose its financial difficulties before the 1982 failure of the Penn Square Bank, a spokesman said today.

title: SOLUTIONS FOR TRAFFIC ON OAHU SEEM TO GET GROUND UP IN THE POLITICAL WARS
description: Now in its third decade of explosive growth, this city and its island, Oahu, are choking on traffic.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Colorful Party For 'Reading Rainbow'

title: INFIGHTING AT LABOR BOARD IS REPORTED
description: Patricia Diaz Dennis, who was appointed to the National Labor Relations Board last year, has told White House officials that the agency is in serious disarray, according to Administration sources.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Cellular Technology Inc., San Mateo, Calif., has appointed Frank Kocsis president and chief executive officer.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENT COMPANY reports earnings for Year to April 30
BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago per share figures have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1, 1983 and a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 1, 1984.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHITE MAYOR OF SELMA IS RETURNED TO OFFICE
description: Despite a heavy turnout of black voters, Mayor Joseph T. Smitherman won a decisive victory for re-election tonight over Frederick D. Reese, a popular black opponent.

title: EWING PLAYS AN UNACCUSTOMED ROLE
description: As the United States men's Olympic basketball team continued to measure its growth by examining statistical charts and videotape of encouraging moments in its hurried preparations, one of its most significant parts could easily see his progress this week.

title: A FAITH TO SHED INHIBITIONS
description: The Church of Scientology calls itself a ''new religion,'' one not based on the worship of a God but one that purports to teach members how to improve the quality of their lives.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CROSSING POINTS IN BEIRUT ARE REPORTED
description: All crossing points between Moslem and Christian parts of the Lebanese capital were open today and activity at the seaport and airport resumed in the first day of real calm since a Government peace plan took effect a week ago.

title: HARLEM DANCE THEATER PERFORMING IN LONDON
description: Dance Theater of Harlem, appearing here for the first time in three years, opened an 18-day season at the London Coliseum Monday night to a full, enthusiastic house and, this morning, to generally approving reviews.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday on the Jacksons' new album, ''Victory,'' incorrectly described the first concert program of the group's summer tour. It included no songs from the record.

title: PILOT'S JUDGEMENT ON FIRE IS FAULTED
description: Federal investigators, citing ''a chain of misjudgments,'' concluded today that the crew of an Air Canada jetliner underestimated the severity of an on- board fire and waited too long to make an emergency landing.

title: SCIENTOLOGY CHIEF GOT MILLIONS, EX-AIDES SAY
description: Former officials of the Church of Scientology say they helped L. Ron Hubbard, the reclusive founder of the cult- like organization, to secretly divert more than $100 million from the church into foreign bank accounts he controlled.

title: LEBANESE QUAGMIRE
description: For some days now, international attention has been focused on the Lebanese Government's effort to implement a bold peace plan in the third of the country under its control.
