Meanwhile, in southern Lebanon, time is running out for Israel. Israelis are intensely concerned - and rightly so - to insure the security of their northern border. What they don't understand is that they would probably wield more rather than less influence in southern Lebanon if they withdrew their forces.

title: Rio Tinto Lifts Enterprise Stake
description: The Rio Tinto- Zinc Corporation, a British mining group, completed a tender offer that lifted its stake in Enterprise Oil to 29.9 percent, the London Stock Exchange said. The announcement seemed to end Rio Tinto's battle with the British Government, which had restricted the company's share of the initial Enterprise offering to 10 percent.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TOMATOES, SHEKELS, VOTES
description: It all began with tomatoes.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADNG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
REAGAN'S VISIT TO TIDELANDS IRKS ENVIRONMENTAL CRITICS
description: President Reagan traveled to the salt marshes and crabbing grounds of the Chesapeake Bay today to claim credit for cleanup efforts in the area, but his visit provoked a new outcry among longtime critics of his environmental policies.

title: U.S. BLAMES HANOI FOR ICY RELATIONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that all efforts by the United States to hold ''reasonable negotiations'' with Vietnam on establishing diplomatic relations have ''run into a stone wall'' that he said had been put up by Hanoi.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for 2 percent stock dividends paid in August 1983 and December 1983 and for a 6-for-5 stock distribution paid in May 1984.

title: Cosmos Desperate In Scoring Drought
description: Unlike the Cosmos of the past, the present team is losing games and fans because it is having difficulty scoring.

title: Chile in Reversal
description: Chile, reversing an earlier decision, will send a soccer team to compete in the Olympics, the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said today.

title: Hard Road Back An attempt by
description: Campy Russell , the former Knick, to play in the National Basketball Association again, this time with the Denver Nuggets, may not have a happy ending.

title: WINE TALK
description: SHOULD a wine lover be seen in a brewery? When the brewery is in the wine country, when the brewer is a grape grower and when it is the Anchor Brewing Company in particular - yes.

title: Louisiana Banks Agree to Merge
description: Three Lousiana banking companies have agreed to merge, creating the biggest banking organization in the state, it was announced yesterday.

title: COTTON DUST PLAN IS DROPPED
description: Dan River Inc. today abandoned its proposal to conduct an experiment that involved exposing workers in a Virginia textile mill to cotton dust levels exceeding Federal safety limits.

title: BRIEFING
description: Women on the Ticket

title: Canada Cites Trade Surplus
description: Canada exported $1.6 billion more of goods in May than it imported, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today, giving the figures in Canadian dollars. This narrowed the monthly trade surplus by $70 million from the April level.

title: UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LILCO EMPLOYEES REJECT A PAY CUT AND GO ON STRIKE
description: The unionized employees of the Long Island Lighting Company went on strike today after refusing to accept a 5 percent pay cut that the utility insists it needs to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Philippines Paying Late
description: The central bank of the Philippines is making available $88 million for paying interest that was due in May on some of the country's foreign debt, the bank said today.

title: VACATIONING? DON'T PACK YOUR TROUBLES
description: -away-from-it-all times that restore the soul, if not the body and mind. Leisure-time experts say that for most people vacations are an essential ingredient in an emotionally well-balanced life, a time that helps to make work during the rest of the year enjoyable or, at least, bearable. For those in emotionally intense professions, vacations can be vital to countering burnout. And for some workaholics, who might otherwise work themselves into an early grave, vacations can even be lifesaving.

title: PERES TURNS DOWN PROPOSAL
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, today rejected Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's proposal that Labor join the Likud bloc in a government of national unity after the July 23 elections.

title: A.T.& T., IN BID TO LOWER COSTS, FREEZES SALARIES
description: Bowing to pressure from New York City, A.T.&T. will add exhibition space at its new tower. Page B2.

title: ADOPTION LAW BEING THWARTED BY STATE JUDGES
description: A year ago, the State Legislature approved landmark legislation giving adults who had been adopted as children routine access to information about their natural parents, even when the information had been sealed by court order.

title: THE SCREEN:'CONDUCT,' ATTACK ON CASTRO'S CUBA
description: ''Improper Conduct'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 11. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 2, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: Singapore Work Rules
description: Singapore will refuse work permits to foreigners who earn less than 1,500 Singapore dollars a month - about $700 - or are not graduates of recognized universities, the Government said today.

title: Tunisia Lifts Grain Price 6 Months After Protests
description: The prices of bread and other grain products were increased by 10 to 12 percent in Tunisia today.

title: INDIANS SAY EXILES IN EUROPE AND U.S. STIRRED SIKH REVOLT
description: The Indian Government issued a 170-page report today on the Punjab situation, saying that the Sikh campaign that led to the army's raid on the Golden Temple had been inspired by Sikh separatists in the United States and Western Europe.

title: Michelob Accounts To Bates and Needham
description: Anheuser-Busch, the nation's leading brewer, announced yesterday that it was moving its Michelob and Michelob Light brands out of D'Arcy MacManus Masius in St. Louis and into Ted Bates Advertising, New York, and Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, respectively.

title: FROM ALE TO STOUT: GUIDE TO BEER WITH FOOD
description: FOR generations of Americans beer has been a quaffing beverage, simple and straightforward, brewed for those who could put away a six-pack after a softball game or at a backyard picnic. So the notion of pairing specific beers with certain foods was rarely a serious issue.

title: AN AILEY DANCE BENEFIT SALUTES ROHATYN
description: SURELY it was the kind of evening that those who conceived of Lincoln Center dreamed about. The plaza was bubbling Monday. Musicians played, people strolled, balloons and ice cream cones were everywhere. From Avery Fisher Hall came the opening-night strains of the Mostly Mozart Festival. And the Metropolitan Opera House was jumping with the premiere performance of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, celebrating its silver anniversary with the first program of a two-week engagement. It was the company's first appearance at the Metropolitan.

title: MISSILES HIT A BRITISH SHIP IN GULF
description: Efforts by Iran and Iraq to damage each other economically by attacking tankers in the Persian Gulf continued today, with Iran apparently hitting a large British tanker and Iraq reporting it had destroyed an unspecified ''large naval target.''

title: 133 TAIWAN MINERS ARE TRAPPED BY FIRE DEEP INSIDE TUNNEL
description: A fire swept through a coal mine near here today, and the authorities said 133 miners were trapped in a tunnel. It was Taiwan's second mine disaster in a month.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: The widow of the man referred to by residents as the ''town bully'' of Skidmore, Mo., who was killed three years ago in an unsolved vigilante-style slaying, has filed a $5 million damage suit, charging that her husband's civil rights were violated.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Visitor From China Talks About Its Y's

title: FRIENDSHIP: SOMETHING THAT CAN'T BE LEGISLATED
description: The denizens of Capitol Hill are, in the main, genuinely friendly, outgoing folks, but their capacity for friendship is tempered by their sizable egos, highly developed competitive instincts and tendency toward self- absorption.

title: Paper Concern Net Up 34.5%
description: The International Paper Company reported yesterday that its earnings jumped 34.5 percent, to $67 million, or $1.21 a share, in the second quarter, up from $49.8 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: TRUST CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income figures for the latest periods include a nonrecurring gain of approximately $2.2 million from the exchange of debt for equity.

title: HBO OFFERS SPOOF OF THE OLYMPICS
description: HOME BOX OFFICE's monthly comedy series ''Not Necessarily the News,'' at best an uneven effort, occasionally attempts a ''theme show'' devoted to a single target. The latest, which can be seen on the pay-TV channel tonight at 9, is ''Not Necessarily the Olympics,'' a spoof of the games and hoopla we will be seeing in Los Angeles this summer. Unfortunately, the effort doesn't even come close to being uneven.

title: BRITAIN CHARGES THREE ISRAELIS AND NIGERIAN IN KIDNAPPING OF EXILE
description: The Government charged a Nigerian diplomat and three Israelis today with the kidnapping of a wealthy Nigerian exile.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch Monday from Burlington, Vt., about the Amtrak train that derailed, misidentified a New Jersey tour agency whose president was a passenger. It is Unlimited Adventures.

title: WEDNESAY SPORTS Powerboating
description: New Jersey Grand Prix, off Point Pleasant Beach, 10:30 A.M. This is a 155-mile race around five checkpoints between Manasquan Inlet and Seaside Heights. Thousands of spectators line the beach to watch every year.

title: No Headline
description: Francis R. Elliott, 81, Borden's Former Head

title: KEY PART IS DROPPED
description: The Federal Trade Commission today tentatively accepted a measure that would require dealers to give buyers more information on used cars and suggest that consumers seek independent inspections before buying.

title: STRATUS'S NONSTOP COMPUTERS
description: Keith Johnson suggested looking at one of the computers in the demonstration room. Nothing outward about it seemed especially unusual. The inside was another story. It was two computers nestled inside one frame - data-processing Siamese twins. When one twin malfunctions, its sibling takes over its chores.

title: Gretzky Goes Under Cover
description: Wayne Gretzky, the captain and explosive scorer of the Edmonton Oilers, needed minor surgery on his left ankle after leading his team to its first Stanley Cup victory, dethroning the Islanders in the championship round.

title: Bridge: Jacoby's Visits to New York Are Recalled With Affection
description: Although the late Oswald Jacoby abandoned his native Brooklyn for Dallas almost half a century ago at the age of 34, New York players still remember him with great affection. He returned on many occasions, pursuing a dynamic and varied career as a player of, and writer about, bridge and other games.

title: U.S. PLANNING SATELLITE TO SPY ON LASER WEAPONS IN SOVIET
description: Representative George E. Brown Jr., Democrat of California, said today that both chambers of Congress had approved a program for a new spy satellite that could detect Soviet ground-based laser weapons.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $91,000 for the quarter and $167,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERBAN 'TURNADOT' FOR ROYAL'S DEBUT
description: With an unorthodox new production of ''Turandot,'' Princess Anne in the audience and a river of silver fireworks pouring down the walls of the Los Angeles Music Center after the sold-out performance, the Royal Opera of Covent Garden made its American debut at the Olympic Arts Festival here Monday night.

title: WILLIAM MOUNT-BURKE, HEAD OF LIGHT OPERA OF MANHATTAN
description: William Mount-Burke, the conductor, director and producer who founded and led the Light Opera of Manhattan, died Sunday evening at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 48 years old.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MGM/UA Shares
description: An investment group led by National Amusements Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 5.1 percent of the common stock of MGM/UA Home Entertainment Group Inc. The group said it holds its 1,498,900 shares for investment purposes, and that its most recent purchases include 135,400 shares bought between May 7 and Thursday. The group includes Michael Redstone, chairman of National Amusements, and Sumner Redstone, its president. On the New York Stock Exchange today, MGM/UA rose 37.5 cents, to $20.375.

title: Cooney's Condition The first portion of computerized X-ray tests performed at New York University Medical Center yesterday on
description: Gerry Cooney 's left shoulder showed ''no evidence of damage to the rotator cuff,'' according to a statement issued yesterday by Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff , Cooney's orthopedist. ''If the second portion of this test is also negative, which should be known by tomorrow, then we are left with a muscle pull, for which the prognosis is excellent,'' said Dr. Minkoff. Cooney's comeback fight scheduled for July 20 in Dallas against Phillip Brown , which had been postponed twice previously, was postponed indefinitely Monday after the heavyweight fighter had complained of pain in his shoulder late last week.

title: Careers; A Need for Nuclear Engineers
description: IS there hope for nuclear engineering as a career despite the continuing financial difficulties at so many nuclear power plants?

title: NEW DUTIES FOR OFFICIAL OF CALIFORNIA THRIFT UNIT
description: David L. Tilton, chairman and president of Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara, was given the additional title of president of the holding company's principal subsidiary, the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association. Mr. Tilton, 57, replaces Berry Holmes, who becomes one of two new vice chairmen. E. Douglas Reddan, an outside director of the California company, was also named a vice chairman.

title: Delmed Receives Grace Proposal
description: Delmed Inc. said W. R. Grace & Company had proposed to acquire from Delmed 3 million common shares, or 20 percent of those outstanding, and warrants to buy an additional 3 million shares.

title: Ursinus Factor
description: When the United States women's field hockey team competes in the Olympic Games for the first time next month in Los Angeles, the winning tradition of Ursinus College will be evident among the 16 players and coaching staff.

title: INDIANS PLAN BINGO HALL AND A PRIZE OF $100,000
description: Mohawk Indians are planning to turn around the depressed economy of their reservation here by holding bingo games with six-figure prizes in a salon to be built behind a truck stop.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE 'HEINOUS MISADVENTURE' FACING TIMES SQUARE
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT'S 'GOOD FAITH' EXCEPTION
description: Whether the exclusionary rule will survive the Supreme Court's ''good-faith'' decisions of last week is an open question. Some experts believe that by pruning the exclusionary rule, the Court has dampened widespread criticism that would, in the long run, destroy the rule completely. I disagree. I believe the new ''good faith'' exception brings the exclusionary rule one step closer to its ultimate demise. The new exception is only likely to embolden the rule's restive critics, who may be encouraged to launch a final, all-out attack (although perhaps only after a decent pause).

title: CBS PROFIT IS UP 51%, TO RECORD
description: Bolstered by strong sales of Michael Jackson albums and record earnings in its broadcast division, CBS Inc. yesterday reported a 51 percent increase in profits in the second quarter.

title: Australian Bank Plan
description: Australia will grant licenses to a limited number of foreign banks within six to 12 months, the federal Treasurer, Paul Keating, said today.

title: OLYMPIC THREATS REPORTED ABROAD
description: The Olympic Committees of Malaysia, South Korea, Zimbabwe and other third- world countries have complained to the United States in recent days about receiving death threats to their Olympic athletes purportedly sent from the United States by the Ku Klux Klan, American officials said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JOSEPH DE MARTINI
description: Joseph De Martini, a painter, died July 5 in the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a foreign currency translation loss of $300,000 for the quarter and year and a gain of $3.5 million, or 41 cents a share, for the year on the sale of Tyco's 20 percent interest in Mobil Tyco Solar Energy Corp.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $71,000 for the quarter and $126,000 for the 6 months.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $811,000 for the latest year and $502,000 for the previous year.

title: Judge Orders Benefits
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Reagan Administration must restore Social Security benefits to people who have been removed from the disability rolls until challenges to their removal are heard in court.

title: HELP FOR JELLY-MAKERS
description: THE season for native fresh fruit and berries is so fleeting in this part of the country that I try to make the most of it. My desserts almost always include some variation of fresh strawberries, blueberries, plums or whatever looks tempting. When time permits, I prepare jellies and preserves to enjoy during the period when we are forced to rely on fruit of questionable quality from distant places.

title: Comings and Goings As expected, the Boston Celtics announced that
description: Red Auerbach will step down as general manager but stay on as club president. Auerbach will be succeeded by Jan Volk , who has been with the team for 13 years and was named assistant general manager in 1981.. . The weight lifter Jeffrey Michels , suspended for two years by the International Weightlifting Federation because the hormone testosterone was found in his blood at the Pan American Games last year, was refused a spot on the Olympic team by a special United States Olympic panel. He said he would appeal the decision.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The latter part of the 20th century has been a demographic watershed, the high point of several centuries of accelerating growth and the beginning of what demographers project to be a continuous decline.'' - The World Bank. (A4:1.)

title: Florida Court Declines To Stop 2 Executions
description: Florida's Supreme Court today declined to halt the scheduled executions Thursday of two convicted murderers, clearing one roadblock to what would be the nation's first double execution since capital punishment was restored eight years ago.

title: Another Clemente The son of the late
description: Roberto Clemente said rejection by his father's former team, the Pittsburgh Pirates, shook but did not destroy his belief that he has a future in major league baseball. Branch Rickey , the minor league director for the Pirates, advised Roberto Clemente Jr. to drop his dream of becoming a professional player.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include operations of Marine Bank since Jan. 23, the date of the PNC-Marine Bank merger.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today July 11, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 11, 1984

title: NEW FIRE INSPECTIONS TO TAKE MORE SUBWAY CARS OFF LINES
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that more subway cars would be taken out of service for inspections in an effort to halt a series of fires, but it refused to say how many it would check.

title: THEATER:A REWORKING OF 'STRIKE UP THE BAND!'
description: PHILADELPHIA GEORGE and Ira Gershwin wrote many of the greatest songs of Broadway history, but the tragedy is that they didn't write them for the best musicals. ''Porgy and Bess'' and, in a stretch, ''Of Thee I Sing'' aside, the Gershwin shows are dated artifacts now - and, for present-day theater people, they present a frustrating dilemma. How do you revive the popular Gershwin scores onstage without reviving the deadly period pieces that contain them?

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOOD NOTES
description: Pies and More

title: Mondale Plans Weekend In West Before Parley
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign announced today that the probable Democratic Presidential nominee would spend the weekend at Lake Tahoe, Calif., before flying to San Francisco Monday for the party's convention.

title: ROOSEVELT-CHURCHILL LETTERS DEPICT TENSIONS
description: New insight into serious strains that developed between Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston S. Churchill, after they forged a military alliance to defeat the Axis powers, has come to light in the complete correspondence between the two leaders.

title: METROPOLITIAN DIARY
description: THE setting: a southbound Broadway bus, the kin with no window in the back. Up front, occupying the seats nearest the driver, two tourists, one male, one female. As the bus pulls away from the 43d Strret stop, moving swiftly past 42d, the woman leans toward the driver and aska, 'Where is Times Squares?'

title: Vatican Backs Leaders Of Nicaraguan Church
description: Angered by the expulsion of 10 foreign priests from Nicaragua, the Vatican today took a strong stand in support of the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy in its latest confrontation with the left-wing Government here.

title: Required Reading A Military Point
description: Vice Adm. James A. Lyons, Deputy Chief of Naval Operations, discussing the war powers resolution in an address before the Naval War College, June 19:

title: ISSUES IN THE LILCO WALKOUT
description: A dispute over wage cuts sought by the Long Island Lighting Company led to yesterday's strike by 3,900 members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. These are the major issues in the dispute.

title: Market Place; Waiting Game For Collagen
description: SINCE the average price for 18 biotechnology stocks peaked more than a year ago, it has plunged by 63 percent. And within the group, the worst showing of all was turned in by the Collagen Corporation, whose stock fell to its present trading range of under $9 from a peak of just over $30 in February 1983.

title: Jamaican Held in Slaying
description: A man working aboard a cruise ship was shot to death by another employee in a dispute over a $10 gambling debt, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Monday. The victim, Herman Augustus Charles, 28 years old, of Jamaica, was shot Sunday while the Norwegian-registered Song of America was off the Florida coast, said an F.B.I. spokesman.

title: 'ANOTHER TIME,' A BRITISH IMPORT, OPENS
description: THE luminous presense of Phyllis Logan, a fine young Scottish actress who, like Vanessa Redgrave, can look believably plain and unbelievably beautiful at almost the same second, lights up Michael Radford's ''Another Time, Another Place,'' a somber, extremely symmetrical new British film that opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Theater.

title: ANTITERRORISM PLAN WEIGHED
description: The Reagan Administration, attempting to reach an agreement with Congress on how best to combat international terrorism, is currently discussing a plan with the House Foreign Affairs Committee which for the first time would allow the State Department to impose licensing requirements on services being exported to foreign nations.

title: Prime Computers
description: Prime Computer Inc. introduced two super-minicomputer systems, which the company said performed 35 percent to 75 percent faster than the systems they replace.

title: Salomon Assisted With CATS Issue
description: To meet growing investor demand, Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it would be joined by three other major financial institutions in originating Certificates of Accrual on Treasury Securities, known as CATS. The others are Shearson Lehman/ American Express, Paine Webber Inc. and Citibank.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Albany Planning Bonds To Help Home Buyers

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN POSTS LOSS
description: The European American Bancorp - a successor to the Franklin National Bank that failed a decade ago - yesterday reported a loss of $137.8 million for the second quarter, one of the largest quarterly losses ever reported by a banking company in the United States.

title: FOR NEW YORK STATE, AN UPSWING IN JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco-Getty Deal Approved
description: The Federal Trade Commission gave final approval to Texaco Inc.'s purchase of the Getty Oil Company for $10.1 billion. The F.T.C. in February tentatively approved the merger and allowed Texaco to buy Getty stock but said Texaco would have to divest itself of some assets to end antimonopoly objections to the merger.

title: VERSATILE SWEATER AND SKIRT
description: 1. Lean and Long

title: Utilities in Zimmer Suit
description: The three utilities that own the canceled Zimmer nuclear plant in Moscow, Ohio, yesterday jointly sued the General Electric Company and Sargent & Lundy Engineers, asserting that key nuclear safety equipment was defective and caused millions of dollars in extra costs. About $400 million in direct and punitive damages is being sought by the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, the Dayton Power and Light Company and the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company. Neither G. E. nor Sargent & Lundy could be reached for comment yesterday.

title: Lloyd's Asks Stiffer Rules
description: Lloyd's of London today proposed reforms in underwriting agreements and in the auditing of syndicates.

title: TESTS FIND FLAWS IN HEART OF SWALE
description: Pathologists have discovered evidence indicating that Swale, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes, may have died of heart failure.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Gracie Mansion And Cannonballs

title: OPEC Defers Nigeria's Plea
description: Nigeria asked to increase production today as OPEC oil ministers tried to prevent price cuts in a weak market.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acme-Cleveland Corp., a cutting- and threading-tools company in Cleveland, said it had acquired Wagner G.m.b.H. of West Germany and C and A Products Inc.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A DOUBLING OF THE WORLD'S PEOPLE TO 10 BILLION IN 2050 IS PREDICTED
description: The World Bank has projected that the earth's population may double to 10 billion people by the year 2050, with most of the increase coming in poorer countries whose economic advancement it says may be held back as a result.

title: A.T.&.T.IN A REVERSAL, TO OPEN EXHIBITION SPACE
description: In a reversal prompted by sharp objections from the city, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has decided to establish a public exhibition space in an annex to its new headquarters on Madison Avenue.

title: MAYOR TERMS HIS WAR ON POTHOLES A SUCCESS
description: A three-month campaign to fill potholes and resurface some of the city's most ravaged streets was ''a tremendous success,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Big Wheat Crop Seen
description: Farmers are harvesting a winter wheat crop estimated at 2.02 billion bushels, the third largest on record, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $505,000 from income tax-related adjustments. c-Including a net credit of $1,040,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to include four banks acquired during the latest quarter.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FLASHBACKS Hollywood stills, the sort of pictures that traditionally adorn the fronts of movie houses, fill the ground-floor Joseph Exhibition Room of the elegant Hebrew Union College- Jewish Institute of Religion, 1 West Fourth Street, west of Broadway at Mercer Street (674-5300).

title: Company Set to Bar Takeovers
description: The General Foods Corporation, girding for a possible attack, said it would ask stockholders next Wednesday to approve a series of antitakeover measures that include a provision requiring that any hostile takeover of the company would have to be approved by owners of 80 percent of the company's stock.

title: N.C.A.A. TV PLAN IS REJECTED
description: The last apparent chance for the National Collegiate Athletic Association to exercise some control over college football telecasts this season ended today when the sport's major schools voted down a voluntary plan that the organization had submitted for their approval.

title: Bumpers Tells Mondale To Drop Him From List
description: Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas announced today that he had told Walter F. Mondale he no longer wanted to be considered for the Vice-Presidential nomination, preferring to remain in the Senate.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-After unrealized losses of $1,114,000 for the quarter and $1,262,000 for the 6 months from a decline in the value of temporary investments.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $8.6 million. c-Net loss including tax credits of $41.9 million for the quarter and $73.8 million for the 6 months.

title: Disney Letter
description: Facing about 20 shareholder lawsuits, Walt Disney Productions is vigorously defending the strategy it employed to defend itself against a takeover by the financier Saul Steinberg and its decision to buy back his 11.1 percent stake for $325.3 million - 19 percent above what the stock was trading for at the time. After the Steinberg buyout, the value of Disney's stock plunged about 30 percent. In a letter to shareholders dated July 2, Disney's president, Ron Miller, said, ''To challenge Mr. Steinberg and his investment group would have been costly, time-consuming and perhaps extremely damaging to Disney.''

title: Thunderstorms Cut Power To 40,000 Electric Customers
description: Nearly 40,000 New Jersey electric customers lost service last night as thunderstorms moved through the New York metropolitan area.

title: 2 ARE KILLED
description: An Amtrak passenger train crashed into a gasoline truck at a crossing early today and the truck exploded and burned, the authorities said. Two people were killed and five others were injured.

title: CALIFORNIA AMPLIFIER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FINE POINTS FOR THE CAREFUL BUYER
description: The first thing John C. Edelmann advises antique-rug buyers is to have an old carpet laid out so it can be viewed as a whole.

title: Woman Burns Herself To Protest Pornography
description: A woman who doused herself with gasoline and set herself afire to protest pornography was in critical condition today, and supporters of an antipornography ordinance called her action ''a statement for women everywhere.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COONEY'S AILMENT FOUND LESS SERIOUS
description: Gerry Cooney is expected to be sidelined only three weeks with what is now diagnosed as a pulled muscle in his left shoulder instead of rotator- cuff damage. But some observers at Cooney's training sessions doubt that the injury is even that serious. They believe that the erstwhile heavyweight contender, after being off for two years, was looking so bad in sparring that his camp was afraid to go through with his July 20 comeback fight with Philip Brown.

title: LEBANESE APPOINT PANEL ON THE MISSING
description: The Lebanese Cabinet appointed a special committee today to try to obtain the release of hostages held by Moslem and Christian militias and to investigate the fate of other missing persons.

description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $428,000 for the quarter and $437,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $356,000 for the quarter and $362,000 for the 6 months and charges $115,000 for the quarter and $230,000 for the 6 months for reorganization administrative costs.

People

title: DANCE: ALVIN AILEY OFFERS PREMIERE OF 'PRECIPICE'
description: THE rise and fall of the popular entertainer is a theme that has attracted Alvin Ailey as a choreographer on several occasions. Tuesday night the United States premiere of ''Precipice'' presented Mr. Ailey's latest thoughts on the subject and starred the fabulous French dancer, Patrick Dupond.

title: Atlanta Study Finds City Zoo Broke Animal Welfare Rules
description: Atlanta Zoo officials violated Federal, state and local animal welfare regulations when they moved an ailing 15-year-old elephant, which died days later in a circus, according to the city law department.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SINGER'S SHIFT INTO HIGH TECH
description: After nearly a decade of selling off unprofitable business lines, closing plants and investing heavily in new lines of aerospace and military products, the Singer Company appears to have completed what some analysts call one of the most thorough corporate restructurings in recent memory.
