title: BRASSAI, PHOTOGRAPHER OF PARIS NIGHTLIFE, DIES
description: Brassa"i, whose images of the Paris demimonde of the 1930's and portraits of French artists such as Dali and Picasso made him one of the major European photographers of this century, died Sunday at his home on the C^ote d'Azur near Nice. He was 84 years old.

title: ; SMALL BUT VITAL CHARITIES UNFAIRLY BURDENED
description: To the Editor:

title: STALKING THE NEWEST ETHNIC DISH
description: Here is news for citizens who think of the nation's capital as a city of silverware and starched linen: On any given evening, legions of Washington's best and brightest can be found eating stew with their bare fingers.

title: No Nonsense Consolidates at Grey
description: No Nonsense Fashions, the pantyhose provider, is consolidating all of its advertising in one agency, moving the Comfort Stride Light Support brand into Grey Advertising from Ogilvy & Mather.

title: LEVY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a special gain of $3,191,554. c-Including a special gain of $478,671.

title: CABARET: ELLEN FOLEY SINGS
description: AMONG younger pop singers, many of whom appeared in ''rock'' musicals such as ''Hair,'' the distinctions between rock and the theatrical-cabaret tradition don't seem as clear as they did to an older generation. Ellen Foley, who is performing at Freddy's Supper Club through Saturday, has appeared in shows such as ''Hair'' and ''Boy Meets Boy.''

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BACKMAN FILLS GAP FOR METS
description: Wally Backman finds it difficult to pick out a single turning point in the Mets' season. The team's success, he said, was more a matter of surges and momentum, of good days strung together, than any one point in time.

title: MRS. FERRARO OUTLINES A PARTY FOREIGN POLICY
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic platform committee chairman who is a strong contender to be named Walter F. Mondale's running mate, said today that the foreign policy of a Democratic administration would ''oppose the tyranny of the Soviet Union'' but at the same time seek to revive arms control negotiations with Moscow.

title: FEARS UNIFYING SMALL NATIONS IN GULF
description: In the five years since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini came to power in Iran, the conservative rulers of the smaller Persian Gulf countries have been edging closer together, building collective defenses against the disruptive effects of the Iranian revolution and the war between Iraq and Iran.

title: HERS
description: WHEN I hesitantly confided to a close friend that, after a difficult divorce and hard-wo n adjustment to single life, I was, to my surprise, considering remarriage, she hardly responded with the misty- eyed smile and heartfelt embrace I had expected. Instead she told me the story of a woman just my age in her office who had remarried and set off on her wedding trip, only to return three days later with a husband who had chest pains, was in a hospital recovering from a heart attack and would probably never be able to work again.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Even in an age accustomed to the malevolence in monthly crime tallies, serial murders and reports of young children beaten and maimed, evil - real evil - still has the power to stun and confound.

title: Storer Systems
description: Storer Communications Inc. said it had signed contracts to sell four cable television systems in California and Texas for $18.5 million.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,526,000 for the quarter and $3,226,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of United States Telephone in June 1984.

title: The U.N. Today July 12, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: GREG FOSTER NOW PLAYS LEAD
description: He can appear as distant as a runner disappearing over a rise on a morning jog, a man who, it is said, still broods because he has never been able to clear the hurdle presented by Renaldo Nehemiah. But then there are moments, such as the one after the 110-meter hurdles final at the Olympic track and field trials in mid- June, when Greg Foster exorcises his demons and permits himself to enjoy a victory. After that final, he embraced a surprised Tonie Campbell and Roger Kingdom - the second- and third-place finishers - in celebration of having made the Olympic team.

title: Opposition Parties Unite To Criticize Mrs. Gandhi
description: India's opposition political parties opened a national campaign against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today over the dismissal of the chief minister of the state of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: HART, IN A REVERSAL, SAYS HE IS WILLING TO BE RUNNING MATE
description: With time running out and no obvious way to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Gary Hart said today for the first time that he would accept the second spot on the ticket.

title: KURALT AND MOYERS IN CBS NEWS 'CROSSROADS'
description: ''CROSSROADS,'' the new series from CBS News, is distinguished not so much by the stories it tells as by the two correspondents who tell them. Charles Kuralt and Bill Moyers lend something like a moral presence to their work; we are not necessarily interested in what they talk about, although we tend to be partial to them. ''Crossroads'' is an exercise in personal journalism.

title: U.N. Chief Is in Moscow For Talk on Afghanistan
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations arrived in Moscow today for talks with Kremlin leaders focusing on Afghanistan.

title: Indiana Recount Finds No Votes Are Changed
description: Not one vote was changed when a court-appointed commission recounted Democratic primary ballots in Indiana's Porter County at the request of the loser, Representative Katie Hall.

title: JACKSON SAYS HE CAN ACCEPT MONDALE APPROACH TO TICKET
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said last night that, after having a telephone conversation with Walter Mondale, he accepted as ''honorable'' the former Vice President's reasons for not considering him for the second spot on the Democratic ticket. Mr. Jackson, seated in his home in the Hyde Park section of Chicago, also said he now viewed the process in which Mr. Mondale interviewed two black persons, three women and an Hispanic for the post as ''good on balance'' and even commendable. Both comments represented reversals of positions Mr. Jackson had taken as recently as two days ago. He had criticized Mr. Mondale's failure to consider him as the Vice Presidential nominee and condemned the process as not being serious. Three weeks ago, when Mr. Mondale first announced the series of interviews to be held at his North Oaks, Minn., home, Mr. Jackson called it a public relations ''parade.'' In explaining these two reversals of his position, the 42-year-old candidate said Mr. Mondale had explained that he had not considered Mr. Jackson as a possible running mate because they were ''incompatible'' politically.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Auction Is Successful For 'Paperless' Bonds
description: An investment group led by the Citibank Capital Management Group outbid 13 other syndicates yesterday for $10 million worth of State of Utah general obligation bonds. It was the first successful competitive bid offering for book-entry, or ''paperless,'' municipal bonds.

title: Accounts
description: * General Electric's Plastic Group to Marsteller.

title: No Headline
description: A Law Helping Banks Is Signed by Governor

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split that was effective Jan. 5, 1984.

title: Tampering Charge
description: A part-owner of the Houston Gamblers, Jay Roulier , said that he planned to pursue tampering charges with the United States Football League against a fellow owner, Doug Spedding of the Denver Gold. Roulier said that Spedding had interviewed Darrell (Mouse) Davis for the Gold's head-coaching job while Davis was still under contract as Houston's offensive coordinator.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
People Express Notes Offered
description: People Express Airlines Inc. yesterday offered $40 million of seven- year notes.

title: U.S. SETS '89 DATE FOR CAR AIR BAGS BUT GIVES CHOICE
description: The Government said today that air bags or automatic seat belts would have to be provided on all new passenger automobiles sold in the United States in five years.

title: A WAY TO IMPROVE THE BREED
description: So Swale most likely died of heart

title: LIQUOR, WINE AND BEER DESERVE LIKE TAXATION
description: To the Editor:

title: I.T.C.'s Plan On Steel Curbs
description: Following are the highlights of the steel-import protection plan recommended today by the International Trade Commission:

title: Mildred S. Tunnell Is Dead; Former Delaware Legislator
description: Mildred South Tunnell, the first woman elected to the Delaware Legislature, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at her home in Wilmington. She was 72 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day yesterday on groundbreaking ceremonies at Steeplechase Park in Coney Island misattributed a quotation. It was Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin who said, ''We're not doing the Parachute Jump yet, but that's next.''

title: CHAGALL REACHES 97 AND NEW ACCLAIM
description: Marc Chagall turned 97 years old last week, and that has led to much celebration of the artist, who is thought of by the average Frenchman as ''the guy who paints cows that fly.''

title: Another Phillie Hurt
description: Already laden with injuries, the Philadelphia Phillies had to put the rookie outfielder Jeff Stone on the 30- day disabled list, retroactive to last Saturday, because of a pulled groin muscle. He had to go on the 30-day list because the team had no vacancies on either their 21-day or 15-day lists, which include the pitchers Tug McGraw and John Denny , the catcher Bo Diaz, the first baseman Len Matuszek and the outfielder Joe Lefebvre . . . . Meanwhile, the Philadelphian famed for not speaking to reporters has broken his 11-year-old public silence - in a television commercial.

title: MONDALE SAYS HE WON'T RUN WITH JACKSON
description: Walter F. Mondale says he will not run on a ticket with the Rev. Jesse Jackson because of deep differences between them.

title: DOCTOR'S FRIENDS CALL HIM MODEL ISRAELI
description: Friends of one of the Israelis arrested in Britain on charges of abducting a Nigerian exile have described him as a model citizen who would never have become involved in such illicit activity except for patriotic reasons.

title: Debt Issues
description: First Chicago Corp. said it had filed for a shelf registration covering $150 million of subordinated notes. It said proceeds would be used primarily to reduce short-term debt and to fund investments in or extend credit to subsidiaries.

title: COLONIAL OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WESTCHESTER MUSICIAN VISITING THE BRONX KILLED BY GUNMAN IN CAR
description: A 25-year-old musician from New Rochelle, N.Y., was shot and killed on a northeastern Bronx street early yesterday by a gunman who fired from a passing car.

title: STEARNS IS ACTIVATED FOR PENNANT BID
description: Dave Johnson ended a two-day break in the Catskills yesterday and returned to Shea Stadium with all the dash of a man opening the second half of the season in a rare place: first place.

title: NEW ENGLAND CRIME FIGURE
description: Raymond L. S. Patriarca, the reputed boss of organized crime in New England for more than 25 years, died of a heart attack yesterday in Providence, R.I. He was 76 years old.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $193,000 for the quarter and $401,000 for the 6 months.

title: POLE, AUTHOR OF LETTERS FROM JAIL, IS AWAITING TRIAL HE LONG SOUGHT
description: Since martial law was imposed in Poland in December 1981, letters smuggled out of prison by Adam Michnik, an adviser of Solidarity, have helped sustain hope in the outlawed movement.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JULY 12, 1984

title: CONCERT: TOKYO QUARTET PLAYS MOZART AND BEETHOVEN
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW once wrote that you had to hear Melba to be reminded of the difference between really singing in tune and just avoiding the fault of being obviously out of tune. That Melba of chamber music, the Tokyo String Quartet (Peter Oundjian, Kikuei Ikeda, Kazuhide Isomura and Sadao Harada), regularly proves that really playing together is a hundred times more exciting than getting through a piece without any noticeable hitches.

title: CRUMP E.H. COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $44,000 for the quarter and $331,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $77,000 for the quarter and $47,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings figures have been restated for shares issued in connection with polling of interests in July 1983 and May 1984.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'GOBBLEDYGOOK' BANNED FROM MEDICARE FORMS
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the Government to remove the ''gobbledygook'' from Medicare forms to help the country's elderly understand why their claims were turned down or reduced.

title: C.D. YIELDS UP SHARPLY
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market deposit accounts made their sharpest increases in nearly two months, The Bank Rate Monitor said in its report on the week ended yesterday.

title: POLICE IN SAN FRANCISCO READY FOR STREET RALLIES
description: After a year of preparation, this 49-square- mile city and its 650,000 residents appear ready to receive 30,000 delegates, alternates, reporters and various hangers-on at the Democratic National Convention next week.

title: Order Is Restored At Tennessee Prison
description: About 75 inmates broke out of their cells at the maximum security Tennessee State Prison today, stabbed one guard and took another hostage for about 90 minutes before calm was restored, correction officials said.

title: STAMPS FOR THE LANDLORD
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Face of Criticism
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Firefighters' Memorial
description: Three months to the day after his father, a firefighter, lost his life on the job, John Donelon was born 54 years ago.

title: A Murder Convict Is Executed in Georgia
description: Ivon R. Stanley, convicted of killing a man who was robbed, beaten and buried alive, was electrocuted early this morning minutes after the Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal.

title: Topics Before and After
description: Albert Blumenthal

title: POPE DENOUNCES SANDINISTA ACTION
description: Pope John Paul II today denounced the expulsion of 10 missionaries from Nicaragua and urged the Sandinista Government to reverse its decision.

title: Suit Over Thrift Unit
description: Maria Chen of Hong Kong, majority stockholder of the defunct American Savings and Loan Association of Guam, filed a lawsuit to regain control of the financial institution. First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hawaii took control of American Savings on June 28 after the Federal Home Loan Bank Board declared it was insolvent. Miss Chen said in her suit, filed Monday against First Federal, that Government officials wrested control of American Savings from her because she is a woman and not an American citizen.

title: Jersey Abolishes Police Age Limit
description: Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman today abolished maximum age limits for enrollment in the state police and local law enforcement agencies because they violated a Federal agediscrimination statute.

title: DRUG TRIAL OF DELOREAN BRINGS OUT ACTIONS EMBARRASSING TO BOTH SIDES
description: If the prosecution's presentation against John Z. DeLorean made one thing clear, it is that both the defendant and the Government investigators did things before his arrest on drug charges that have made them squirm a bit at the trial.

title: NEGLECT OF PATIENTS DURING STRIKE IS LAID TO A NURSING HOME
description: New York State health authorities charged the operators of a Queens nursing home yesterday with subjecting frail and elderly patients to gross neglect and inadequate medical and nursing care during a strike in April.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 12, 1984 International
description: The trial of a Solidarity adviser, Adam Michnik, whose defiant inspiring letters from prison have helped sustain hope in the outlawed labor movement since martial law was imposed in 1981, was scheduled to begin Friday. It is a trial that the Polish authorities reportedly tried to avoid by offering Mr. Michnik his freedom, but one that the 38-year-old activist demanded. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) The Ambassador to the Vatican, William A. Wilson, was permitted to retain positions on the boards of two corporations when he was raised to that rank in January, according to State Department officials. The department could not provide an example of an ambassador who had been granted such an exception to the general policy requiring ambassadors to step down from directorships in profit-making companies. (A1:1-2.)

title: 7 Charged With Race-Fixing
description: Five jockeys and two trainers have been charged with fixing races in connection with an undercover sting operation at the suburban Penn National track, Attorney General LeRoy Zimmerman said today.

title: Safety Is Not Shoreham's Problem
description: This week's strike at the Long Island Lighting Company is a vivid symptom of its increasing troubles. Lilco seeks stiff givebacks from its unions because it's been driven near bankruptcy by its completed but idle nuclear power plant at Shoreham. Whatever the merits of the labor dispute, the blame for the underlying predicament is clear. It lies with the continuing failure of New York's Governor Cuomo to lead Long Island out of the mess created by Suffolk County's Executive, Peter Cohalan.

title: U.S. Suggests a Soviet Role In Threats Against Olympics
description: The State Department suggested today that death threats sent to third-world nations taking part in the Olympics in Los Angeles this summer were the work of the Soviet Union.

title: Guatemala Will Seek Fine From Nonvoters
description: The estimated 500,000 registered voters who did not cast ballots in the July 1 election for the Constituent Assembly will be fined, a Government official said today.

title: British Banks Raise Rates
description: Britain's major commercial banks raised their base lending rates two percentage points today, to 12 percent, the highest level in two years.

title: Unfair to Academe
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the year-ago second quarter include a net gain of $2.8 million from the sale of property.

title: Yankees Release Dent
description: Bucky Dent is back home in Florida, his hopes for a return to the Yankees over. The Yankees made no official announcement about Dent, but his agent, Ed Kleven, said yesterday that they had told him they couldn't use Dent.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated for an acquisition.

title: Trottier's Choice
description: Five Islanders and a Ranger rookie were among the 30 players named yesterday to Team Canada's roster for the Canada Cup international tournament that begins Sept. 1. But only four Islanders will attend the training camp starting Aug. 5 at the Montreal Forum.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE are gardeners who accept the fact of weeds calmly and even cheerfully. Coexistence is their motto. There aren't many, though. Most of us want weeds abolished - at least in our gardens.

title: REP. GREEN PLANS CAMAPIGN IN FACE OF FISCAL LOSS
description: Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, said today that his family had lost $30 million to $40 million through the ''unauthorized'' use of the funds by his brother-in-law but that the loss would not affect his ability to campaign for re-election this year.

title: Chiat/Day Picks Up Porsche Cars Business
description: Chiat/Day of Los Angeles and New York yesterday picked up Porsche Cars North America in Reno.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Discoveries column of The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect address for Jonal. The store is at 17 East 67th Street.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WEIGHT OF THE WORLD. By Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 243 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $16.95.

title: REAGAN PUSHES ENVIRONMENT ISSUE A SECOND DAY
description: President Reagan's campaign to proclaim his support for clean air and water ran into more snags today as several environmental leaders invited to a special Presidential ceremony denounced his policies on the environment.

title: LAW ON PLANT CLOSINGS IS SIGNED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: After prolonged debate between business and labor groups, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today announced the signing of a ''national model'' law to protect workers against plant closings.

title: Florida Loses U.S. Trust Ruling
description: The Federal Reserve Board said it had denied the petition of Florida banking regulators to delay the expansion of New York's U. S. Trust Corporation banking business in the state.

title: MITSUI MANUFACTURERS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERITAGE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bergen Civil Servants Ordered to End Strike
description: Judge Sherwood Lester of Superior Court today issued an injunction ordering striking public employees in Bergen County back to work.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH outdoor furniture is supposed to take a lot of wear, most lawn and patio furniture needs repair or replacement after a few years of use. So it pays to maintain the furniture, to prolong its life.

title: Upjohn Cuts Price of Top-Selling Drug
description: The Upjohn Company said yesterday that it had sharply cut the price of its best-selling prescription drug, Motrin, in the face of competition from other brands.

title: JAZZ: SUN RA BAND AT SWEET BASIL
description: THE pianist Sun Ra doesn't just want a place in jazz history; he wants it all. So in a set like his early one Monday at Sweet Basil - where he will lead his 15-member big band, the Omniverse Jet Set Arkestra, the next two Mondays - he'll go hopscotching through a songbook that includes swing tunes (''Yeah Man''), standards (''Skylark'') and a New Orleans-flavored version of ''Mack the Knife'' along with his own tunes and lyrics about astral traveling and nuclear war.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS INVOLVING AIR BAGS
description: Following is a chronology of major events in the history of Federal action on the installation of air bags or automatic seat belts in passenger cars: 1952-55 - Patents filed for air bag

title: MIXED-MEDIA 'BLUEBEARD' DRAWS ON OPERATIC PAST
description: AT the recent appearance of Pina Bausch's Wuppertal Dance Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, dance critics pointed to the surprisingly modest portion that strictly choreographed movement played in all of Miss Bausch's work except ''The Rite of Spring,'' and to the derivative quality of what movement there was. Yet she remains a riveting theater artist, fully characteristic of her country and time.

title: SUN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SMOG IS INTENSE, SCALPERS ARE SOUR BEFORE OLYMPICS
description: ''We've got so many first-stage smog alerts around here today I can hardly count 'em,'' an announcer for a Los Angeles all-news radio station said one hot afternoon this week. ''You've got lots of unhealthy air out there, so if you possibly can, stay inside!''

title: The Small Type
description: Advertisements for the Aspen Tennis Festival say that Tracy Austin will play in the event later this month, but she says she will not.

title: List of Most Wanted Is Expanded by F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation opened a nationwide hunt today for Alton Coleman, who is wanted on charges of murdering young women and children in six weeks in five states.

title: SOVIET CONSTITUTION'S RELIGIOUS FREEDOM FOR SOME
description: To the Editor:

title: MoreSubwayCars Being Inspected
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that 41 more subway cars with a history of three or more problems in their acceleration control boxes had been removed from service for inspection as of late Tuesday night.

title: HENRY SPITZ, LAWYER WHO HELPED CREATE NEW YORK BIAS LAWS
description: Henry Spitz, former general counsel to the New York State Division of Human Rights and a leader in drafting the state's human rights and antidiscrimination laws, died yesterday at Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FAST START AIDS WINNING BOAT
description: Minutes after the race began, when his boat led as it passed Seaside Heights for the first time, Bob Idoni realized Mercruiser Special was going to win the New Jersey Off Shore Grand Prix today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; A New Chairman At Dayton-Hudson
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest non-foods retailer, yesterday named Kenneth A. Macke as chairman. Mr. Macke will keep his present title of chief executive officer.

title: Robertather
description: Benjamin Abrams, the father of Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, died yesterday at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: ALABAMA VOTING:SOME GAINS FOR BLACKS
description: Although Selma's black majority failed to gain control of the city government in voting here Tuesday, other blacks in the small towns of Alabama continued to make impressive political gains. And black leaders said they would continue their drive here and elsewhere to elect members of their own race to public office, even those running against whites who espoused black goals.

title: Commonwealth Oil in Chapter 11
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said it had filed to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: DIPLOMAT ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary gains of $9,207,000. c-The company did not give a share earnings figure for the year-ago fourth quarter. d-The company went public on March 22, 1984 and results for fiscal 1983 were not reported.

title: Sun, Phoenix to Merge
description: Two of Britain's biggest insurance groups, Sun Alliance and Phoenix Assurance, said they had agreed to merge in a nearly $520 million deal. N. M. Rothschild & Sons, Sun's financial adviser, said Sun would make a recommended offer for all the Phoenix shares it does not already own. The Phoenix directors said they considered the terms - a bid of $8.50 a share for Phoenix - fair and recommended that shareholders accept the bid.

title: SHULTZ EXPRESSES CONCERN ON RIGHTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz expressed concern to Indonesia's Foreign Minister today about reports of continuing human rights abuses being carried out by Indonesian forces in East Timor, an American official said.

title: ROCK: RANK AND FILE QUARTET PLAYS RURAL TEXAS TUNES
description: RANK AND FILE, a rock quartet from Austin, Tex., by way of Los Angeles, makes music that some have called country-punk. But from the evidence of the group's two albums and from its taut, disciplined performance at the Ritz on Monday that label isn't entirely appropriate.

title: 3 Issues Priced For Farm Credit
description: Three issues of Federal Farm Credit Banks consolidated systemwide bonds, totaling $1.58 billion, were priced yesterday.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenues were approximately $885 million for the second quarter of 1984 and $778.4 million for the second quarter of 1983.

title: ASAT'S AND SECURITY
description: In response to the Soviet invitation to negotiate in Vienna, the Administration may seek a ban on anti-satellite weapons, or ASAT's, that could destroy satellites in high-altitude orbits, while permitting low-altitude ASAT's. If so, it could well miss a golden opportunity to improve American security through a ban on all tests of space weapons.

title: 8 COSMOS NAMED BY U.S.
description: The United States Soccer Federation tonight named eight members of the Cosmos among the 25 players selected for the Olympic team. The list will be reduced to 17 players Saturday, which is the deadline for submitting the final roster and two weeks before the Summer Games open in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. WATCHING DISSIDENT TRIAL
description: United States officials said today that the Government would be closely watching the trial of the four Solidarity advisers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Dining Out Guide in Weekend on Friday gave an incorrect rating for the Homestead Inn. It was given three stars on March 18, 1984.

title: A.& P.'s Net Rises Sharply
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced today a huge earnings gain for its first quarter and said it would be in a position to resume paying dividends in fiscal 1985. The company said it earned $151.3 million, or $4.03 a share, in the quarter ended June 16, up from $13.1 million, or 35 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: Summer Bruin
description: Nick Fotiu of the Rangers has spent his last four summers in Falmouth, Mass., on Cape Cod, where he owns a summer home and runs a restaurant- bar called The Hunt Club. Many of his customers are from the Boston area and fans of the Bruins.

title: MONDALE TO NAME HIS RUNNING MATE IN ST. PAUL TODAY
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign chairman, James A. Johnson, said tonight that Mr. Mondale would announce his Vice-Presidential running mate on the Democratic ticket at noon Thursday at the State Capitol in St. Paul.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
UNION AND 49 HOSPITALS IN DEADLOCK ON WAGES
description: Negotiators representing unionized hospital workers and New York City's voluntary hospitals reported little progress last night, with a strike scheduled for 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Antibodies Diagnose Cancers
description: Cancers so small that they are invisible to surgeons can be revealed by specially made antibodies that seek them out within the body, new research shows.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Diversified and A.T.& T. Settle
description: Diversified Industries said it had agreed to accept $31.5 million as settlement of its antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and two of its subsidiaries. Diversified said the agreement, which also included $13.5 million in legal expenses, avoided, in part, the uncertainties of an appeal.

title: Texas American
description: The Texas American Energy Corporation said it had purchased all of its stock held by the Cavalcade Oil Corporation for $7.75 a share, or nearly $3.4 million.

title: S.E.C., 50 YEARS OF TENDING THE WORLD'S REPAIR
description: Fifty years ago, in the first days of the agency that was to remold Wall Street, the nation's securities markets were moribund and deep in the grip of the Great Depression.

title: WHERE TO LEARN HOW TO CHOOSE AN ORIENTAL RUG
description: NEXT to a house, a cooperative apartment or a new car there is probably no household purchase as expensive and risky as an antique Oriental rug. While there are real-estate appraisers for homes and cooperatives and consumer guides for cars, Orientals costing thousands of dollars are often purchased with little reliable information about their actual value, age or condition.

title: Olympic Update
description: This nation, hosting its first Summer Olympic Games since 1932, has been inundated with words and pictures about the competition in Los Angeles. By the time the athletes begin straining their muscles, some feverish fans may be craving results like a child looking forward to presents at Christmas.

title: BRIEFING
description: Eyes on San Francisco

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOLDAWAY DESIGNS IN WORK SURFACES
description: A WORK surface that folds away into its own cabinet saves space and reduce clutter. A folding hobby and worktable and two folding ironing boards helps keep chores organized.

title: SELLING WAVE SWAMPS ITT
description: IN the wake of a shocking dividend cut announced

title: AMERITRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A FORMER SALVADORAN REBEL CHIEF TELLS OF ARMS FROM NICARAGUA
description: A former Salvadoran guerrilla commander who was captured in Honduras said today that virtually all the arms received by the guerrilla units he led came from Nicaragua.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Phil Niekro, the 45-year-old knuckleballer, goes after his 12th victory. His opponent is Larry Gura, looking for his 10th. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.)

title: WHY INFLATION REMAINS LOW
description: Remarkably, in the face of the economy's continued rapid growth, the stubbornly high inflation that blighted the American economy for more than a decade has dissipated, and a vast majority of the nation's economists see little reason for it to return for as far as they can predict into the 1980's.

title: BRITISH TRADE THREATENED AS STRIKES GAIN SUPPORT
description: British seamen and railwaymen threw their support today behind the two-day-old dockworkers strike, itself a spinoff from an 18-week-old walkout by coal miners.

title: RACING BOARD ASK MORE EXACTA RACES
description: The trustees of the New York Racing Association voted at their monthly meeting yesterday to ask the State Racing and Wagering Board for permission to replace all quinella betting with exacta betting.

title: Bank of New York Net Is Up 20.6%
description: The Bank of New York Company reported yesterday that second-quarter net income rose 20.6 percent, to $26.3 million, from $21.8 million in the period a year earlier. On a per-share basis, net rose 17 percent, to $1.58, from $1.35.

title: 10 AIDES CHARGED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: Ten New York City water and sewer inspectors were charged yesterday with taking bribes for certifying work on private homes and other buildings without properly inspecting them.

title: Red Shuffle
description: The Cincinnati Reds, who were swept in a five-game series by the Mets last week, did some sweeping of their own yesterday, sending four players to the minors and putting the right-anded pitcher Frank Pastore on the 15-day disabled list with an arm injured by a line drive. Sent down were the pitchers Charlie Puleo and Bill Scherrer; the catcher Dann Bilardello, and the infielder Tom Lawless. Called up were the pitchers Brad Lesley, Jay Tibbs and Keefe Cato, the catcher Dave Van Gorder, and the infielder Skeeter Barnes.

title: REAGAN NEEDS SPOKESMEN
description: President Reagan's Administration is probably the first in history that manages to terrify the financial markets with good economic news. Last Friday, for example, the Government announced that the economy had created 460,000 jobs in June, bringing the unemployment rate down from 7.5 to 7.1 percent in a single month. The financial markets trembled. Normally, investors welcome employment gains as a sign that the recovery is continuing. In this recovery, however, investors sell when they hear good news.

title: CABARET: PAMELA MYERS AND STAN FREEMAN
description: PAMELA MYERS, who made a memorable Broadway debut in ''Company'' singing ''Another Hundred People,'' has teamed up with Stan Freeman, the composer, conductor, pianist, writer, singer and special materials expert, in a smoothly free-wheeling act at Freddy's, through Saturday, called ''Together Again for the First Time.''

title: Cuomo and Friend Honored
description: Governor Cuomo, visiting Jamaica

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. and Greece Discuss Ways to Ease Tensions
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and the United States Ambassador, Monteagle Stearns, met for two hours today to try to ease Greek-American tensions.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $13,007,000, or 83 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: ISRAEL'S VITAL CHOICE
description: The televised debate between Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, and his challenger, Shimon Peres, was reportedly ho-hum. The campaign for elections on July 23 is coming to an end without directly addressing Israel's most severe and immediate problems.

title: PRIORITIES AN ISSUE ON MILITARY FUNDS
description: The Air Force and the Navy, confronted with tightening budgets, have touched off a struggle within the Administration by proposing reductions in President Reagan's program to modernize the strategic nuclear force.

title: SEOUL AWAITS AN APOLOGY BY HIROHITO
description: Emperor Hirohito is being called on to express public regret over a part of Japan's militaristic past.

title: TRADE COMMISSION, 3-2, ASKS WIDE CURBS ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: The International Trade Commission, splitting 3 to 2, recommended to President Reagan today that he give broad new import protection to American steel producers and workers.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 16
MERRILL BANKSHARES CO (BANGOR, ME) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOW A DRAGNET FOR FRUIT FLIES WAS CAST IN MIAMI
description: George Gwin, a state agriculture inspection supervisor, was substituting for an ill co- worker on a routine examination of residential fruit trees last month when he came upon four fruit flies in a trap set by inspectors in a sour orange tree in the Little Havana section of the city.

title: KEEPING A BICYCLE SAFE FROM THIEVES
description: -speed bike or ride a cranky castoff in the park on weekends, there will be times when you can't take your bicycle with you. You'll have to trust it to a lock - and if you're like many New Yorkers, you will be relieved every time you return to find it still there.

title: JUDAICA SALE COURT DATE IS POSTPONED
description: A New York State Supreme Court appearance originally scheduled yesterday for Sotheby's and the State Attorney General has been postponed to Monday, a spokesman for the Attorney General said yesterday.

title: CONTEMPT CASE AGAINST CBS IS VOIDED
description: A Federal appeals court will not cite CBS News for contempt of court for refusing to show a ''60 Minutes'' transcript to a judge before broadcast.

title: A Team Promotes President
description: IT may be in the very heart of the

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Bond Prices Little Changed
description: Bond prices were little changed after light but volatile trading yesterday in the credit markets.

title: 'Chauvinistic Remarks' Conceded by Young
description: Mayor Andrew Young has admitted that he made ''some blatantly chauvinistic remarks'' about the candidacy of Alveda King Beal for the Fifth Congressional District seat and has since apologized to Mrs. Beal.

title: THE WORLD OF LE MONDE IS TURNING TOPSY-TURVY
description: For the last two weeks a sardonic modern romance has been played out daily on the inside pages of Le Monde. Konk, a cartoonist, has sketched a Jules Feifferish comedy of misplaced jealousy and desperately inept communication. Last weekend, opposite the financial page and an article about world fishing resources, the newspaper's loving couple ventured into print in the nude.

title: KRUEGER W. A. CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 9.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIDGE: BRITISH PARLIAMENTARY TEAM PLAYING ONE FROM CONGRESS
description: A player's forgetting a passport and so missing a plane would not normally help his team, but it happened Tuesday in England.

title: AUTO MAKERS HOPING STATE LAWS SAVE THEM FROM AIR BAG RULING
description: The nation's three leading automobile manufacturers said today that they hoped enough states would pass seat belt legisation to allow them to avoid installing air bags in some of their 1987 model cars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amarex Inc., an oil and gas company in Oklahoma City, said it had filed a joint plan of reorganization in which stockholders would receive 2 percent of the common stock of the reorganized company.

title: EARNINGS ; G.E. POSTS 11.1% RISE IN QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that net income rose 11.1 percent in the second quarter, to $579 million, or $1.28 a share, from $521 million, or $1.15 a share, a year earlier.

title: LTV Shifts Work
description: The LTV Corporation said its Flat-Rolled division would suspend indefinitely its hot-strip finishing operations at its Cleveland East plant beginning July 21. Production from the units affected will be transferred to the company's Cleveland West plant. About 160 employees will be affected by the action, LTV said.

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 16
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $18,000. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $86,000.

title: U.S. INDICTS AIR FLORIDA OVER PRICES
description: Air Florida, which has been grounded since filing for protection from its creditors on July 3, has been accused by a Federal grand jury of illegally raising and fixing air fares between the United States and Central America during 1982 and 1983.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Pohlad , who earlier signed a letter of intent to purchase 52 percent of the Minnesota Twins from Calvin Griffith and Thelma Haynes , said he had also reached agreement with a group in Tampa, Fla., to buy its 42 percent interest in the team. Pohlad's total purchase price of about $44 million is believed to be the second-highest in baseball history, behind the $55 million that Tom Monaghan paid for the Detroit Tigers. . . . Kevin Maher , a 23-year-old defender for the Pittsburgh Spirit who also played for the United States Pan American team last summer, has been named the Major Indoor Soccer League's rookie of the year.

title: Board Backs Aide AtConventionSite
description: The board of the corporation established for the city's new Convention Center gave a strong vote of confidence yesterday to the center's president, Thomas F. Galvin. He was sharply criticized last month by the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
OPPRESSION HASN'T STILLED ESTONIAN LITERATURE
description: At the recent Tokyo meeting of P.E.N., the international writers' organization, the novelist Kurt Vonnegut Jr. came upon a pamphlet published by the Estonian P.E.N. Center. Inside was ''A Poem From Estonia,'' which Mr. Vonnegut later described as ''perfectly wonderful,'' an allegorical cry for freedom from a land that had been annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940.

title: Japanese Coal Venture
description: Japanese companies will establish a joint venture to develop coal liquefaction, aiming for commercial use by the end of this century, an official of the semi- governmental New Energy Development Organization said today.

title: Bluefish Prospects Still Strong
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Large and medium-sized bluefish abundant offshore. Excellent fluke fishing continues in Margate Bay.

title: WILLIAM T. BRAZELL
description: William T. Brazell, assistant to the president and secretary of the Mohasco Corporation in Amsterdam, N.Y., died Sunday in a boating accident on the Mohawk River near Amsterdam.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for the latest quarter and 6 months reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 1.

title: Sidewalk Squeeze
description: ''It's such a big sidewalk and the people are walking over each other,'' grumped a woman as she squeezed by another pedestrian in the human morass of Times Square.

title: AT OLD WESTBURY, GRACIOUS GARDENS
description: IN 1905, the financier and sportsman John S. Phipps and his

title: Six Are Charged
description: Six people, including a physician and three pharmacists, were charged today with distributing or using anabolic steroids that are taken illegally by athletes to build muscles.

title: Big 10, Pacific-10 Reject C.F.A.
description: The Big Ten and Pacific-10 conferences indicated today that they would not join the College Football Association in a fall television package, choosing instead to form a coalition that could rival the 63-member C.F.A. for the biggest share of the telecasts.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Writer Pleads in Land Case
description: A Dutch financial writer accused of helping run one of the biggest frauds in United States history has pleaded not guilty to charges of selling virtually worthless American land to Dutch investors.

title: CONVENTION TO HEAR JACKSON AFTER IT VOTES ON HIS PLANKS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will address the Democratic National Convention here next week, but the delegates will hear him only after his attempts to amend the party platform have been voted up or down, according to a convention schedule announced today by party officials.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
American Express Post
description: Thomas O. Ryder, and that

title: PEOPLES BAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Management Science Stock
description: The stock of Management Science America Inc. plunged nearly 40 percent in heavy trading after the company said it expected to report a loss for the second quarter.

title: City Officials Meet On Arraignments
description: -enforcement officials met at City Hall yesterday to try to end delays that have held up the arraignment of thousands of accused criminals.

title: ADULT CHILDREN AND FAMILY MONEY
description: FOR the past three years a New York stockbroker, taking advantages of changes in estate and gift-tax laws, has divested himself of some of his holdings by presenting each of his children with $10,000 a year. This year one of his daughters, thanking him for his generosity, announced that she could now afford to have a baby as a single parent.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE BURFORD APPOINTMENT CAN BE UNDONE
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST-WEST EXCHANGES: BEST WEAPON FOR PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: RARE RULING LET ENVOY TO VATICAN REMAIN ON TWO CORPORATE BOARDS
description: William A. Wilson, Ambassador to the Vatican, was permitted to retain positions on the boards of two corporations when he was raised to that rank in January, according to State Department officials.

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALENDAR OF EVENTS: NEW YORK ON FOOT
description: Discover New York Talk and Tour:

title: Consumers Power Plans Midland Halt
description: Directors of the Consumers Power Company today ordered cancellation of the Midland nuclear power plant if no agreement is reached by Friday with opponents of the project.

title: CONRAIL NET CLIMBS 84% IN QUARTER
description: Bolstered by stringent cost controls, increased traffic and employee wage concessions, the Consolidated Rail Corporation yesterday reported an 84 percent increase in second- quarter profits, to $179 million - the most profitable quarter in the Government-owned railroad's history.

title: DOW DROPS 18.33 ON ITT SELLOFF
description: A plunge of almost 10 points in ITT's stock price sent the stock market tumbling yesterday. In hectic trading, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.33 points, to 1,108.55.

title: Gannett Net Grows 14%
description: The Gannett Company said that second- quarter net income rose 14 percent, to $59.7 million, or 75 cents a share, from $52.5 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues were $492 million, up from $427 million.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: S.E.C. Filing By Murdoch
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had refused to sign an agreement sought by William R. Haselton, chairman of the St. Regis Corporation, not to buy more shares in the company.

title: OPEC DECIDES TO KEEP SAME PRICES AND OUTPUT
description: OPEC oil ministers vowed today to hold prices at current levels, and the organization's largest producer, Saudi Arabia, agreed to cut its oil production to give more sales to Nigeria.

title: Toshiba Profit Surges in Year
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that improved performances by its overseas affiliates helped raise its earnings 54 percent in the fiscal year ended March 31, to a record $244 million, from the previous year's level.

title: A COMPANY TRACES FAR-FLUNG ALUMNI
description: CHICAGOA cottage business formed last year to stage high-school class reunions here has blossomed into a national network aimed at bringing old friends back together.

title: Stamford Ahead In Property Values
description: Stamford remains the wealthiest Connecticut municipality in terms of taxable property and is 50 percent ahead of its closest challenger, according to a new study.

title: Yet Another Promotion For Beatrice Executive
description: When Anthony Luiso, 40, was named to the ''office of the chairman'' of the Beatrice Companies in March, it was a big step up for the president of Beatrice's international division and corporate senior vice president. Yesterday, Mr. Luiso got another promotion. He was named a corporate executive vice president and president of the company's United States food unit.

title: ON LILCO'S PICKET LINE, ANGRY STRIKERS REFLECT
description: Michael Lehron, who started at the Long Island Lighting Company 19 years ago as a sweeper and has not missed a paycheck since, stood at the entrance to the company's Northport generating station this afternoon, reflecting on the strike that began yesterday.

title: BIG BOARD REVIEW SET ON LISTINGS
description: The New York Stock Exchange, facing the loss of several listed companies, even General Motors, yesterday announced a ''major review'' of requirements it imposes on companies that trade on the Big Board.

title: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toronto Stores Raided For Fake Jackson Items
description: The police, taking aim at retailers selling millions of dollars worth of unauthorized Michael Jackson merchandise, have raided a string of Toronto stores, seizing scores of badges and T-shirts.

title: Symphony vs. Cacophony
description: Some subway riders are finding a

title: SATELLITE TV SYSTEMS SEEN IN DOUBT
description: The future of a new technology to beam television signals from satellites to rooftops across the nation has been cast into doubt by the abrupt exit of several companies once expected to be major providers of the service.

title: CLAIM FILED FOR LOSS ON EUROBONDS
description: A small London-based bond trading firm has filed a claim against Bear, Stearns & Company in an effort to recover money lost in a Eurobond trading scheme.

title: KOCH DEBATE:RACE AN ISSUE
description: Was Mayor Koch's decision to engage the editor of a black weekly newspaper in debate calculated to enhance the Mayor's appeal to white voters? Or was it an impulsive but predictable response, given his penchant for rarely letting criticism go unchallenged?

title: NORANDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: After preferred dividends earnings per share for the year-ago quarter and 6 months were minimal.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Logic Systems Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., announced that Richard Ribas had resigned as president and chief executive.

title: Sir Caspar John Dies; Headed Britain's Navy
description: Sir Caspar John, the first aviator to command the Royal Navy, died today in a Cornwall hospital at the age of 81, his family said. The admiral was largely responsible for developing Britain's naval air fleet in World War II.

title: Louisville Gesture
description: On network television seven months ago, Tom Brookshier insulted the University of Louisville's basketball team by commenting that the players had ''a collective I.Q. of about 40.'' All is forgiven, evidently, because the university's president, Donald Swain , has invited Brookshier, a football commentator for CBS Sports, to be the featured speaker at the university's annual football kickoff luncheon next month.

title: Poll Shows Narrowing Of Reagan Lead in Race
description: President Reagan's lead over Walter F. Mondale has narrowed in the last month, according to the latest Harris Survey.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zabriski Wins Open
description: Bruce Zabriski, an unattached professional golfer from Southampton, L.I., surprised everyone today, including himself, by winning the Michelob New York State Open by a shot.

title: BUS SERVICE TO BEGIN TODAY FROM WEST SIDE TO AIRPORTS
description: Bus service linking Manhattan's West Side with La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports will begin today, making direct bus service available for the first time in 12 years.

title: Net Results, In Writing
description: Anyone for a tennis tome?

title: Molestation Inquiry Widens
description: Up to 30 more people are under investigation in the McMartin Pre-School child- molesting case, which has already resulted in 207 felony charges against six former teachers and the school's founder, prosecutors said Tuesday. The additional suspects do not include anyone involved in a separate Federal grand jury investigation, said the deputy district attorney, Lael Rubin. ''We're talking about an investigation of as many 30 uncharged suspects,'' the district attorney's spokesman, Al Albergate, said.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
General Interests
description: Wilt Chamberlain looked like Lemuel Gulliver surrounded by a group of bounding Lilliputians yesterday when he played among pre-teen-age athletes in a Mobil Big Apple Games volleyball clinic at the Felt Forum.

title: SPIRITED DESIGN THAT SUGGESTS NEW DIRECTIONS
description: In recent months, inventive directions in interior design have

title: BRITISH SEEK FOUR MORE IN KIDNAPPING OF NIGERIAN
description: The head of Scotland Yard's antiterrorist branch said today that the authorities wanted to question four more people in the kidnapping of a wealthy Nigerian exile.

title: COSMOS BREAK OUT OF SCORING SLUMP
description: The Tampa Bay Rowdies proved the right antidote for the ailing Cosmos, who ended a three-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: The Days of the Jackal
description: In a brazen operation last week, a political exile in London was kidnapped, drugged and jammed into an air crate labeled diplomatic baggage. But the culprits weren't working for Libya's Colonel Qaddafi; they were apparently agents of the Nigerian military regime led by Gen. Mohammed Buhari, a man with a moderate's reputation. And held as accomplices were three citizens of Israel, where terrorism is the foulest political word.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: AMERICANA A treasure of American art awaits the browser who ventures into the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, one flight down from the big ground- floor atrium of the I.B.M. building at Madison Avenue and 56th Street.

title: Sulliman Joins Devils
description: The Devils have signed Doug Sulliman , a wing who started his N.H.L. career with the Rangers five years ago and last week became a free agent without compensation from the Hartford Whalers. The 24-year-old Sulliman, the Rangers' first selection and 13th over all in the 1979 entry draft, has spent the last three seasons with the Whalers, for whom he had 6 goals and 12 assists in 67 games last season.

title: TORTURING SAKHAROV
description: There has always been a sense that Andrei Sakharov's standing in the world - his eminence as scientist and voice of conscience - set some limit to his persecution by Soviet authorities. But the latest reports on the great dissident have a more ominous tone than anything that has gone before.

title: Niagara Barrel Stunt Brings a Fine of $500
description: A 37-year-old stunt man who went over Horseshoe Falls last week in a barrel pleaded guilty today to a minor charge and was fined $500.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TWO WAYS TO MORE U.S. REVENUE FROM INVESTORS

title: More Funds for AIDS Study
description: New York State has awarded an additional $1.2 million to research institutions in the state to finance the study of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

E.P.A. TO LIMIT THE SALE OF 3 WOOD PRESERVATIVES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would restrict the sale of three widely used wood preservatives that have caused cancer and other illness in test animals.
