description: ''The language used is bureaucratic gobbledygook, jargon, double talk, a form of officialese, federalese and insurancese and double speak.

title: WOODEN SPLINTS FOR CHAIR SEATS
description: Apart from solid wood, no seating material serves a chair as well, without attention, as a weave of wooden splints.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Mitsubishi Net Up; Sales Flat
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation said today that declining interest costs offset virtually flat revenues in the fiscal year ended March 31 and helped increase earnings 5.3 percent, to $111 million, from the year before. Revenues at Japan's largest trading house increased eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $65.44 billion.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1984.

title: 'Ghostbusters' Grosses Near 'Indiana Jones'
description: ''Ghostbusters,'' with box-office earnings just shy of $100 million, is closing in on ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' as the summer's biggest movie hit.

title: 'FESTIVAL OF INDIA' IS SET FOR THE U.S. IN 1985-86
description: In what is believed to be the largest cultural program of its kind, India will export many of its major artists, craftsmen, performers and national art treasures to American museums and cultural institutions as part of a ''Festival of India'' in the United States in 1985 and 1986.

title: Profit Shown By Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, which experienced a loss of $51.3 million in the second quarter of 1983, today reported net income of $32.5 million, or 74 cents a share, for the quarter just completed.

title: TOOLING PARTS BY WATER JET
description: DETROIT

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: b-Including a tax credit of $5,250,000, or 14 cents a share, and an extraordinary credit of $135 million, or $3.59 a share. c-Including a tax credit of $4 million, or 11 cents a share.

title: HOME BEAT
description: EAMONN McMAHON (shown standing at right, with Martin Kennedy's gas pump clock cabinet, $1,200) and Anthony Robinson (seated) have opened a bright SoHo emporium full of English things. ''The English have eclectic minds, and because of their heritage they can throw together things that others might be afraid of,'' said Mr. McMahon.

title: NBC AND UNION TO USE MEDIATION TO AVERT STRIKE
description: The National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians yesterday agreed to use a Federal mediator in its negotiations on the threatened strike against NBC, the network and the union announced.

title: OUTLOOK REMAINS GLOOMY
description: The question marks that hung ominously over the Yankees in the spring have turned into exclamation points this summer: Their pitching is poor! Their defense is dreary! Their team is torn and tattered!

title: Topics Before and After Leverage For years the bandshell in Brooklyn's Prospect Park was a sorry symbol of neglect. The rundown structure seemed to deserve the graffiti that stained it and the floodwaters that surrounded it each spring.
description: Still, it offered the only available stage for a performing arts festival organized by a civic group called the Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn. With encouragement from the New York City Departments of Parks and Cultural Affairs, the State Council on the Arts, Borough President Howard Golden and several local corporations, the Celebrate Brooklyn festival offered free music and dance concerts.

title: PITCHERS STEAL ALL-STAR SHOW
description: The strikeout pitchers and their victims all headed home today to open the second half of the baseball season. But they were still marveling at the display of hardball Tuesday night that set records and restored the National League's dominance in the All- Star Game.

title: Melee in Court Ends With Lawyer's Arrest
description: A lawyer was arrested yesterday after a courtroom melee in which he and his client battled with court officers, officials said.

title: TEEN-AGER INDICTED ON L.I. IN RITUAL SLAYING OF YOUTH
description: A Suffolk County grand jury has indicted an 18-year-old East Northport, L.I., youth for second-degree murder in the ritual killing of another East Northport teen- ager.

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Low Rate Seen For Mortgages
description: Governor Cuomo of New York said yesterday that the State Mortgage Agency would be able to make $179 million worth of low-interest, fixed- rate mortgage funds available through a $200 million bond issue.

title: DANCE: JAPAN'S KYOGEN
description: SINCE the 14th century, Japanese actors have staged the comic plays known as kyogen in gardens and city squares, as well as in theaters. But not until the Nomura Kyogen Theater appeared Monday night in Lincoln Center Plaza has such an outdoor performance been seen in America.

title: The Chicago MercantileNames a New President
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the second-largest futures market after the Chicago Board of Trade, announced yesterday that William J. Brodsky would replace Clayton K. Yeutter as president and chief executive officer next summer. The news was not unexpected, as Mr. Yeutter had informed the exchange's board earlier this year he planned to leave to ''seek a career change.''

title: DEMOCRATIC DELEGATES HEADING WEST DIVIDED BUT SEEKING TO CONQUER
description: Although neighbors geographically, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are sending disparate delegations to the Democratic National Convention that opens Monday in San Francisco.

title: GAINS FOR REBELS SEEN IN CAMBODIA
description: An anti-Vietnamese coalition in Cambodia is beginning to cause military problems for Hanoi, Southeast Asian nations were said to have told the United States, Japan and other countries today.

title: U.S. TEAM WINS AS JORDAN STARS
description: Michael Jordan made a triumphant return to North Carolina tonight and led the United States Olympic basketall team to its sixth straight victory, a 96-85 triumph over a team of National Basketball Association all-stars.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Have a craving for a frosty beer on a hot summer day? How about a bottle of Kulmbacher Schweizerhof-br"au from Bavaria, or Tooths Sheaf Stout from Australia, Tiger from Singapore, Chihuahua from Mexico or EKU 28 from West Germany, billed as ''the strongest beer in the world.''

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 3, 1984.

title: Swiss Jobless Drop
description: Switzerland's unemployment rate dropped to 1.1 percent in June, from 1.2 percent in May, but was still higher than the nine-tenths of 1 percent rate in June 1983, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The number of jobless workers at the end of June was 34,499, compared with 35,565 at the end of May and 26,795 at the end of June 1983.

title: AMERICAN HOSPITAL SUPPLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an art review in Weekend last Friday, of the show ''Abstract Painting and Sculpture in America, 1927-44'' at the Whitney Museum, incorrectly characterized the sculptor Theodore Roszak. He should have appeared in a list of well-known artists.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: Frank Martin and Clem Gwynn are members of the biggest group of drivers in the Philadelphia area. They are among the throngs of people who hate the Schuylkill Expressway.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DELUGE OF RAIN BOTH GIFT AND CURSE FOR BUSINESS
description: Heavy rain on weekends that forced people in the New York area indoors the first part of the summer hurt attendance at beaches and outdoor music festivals, but theaters, shops and museums have prospered.

title: SOVIET-U.S. ACCORD TO SPEED HOT LINE IS CLOSE TO SIGNING
description: The Soviet Union and the United States are expected to initial an agreement in the next few days to modernize the existing hot line for crisis communications between the two governments.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Haslett , a linebacker with the Buffalo Bills, has been fined $200 by Judge Russell D. Coogan , who ordered Haslett to do 40 hours of volunteer work for the youth bureau of the City of Lockport, N.Y. for his part in a tavern brawl there. . . . Thomas Iannacone , an assistant athletic director at Fordham University since 1977, has been named director of athletics at St. Francis College of Loretto, Pa., replacing Art Martynuska , who resigned June 1. . . . Diane Dixon, formerly of Brooklyn Tech High School, has been named to the United States Olympic track team as an alternate in the women's 1,600-meter relay. . . . Cindy Olavarri of Pleasant Hill, Calif., withdrew from the United States Olympic road racing team because of mononucleosis and her place on the bicycling team will be taken by Inga Thompson of Reno. . . . Ronnie Lott , an all-pro for the San Francisco 49ers, has been made an offer, according to the team's president and coach, Bill Walsh , that will make him the ''highest paid defensive back in the history of football.'' Walsh would not reveal the figure, but Lott, who has talked with the Arizona Wranglers of the United States Football League, had been asking about $800,000 a year.

title: The U.N. Today July 13, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; City Sets Bond Offering
description: The City of New York will offer at public auction next week $250 million worth of general obligation bonds, Mayor Koch and Harrison J. Goldin, Comptroller, announced yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Poor Prognostication

title: FRIDAY, JULY 13, 1984
description: Companies

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mayotte Defeats Drewett, 63,7-6
description: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte of Springfield, Mass., defeated sixth-seeded Brad Drewett of Australia, 6-3,7-6, today in the quarter-finals of the Miller Hall of Fame Championships.

title: URUGUAYAN CLERIC TO HEAD COUNCIL
description: The Rev. Emilio Castro, a Latin American Protestant figure who has played a major role in shaping liberation theology, was chosen today to head the World Council of Churches.

title: A Break for Homeless Kids
description: More than 7,000 children live with their families in New York City hotels, motels and shelters for the homeless. Such a life can't be pleasant for the parents; for the kids it must be akin to jail.

title: STAGE: 'COME BACK, LITTLE SHEBA'
description: The American theater is still haunted by the sad ghost of William Inge, whose first Broadway hit, ''Come Back, Little Sheba,'' is receiving a revival at the Roundabout. During the 1950's, this playwright wrote one acclaimed play after another; his name was ritualistically linked with Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller. But when the decline came, it was swift and steep. Inge never had a critical or popular stage success after ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs'' in 1957. He killed himself in Hollywood in 1973.

title: No Headline
description: Pentagon Aides Agree On a 'Nuclear Winter'

title: LURING CAPITAL FROM OVERSEAS
description: BY most expectations, billions of dollars in new investment capital will soon begin flowing into the United States from overseas. The lure: new United States Government bonds that will be sold tax-free to foreign investors.

title: COMPLEX MIX OF PRINCIPLE AND POLITICS
description: Just as a long conflict over the use of a racial quota at the Starrett City housing project seemed to be resolved, the Reagan Administration intervened last month in an attempt to upset the arduously achieved compromise. The dispute at Starrett City, one of the country's largest publicly supported housing projects, is over the legality of a quota adopted to keep the 46- building Brooklyn development integrated. The case exemplifies the clash of principles and politics involved in the complex issue of racial quotas.

title: Paramount Promotes Distribution Executive
description: The Paramount Pictures Corporation yesterday named Barry London president of domestic distribution for its Motion Picture Group. Mr. London, 37, fills a position left vacant since March 1983, when Frank G. Mancuso became president of the entire group.

title: Carter Hawley Reincorporation
description: A judge cleared the way for Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. to reincorporate under Delaware law, a move designed to prevent a competing apparel chain from winning a hold on the retailer's board. Judge Bruce Geernaert of Superior Court said that Carter Hawley's proposed corporate move from California to Delaware did not violate state corporation statutes and was a legal way for the Los Angeles company to protect itself from unfriendly influence by The Limited Inc. of Columbus, Ohio.

title: A MONTH OF SUMMERFARE FROM BACH TO ZARZUELA
description: Though only in its fifth year, Pepsico Summerfare, the monthlong performing- arts festival at the State University's Purchase, N.Y., campus, has already established itself as an innovative cultural melting pot. This year's festival, which opens tonight and continues through Aug. 12, will offer more than 140 events, from free jazz concerts to internationally acclaimed theater.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR DEMOCRATS, SOME GRAND OLD PARTIES
description: Four days of part-time partying aren't really sufficient for the 100 or so social events - large and small - that have been scheduled around the Democratic Party's National Convention, opening here next Monday. So local politicians have spun the social merry-go-round into motion this week and will entertain a cast of thousands all through the weekend. After the convention starts, parties have been carefully scheduled to start at breakfast, continue through lunch, then pick up again after the sessions end in the evening.

title: No Headline
description: Court Urged to Allow Meditation in Schools

title: Big Boeing Order
description: The Boeing Company said Southwest Airlines had exercised options for 21 more new-generation 737-300 jetliners in an order Boeing valued at about $500 million.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,021,000. c-Net income.

title: NEGOTIATORS TRY TO AVERT STRIKE AT 27 HOSPITALS
description: Negotiators attempted last night to reach a contract settlement that would avert a strike set for 6 A.M. today by 46,000 employees at 27 New York City nonprofit hospitals and 6 hospital-affiliated nursing homes.

title: KUWAIT INITIALS A $327 MILLION SOVIET ARMS DEAL
description: Kuwait has initialed a $327 million arms deal with the Soviet Union aimed at defending Persian Gulf commercial shipping against Iranian attacks, Kuwaiti officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday on an article about exacta betting misstated the racing board's role. The board is being asked to approve additional exacta races.

title: NONSTRIKING LILCO STAFF KEPT BUSY AT NEW JOBS
description: Raphael Urena, who usually designs Long Island Lighting Company substations and small transmission cables from behind a desk in an air- conditioned office, set out the orange cones behind the yellow Lilco truck.

title: ; Two worlds of bidding.
description: Art auctions in this country - especially those events at which collectors, museum curators and dealers from all over the world vie to pay astronomical prices for Turners and Raphaels - are often described as pure theater, even circuses. The most important New York art sales at Sotheby's and Christie's attract huge crowds, with many bidders in formal attire.

title: FALWELL'S FORUM OPENS AS STREET MELEE ERUPTS
description: A Moral Majority conference began here today and touched off a raucous demonstration by opponents of the group, including the city's vocal homosexual community.

title: CONSISTENT LIBERAL RECORD IN HOUSE
description: In six years in Congress, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro has established a voting record considerably more liberal than the conservative Queens district she represents but not quite so liberal as Walter F. Mondale's.

title: Coast Man Convicted Of 2 Skid Row Murders
description: Bobby Joe Maxwell, charged with stabbing 10 men around the downtown skid row district in the winter of 1978-79, was convicted today of two counts of first-degree murder.

title: GERALDINE FERRARO IS CHOSEN BY MONDALE AS RUNNING MATE, FIRST WOMEN ON MAJOR TICKET
description: Remarks by candidates, page A8.

title: Johnson Tested By Miami Legacy
description: Without a doubt, Jimmy Johnson is in a tough spot as the new head football coach at the University of Miami.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFING
description: Trust and Advertising

title: CITY NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jockey Sits Down
description: Kenny Black , taken off his mounts at Hollywood Park in California last week when a urinalysis he volunteered for showed traces of cocaine in his system, has decided not to ride for the rest of the meeting, which ends July 23. The 20-year-old Black is the sixth-leading rider at Hollywood Park with 28 victories.

title: ROWE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GIANTS TRADE VAN PELT
description: The owner of the nine-hole Club Ten golf course in Owosso, Mich., was called to the telephone yesterday to learn that he had been traded, but not any closer to his clubhouse. He is Brad Van Pelt, who, after five years of asking to be dealt away from the Giants, was sent to the Minnesota Vikings in exchange for Tony Galbreath, a badly needed backup fullback.

title: A NOVELIST FINDS AN UNEASY HAVEN IN EAST BERLIN
description: Four days ago, thanks to the Freedom of Information Act, Stefan Heym received an envelope with copies of pages in a file that the Federal Bureau of Investigation kept on him during the anti-Communist fervor of the McCarthy years.

title: CHICAGO PAPERS TAKE UP THE CUDGELS
description: It was a page out of the old rough-and-tumble history of Chicago journalism. When the jury reached a verdict in the Federal trial of a local judge on corruption charges, the editors of The Chicago Sun-Times called in workers and rushed an extra edition off the presses, several hours ahead of the usual schedule.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KIEWIT BREAKS WITH TRADITION
description: Although Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. is not well known around the nation, the construction and mining company is the stuff of legend in this agribusiness center along the Missouri River.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable Aug. 1.

title: A WEEKEND OF FREE MUSIC IN THE PARKS
description: With luck, a soft breeze will ruffle T-shirts and summer dresses this weekend as listeners in parks across the city settle back on benches, blankets and folding chairs to listen to free concerts of Strauss waltzes and other standbys of the band repertory, jazz and blues, Puccini and Gershwin.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Vice President - it has such a nice ring to it.'' - Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro. (A8:1.)

title: TRANSCRIPT OF MONDALE ANNOUNCEMENT AND REPRESENTATIVE FERRARO'S REPLY
description: Following is a transcript of remarks in St. Paul yesterday by Walter F. Mondale and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MONDALE DECISION:PRAISE IGNORES RISKS
description: Democratic leaders today greeted Walter F. Mondale's choice of a woman as his running mate as a bold attempt to reshape his political image and to fire up what some feared would become a humdrum, almost hopeless challenge against President Reagan. By proposing Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens as the first woman to be nominated by a major party, they said, Mr. Mondale had acquired a political partner whose background and policies seemed tailor-made for offsetting Mr. Reagan's strengths.

title: AMY ALCOTT CONTINUES STREAK
description: Amy Alcott, winner of this event in 1981, overcame the distractions of slow play today, shot a one-under-par 71 and shared the lead with Jo Ann Washam in the first round of the United States Women's Open.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESS IN SOUTH AFRICA CAN BE A FORCE FOR CHANGE
description: Before pop singer Michael Jackson completes his schedule for his tour of the United States, he should do America a favor and add one more stop - Soweto, the largest black township in South Africa.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WARTS AND ALL, THE BUDGET ACT IS 10 YEARS OLD
description: Today marked the 10th anniversary of the signing of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, which established the Congressional budget process now in use. But the anniversary went largely unnoticed in the Capitol, except for a barbecue at nearby Fort Washington, Md., attended by House and Senate Budget Committee staff members who have worked largely behind the scenes for the last decade.

title: ABORTION FOE PARADOX
description: To the Editor:

title: A CONSERVATIVE FUND'S METHOD
description: WHEN Stephen Tabb picks up a company's annual report, he skips the glossy pictures in the front and starts reading from the back ''to check the financials,'' as he puts it.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Playing Safe on Auto Safety
description: Secretary Dole's new ruling on air bags and other car safety restraints is a compromise crafted to disarm political opposition. It may be the most that could be expected from an Administration so hostile to Federal safety regulation. But it's still a lost opportunity to save lives on the road.

title: Utah Governor Insists Mondale Offered Post
description: Gov. Scott M. Matheson of Utah reasserted Wednesday that Walter F. Mondale had offered him a high-level Government position if the former Vice President won the Presidential election in November.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fleet Financial
description: The Fleet Financial Group yesterday priced $75 million worth of one- year extendable notes carrying a final maturity of July 15, 1991. The notes were priced at par and carry a coupon of 13 percent. Salomon Brothers is acting as the lead underwriter for the issue, which has been rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: How the Word Was Greeted
description: Most prominent Democrats said the choice of Geraldine A. Ferraro would help the party in November.

title: Strike Costs VW Profits
description: Volkswagen, West Germany's largest auto maker, lost $180 million in profits because of the seven-week metalworkers' strike for a shorter workweek, Carl Hahn, company chairman, said today.

title: Joint Hong Kong Panel Is British-Chinese Issue
description: China and Britain ended another round of talks today on the future of Hong Kong. The discussions were said to have included a Chinese proposal for a joint committee to monitor events leading up to the transition of authority for the colony.

title: Precedents in House On Bid for No. 2 Post
description: If Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro wins the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination, she will be the fourth member of the House of Representatives in this century to run as a major-party Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: STEELMAKERS HAIL LINK OF RELIEF TO MODERNIZING
description: Representatives of the American steel industry, eager to win the protection against imports recommended by the International Trade Commission, today applauded the agency's proposal to make such protection dependent on industry efforts to modernize.

title: JUDGE BLOCKS CUOMO PLAN TO USE STATE WORKERS IN VOTER REGISTRATION EFFORT
description: A State Supreme Court justice today temporarily blocked Governor Cuomo's plan to use state employees to conduct voter registration drives in state offices.

title: METS GET 5 RUNS IN NINTH TO WIN
description: If Manager Dave Johnson was looking for an omen to indicate how things might go for the next three months, he may have found a good one tonight.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RIVAL PRO-SYRIAN FACTIONS CONTINUE BATTLE IN NORTH LEBANON
description: A second day of pitched battles raged in northern Lebanon today between two pro-Syrian factions, and Damascus rushed a special envoy to the region in an effort to end the conflict.

title: PARKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a $15.7 million writeoff of manufacturing inventory writedowns, accounts and notes receivables writeoffs and drill pipe writeoffs.

title: ORIOLE SWEEP ENDS WHITE SOX STREAK
description: Scott McGregor hurled a four-hitter, and Cal Ripken had a homer as the Baltimore Orioles defeated Chicago, 3-0, and completed a sweep of tonight's twilight-night doubleheader with the White Sox.

title: HUDSON VALLEY 'BATTLE' AND FESTIVALS
description: The Hudson Valley is blossoming with activities this weekend, including a re-enactment of a battle of the American Revolution, an old-stone- house tour, a German Alps festival and a farm festival.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $750,000. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend in March 1984.

title: MORE WARS IN 'LAST STARFIGHTER'
description: In a summer holding no promise of a fresh new installment in the ''Star Wars'' saga, terrestrial yearning for entertainment culled from outer space will have to content itself with ''The Last Starfighter,'' today's arrival at the Rivoli and other theaters.

title: SMOG TROUBLES UEBERROTH
description: Organizers of the Summer Olympics said today that they were concerned about a severe smog attack that has blanketed much of Los Angeles with foul air this month but that they had no plans yet to change the schedule of competition for the Games, which start in 16 days.

title: LIBERAL DEMOCRAT FROM QUEENS
description: Six years ago, running on the campaign slogan of ''Finally, a tough Democrat,'' Geraldine A. Ferraro, an Assistant District Attorney, the mother of three children, the product of a Roman Catholic, working-class, big-city background, won election to the House of Representatives.

title: Jewel Tender
description: The American Stores Company said its AS Acquisition Company unit is purchasing 8,780,316 common shares and 2,131,395 series A $2.31 cumulative convertible preferred shares of the Jewel Companies under a cash tender offer that expired on June 28. American said the share purchases represent about 75.5 percent of all properly tendered common and preferred shares. American said it now owns Jewel common and preferred shares representing, or convertible into, about 67 percent of the outstanding and issuable common shares.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Bergen Strikers Return to Work
description: Most striking Bergen County employees obeyed a back-to- work order today and ended a walkout over the hiring of three nonunion clerical workers.

title: ARGENTINE LOANS HURT 4 BANKS
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation - the largest lender to Argentina - reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were reduced by $21.4 million as the result of its loans to that financially troubled country.

title: Harte-Hanks Cable Offering
description: Harte-Hanks Cable Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. of San Antonio, said yesterday that it had begun a public offering of $50 million worth of subordinated debentures and zero- coupon subordinated notes.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GERMANIZED 'CLASS ENEMY' OPENS
description: ''Class Enemy,'' which opens today at the Vandam Theater, is of somewhat more theatrical than cinematic interest, being a German film adaptation of Nigel Williams's English play, now set in West Berlin, instead of London, and directed for the screen by Peter Stein, one of the more celebrated figures in the European theater.

title: JAPANESE WHALERS' MISDIRECTED PROTESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BARBARA LEWIS
description: Barbara Lewis, a writer and a former reporter for The Associated Press, died Tuesday, her 56th birthday, at her home in Manhattan after a long illness.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL WON'T PAY BANKRUPTCY JUDGES
description: The tangled story of the Federal bankruptcy court system has taken another odd twist with the refusal by the Federal judiciary's top administrative officer to pay the salaries of the nation's bankruptcy judges - or former judges, as he calls them.

title: CUOMO CITES SAFETY STUDIES AS HE SIGNS SEAT-BELT LAW
description: Legislation requiring automobile drivers and their front-seat passengers to wear seat belts was signed into law yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: G.M. Will Reopen An Assembly Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that because of the demand for larger cars it will reopen an assembly plant idle since 1982, and cancel plans to close a second factory.

title: THE REGION ; ;  No-Smoking Law Signed by Cohalan
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, today signed into law a bill requiring large offices to segregate smokers and nonsmokers and large restaurants to provide no-smoking sections or air filters.

title: CHIEF TAKING LEAVE AT MICHIGAN BANK
description: Stanford C. Stoddard, the 53-year- old chairman and chief executive of the Michigan National Corporation, will take an indefinite leave of absence, the bank holding company announced yesterday. In a statement, Michigan National said: ''As previously disclosed, regulatory authorities are conducting various inquiries concerning the corporation.''

title: Smurfit Group Ends Loan Pact
description: Jefferson Smurfit Group Ltd. said it had terminated a $550 million credit line it set up in an attempt to acquire Southwest Forest Industries.

title: Bangladesh Election Set
description: The election commissioner said today that voters would choose a 300-member Parliament on Dec. 8, six months later than scheduled. The official, A. K. M. Nurul Islam, did not say when presidential elections would be held. Opposition parties are demanding an end to military rule.

title: CUBAN-U.S. MEETING ON REFUGEE MEETING IS REPORTED
description: Cuban and United States officials began discussions in New York yesterday about immigration issues, including the possible return of 1,000 Cuban refugees who came to the United States during the 1980 boatlift, a Reagan Administration source said last night.

title: ...FIASCO ON ARMS ENTERS STAGE THREE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION ; ;  Credit Card Calls Repaid by Official 13.4
description: State Treasurer Henry E. Parker, who acknowledged that family members were using his state-issued telephone credit card for personal calls, reimbursed the state $2,201.94 today to cover the cost of those calls.

title: People
description: * Peggy Healy named senior vice president and business manager for DYR Worldwide.

title: Paying Dividends
description: The Enterra Corporation said its directors had voted to eliminate the company's dividend.

title: Mary Decker's Decision
description: After deciding that the physical toll taken when she ran in the preliminaries and finals in the 1,500-meter and 3,000-meter races at the Olympic track and field trials last month might result in a serious injury or otherwise lessen her chances to win a gold medal at the Olympic Games, Mary Decker said that she would return home to Eugene, Ore., and choose between the two events. Yesterday she said that she would run in the 3,000. ''I am disappointed and wish I could run in both events,'' Miss Decker said: ''but I risk losing a gold medal.

title: REAGAN PEACE POLICY TRIUMPH...
description: To the Editor:

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ONTARIO'S SEAT BELT LAW HAILED FOR SAVING LIVES
description: While patrolling a main commuter highway on the outskirts here, Constable Stephen McEdwards noticed sunlight reflecting off the clasp of an unbuckled seat belt in a sports car in the next lane.

title: Singer to Sell Part Of Malaysia Unit
description: The Singer Company said it had agreed to sell 48 percent of its consumer durables subsidiary in Malaysia to Berjaya Kawat Berhad, a company based in that nation. The transaction is part of Singer's plan to sell 51 percent of the unit; the additional 3 percent will be sold to other local investors in Malaysia.

title: POP: NINA SIMONE SINGS
description: Isn't music wonderful! I think it's the salvation of the earth!,'' Nina Simone burst out near the end of her opening set at the Blue Note last Wednesday. Though not many pop performers can back up this kind of statement with music that seems intent on really changing peoples lives, Miss Simone's singing has that kind of emotional fervor.

title: Relatives in Italy Celebrate
description: ''Champagne for everyone!'' a relative of Geraldine A. Ferraro shouted today after hearing that the Congresswoman was Walter F. Mondale's choice as his running mate on the Democratic ticket. The Representative from Queens has more than a half-dozen relatives in this town of 2,400 people about 30 miles north of Naples and in another nearby community.

title: HYTEK MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS: DEADLY CATCH
description: ASIA RIP. By George Foy. 266 pages. Viking Press, New York. $16.95. If you're headed for Cape Cod

title: SCULPTURE GOES OUTDOORS FOR SUMMER
description: Even beyond the 25 Henry Moores that are on display throughout the boroughs, this is a very good summer for outdoor sculpture. There are many works by less-known and in some instances unknown sculptors that can alter the way we experience our surroundings. The outdoor sculpture this year is a reminder of how much good art continues to be produced by artists working outside or on the periphery of the New York City gallery system.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FERRARO SPEECH ON FOREIGN POLICY TO WORLD AFFAIRS COUNCIL
description: Following is a transcript of remarks in St. Paul yesterday by Walter F. Mondale and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: O'NEILL FELT REP. FERRARO COULD BE FORCE IN PARTY
description: When Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, endorsed Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro for the Vice-Presidential nomination last May, some of his fellow Democrats expressed surprise and irritation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Aid for Addabbo

title: Turk Flees Into Greece
description: A 31-year-old Turkish political refugee escaped into Greece despite being shot and wounded while half way across the Evros River bridge separating the two countries, the police in the Greek city of Salonika said today.

title: YANKS TOP ROYALS: NIEKRO WINS 12TH
description: As Yogi Berra looked ahead to the second half of the season, he remarked wishfully, ''Maybe we can start the second half the way Detroit started the first half.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE BROWSER'S BOOK OF BEGINNINGS: Origins of Everything Under

title: Ally & Gargano
description: Larry Dexheimer, senior vice president and director of media services at Ally & Gargano, has been named acting chairman of the newly formed operations committee.

title: 4 Polish Sailors Jump Ship
description: Four Polish sailors have defected from sailing vessels taking part in an international display of tall ships around Canadian ports. Two sailors jumped ship in Toronto Wednesday from the Tryglaw before it left for Rochester, N.Y., while two others defected from the square-rigger Dar Mlodzieizy in Nova Scotia at the start of a tall ships race to Britain. Last month, a sailor from the Dar Mlodzieizy jumped ship in Halifax.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.6 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply declined by $1.6 billion in the week ended July 2, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday.

title: TO IDENTIFY AND TREAT A MENTAL DISORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY ;  FRIDAY, JULY 13, 1984 International
description: The Soviet-American hot line for emergency communication between the two governments is to be modernized under an agreement expected to be initialed in the next few days. Administration officials and foreign diplomats say the accord is part of an expanding agenda of nonpolitical discussions. (Page A1, Column 2.) Britian expelled two Nigerian diplomats and informed Nigeria's chief envoy, who was recalled to Lagos, that he was not welcome to return. Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons that the action came after Nigeria turned down a request from authorities that they be allowed to question several members of Nigeria's diplomatic staff about the July 5 kidnapping of a wealthy Nigerian exile, Umaru Dikko. (A1:1.)

title: ON HER CONSTITUENTS, ARMS AND ABORTION
description: Following are some of the views expressed by Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens on major issues:

title: Man of the Hour
description: Diego Armando Maradona of Argentina has been widely considered the best soccer player in the world since Pele, Franz Beckenbauer, Johan Cruyff and Georgie Best were in their prime. His talents have been appreciated everywhere in the world, especially in Italy.

title: Unhappy Giant
description: Disappointed over the team's showing this season, Al Oliver of the San Francisco Giants said he would ask to be traded if the club did not come back from its last-place position to win a division title. He said there were two reasons he was disclosing his plans to ask for a trade now.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: Chrysler Sets Bonus Package

title: Redmen on Radio
description: St. John's basketball fans, especially those who cannot be squeezed into the 6,000 seats at the Alumni Hall gymnasium, should be pleased that all 27 games on the Redmen's 1984-85 schedule will be broadcast over WCBS-AM radio, 880 on the dial. Postseason games will also be broadcast.

title: AL HIRT QUITS BOURBON ST. FOR THE ROAD, DROPS IN ON FAT TUESDAY'S
description: Al Hirt, the big, bearded trumpet player, whose publicity used to proclaim him ''The King,'' is in New York for the first time in more than a decade, appearing at Fat Tuesday's through Sunday. After spending almost 15 years at home in New Orleans, where he had his own club on Bourbon Street, Mr. Hirt is on the road again.

title: HART CALLS SELECTION 'A GOOD CHOICE'
description: Senator Gary Hart today called Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro ''a good choice'' as Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee but vowed to continue his own Presidential campaign.

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOWER PROPOSED WITH 130 FLOORS AT 59TH ST. SITE
description: Consultants to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have submitted a dozen possible development plans for the Columbus Circle site occupied by the New York Coliseum, including one for the world's tallest building, M.T.A. officials said yesterday.

title: St. Regis Trading
description: Shares of the St. Regis Corporation jumped $2.875, to $44.375, yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange amid widespread expectation that Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, was preparing a takeover bid for the company. Insiders said Mr. Murdoch would file new papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission today acknowledging, among other things, that he had met with his bankers to discuss a possible hostile tender offer for St. Regis. They said, however, that Mr. Murdoch will say that he still has no intention of making a tender offer.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STOCK SUIT BROADENED BY S.E.C.
description: An insider trading case involving the merger between the Santa Fe International Corporation and the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation has grown to involve six more defendants, including the Minister of the Interior in Qatar and a leading Qatari businessman; a Jordanian businessman with offices in Beirut, London and New York; a resident of Surrey, England, and a Lichtenstein-based foundation.

title: PRESIDENT HAILED AT CAMPERS' RALLY
description: President Reagan got an enthusiastic welcome from tourists at a vast campground of recreational vehicles today as he asserted that he had saved the national park system and the environment in general from the neglect of his predecessors.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: INTEL DOUBLES
description: Aided by increases in its industrial, broadcasting and commercial divisions, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday reported a 32.9 percent rise in second-quarter profits.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, twilight-night doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, 5:30 P.M. A disappointing Ron Guidry tries to even his record at 7-7. (Television - SportsChannel, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 5:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. An important series between division threats continues. The Mets go with Walt Terrell, and the Braves counter with Pascual Perez, who is looking for his 10th victory. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:15 P.M.) Golf

title: GYM NIGHTS SET FOR WELFARE CHILDREN
description: The Koch administration will begin an evening recreation program Monday for children living in welfare hotels near Times Square, officials said yesterday.

title: Y BOYS' CAMP: 100 YEARS OF FUN AND PRINCIPLES
description: The 400 boys had just finished a traditional Saturday night supper of franks and beans when a Camp Dudley counselor rose to make an announcement.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Across the river, food with a view.

title: Beech-Nut Baby Food Campaign
description: THE problem that the people from Nestle S.A. inherited when they acquired Beech-Nut baby food was a declining consumption pattern - the average American child had cut back from 54 dozen jars to 44 dozen. And that's not good for business.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Beaches Stay Shut In Westchester
description: Six Westchester County beaches remained closed today because of untreated sewage that was discharged into the water because of heavy weekend rain, county officials said.

title: Bridge: British Parliamentary Team Easily Beats U.S. Opponent
description: The British Parliament, perhaps seeking revenge two centuries too late, scored a substantial bridge victory against its American opponents in Washington on Wednesday.

title: GREENPOINT, AT LAST, GETS NEW HOME DELVELOPMENT
description: In the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, just south of Newtown Creek, which forms the border with Queens near the East River, the housing stock has been a model of stability.

title: Profit Posted At Reynolds
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said today that it earned $37.3 million, or $1.74 a share, in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $69.1 million a year earlier.

title: Thorn-EMI Will Buy A 76% Stake in Inmos
description: Thorn-EMI P.L.C., one week after withdrawing its bid for British Aerospace, announced today that it would buy the British Government's 76 percent stake in Inmos, the state-controlled manufacturer of semiconductor chips, for $124.1 million.

title: C.F.A. Agrees on Plan
description: The College Football Association announced yesterday that all 63 of its members had committed themselves to being part of the television sales plan that the association is putting together for the coming season.

title: M.I.S.L.'s Pride Preparing to Fold
description: The Phoenix Pride of the Major Indoor Soccer League is ceasing operations after four seasons, an informed source said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Ed Norton Resurfaces

title: Hosea Williams ShiftsOn Runoff Primaries
description: Hosea Williams, a candidate for Georgia's Fifth District seat in Congress, has dropped his opposition to runoff primaries, saying Wednesday that his own campaign would be doomed without one.

title: No Headline
description: 45 Held in Drug Raids In 3 Counties in Jersey

title: CHICAGO & NORTH WESTERN TRANSPORTATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results reflect a change in accounting for depreciation of track structure adopted in the fourth quarter of 1983.

title: ISRAELIS INCONSPICUOUSLY RESUME ACTIVITIES IN AFRICA
description: The arrest of three Israelis in connection with the kidnapping of a former Nigerian Cabinet minister in London has focused attention on a subject about which little is known: the growing presence of Israelis in African countries that years ago broke relations with the state of Israel.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a net charge of $3.2 million for the quarter for termination pay and other costs associated with the closing of the company's mining operation in Jamaica and a LIFO GAIN OF $400,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after a charge of $52.7 million for the quarter and 6 months for the writeoff of several uneconomic production facilities and LIFO inventory gains of $10.2 million for the quarter and $16.3 million for the 6 months.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Woman's Killer To Be Executed
description: A man who pleaded guilty to the sexual assault and murder of a 38- year-old woman was sentenced to death by a Superior Court jury tonight, officials said.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D. INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
French Prices Up O.5%
description: French retail prices grew five-tenths of 1 percent in May and again in June, but the monthly rises were still below the seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in April, the national statistics institute said today. The increase brought the price rise in the 12 months through June to 7.7 percent, compared with 7.8 percent during the year ended in May.

title: Knicks Get Cummings
description: The Knicks clinched a deal yesterday for Pat Cummings, the free-agent center-forward, by compensating his former team, the Dallas Mavericks, with draft choices in the next two years. In return, the Mavericks agreed not to match the offer sheet that Cummings signed with the Knicks.

title: Lone Star Country Fare
description: Jerry Jeff Walker, the country-rock singer and songwriter, is appearing at the Lone Star Cafe (242-1664), Fifth Avenue and 13th Street, tonight at 8:30 with the Lost Gonzo Band. Admission is $12.

title: TELEDYNE RISES SHARPLY ON INVESTMENT GAINS
description: Teledyne Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter, ended June 30, rose almost fivefold, to $355.7 million, or $20.65 a share, from $72.6 million, or $3.54 a share, in the comparable quarter last year.

title: Italy's Budget Minister Quits Over Scandal
description: Italy's Budget Minister, Pietro Longo, linked by a parliamentary report to a spurious Masonic lodge, resigned today, the Italian news agency ANSA said.

title: How Skyscrapers Grew
description: ''Manhattan Skyline: New York Skyscrapers Between the Wars,'' an exhibition on the development of New York's skyscrapers during the 1920's and early 30's is on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, through Sept. 23.

title: ART: 7 ABSTRACTIONS BY NORMAN BLUHM ON L.I.
description: A bellwether Norman Bluhm is not: he's been absent too long from the New York scene, though well known in Europe, to be an example to any but dissenters like himself. But his ''Seven From the 70's'' show, at the State University's Fine Arts Center in Stony Brook, L.I., remarkable enough in itself, also paves the way for another event of equal importance. This is an exhibition scheduled for the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center after its run at the Newport Harbor Art Museum in Newport Beach, Calif., which focuses on Bluhm, Michael Goldberg, Grace Hartigan, Al Held, Al Leslie and Joan Mitchell as they were in the 1950's.

title: CENSUS DATA SHOW RESULT OF TAX CUT
description: The Census Bureau today issued a report on household income that confirms neither President Reagan's view of his tax cut nor the views of his Democratic critics.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 29.

title: Allen Envisions a 2-League Title Game
description: The way George Allen sees it, the National Football League will have to effect an eventual accommodation with the United States Football League, one that would bring about a game between the champions of the two leagues.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Stevie Wonder Interviewed On 'Tony Brown's Journal'
description: Stevie Wonder, one of America's greatest songwriters, also gives one of the pop world's least enlightening interviews. On an episode of ''Tony Brown's Journal'' called ''Stevie Wonder Plays His Own Keys of Life,'' on Sunday at 4 P.M. on Channel 13, Mr. Wonder's most eloquent moments are a snippet from a 1964 ''Teentown'' show, when he was Little Stevie Wonder, and two short excerpts from the Detroit concert recently broadcast on the Showtime cable channel.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COASTLAND CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: JUDGE CENSURED OVER RACIAL SLUR IN STATE SUPREME COURT IN QUEENS
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens was censured by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct yesterday for having used a racial slur in court.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Beneficial Tax Centers Inc., a subsidiary of Beneficial Corp., said it had signed an agreement with Montgomery Ward to operate income tax preparation services in about 175 Montgomery Ward stores.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $2,908,000 from the transfer of consolidated long-term debt into an irrevocable trust.

title: STEPS URGED TO HELP CURB AIR TRAFFIC DELAYS
description: High-level Government and industry officials yesterday completed a package of recommendations to alleviate the huge increase in air traffic delays.

title: Stock Exchange PicksMcCaffrey & McCall
description: McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing has been tapped to do the first advertising for the New York Stock Exchange's Options division and New York Futures Exchange.

title: Assets of Money Market Funds Up in Week
description: Assets of the nation's 332 money market mutual funds rose $1.33 billion, to $175.39 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Amoco Chemicals
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said its Amoco Chemicals Corporation unit had agreed in principle to acquire the Gulf Corporation's polypropylene facilities at the Cedar Bayou chemicals complex near Baytown, Tex.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN JOURNAL FRAUD CASE
description: Peter N. Brant, a stockbroker charged with profiting from advance knowledge of articles in The Wall Street Journal, pleaded guilty yesterday to three criminal charges of conspiracy and fraud.

title: FOOD STAND GUIDE TO HAMPTONS
description: On a recent Sunday, as a steady line of traffic made its way westward along the Montauk Highway, a large tour bus pulled into the parking lot of a farmstand in Sagaponack, L.I. Sixty or so sightseers crowded into the simple building and bought berries, cucumbers, lettuces and pies. Like the windmills, mansions, beaches and villages, vegetables and baked goods have become tourist attractions in the Hamptons, especially on weekends.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE LABS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Firsts
description: So much for the snickers about Boring Mondale, the candidate who ''dares to be cautious.'' So much for the punditry of Richard Nixon, who predicted that Walter Mondale would pick Gary Hart as his running mate. So much for those who said the Mondale interviewing process evoked Jimmy Carter. Mr. Mondale's choice of Geraldine Ferraro turned out to be more reminiscent of Lyndon Johnson's love of surprise, drama and history.

title: TV WEEKEND ; KIRK DOUGLAS WESTERN; VIEW OF STEVIE WONDER
description: Home Box Office, the pay-television service, is now earnestly in the business of producing made- for-cable movies. A few weeks ago, HBO ran a sneak preview of its ''premiere film'' ''Sakharov,'' a sketchy portrait of the Russian dissident. Sunday at 8 P.M., there is ''Draw!,'' a $2.5-million western, starring Kirk Douglas and James Coburn.

title: CUBS TOP DODGERS ON HOMER IN 10TH, 3-2
description: Ryne Sandberg led off the bottom of the 10th inning with a home run today to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Nevada Theft Suspects Arrested in Paraguay
description: A bank employee and her friend, accused of stealing $2.7 million in one of the largest bank thefts in Nevada history, have been arrested in South America, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has announced.

title: SUPREME COURT TURNS DOWN PLEA FOR STAY OF MURDERER'S EXECUTION
description: The Supreme Court late tonight denied a stay of execution for David Leroy Washington, clearing the way for the confessed murderer of three to be executed in Florida shortly after dawn.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday with an article about the Cosmos misidentified the player taking control of the ball. He was Steve Wegerle of the Tampa Bay Rowdies.

title: GIBSON, C.R. CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WOMEN RAN FOR OFFICE BEFORE THEY COULD VOTE
description: If she becomes the first woman to be nominated for Vice President by a major party, as is expected, Geraldine A. Ferraro will be the newest member of a distinguished if diverse sisterhood of political pioneers.

title: Sears Project To Thompson
description: in Chicago confirmed yesterday that it had retained The J.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
6 ARRESTED FOR FAKE MEDICAL DEGREES, INCLUDING 3 KNOWN AS DOCTORS
description: Six people, three of them working as doctors, were arrested yesterday in the New York City area on criminal charges of possessing fraudulent medical degrees, and the state authorities said about 100 others would face similar charges in the near future.

title: VLADIMIR A. ENGELHARDT DIES;PROMINENT SOVIET BIOCHEMIST
description: Vladimir A. Engelhardt, one of the Soviet Union's most prominent biochemists and director of the Soviet Institute of Molecular Biology, died Tuesday at the age of 89, the Soviet Government's official press agency, Tass, reported yesterday. The announcement did not include the cause of his death.

title: ENTITLEMENTS DO THE MIDDLE CLASS NO FAVORS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: The longer evenings of summer

title: Parked Rail Cars at Issue In Carolina Train Crash
description: Highway patrolmen said today that idle freight cars were parked so close to a railway crossing that a tanker truck driver could not see the Amtrak passenger train that hit him, killing two men and dragging cars loaded with 309 passengers through ensuing fire.

title: Mitterrand Responds To Critics on Liberties
description: President Francois Mitterrand, seeking to head off opposition charges that his Government has sought to limit personal freedom, announced tonight that he would seek a constitutional amendment permitting national referendums on issues involving ''public liberties.''

title: FILM: BROADWAY SETTING FOR 3D MUPPET ROMP
description: ''The Muppets Take Manhattan''doesn't quite tell the entire story. With their various television shows and two feature films already under their felt belts, Jim Henson's Muppets have long since taken not only Manhattan, but also London, Los Angeles, Eugene, Ore., and Chillicothe, Ohio. All that notwithstanding to the contraire, as Miss Piggy might wish to dire, they arrive today at the National and other theaters, and nous sommes theirs.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Gain for Owens-Illinois
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. today reported second-quarter earnings of $40.8 million, or $1.45 a share, up 35 percent from $30.2 million, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent, to $908.5 million, from $889.1 million. Strength in forest products was cited.

title: MANY FEMINISTS ARE ELATED
description: Prominent Democrats yesterday rallied around Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, Walter F. Mondale's choice for the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination, and feminist leaders praised the selection as a historic breakthrough.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Federal Employee Charged in Fraud
description: A Social Security Administration employee was indicted yesterday on charges that she had misappropriated $67,000 by devising a computer scheme in which scores of checks were issued to beneficiaries who were dead or could not be found.

title: Taiwan Closes Mines As Toll Rises to 101
description: The Government today ordered Taiwan's 124 coal mines closed for safety checks after the country's worst mine disaster. The death toll rose to 101 today, and the search continued for two miners still missing.

title: A BAD BEST CASE
description: President Reagan ''appears to have written off serious arms control efforts,'' I wrote in this space on May 25, and to have chosen instead ''to seek military superiority behind the high-tech 'strategic defensive system' commonly called Star Wars. . . .''

title: Affordable Mental Health
description: An hour with a New York City psychiatrist can cost $150 - unaffordable for many even when health insurance pays half. Yet proper help need not cost that much.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Bonn Aide Warns U.S. On Troop Cut Threats

title: PUBLISHING: WAS KATHERINE PORTER AN INFORMER?
description: The novelist and critic Josephine Herbst was not widely known when she died in 1969, and Elinor Langer did not even hear of her until 1973. But Miss Langer's new biography, ''Josephine Herbst'' (Atlantic-Little, Brown), is likely to make the novelist's name better known - and it will undoubtedly raise some eyebrows because of the charges it makes against the late Katherine Anne Porter.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MYTH AND MASKS AT MET

title: ; Man behind the Muppets has a secret.
description: Do a blue-eyed pig dressed in white, a very nervous frog and a man in a clerical collar spell marriage? Well, Frank Oz, director and principal scriptwriter of ''The Muppets Take Manhattan,'' is not about to tell us whether Miss Piggy takes Kermit in holy wedlock - at last. ''We're dropping hints, but we really want to keep it a secret,'' he says. For those who cannot bear to wait another moment for the answer, the latest Muppet movie opens today in theaters all over the metropolitan area and across the country (reviewed on page C10).

title: Gerdes at Speakeasy
description: The folk singer George Gerdes will perform at Speakeasy (598-9670), 107 Macdougal Street, today and tomorrow at 9 and 11:30 P.M. There is a $5 cover charge.

title: RAYTHEON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $96.4 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $1 million. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.3 million.

title: New Role for Bradshaw
description: Terry Bradshaw, who hedged a month ago on his retirement plans despite a painful throwing arm, is now resigned to ending his football career and announced as much yesterday. ''I'm facing the fact that I'm not going to be able to play,'' Bradshaw said from his northern Louisiana ranch.

title: No Headline
description: Aquarium Arrivals

title: Laurie Anderson Show
description: A retrospective exhibition of multimedia work by the performance artist Laurie Anderson is on view at the Queens Museum in Flushing through Sept. 9.

title: Marketing ExpertiseFor Physicians
description: If physicians who have no marketing knowledge are the highest-paid professionals, imagine how well they might do with marketing knowledge.

title: Goldman, Sachs Prices Bonds
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday priced $158.2 million worth of collateralized mortgage obligation bonds.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOP GRASS RUNNERS IN 3 WEEKEND TESTS
description: The best grass horses in the East, in all three major divisions, will be running this weekend at either Belmont Park or Atlantic City Race Course. The action begins with the Grade III Lexington Stakes for 3-year-olds at Belmont tomorrow, continues with the Grade I United Nations Handicap at Atlantic City tomorrow night, and concludes with, perhaps the best of all, the Grade I Sheepshead Bay Handicap at Belmont Sunday.

title: Baker Gets G.O.P. Post Of Temporary Chairman
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee will be the temporary chairman of the 1984 Republican National Convention, party officials announced Wednesday.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ONE OF 8 DELOREAN DRUG CHARGES DISMISSED, BUT TRIAL GOES ON
description: Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi today dismissed one count of a nine-count indictment charging John Z. DeLorean with possession and conspiracy to sell cocaine and dropped from the charges two of 20 acts he was accused of committing to advance the conspiracy.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Cuomo Is 'O.K.' AfterCarAccident
description: ''A little stiff, but otherwise O.K.'' was how Governor Cuomo said he felt yesterday, a day after his car was struck from behind by another while he was in Buffalo.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quaker State Deal For First Heritage
description: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation said it would acquire the First Heritage Corporation, a California insurance concern, in an exchange of stock valued at about $38 million.

title: DIVERSITY STAMPS THE FERRARO DISTRICT
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro's Ninth Congressional District in the northwestern corner of Queens is an unlikely launching pad for a national political career.

title: Donald G. Herold Dead at 57; RanBuffaloScienceMuseum
description: Donald G. Herold, director of the Buffalo Museum of Science, died Tuesday while leading a group on a tour of Mexico, apparently of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS IN TURKEY:IS THE GLASS HALF EMPTY OR HALF FULL?
description: Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, is in Turkey this week, where he has an opportunity to exercise some much needed quiet diplomacy.

; AN E.R.A.'S UNKNOWABLE CONSEQUENCES
description: To the Editor:

NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: ABC News Campaign Has A Political Theme
description: ABC News, inspired by Leonard H. Goldenson, chairman of the American Broadcasting Companies, is combining a get-out-the-vote campaign with a watch-our-coverage campaign of sizable proportions. The TV portion started on the network last Tuesday and the newspaper advertising, using the same nationally known political figures, starts this Monday.

title: ART: SCULPTURE ON THE SANDS OF BATTERY PARK CITY
description: The construction of Battery Park City draws ominously closer to the sandy acreage of ''Art on the Beach,'' the sculpture and performance show now having its sixth summer run (through Sept. 16) on the landfill at West and Chambers Streets. But though the site - alas! - will be swallowed up in a year or two, the spirit is still strong.

title: TWO PLANNED FLIGHTS OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE ARE TO BE COMBINED
description: The space agency announced today that it would combine the space shuttle Discovery's first and second flights into one mission, scheduled to begin Aug. 24.

title: Stocks Are Lower In Quiet Trading
description: Stock prices finished slightly lower yesterday in subdued trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BRITAIN EXPELS 2 NIGERIA AIDES AND BARS ENVOY
description: Britain has ordered two Nigerian diplomats to leave the country and informed Nigeria's chief envoy that he is not welcome to return, Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Foreign Secretary, said today.

title: MEXICAN ARMY ACCUSED ON GUATEMALA EXILES
description: A Roman Catholic diocese in southern Mexico says the Mexican Army tortured and killed three Guatemalan refugees last week and has denied food to thousands of refugees along the Mexican-Guatemalan border.

title: Dining Out Guide: Country Dining, New Jersey
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the New Jersey Weekly section of The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: JACKSON APPLAUDS MONDALE ON 'CLOSING OF GENDER GAP'
description: In glowing terms such as ''breakthrough,'' ''giant step'' and ''major victory,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson today extolled Walter F. Mondale's selection of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro as his running mate.

title: OPEC Trade Deficit
description: The overall current account deficit of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should narrow to about $10 billion in 1984, from $20 billion in 1983, Deutsche Bank said today.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Central Park Fun LAKESIDE GAMES AND MUSIC a program with Barrie Kavasch, naturalist, Saturday at 1 P.M. (reservations required: 772-0210), and FOLK DANCES OF PANAMA, with the Molas of Panama, Sunday at 2 and 3 P.M., Belvedere Castle, 79th Street, south of the Great Lawn. Free. THE MUPPETS TAKE MANHATTAN: An Exhibition, a back-stage view of costume designs, set models, puppets and props from the film ''The Muppets Take Manhattan,'' with scenes from the film shown continuously Tuesdays through Sundays until Sept. 3, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., at the Central Park Dairy, 64th Street, east of the carousel, north of Wollman Rink. Free. Information: 397-3156.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
13 Killings in Uganda
description: Thirteen people were recently hacked to death by killers in two separate incidents in central Uganda, it was reported today. The independent Kampala daily Taifa Ya said the killings took place at Wattuba village, in Mubende district.

description: The Police Honor Sons of Liddy

title: Debt Ratings
description: Bangor Punta Corp.'s subordinated debt was upgraded by Moody's to Baa-1, from B-2, because of its recent assumption by Lear Siegler Inc., Bangor Punta's parent.

title: SEARLE, G.D. CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.3 million for the quarter and $1.9 million for the 6 months and a gain of $2.8 million for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Racist Is Convicted Of Bombing Synagogue
description: Joseph Paul Franklin was convicted today of the bombing of a Chattanooga synagogue in 1977 after he told the jury he had done it because it was the ''synagogue of Satan.''

title: TAX REFORM MUST END BIAS AGAINST SAVINGS
description: The major tax reform proposals now under discussion - fast, fair and flat - suffer from a common failing: they don't go far enough to correct the existing tax system's bias against savings and investment.

title: Dailey & AssociatesGets Teleflora Account
description: Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, the newest major member of the Interpublic Group of Companies, yesterday was named agency for Teleflora, the worldwide flower delivering service with a $6 million ad budget.

description: b-Including tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $994,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $222,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a gain of $1,111,000 for the 6 months from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Poll Shows Mondale Is Gaining on Reagan
description: A new Washington Post-ABC News poll shows that Walter F. Mondale trails President Reagan by 7 percentage points, substantially less than two major public opinion surveys issued recently.

title: DANCE: POOH KAYE'S 'WILD-FIELDS' IN DURHAM
description: The American Dance Festival has had a history of supporting experimental dance, starting with the founding of the Bennington College Summer School of Dance by Martha Hill, in 1934, to which the festival traces its beginnings. The original school and performing program gave four modern-dance pioneers - Martha Graham, Hanya Holm, Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman - a place and time to work, with students and their own dancers, on new choreography.

title: WATERS FOR NEW CANOEISTS
description: Beginning canoeists should limit their initial trips to gentle streams, several of which are situated in New Jersey's Pine Barrens.

title: Firm Warned On Reports
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday warned a New York public relations firm not to disseminate false or misleading information about publicly traded companies.

title: DANCE: TWYLA THARP AND '9 SINATRA SONGS'
description: Two of the premieres Twyla Tharp presented last January at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are back on view now to make up a program that will be repeated through July 22 at the Gershwin Theater.

title: Satellite TV Permit Given
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it had granted a second launch permit for a satellite-to-home television system to the United States Satellite Broadcasting Company, a subsidiary of Hubbard Broadcasting Inc. of St. Paul.

title: MT. NEBOH OWNER FACES FORECLOSURE THREAT
description: The owner of the former Mount Neboh Synagogue on West 79th Street must pay $500,000 by Monday or lose the landmark structure in a foreclosure auction.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Some Problems For a Koch Hangout

description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter rose 21 percent from a year earlier, mainly as a result of revived sales of its Carrier air-conditioners and automobile products.

description: * A. L. Laboratories Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., announced that Michael W. Keeler had joined the company as vice president-finance and chief financial officer.

description: The Federal Communications Commission today placed new limits on the authority of state and city governments to regulate the rates charged by cable television operators.

description: A group of investors headed by William Siegal, a former executive of ARA Services Inc., offered yesterday to buy the company for $60 a share, or $732 million.

title: CASE OF VATICAN ENVOY UNEXPLAINED
description: The State Department today made public its written policy on corporate directorships held by ambassadors but refused to explain how its decision allowing the Ambassador to the Vatican to keep two corporate posts had conformed with the guidelines.

title: NOTES, SORT OF, ON BENCHMARK FUZZ
description: No one has ever accused the Supreme Court of undue clarity, but the Court outdid itself in obscurity last week as it struggled to finish the 1983-84 term.

description: b-Including tax credits of $1,760,000 for the quarter and $3,441,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.
