title: BROADWAY;
description: Royal Shakespeare to offer a rare treat in classics here.

title: DETROIT EXPECTS PROBLEMS FROM AIR BAG DECISION
description: The nation's leading automobile manufacturers say they are concerned that a Government decision to require either air bags or automatic seat belts by 1990 would cause them substantial design and production problems.

title: U.S. REVISES STAND ON AID AND ABORTION
description: The White House gave final approval today to a policy statement that would deny Government family planning money to international organizations supporting abortion, Administration officials said.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY OPERA'S NEW TENOR GETS A LIVELY WELCOME
description: ''The reception that night,'' says Imre Pallo, ''was one of the warmest I've ever experienced at the City Opera. And I've experienced quite a few.''

title: THE REGION ; ;  Youth Arraigned In Ritual Slaying
description: An East Northport teen-ager pleaded not guilty today in the killing of a 17- year-old youth in what authorities say was a ritual of a satanic cult.

title: Taiwan-A.T.& T.
description: Taiwan has approved a $40 million joint venture with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to manufacture digital telephone switchboards here, a Cabinet official said. Under the agreement, he said, A.T.& T. will provide 70 percent of the investment; the state-owned Directorate General of Telecommunications, 15 percent; the Bank of Communications, 10 percent, and the Yao Hua Glass Company, 5 percent. The joint company plans to produce 200,000 switchboards a year by 1986, half of which will be for export.

title: The Worm and the Apple The Subway's Silent, Suffering Majority
description: The New York Assembly has voted to put million-dollar elevators in dozens of subway stations to make them accessible to people in wheelchairs, even though in cities that already have such elevators, few disabled people use them. Westway, that long-promised $4 billion parkway, if it is ever built, will probably make commuters happy. But what's happening to ease life for those millions of New Yorkers who are dependent on public transit? Supposedly, nearly $3 billion in capital funds, voted in 1981, should by now be making the M.T.A. work better. If recent personal experience is any gauge, things are getting, if anything, worse.

title: PINK TOWER HAS SOME IN LOUSIVILLE SEEING RED
description: Is it grand, or is it 27 stories of what one local architecture writer called ''ego-thumping garishness''?

title: Justice Department Is Asked To Investigate Selma Election
description: The Southern Christian Leadership Conference asked the Justice Department today to begin an investigation of Tuesday's election in Selma, Ala., asserting that black voters were intimidated.

title: MCENROE, CONNORS WIN IN DAVIS CUP
description: A year ago, Jose Luis-Clerc, buoyed by a flag- waving crowd in his homeland of Argentina, outlasted the talented but temperamental John McEnroe in five sets to start his country on the road to an upset victory over the United States in the opening round of Davis Cup play. It was a crowning moment for the Argentines, who have never won the prestigious tennis cup.

title: EXCITEMENT STIRS DEMOCRATS WITH WOMAN SET FOR TICKET
description: Thursday the Democrats made history. Today they made plans.

title: Eagle Computer
description: Eagle Computer Inc. has announced it will lay off 83 administrative and manufacturing employees, leaving the company with 140 workers - down from a high last year of 330. At the same time, Robert N. Mickwee, Eagle's president, announced yesterday that an informal committee of unsecured creditors has approved an agreement restructuring the company's $9 million debt. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Rained Out

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
European Newspapers Praise Ferraro Choice
description: Most European newspapers reacted enthusiastically today to Walter F. Mondale's choice of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro as his running-mate, praising it as a daring move. But some warned that he ran the risk of being eclipsed by her.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $2.8 million on the sale of branch offices. c-Net loss.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS G.O.P. WOMEN MAKE BIG GAINS
description: President Reagan said today that Republican women were making greater gains than Democratic women because they were ''doing it by merit'' without ''tokenism or cynical symbolism.''

title: Sandoz Revenues Up
description: Sandoz Ltd., one of Switzerland's major chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturers, said today that revenues in the first half of 1984 rose 14 percent, to 3.75 billion Swiss francs, or $1.5 billion, from 3.29 billion francs a year before. It did not provide figures on its profit, but said earnings ''showed a favorable trend.''

title: EARLY JULY AUTO SALES ROSE 32%
description: Sales of new cars in the first 10 days of July climbed 32 percent from the comparable period last year, the major American manufacturers reported here today. The increase pushed the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate to 9.1 million units, the highest since mid-February and only the second time it has topped 9 million units since March 1981.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Edison Brothers
description: Edison Brothers Stores Inc. said its Handyman division had agreed to sell 15 of its Texas and Oklahoma City stores to Ross Stores Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but Edison said the transaction would result in a substantial one-time gain after taxes and after providing for the cost of closing the stores. Including net proceeds from liquidation of inventory and the separate sale of Handyman's Texas distribution center and six remaining Texas and Oklahoma stores, it said the sale is expected to generate more than $25 million immediately and more than $40 million when the transactions are completed.

title: RAISING THE DRINKING AGE IS NO SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE-PARK HOMER LIFTS TIGERS IN 11TH
description: Lou Whitaker's two-run, inside-the- park homer with two out in the 11th inning lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 5-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.

title: IS IT NAT MOORE? NORTH MOORE? OR NO MOORE?
description: What's in an N?

title: PATENTS ; Operating System For Nuclear Reactors
description: A method of operating a nuclear reactor by digital computer was patented this week for the Department of Energy. The inventor, Robert W. Colley, is an employee of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation based in Richland, Wash.

title: Forbes Hurt in Cycle Crash
description: Malcolm S. Forbes, 64 years old, publisher of Forbes magazine, an internationally known sportsman, was seriously injured in a motorcycle accident Thursday in Glacier Park, the authorities said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Symbol for Tunnels

title: C3 Inc. Stake
description: The Penn Central Corporation increased its stake in C3 Inc. to 750,900 common shares, or 7.8 percent of the total outstanding, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: THE POTHOLE: A SOURCE OF PERVERSE CIVIC PRIDE
description: Donald Maxwell, like a lot of other New Yorkers, believes that the city offers the very best and the very worst of everything.

title: BRITON BUYS THE MIRROR CHAIN
description: The publisher Robert Maxwell completed negotiations today to buy the Mirror Group of newspapers from Reed International Ltd. for $148 million.

title: South Africa Blast Toll at 5
description: The death toll in a car- bomb explosion Thursday climbed to five today when a 24-year-old man died of his wounds. The police said 26 people were wounded in the blast, which Law and Order Minister Louis Le Grange said was the work of the African National Congress, the main guerrilla group fighting South Africa's policy of apartheid. There has been no claim of responsibility.

title: Bus Leased by Mission Hits A Truck in Arizona, Killing 3
description: A bus carrying 47 people, mostly young missionaries, collided with a gravel truck in northern Arizona today, killing three people and injuring about 20 others.

title: WHEN THE RENT CHECK DOESN'T COVER THE RENT
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGE OF PLUSES AND MINUSES FOUND IN POLL ON REP. FERRARO
description: The instant public reaction to Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro as a Vice-Presidential candidate is mixed, with a wide range of minuses to accompany the pluses, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: No Headline
description: 7-Day Strike by 1,400 Ended in Connecticut

title: DANCE:VIOLENT NEW PILOBOLUS WORK
description: ''Sexist! Racist!'' a man cried out amid the cheers as the curtain fell on ''Return to Maria La Baja,'' a dark and violent new work by the Pilobolus Dance Theater, commissioned by the American Dance Festival and performed on Thursday in Page Auditorium at Duke University, where the festival is held. ''This morning Vice President, tonight rape,'' a woman commented philosophically, referring to the political news of the day.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Man Held in Fire Fatal to Woman
description: A 25-year-old Bronx man was arrested last night and charged with murder and arson in connection with a four-alarm fire that killed a woman in the South Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisitions completed during the second quarter of 1984.

title: Midland Plant Halt Delayed
description: The Consumers Power Company said today that it had extended the deadline for canceling its Midland nuclear plant, which had been today, and offered opponents of the plant a new compromise plan for completing part of the project. A spokesman said the company offered to drop its requirement that a settlement plan with state officials include immediate rate increases.

title: How Not to Reduce the Deficit
description: The deficit ''down payment'' now awaiting President Reagan's signature makes almost 200 changes in Federal tax law. Most mean higher taxes and a smaller deficit, but a dozen will reduce Government income and increase the deficit. That there are any tax increases in an election year is remarkable. But the last-minute plums favoring only a few are deplorable.

title: ; AMERICAN TEXTBOOK PUBLISHERS' EYES ON TEXAS
description: To the Editor:

title: IVB FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $508,000 for the quarter and $1,016,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $167,000.

title: Wood Cards a 68
description: Rain interrupted the second round of the $350,000 Anheuser-Busch Classic today, but it did not stop Willie Wood, the first-day leader, from shooting a 68 for a two-day total of 131, the tour's lowest two-day total this year.

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: The caption on a picture by The Associated Press yesterday showing the family of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro reversed the identities of her daughters. Laura was at left; standing next to her was Donna.

title: ;  Francis Is Grounded
description: An attempt by Russ Francis, the 49ers tight end, to set a small-plane world speed record this weekend was grounded by the San Francisco head coach, Bill Walsh , who talked the 12- year flying veteran out of it. ''It really didn't make a lot of sense to me,'' said the coach. Instead, Francis will watch as a colleague flies the single-prop plane at what his team of fliers hopes will be speeds in excess of 300 miles an hour.

title: CHICAGO 'COUNCIL WARS' DRAG INTO INTERMISSION
description: The special City Council meeting on Thursday was to have been the final curtain call before Chicago's longest-running political show, known locally as ''Council Wars,'' shut down for the summer.

title: IMPACT OF JERSEY'S LIQUOR LAW
description: Over a year has elapsed since New Jersey raised its minimum drinking age from 19 to 21, and, as expected, the new law has helped curb the number of highway deaths. But it has also required some serious adjustment on the part of the proprietors - and patrons - of the state's 11,417 taverns and liquor stores.

title: LILCO MEDIATOR: PLYING THE ART OF ACCORD
description: As Robert Swanson, the Federal mediator assigned to the four-day-old strike against the Long Island Lighting Company, likes to tell it, the first strike he was ever involved in helped him bring a focus to his life. And he has been involved in labor disputes ever since.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. .

title: ODD DAY IN COURT
description: JUDGMENT IN BERLIN. By Herbert J.

title: CLASH OVER SMUT LEADS TO ARRESTS
description: The City Council passed an ordinance today defining pornography as a violation of the civil rights of women, but a vote to delay the ordinance led to a chanting, stomping demonstration with 25 arrests. The Mayor later vetoed the measure.

title: German Prices Climb
description: Wholesale prices rose one-tenth of one percent in June from May and three percent from June 1983, the Bonn Government said today.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: A flashlight battery almost hit Pedro Guerrero of the Dodgers while he was playing right field in the ninth inning of the game Thursday against the Chicago Cubs in Wrigley Field. ''They don't do that sort of thing in Los Angeles,'' said Guerrero. . . . Alan Trammell , batting .307 for the Detroit Tigers, was placed on the 15- day disabled list, retroactive to last Friday, with tendinitis of the right shoulder.

title: PANEL URGES CITY TO WITHDRAW PENSION FUNDS TO PROTEST APARTHEID
description: New York City should promptly withdraw its pension fund investments from some companies doing business in South Africa, according to a report submitted to Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: Machinists to Vote on Pact
description: The International Association of Machinists announced today that it had reached a tentative agreement on a new contract with General Dynamics' Convair Division, which it struck July 3. Andy Barnes, an international representative for the association, said the union would recommend passage of the proposed agreement in a ratification vote Sunday. A total of 4,200 machinists walked off their jobs at Convair plants in San Diego, at Vandenberg Air Force Base and in Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Hart Speech May MissRS00.3Prime Time for TV
description: According to the Democratic National Committee's tentative schedule for the Wednesday night session of the peryt's convention here, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado will speak before the networks begin their prime-time coverage of the convention.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 14, 1984 International
description: China said frontier guards repulsed a major attack by Vietnam Thursday after 10 hours of heavy fighting in Yunnan Province. The new border fighting was first reported by the Vietnam News Agency, which accused China of shelling Ha Tuyen Province, which abuts Yunnan Province, with artillery and rockets since early July. (Page 1, Column 2.) Advisers to Solidarity went on trial in Warsaw, and Lech Walesa, leader of the banned union, was not permitted to enter the courthouse. Four defendants are accused of preparing to topple the Government by force. (2:1.)

title: PROBLEMS PILE UP FOR MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been thrown onto the defensive, a year after her re-election, by a series of serious economic and political problems.

title:
PATENTS;
 Grounding Unit
description: A device for preventing static electricity buildup on humans has been invented by Harold F. Vandermark for Nu-Concept Computer Systems Inc. in Colmar, Pa. Patent 4,459,633, granted this week, describes a unit that is worn on the wrist and connected to a wire that runs to the ground. The device has a means of disconnecting the ground wire if there is danger of shock or electrocution to the wearer.

title: WILBERT TATUM, THE MAYOR'S DEBATER, HAS HIS OWN FLAIR FOR THE DRAMATIC
description: The last thing Wilbert A. Tatum expected to be doing tomorrow was debating the Mayor of New York on racial issues. ''I was surprised as hell,'' said Mr. Tatum, chairman of the board and editor in chief of The Amsterdam News.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS TAKEN
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Thursday with 943 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 747 said they were registered to vote.

title: CONFESSED MURDERER OF 3 EXECUTED IN FLORIDA
description: David L. Washington, 34 years old, a confessed triple murderer whose appeal for a reprieve was rejected Thursday night, died this morning in the electric chair at the state prison here.

title: U.S.-CUBAN PARLEY SAID TO BE NARROW
description: Talks between the United States and Cuba that began in New York on Thursday will be limited to a narrow agenda of immigration issues and are unlikely to produce any major improvement in relations, senior Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Industry to Reduce Smog
description: About 3,500 industrial concerns in the Los Angeles area will cut operations by up to 30 percent for the Olympics to ease the longest July smog wave here in 10 years, a county official said today.

title: ;  Kicker Seeks a Raise
description: Raul Allegre , who kicked 30 of 35 field goals as a rookie last season, says he is unhappy with his contract with the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Bush Sends Rep. Ferraro Note of Congratulations
description: Vice President Bush said today that he had sent a brief note of congratulations to Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro after her selection as Walter F. Mondale's running mate and was willing to debate her in the forthcoming campaign.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPLIANCE WITH SEAT BELT LAWS SAID TO BE LOW
description: Although it has been the law in New York State for more than two years that children 6 years old and under must wear seat belts or safety restraints while riding in cars, safety experts and police officials say compliance is spotty.

title: SHULTZ DEFENDS STRONG DOLLAR
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reacted sharply today to third-world criticism of American economic policies by accusing developing countries of being much more protectionist than the United States and of benefiting from the strong dollar they condemn.

title: Healthdyne Cuts Its Work Force
description: Healthdyne Inc. said it had recently reduced its work force about 10 percent to control costs and bring expenses in line with expected revenues.

title: TELECRAFTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,703,827 for the quarter and $3,390,353 for the 9 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $97,186 for the quarter and $108,856 for the 9 months.

title: METS TURN BACK BRAVES FOR 7TH STRAIGHT VICTORY
description: If the Mets aren't looking over their shoulders before each game, they've played their last two games like a team that feels the heat from their pursuers.

title: A RULING ON PREVENTIVE DETENTION THAT PUNISHES THE YOUNG
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Bank Takeover
description: Twelve of Spain's largest private banks said today that they would take over 17 banks once controlled by Ruiz Mateos, the holding company that the Government expropriated in 1983. The purchasers will acquire them by buying low-interest certificates valued at $2.75 billion.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Hard Times

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable July 20.

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. POLICY ON ABORTION: A LIKELY TARGET NAMED
description: A Reagan Administration official today identified the International Planned Parenthood Federation as the likely first target of a new Administration policy that would deny family planning money to organizations that support abortion overseas.

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WASHINGTON TALK-BRIEFING
description: Test Crash for Air Safety

title: INVESTORS SOUGHT FOR CHICAGO BANK
description: Investment bankers are scrambling to line up outside investors who will participate in the rescue of the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Wall Street and commercial banking sources said yesterday.

title: OPERA: PUCCINI IN THE PARK
description: Under a stunning moon in paradisial weather, the New York Grand Opera launched its summer Puccini festival Thursday night in Central Park. ''The Girl of the Golden West,'' one of the few Puccini operas not being done this summer at the City Opera, was on the bill.

title: LANE CO AND WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Stepping Up the Line

title: MORELAND BATS IN 4 AS CUBS TRIUMPH, 7-5
description: Keith Moreland drove in four runs with a home run and a single to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 7-5 victory today over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Pennzoil Stock
description: The Pennzoil Company said it plans to periodically purchase up to 5 percent of its common shares in open market transactions.

title: ;  Volunteer Guardian
description: If the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee feels it needs help with security during the upcoming Games, there is a volunteer. Curtis Sliwa , the founder and leader of the Guardian Angels, has notified President Reagan and the State Department that his group was willing to protect Third World athletes.

title: JUDGING AMERICAN BUSINESS BY ITS WRITING HABITS
description: Here's another symptom of change in American business: executives are less likely to answer mail from consumers and stockholders promptly and carefully - or at all.

title: COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOTHEBY'S DELAYS SALE OF GUEVARA'S DIARIES
description: Sotheby's, which had hoped to auction the last diaries of Ernesto (Che) Guevara next Monday, has agreed to postpone the sale indefinitely until their true ownership is decided in court, according to a spokesman for the auctioneer.

title: FIRST SAVINGS ASSN OF WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Final Four Sites For '89, '90 Picked
description: Dave Gavitt, the chairman of a committee that was to have chosen today only the site of the 1989 Final Four in basketball, instead announced that the Kingdome in Seattle had been awarded the 1989 event and that the McNichols Sports Arena in Denver would get it in 1990.

title: RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I support the idea of a man on our ticket.'' - Vice President George Bush. (6:6.)

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DANCE: SOLO BY WILLIAMS ON AILEY BILL
description: Wednesday night's program by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in the Metropolitan Opera House was a demonstration of ways of contending with that theater's vast stage space.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about Vice- Presidential races by members of the House of Representatives incorrectly described the history of James Sherman of New York. He was elected Vice President in 1908 and served until his death in 1912.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
2 Arrested in Burning Of 3 Black Churches
description: Three rural black churches were burned early today but officials said two white men arrested as they were about to set fire to a fourth were not part of any racist group and were using the fires to cover burglaries.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan today to Republican women who hold or are candidates for elected office:

SATURDAY, JULY 14, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Houston Gas
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said its board had authorized the repurchase of as many as 3 million shares of its common shares on the open market. The company said the stock purchase would be an alternative to using available capital to expand its pipeline and exploration businesses. The board will continue to evaluate that option, it added.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Urgent Word From Albany

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUBWAY ELEVATORS NOT FOR THE DISABLED ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday about the arrest of suspects in a 1977 Bronx murder case incorrectly described the victim, Michael D. Johnson. District Attorney Mario Merola, who originally said Mr. Johnson had attended graduate school at Fordham University, now says the information was in error.

title:
PATENTS;
SEAT USES SPRINGS AS CUSHIONS
description: WASHINGTON

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: SALVADOR KILLINGS REPORTED DOWN
description: The Reagan Administration said today that there had been a significant decline in political slayings by right-wing death squads in El Salvador but that ''much remains to be done'' to stem the killings.

title: JUG WINES TO TRY SUMMER
description: This is a good time of year to get

title: Midland Seeks Rest Of Crocker
description: Midland Bank P.L.C. of London, which owns 57 percent of the Crocker National Corporation, offered yesterday to purchase the remaining outstanding shares of the San Francisco- based bank for $207 million in preferred stock, or $25 a share.

title: Quartet at Sweet Basil
description: The New York Jazz Quartet is appearing at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South, tonight and tomorrow. The group consists of the saxophonist and flutist Frank Wess, the pianist Roland Hanna, the bassist George Mraz and the drummer Grady Tate, who is making his first appearance with the quartet in several years. Show times tonight are 10 and 11:45 P.M., and 1:30 A.M.; tomorrow, 10 and 11:30 P.M., and 1 A.M. Admission is $8, with a $6 minimum.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Leconte Topples Lendl
description: Henri Leconte of France gambled on an all-out attack today and scored a stunning 6-3, 8-6, 6-4 victory over Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia in the opening match of a Davis Cup quarterfinal.

title: All-White Parliament Adjourns in South Africa
description: The South African Parliament adjourned today after 74 years as an all- white body to make way for a new legislature that will include Asians and people of mixed race, but not the nation's black majority.

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Polish Dissident Trial Begins
description: Jacek Kuron, left, Adam Michnik, two of four defendants, before military tribunal.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $786,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: No Headline
description: KENNETH GODFREY

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: RearWorld War II

title: SAFETY IN SUMMER: WINDOW GUARDS
description: When a one-year-old boy died after he fell from an open window in the Bronx last April, it was the first such fatality this year. Officials from the city's Department of Health warn that falls from windows usually increase in summer.

title: CHINESE REPORT THEY BEAT BACK VIETNAM ATTACK
description: China announced Friday that its frontier guards repulsed a large-scale attack by Vietnam Thursday across their tense border after 10 hours of heavy combat.

title: KUWAIT'S SOVIET ARMS DEAL STIRS UNEASE IN WASHINGTON
description: The State Department, reacting to an agreement by Kuwait to buy Soviet weapons, expressed concern today that the Persian Gulf nation might be moving toward increased reliance on Moscow to defend its oilfields and shipping from attack by Iran.

title: SPARE US YOUR SAVIORS
description: With the resignation last May of Anthony J. Alvarado, Chancellor of the New York City school system, the educational foot soldier had seen another comet come and go. You will have to forgive the cynicism, but those of us in the inner-city schools have become inured to the regular appearances of pedagogical wizards who somehow have discovered the key to teaching the underprivileged child. These luminaries flare briefly with sudden insight, then just as quickly disappear.

title: KNIGHT IN A TIRADE
description: Bobby Knight, the coach of the United States Men's Olympic basketball team, was involved in an extended angry confrontation with a referee tonight for the first time in the three months that he has overseen the team.

title: Swiss Trade Deficit Cut
description: The Swiss merchandise trade deficit shrank to $224 million in June from $235 million in May and $280 million in June 1983, the Government said today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Advance Broadly;  Short-Term Rates Drop
description: The credit markets finished their best week of the year yesterday, as bond prices rose throughout the maturity range.

title: Queens Man Slain in Dispute
description: A 40-year-old Queens man died early today after he was shot in a dispute with an off-duty New York City police officer and the owner of a Floral Park bar, the Nassau County police said.

title: VIOLATIONS ADMITTED BY CASINO
description: Lawyers for the Golden Nugget Hotel Casino have admitted that four employees violated gaming laws when Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin played blackjack in the casino last Dec. 1, state officials said today.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCITON SHOWS INCREASE OF 0.5%
description: Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government reported today, providing fresh evidence that the economic expansion is slowing to a more moderate pace.

title: LOOKING FOR A GOOD THING
description: Now is the time of year when anyone who often gets around the stable area at the race track suddenly finds himself very popular with bettors. The most casual of acquaintances, and even strangers, stop you to talk, tell you that you're looking well and pass off other lies as pleasantries. It isn't that the nice weather has put the railbirds in a good mood. Their purpose is clear, and the important question they finally get around to is inevitable:

title: SCOUTING;
description: A Special Team

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Canada Sets Gas Plan
description: The Canadian Energy Minister, Gerald Regan, announced today that the federal Government had approved what amounts to near-deregulation of the export price of natural gas.

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEFICIT MADNESS
description: A certain amount of hysteria has attended the issue of Federal budget deficits, and there promises to be more as the Presidential campaign heats up. A look at how deficits are calculated, however, reveals that they are not always what they seem. That has some important implications for future, as well as past, policy decisions.

title: India to Buy Six Airbuses
description: The Indian Government has approved Air India's plan to buy six European-built Airbus Industrie jetliners to replace its aging, United States-built Boeing 707 fleet, a Cabinet minister said today. The Tourism and Civil Aviation Minister, Khursheed Alam Khan, also said the Government was considering a proposal by Indian Airlines, the country's domestic carrier, to purchase 12 Boeing 757's for $500 million to replace five older and smaller Boeing 737's.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NETWORKS AND SEASONAL ADJUSTMNET
description: It's always a mystery why a network that has a hard time during the cold months - say, NBC - can do so well during the summer, and why another network that does very well in the winter - say, ABC - suddenly goes to the ratings basement when the weather heats up.

title: UNOCAL STOCK SURGES ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
description: Oil fever shook the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the first time in many weeks as shares in the Unocal Corporation surged $4.62 1/2 on the Big Board by the 4 P.M. close and then advanced a dollar more on the Pacific Stock Exchange to end the day at $36.62 1/2, up $5.62 1/2, on a volume of more than a million shares.

title: Reputed Crime Leaders Arraigned in California
description: Two leaders of a reputed Chicago crime group accused of moving into loan-sharking and bookmaking in Southern California and Las Vegas were arraigned today in Federal court.

title: U.S.F.L. SEEKS A CAP ON PLAYER SALARIES
description: The United States Football League, only two seasons old but already facing what it perceives as a need for belt- tightening, is trying to negotiate a cap on player salaries for each of its teams.

title: BECKER MILK CO reports earnings for Year to April 30
INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION FOR ENGLISH CITY
description: At 1:30 A.M. on a Sunday, as they wait for the youths to begin spilling out after a Saturday night at the city's discoth eques, the groups of policemen strolling along Portland Street are hopeful, but they do not find talk of the economic recovery here in northwest England very convincing.

title: U.S. Judge Rules In Michels's Favor
description: Jeff Michels's long legal battle to gain a spot on the United States Olympic weight-lifting team took another complicated turn today.

title: DUSTIN HOFFMAN'S TOUR DE FRANCE
description: Caravan of Promoters

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE CITY ; ;  Mt. Neboh Razing Blocked by Judge
description: Demolition of the former Mount Neboh Synagogue on West 79th Street was halted yesterday by a court order obtained by a community group, the Committee to Save Mount Neboh.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Ownership in Australia
description: Australia's governing Labor Party today softened its tough line against foreign control of energy projects when it voted to insist on 51 percent Australian ownership only ''where feasible.'' This policy change ends doubts about Japanese participation in a gas project off the northern coast of Australia.

title: Van Gogh and a Monet Stolen at Coast Home
description: Two paintings by Vincent van Gogh and Claude Monet valued at $3 million were stolen from a Bel-Air home by thieves who, the police say, apparently ''knew exactly what they wanted.''

title: AT NEW HOME IN U.S., FREED CUBAN DECRIBES PRISON BEATINGS

description: Walter F. Mondale's choice of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro as his running mate has set off a competition among Queens politicians for her House seat.

description: Rutgers University's board of governors, facing opposition from some students and teachers, today approved a proposal to lease a four- acre parcel of Cook College property to the New Jersey Bar Association for a new headquarters.

description: Frederick's of Hollywood Inc. said its board had voted to omit the quarterly cash dividend.

title: Swiss Offer In Rich Case
description: Swiss authorities moved today to end an impasse with the United States over Marc Rich Ltd., the Switzerland- based commodity brokerage concern, by offering to hand over documents they had withheld if the United States would block a $50,000-a-day fine against the company. It is headed by Marc Rich, who holds both American and Belgian citizenship.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Supper Club Twin Bill
description: The singer Pamela Myers and the composer-pianist Stan Freeman are appearing at midnight tonight at Freddy's Supper Club (888-1633), 308 East 49th Street. There is a $10 cover charge and a $10 food-and-drink minumum.

title: Curtiss C. Grove, 88, Dies
description: Curtiss C. Grove, 88 years old, a longtime banking executive who was an adviser to President Reagan, died Tuesday at his home here. Mr. Grove was a vice president and director of the Chase Manhattan Bank and a member of a Presidential study group and the Council of Foreign Relations.

title: PEKING-HANOI INTERESTS SPLIT AFTER VIETNAM WAR
description: ''As close as lips and teeth'' was the way Communists in China and Vietnam described their relationship during Vietnam's wars against France and the United States.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMMODORE TRADE SECRETS
description: A Pennsylvania judge today temporarily extended an injunction that prevents four former employees of Commodore International Ltd. from revealing any Commodore trade secrets at their new jobs with Atari Inc.

title: Murdoch Filing On St. Regis
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher whose companies own 5.6 percent of the St. Regis Corporation's stock, said no decision had been made to buy more. He said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he met in London on July 6 with the Midland Bank and 22 other banks to discuss a hostile takeover bid for 50.1 percent of St. Regis at between $50 and $55 a share, subject to St. Regis shareholders rejecting company plans to buy the Colonial Penn Insurance Company. Part of the discussions centered on his buying the rest of St. Regis in exchange for some form of debt securities, with the possibility that some of the operations of the forest-products company would be sold to pay the debt. Mr. Murdoch said, however, that his companies ''do not have any present intention to seek to acquire control of the company or to request representaton on the company's board of directors.'' St. Regis, which jumped $2.875 on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday in expectation of an imminent takeover bid, fell $2.625 yesterday, to $41.75.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Police Arrest Escapee After Tip on Another
description: Federal agents who staked out a street corner here today on a tip that a fugitive sought in several slayings was in North Jersey arrested instead an escapee from a Delaware prison.

title: No Headline
description: Pavelich Happy To Be Fishing

title: MAN GETS 62 YEARS IN KILLING AND RAPE
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn man was sentenced to 62 1/2 years in prison yesterday for killing one woman and raping another in Gershwin Park in Brooklyn in the spring of 1983.

title: ADVANCE OF 5.30 FOR DOW REDUCES WEEK'S LOSS
description: The stock market, bolstered by signals of a moderation in economic growth, moved modestly higher yesterday. The rise followed three days of declines that saw the Dow Jones industrial average sink nearly 30 points.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $3,146,000, or 37 cents a share, from the disposition of options. c-After a loss of $2,458,000 from the sale of subsidiaries.

title: ;  Turner's Regret
description: While Phil Niekro was winning his 12th game of the season for the Yankees two nights ago, Ted Turner, the owner of the Atlanta Braves, admitted it was ''dumb'' for his team to release the 45-year-old pitcher after last season.

title: JUST SLIGHTLY PURPLE
description: I've canceled my arrangements to go to San Francisco for the convention, thank you. No, of course I'm not mad at anybody. What's to be mad about? I've never said I was even half qualified to be Vice President, have I? Have I ever said that?

title: AROUND THEN NATION;
description: A schoolteacher who lost the use of her arms and legs in an automobile accident has been awarded $7.5 million in compensatory damages.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: UPTOWN The uplands of northern Manhattan are infrequently explored by downtowners who live in the manmade upthrusts of the island's southern half. The natural heights of the borough's northern bounds are not only of a salubrious altitude but they are also, by way of parks and other open spaces, quite beautiful and comparatively tranquil. One of these is Fort Tryon Park, bounded by the Hudson River on the west, Broadway on the east, Dyckman Street on the north and Fort Washington Avenue and Cabrini Boulevard on the south.

title: Bomb Suspect in Ulster Killed by British Troops
description: An undercover British Army squad today shot and killed a man suspected of trying to plant a bomb at a village factory, the police said.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: 2 LEAD OPEN BY A SHOT AT 144
description: Penny Pulz, a 31-year-old Australian who has only one victory in 11 years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, and Rosie Jones, who has never won in two years as a pro, were the surprise co-leaders today halfway through the 39th annual United States Women's Open championship. They were at even par 144.

title: Japanese Help for China
description: The Aisan Industry Company, an engine maker affiliated with the Toyota Motor Corporation, said today that it had signed a contract with China's Ministry of Railways to advise it on producing diesel valves for locomotive engines.

title: RETAIL SALES ROSE 0.8% LAST MONTH
description: Retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Turkish Goods Curbed
description: The Common Market said today that four of its countries would curb imports of some textiles from Turkey until the end of the year. Cotton shirts and bed linen shipped to Britain, West Germany, France and Italy will be affected.

title: BURGER SAID TO SUPPORT BAN ON BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: With disarray and confusion mounting in the nation's bankruptcy courts, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger was reported today to have backed up a judicial administrator's refusal to pay the salaries of Federal bankruptcy judges.

title: Nina Simone Sings
description: Nina Simone, the jazz and pop singer, is appearing at the Blue Note (475- 8592), 131 West Third Street, through tomorrow. Show times are 10 P.M. and midnight, and admission is $25 a table, plus a $7.50 food-and-drink minimum.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAJOR ISSUES IN THE STRIKE
description: The bargaining agent for the 49 voluntary hospitals and 6 nursing homes is the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes.

title: ;  Bad News for Pearson
description: ''If my career ended tomorrow, I would be satisfied,'' said Drew Pearson , the Dallas Cowboys' 32-year-old star receiver for whom tomorrow has apparently arrived. After learning from doctors Tuesday that he had a 7-centimeter hole in his liver, the result of the March automobile accident in which his brother was killed, the leading receiver in Cowboy history (489 catches for 7,822 yards and 48 touchdowns) said he has ''psychologically prepared'' himself for retirement.

title: Clarity by Decree
description: Joseph David, a retired employee of the Internal Revenue Service, couldn't understand why identical claims for his wife's medical treatments resulted in different reimbursements. Faced with a fight with a form letter, many an American might have chosen to forget the whole thing.

title: KING COAL'S BID FOR COMEBACK
description: Domestic coal production and sales are at record levels after two years of stagnation, but few in the industry are joyful.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest second quarter include operations of Ellis Banking Corp., acquired March 16.

title: Education Measure Is Approved in Texas
description: Seated at a desk from the school where his mother once taught, Gov. Mark White today signed what he called Texas's ''most sweeping educational reform bill'' and the $4.6 billion tax bill that accompanies it.

title: BRIEFS
description: Atlantic Financial Federal of Bala- Cynwyd, Pa., said it had completed its acquisition of San Francisco Bancorp for $8.50 a share, or about $31 million.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANK GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FAITHS RELY ON SCRIPTURE IN HOMOSEXUALITY ISSUE
description: The issue of homosexuality is troubling religious groups throughout America. They are under pressure from the outside to ease their traditional hostility and from within to revise their theology.

title: 300 Reported Injured In West German Storm
description: A storm pounded the Munich area with hailstones the size of tennis balls, high winds and heavy rains, injuring 300 people and causing extensive damage, officials said today.

title: COMPASSIONATE PASTOR
description: The Rev. Emilio Castro, elected Thursday as general secretary of the World Council of Churches, was reared as one of nine children of working-class parents in Uruguay, where deep secular inroads made Christian faith very weak by Latin American standards. For a long time, the Government showed its disdain for Christian belief by spelling God with with a small ''g,'' Mr. Castro recalled in interview recently.

title: French-German Border Pact
description: An accord abolishing formalities for citizens of Common Market countries crossing between France and West Germany was signed today near Saarbr"ucken. The accord, which goes into effect Monday, allows travelers to cross the border without stopping for the usual checks or presenting passports, provided their vehicles bear a green sticker certifying all passengers are citizens of Common Market countries with nothing to declare to customs.

title: U.S. WOMAN WINS
description: Saturday is Bastille Day, but it was the American team, not the favored French one, that started dancing in the streets today after the women's Tour de France bicycle race had finished its 12th stage, its first in the Alps.

title: Bridge: GIn to Matches
description: The semifinal stage of the Grand National Team Championship began here this afternoon with Florida opposing Virginia and Chicago clashing with Denver.

title: Bid for Fischbach
description: Victor Posner, chairman of the Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, said the company intends to acquire enough shares of the Fischbach Corporation to raise its holdings to more than 50 percent of the voting securities outstanding.

title: ONCE A SCULLER...
description: This summer, after celebrating 25 happy years of marriage, I rekindled an old college flame. The object of my affection weighs 40 pounds and measures 16 feet long and 25 inches across the middle. She is a sleek and stunningly beautiful single rowing scull.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: The quarterbacks Pat Ryan and Ken O'Brien, expected to compete for the starting job this season, reported with the rookies and free agents today as 86 of the 117 Jets' players opened training camp. The veterans are to report July 20.

description: The Senior PGA Tour made its annual call here today, to be greeted by flawless seaside weather, friendly spectators and a tournament name with nearly as many syllables as players: the Merrill Lynch/Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Ex-Church Aide Held in Bribe Case
description: A former Riverside Church employee has been arrested on charges of receiving $50,000 in bribes from a company that did business with the church, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: PIONEER IN CANCER TREATMNET
description: Dr. Max Cutler, one of America's pioneers in the campaign against cancer, died July 6 at his home in Camarillo, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS TO MEET IN A HALL, WITHOUT A FULL VIEW
description: The Democratic National Convention, one of the world's most visible events, begins here Monday in a hall so curiously shaped that no one in it can see everyone else.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 1.

description: Soviet television today said that Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro could win Walter F. Mondale many votes because of widespread discontent among American women victimized by inequality.

title: PATENTS ; E.P.A. Process Cuts Emissions From Boilers
description: The Environmental Protection Agency received a patent this week for a process meant to reduce the nitrogen-oxide emissions in the combustion of nitrogen-containing fuels in boilers and gas turbines.

title: SOME MENU LISTINGS ARE FOR READING, NOT EATING
description: Sometimes nothing makes lighter reading than restaurant menus with their misspellings and garbled translations. The hand-lettered daily specials tacked up outside restaurants to entice passers-by can also be amusing window shopping. Often, usually inadvertently, the advertised specials turn off potential customers.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE ENVIRONMENT
description: After nearly four years of saying relatively little about the environment, President Reagan cast himself this week as a fighter against pollution and a steward of the public lands and resources. He got mixed reviews.

title: Behold the Westway Park
description: No matter how the legal travails of New York City's Westway have distracted its backers, the designers of its park component have kept their minds on their work. The proposal by Clark and Rapuano, Salmon Associates and architect-designers Venturi- Rauch-Scott Brown hits a high-water mark in recent urban park design.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Coed Hockey

title: Tandon-Tandy
description: The Tandon Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell up to $125 million of products to the Tandy Corporation, a consumer electronics concern based in Fort Worth. Tandon, which makes disk drives for desktop and other small computers, said the agreement covers a variety of products. Shipments, which have already begun, are subject to definitive purchase orders by Tandy through the end of 1985, Tandon said.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW SOVIET TACK SEEN IN EXERCISE IN GERMANY
description: The West German Defense Minister said here today that the Soviet Union has 60,000 troops training near the border between East and West Germany in new tactics designed for a swift, deep strike into West German territory.

title: BOND OPTIONS: LIMITING RISK
description: A new alternative for fixed-income investors, the tender option bond, has made its appearance this year. Its major feature: protection against the possibility of declining bond prices when interest rates advance.

title: No Headline

description: The three Olympic Villages open Saturday to receive athletes from the 141 nations that will compete in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad.

title: YANKS ROMP TWICE, EXTEND STREAK TO 3
description: Yogi Berra, a frustrated manager in the first half of the season, has become a manager with a touch of magic in the second half. For the second consecutive night, Berra made a wishful comment, and it produced instant results.

title: 2 TV Series Scorned
description: American television exports ''trash'' when it exports such programs as ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty,'' according to an industry observer quoted on Wednesday in Daily Variety. The observer, Herb Schmertz, who dispenses financing from the Mobil Oil Corporatiion to public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' and other television shows, made the remark in an address to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Beverly Hills, Calif. He said the ''trash'' programs emphasized greed and crime in a ''tawdry'' depiction of life and misrepresented business and the police and other authority figures.

title: EMPLOYEES STRIKE AT 27 HOSPITALS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Nonmedical employees at 27 of New York City's private, nonprofit hospitals went on strike yesterday. Their union's leader described a two-year, 8 percent wage increase they were offered as ''insulting.''

title: Ex-Mayor Loses Bid To Block Confession
description: A Federal judge ruled today that a confession authorities say a former Atlantic City Mayor made could be used as evidence against him in an upcoming trial on charges he peddled his influence to an organized crime group.

Performances are today at 2, 4 and 7 P.M., and tomorrow at 1 and 4 P.M. Admission is free. Information and travel directions: 853-9620 or (914) 557-8874.

title: CONCERT: 'VIVA VIVALDI!' AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: Somebody in programming at Lincoln Center seems to be addicted to alliteration. There have been recent Lincoln Center series devoted to ''Basically Bach,'' and Thursday night the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra presented a program entitled ''Viva Vivaldi!'' at Avery Fisher Hall. What next? Quaintly Quantz?

description: The profits made by the six new defendants in an insider trading case involving the merger of the Santa Fe International Corporation and the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation are part of more than $6 million frozen by court order three years ago.

description: A state trooper died Thursday night after being struck by a tractor-trailer on the New Jersey Turnpike.

description: A new kind of shop is emerging in Tokyo, where there are an extraordinary number of stores, most of them chock-full of merchandise of every description.

description: Art work by 100 finalists in the Students Art Festival sponsored by WNET, Channel 13, can be seen in the Community Gallery at Hostos Community College, 475 Grand Concourse in the Bronx, through next Friday.

title: ;  Switzer Arrested
description: Barry Switzer , the University of Oklahoma football coach, was arrested yesterday for drunken driving, just west of downtown Oklahoma City after consuming what he said were ''only a few drinks'' at a dinner party. Switzer, who automatically will have his license suspended for 90 days, pending appeal, said he ''deeply regretted'' the incident and ''frankly believed I could pass the Breathalyzer test.''

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
DISTRESS SATELLITE LOSES ORBIT
description: In April a woman on a solitary dogteam trek from Kotzebue to Point Barrow, Alaska, became severely ill. In May a man alone in a 19-foot yacht off the Azores lost his sails in a violent storm and wallowed helpless in the sea. A few weeks earlier the vessel Arctic Wind suffered severe damage to her sails off the California coast.

title: WALESA IS BARRED AS TRIAL OF 4 DISSIDENTS BEGINS
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, was denied entry today to the court where four advisers to the labor movement went before a military tribunal on charges of having plotted to overthrow the Polish system by force.

title: I.B.M. NET UP 20.9% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, continuing to surprise Wall Street with the pace of its growth, said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter rose 20.9 percent over the same period a year ago.

INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP
description: Despite expectations that the economy's stubbornly good health would aggravate inflation, an important measure of prices held steady in June for the third consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: REP. FERRARO ASKS BUSH FOR DEBATES IN FALL CAMPAIGN
description: Politicians in Queens are already competing for Mrs. Ferraro's House seat and a primary seems likely. Page 26.

title: BUBKA SETS RECORD WITH 19-1/4 VAULT
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union and Zola Budd of England broke world records tonight during an international meet at the Crystal Palace. Bubka, 20 years old, exceeded his mark in the pole vault with a jump of 19 feet, 4 1/4 inches. Miss Budd, 18, lowered the women's 2,000-meter record with a time of 5 minutes 33.15 seconds.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption to a photograph accompanying ''300 Years of Treasures at Chatsworth'' (Travel, July 8) referred incorrectly to a building on the grounds of Chatsworth in England. It should have identifed the picture as Paxton's Conservative Wall, a greenhouse built in 1848.

title: HELPING TO SUPPORT MOM AND DAD
description: As the baby boom generation grows older, more children are contributing to the support of their aging parents and looking to tax savings go minimize their costs. Here are some basic tax principles and some recent developments in this area.

title: Miss Hoversten Plans To Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Moris T. Hoversten of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Richardson Hoversten to William Roy Battey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Battey of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Cara Forstmann to Be Married Sept. 21
description: Anthony Forstmann of New York and Candida Cagney Forstmann of Sun Valley, Idaho, have announced the engagement of their daughter Candida Crowe Forstmann to Jeffrey Patterson Anthony, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Anthony of Seattle. The wedding is planned for Sept. 21 in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Moscow Gets U.S. Proposal
description: The United States has submitted to the Soviet Union a proposed agreement on renewing cultural, scientific and educational exchanges, an American Embassy spokesman said Friday. The former agreement expired in 1980.

title: SANTA FE'S INDIAN MARKET
description: -based writer, is studying American folk art at New York University.

title: DEMOCRATIC FACTIONS SAY AIM IS UNITY
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT'S delegation to the Democratic National Convention has headed for San Francisco this weekend emphasizing its unity and downplaying its divided loyalties.

title: MONOTYPE SERIES IN KATONAH
description: A MONOTYPE is a unique image obtained by pressing paper to a flat smooth surface on which shapes have been inked or painted. A second ''pull'' is sometimes possible and additions to the prints by hand are common, but basically the process is a one-shot printing deal that does not require the expertise necessary for, say, lithography or etching. Just the same, the ministrations of a professional printer enhance monotypes immeasurably and, bearing witness to this, are 28 handsome specimens done by Helen Frankenthaler at San Francisco's Experimental Workshop and on view at the Katonah Gallery (28 Bedford Road, Katonah, through Aug. 19).

title: No Headline
description: New York University has announced the appointment of Dr. Richard R. West as dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration. He succeeds William F. May, 68 years old, who had been dean since 1980. Dr. West, 46, an expert in securities markets and corporate governance, arrives at N.Y.U. from Dartmouth College, where he had been a professor of finance and dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration.

title: RULES OF PARTY PLAYING DESIRED ROLE, POLL FINDS
description: Democratic Party leaders say new rules adopted for this year's convention have fulfilled their purpose and created a more stable and predictable nominating process that favors mainstream candidates and policies.

title: FIVE MODERN COMPOSERS ON CAMERA
description: A five-part series entitled ''Soundings'' makes its debut on WNET/Channel 13 tonight and it might seem only reasonable that public television get a few pats on the head for paying some attention to contemporary music. Well, maybe a single pat will do. The public system certainly hasn't been neglecting classical or ''serious'' music over the years. But, with the exception of a new opera here or an adventurous ballet score there, the schedule has virtually duplicated the conservative menu that can be found in most major concert halls across the country. Pleasing most of the customers most of the time still seems to mean feeding them a diet overloaded with Bach, Beethoven and Brahms. So, it is not surprising that ''Soundings'' is being presented on WNET/ 13 at the less than inviting hour of 11:30 P.M., presumably on the theory that anybody who could possibly be interested in contemporary music doesn't have to go to work early on Monday.

title: MOORE DEFEATS BENI TEZ
description: Davey Moore stopped Wilfred Benitez at 1 minutes 18 seconds of the second round of their scheduled 10-round middleweight fight today.

title: PROCLAIMING 1984 'THE YEAR OF THE DELEGATE'
description: AS 3,944 Democratic delegates pour into San Francisco's Moscone Center tomorrow, observers may wonder what the excitement is all about. After all, the nominee seems certain, his Vice Presidential choice has been announced and the platform has been shaped by party officials.

Kenney of Kennett Square, Pa., and the late Eleanor Foster Kenney. A September wedding is planned.

title: WHAT CONSTITUTES A CIVIL RIGHT?
description: Morris Abram's article on civil rights maintains that black college students are underrepresented among students majoring in ''more marketable'' subjects. The current shortage of black professors and secondary-school teachers is in large part due to the influx of black students into the more marketable professional schools of law, business and medicine, as opposed to teaching. We are experiencing a distinct trend toward more career-related courses of study for minority students. CHRISTOPHER F. EDLEY President

description: Swaziland has ordered a senior member of the African National Congress to leave the country after a court order to release him from detention, it was announced here.

Though falling gasoline prices made wood alcohol, or methanol, no bargain, the Ford Motor Company said it wanted to encourage use of alternatives to petroleum.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, Henry R. Lieberman's review of ''My China Years'' by Helen Foster Snow (May 27) incorrectly characterized the political affiliation of the 1930's figure Zhang Xueliang, known as the ''Young Marshal.'' He was second in command to the Nationalist leader, Chiang Kai-shek.

title: NICARAGUA PRIEST WILL GO ON TRIAL
description: Nicaragua announced today that it intended to proceed with a trial of a priest charged with ''counterrevolutionary'' activities.

title: Jean E. Hoins Is Bride Of Stephen B. Gross
description: Jean Elizabeth Hoins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Hoins Jr. of Orient, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Barrett Gross, a son of Barrett M. Gross of La Jolla, Calif. and Dorothy E. Toomey of Wakefield, R.I. The Rev. Milton Heitzman, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Walter E. Clark, in Keene, N.Y.

title: WATTEAU PAINTED MORE THAN JUST SILKS AND SATINS
description: Something extraordinary in the way of a temporary exhibition of paintings and drawings can be seen at the National Gallery in Washington through Sept. 23. Located in the West Building, it includes a figure of Pierrot that is one of the most poignant studies of alienation to be found in all European painting. It also includes a direct and unsentimental evocation of what it feels like to be a wounded soldier who has been left behind after a battle, and some investigations of beggary that can rank with Rembrandt. At the very end of it is a former shop sign that has come to be regarded as one of the most beautiful pictures that ever was painted.

title: PAINTING TO CAPTURE THE SOUND OF MUSIC
description: THE affinity between the visual arts and music is the ostensible point of departure for ''All That's Jazz,'' the current members' exhibition at the Northport Galleries cooperative. The term ostensible is appropriate because few works in the show are directly related to or clearly inspired by jazz.

title: RABBI LOOKS AHEAD TO A NEW ROLE
description: WITH little prodding, Jody Ruth Cohen speaks excitedly about being the new rabbi in West Hartford, about serving as a role model for children, about bringing the Bible to life for people and ''speaking out against the wrongs in our society.''

title: BABY-BOOM VOTERS...
description: In this city of mood swings, Democrats are now in depression. There is open talk of defeat in November, but behind doors, on phones and among friends there are darker premonitions that 1984 could be a realigning election in which their party slides toward minority status for the rest of the century.

title: RESERVOIR YIELDS MORE THAN WATER
description: YOUR eyes follow shafts of midmorning sunlight through 20 feet of pure, drinkable water, and there, at the bottom of the Saugatuck Reservoir, are stone foundations of farm houses that once occupied this agricultural river valley.

title: Doonesbury Returns From Break Sept. 30
description: Doonesbury, the Pulitzer-Prize winning comic strip that last ran in January 1983, will return Sept. 30, the Universal Press Syndicate announced today.

title: DONNA WHITE'S 218 TIES FOR OPEN LEAD
description: - Donna Horton White, who underwent back surgery less than a year ago, tied Amy Alcott for the lead after three rounds of the 39th United States Women's Open at the Salem Country Club today.

title: CUP SERIES TO U.S.
description: The United States put a spirited end to the bitter memories of last year's early-round elimination by Argentina in Davis Cup competition, as John McEnroe and Peter Fleming defeated Jose- Luis Clerc and Martin Jaite in doubles today to clinch the three-of-five- match quarterfinal series, 3-0.

title: FOREIGN TEACHERS SHARE IMPRESSIONS
description: WITH memories of pep rallies, proms and pizza still fresh in their minds, 31 foreign teachers of English gathered in Bronxville recently to share their impressions of American high schools before going home.

title: Praised Dignity Wins Pace
description: Praised Dignity made a late rush from far back to win the $643,000 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace for 2-year-old pacers tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: UPDATE ON THE JAPANESE
description: IRENE DIAMANT, A THEATER DIRECTOR, BROWSED through a markdown rack of summer cottons by Yohji Yamamoto. She was in the Japanese designer's new 2,000- square-foot boutique in the recently opened Charivari shop at l8 West 57th Street. ''Japanese clothes are not for everyone,'' she said as she pulled out a voluminous white cotton dress. ''They're very comfortable, but I feel lost in them. I'm attracted to them because they're like works of art. But I'm not able to wear them.'' Next door, at Henri Bendel, the entire summer collection of Comme des Gar,cons by Rei Kawakubo was marked down 50 percent. There, in the small, quiet boutique on the third floor, Alicia Bilbruck was pulling out a white cotton skirt that was crinkled, pleated and folded with the Japanese trademark: one size fits all. ''This is a great skirt,'' she said, as she held it up against her Calvin Klein shirt and Ralph Lauren skirt. ''I've always liked the Japanese clothes. They're funky. They're always in good fabrics.'' As a Westchester housewife who has been buying Japanese clothes for the past two years at Barneys New York and at Bendel's, she finds their big selling point is comfort. ''I'm not wild about Japanese shoes, however,'' she says. ''They're so unattractive!''

title: INCORRECT LETTERS SENT OUT BY I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service blames human error for the agency's mailing of letters incorrectly informing an unknown number of taxpayers that they owed fines for underestimating quarterly payments.

title: APPEALS COURT BACKS INVALIDATING S.A.T.'s of 4 INCHEATING INQUIRY
description: A New Jersey appeals court has upheld a lower-court decision invalidating the college entrance examinations of four students who had been suspected of cheating.

title:
LONG ILSAND OPINION;
OLD NEIGHBORHOODS AND NEW
description: '' HEY, what d'ya think this is - Brooklyn?'' It must have been some instinctive urge from the deep recesses of my psche that led me, on a a recent sunny day, to sit out on the front steps of my house. This occasioned the flip but good-natured remark from a neighbor who happened to be driving by.

title: TRUCK SALES RUMBLE UP
description: There has been no down-shifting in sales of heavy trucks, which are near the record set in October 1979 - and may even break it before the year is out.

title: THE BAD TIMES SEEM OVER FOR AUTOS, BUT NOT FOR DETROIT
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young beamed as he looked into the television cameras ranged behind the big table in his conference room last week. ''This is, I believe, a most significant day for our city,'' he declared as he announced plans to build a $420 million ''resource recovery'' facility that will burn virtually all the city's garbage to produce electricity and steam for heat in the downtown area.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS July 15, 1984Fiction1
description: HOLLYWOOD WIVES, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $3.95.) The struggle for money and power in Tinseltown. 2 THURSTON HOUSE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) Three generations of a San Francisco family. 3

title: HIKING ALPINE TRAILS
description: The Michelin green guide said: ''In the Queyras it rarely rains during the summer.'' Could there really be a dry spot in Europe? We had come to the southern French Alps to hike and had been dealt days of foggy, soggy weather. Such days are not uncommon to hikers (or to travelers in general for that matter), and we had known them on hikes in Scotland, Switzerland, Germany, Norway and other parts of France, but this time our usual stoicism had been tested too far. So, with tempered optimism, we headed for the Queyras, a regional park southeast of Grenoble, snuggled against the warm Italian border.

title: Peter Ziluca Wed To Randel Mason
description: The marriage of Randel Leigh Mason, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Ronald Mason of Greenwich, Conn., to Peter Garibaldi Ziluca took place at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich yesterday. The Rev. Robert Green performed the ceremony.

title: Small Hotels

title: FLOWING WITH BUTTERMILK
description: ONE OF MY most favorite beverages as a between- meal drink or as a basis for soup has the misleading name of buttermilk. As a child in the South, I grew up on it; back then, pardon the expression, the name was more richly deserved. The milk was made from clabbered milk, which is to say milk that had been left to stand and become slightly sour overnight (thanks to the action of harmless bacteria). The fat from the milk would rise to the top, and the milk would be churned up and down with a ''paddle.'' The top fat would become sweet butter, and there would be flecks of this throughout the snow-white and, to my taste, delectable liquid that remained.

description: ''Olympia'' is returning. Leni Riefenstahl's famed camera record of the 1936 Berlin Olympics, with athletes representing 51 countries, will be shown in its entirety on the USA Network, Monday at 8 P.M. and Saturday at 1 P.M.

Mr. Stockman, whose Government salary is $72,600 a year, reported $101 to $1,000 in reprint fees for an article he once wrote on energy policy and less than $100 in dividends each from the Wright Patman Congressional Credit Union and the Allegheny Beverage Corporation of New York.

description: Two militia soldiers, one of them a woman, were killed today when their patrol was attacked by landmine and gunfire on the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, the police said.

title: PENNSYLVANIA SETTLES KEY SUIT ON FACILITIES FOR THE RETARDED
description: The first lawsuit in the nation to argue that the mentally retarded have a constitutional right to living quarters and education in their home communities has been settled after 10 years with state officials agreeing to shut down the Pennhurst Center for the Mentally Retarded.

title: FRUITS OF SUMMER FOR DESERT
description: HOW often do we get the chance to taste an apricot that is warm from the sun and bursting with flavor, or a peach so juicy you almost need to wear a bathing suit to eat it? We get our peaches, plums, nectarines or apricots from the supermarket or fruit stand. These usually look perfect. But their looks deceive. All show, it turns out, for when it comes to eating, very often they fall into two categories: hard or woolen.

title: Review: Muriel Sparks The Only Problem
description: The only problem for Muriel Spark, it would seem, is that there are many questions for few answers. This is the theme of her new novel, as it may well have been of all her others. Her devoted readers have always been aware that there is a metaphysical component to her fiction, and it is something of a relief that it has at last broken cover in the present work, which is both an extremely sophisticated account of the perils that surround our unsuspecting lives in the world today and a disputation on the subject of the Book of Job, which she calls ''the pivotal book of the Bible.'' Job and his disconcerting predicament challenge every optimistic belief one yearns to accept, lodging like a hard mass of contention in the consciousness of the hopeful believer. The same sort of existential distress is experienced by Mrs. Spark's current protagonist, Harvey Gotham, yet Mrs. Spark is too wise a writer to impose this metaphor on her readers, and her narrative is as seamless, as unnerving, and as expert as her readers have come to expect from this most excellent of storytellers.

title: GLOOM REMAINS, DESPITE A $3 BILLION INFUSION
description: One afternoon last week, a clerk in a gift shop in a Los Angeles hotel spent three minutes ringing up all the items that a sun-bronzed European man in his late 30's had piled up next to the cash register.

title: SELF-ABSORPTION FILTERED TROUGH ARTISTIC SOPHISTICATION
description: There is art that is ordered, thoughtful and intellectual, and there is art that is unruly, impulsive and emotional. Lucas Samaras's work clearly clings to the latter pole. His sculptures built of mirror shards and nails, his sewn-fabric ''paintings,'' his Polaroid photographs, his anti-ultilitarian furniture and his Rorschach-blot drawings add up to a byzantine catalogue of myth, perversity and creative self-indulgence. And yet there is a touch of self-consciousness about it all, the barest hint that Mr. Samaras knows exactly the effects his primitivist sensibility provokes. This trait of self-consciousness is not without virtue: it tempers the self-indulgence and narcissism, giving his compulsiveness an air of calculation.

title: LEGAL AID FOR THE PRESS
description: Reporters covering the Democratic National Convention here can call a ''hot line'' and obtain free legal service if arrested for misdemeanors other than drunkenness while working. The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press made the special arrangement with the San Francisco authorities.

title: METS WIN, 7-0, FOR 8TH STRAIGHT
description: The Mets breezed to their eighth straight victory tonight, their longest winning streak of the season, and put some space between themselves and second-place Chicago in the National League East.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
'IMAGINATION MUSCLE' STRONG BUT UNUSED
description: XIANA, brave girl of the jungle, rode her untamed steed until she came to the running water where her brother Chooyooch was fishing. She crossed the perilous river, stepping on sharp green slimy stones as the rapids swirled over her feet. Once, she almost fell into the rushing water, but she was surefooted and recovered her balance. Near the opposite shore, she grabbed a sturdy branch that supported her as she climbed the steep bank to safety. She called to Chooyooch to keep fishing. She would find meat.

title: REWORKING 'A QUIET PLACE' FOR LA SCALA
description: -eight hours prior to the premiere of Leonard Bernstein's newly revised opera, ''A Quiet Place and Trouble in Tahiti,'' at La Scala, Milan, the composer's nights were sleepless and tormented. Rehearsals were going badly, notes he had given his cast had not been followed, the promised technical crew had shown up a week late. Mr. Bernstein's anguish was such that he was ready to leave the production entirely in the hands of Stephen Wadsworth, his collaborator and director, and return home. ''I thought it would never work,'' he said. ''I wanted to leave then and there.''

Some time before Beattie departed the pressure and tumult of the Yankee scene, the operator of the asylum said he looked ''scared stiff'' on the mound. While Ken Clay was there, the operator said he had ''spit the bit.''

title: IS THE WESTERN REALLY DEAD, OR SIMPLY IN DISGUISE?
description: This evening, Home Box Office will present ''Draw!,'' a made-for-television feature film starring Kirk Douglas and James Coburn. Nothing so unusual in that, one might think, as the cable network has lately backed a number of original dramatic projects showcasing other performers of like stature. Yet for a movie made in 1984, HBO's venture is indisputably novel in one important respect. ''Draw!'' represents a genre that lately has vanished as surely as the free-ranging bison - the movie western.

title: YALTA:AN ANOMALY THAT SURPRISES
description: Almost everyone who visits the Soviet Union passes through Moscow, and most go on to Leningrad. For those with more time, Georgia and the fabled caravan stops along the old silk route - Tashkent, Bukhara and Samarkand - are favorites. They are places full of fascination, but when friends ask this correspondent to recommend a destination that isn't quite so obvious one name springs immediately to mind: Yalta, jewel of the Crimea, playground of Czar Nicholas II, site of possibly the most controversial diplomatic conference of the century.

The other transformation is in the role of the conventions, one that can be seen by examining the phrase ''gavel-to-gavel coverage,'' which is what the television networks have decided to abandon.

title: MORE BLACKS ARE TURNING TO THE POLITICS OF FRUSTRATION
description: In this former stronghold of segregation where the limits of black power are still clearly delineated, it is easier to see why so many black leaders are attempting to elect blacks to public office over white moderates who have worked with them in the past. The controversial movement away from coalition politics has taken hold from the largest cities to the rural areas of the South. And it is related to the exacerbation of the conflict between blacks and Jews, as well as to some of the controversy surrounding the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: FAVORITA:A WEALTH OF ART IN LUNGANO
description: Last summer, for the first time in my life, I coveted another man's house. Not for me a ducal chateau in the Loire or a penthouse overlooking Central Park or a hideaway on my very own Greek island. I want the Villa Favorita. The man who owns it, I tell myself in my pipe dreams, has lots of other places to live - one in Jamaica, one in St. Moritz, a stately pile near Oxford, a town house in Chester Square in London, a stupendous yacht; surely he could get along with less.
