title: LONDON PLAYS UNWILLING HOST TO FOREIGNERS' FEUDS
description: This most civilized of cities had an unpleasant shock nine days ago when Umaru Dikko, a former Nigerian Transport Minister, was found drugged and unconscious in a crate after being kidnapped from a street near his $600,000 Bayswater home. The British authorities made it clear that Nigerian diplomats were implicated. Despite Nigeria's importance as a Commonwealth country and a major market for British exports, London expelled two of its diplomats and said the Nigerian High Commissioner, Maj. Gen. Haldu Hananiya, would be unwelcome to return. Nigeria took reciprocal action, expelling two British diplomats and advising the British High Commissioner to leave Lagos.

title: Plane Slams Into Shed, Killing 6 in California
description: A twin-engine airplane slammed into a shed behind an automobile dealership and exploded in flames today, killing all six aboard the aircraft, the authorities said.

title: VILLAGE EXPERIMENTS WITH WILDFLOWERS
description: '' IT is a new concept here,'' said Peter Woodcock, Director of Public Works in Scarsdale, as he discussed the planting of wildflowers at selected locations throughout the village. ''We're doing it to try to eliminate some of the mowing in areas where we're planting, and also to make it more pleasing to the eye.''

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; CaliforniainMaine
description: Erwin Kreuz, a Bavarian brewery worker who spoke no English, visited the United States in 1977 and became a folk hero by getting off the plane too soon. He spent three days in Bangor, Me., believing it was San Francisco.

title: International
description: President Reagan was willing to delay the start of Soviet-proposed talks on space weapons until after November to keep the issue out of the Presidential campaign. The new element in the talks came in a letter to the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, according to Administration officials. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: Nancy Bader Is Bride Of Michael Leventhal
description: Nancy Rae Bader, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Bader of Fresh Meadows, Queens, and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Lawrence Leventhal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Leventhal of Smithtown, L.I. Rabbi Mordecai Efron performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: WALKOUT ADDS TO LILCOO'S WOES
description: WHEN 3,900 unionized employees struck the Long Island Lighting Company on Tuesday, the event was an acute problem for the company but not an isolated one. The strike was another chapter in a series of increasingly severe financial problems.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
HALL OF FAME MEDAL HONORS A NOBEL LAUREATE
description: World-renowned author, Isaac Bashevis Singer, turned 80 yesterday. He also became the 16th member of the Jewish-American Hall of Fame. To mark both occasions, the Magnes Museum of Berkeley, Calif. has issued a medal bearing the author's portrait and capturing his wry personality.

title: FIZZ THAT LASTS
description: Soft drink connoisseurs have long argued, and the beverage industry has long known, that the taste of soda pop depends on its ''vintage.''

title: Lisa Linden Plans to Wed David Rosenblatt Sept. 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Linden of Bayside, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Robin Linden, to David Allan Rosenblatt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Rosenblatt of Noank, Conn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 15.

title: MOZART OPERAS AT CASTLE HILL
description: An American Glyndebourne in Massachussetts? William Conner, the executive director of the Castle Hill Festival, thinks it can be done.

title: Daphne Geary Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Marian Smithers Moore of New York and John White Geary 2d of New York and Southampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Daphne Harrison Geary to William Morrison Waggaman, a son of Mrs. Robert Waggaman of Washington and Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mr. Waggaman.

title: WHAT'S IN A FRAME? LESS AND LESS AT THE MODERN
description: Now that all the hoopla is over, and the Museum of Modern Art is shaking down in its glossy new quarters, a certain change has come to light. Quietly but determinedly, though not without soul-searching, the Modern has reframed - or as one irate aficionado put it, downframed - most of the paintings in its first four 19th- and 20th-century ''introductory'' galleries, ending in 1906 with the Fauve period.

title: Greeks Discuss NATO With U.S. General
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the American who is top NATO commander in Europe, have ended talks on the inclusion of the Greek Aegean island of Lemnos in alliance exercises and the establishment of a NATO command in central Greece, an official close to the talks said today.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MAJORITY cards, which the State Department of Liquor Control phased out two years ago, will return next July 1 under the auspices of a different agency.

title: Wood Leads by 4 Shots
description: Willie Wood, the rookie who has been the leader since the first round, shot a 5-under-par 66 today to set a second season mark and expand his lead to four strokes after the third round of the $350,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: MUSICAL BY AND ABOUT WOMEN
description: '' I'M Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Road'' is a musical by women, about women and for women and the men they care for. Gretchen Cryer, the book and lyric writer, and Nancy Ford, the composer, have written a charming albeit barbed musical about a cabaret singer named Heather, who is putting a new act together, much to the emotional distress of Joe, her chauvinistic manager.

title: Sarah M. Poutasse, Buyer, Wed to W. J. Carpenter 3d
description: Sarah Meghan Poutasse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John David Poutasse of Pittsfield, Mass., was married there yesterday to William Joseph Carpenter 3d, the son of Mrs. Thomas Maguire of Pittsfield and the late Mr. Carpenter 2d.

title: UP, UP AND AWAY
description: More than 60 hot-air balloons will rise from Solberg Airport in Readington Township next weekend to vie in five races, the Northeast Regional Championships of the Balloon Federation of America. As many as 65,000 spectators are expected.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART, DICHTER AND OLIVEIRA
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival continued Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall with two concertos by Mozart and symphonies by two Haydns. The festival's orchestra was conducted by Gerard Schwarz with Misha Dichter and Elmar Oliveira the soloists.

title: L.I. DELEGARES 18-6 FOR MONDALE
description: LONG ISLAND delegates to the Democratic National Convention that opens tomorrow in San Francisco are overwhelmingly supporting Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Q&A

title: FRESH AIR CAMPERS LEARN THE SKIES
description: When were the first stars born?''

title: A PRAGMATIC AND CANDID STYLE
description: LAKE TAHOE, Calif. WHEN the Democrats were working two years ago to change the rules of delegate selection for their national convention that opens tomorrow, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro argued on behalf of the party leadership. She sought more seats for party officials, most of whom are white males. She was opposed in the debate by another woman, who represented feminist interests. In the end, Mrs. Ferraro prevailed. The composition of the officially uncommitted ''super delegates'' on the convention floor in San Francisco is largely her work. ''She was very tenacious, but very calm and even,'' said Cleta Deatherage Mitchell, a member of the Oklahoma Legislature. ''She tries to keep everyone from getting at each other's throats.''

title: Presidents I Have Known
description: Clifton Daniel shortchanged himself in his insightful article, ''Presidents I Have Known'' (June 3).

title: CHINA-U.S. TIES MAKE SOUTHEAST ASIA SQUIRM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has ended a trip to Southeast Asia obviously nettled by some of the criticism he has heard about American policy toward China.

description: AT first glance, the modest wood-frame

title: Indians 5, Rangers 0
description: Steve Farr pitched a five-hitter over eight and one-third innings for his first major league victory.

title: DISPLAYS AT THE HALE HOMESTEAD
description: THE old apple orchards and meadows that surround the house built by Nathan Hale's father in 1776 will be the setting Saturday for the 20th annual Nathan Hale outdoor antiques festival in Coventry.

title:
REGULATION AND GENETIC ENGENEERING;
BIOTECH SAFEGUARDS ARE ALREADY IN PLACE
description: BIOTECHNOLOGY is a generic term that has come to denote the industry built around some of the new biological fields, such as recombinant DNA, or gene splicing. In fact, the term identifies industry's application of any biological technology, including the fermentation process, which man has been using for the past 6,000 years.

title: COMMENTS MISLEADING, A FEMALE LAWYER SAYS
description: Our firm of 17 lawyers (Mandelbaum, Salsburg, Gold and Lazris of East Orange) has two female partners, one of whom started as an associate and became a partner.

title: RIGORS THAT CANCER PATIENTS ENDURE: READERS RESPOND
description: Joan Swirsky's article, ''Enough Rigors for Any Patient to Endure'' (Opinion Page, June 24), expresses so well the frustration of having to deal with a physical and mental nightmare without the comfort and support of those who are most able to help - the health team. A diagnosis of cancer almost instantly causes an individual to think that he has no chance of survival and will suffer disfigurement and pain while awaiting death. Certainly the family and extended family network can help buoy spirits, but one looks to experts for expert help and reassurance.

title: Washington and Lee Ends Men-Only Policy
description: The Washington and Lee University board of trustees decided today by a vote of 17 to 7 to admit women as undergraduates for the first time in 235 years. The policy goes into effect in the fall of 1985.

title: DANCE
description: The Sankai Juku group from Japan and the Jazz Tap Ensemble from California are the two very different companies that launch the dance side of the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Westchester County. All performances take place at the State University of New York in Purchase, including the outdoor event at 5 P.M. next Sunday (July 22) that will consist largely of the Japanese dancers suspended upside down from a building.

title: CANALSIDE HOSPITALITY
description: The Pulitzer is certainly not the grandest hotel in Amsterdam - the Amstel's claim to that title rests unchallenged - nor is it the most expensive. I would never recommend it to travelers who demand the ne plus ultra in luxury and the vicarious esteem that comes from knowing that Arab potentates and media-celebrated plutocrats are sleeping under the same roof. Among other insufficiencies, the hotel does not offer 24-hour room service and the staff lacks training in bowing and scraping. The bellhops welcome guests as long-lost relatives, the waiters treat them in an egalitarian manner.

title: PRIVATE GROUPS IN U.S. AIDING MANAGUA'S FOES
description: Nicaragua announced that it intended to proceed with a trial of a priest charged with counterrevolutionary activities. Page 11.

description: HENRY MORGAN is a longtime commentator and humorist on radio and television.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article ''The World of Pere Lachaise'' (Travel, June 17) stated incorrectly that Victor Hugo was buried in the Pere Lanchaise Cemetery in Paris. Hugo's remains are in the city's Pantheon

title: AS RELIGIOUS PARTIES FEUD, THEIR SECULAR POWER ERODES
description: More than ever before, Israel's religious parties seem to be fragmenting over nonreligious issues. Before the 1967 war, religious voters were offered a relatively simple choice: The Zionist National Religious Party, which sought to marry religious Judaism with modern secular nationalism, and the Agudat Yisrael party, made up of Orthodox non-Zionist Jews, whose primary concern was preservation of Jewish traditions until the coming of the Messiah. For the Agudat, Israel was just another secular state. The two parties, despite their small size, have always carried important political weight because the major parties, Labor and Likud, never had an absolute majority in Parliament. In return for taking part in coalition Governments, the religious parties won concessions ranging from grounding El Al, the national airline, on the Sabbath to maintaining strict Orthodox rabbinical control over marriages.

title: MORE WATERS ARE CLOSED FOR CLAMMING
description: WATER contamination is closing a widening area of the Island's shoreline to safe, legal clamming and shellfishing. The trend reflects increased shoreline development and stricter enforcement of shellfish purity standards by state and local officials.

title: ERUPTION IN 1783 OFFERS CHALLENGE
description: The widely accepted view that great volcanic eruptions invariably cool rather than warm the world climate has been challenged on the basis of a study of records kept in Europe after the 1783 eruption of the Laki volcano in Iceland.

title: French Cars Burned in Spain
description: Assailants hurling bottles filled with gasoline set fire today to four parked cars bearing French license plates, destroying three of them, the police said.

title: IN A STATE OF ODD POLITICS,SAN FRANCISCO STANDS OUT
description: SAN FRANCISCO THE only previous Democratic National Convention staged in San Francisco, and the first Presidential convention held west of the Rockies, was in 1920. The Democrats still used a rule, abandoned in 1936, requiring a two-thirds majority to nominate. After 44 ballots they picked the Governor of Ohio, James M. Cox, from 23 candidates. For Vice President, they chose the former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: BUSH OPENS ATTACK ON MONDALE;CITES FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC POLICY
description: Vice President Bush, opening a new phase in the Republican campaign for the White House, today directly attacked the economic and foreign policies of Walter F. Mondale.

description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Fire Damages Dublin College
description: A fire destroyed part of Trinity College Dublin Friday night, but most of its valuable paintings and silver were saved, officials said. The blaze destroyed the roof and part of the upper story of the college's 18th-century dining room. One fireman was injured.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS TAKEN
description: The New York Times survey of Democratic delegates is based on telephone interviews conducted June 14 through July 9 with 1,561 delegates. This includes 523 of the 568 unpledged delegates and 1,038 of the 3,376 pledged delegates.

title: Gale T. Pryor Plans to Marry
description: A winter wedding is planned by Gale Taylor Pryor and Karl Devon Leabo, who graduated with the class of '83 from Cornell University.

title: Members of Opposition Are Arrested in Seoul
description: Nine members of a new opposition political group were detained by the police Friday night as they tried to set up headquarters at a downtown office building, witnesses said today.

title: IN SEARCH OF A LAUREATE:MAKING BOOK ON BRITAIN'S NEXT OFFICIAL POET
description: THE death of John Betjeman in May not only removed from the scene a notable poet - and in Britain, at least, a notably popular one - but also left vacant the office of Poet Laureate, which Betjeman had held since 1972. Now someone else will have to be found to turn out verses commemorating jubilees and great occasions and royal milestones. The appointment, formally made by the Queen but on the Prime Minister's recommendation, is not expected to be announced until the autumn, but it has already provoked a great deal of comment in Britain - far more, I think, than was the case while Betjeman and his immediate predecessors were being chosen. Leading bookmakers are even offering odds on the main contenders, and finding plenty of takers. Philip Larkin is the clear favorite so far; other names who have suddenly found themselves propelled onto the front page include Roy Fuller and D. J. Enright, Gavin Ewart and the Cornish poet Charles Causley.

title: DESPITE SHAW'S SCORN, THE BRAHMS REQUIEM ENDURES
description: No doubt to the eternal discomfiture of Johannes Brahms, the name that comes most immediately to mind in conjunction with his German Requiem is George Bernard Shaw. Shaw was a music critic before he established his fame as a dramatist, and some think he was the most brilliant of them all; certainly he was the most stylishly dazzling.

title: Shift at Washington Times
description: Smith Hempstone has become editor in chief of The Washington Times, succeeding James R. Whelan in the top editorial position, the newspaper announced Friday. Mr. Whelan had been editor and publisher and Mr. Hempstone had been executive editor. The newspaper said full responsibility for business operations would be assumed by Paul Rothenburg, general manager.

title: THE POLITICS OF SAFETY HAS A LIFE OF ITS OWN
description: When President Reagan sets his re-election campaign in full gear, he is likely to boast of success in slashing Federal regulations for once-sheltered industries such as the banking business and the airlines.

title: LIBRRAIES ENTICING CHILDREN TO READ
description: TIME VOYAGERS could be the latest craze for youngsters this summer, if a new program by a county institution goes forward as planned. It is not, however, a video game, a television show or a movie.

title: IDEAS FOR HIS SPEECH LED MONDALE TO MRS. FERRARO
description: A little over a week ago Walter F. Mondale sat down with a political supporter and talked about his interviews with Vice- Presidential contenders. Mr. Mondale warmly praised Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco and then brought up the name of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens.

title: IN THE ENGLISH MANNER
description: -BEDROOM PARK AVENUE apartment from a large Sutton Place maisonette a few years ago. ''I have a house in Southampton and wanted a manageable place in town,'' says Josef Pricci. Nevertheless, when it came time to decorate the apartment, Pricci opted for the kind of furnishings - overstuffed furniture, billowing draperies and collections of collections - that are more often associated with grand English country houses than with Manhattan pied- a-terres. ''I wanted to create the feeling of a home rather than an apartment,'' says Pricci. The result is a gracious, well-mannered interior that translates the feeling of the English country house into a more urbane scheme. This might be because Pricci was not schooled in interior decoration. Although he majored in economics and designed jewelry for a number of years, Pricci sort of fell into interior design when he was asked to do a 22-room duplex eight years ago. ''Of course it was done in the English manner,'' says Pricci. ''I had grown up in apartments and country houses that were always filled with English things, so it was an easy style for me to fall into. And it was the style I knew the best.''

title: A COMMANDING VOICE FOR THE MILITARY
description: Richard Halloran, a member of The Times's Washington bureau, covers military affairs.

title: SOVIET TARGET:AFGHAN AREAS AIDING REBELS
description: Soviet forces in Afghanistan, now in their fifth year of fighting, have greatly disrupted the rural communities that have been supporting the Afghan rebels, military analysts say.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photo caption on page 2 of the Real Estate section last Sunday incorrectly described the house above it as designed or overseen by Frank Lloyd Wright. The house was a prefabricated structure built in the 1950's and later expanded.

title: SOUND ; NEW DESIGNS KEEP CASSETTES FROM MELTING IN THE SUN
description: ''A snowball's chance in hell.'' The homey phrase applies quite literally to the fate of a stereo cassette left in the glove compartment of a parked car in midsummer. Unshaded in the noonday sun, a car certainly qualifies as a vestibule to Hades. Dashboard temperatures up to 220 degrees Fahrenheit have been measured under such conditions; so when you get back to your car your music may have twisted into a pretzel.

title: MEDICAL MALPRACTICE COST DEBATED AT HEARING
description: The costs of premiums for medical malpractice insurance and of malpractice litigation are rising at the most alarming rates since the mid-1970's, representatives of physician, hospital and insurance groups have told Congress.

title: Mittee Stops Spaniard
description: Sylvester Mittee of Britain stopped Perico Fernandez of Spain, the former World Boxing Council light-welterweight champion, in the fifth round of a scheduled 10-round welterweight fight today. The 31-year-old Spaniard, who had never been knocked out in 112 professional bouts, was being badly outclassed when the referee intervened.

title: KENNY DELMAR, RADIO'S SENATOR CLAGHORN, DIES
description: Kenny Delmar, the actor who played the blustery Southern Senator Beauregard Claghorn on the old Fred Allen radio show, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. He was 73 and lived in Stamford.

title: Marines Oust a Captain In Love With a Corporal
description: A Marine Corps pilot has been convicted of ''conduct unbecoming an officer and gentleman'' and other charges when he decided to marry an enlisted woman and would not stop seeing her, officials say.

title: ;  Drew Pearson Retires
description: Drew Pearson , the 33-year-old wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, says his professional football career is over. Pearson, who underwent surgery to repair damage to his liver after an automobile accident earlier this year, made the announcement from Dallas in a telephone conversation with the Cowboys' coach, Tom Landry .

title: GIFTS TO OFFICIAL RULED NOT PROOF OF EXTORTION
description: A public official cannot be convicted of Federal extortion charges for merely accepting some gifts from companies doing business with his agency, according to an appeals court.

title: Boyhood Echoes Of Jersey City
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PRO-SOLIDARITY POLISH PRIEST SAYS HE IS ACCUSED OF CAUSING UNREST
description: A pro- Solidarity Roman Catholic priest under investigation for purported abuse of religious freedom said today that he faces charges of causing public unrest.

title: No Headline
description: Hart and Jackson Meet Over Manatt Situation

title: NEW HELP OFFERED TO COCAINE USERS
description: LAST fall, middle-class, upper- management people started showing up at Liberation House, a drug treatment center in Stamford, ''complaining they were not having control of a drug they thought they were supposed to have control of,'' said Norman Itkowitz, a program coordinator. They were cocaine users, afraid their habit threatened their jobs and their marriages.

title: DRIVING ACROSS THE SOVIET BOONDOCKS
description: S. Frederick Starr is the president of Oberlin College. His most recent book is ''Red and Hot: The Fate of Jazz in the Soviet Union, 1917-1980.'' WHERE NIGHTS ARE LONGEST

title: Top-Seeded Miss Callen Loses U.S. Clay Final
description: Hee Baek of Houston used a powerful serve in a 6-4, 6-0 victory over top- seeded Becky Callen of Boulder, Colo., in the women's singles final of the United States Tennis Association's national amateur clay court championships today.

title: MR. FIX-IT ; TURNAROUND MAN AT MONGOMERY WARD
description: STEPHEN L. PISTNER doesn't

title: Scott Beats Walker At Finish of Mile
description: The sponsors of today's Kinney Invitational track meet gave a poster to each of the 17,433 spectators who bought a ticket. The poster hero was Steve Scott, and he said thank you by winning the featured mile.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ; BROADCAST TV
description: Pandas came once more into the news this year when Nancy Reagan gave Chinese officials $13,000 from a ''Pennies for Pandas'' campaign that had been conducted by American school-children. Indeed, it is hard to think unkind thoughts about pandas, and practically everyone loves them.

title: MIKE NICHOLS:THE DIRECTOR'S ART
description: In Barbara Gelb's article on Mike Nichols and in Barbara Ehrenreich's ''A Feminist's View of the New Man'' (May 20), we have seen articles about men who are professionally successful but emotionally and personally frozen. As evidence, note Mr. Nichols's description of an insanely jealous woman as a ''dead mammoth'' and the eerily remote and cold quality to the photograph of his wife and himself.

title:
GARDENING;
KNOWING WHEN TO HARVEST
description: PERHAPS there are as many reasons for engaging in gardening activities as there are gardeners. Some enjoy the exercise, while others love the opportunity it provides to ''get back to nature.'' When it comes to growing fruits and vegetables, however, there can be little doubt that the main goal is enjoying the flavor and quality of home-grown produce.

title: CITY'S FIRST NEW FIREHOUSE IN 12 YEARS OPENS IN QUEENS
description: Happy to have the big brick box in their tree-lined midst and eager to get a rare glimpse of their Mayor, the people of Bayside, Queens, filled Springfield Boulevard last Monday for the first opening of a New York City firehouse in 12 years.

title: Mark Friedman, Lawyer, to Wed Leslie J. Koeppel
description: Announcement has been made by M. Herbert Koeppel of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of his daughter Leslie Joyce Koeppel to Mark L. Friedman, a son of Irving Friedman of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Rose Friedman. The wedding is planned for September.

title: KEEPING TRACK OF AMERICAN PRESIDENCY
description: FOR more than 50 years, William Michaelsen of Croton-on- Hudson has been fascinated by the United States Presidency. ''I can't put my finger on what it is that intrigues me,'' he said during a recent interview. ''Of course, it's such a prestigious office. It's one of the really original inventions of the United States.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION ;
STATE LOANS THAT CREATE JOBS
description: FOR a while, it seemed that in order for Stanley Rabinowitz, owner of Yorkville Industries in Farmingdale, to finance the expansion of his lighting products business, he would have to move his company's headquarters and 200 jobs out of state. Then, through the information given him by a Long Island builder, Mr. Rabinowitz put in an application for a low-interest loan from New York's Job Development Authority.

title: FINALLY, THIS HENRY BECOMES A LIVING, BREATHING HERO
description: Shakespeare's ''Henry V,'' like his ''Merchant of Venice,'' has come to embarrass and distress many of us; and yet, almost as much as ''The Merchant,'' it would seem to operate on two levels, one obvious and official and the other not so obvious and unofficial. Shylock is allowed to say too much on his own behalf, and the Christians are too often permitted to expose their opportunism and avarice, for the earlier play to be bluntly dismissed as anti-Semitic propaganda. And Shakespeare opens ''Henry V'' by suggesting that the great Agincourt campaign was inspired by Machiavellian churchmen, who saw in it a way of deflecting legislation that would rob them of revenues; he goes on to show the fear, the resentment, the cynicism and the rapacity to be found in the ranks of the conquering army; and in the very last sentence of the play he reminds the audience that Henry VI promptly lost everything his father had so painfully gained in France. ''The surface meaning is certainly that Agincourt was a lovely war,'' the dramatist John Arden once wrote, ''but there are so many corrections of this view in the structure that one is forced to wonder if the author had not written a secret play within the public one.''

title: MORE INDICATIONS OF STEADY GROWTH
description: Most economists rejoiced with the release of new indicators showing the economy has hit its stride. Many of the forecasts were off target again, but economists said that just meant they would have to revise their expectations upward. Producer prices were unchanged in June, the third month they have been at a plateau, surprising forecasters who had expected a small increase. Drops in the prices of both food and gasoline mean that inflation at the producer level is running at a 2.8 percent annual rate, far below the 4 to 5 percent forecast by most economists.

title: DEPRESSED LILCO LOSES ITS 'ONLY FRIEND'
description: Even after consumers complained about the Long Island Lighting Company's high electric rates and politicians fought its costly Shoreham atomic plant and investors lost confidence, the embattled utility's workers remained loyal, defending management and its decisions. That 3,900 union members walked off their jobs last week in the first strike in Lilco's 74-year history underscored the company's desperation. Several weeks from bankruptcy, its stock at a record low, its finished Shoreham plant unopened, Lilco has now been shrunk to 1,465 supervisors and nonunion employees who are trying to keep the system running while a pared-down management team tries to keep the utility afloat.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL ON July 23, 1903, Theodore Roosevelt made a Presidential visit to Meadowcroft, his cousin John Ellis Roosevelt's summer home in Sayville. But behaving true to form, Teddy Roosevelt did not arrive the traditional Presidential way; he rode into town on horseback from his Oyster Bay estate.
description: To commemorate the jaunt - and publicize efforts to preserve and restore Meadowcroft - local historical societies on Saturday will re-enact the visit. Taking a short cut, ''Mr. Roosevelt'' ( James Foote of the Theodore Roosevelt Association) and his entourage, composed of his ''son Theodore Jr.'' and his ''nephews George and Jack Roosevelt'' (young members of the Islip Horsemen's Association), will saddle up at the Veterans of Foreign Wars parking lot on Railroad Avenue at 10 A.M. and then proceed to Middle Road and Meadowcroft.

title: HOMELESSNESS SPREADING TO BEDROOM COMMUNITIES

Such a scene, unimaginable a few years ago among the split levels, two-car garages and tree-lined streets, is still rare enough to startle passers-by. But there is growing evidence that the cancer of homelessness has spread beyond the city line to the suburbs.

Citizens, including members of the League of Women Voters, have responded to most of the public meetings relating to Mitchel Field, and have been asking since 1982 for an assessment of the cumulative impacts of the whole Mitchel Field development on our human environment, air quality, water and traffic.

title: WHAT ABOUT THOSE VEXING BLURBS?
description: There is an element of deceit, however slight, in any sales pitch. The idea, after all, is to put the product in the kindest possible light. The fruit vendor arranges his boxes so that the biggest and ripest strawberries are on top. The sports car salesman focuses attention on speed and rakish lines, not on miles-per-gallon. And, just as naturally, musicians or their managers issue publicity brochures that quote the flossiest words and phrases that can be winnowed from reviews: ''Stunning...a revelation'' - The Bigtown Gazette.

title: Smashing Projects
description: After building a 2.4-mile circular tunnel on Long Island and starting work on an atom smasher that was to have used the tunnel, the Federal Department of Energy was told by a panel of physicists a year ago that the project really should be scrapped. Some $200 million had been spent on the work at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, but the physicists - a subcommittee of the department's High Energy Physics Advisory Panel - said the atom smasher would be obsolete by the time it was finished in 1987.

Those days are happily gone, and Connecticut music lovers can now revel in much the same glorious cultural profusion in July that brightens their November.

STAMPS;
FIRST ENGLISH COLONY
description: A 16th-century vessel under full sail on the Atlantic Ocean is shown on a new 20-cent commemorative. The stamp marks the 400th anniversary of the Roanoke Voyages that extended from 1584 to 1590. They led to establishment of the first English colony in the New World.

title: WHAT CONSTITUTES A CIVIL RIGHT?
description: Morris Abram devotes much of his article to denouncing those who regard what he calls ''economic entitlements'' (shelter, day care for children, health care) and affirmative-action programs as civil rights. The basis of his argument is that none of these desiderata ''are to be found in the Constitution.''

title: Laura Childs To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Laura Mabon Childs, a vice president of the investment banking firm of Becker Paribas in New York, to Kenneth A. Saverin, an associate with the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. J. Mabon Childs of Pittsburgh, parents of the bride-to- be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Saverin of Manhasset, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: Wendy Van Cott Wed in Maryland
description: Wendy Jane Van Cott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius James Van Cott of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Robert Emerson Lamb Johnson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Jr. of Gibson Island, Md., and Albany. The Rev. William R. Wooten Jr. performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in Kensington, Md.

description: Harry Sieber, chairman of the department of Hispanic and Italian studies at Johns Hopkins University, teaches Renaissance and Baroque Spanish literature. TIRANT LO BLANC

description: Senator Gary Hart's campaign took hope today from opposition that developed in response to reports Walter F. Mondale had decided to elevate Bert Lance to a prominent position in the Democratic Party. But the hope quickly fizzled when the Mondale camp announced that Mr. Lance would be chairman of the Mondale campaign.

title: ...AN EXAMPLE OF FIRST-CLASS JOURNALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Maria Alkiewicz Is Connecticut Bride
description: Maria Sabine Alkiewicz, the daughter of Andrzej Witold Alkiewicz of Ridgefield, Conn., and Janet Wallace Ley of Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to Edward Clay Penberthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Penberthy of Rowayton, Conn. The ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield was performed by the Rev. Frederic D. Hoesli, a priest, and by the Rev. Richard C. Devor, the bridegroom's uncle and a Methodist minister.

title: WAYS TO CUT DOWN ON NOISE
description: ONE problem that has become increasingly bothersome to homeowners in recent years is noise pollution. As houses become more and more airtight, with the help of air-conditioning in the summer and weatherstripping plus storm windows in the winter, occupants are being bombarded on all sides not only by noises from outside the house but also by those generated inside.

title: 'It's a Rare Dog That Is an Idiot'
description: Upon reading ''Frisky, How Could You?'' by Ruth Jernick (Opinion Page, July 1), I have to write my piece. It is a rare dog that is an idiot.

title: No Headline
description: Leslie Homer Betrothed

title: ALEXANDER RAMSDEN POUCH WEDS EILEEN M. MORRISSEY
description: Eileen Marie Morrissey, the daughter of Thomas L. Morrissey of Deal, N.J., and the late Doris Pier Morrissey, was married yesterday to Alexander Ramsden Pouch, a son of Alfred T. Pouch Jr. of Dongan Hills, S.I., and Mrs. David P. Lighthill of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Urban Voll, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Deal.

title: MORTGAGES: SO FAR SO GOOD
description: Although economists warn that rising interest rates could convert adjustable-rate mortgages into financial time bombs for homeowners of modest means, lenders have yet to hear any ticking. The only explosion thus far has been in the numbers of adjustable-rate mortgages being issued.

title: Jeffrey Himmel Weds Leslie Ellen Wohlman
description: Leslie Ellen Wohlman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Wohlman of White Plains, was married at the Pierre Hotel in New York yesterday to Jeffrey Steven Himmel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Himmel of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Seth Bernstein officiated.

title: AT AGE 59, EXPERIENCED BUT JOBLESS
description: HE gave himself enough time, found a parking space in the company's huge lot. Despite the sleepless night's thoughts, he walked toward the entrance feeling a bit optimistic. Nice, sunny morning, he told himself.

title: MONDALE REQUESTS THAT MANATT QUIT PARTY'S TOP POST
description: As Democrats gathered here today for their 39th national convention, Walter F. Mondale acted to remove Charles T. Manatt as chairman of the Democratic National Committee and announced the creation of a new job of general chairman of the Mondale campaign for Bert Lance.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHEN CHOOSING CHECKBOOK GRPAHICS, CONSIDER RELEVANCE
description: A CERTAIN dread is upon me once again. This dread crops up about two or three times a year, depending on how many checks I write. And what's the nature of this dread? Fear of being overdrawn? Fear of financial embarrassment? No. Not at all. I am petrified that once again I will have to select a graphic design that is to appear on my checks.

Lipsay of Floral Park, Queens, and Alan W. Lipsay of Manhattan. Rabbi Robert Kirzner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: STATE FAULTED OVER RATES TO HOSPITALS
description: PRINCETON OFFICERS of the New Jersey Hospital Association here have charged that the recent disagreement between Washington and Trenton over 1984 hospital rates in New Jersey has stemmed in part from miscalculations by the state's Department of Health.

title: SANDMAN REMEMBERS
description: ERMA PARK TEN YEARS ago this month in nationally televised hearings, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s voice was the most strident one against the articles of impeachment that a majority of his fellow House Judiciary Committee members had voted against then-President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Turkish 5-Year Plan Seeks Economic Growth
description: Parliament has approved a five- year economic plan designed to cut inflation, increase exports and prepare for full membership in the European Economic Community.

title:
ROBOTS IN THE WORKPLACE: A CALL TO ARMS;
MAKING A CASE FOR UNMANNED FACTORIES
description: TECHNOLOGICAL advances with industrial robots are making possible drastic changes in manufacturing - changes that will have a greater impact on the economy and society of the United States than any events of the last 40 years.

title: PATERSN TAKES A SHARE IN OFFICE GROWTH
description: PATERSON, the old settlement on the Passaic River that was the country's first industrial city, was one of the last of New Jersey's major communities to begin the shift from manufacturing plants and factories to the sleek, new office towers of the post-industrial era.

title: TENNIS EVENT IN LIVINGSTON
description: GENE SCOTT, who played for the United States in the Davis Cup competition, remembers how hard it was for him as an aspiring youngster to get into any major tennis tournament.

title: Dorian Beth Harris Weds
description: Dorian Beth Harris, a daughter of Friede A. Harris of Manchester, and the late Howard E. Harris, was married in Manchester yesterday to Dr. Scott Paul Price, a son of Carol Price Fischer of the Bronx and the late Stanford L. Price. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Hildene, Robert Todd Lincoln's home. The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is an assistant film editor of the forthcoming movie ''The Cotton Club.'' Dr. Price is a chief resident in orthopedic surgery at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

description: Amy Gail Spiegelman, the daughter of Mrs. Harold Eisenberg Jr. of New York and Lee Arnold Spiegelman of Coconut Grove, Fla., was married in Coconut Grove yesterday to Daniel Edward Kelly 2d, a son of Dr. Kelly of Miami Lakes, Fla., and Joyce Kelly of South Miami, Fla. Judge Moie J. L. Tendreich of the Florida State Circuit Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: ;  Hamilton Skates OnMaking his pro debut at the Sun Valley (Idaho) Ice Show this weekend,
description: Scott Hamilton , the Olympic figure-skating champion, said he was glad his amateur days were over and said he hoped the Games would be open to all athletes, amateur or pro.

description: Our new co-op is beginning to organize and would like to establish house rules. Are there any model rules governing such issues as noise, carpeting and other cooperative behavior? . . . J. P. M., Manhattan

title: 2 Legal Groups Charge Escorts Killed Aquino
description: Two lawyers' groups charged in a report today that Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader who was slain at the Manila airport Aug. 21, 1983, was killed by his military escorts as part of a high-level ''military conspiracy.''

description: New York's China Hands

title: DRUG COMPANY OFFERS $120 MILLION IN SETTLEMENT
description: Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals agreed today to set up a $120 million fund for hundreds of people who said their birth defects were caused by by Bendectin, an anti- nausea drug taken by millions of women during pregnancy.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Francisco (Pancho) Segura, Neale Fraser, Manuel (Manolo) Santana, John Bromwich and Adrian Quist were inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame at Newport, R.I. . . . The British Open will start Thursday at St. Andrews, Scotland, without three top American golfers. Tom Weiskopf, who won the tournament 11 years ago; Curtis Strange and Lou Graham all withdrew yesterday. . . . The Milwaukee Bucks plan to match the estimated $1.7 million, five-year contract offered by the Kansas City Kings to Paul Mokeski, their 7-foot reserve center. . . . Oklahoma linebacker Jackie Shipp, the top draft choice of Miami, has finalized a contract with the Dolphins after holding out two days.

Bonser of Dallas. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

description: For more than 20 years many record collectors have considered Discophile not only New York's pre- eminent specialty shop but possibly the finest record store in the world.

description: A Cosmetic Problem

title: AN IRISH PUB WITH A VARIED MENU
description: TO call Finn MacCool's in Port Washington an Irish pub does not tell the full story. The theme of this new place is decidedly Gaelic; one side of the spacious premises is occupied by a bar that seems to have an active following and remains open until 3 A.M., but the dining areas are extremely pleasant. They have subdued lighting, brick walls and cozy, attractive setting. Touches of green are evident without being overbearing, and ducks made out of straw, metal and pottery are placed around the room. The breadbasket, which comes filled with Irish soda bread as well as rolls, is also in the shape of a duck.

description: While others worry about sustaining life and song on Times Square, New York's Harbor Festival Foundation worries about keeping waterfront memories alive.

description: Lisa Lynn Edmondson and William G. Spears Jr. plan to be married Sept. 15, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Paul Edmondson of San Marino, Calif., have announced. Mr. Spears is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gerli Spears of Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE REGION
description: More Inspectors Are Indicted

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MASTERS FESTIVAL

title:
DINING OUT;
A RESTAURANT NEAR CARAMOOR
description: THE restaurant site at the Katonah Station has changed hands many times. Right now the restaurant is called S.B.R.'s for Samuel Boyd Rogers, the owner, and it has been open for more than a year and a half, which might be a record. It serves simple, unimaginative dishes, decently prepared, and, coincidentally, it is one answer to readers' requests for dining spots near Caramoor, just three miles away. Those desiring a pre-concert meal had best announce curtain time at the outset; dining room staff can be inexperienced and the pacing slow.

title: Shari Kahn, a Lawyer, To Wed Todd Krouner
description: The engagement of Shari Lynne Kahn to Todd J. Krouner has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Ivan J. Kahn of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Krouner of Albany.

title: SAUL HOROWITZ, RETIRED CHIEF OF H.R.H. CONSTRUCTION CO.
description: Saul Horowitz, retired chairman of the H.R.H. Construction Company, which built many of the grand Manhattan apartment houses of the 1920's, died last Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: DON'T MENTION STALIN BY NAME
description: WILD BERRIES

title:
GARDENING;
KNOWING WHEN TO HARVEST
description: PERHAPS there are as many reasons for engaging in gardening activities as there are gardeners. Some enjoy the exercise, while others love the opportunity it provides to ''get back to nature.'' When it comes to growing fruits and vegetables, however, there can be little doubt that the main goal is enjoying the flavor and quality of home-grown produce.

title: BUYERS GET A HELPING HAND ON MORTGAGES

title: SOTHEBY SUIT PUTS LAW UP FOR GRABS
description: Before the sale of 58 rare Hebrew books and manuscripts at Sotheby Parke Bernet last month, the auctioneer made an unusual announcement. Speaking before a packed audience in the auction house's main gallery, he strongly suggested to prospective buyers that the ''good title'' of ownership to some of the items might be questioned after the sale.

title: AT CATHEDRAL IN YORK, SOOT AND HOPE
description: Maimed but still magnificent, York Minster prepared today for its first Sunday services since a fire ravaged its south transept before dawn last Monday.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: GAMBLING WITH HISTORY: Ronald Reagan in the White House, by Laurence I. Barrett. (Penguin, $8.95.) Our reviewer, Nicholas Lemann, described ''Gambling With History'' as ''an impressively clear and thorough account of the past three years'' of Ronald W. Reagan's life. Laurence I. Barrett, chief White House correspondent for Time magazine for those three years, ''obviously likes the President personally,'' Mr. Lemann believes, but ''there is no cheerleading here.'' Portraits of Reagan lieutenants are vivid, Mr. Lemann wrote, and ''descriptions of their elaborate efforts to change the mind of the intellectually immobile leader on issues like the Federal deficit are a little scary.'' THE GEEK, by Craig Nova. (Dell, $3.95.) The story of a young American expatriate on a Greek island and his relationships with the islanders and a young American woman, ''The Geek'' is one of Craig Nova's four novels. C. D. B. Bryan, our reviewer, wrote, ''It has been a long time - a very long time - since I have come across a novel so gripping, a talent so exciting, so immense and so pure that I am ashamed I have not read him before. This book is so powerful, so alive, it is a wonder that turning its pages doesn't somehow burn one's hands.''

title: DISCIPLINE BY FIRING SQUAD
description: Peter Vansittart's latest book is ''Voices From the Great War.'' FOR THE SAKE OF EXAMPLE

title: Miss Crocker Plans to Wed An Architect
description: Catherine Rae Crocker, who received a master's degree in international relations in the spring from Yale University, and Stephen Andrew Moser, who received a master's degree in architecture this spring from Harvard University, plan to be married Aug. 18.

title: MAN DIES AS OUT-OF-CONTROL CAR DRIVES OFF CROWDED BROOKLYN PIER
description: A man was killed yesterday afternoon when a car went out of control on the crowded Canarsie Pier in Brooklyn, knocked him into the water, then drove into Jamaica Bay, officials said.

title: A DISGRUNTLED FRANCE
description: France is in a state of inner turmoil as it celebrates this 195th anniversary of Bastille Day. The left is in power, but it is broadly unpopular.

title: FACING THE PROBLEM OF DOCTORS ON DRUGS
description: S HORTLY after two years of service as a physician in the United States Navy, Dr. Robert Abel's medical career came to an abrupt halt. He had become addicted to drugs. Over a three- week period, he said, he went from being a social drinker to using intravenous narcotics. ''I used so heavily that I immediately became nonfunctional,'' he said.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: B EING unable to walk has not kept Rosalie B. Cooper of Lakewood from moving onward and upward.

title: REAGAN IS WILLING TO DELAY A PARLEY ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: President Reagan, in a letter to the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, has said he is willing to delay the start of Soviet- proposed talks on space weapons until after November to keep the issue out of the Presidential campaign, according to Administration officials.

title: DWIGHT GOODEN'S 'SYNCHRONIZATION'
description: NEWPORT, R.I. He's considered to be golf's premier professor, but Bob Toski studies as much as he teaches. By the nature of his role in analyzing the movement of a golfer's swing, he applies kinetic knowledge to athletes in all sports. At the Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am, where he is the honoree here this weekend, he suddenly started talking about Dwight Gooden, the Mets' rookie right-hander who walked into the All-Star Game last Tuesday and fired his fastball for three quick strikeouts. The more Bob Toski talked, the more his eyes lit up, the way a scientist's do at a great discovery.

title: JAPAN'S NEW DANCE IS DARKLY EROTIC
description: Something dark and definite has stirred in the Japanese dance world and we are just beginning to feel the effect. Granted, there is nothing totally ''new'' in the arts nowadays. Nonetheless, the rise of the dance esthetic in Japan that calls itself Butoh signals a phenomenon unto itself. A compound of the grotesque and the beautiful, the nightmarish and the poetic, the erotic and the austere, the streetwise and the spiritual, Butoh is a highly theatrical form.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON
description: -ON-HUDSON was named after Hastings, England, or so the story goes, because the hilly nature of the Westchester County village reminded an early settler of the cliffs of the British coastal town. More than a century later, those features remain an important part of the community's personality.

title: Bomb Kills 10 in Angola
description: A bomb killed 10 people and damaged a major pipeline at the Angolan city of Chimbolo in Cabinda Province, the official Angolan press agency said today. The agency, in a dispatch received here, reported that the bomb destroyed a house where a family of 10 was sleeping. It said the attack was the work of guerrillas opposed to the Angolan Government.

title: THE COURT'S CONSERVATIVES ARE MAKING THEIR MARK
description: Forces ''deep below consciousness'' shape a judge's work, Benjamin N. Cardozo wrote more than 60 years ago in ''The Nature of the Judicial Process.''

title: HIGH MINDS AT LIFE AND WORK

title: BADLY TREATED BY ALL HER SONS

title: 'THE ALAMO' IS AN OFFBEAT AMERICAN BARROOM BALLAD
description: ''Last Night at the Alamo,'' an 82-minute import from Texas, photographed on grainy, black- and-white film stock, is a small, unassuming, all-American classic. It's the kind of low- budget, regional movie that suddenly reminds us that, between New York and Hollywood, there's a vast, unruly, exuberant continent and filmmakers still capable of seeing and hearing what's going on in it. It's simultaneously funny and bleak, sweet and unsentimental. If I had to choose the one current film that most accurately reflects what a certain kind of American life is like today, this would be the film.

title: IN SOVIET, RELIGION CEASES OUTSIDE CHURCH DOORS
description: ''The question of religion here is very complicated,'' a spokesman for the state-controlled Russian Orthodox Church said in a recent interview.

title: CRAFTING BRAND-NEW 'ARTIFACTS'
description: JEFFREY KALIN hacks hatchets from stone, chips arrowheads and flakes flint knives that would satisfy any Stone Age man. Mr. Kalin, a 33-year- old experimental archeologist, has perfected the arts of Stone Age toolmaking, hide tanning and shelter building through the study of Connecticut's rich archeological sites.

title: A PARTNER; At First and 51st A Partner
description: An Ohio bank has become a partner in a $33 million project to convert the former school building at First Avenue and 51st Street into apartments.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT

title: WINDOW TIPS;  How to enliven window displays with such inexpensive props as tin cans and paper bags, and how to add dramatic lighting and eye-catching colors to draw shoppers are among the tricks of the window-dressing trade offered in two booklets recently published by the Public Development Corporation.
description: The widow display guides evolved from the corporation's Neighborhood Economic Development Program and were devised as tools to help local merchants improve business with enticing window treatments.

title: Survey Gives an Edge To Reagan-Bush Ticket By United Press International
description: A Mondale-Ferraro Democratic ticket would trail a Reagan-Bush ticket by only six percentage points if the Presidential election were held now, Newsweek magazine said yesterday.

title: WHAT CONSTITUTES A CIVIL RIGHT?
description: The New York Times made a wise decision to print Morris Abram's article, ''What Constitutes a Civil Right?'' Finally you allowed the ''other side'' newsprint sace. CLARENCE M. PENDLETON JR. Chairman

title: The Mathematics Of Chaos
description: It was very exciting to see James Gleick's article, ''Solving the Mathematical Riddle of Chaos'' (June 10). It was particularly gratifying to me, since I've been laboring in this fascinating discipline since 1963 and would thus seem to predate the pioneers featured in the article.

title: ANOTHER STAB AT PENSION REFORM
description: WASHINGTON THE 10th anniversary of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act arrives in September, and forces in Washington are already mobilizing to preserve and protect - or, in some cases, change and extend - the nation's basic pension law. In hearings and conferences, studies and legislative drafts, pension experts are keeping pension law a priority item in Congress' shortened election-year calendar.

title: Heatherten Set to Make Hollywood Park Debut
description: Heatherten, winner of all seven of her 1984 starts, will make her Hollywood Park debut Sunday in the $200,000 Vanity Handicap.

title: Pamela Jane Oresman Becomes Bride Of Keith N. Browning in Connecticut
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., Pamela Jane Oresman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Oresman of Darien, was married yesterday to Keith Nulton Browning, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Browning of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean performed the ceremony.

title: Colombia Holds 2 Reporters
description: Reporters for BBC and Time magazine have been arrested here on charges of possession of marijuana, the Colombian police have announced. The two, Nigel Parsons of the BBC and Thomas Quinn of Time, are being held until the source of the marijuana can be determined, the police said, adding that both men had denied the charges.

title: THE UNWELCOME MAT IS OUT FOR IDEOLOGICAL UNDESIRABLES

title: A BANK WITH THE AURA OF A CLUB
description: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation is not like other international banks. Its image has been streamlined in recent years as it jumped into the international arena, but it retains many of the qualities of a British colonial institution.

title: Dr. Jeffrey Rudell Weds Miss Greer
description: Judith Greer, the daughter of Mrs. Mortimer Greer of New York qnd Falls Church, Va., and the late Dr. Greer, was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Holmes Rudell, the son of Mrs. Richard Rudell and the late Mr. Rudell of New York. Lieut. Comdr. Fred A. Natkin, U.S.N. Chaplains Corps, performed the Jewish ceremony at the Naval Medical Command in Bethesda, Md.

Blumberg of Becker Paribas Inc., is so encouraged by the recent chart action that he said, ''Purely on a technical basis, aerospace ranks as my favorite group.''
