description: QUESTION: In football, can a player make a fair catch of a punt in the end zone or is he required to run the ball out?

title: 'GURU' OF LAW HELPS STUDENTS CONQUER THE BAR
description: John M. Pieper stood before 1,000 anxious law- school graduates the other day and reflected on the ordeal he had subjected them to.

title: EVEN WITHOUT SUSPENSE, IT'S LIKELY WORTH A LOOK
description: Whatever its political merits, Walter F. Mondale's decision to disclose his choice for a running mate last Thursday robbed the Democratic National Convention of its major element of suspense and television broadcasters of their major subject of speculation.

title: Princess Rooney Takes Coast Race
description: Princess Rooney put on a stretch drive, overhauled the favored Adored and won the $200,000 Vanity Handicap for fillies and mares by a head today at Hollywood Park.

title: Maine Marks Century of Moxie Soft Drink
description: Celebrations this weekend marked the 100th anniversary of Moxie, the nation's oldest soft drink, which once outsold Coca-Cola and was touted as a cure for almost anything.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page caption on July 6 incorrectly described a picture of soldiers on parade in La Paz, Bolivia. They were escorting Venezuelan officials to a statue of Simon Bolivar for a traditional celebration of Venezuela's independence day.

title: OUTDOORS: AS SUN SETS, A SEARCH FOR BLUES
description: GAY HEAD, Mass.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Finder, Not a Keeper

title: FLORIDA MAN NAMED IN GOLD FRAUD CASE IS STABBED TO DEATH
description: An owner of the defunct International Gold Bullion Exchange, accused of bilking investors nationwide of millions of dollars worth of undelivered gold bullion, was stabbed to death today, apparently in an argument over use of his car, police said.

title: Futures/Options; Link Set To Amex For Index
description: NEXT Monday the securities and futures markets will take a giant step toward the integration of their industries. On July 23, members of the Chicago Board of Trade, the largest futures exchange market, will have access to the options on the Major Market Index of the American Stock Exchange.

title: Television Coverage
description: The following daily television coverage is planned for the Democratic National Convention:

title: Where's Fun? Mantle Asks
description: Mickey Mantle believes ballplayers do not seem to enjoy themselves the way he did when he was the Yankee center fielder before retiring in 1969.

title: China Criticizes Vietnam For Border Attacks
description: China criticized Vietnam today, saying that the main reason for what it called Hanoi's ''wretched'' economic state was its occupation of Cambodia and its intensified provocations on the Chinese border.

title: Scott C. Liebman Married To Elaine Deborah Cohen
description: Elaine Deborah Cohen, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Philip Cohen of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Scott Cary Liebman, a son of Lieut. Col. Seymour Liebman, U.S.A.F. retired, of Northport, L.I., and the late Rhea Liebman.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FILM INDUSTRY THRIVES
description: The movie business is booming. Each summer for the last three years has set a new record. This summer also promises to be the best in Hollywood's history. From ancient movie palaces that have been carved in half to four- screen complexes in suburban shopping malls, theaters are thriving. The summer follows a spring that has been labeled ''magnificent'' by the executives who sell movies to theaters. By Dec. 31, movie theaters will probably, for the first time, have sold $4 billion worth of tickets in a single year. For the present, at least, Hollywood seems to have learned the magic formula for making movies people want to see.

title: Mr. Fitzgerald and the Phoenix
description: Ernest Fitzgerald is the Air Force cost analyst who was fired by President Nixon for revealing cost overruns on a military transport plane. Reinstated by court order in 1982, Mr. Fitzgerald is still worrying about the cost and quality of weapons the Pentagon buys, is still unpopular with his superiors and still worth hearing.

title: IRAQ DEAL REFLECTS POLITICS OF STEEL
description: The United States Government guaranteed $425 million of loans to help Iraq build an oil pipeline through Jordan only after Iraq revised the proposal to include large quantities of American steel pipe, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: NEW CONEY I. HOMES CALLED FLAWED
description: Rochelle Bromberger says the new house she bought in a federally subsidized development in Coney Island is ''held together with spit and glue.'' Raymond Bermudez, her neighbor, says the stairway to his house pops up if he grasps the bottom step and pulls.

title: INGREDIENTS FOR A GOOD PARTNERSHIP
description: A Business collaboration, psychologists have observed and

title: 1964, YEAR OF DEMARCATION FOR THE SOUTH
description: For my generation of Southerners, the civil rights movement cuts across the middle of our lives like a social and political canyon. On one side lie the ruins of the ancient, segregated civilization where we were born and grew up. On the other side stretch all the new assumptions, possibilities and surprises we will know until our time is up.

title: EXXON REFUND: RULING IS NEAR
description: WASHINGTON

title: ;  No Small Potatos Two weeks ago in St. Pie, Quebec, as he waited for the green light to signal the start of the final round in the grand national drag races, Gary Beck had good reason to feel confident. His opponent in the quarter-mile sprint, the other survivor of two elimination rounds, was Larry Minor, of Hemet, Calif. Even before he floored the accelerator on his 3,000-horsepower top fuel class dragster, Beck, the defending Winston world champion, was virtually assured of victory.
description: Minor owns the Lite All-Star Racing team that prepares the cars he and Beck drive on the National Hot Rod Association circuit. But Beck is the team's No. 1 driver, and when he and Minor face off, the team owner's car always seems to run at a little less than its full potential.

title: CRUISE CONTROL PERIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: AS CONVENTION OPENS, DELGATES SEE UPHILL CAMPAIGN; POLITICAL NEED LED TO CHOICE OF BERT LANCE
description: SAN FRANCISCO A combination of political needs and personal chemistry led Walter F. Mondale to name Bert Lance as general chairman of his Presidential campaign, according to Mondale campaign aides.

title: SHARON'S CAMPAIGN JOB: ROUSE THE ISRAELI RIGHT
description: ''Ladies and gentlemen,'' says the master of ceremonies, introducing his guest of honor, ''the hero of Israel.''

title: 3D PARIS BOMB IN 2 DAYS RIPS OFFICE
description: A banned group of extremists, Direct Action, claimed responsibility today for its third bomb attack here in 48 hours.

title: STRIKE BY 5,000 WORKERS SET AT 11 NURSING HOMES
description: A strike by 5,000 workers at 11 of New York City's private, nonprofit nursing homes was set for 6 A.M. today after efforts to avert a walkout failed early this morning.

title: IOWAN TRIES TO HOLD RACE TO 'SUBSTANTIVE ISSUES'
description: A campaign button says, ''Roger Jepsen - Porn Again.'' A bumper sticker promises, ''The Leisure Spa Sex Shop Is Not an Issue.''

title: THE REGION ; ;  FireKillsBabyGirl In Her New Home
description: A 6-month-old girl was killed early this morning in a fire that was apparently started by candles used to light a home where new residents had not yet got electricity connected, the police said.

title: Advertising; Mid-Size Agencies Prospering
description: IT was not long ago that the pundits

title: Required Reading;  Judicial Isolation
description: Judge Harry T. Edwards of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, writing in The Cleveland State Law Review on the effect of isolation on a judge:

title: Scholastic, Two Others Join Computer Project
description: Scholastic's Family Computing magazine has gotten itself involved in a pair of capers with magazines of other publishers. Both involve inserts and in both cases the ad sales staffs of both publications will be out peddling space.

title: The U.N. Today July 16, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: IN 'YOU' MAMA,' MAMA ISN'T IN THE PICTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Fugitive Is Charged In Another Killing
description: Alton Coleman, a fugitive sought on charges in five states, has now been charged with bludgeoning to death a former Sunday school teacher and beating her husband.

title: COSTELLO RETAINS TITLE ON DECISION
description: In what was probably the hottest event in this town since the British burned it in 1777, undefeated Bill (''Don't call me Billy'') Costello returned home and successfully defended his World Boxing Council junior-welterweight title with a unanimous 12-round decision over top-ranked Ronnie Shields.

title: Amritraj Takes Final
description: Vijay Amritraj, who was unseeded, beat top-seeded Tim Mayotte today, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4, and won the Miller Hall of Fame grass-court tennis tournament.

title: ;  Breland's Conqueror How do you beat Mark Breland, America's brightest Olympic boxing hope? Only Daryl Anthony knows for sure.
description: The only loss Breland has suffered in his 105 amateur fights came against Anthony in May 1981, on a split decision. ''It was a very close fight,'' Anthony, who is 25 years old, recalled last week from his home in St. Louis. ''In the last round, I dropped him with a right hand, which I think gave me the edge.''

title: Hydroplane Race Is Postponed
description: The $100,000 Stroh's Thunderfest unlimited-hydroplane race has been postponed until Monday because of treacherous high winds on the Detroit River, officials said today.

title: TOUR MOVES TO ALPS AS FIGNON EXCELS
description: Laurent Fignon showed today why he is a strong favorite to win the Tour de France for the second successive year, finishing first in an individual time trial just before the bicycle race enters its decisive phase of four days of mountain climbing.

title: ADJUST LANDING FEES TO DECONGEST OUR AIRPORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION ; ;  L.I. Firefighter Dies in Accident
description: A volunteer firefighter for the fire department here was killed today when he was crushed under the wheels of a fire truck that he and other firefighters were washing, the Suffolk County police said.

title: CAPTIVE NATIONS WEEK BEGINS WITH A PROTEST OF SOVIET RULE
description: The pews in St. Patrick's Cathedral were filled with people dressed in the colorful, native clothes of such lands as Turkestan, Hungary, Latvia and Bulgaria. Their heads bowed, they listened yesterday as the Rev. Peter Finn spoke of the search for freedom. Some fingered creased photographs of relatives who no longer resemble the pictures of their youth.

title: NEW DIVORCE LAW IN ENGLAND STIRS DEBATE
description: In a matter of weeks, a bill that imposes a ban on filing for divorce within the first year of marriage will become law in England and Wales. Opponents have condemned it as a ''quickie divorce bill.''

title: NBC DOING WALLENBERG'S FIGHT FOR JEWS
description: The story of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved as many as 100,000 Hungarian Jews from Nazi death camps and who later disappeared somewhere in the Soviet Union, has been told in print several times. Now, after years of postponements, it is to be filmed under the title ''Wallenberg'' for NBC-TV.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JULY 16, 1984

title: ENTIRE PARTY WATCHES JACKSON'S SHOW
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson stood in Chicago recently before an audience at Operation PUSH, his longtime power base, amid all the trappings of a returning hero.

title: 26 YEARS LATER, EPSTEIN RETURNS TO 'ENDGAME'
description: An irascible blind man sits on a battered throne in a bleak room. His servant shuffles about in pain, performing futile errands, but threatening to leave. The blind man's parents live close by in ash cans.

title: YUGOSLAV REPRESSION
description: Until recently, one could reasonably hope that post-Tito Yugoslavia was moving gradually toward democratization. The main evidence was an increasing latitude for discussion of political issues in the press.

title: Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. said it had agreed to sell $75 million of extendible notes through an underwriting syndicate co-managed by Salomon Brothers Inc. Bearing an annual interest rate of 13 percent through July 14, 1985, the notes are priced at par and will mature in 1991. Afco Credit Corp.'s commercial paper program, supported by a capital subscription agreement from its parent, the Continental Corp., was downgraded to A1, from A1x, by Standard & Poor's.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LA TRAVIATA,' WITH MARIANNA CHRISTOS
description: Verdi's ''Traviata'' returned to the repertory of the New York City Opera Saturday afternoon, in a substantially altered revival of the company's 1981 production.

title: IN TOWN: PERFECT MATCHES, OR NEARLY SO
description: It has always been usual for twins to dress alike. But sometimes young sisters or look-alike friends enjoy doing

title: Philippe Wynne, Soul Singer, Is Stricken at Club and Dies
description: Philippe Wynne, a singer who was a former member of the Spinners soul music group, collapsed in a performance at a nightclub Friday night and died early Saturday at a hospital.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Protecting Rep. Ferraro

title: LEADING THE YOUNG BACK TO BOOKS
description: Television is known to sell a lot of books. Let a novel be dramatized on the small screen, for instance, and its title is very likely to pop up on the best-seller lists. Yet many critics, most notably schoolteachers, insist that watching television is killing the habit of reading. In support, a new survey by the Book Industry Study Group is reporting that book reading among Americans under the age of 21 has dropped sharply since 1978, from 75 percent of that group to 63 percent.

title: HONG KONG'S BANKING GIANT
description: This British colony pursues commerce and wealth so single-mindedly that its magnificent natural setting has become a mere backdrop to its driving purpose. Tall buildings sprout everywhere, their walls often dense with advertising. Open stretches of sidewalk turn into crowded markets.

title: CUOMO PUTS FINAL TOUCHES ON KEYNOTE ADDRESS
description: A day before he serves as the first New Yorker in 68 years to keynote a Democratic National Convention, Governor Cuomo today promised a speech that, lawyer-like, would make ''a case for the Democrats, 1984.''

title: No Headline
description: Panel Urges Full Power For Diablo Atom Plant

title: BRIEFING;
description: Remember Marc Marks?

title: ESSAY ; HOW TO WATCH THE CONVENTION
description: Mr. Mondale's choice for Vice President has stated she does not believe the President can claim to be a good Christian, and Mr. Reagan has countered by hinting broadly that Mrs. Ferraro's choice was cynical tokenism. We have liftoff.

title: 'CUTTHROAT TIME' FOR GIANTS
description: The Giants' coaches marched through an empty campus today, passing the empty dormitory rooms and the plastic tent, where the Nautilus exercise machines sat quietly, into their offices for a final meeting before the first day of training camp.

title: ROYAL OPERA PRESENTS 3 WORKS IN LOS ANGELES
description: For most of the year, Los Angeles is bereft of big-time opera, the only major American city without a real company of its own. But for one glittering 13-day span, from last Monday through this Saturday, this has become the operatic capital of the country. The reason is the first visit ever to the United States by London's Royal Opera, Covent Garden. The company is playing only here, as part of the Olympic Arts Festival, presenting 11 performances of three productions. Taken together, the three evenings rank as about the most satisfying operatic triple- header in this writer's recent experience.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Birtcher Corp., El Monte, Calif., a manufacturer of electronic equipment, has elected to its board Howard Judah, former president and major stockholder of National American Corp. and National Consolidated Institute.

title: MINING MAY OFFER LIFT FOR UPPER VOLTA
description: When the left-wing officers who took power here last year vowed to end foreign exploitation of their country, many economists expressed sentiments similar to those voiced by a French businessman: ''This regime has talent - for satire.''

title: ENDORSEMENT SPURS DEBATE IN ATLANTA: RACISM OR FRIENDSHIP
description: They were both allies of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and they share many common memories from the 1960's, when they campaigned together across the South in behalf of civil rights.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: From the Caribbean, The Sounds of Africa

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section Thursday misstated the amount of money that parents may give to children without gift-tax consequences. Each parent may give each child or grandchild $10,000 a year in addition to making direct payments for educational and medical expenses.

title: ARTISTS KEPT FROM DONATING THEIR ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIALS CITE SAFETY CONCERNS AFTER TWO FATAL AMTRAK ACCIDENTS
description: Federal officials say the fatal train accidents this month in Vermont and South Carolina raise anew several longstanding questions about the safety practices of railroads that carry Amtrak passenger trains.

title: People
description: * James V. Vehko promoted to senior vice president at Ross Roy, Detroit.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Uranium Suit Won, UNC Chief Retires
description: After successfully guiding UNC Resources Inc. through nearly nine years of litigation over uranium pricing, Keith A. Cunningham, chairman and chief executive, has announced his retirement from the company.

title: Lori R. Offenberg Weds Joel B. Wiener, a Lawyer
description: Lori Robbin Offenberg, the daughter of Mrs. Gerald S. Offenberg of New York and the late Mr. Offenberg, was married yesterday to Joel Benjamin Wiener, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Wiener of Allentown, Pa., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi William Greenburg performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: YANKS' 5TH IN ROW SWEEPS ROYALS, 4-1
description: Maybe Jay Howell has found incentive for his effective pitching from Chaz C., a ''disgusted Yankee fan in New Jersey,'' but what about the rest of the Yankees' pitchers?

title: ;  Memory Lane Almost anything can happen in an old-timers game. Just ask Mel Allen. The Yankees' play-by-play announcer for 25 years before he was unexpectedly let go in 1964, Allen has collected 37 years of old-timers memories. He recalls sitting in the dugout with Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle before the 1979 old-timers game. Suddenly, Billy Martin, who had been replaced as Yankee manager the year before, was introduced to the crowd as the team's future manager.
description: Martin ran on the field to a thunderous ovation.

title: SAN FRANCISCO GALLERY; IN THE SPLENDID LOBBIES OF THE CONVENTION CITY
description: Like the heroine of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' a novice at the convention has to rely from time to time on the kindness of strangers. ''Work the hotel lobbies,'' was the advice I got from a veteran (now retired) of the convention circuit. Another said, ''Take a wine trip in the Napa Valley till the thing begins.'' But I opted for the lobbies.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL; A City for Romance
description: The Democrats packed into the

title: Moon's Church Pays Taxes to Keep 83 Boats
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church has paid more than $41,000 in taxes on 83 church-owned fishing boats but plans to seek a refund in court.

title: Bally's Casino Planning To Switch Its Agency
description: Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel in Atlantic City has been looking for an ad agency. It has talked to five of them and should be making a decision in a week or so, according to Alan Rosenzweig, director of advertising and public relations.

title: 2 Players Receive Warning
description: Two players, Kenny Daniel and Chris Godfrey, who are moving from the United States Football League to the Giants of the National Football League, have been sent letters reminding them that their contractual obligations to their U.S.F.L. teams have not ended.

title: MONDAY, JULY 16, 1984 International
description: Stronger controls on nuclear exports were decided on by Western countries that supply nuclear technology at a secret meeting in Luxembourg last week, Reagan Administration officials said. The suppliers reportedly agreed they had to do more to prevent the spread of the ability to build nuclear weapons. (Page A1, Column 1.) New Zealand's Prime Minister-elect said he wanted avoid an early confrontation with Australia and the United States over the issue of nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships. But David Lange, whose party swept to victory in the general elections Saturday, said he stood by his party's pledge to ban such vessels from New Zealand waters. (A1:2.)

title: NUCLEAR NATIONS AGREE TO TIGHTEN EXPORT CONTROLS
description: Western countries that supply nuclear technology met in Luxembourg last week and decided to strengthen controls on nuclear exports, according to Administration officials.

title: A RUNNER ENJOYS YEAR OF SURPRISES
description: Ruth Wysocki has a problem. Once you achieve your goal, what do you do for an encore? Her goal was to make the United States Olympic track and field team, and she did that last month by finishing second in the 800- meter final of the Olympic trials. She was so excited that she could not sleep that night. At 4:30 A.M., she routed her husband, Tom, a nationally ranked distance runner, out of bed, and they went for a walk.

title: HOW MONDALE CAN WIN
description: The Democrats come in to this convention on an up beat. Walter Mondale lifted the gloom by choosing Geraldine Ferraro as his running mate. What threatened to be a wake is shaping up instead as a celebration of possibility.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Friday about ARA Services misidentified the former executive seeking to acquire the company. He is William Siegel.

title: POP: SIOUXSIE AND BANSHEES
description: Siouxsie and the Banshees are one of the few bands left from the first wave of punk-rock in Britain. While the band's lineup has changed, and its staging and lighting have grown quite professional, its concerts last weekend at the Beacon Theater depended on punk-rock's visceral impact.

title: JAZZ: SHARPE ON SAXOPHONE
description: If Ornette Coleman had been

title: After a 15-Year Quest, Briton Buys Newspaper
description: Robert Maxwell has finally pushed his way onto Fleet Street. With his acquisition on Friday of the Mirror Group for $148 million, the 61-year-old publishing magnate ended his 15- year-long quest for control of a major British newspaper.

title: SABIN IS WINNER AT BELMONT
description: The roar began at the top of the stretch yesterday as the familiar scenario began again: Sabin, the gritty little filly, leading the pack and trying to hold on to the wire. It happened time and again in major races last year, but this was Sabin's first start of the year in front of her fans at Belmont Park. They didn't know that this time it would be easier, because Sabin is a different filly this year.

title: BRIEFING;
description: The NASA Rumor

title: THE PARTY'S ENDURING PROBLEMS: POWER, MONEY AND IDENTITY
description: This week the Democrats, in their quadrennial effort to define themselves, will be looking for a way to shake the image of being mired in the New Deal without turning off the kinds of voters brought to the party's colors by that age in American politics.

title: IDAHO STRUGGLES AGAINST ODDS TO HELP THE SALMON
description: The life of a Columbia River chinook salmon has never been easy, but of late it has been harder and it may become impossible.

title: MONDALE'S CHANGES AT THE LAST MINUTE
description: For weeks, Walter F. Mondale's overall campaign strategy has called for using the Democratic National Convention opening here Monday to focus the attention of the delegates on the need for party unity and that of the nation on the themes of the election campaign.

title: CALIFORNIA ARGOT: WE'RE NOT IN KANSAS ANYMORE
description: To a San Franciscan, this is not San Francisco. It is simply the City.

title: Soviet Reports Oil Slick On Volga Caused a Fire
description: Fireboats battled all night to contain a blaze on the surface of the Volga River caused by a huge oil slick from a broken pipeline, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

title: Marcos Visits Front To Supervise Battle
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos paid an unexpected visit today to a northern battlefront, where he reportedly directed soldiers fighting a mountain offensive against Communist rebels.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL; Instant Replay
description: Delegates were not to be denied their hard-won insider status, even in the face of gross ignorance of events.

title: Upturn at the World's Fair
description: The World's Fair here earned $1.5 million in the first week of July, its first substantially profitable week since it opened May 12, Petr Spurney, president of the exposition, said Friday. That week included Fourth of July attendance of more than 90,000, he said. Attendance for the past several weeks has exceeded 45,000 a day, up from an average 41,000 the first month.

title: BILLS AND PACIFIC GAS BONDS HEAD LIST
description: With no new intermediate or long- term issues scheduled to be sold until next month, today's weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills highlights the Government securities calendar this week.

title: BRIEFING;
description: -rayed and X-rated

title: Chow Chow Wins
description: A chow chow, Ch. Koby Cassanova of Sweetkins, owned by Mrs. Alan Robson, Michael Wolf and Desmond Murphy, today was named by Dr. Robert Turton as best of 1,246 dogs at the Twin Brooks Kennel Club show at Caldwell College.

title: MANATT WILL STAY AS PARTY'S LEADER AS MONDALE YIELDS
description: Faced with rising protests from the Democratic convention delegates who he expects will nominate him for the Presidency, Walter F. Mondale reversed himself today and decided to keep Charles T. Manatt as party chairman.

title: Czechs Beat France HRADEC KRALOVE, Czechoslovakia, July 15 (UPI) - Ivan Lendl defeated Guy Forget, 11-9, 6-4, 6-2, today to give Czechoslovakia an unbeatable 3-1 lead over France and a place in the Davis Cup semifinals against Sweden.
description: In the last singles, Czechoslovakia's No. 2 player, Tomas Smid, was beaten by Henri Leconte, 6-3, 6-3, for the final 3-2 result.

title: THOUSANDS OF UNIONISTS PARADE FOR DEMOCRATS
description: More than 100,000 people marched through midtown San Francisco today in what union leaders called a vast demonstration of labor's strength and unity on the eve of the Democratic National Convention.

title: Astros Top Phillies, 3-2, in 16
description: Alan Ashby's one-out single in the 16th inning drove home Jose Cruz from second base to give the Houston Astros a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL; Oratory as of Old
description: Down on the convention floor, soon to be home to such exotically titled workers as ''lead roving whips,'' there are word-processing computers stationed like electronic bank tellers at each state delegation. This year, chairmen will use glyphs and cursor to register vox pop. Party officials emphasize, however, that the voting ritual will still allow the redundancy of loud- mouthed proclamations from the floor about how the vote count goes in the ''Great State of Euphoria, Home of the Best Intentions,'' or some such place and claim.

title: SIOUX AGONIZE OVER TAKING MONEY OR REGAINING BLACK HILLS
description: Four years after the United States Supreme Court upheld nearly $106 million in compensation to the Indians for the Black Hills of South Dakota, the Sioux here have still not received the money, and many say they do not want it.

title: DIFFERENT MCENROE EMERGING
description: The ball was out. Or so said the linesman who watched as John McEnroe's lightning serve landed in a blur near the yellow line on the court.

title: Insure the Banks, and Rate Them
description: The domestic banking crisis is over. Quick, effective intervention by Federal regulators helped Continental Illinois retain the deposits it needed to keep its doors open. With luck, a merger partner for the big Chicago bank may yet be found, allowing it to avoid liquidation. But more was at stake here than the fate of one bank that made bad loans to Texas wildcatters.

title: AL SCHACHT, BASEBALL'S COMIC
description: Al Schacht, who entertained millions of fans as the Clown Prince of Baseball, died Saturday in Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness.

title: Article 067198 -- No Title
description: The South will not rise again, but the building that served as its unofficial White House should.

title: Lois Kleinerman Married To Stephen M. Bernstein
description: Lois B. Kleinerman, an assistant vice president of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, and Stephen M. Bernstein, a lawyer, were married yesterday at Windows on the World by Rabbi Jonathan Ginsberg.

title: VOLUNTEERS FILL A GAP AT HOMES
description: For the last two nights, Arlene Dym has been sleeping on two chairs she pulled together beside her mother's bed in the Rutland Nursing Home in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. She plans to stay there until a strike of nonmedical hospital and nursing home employees ends.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He has to show he is a person with a dynamic program.

title: Syrian Soldiers Move Into Lebanese Villages
description: Syrian Army troops moved into several Christian villages in northern Lebanon today to enforce a cease-fire between two pro-Syrian militias fighting for dominance of the region's farmlands, the state television said.

title: COPY OR PERISH
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLLIS STACY WINS OPEN BY 1
description: Hollis Stacy came from five shots off the pace in the last 14 holes today to win the United States Women's Open for the third time. She won by a single shot over Rosie Jones.

title: CITY CLUB PRESIDENT PLANS A YEAR AS GADFLY
description: Sally Goodgold, a West Side activist who took over this month as the first woman to be president of the City Club of New York, describes her favorite method of operation as ''bagel diplomacy.''

title: Cubs' Rainey Traded to A's
description: Chuck Rainey, who led the Chicago Cubs' pitching staff with 14 victories last year, was traded to the Oakland A's today to make room for the reactivation of Dick Ruthven.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Manitoba Gives Jersey 10 Eagles
description: New Jersey has received 10 bald eagles from Manitoba, Canada, as part of the state's 1984 eagle program.

title: German Pact On Credit Near
description: West Germany has completed

title: HIPPOS DIE IN ZOO MISHAP
description: Three hippopotamuses were found dead at the Karlsruhe Zoo early today. Authorities said an elephant did it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE QUALITY OF MERCY: CAMBODIA, HOLOCAUST AND MODERN

title: Barry H. Miller Wed To Karen H. Winter
description: Karen H. Winter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Winter of New York and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Barry H. Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Miller of Palm Beach, Fla., and Hickory, N.C. Rabbi Irving Koslowe performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: Air Florida Sued on Pay
description: Sixty laid- off Air Florida pilots have agreed to pay cuts while some former employees filed suit seeking back pay and benefits they assert were withheld when the troubled carrier halted operations.

title: THEATER: 'STORK BOOGIE,' BY MELVIN VAN PEEBLES
description: A melange of tall tales, puppetry, vaudeville and pop- soul music, ''Waltz of the Stork Boogie,'' presented by the New Federal Theater, suggests a funky Muppet show run amok in cosmic pretensions.

title: Italian Output Expands
description: Italy's industrial production rose 5.5 percent in the 12 months ended May 31, the Government reported.

title: TO LURE LAW STUDENTS TO PUBLIC-INTEREST JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: ERNEST R. TIDYMAN, SCREEN WRITER, DIES AT 56
description: Ernest R. Tidyman, author and screenwriter whose screenplay for the movie ''The French Connection'' won him an Academy Award, died Saturday in Westminster Hospital in London of a perforated ulcer and complications. He was 56 years old and lived in New Preston, Conn.

title: Vassar College Is Recipient Of a $750,000 Computer Gift
description: Vassar College has received a gift of $750,000 in computer equipment from the Digital Equipment Corporation, college officials have announced.

title: THE DEMOCRATS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Constituencies: Not surprisingly on the morning of the day the Democratic convention opens, many of the larger constituent groups that claim party influence will be publicly flexing their political muscles in a series of separate news conferences and meetings all over San Francisco. Democrats being ostentatiously inclusive, the list is long. It begins with the Women's Caucus (11 A.M. Eastern daylight time, 8 A.M. Pacific time) and moves on, in part, to the Democratic National Committee Black Caucus (11:30 A.M.) and several others.

title: Rachel Burack, I.R.S. Lawyer, Marries
description: Rachel Susan Burack, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Burack of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Mason Kowal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kowal of New York. Rabbi Jack Sable performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue in New York.

title: THE IMAGE AS MESSAGE, THE MASSAGE AS IMAGE
description: Look, everybody. There is President Reagan with some happy family picnickers in Alabama. There he is again with some assembly-line workers at an automobile factory in Michigan. And look, there he is again in Kentucky, wearing a Smokey the Bear hat and proclaiming his love of the outdoors.

title: British Prices Rise
description: British consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June from May and were 5.1 percent higher than June 1983 levels, according to the Department of Employment. In a separate report, the Central Statistics Office said industrial production fell 1.3 percent in May from April, and was off five- tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 16, 1984: MONDAY Bally MfgJohnson & JohnsonDana CorpL & N HousingEastern UtilitiesLilly (Eli)Goodrich (BF)Southern Co TUESDAY Cincinnati MilacronLehman CorpGreat Western FinanlScott PaperHoneywell Inc.Security PacificInterfirst CorpSouthern Ind G&EInterpublic GroupStauffer ChemicalJostensV F CorpK Mart Corp

title: 21 SALVADOR POLICE DIE IN TRAIN ATTACK
description: Salvadoran military sources said today that 21 Treasury policemen were killed on Saturday when leftist guerrillas attacked a cargo train 25 miles north of the capital.

title: Gerald Sykes, 80, Dies; Was Author and Critic
description: Gerald Sykes, an author, philosopher and critic whose positive reviews helped focus attention on writers such as Lawrence Durrell and Franz Kafka, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital from kidney failure. He was 80 years old and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: A 'BORN DEMOCRAT' MAKES THE PLANS: ROSALIND WEINER WYMAN
description: ''I was born a Democrat,'' Rosalind Wyman likes to say, and to prove that she enrolled in her party at an early age, she may show you a photograph of herself as an infant with a 1932 Roosevelt campaign poster. On Monday Mrs. Wyman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Democratic National Convention planning committee, will help open a four-day party that she has been planning for her party for more than a year.

title: ;  Spoils of the Cup It has been nearly a year since the America's Cup was lost to the Australians. The large silver urn is gone from its pedestal at the New York Yacht Club and has been moved to simpler quarters at the Royal Perth Yacht Club in Western Australia.
description: But left behind are numerous unsolved problems, not the least of which is how to deal with trademark rights to the cup.

title: Cup Plot Thickens
description: NEWPORT, R.I.

title: Spill Shuts Houston Port
description: The Port of Houston's ship channel was closed Saturday night to allow crews to clean up a fuel oil spill from a Venezuelan tanker, the Coast Guard said. A spokesman said the ship, the Turpial, ran aground and ruptured Saturday night. There was no danger of explosion from the 600 gallons to 700 gallons of oil that leaked so far, he said.

title: Sweden 3-1 Winner
description: Henrik Sundstrom defeated Francisco Gonzalez of Paraguay, 6-3, 6-1, 6-2, today and clinched a Davis Cup semifinal berth for Sweden.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: EAST SIDE The Lower East Side is a part of Manhattan that many New Yorkers look back on mainly as a place of roots, but it is an area that is very much alive in its own present, as is attested to by the exhibition at the second-floor City Gallery of the Department of Cultural Affairs in the white building at 2 Columbus Circle.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL; In the Hall With Fame
description: If the standards for apocrypha are

title: MUSIC IN THE AIR IS FREE AND DRAWS THOUSANDS
description: Thousands of music lovers thronged to New York City's free outdoor concerts over the weekend, putting up with such distractions as noisy children, eccentric strangers and barking dogs to enjoy the notes that wafted through the fresh air.

title: MINEBEA'S BALL BEARING BID
description: Two weeks ago, the chief executive of New Hampshire Ball Bearings Inc. unexpectedly received in the mail an offer to buy the company outright for $110 million from the Minebea Company of Tokyo, Japan's largest manufacturer of ball bearings.

title: What's Properly Public About TV
description: No, ''60 Minutes'' isn't about to be replaced by reruns of ''The Gong Show.'' Nor are viewers likely to face a rash of more ads for frozen chicken patties and antacids. The Federal Communications Commission has rescinded the guidelines it posted a decade ago for commercial television programming and advertising, but the change won't greatly alter what the public sees.

title: ARTS FESTIVAL ON A SHOESTRING THRIVES IN CENTRAL PENNSYLVANIA
description: Banners are flying, traffic clogs College Avenue and crowds sprawl across an elm-lined campus mall and on through the borough's business district.

title: 20TH ANNIVERSAY PARTY FOR THE O'NEILL CENTER
description: Back at the start, nearly 20 years ago, a bus arrived near here and disgorged some young men named Lanford Wilson, Sam Shepard, John Guare and Israel Horovitz. As playwrights, they were virtually unknown, and so was the brand-new retreat to which they had come, the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center.

title: SENIORS TITLE TO DE VICENZO
description: Roberto De Vicenzo, who signs a weekly newspaper column for Clarin in Buenos Aires, had something to write home about today. In the light breeze of a flawless summer afternoon by the sea, the 61-year-old Argentine won the Merrill Lynch/Golf Digest Commemorative by two strokes. He scored 70, 2 under par for the Newport Country Club, for a 54-hole total of 206, which is 10 under par.

title: NEW ZEALANDER WANTS TO AVOID FIGHT WITH U.S.
description: Prime Minister-elect David Lange said today that he wanted to avoid an early confrontation with the United States but that he stood by his party's pledge to ban nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships from New Zealand waters.

title: No Headline
description: Bryna Starobin Weds

title: BATHERS CELEBRATE NUDE DAY
description: Beachgoers basked naked yesterday in Rhode Island to mark National Nude Day but sun worshipers in south Florida tangled with the police, who ordered a cover-up.

title: A PASSION IN TRUFFLES FOR TEXAS
description: ''It used to be said,'' Francois Picard observed with a Gallic flair for metaphor, ''that the truffle was the daughter of earth and thunder. In the old days they noticed that after a thunderstorm, the truffle bore fruit.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Texas Rangers , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Dickie Noles, acquired from the Cubs several weeks ago, will start for the Rangers. Joe Cowley, purchased last week from Columbus, where he was 10-3, gets his first start for the Yankees. (Television - Sports Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.).

title: Coke Is Upheld On Pepsi Spoof
description: You may not be watching

title: A RECORD WIN FOR VIRGINIANS IN THE GRAND NATIONAL FINAL
description: The biggest victory ever recorded on such an occasion resulted from the final of the Grand National Team Championship here Saturday night. There was no doubt about the result, but some doubt about how to describe the winning team, which has now qualified to represent the United States in the 1986 world championships.

title: 2 Jewel Officers Resign; President Is Promoted
description: Jewel Companies Inc., the Chicago supermarket and drugstore company that is being acquired for $1.16 billion by the American Stores Company of Salt Lake City, has announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive. W. R. Christopherson, 58, and of its vice chairman, Lawrence Howe, 62.

title: Galgey Head Denies Fraud
description: The head of T. Galgey & Company, a London securities firm, has denied that his firm has been involved in fraudulent Eurobond trading.

title: HIRING HOMOSEXUALS: AN ISSUE IN NEED OF PROPER DEFINITIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Convention Rostrum Highlights
description: Here is the tentative schedule for the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco. (All times are Eastern daylight time; Pacific time is three hours earlier.)

title: AT REVIVED ASTORIA STUDIOS, THE BIRTH OF A MUSEUM
description: To most observers, the four-story building that takes up a square block at 35th Avenue and 36th Street in the Astoria section of Queens is an abandoned gray structure whose walls are covered with graffiti and topped with barbed wire.

title: NORMAN POWERS HIS WAY INTO GOLF'S ELITE
description: When Greg Norman survived an atrocious approach shot into the bleachers and rolled in a curling 40-foot par putt from the left fringe of the 18th hole at Winged Foot June 17, the 29-year-old Australian did more than force a playoff with Fuzzy Zoeller for the United States Open championship. He also got the attention of golf fans everywhere.

title: A BRAZILIAN CHALLENGER SEEKS TO UNIT THE DISAFFECTED
description: Amid the optimism of the tumultuous street campaign here earlier this year calling for direct presidential elections, many opposition politicians were confident they could defeat any Government-backed candidate at the polls and become Brazil's first civilian head of state in two decades.

title: DROUGHT SPREADS TO KENYA, STIRRING FEAR OF A FOOD CRISIS
description: The clouds at dawn are gray and heavy and people say, without conviction, ''Perhaps it will rain.''

title: FED PANEL TO MEET ON GOALS
description: On the eve of an important policymaking meeting of the Federal Reserve, many of the analysts here and on Wall Street who monitor the Fed expect no more than a fractional increase in interest rates, at least through the summer, and some doubt that the Fed will even go that far.

title: KOCH DEBATES EDITOR ON RACIAL TENSIONS
description: Mayor Koch and the editor of The Amsterdam News clashed repeatedly during a radio debate last night on the extent of racial tension in New York City and whether the Mayor's statements and policies had worsened matters.

title: THE DEMOCRATS IN SAN FRANCISCO ; TV AND THE CONVENTIONS: A CHANGING MARRIAGE
description: From the top level of the glass blockhouses the television networks have erected in the convention hall here, 5,000 delegate seats spread away in a parquet pattern of little gray metal chairs.

title: BRAVES END METS' STREAK, 8-3
description: The Mets' march through Georgia ended on a losing note today. Their eight-game winning streak ended as they were defeated by the Braves, 8-3.

title: PARTY GATHERS IN A CHANGING, SOPHISTICATED CITY ALL ITS OWN
description: This sophisticated city is greeting the Democratic National Convention with breathless enthusiasm, confidence and the barely concealed self- doubts of a beautiful teen-ager just before the senior prom.

title: DANCE: QUEBRADANZA, AN ECUADOREAN TEAM
description: Quebradanza, a modern- dance organization founded in 1982 in Quito, Ecuador, brought a program of solos and duets by Susana Reyes to La Mama on Friday night. The choreography was only of intermittent interest, but it did serve to display two pleasant young dancers, Miss Reyes and Juan del Hierro.

title: ANGRY PROSECUTOR RAISES G.O.P. HOPES IN HAWAII
description: After four years of major shifts in Hawaiian politics, Mayor Eileen Anderson, a Democrat, has announced her candidacy for re- election.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Man Shot to Death In Washington Sq.
description: A Brooklyn man was shot to death and a second man was wounded late Saturday night in crowded Washington Square Park, the police said yesterday.

title: DARTMOUTH GROUP IN PRIVACY BATTLE CONCORD, N.H., July 15 (AP) - A student reporter's taping of a Gay Students Association meeting and the publication of excerpts in an unofficial Dartmouth College newspaper have stirred a dispute over privacy rights and freedom of the press.
description: The reporter, Teresa Polenz, a freshman on The Dartmouth Review, is the subject of a criminal investigation by the State Attorney General's office and faces possible school disciplinary action.

title: AS CONVENTION OPENS, DELEGATES SEE UPHILL CAMPAIGN ; FEW IN POLL EXPRESSING CONFIDENCE
description: SAN FRANCISCO On the eve of the Democratic National Convention, party delegates concede that their national ticket faces an uphill fight against President Reagan in November.

title: JOBS OPEN ON JETS AS DRILLING BEGINS
description: Jobs are available on the Jets, Coach Joe Walton reminded the first group of training-camp players before their intitial workout today. He then worked them to exhaustion. Monday will be worse.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL; As Time Warps By
description: Delegates touched down in jumbo jets, stiff-legged with transcontinental cramp and perhaps somewhat anxious over the big- screen television news footage on the planes that depicted the time-warp spectacle of police officers wielding clubs against some early street demonstrators last Thursday.

title: U.S. MARK BROKEN IN HAMMER THROW
description: Bill Green shattered his American record in the hammer throw in an international pre-Olympic track and field meet tonight.

title: LAST ONE OUT, TURN OFF THE LIGHTS
description: This city is populated with political warhorses who begin to chap at the bit when political convention time rolls around. So for those Washingtonians who are linked in even a peripheral way with Democratic politics but find themselves in Washington this week instead of in that city by the bay, there is a definite sense of being on the B Team.

title: U.S.F.L. TITLE IN 23-3 ROUT
description: It was no contest. The Philadephia Stars routed the Arizona Wranglers tonight, 23-3, and won the United States Football League championship.

title: DELBELLO MOVES UPTOWN
description: Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello, whose

title: Massachusetts Secretary Wins $15.6 Million
description: A secretary claimed $15.6 million in the Massachusetts Megabuckets Lottery today, cashing in the second ticket she had ever bought to become what lottery officials said the biggest single jackpot winner in the world.

title: ALLOWING BOND OWNERS TO REMAIN ANONYMOUS
description: The Treasury Department, exploring new ways to reduce the cost of financing the nation's huge debt, is considering reviving bearer bonds to elicit greater demand from foreign investors who have a penchant for anonymity.

title: Prisoner Is Killed in Fight
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., July 15 (UPI) One convict was killed and five were injured in a fight between Hispanic and black gang members at San Quentin Prison, the prison authorities said today.

title: MOBIL TITLE TO FLORIDA SITE UPHELD
description: A Florida appeals court has affirmed the Mobil Oil Corporation's title to 15,000 acres of land in central Florida that have been part of a complicated series of lawsuits involving Mobil, the state of Florida and the Coastal Petroleum Company.

title: Robert J. Meyer, 49, Member Of Assembly in Jersey, Dies
description: Assemblyman Robert J. Meyer, a Republican who had represented Burlington County since 1981, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Memorial Hospital of Burlington County in Mount Holly Saturday. He was 49 years old and lived in Medford.

title: Curfew Called in Punjab To Prevent Sikh March
description: Authorities have imposed an eight-hour curfew on this city to prevent a march scheduled for Monday by Sikhs to the Golden Temple, scene of a fierce battle last month between Indian Army troops and Sikh militants, the Punjab radio said today.

title: CRITICS SAY U.S. PROGRAM ENTANGLES GOVERNMENT AND RELIGION
description: Federal officials have become concerned over whether Federal money has been used to support the teaching of religious doctrine under a new Government program designed to discourage adolescent sexual activity.

title: A GUIDE TO SOME FACES AT THE ROSTRUM
description: Dorothy V. Bush

title: MONDALE AND HIS PARTY
description: Seldom has a single event - the choice of Geraldine Ferraro to be Walter Mondale's running mate - so transformed, as from night to day, the mood and the morale of a national political convention.

title: Nicholson Buys Rights To Book on Napoleon
description: Jack Nicholson has paid $250,000 for the film rights to a controversial book whose premise is that Napoleon died by poisoning.

title: Philippine Bishops Ask Concession of Marcos
description: In a pastoral letter made public today, Philippine bishops called on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to give up his legislative powers, which it said were ''open to gross abuse.''

title: Triton, Sundance
description: The Triton Energy Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that a unit of the Quebec government had asked it to explore the possibility of cooperating with it in acquiring additional shares of the Sundance Oil Company. Triton said that talks between it and the Societe Quebecoise d'Initiatives Petrolieres had so far been ''preliminary in nature'' and that the two companies should not be construed as acting in a group to acquire Sundance shares.

title: MISS STACY'S EAGLE 2 'JUST KEPT ROLLING
description: PEABODY, Mass.

title: EXUBERANT WELCOME GIVEN MONDALE AND REP. FERRARO
description: Thousands of Democrats exuberantly welcomed Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro to San Francisco today.

title: MASLAND, C.H. & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GRACE, W.R. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
30 Seattle Picketers See Bias in 'Indiana Jones'
description: Thirty people demonstrated peacefully against the box-office smash ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' at a theater here last Thursday because, they said, it depicts the people of India as either helpless or evil.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSOC. (FNMA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: FERNANDO SANCHEZ'S parrot

title: BOND PRICES OFF MODERATELY
description: Bond prices slipped in light trading in the credit markets yesterday, amid profit taking and Government reports showing that the economy continues to expand at a rapid clip.

title: Bulky Soviet 'Pouch' Is Waylaid by Swiss
description: A wrangle over the biggest ''diplomatic pouch'' ever seen here continued today with Switzerland demanding that Moscow supply a list of its contents.

title: 125 SIKH WOMEN ARE SEIZED IN MARCH ON GOLDEN TEMPLE
description: A group of 125 elderly Sikh women were arrested tonight as they tried to march to the Golden Temple to demand an end to the Indian Army occupation of the shrine. No violence was reported.

title: GRAINGER, W.W. INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COURT BACKS JUDGE WHO FOUND SLAYER HAD BEEN PROVOKED
description: A judge criticized for saying that a man who killed his wife had been ''provoked'' by the victim was only trying to explain the sentence and should not be reprimanded, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Ford's Europe Sales Up
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its car sales in Europe were at a five-year high in the first half of 1984 as it sold 733,500 cars, up from 727,300 in the first six months of 1983. Ford said its 1984 first-half share of the European market was estimated at 13 percent, up from 12.8 percent a year ago and the best showing since it achieved a 13.2 percent share in the first half of 1978.

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OFFSHORE DRILLING: BLANKET MORATORIUMS WON'T SERVE US WELL
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Budweiser Captures Race
description: Miss Budweiser, driven by Jim Kropfeld, scored an easy victory today in the $100,000 Stroh's Thunderfest unlimited-hydroplane race on the rough waters of the Detroit River.

title: BUSHWICK, A SHAMBLES IN '77, SHOWING SIGNS OF RECOVERY
description: Seven years ago, an Ecuadorean priest with pinched cheeks and somber demeanor looked out over the depleted congregation at Sunday mass at St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church in the north Brooklyn community of Bushwick and contemplated what seemed to be a neighborhood's death rattle.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Great Northern Nekoosa Gains
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said today that investment tax credits combined with record shipments and higher prices for pulp and paper products helped raise profits 61.8 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier. The company said it earned $35.1 million, or $1.35 a share, up from $21.7 million, or 83 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1983.

title: UNIONS UPHELD AT SPY CENTER IN BRITAIN
description: A judge today nullified a ban imposed by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on trade unions at a top-secret intelligence listening post at Cheltenham.

title: TWO-WAY SIXTH AVENUE
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE PLAN FOR THE FALL
description: Governor Cuomo set the tone and tactics for the Democratic campaign by telling the nation tonight to ''look past the glitter, beyond the showmanship'' of Ronald Reagan's Presidency and see that a regal insensitivity had divided American society ''into the lucky and the left out.''

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CPC Income Up 4.2%
description: CPC International Inc. said today that net income for the second quarter rose 4.2 percent, to $50 million, or $1.03 a share, from $48 million, or 99 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN BANK (NYC)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRANSCRIPT OF KEYNOTE ADDRESS BY CUOMO TO THE CONVENTION
description: Following is the transcript of the keynote address by Governor Cuomo of New York to the Democratic National Convention last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: The U.N. Today July 17, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 4 Bombs Explode in Spain
description: Bombs exploded at Government offices here and in two other Spanish cities today, but authorities said there were no casualties. A total of four bombs exploded in Barcelona, in nearby Tarragona and in the southern town of Torrente. The Catalan separatist group Terra Lliure took responsibility for two blasts in Torrente and the police said they suspected the group in the other explosions.

title: ENGLISH OPERA PICKS ADMINISTRATOR
description: Peter Jonas, the artistic administrator of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will replace Lord Harewood as managing director of the English National Opera next year, the opera company announced yesterday in London.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: GREEK TO US The Greek National Theater brings ''Oedipus Rex'' to New York today, from Greece by way of Los Angeles and other cities between us and the West Coast, where the theater presented the Sophocles tragedy as its country's representation of the performing arts in this Olympic year.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stocks Rebound; Dow Rises by 6.96
description: The stock market, after drifting below its Friday closing point, rallied late yesterday to finish higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.96 points, to 1,116.83, from Friday's close at 1,109.87.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OUTDOOR MARKET ENDURES IN CHICAGO DESPITE MANY PRESSURES FOR CHANGE
description: At the open- air market on Maxwell Street and its environs you can find almost anything, including kitchen sinks.

title: IN NORTHPORT, A MEETING ON MURDER
description: Residents of this waterfront community met in a church here tonight to bind wounds opened by the murder of a teen-ager in what authorities said was a satanic ritual that involved illegal drugs.

title: Talking Business with Lawson of Frederick Atkins Inc. ; Store Brands In Retailing
description: For decades, national brand names dominated retailing. But in recent years, as major brands have come under severe pricing competition, stores of all kinds have begun selling more goods under their own labels.

title: JAZZ CONCERT:OLIVER LAKE IN SAND SOLOS
description: AS it has for the last five summers, the landfill where Chambers Street approaches the Hudson River has become an avant-garde sandbox. Playful, participatory sculptures, among them a giant megaphone and a bulldozer-cum-funhouse mirror, loom in the seashell-studded sand, and performances sponsored by Creative Time will take place on the site Sundays and Wednesdays through September. Those events are conceived as collaborations between artists, architects and performers.

title: NEW PUBLICATION IS SAID TO CONTAIN ALL DOCUMENTS OF AGLILEO TRIAL
description: The Pontifical Academy of Sciences has taken one of the last official steps the Roman Catholic Church can take to repair the wrong that it committed 351 years ago to one of the fathers of modern scientific thought, Galileo Galilei.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bankers Trust Co., has elected Eugene B. Shanks executive vice president of technology.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS PROFIT OFF 28.8%
description: The American Express Company, continuing to suffer from sharp declines in its securities and insurance businesses, yesterday reported a 28.8 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. Net income was $138.7 million, or 64 cents a share, down from $194.9 million, or 96 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.

title: Gearhart Deal
description: Gearhart Industries said it had completed the acquisition of Geosource Inc. from the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.

title: South African Police Use Tear Gas in Melee
description: --The police fired tear gas at black protesters in the second day of demonstrations against rent and tax increases in a black township 50 miles south of Johannesburg.

title: Hispanic Delegates Told To Threaten a Boycott
description: Hispanic delegates to the Democratic convention were urged today to withhold their votes from all Presidential candidates on the first ballot unless party leaders agreed to seek the defeat of the immigration legislation now before Congress.

title: U.S. NAVY WON'T GO TO NEW ZEALAND
description: The United States, seeking to avoid a crisis within the Pacific alliance, will probably not send Navy warships to New Zealand waters until mid-1985 at the earliest, senior American officials said Monday.

title: Bridge: Contest for Life Master Pairs
description: Two New York experts, enmeshed in a small ambiguity, led into the semifinal stage of the Life Master Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Idled Farm Land Rises
description: A preliminary report today by the Agriculture Department showed farmers idled a record 75.6 million acres last year under Federal crop programs, including one that gave growers $9.7 billion worth of free surplus commodities in return for cutting back.

title: Chess: Queens Tourney
description: After three rounds of the 1984 United States Championship, Maxim Dlugy, an international master from Queens, held the lead with 2 1/2- 1/2. Dlugy, an 18-year-old Russian emigre, is the youngest player in the 18-man field.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago results were not available.

title: PADRES DOWN CUBS WITH A 4-HITTER, 4-0
description: Bobby Brown hit a two-run homer to back the combined four-hit pitching of Mark Thurmond and Rich Gossage and lead the San Diego Padres to a 4-0 triumph over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: TV IS POLISHING ANN-MARGARET'S IMAGE
description: Movie actors often turn to television when their careers are faltering, but rarely do they make the transition as successfully as Ann-Margret has.

title: CARTER'S ALLIES SAVORING LANCE'S RETURN TO POWER
description: For Walter F. Mondale and his senior aides, the past few days have been trying and turbulent. But for one group of political veterans they have been as sweet as a Vidalia onion.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sports and Salads

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Under Park Ave., An Infestation of Fleas

title: APPLIED DATA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Newhouse May Retire
description: It was only last week that the wide receiver Drew Pearson announced that a liver injury related to an auto accident might mean the end of his pro football career. Now another veteran player, after 12 years with the Dallas Cowboys, is on the verge of leaving the team.

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,000,000 for the quarter and $29,000,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax benefits of $39,000,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting method. Share earnings reflect 1984 preferred dividend requirements reduced by $5,000,000 as a result of the company's repurchase program, and are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split which was declared in the latest quarter.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SLENDER SKIRT BACK IN STRIDE
description: Fashion is taking one of its unexpected turns: In the heat of summer, city streets are full of long tubular skirts and dresses or jumpers, worn at midcalf or lower. The skirts, one young wearer said, ''are hard to walk in and hot, but they are something I've never experienced before.''

title: Daughter of Sakharov Asks Jackson to Help
description: In a meeting here today with the stepdaughter of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, the Rev. Jesse Jackson was urged to pursue his attempt to visit the Soviet Union to help secure medical treatment for Mr. Sakharov's wife.

title: Help Wanted
description: Football coaches usually don't have that much faith in the press, especially if they're having a losing season.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF CARTER'S ADDRESS ON SECURITY, DIPLOMACY AND HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Following is a transcript of the address by former President Jimmy Carter at the Democratic National Convention last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: RISING VOICE IN DEMOCRATIC RANKS
description: At this time two years ago, Mario M. Cuomo, tonight's keynote speaker at the Democratic National Convention, had been written off as a loser by almost everybody who knew anything, or thought they did, about New York politics. He was campaigning for the post of Governor of New York in a Democratic primary against the well-known Mayor of New York City, Edward I. Koch.

title: PROPOSED DRUG FUND A TRADE-OFF FOR 2 SIDES
description: In 1971, during her sixth pregnancy, Rita Noe took Bendectin, a prescription anti-nausea drug - and her daughter, Michelle, was born with a webbed left hand. Last weekend, on Michelle's 12th birthday, Merrell Dow Pharmaceutical Inc., the Cincinnati-based manufacturer of Bendectin, agreed to put $120 million into a settlement fund to pay damages to the Noes and more than 700 other families who have filed lawsuits arising out of birth defects they say were caused by Bendectin.

title: THE QUINTESSENTIAL 'MONDALE MAN'
description: There is a photograph on Michael Berman's wall that shows Walter F. Mondale in shirtsleeves, working on a speech and smoking a cigar. The former Vice President's arm is in the air, and Mr. Berman is sewing on a cuff button.

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $800,000 on the sale of real estate. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 30, 1984.

title: TEXT OF 5 DISPUTED PLATFORM PLANKS
description: Five sections of the Democratic Party platform approved by the platform committee and supported by delegates favoring Walter F. Mondale have been disputed, four by supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and one by supporters of Senator Gary Hart. Minority reports that would substitute language in the published platform or add to it have been proposed, and may be presented to the convention on Tuesday. Following are texts of the portions of the published platform that would be changed and of the minority reports:

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-earlier share earnings were restated to reflect 3-for-1 stock split paid June 1.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISE A RECORD
description: Consumers, credited with propelling the economy's lively expansion, took on more than $10 billion in installment loans in May, the Federal Reserve said today. It was far and away the largest monthly increase on record.

title: REPORTER'S PROJECT RUINS HIS CAREER
description: An investigation by a news organization often ends with the subject of the inquiry under a cloud and the reporter accepting praise. Carlton Sherwood's inquiry into alleged financial irregularities in the construction of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington has ended the other way around.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CAPACITY USE ROSE 0.2% IN JUNE
description: The Government reported today that the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated in June at the highest level since July 1981.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FILM AT THE CONVENTION PAYS TRIBUTE TO TRUMAN
description: He was an ''accidental President,'' a plain man who laid the foundation for decades of peace between the super powers and then beat the longest of odds to win election in 1948.

title: HONG KONG STEW: AND NOW A DASH OF DEMOCRACY
description: Hong Kong has never been permitted an elected government by Britain, and until recently its residents left the running of the colony to British paternalism while they earned money.

BRIEFING
description: Statistics for Sale

description: To the Editor:
