description: b-Includes a tax credit of $156,000.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Television Coverage
description: The following daily television coverage is planned for the Democratic Convention in the New York area:

title: S.A.S. Plane Deal
description: The state-owned Scandinavian Airlines System said it had taken an option to buy six MD-80 aircraft from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in a package valued at $146.3 million. S.A.S. said it expects to make a decision on purchasing the aircraft within two months. They would be delivered between September and December 1985. An S.A.S. spokesman said the six aircraft, expanded versions of McDonnell Douglas's DC-9, were chosen after the airline shopped unsuccessfully for secondhand aircraft for its European routes.

title: TECHNOLOGY: THE JAPANESE CHALLENGE - Ninth article of a series to appear periodically; JAPAN'S COMPUTER WEAKNESS
description: Since the beginning of the personal computer business about seven years ago, Japanese companies have been expected to invade the rich American market and take a big share of it, as they had with automobiles and televisions.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect 4-for-1 stock split that was effective April 18.

title: AMERICAN NATURAL REOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JUROR IN DRUG TRIAL REPORTS MAN ASKED HER ABOUT CASE
description: The foreman of a jury in a Federal heroin-smuggling trial testified yesterday that a stranger had approached her about the case outside her home that morning.

title: Ovett Back on Track
description: Steve Ovett of Britain, whose preparations for the Olympics have been hampered by a mysterious skin rash, intends to run in a 1,500-meter race in Edinburgh today. Ovett pulled out of last Friday's major international meet in London in order to consult a doctor and then withdrew from another, in Birmingham, England, on Sunday. Although he is nowhere near 100 percent fit, he desperately needs competition before he leaves for Los Angeles.

title: Required Reading On Television
description: Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., Republican of upstate New York, in his weekly report to constituents, July 9:

title: STANDARD SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The net includes equity in earnings of the Pittway Corp. of $3,990,000 in 1984 and $2,935,000 in 1983.

title: MORTY GUNTY
description: Morty Gunty, the Brooklyn-born nightclub comic who played himself in the recent Woody Allen film, ''Broadway Danny Rose,'' died of cancer yesterday in the Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 55 years old and lived in New City.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prime Rate Up In South Africa
description: Major South African banks announced today that they were raising their prime lending rates to a record high of 22 percent from 21 percent. The increase in the prime, the interest charged to the banks' best customers, reflects the Government's need to prop up the South African rand, which has been hard hit by the recent slump in the price of gold to its current level of $350 an ounce, economists say.

title: Military Contract
description: The United Technologies Corporation received a $260 million Air Force contract, the Defense Department said. It said the contract, given to the Government Products division of the company's Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group, is for production of engines for the Air Force and for sales to the Netherlands, Pakistan, Venezuela, Egypt and South Korea.

title: NO FAST END SEEN
description: The union that struck 27 private hospitals and 3 affiliated nursing homes in New York City last Friday struck 11 of the city's largest private nonprofit nursing homes yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pitching In

title: PERSONAL-INJURY LAW ISN'T A TICKET TO RICHES
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE GO ON TRIAL IN EXTORTION CASE
description: Seven former Philadelphia policemen charged with extorting more than $350,000 ''were selling their badge'' to protect illegal gambling, a Government prosecutor said today in his opening statement at their trial.

title: West Bank Settlement Is Released to Civilians
description: The Israeli Army today turned over a paramilitary settlement in the occupied West Bank to civilians.

title: Andropov's Son, Igor, Is Now Envoy to Greece
description: The Government said today that the Soviet Union had appointed Igor Y. Andropov, son of Yuri V. Andropov, as its new Ambassador to Greece.

title: INMATES NEED JOBS
description: Less than 20 percent of the national prison population works. Most inmates just sit around, becoming bored, restless and, sometimes, violent. The best way to reduce idleness and prevent violence, while cutting costs and helping prisoners rehabilitate themselves, is to give inmates a job.

title: RESHUFFLING THE COLLEGE FOOTBALL LINEUP
description: ''It's a stampede,'' said Terry Reed, publicity director for Katz Sports, the cable-television

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: In part of its financing program, Citicorp announced yesterday that this week it would offer $250 million worth of notes due in 1989.

title: Bass Brothers
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. and Perry R. Bass Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had sold their holdings in Mattel Inc.'s $2.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock, series A. The group said it sold 143,600 of the preferred shares on the New York Stock Exchange between June 25 and July 10. The two companies said they also eliminated a short position they had held in the common stock of the toy maker.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Dining Out Guide in Weekend last Friday gave an incorrect address for the Shanghai Wok in Ocean Township, N.J. It is at Route 35 and Deal Road in the Middlebrook Shopping Center, (201) 493-8118.

title: 2 PLANES NEAR MISS ABOVE GEORGIA LAID TO CONTROLLERS' ERROR
description: An error by air traffic controllers today brought an Eastern Airlines 727 jetliner and an Air Force C-135 within a quarter of a mile from each other, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Thriftimart
description: Pilara Associates, an investment concern based in Walnut Creek, Calif., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is soliciting proxies from up to 10 individuals with a view toward electing one member to the board of Thriftimart Inc. at the company's annual meeting on Thursday. Pilara said investment clients and investment accounts it handles hold a total of 61,600 Thriftimart class A shares, or 9.3 percent of the total outstanding. On the American Stock Exchange today, Thriftimart fell $2.125, to $74.

title: Jury Being Picked In Beatty Trial
description: Jury selection began in Brooklyn yesterday in the Federal District Court trial of former State Senator Vander L. Beatty on charges of funneling more than $200,000 of state money into private real-estate deals.

title: RECRUITING ABROAD
description: WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in Kuala Lumpur last week on a state visit, Malaysian officials greeted him with what must have seemed a strangely familiar question: How can they get their children into Ivy League schools?

title: TV'S OWN CONVENTION
description: The hegemony of television over the political convention has been firmly established. Its forces (14,500) outnumber delegates and alternates 3 to 1 and outspend them at a considerably higher ratio. It is as though the media had assembled for a convention of their own, with politicians invited to perform.

title: UNLIKELY ALLIES EMERGE OVER PERSIAN GULF WAR
description: The fortunes of the Persian Gulf war have clearly placed the United States and the Soviet Union in a de facto alliance in support of Iraq, according to diplomats here.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POLAND ACQUITS 2 POLICEMAN IN DEATH
description: In a case that has become a rallying point for supporters of the outlawed Solidarity union, a court here acquitted two policemen today in the beating death in May 1983 of Grzegorz Przemyk, the 19- year-old son of a well-known dissident.

title: BUSINESS SOFTWARE DESIGNED FOR THE BOSS
description: LAST week's column explored some of the features of the management control software package OZ. Whatever a program's possibilities and promises, however, its real test lies in utilization. So I loaded the financial information from a small airplane leasing company, Condor Aviation Inc., into the computer to see what the software could do with real data.

title: DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: c-Inludes a tax credit of $161,000.

title: Motorola Net Surges 92.2%
description: Motorola Inc. reported today that its earnings in the second quarter surged 92.2 percent, to $98 million, or 83 cents a share, from $51 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: SMITH, A.O. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
APPLE'S SALES PUSH IN JAPAN
description: When readers here opened their newspapers July 4, they were greeted by an advertisement spread over two full pages - an unusual sight in a nation where the daily newspapers typically have only 16 pages. Even more unusual was what the ad showed: Buddhist priests, the conveyors of wisdom, walking around with apples in their hands.

title: Please Be Seated
description: It took Jim Purol, a 32-year-old comedian-musician from Redford, Mich., 96 hours 12 minutes to sit briefly, very briefly, in each of the 101,701 seats in Michigan Stadium last month. But he did it and raised $3,500 in pledges for the American Lung Association.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1.4 million. c-After a gain from divested and discontinued operations of $8.3 million.

title: STAGE:O'NEILL 'INTERLUDE,' IN LONDON
description: It's no surprise to find that London's West End is glutted with American plays and musicals this summer. English audiences are every bit as fond of Broadway hits as New Yorkers are enamored of Tom Stoppard and Andrew Lloyd Webber. The only trouble is that Broadway no longer produces enough new theatrical products to satisfy London's demand. These days, West End managements must augment their slender roster of new imports (''42d Street,'' Al Pacino's ''American Buffalo'') with homegrown revivals of such past Broadway properties as ''West Side Story,'' ''Little Me'' and ''Morning's at Seven.''

title: RUSSIAN EX-U.N. EMPLOYEE SAYS SOVIET VIOLATES CHARTER
description: A former Soviet employee here who defected rather than return to Moscow says the Soviet Mission is violating the United Nations Charter by requiring Soviet citizens who work for the Secretariat to follow the mission's orders.

title: JACKSON PREPARING FOR LESS THAN VICTORY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has indicated a strong wish to continue to play a major role in Democratic Party politics even as he prepares his delegates for the likelihood of leaving here without clear-cut victories.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company was a unit of Time Inc. until December.

title: Police Chief Threatens Town Officials With Jail
description: Police Chief Thomas Womack Jr. today threatened to arrest the town's entire board of aldermen to quell resentment he says was brought on by his hiring of a white officer in this predominately black community. Chief Womack, who heads a three-member force, is black, as are all the aldermen.

title: MCI SLIPS
description: Two of the regional telephone companies created from the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company - Nynex and Ameritech - reported yesterday that profits rose in the second quarter over the first.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENDLESS ENEMIES. The Making of an Unfriendly World. By Jonathan Kwitny. 435 pages. Illustrated with endpaper maps. Congdon & Weed. $19.95.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $4,400,000, or 11 cents a share, on sales of marketable securities. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the change of fiscal year-end of certain foreign units.

title: UNITED STATES BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sharp's Net Rises 27%
description: The Sharp Corporation said today that strong sales and foreign exchange gains helped increase profits 27 percent in the year ended March 31, to 38.07 billion yen, or $158 million, from 29.9 billion yen a year earlier. The maker of electric appliances and business equipment said revenues rose 13.3 percent, to 1.02 trillion yen, or $4.24 billion, from 898 billion yen.

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9,335,000 for the quarter and $8,561,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $688,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the 6 months. The income from discontinued operations in the latest periods included gains on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: THE INVISIBLE SPORT IS A VIRTUAL LOTTERY
description: It was a balmy summer evening last

title: FUSINA A KEY TO STARS' TITLE
description: Kelvin Bryant, Chuck Fusina, Sam Mills.

title: New Deadline Set On Shell Oil Stock
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which is offering $58 a share for the 30 percent of the Shell Oil Company it does not own, said the deadline to take back stock would be extended to 5 P.M. July 30 under an order of the Delaware Chancery Court extending such rights for 10 days.

title: Market Place; A Volatile Software Stock
description: THE computer software industry is highly

title: CORRECTION
description: An article June 27 about HBO documentaries misidentified the producer of the PBS series ''An American Family'' 10 years ago. He was Craig Gilbert. Alan and Susan Raymond had the title of film makers.

title: Search for a Fugitive Turns to Kentucky
description: Federal agents, encouraged by the discovery of an abandoned automobile, streamed to the Lexington area today to search for a fugitive sought in a five- state crime spree of murder, rape, abduction and beating.

title: INDUSTRY TAKES DOMINANT SCIENCE ROLE
description: American industrial research, once thought to be wilting in the face of economic recession and Japan's technological challenge, appears to be surging ahead with unexpected vitality.

title: MONDALE MEETS WITH HIS RIVALS IN A UNITY BID
description: Walter F. Mondale and his two remaining rivals for the Democratic nomination made a last attempt tonight to compromise their differences on the party platform and insure a smooth second day of the national convention Tuesday.

title: Homestead Notes Backed by Bond
description: Homestead Savings, a savings and loan association that is the principal subsidiary of the Homestead Financial Corporation of Burlingame, Calif., said yesterday that it would issue up to $90 million of medium- term notes supported by a surety bond.

title: Metro-North To Permit Bikes
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad announced today that it would allow bicyclists who bought $5 permits to take their bikes on board its trains at specified times.

title: YOUTH MISTAKEN FOR TERRORIST ON L.I. HAS CASE DISMISSED
description: A Nassau County judge today dismissed charges against a teen-ager who, with three friends, stumbled upon a stakeout by Federal agents at a Soviet diplomatic residence on Long Island last April.

title: WITH CUOMO AWAY, HIS LIEUTENANT STAYS HOME JUST IN CASE
description: With Governor Cuomo delivering the keynote address to the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco, Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello presided over New York State today as acting Governor. He made little use of his temporary powers.

title: INVENTORIES AND SALES UP IN MAY
description: American businesses raised inventories by nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, while sales surged 1.6 percent, the biggest sales increase since December, the Government reported today.

title: Rangers Sign Osborne
description: Mark Osborne , who had 19 points in the last 20 games last season, was signed to a new contract by the Rangers, who refused to disclose details. The Rangers also announced the signing of Grant Ledyard, a 22-year-old defenseman who, while playing for the Ranger farm at Tulsa last season, was the Central Hockey League's most valuable player. . . . Steve Tsujiura, a 22-year-old free-agent center formerly with the Philadelphia Flyers' organization, was signed to a multiyear contract by the Devils, who will assign him to their top affiliate, the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League.

title: Nuclear Plant Sets Operating Record
description: The Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant in East Haddam set a world record today with its 401st day of uninterrupted generation of electricity, according to its owner, Northeast Utilities.

title: Injured Forbes Goes Home
description: The publisher and sportsman Malcolm S. Forbes, injured Thursday in a motorcycle accident in Glacier National Park, left Montana in a private jet today on his way to his home in New Jersey. An ambulance attendant said Mr. Forbes, publisher of Forbes Magazine, was walking but in obvious pain. He suffered a mild concussion, broken ribs and a collapsed right lung after his motorcycle hit loose gravel and overturned.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOUISVILLE CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DOCTOR'S LOBBY FACING UNSOLICITED 2D OPINIONS
description: The American Medical Association, long one of Washington's most powerful political lobbies, is accustomed to getting its way when medical issues come before Congress. But the days of such dominance may be ending.

title: No Headline
description: The Democratic Track New York's Governor Cuomo has summoned his party to unite the nation, ''the family of America,'' and not a minute too soon. In the last couple of days, Walter Mondale and Geraldine Ferraro had been threatening to fumble away their time of triumph in endless distractions.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Comparable results do not exist because the company began operations as a new entity on Jan. 1, 1984.

title: Kaiser Steel Signs Pact to Sell Plant
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that it had signed a final agreement to sell its idled Fontana Works for ''in excess of $100 million'' to a joint venture involving a southern California business and Brazilian and Japanese companies.

title: From Grocery Clerk To McKesson President
description: Thomas W. Field Jr., who worked his way from grocery store clerk to president of American Stores Company, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the McKesson Corporation.

title: ALLIES CURB COMPUTERS FOR SOVIET
description: The United States, 13 NATO allies and Japan have jointly agreed to impose broad, new export controls on the sale of small computers and sophisticated telephone equipment to nations of the Soviet bloc, Western diplomats said today. The agreement comes after two and a half years of difficult negotiations.

title: Stock Letter Must Register
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the publisher of Stock Market Magazine acted illegally when it failed to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission as an investment adviser. Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. of the Federal District Court here issued an injunction last Thursday ordering the Wall Street Publishing Institute Inc., the publisher, to cease doing business as an investment advisory publication unless it registers with the S.E.C. The ruling was made public today.

title: Gen. Karl Wolff of SS; Gave Up Fight in Italy
description: Karl Wolff, the Nazi SS general who surrendered German troops in Italy in 1945, died today. He was 84 years old.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because Ameritech became a publicly held company independent of American Telephone & Telegraph on Jan. 1, 1984.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $37,000 for the quarter and $141,000 for the 6 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $32,000. d-After extraordinary credits of $338,000.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chem-Tronics Bid
description: Interlake Inc. said it had agreed in principle to buy all the common shares outstanding of Chem- Tronics Inc. for $23.50 a share.

title: Limited Drops Carter Tactic
description: The Limited Inc. said it had dropped efforts to elect two directors to the board of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. but said it would continue efforts to take over the California-based retail giant. The Limited said its action was prompted by a California court decision last week that paved the way for Carter Hawley to reincorporate in the state of Delaware, making The Limited's takeover attempt more difficult.

title: A Further Bankruptcy Mess
description: There seems no end to the irresponsible blows against America's bankruptcy courts. First Congress botched a necessary reform of the court. Now the Federal court paymaster, who works for Chief Justice Burger, is refusing to pay 227 bankruptcy judges, saying their jobs disappeared while Congress was writing new legislation.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
John Reeves White, 60, Dies; Hunter Musicology Teacher
description: John Reeves White, a professor of musicology at Hunter College, died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan last Thursday. He was 60 years old.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-earlier results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Homeowners Warehouse Inc. in August 1983.

title: Mayor of Washington Seeks Democrats in '88
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington renewed his campaign today to attract the Democratic National Convention to the nation's capital with a ''D.C. for '88'' rally from the steps of a cable car.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1984

title: Tax Bill for McLain Troubles continue to follow
description: Denny McLain, the man who won 31 games for the Detroit Tigers in 1968. Already awaiting trial on Federal racketeering charges in Tampa, Fla., McLain learned yesterday that, in an unrelated case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, had found him liable for about $20,000 in back taxes. The case stems from second-quarter unpaid taxes from 1976 owed by the Memphis Blues, a baseball team that McLain served as general manager and that folded after the 1976 season.

title: A NATURAL DISASTER HAS ITS BRIGHTER SIDE
description: FEW natural events have had worse press than last year's devastating El Nino, the periodic shift in oceanic currents and temperatures off the coast of Peru. Blamed for widespread floods and droughts and the collapse of the anchovy, sardine and other fisheries vital to Peru's economy, it has been portrayed as an unmitigated natural disaster.

title: Shutdown At Midland Is Ordered
description: The Consumers Power Company said today that it would shut down its $4 billion Midland nuclear power plant, after failing to reach agreement on rates with its biggest industrial customers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; New Hewlett Post Aimed at Marketing
description: Dean O. Morton has been elected chief operating officer of the Hewlett- Packard Company, the computer and electronics concern based in Palo Alto, Calif. The company said yesterday that Mr. Morton's appointment to the post - which is a newly established one - is part of a management reorganization aimed at improving marketing operations.

title: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ISSUES IN THE STRIKE BY HOSPITAL UNION
description: The bargaining agent for the hospitals is the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes, and for the homes, the Association of Voluntary Nursing Homes.

title: ARMY SAYS DATA ON THE WESTWAY AREN'T DECISIVE
description: The official who will decide whether to grant a permit for the Westway project said yesterday that after conducting two days of public hearings and reviewing more than 600 written comments, he had not found ''a preponderance of weight one way or the other.''

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Texas Rangers , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Phil Niekro, a Cy Young Award contender at age 45, tries for victory No. 13.

title: Colombian Wins 17th Leg of Tour
description: Luis Herrera of Colombia won the 17th leg today of the Tour de France cycling race, crossing the finish line of the grueling 94-mile leg alone. Laurent Fignon of France displaced a countryman, Vincent Barteau, as the overall leader.

title: DST SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FROM SOUTH OF THE RIO GRANDE: LOOKING FOR BETTER PAY
description: It was 6:30 A.M., and at the edge of the Rio Grande the morning shift of illegal aliens was stripping off clothes and getting ready to wade to work.

title: LILCO FINDS FEW ALLIES AS IT SEEKS HELP IN ITS FIGHT TO FEND OFF BANKRUPTCY
description: When the Long Island Lighting Company finished its Northport 3 generating station in 1975, one company official recalled recently, the project was over budget by 10 percent. Three executives responsible for building the plant were dismissed. It had cost about $100 million. With a projected cost of $4.1 billion, the Shoreham nuclear plant is more than 1,000 percent over budget.

title: Farrakhan Again Describes Hitler as a 'Very Great Man'
description: Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, has repeated for a national television audience his description of Adolf Hitler as ''a very great man.''

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
7 Are Sentenced In B-52 Vandalism
description: Seven antinuclear activists, including the wife of Philip Berrigan, the former priest and Vietnam War protester, were sentenced today to two to three years in prison for hammering and splashing blood on an Air Force bomber.

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TODAY'S CALENDAR
description: Today's Calendar

title: GRACE GAINS
description: The Allied Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter climbed 22.6 percent. bolstered by improved demand in most of its product lines,

title: BOLIVIAN PLOT EMBARRASSES THE U.S.
description: When a group of armed men abducted Bolivia's President before dawn on June 30, the crisis proved to hold an unexpected embarrassment for the United States.

title: COMMON-SENSE APPROACH URGED FOR HIP FRACTURES IN THE ELDERLY
description: CONTRARY to the contentions of medical textbooks, surgical repair of hip fractures is not necessary to save the lives of elderly nursing home patients, according to a small study by two New Jersey physicians.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Here I go again.'' - Jimmy Carter, in a speech to the Democratic convention. (A1:4.)

title: People
description: * Richard L. Sardelli named president of Fredric-Richards Advertising.

title: CONVENTION BEGINS
description: After a weekend of political turmoil, the Democratic National Convention opened here today with a ringing denunciation of Ronald Reagan as a President whose ''shining city'' was closed to most citizens.

title: YANKEES SURVIVE A WILD 9TH
description: When Pete O'Brien lashed the second two-run double of the inning, fans began leaving Yankee Stadium in droves. Many of the fans who stayed, Dave Winfield noted later, ''were out there with their arms spread out and their mouths open, saying, 'What's wrong with you guys?' I think a lot of people thought it was over. We did, too.''

title: BID TO HALT FIRES FORCES CUT OF 60 SUBWAY RUNS
description: A lack of working subway cars forced the cancellation of a total of 60 rush-hour trains yesterday morning and evening, and transit officials predicted similar shortages over the next few days.

title: Top Management Shifts At Madison Resources
description: Top management changes at Madison Resources Inc. were announced yesterday in what were described as the final steps in the transition of the company from a mutual fund to an oil and gas investment concern.

title: D'Arcy and Doremus Executive Changes Set
description: Major executive changes were announced yesterday by D'Arcy MacManus Masius, St. Louis, and Doremus & Company, New York.

title: Comings and Goings Press reports from Britain said that the American golfers
description: Calvin Peete and Jerry Pate had withdrawn from this week's British Open, but there was no indication of a reason. . . . The drag-racing star Shirley Muldowney, severely hurt in an accident June 29, has undergone the first of a series of skin grafts to her left leg. . . . Kazbek Tambi of the Cosmos has replaced one of his teammates, Dan Canter, on the Olympic soccer team. Canter tore ligaments in his left ankle in the victory over Tulsa on Saturday night.

title: HONI COLES: RECALLING 50 YEARS OF TAP
description: Seventy-three-year old Charles (Honi) Coles, a major attraction in the musical, ''My One and Only,'' and the only tap-dancer to win Tony and Drama Desk Awards in the history of the Broadway theater, is not impressed by break dancing.

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CLOUDY DAYS FOR REATAILERS
description: The fashion business doesn't stop when the sun shines. In fact, it generally gets better. Clothing retailers see blue skies and balmy days as catalysts for consumer buying fantasies.

description: 10/ Bump on the Meter

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Tennessee Lawyer May Get Early Prison Release
description: Mary Evans, the disbarred lawyer who was sentenced to three years in prison for helping her client escape, may be released after 130 days because of Federal court orders to reduce the state's prison population.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Almy Stores Inc., a Boston-based department store chain, said its shareholders had approved the company's merger with a subsidiary of Federal Stream Investors Inc., owner of 52 percent of Almy stock.

title: Advertising; Trivial Pursuit Campaign
description: DESPITE its inability to meet consumer demand for its runaway-fad board game Trivial Pursuit, Selchow & Righter, the United States marketer, will be spending more than $1 million between August and Christmas for advertising.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results for the latest periods include the operations of SBT Corp. which was acquired in May 1984. Year-ago results were restated to include the operations of SBT Corp. on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Six Suspects Arrested In Abduction ofBoy
description: Six suspects were seized in Queens yesterday and charged with kidnapping an 18-year-old Elmhurst resident at gunpoint, and with illegal possession of a variety of firearms, the police said.

title: HOMES RAIDED IN NASA COMPUTER BREAK-IN
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized computers and equipment today at four homes where they said they believed computer enthusiasts had penetrated two computer systems at the Marshall Space Flight Center.

title: ISRAELIS SAY ASSAD MAY GROOM BROTHER FOR HIS JOB
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria appears to be cautiously grooming his brother Rifaat as his successor, despite strong opposition from other members of the Syrian political leadership, in the view of authoritative Israeli sources familiar with the situation in Syria.

title: F-14 ENGINE MAY BE CHANGED
description: More than 400 of the Navy's F-14 fighter aircraft may have their Pratt & Whitney engines replaced by newer General Electric power plants, according to an official of the Naval Air Systems Command.

title: Mt. Neboh Owner Averts Foreclosure
description: The owner of the former Mount Neboh Synagogue on West 79th Street averted a foreclosure auction of the one-time landmark property yesterday after refinancing a $500,000 loan.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Thick Skin at the Beaumont

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: FERNANDEZ WINS DEBUT AS METS ROMP ON 22 HITS
description: Sid Fernandez finally made his debut with the Mets tonight, and got a rousing welcome from his teammates: They hammered out 22 hits, their highest total in nearly three years, and buried the Houston Astros, 13-3.

title: MURALS DECK FREEWAYS APPROACHING OLYMPICS
description: When the director of the Los Angeles Olympic Arts Festival, Robert Fitzpatrick, visited Olympia, Greece, in 1981 in preparation for the festival now under way in Los Angeles, he noticed that the path to the stadium was lined with pedestals on which statues of athletes had once stood.

title: Suspect in Killings FacesNewCounts
description: Michael Ross, accused in the slayings of six young women, was charged today with four additional counts of capital felony because, authorities said, he sexually assaulted three of his victims and killed two of them together.

title: ALONG RIO GRANDE, THE LAW RUNS INTO REALITY: NO BARRIER
description: In Matamoros, people say workers will cross the border for better pay in the United States new law or no new law. Page B5.

title: FRICTION INCREASING IN KARAJAN DISPUTE
description: When Berliners discuss the stormy tale of Herbert von Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic, they instinctively reach for the metaphor of a marriage on the rocks. And, like once-sympathetic onlookers who have wearied of a couple's tempestuous marital spats, they are now waiting to learn the terms of the seemingly inevitable divorce.

title: Rise in Wheat Sales to China
description: China is stepping up purchases of American wheat in an effort to meet the terms of a long-term grain agreement with the United States, Senator Bob Dole said today.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: Net income for the latest quarter and 6 months was increased by 5 cents a share as a result of the retirement of certain debentures. Net income for the year-ago 6 months was reduced by 14 cents a share due to expenses associated with a merger with Dillon Cos. Inc. Net income for the same period was reduced an additional 7 cents a share due to estimated costs of an early retirement program.

title: LAB CHIMPS PREPARED FOR DIFFICULT 'RETIREMENT' IN THE WILD
description: ROBERTSVILLE, Liberia STANDING on the bow of the outboard motor boat rocking in the brown water of the Little Bassa river, Betsy Brotman cupped her hands around her mouth and bellowed toward the jungle island. ''Char-lie! Char-lie!''

title: Korey, Kay Gets Humana Inc. Account
description: Humana Inc., a large health-care corporation based in Louisville, Ky., has come to New York for an agency to help introduce a new program, Humana Care Plus, which is an employee hospitalization plan that is expected to be less expensive for companies to maintain than most programs because it will utilize the more than 90 hospitals owned by Humana.

title: PHOTOS SPEAK VOLUMES ABOUT RELATIONSHIPS
description: AMONG the many pictures in the family album was a prescient family portrait: Mother was off to one side holding the dog, father was hugging their son and daughter, and all were grinning happily. Shortly after this picture of seeming familial contentment was taken, the couple divorced, the father took custody of the children and the mother kept the dog.

title: CONTINENTAL TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to include companies subsequently acquired on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Priest Says He Canceled Speech by Rep. Ferraro By The Associated Press
description: The Rev. Henry Lang, a Roman Catholic parish priest in Queens, said yesterday that he canceled a speaking invitation to Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro two months ago because she is ''pro-abortion.''

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment tax credits of $9,000,000, or 36 cents a share. c-Includes investment tax credits of $16,500,000, or 67 cents a share.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table on Sunday showing the backgrounds of delegates to the Democratic National Convention misstated the survey period. It was June 14 to July 9.

title: EX-SUPPLIER OF MOSCOW'S EPICURES REPORTED EXECUTED FOR CORRUPTION
description: The former director of Moscow's most elegant food store, whose connections were said to have included Leonid I. Brezhnev, has been executed for corruption, a Soviet newspaper has reported.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSING, NEVER LIVED IN, BEING RAZED
description: The Naugatuck Heights Apartments, a cluster of 13 buildings that were to have been homes for 135 families, are being demolished, after more than a decade of litigation and controversy.

title: HOST COMMITTEE IS LED BY 'NATURAL' ORGANIZER
description: Outside of California, Nancy Pelosi is probably the least known of the key women at the Democratic National Convention. She is the chairman of the Convention '84 Host Committee, a civic rather than a political organization whose main function is to promote San Francisco.

title: Debt Rating
description: Detroit said the rating of the $40 million of bonds sold for finance capital improvements in its water and sewer department had been rated AAA by S.& P. The issue has an 11 percent interest rate.

title: Yet Another Clemente After rejecting his older brother,
description: Roberto Clemente Jr., who then signed with a rookie team of the Philadelphia Phillies not long ago, the Pittsburgh Pirates offered a tryout last weekend to Luis Clemente, another son of the late Pirate star Roberto Clemente. But afterward the Pirates made no commitments to the 18-year-old Luis.

title: Westinghouse Is Closing Plant
description: About 160 workers will lose their jobs when the Westinghouse Electric Corporation closes one plant in western Pennsylvania, and 600 workers at a nearby plant will be laid off for six months, the company said. Operations at a distribution transformer plant in Greenville will be phased out permanently over the next eight months, and production at Westinghouse's medium-power transformer plant in Sharon will be suspended for six months, officials said.

title: Italians Hope to Find Modigliani Sculptures
description: City workers will dredge Livorno's Royal Canal in an effort to recover valuable Modigliani sculptures that the artist dumped there in disgust in the early 1900's, officials said Monday.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income of $77,224 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after income of $36,966 from discontinued operations.

title: inner-CITY CLASSROOM WITH A LESSON TO TEACH
description: ''THE neighborhood isn't threatening, just desolate. And the kids are so nice.'' The neighborhood was 57 East 129th Street. The kids were local 8-year-olds going to school at The Children's Storefront. The commentator was our son John early in the recent school year when he was a high school senior.

title: Notes Are Priced By First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation yesterday priced $125 million of subordinated floating rate notes due July 24, 1996.

title: MIXING LUCK AND SCIENCE
description: NORTHRIDGE, Calif.

title: RESOLUTION NEAR, SAYS CONTINENTAL
description: A resolution of the Continental Illinois Corporation's financial plight is imminent, David Taylor, its chairman and chief executive officer, said in a letter to employees yesterday. From its text, banking analysts inferred that the company's operating unit, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, would remain independent rather than be merged into a stronger bank and that its huge portfolio of problem loans would be spun off into a separately chartered bank.

title: PPG Industries Gains by 36.7%
description: - PPG Industries said today that its second-quarter profits rose 36.7 percent, to $86.1 million, or $1.23 a share, from $63 million, or 90 cents a share, a year earlier. Heavy demand in the autombile industry for new-car primers and finishes was cited as the reason. The coatings and resins manufacturer said revenues advanced 18.1 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $931.2 million. L. Stanton Williams, PPG's chairman, said that while sales of new-car primers and finishes paced the profit gains, sales of industrial coatings also improved.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
SCOUTING ; For $495 a Week, Triathlon Camp
description: This week, 17 men an eight women, ranging in age from 21 to 48 and paying $495 each for seven days of intensive training, are going to a very special camp.

title: 'LITTLE PEOPLE' LOOKS AT THE LIVES OF DWARFS
description: ''LITTLE PEOPLE'' is about dwarfs, and it is one of the better documentaries you will see this season. It is intelligent and tough-minded, and because it is it becomes moving as well. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. tomorrow.

title: HEILEMAN, G. BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Foreign Study
description: Within the last two weeks, a touring team of college stars from last spring's National Invitation Tournament played the national basketball teams of Yugoslavia, France and Italy, squads that will be competing in the Los Angeles Olympics.

title: U.S.F.L. WARNED BY AGENT
description: The business agent for Chris Godfrey, one of two men who could be prevented from playing for the Giants right away if the United States Football League successfully pursues its current stance, says that if the young league ''does not cooperate'' with him, he and other agents will not cooperate with the league should it decide to switch from a spring to a fall schedule.

title: Authors of 'Heartland' Win Neil Simon Award
description: Beth Ferris and William Kittredge yesterday received the second annual Neil Simon Award for their television script for ''Heartland.''

title: Examining Problem Of Zapping TV Ads
description: There will be an event in Chicago today in the Hyatt Regency that should gladden the hearts of all the peddlers in the print media, because at it six speakers will examine the problem of zapping.

title: Uncertain Progress on Health Costs
description: The Reagan Administration is declaring victory over ''the health care inflation monster'' because medical costs are rising less feverishly. Any celebration, however, should wait until all the causes of the decline are better understood. How much is due to new efficiencies, for which the Administration claims credit, and how much to diminished care?

title: WHEN A PRISON INMATE HAS NOTHING TO LOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS CAN SEIZE CENTRAL AMERICA ISSUE
description: As the Democratic Party convenes, it has an unusual opportunity to capitalize on a foreign policy issue on which President Reagan and the Republicans are most vulnerable. If the Democrats seize the moment, they will not only enhance their prospects in November, they also can help the country step back from the abyss of a Central American war, a war that will likely be upon us if current policy goes unchecked.

title: COLUMBUS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
High Salaries Criticized
description: Joe DiMaggio said he was glad that major league players were able to command high salaries these days. But, he added, those salaries are responsible for some of the game's problems, and he puts the blame on team owners who pay them. ''When I played, I had a hard time getting $5 from those guys,'' said DiMaggio, who added that the big money was creating ''turmoil'' in the sport.

title: NEW YORKERS RIDE HIGH AS THEY DIDN'T AT HOME
description: New York Democrats are playing a more prominent role at a Democratic national convention 2,500 miles from home than they did at the last two national conventions, which were in New York City.

title: T.V.A. Set To Scrap 4 Reactors
description: The staff of the Tennessee Valley Authority recommended yesterday that the T.V.A. scrap four partly built nuclear reactors on which it has spent $2.71 billion.

title: TODD BACK HOME:A SAINT BRIDGES TWO WORLDS
description: MOBILE, Ala.

title: MORGAN OFF
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the third-largest United States bank, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were reduced by $13 million because of loans to Argentina. Chase is Argentina's third-largest creditor.

SWEET EUPHORIA AT U.S. BLOCK PARTY
description: A Democratic National Convention is, as John Chancellor said the other day, one of the nation's more conspicuous bulletin boards. But it is also a block party, where the block stretches across every state in the union and everyone - but everyone - feels important.

title: WEEK OF ANNIVERSARIES FOR SPACE PROGRAM
description: Space Week 1984 got off to a roaring start today with the launching of a model Saturn 5 rocket at the Kennedy Space Center, 15 years to the day after the Apollo 11 astronauts began their flight to the moon.

title: JETS TRY CARTER IN HOLMES'S OLD SPOT
description: Because the draftings of first-round cornerbacks simply do not stir the imagination, Russell Carter may be the most unglamorous No. 1 draft pick the Jets have had in a decade.

title: Time Inc. Net Climbs by 9.7%
description: Time Inc. yesterday reported a 9.7 percent increase in second-quarter net income, helped by a sharp rise in pretax income from its magazines division.

title: TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1984 International
description: American warships will not be sent to New Zealand waters for the rest of this year and probably not until mid- 1985 at the earliest, senior American officials said. The decision is an effort to avoid a crisis within the Pacific alliance. Prime Minister-elect David Lange has pledged to ban nuclear- armed and nuclear-powered ships from New Zealand. (Page A1, Col. 2.) Two Warsaw police officers were acquitted in the beating death in May 1983 of Grzegorz Przemyk, the 19- year-old son of a well-known Polish dissident. Two ambulance drivers were convicted of negligence and were sentenced to two and a half and two years in prison. Two doctors were also convicted of negligence, but were given amnesty. (A3:1-3.) title: Bridge: 2 Ohio Partnerships Ahead In Life Master Tournament
description: Two partnerships from Ohio led into the final two rounds of the life master pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here this afternoon.

title: CAUTION: PRIDE X-ING, EQUILIBRIUM ATILT
description: Some call it the ''Senate syndrome,'' although it has been known to afflict House members, too. It becomes most pronounced about a year before Election Day, especially among longtime legislators who have achieved positions of power and influence.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. Dave Winfield remained far ahead in the American League's batting race after the Yankees' spectacular 9-8 comeback victory Monday night, and Don Mattingly, with four hits, slipped back into the No. 2 spot, past Kent Hrbek.

title: SHUFFLE IN PARIS: INDIRECT INVITATION TO COMMUNISTS TO QUIT THE GOVERNMENT
description: President Francois Mitterrand's decision to appoint a new Prime Minister brings the appearance of new style and character to his fatigued administration at midterm, but it urgently raises the issue of the continued participation of the Communists in the Socialist-led Government.

description: The 1983 figures include an after- tax gain of $2.4 million, or 50 cents a share, on the sale of equity securities.

title: VF-Modern Globe
description: The VF Corporation, an apparel manufacturer, said it had agreed to acquire Modern Globe Inc. for $35 million. Modern Globe, a closely held clothing manufacturer, had sales of $37 million last year.

title: REAGAN SIGNS LAW LINKING FEDERAL AID TO DRINKING AGE
description: President Reagan, appealing for cooperation in ending the ''crazy quilt of different states' drinking laws,'' today signed legislation that would deny some Federal highway funds to states that keep their drinking age under 21.

title: MANILA SEEN AT 'CRITICAL STAGE'
description: Social and economic pressures in the Philippines are reaching a ''critical stage'' and unless there is a change of course, the country may turn Communist within the decade, Representative Stephen J. Solarz, chairman of the House subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, said here this week.

title: Guatemalan Rightists Gain 23 of 88 Seats in Assembly
description: A rightist coalition appears to have won the most seats in the new Constituent Assembly, despite finishing third in balloting July 1, according to the Supreme Electoral Tribunal.

title: Daimler's Mexico Plan
description: Daimler-Benz of West Germany has begun talks on a joint project for manufacturing buses and trucks in Mexico, a member of its executive council, Gerhard Liener, said today. The project would include cooperation with the Government-owned National Diesel Company, he said, adding that plans would not be available until after the talks, which are expected to last six months.

BORG LOSES, 6-3, 6-1, IN LIMITED RETURN
description: Henri Leconte took just 49 minutes to defeat Bjorn Borg, 6-3, 6-1, in the first round of the $115,000 Wiessenhof International tennis tournament today. Borg, 28 years old and the former No. 1 player in the world, has retired from major competition, but has scheduled a program of playing in a few tournaments.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON NEW HOT LINE
description: Soviet and American officials initialed a diplomatic note today upgrading the 21- year-old hot-line link between Moscow and Washington for crisis communications.

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
UPSTATE, A CHEESE PARTY FOR THE GOATS
description: The invitation for last Saturday afternoon said, ''Come meet our kids'' but the youngsters it referred to were goats, 140 females ranging in age from 4 weeks to about a year. They had arrived the week before at the Coach Farm in Pine Plains, N.Y. Lillian and Miles Cahn, who own the farm, decided to give a party to show them off to the neighbors. That the event took place on Bastille Day was appropriate because before the year is out, the Cahns hope to start producing French-style goat cheeses for sale in the New York metropolitan area.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Baghdad dispatch yesterday about American and Soviet support for Iraq misstated the amount of oil Iraq is pumping through its Turkish pipeline. It is about 850,000 barrels a day.

title: Rutledge Is Uneasy Over Job
description: The shadows of long pine trees crossed the trail in front of Jeff Rutledge. He walked slowly and did not notice a small skunk jumping the rows of sunlight on the path. Nor did he give any notice to the clamor of teammates up ahead. Had the walk from the Giants' practice field to the lunchroom been longer, Rutledge would have been glad. The morning workout at Pace University had left him unsatisfied and preoccupied.

Suite Fit for a Speaker
description: Amid the general exuberance at the keynote denunciation of President Reagan as a royalist with a plutocrat's agenda, officials at the Fairmont Hotel are diplomatically declining to disclose the fee on the suite occupied by a leading Democrat, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. His quarters have 6,500 square feet, including three bedrooms, a game room, and room enough left over to caucus or just to fill with smoke, if an old-school politician was so whimsical.

title: JACKSON VOW: LIFT FOR SLATE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's pledge tonight to support the Democratic ticket resolved the most potentially explosive question facing Walter F. Mondale's drive for Democratic unity in the campaign against President Reagan this fall. Just a week ago the black leader raised new worries for the Mondale strategists by implying that his backing for the Democratic ticket would be in question unless he was satisfied by the actions of the convention.

title: DANCE: THE AILEY OFFERS ULYSSES DOVE PREMIERE

The work is a strange excursion into primitive rites with an urban touch. After this New York premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House, the piece was greeted by a cheering ovation from the younger segment of the audience.

title: Harold Lavine Is Dead at 69; A Former Newsweek Editor
description: Harold Lavine, the senior editorial writer at The Arizona Republic and a former foreign correspondent and political writer for Newsweek and several New York City newspapers, was found dead at his home here Sunday. He was 69 years old.

description: It was one of those small but telling moments.

CONTINENTAL CONTROL BY U.S. SEEN
description: Stymied in its attempt to find a private solution to the run on Continental Illinois National Bank, a Federal Government agency is preparing to assume liability for its billions of dollars in problem loans.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Otto Graham On Quarterbacks

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIATED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: ;  Murphy on the Ballot
description: For sports broadcasters, ''San Diego Jack Murphy Stadium,'' the official name of the city's ball park, is too much of a mouthful. So they tend to swallow the ''San Diego'' and call it simply ''Jack Murphy Stadium,'' a practice that has left a bad taste in the mouth of some San Diego residents.

title: IT'S JUST A WASTELAND, BUT IT'S HOME TO GUATEMALANS
description: For thousands of homeless Guatemalans, the huge vacant lot on the south side of the capital was too appealing to pass up.

title: The Stakes in the Hospital Strike
description: New York City's hospital strike has spread, negotiations are stalled and fatigue is taking its toll of nonstrikers. So the focus shifts to Albany: why would Governor Cuomo let national politics distract him from such an urgent crisis at home? Why isn't he leaping in, as governors always have before?

title: Search for Fugitive Shifts Back to Ohio
description: The search for the fugitive Alton Coleman shifted back to Ohio today when a man who was abducted in Kentucky was found here in the trunk of his automobile and a minister and his wife were beaten and their automobile was stolen.

title: Pole Jailed for His Part In a December Rally
description: A court sentenced the brother of a prominent Solidarity leader to 18 months in jail today hours after the Government announced plans for an amnesty for political prisoners to mark the 40th anniversary of Communist rule in Poland.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: GLATFELTER, P.H. CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid April 25.

title: Crocker Has Profit In Quarter
description: The Crocker National Corporation, which lost $178 million in two preceding quarters, said yesterday that it earned $6.1 million, or 28 cents a share, in the second quarter ending June 30. The company said that bad loans to Argentina reduced profits in the period by $10.9 million.

title: Dotting the Hart Ayes
description: Supporters of Gary Hart began displaying red dots on their shoes today, seeking to symbolize what one said was Walter F. Mondale's propensity to ''shoot himself in the foot.'' One delegate, Michael Mervis of Milwaukee, began distributing the dots in an attempt to rally Hart backers seeking to prevent Mr. Mondale's nomination at the Democratic National Convention. Mr. Mervis said he had purchased 3,000 dots at a stationery store for $32.

title: GOODBYE MALE TICKET, HELLO ETIQUETTE GAP
description: From the first, there had to be a policy on kissing.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from San Francisco on Monday about the problems of the Democratic Party misstated the history of Eugene J. McCarthy's 1968 campaign debt. He raised the money to pay it.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Pizza on Streets LeadstoFireI.Jail
description: Two Islip teen-agers were jailed last weekend after they failed to appear in court on charges that they illegally ate pizza on the streets of the Fire Island village of Ocean Beach.

title: AN EAST SIDE INSTITUTION BRANCHES OUT
description: Where in New York can you buy both a blue denim jacket with Michael Jackson's picture on the back and a towering hot fudge sundae? Or a fuzzy teddy bear and a footlong hot dog? Or a board game ''where you become a Jewish mother'' and zen hash?

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $3,940,000. c-Including a tax credit of $2,355,000.

title: CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER APPOINTED BY CITICORP
description: Robert G. Wade Jr. has been named chief investment officer of Citicorp, where he will be responsible for managing $16 billion in domestic investments. He will also be chairman of Citicorp's investment policy committee.

title: L.I.R.R. Mishap Delays Service
description: A car of a Long Island Rail Road freight train partly derailed today, halting all service between Deer Park and Pine-Aire and delaying thousands of commuters during the evening rush hour.

title: STABILIZE BANKING: RESTORE SOME CONTROLS
description: In the aftermath of the Continental Illinois affair, large depositors in the nation's major banks have been asking questions about the safety of their money that haven't been widely asked for nearly 50 years - since the banking industry came under strict Government regulation.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid May 20, 1983.

title: SPERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of investment in Triology Ltd. of $21.8 million and a gain from discontinued operations of $3 million.

title: REAGAN QUESTIONS CURB ON TAKEOVER DEFENSES
description: Over the objections of the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has been voicing opposition within the Administration to legislation that would ban ''greenmail'' tactics and ''golden parachute'' contracts as defenses against unfriendly corporate takeovers.

title: PENN SQUARE INDICTMENT
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former vice president of the failed Penn Square Bank on multiple counts of misapplying bank funds, wire fraud and falsifying records.

title: CUOMO'S THEME
description: The Presidential campaign is picking up speed and losing altitude, so you'd better fasten your seat belt for a long, rough ride.

title: NEW ZEALAND TIES TO U.S. AFFIRMED
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Prime Minister-elect David Lange of New Zealand met for 40 minutes in Wellington today and stressed their desire to avoid a crisis in the 33-year-old alliance of the United States, New Zealand and Australia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Successful Surgery For 14-Year-Old

title: COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP (COMSAT)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3.5% STAKE IS ACQUIRED IN DISNEY
description: Walt Disney Productions said today that Jefferies & Company, a brokerage based here, had acquired about 3.5 percent of the company's stock in the last three weeks.

title: Additional Layoffs For Levi Strauss
description: Just one month after it closed 11 plants and laid off 3,200 workers, Levi Strauss & Company said it would dismiss as many as 400 more employees in mid-August, all from the company's San Francisco headquarters.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 18, 1984 International
description: A new French Cabinet is to be formed. Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy and his ministers resigned and President Francois Mitterrand appointed Laurent Fabius, the 37-year- old Industry Minister, as the new Prime Minister. The governing Socialists have faced a succession of economic and political setbacks. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Mr. Fabius, an economist and moderate technocrat, is the youngest Prime Minister in modern French history. (A6:1-2.) The 1963 hot-line link for crisis communications between Moscow and Washington will be upgraded under an agreement signed by Soviet and American officials. (A1:1.)

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Sentry Data Filing
description: Sentry Data Inc. said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. It also said that before the filing, it had agreed with Sheldon I. Dorenfest & Associates Ltd. for Dorenfest to continue to manage Sentry's operations and to seek to sell Sentry or its assets.

title: Clubmart Plans Public Sales
description: Clubmart of America, the new discounter in New York City selling only to card holder-members, said yesterday that it was reversing its policy and would sell to the general public.

title: AMNESIA WITH REAGAN
description: On television we see President Reagan in a cave. It is the Mammoth Cave, one of America's great caves. The TV news reader says the President has come there to create ''a photo opportunity.''

title: A CASE FOR BACKPACKS
description: They walk breezily and athletically, arms swinging, hands free. They are the men with backpacks. They are more precisely the dressed-up men - clad in suits or sport coats and neckties - whose fabric backpacks have traveled the road from mountain peak to city chic. It is, this teaming up of natty business clothing and casual backpacks, a new look on the block.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST CO (VACHERIE, LA) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Women in Tennessee Prison Will Not Get an Early Parole
description: No women will be among the Tennessee inmates granted early paroles next month under Federal court orders to reduce prison overcrowding, a State Parole Board official said Monday.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Happy Birthday!

title: WHY STUDY LATIN?
description: It is once more fashionable to ask: Why bother with Latin? Challenges are issued, battle lines drawn. Latin is a dead language, say the cons, a mere frill. Oh no, say the pros, Latin improves your English vocabulary, and it's essential if you want to be a doctor or a lawyer. Both sides miss the point.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BELTS, BEARS, SHOES AND BOXES
description: 1.*Big Gray Belt

title: U.S. MOVES A CARRIER INTO CARIIBBEAN
description: The Reagan Administration has sent the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy to the Caribbean off the coast of Nicaragua as part of a subdued military, diplomatic and political campaign expected to last until after the November election, officials said today.

title: AMERICAN CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Warsaw Trial and Test
description: The show trial the Polish regime never wanted is now under way. Formally, it is a proceeding against four key intellectual advisers to Solidarity - Jacek Kuron, Adam Michnik, Zbigniew Romaszewski and Henryk Wujec - for conspiring to forcibly overthrow the Polish system. But in fact, as Lech Walesa observes, it is a trial of Solidarity, and of its appeal to the entire Polish people, a test of the legitimacy of the military dictatorship as posed by the defendants.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $675,000 on the repurchase of debentures and a gain of $11,079,000 from the sale of a building subsidiary. The latest quarter and 6 months include the results of the Southeast National Bank which merged into Fidelcor on June 30, 1983.

title: Sandinistas' Leader To Seek Presidency
description: Nicaragua's governing Sandinistas announced today that Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the junta coordinator, would be their candidate for President and that Sergio Ramirez, a junta member, would run for Vice President in the elections scheduled for Nov. 4.

title: CHALLENGES FORGE BOND OF WOMEN AND BLACKS
description: For a moment today, in the commotion of a platform debate at the Democratic Women's Caucus, the political energy released by the selection of a woman as Vice-Presidential candidate converged with the discontent of blacks.

title: Samuel D. Lipton Dies at 68; Psychoanalyst and Professor
description: Dr. Samuel D. Lipton, a psychoanalyst and clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of Illinois, died Friday at Evanston (Ill.) Memorial Hospital.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY'S PROMISE TO PEOPLE OF ANY AGE: THE UNFAIRLY BURDENED
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MAIN CIVIL LIBERTY: A RIGHT NOT TO STARVE
description: In eight years as director of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union, John Shattuck jousted in the courts and on Capitol Hill with dozens of Justice Department lawyers and intelligence officials in the union's never-ending campaign to protect privacy, individual rights and civil liberties.

RCA's Net Surges 75% In Quarter
description: The RCA Corporation, the diverse electronics and communications company and parent of the NBC network, said yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter rose 75 percent, to a record $109.9 million, or $1.13 a share.

title: 4.7% Federal Express Gain
description: The Federal Express Corporation said today that profits in the quarter ended May 31 rose a modest 4.7 percent from a year earlier, largely because of costs associated with developing a new electronic transmission service, Zapmail. The overnight package service said profits rose to $28.7 million, or 61 cents a share, from $27.4 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: A Narcissistic Touch
description: Even within the hall, television is the only way to try to follow the platform proceedings.

title: IRAN'S BOOTY: A RARE GLIMPSE OF U.S. SECRETS
description: Islamic militants in Teheran are continuing to publish photocopies of secret cablegrams, Government documents and personal papers found when they seized the United States Embassy there on Nov. 4, 1979. And since thousands of pages of sensitive documents are believed to be still in the Iranians' hands, it is possible they will be published for years to come.

title: Today's Calendar
description: Caucuses: With debate on the platform over and nomination of the national ticket assured, only the really persistant Democratic subgroups are still holding caucuses to get their signals straight. Asian Pacific Caucus, 11 A.M. Eastern (8 A.M. Pacific); Women, noon Eastern (9 A.M. Pacific); Hispanic, 1:30 P.M. Eastern (10:30 A.M. Pacific).

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: AT 37, CAPTAIN OF FRANCE: LAURENT FABIUS
description: Laurent Fabius, appointed Prime Minister tonight, personifies the new, hard-headed, pragmatic brand of Socialism on which President Francois Mitterrand is now trying to rebuild his party's battered political fortunes. At age 37, Mr. Fabius is the youngest Prime Minister in modern French history. But despite his youth he is a close confidant of the President as well as a proven, battle- scared political ally.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article July 6 about the hijacking of an Indian airliner inaccurately characterized the Press Trust of India. While the news agency obtains most of its money from the national and state governments, which are its biggest subscribers, it is independent of the Government.

City Plans to Sell Houses for $250
description: THe city plans to sell 33 vacant two-family houses for $250 each and will offer the new owners low-interest loans for building rehabiliation, officials said yesterday.

title: Georgia-Pacific Increases 50%
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that record profits in paper operations helped raise its overall profits 50 percent, to $84 million, or 78 cents a share, from $56 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: 3 Youths Remain Free In Homosexual Slaying
description: Homosexual activists packed a courtroom today and watched angrily as three juveniles were allowed to remain free on charges of killing a homosexual man who drown after he was thrown from a bridge.

title: Photos of artists doing renovations; ARTISTS COLONIZE THE JERSEY CITY HEIGHTS
description: Quietly in recent years, artists have been settling in the section of this city known as the Heights, an old ethnic neighborhood perched on a cliff at the low end of the Palisades.

title: Manville Ads Are Planned
description: The Manville Corporation plans to start advertising on July 31 to solicit claimants in connection with its bankruptcy filing, a move that could add as much as $1 billion to its liabilities.

title: The U.N. Today July 18, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Debt Rating
description: * El Paso Electric Co.'s first mortgage bond rating was reduced to A- from A and the preferred stock rating to BBBx from A- by Standard & Poor's. The action affects about $600 million of securities.

FIRST AMARILLO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
29 Works of Art Are Recovered
description: Twenty-nine art works that were in a truck stolen while parked on Columbus Avenue on May 22 were recovered by the police after they received an anonymous tip Monday, authorities said yesterday.

title: St. Regis Gains On Speculation
description: Speculation mounted yesterday that Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, would soon make a takeover bid for the St. Regis Corporation, a forest products and insurance company. Wall Street professionals said they had no concrete information but were buying because they were convinced that he was preparing an offer.

title: WITNESS CALLS MARCOS A SUSPECT IN PLOT ON AQUINO
description: The inquiry into the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. reopened today and heard two witnesses, one of whom asserted that President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, were two of the possible suspects in a plot to kill the opposition leader.

title: DOW UP 6.07 AS TRADING INCREASES
description: Continuing a pattern of cautious advances, stock prices moved higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: AIM TELEPHONE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: PATRIOT MISSILE DELAYED BY PROBLEMS IN TESTS
description: The Patriot missile, billed as the premier nonnuclear antiaircraft weapon in the American arsenal, is so far behind testing and production schedules that deployment in Europe may not be completed until the 1990's, according to the Army.

description: Koch Speaks on Cuomo, Mondale and Koch

title: POLISH MEDALIST IN DISABLED GAMES DEFECTS TO U.S.
description: A Polish amputee track star who won a gold medal at the International Games for the Disabled last month has defected to the United States, officials said today.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN IND., INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Whither the 'Fanfare'?
description: Missing from the Democrats' prominent ceremonies thus far is their trademark musical theme from past nominating conventions, ''Fanfare for the Common Man.'' Officials said the omission of Aaron Copland's stirring orchestral work at the initial trooping of the colors had nothing to do with the convention's super-sensitivity to the nuances of man-woman equality. They said the ''Common Man'' melody may yet be heard at the convention, though not so prominently.

title: KANTOR CHOSEN TO HEAD MGM/UA PRODUCITON
description: Jay Kanter, who has been a vice president of The Ladd Company for the last five years, will replace Freddie Fields as head of production for MGM/UA Entertainment Company, it was announced today by Frank Yablans, vice chairman and chief operating officer of MGM/UA.

description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.9 million, or 3 cents a share. c-After a pretax charge of $175 million representing a provision from restructuring, income from discontinued operations of $18.9 million and a credit of $75.7 million representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $18.4 million for the quarter and $37.4 million for the 6 months.

title: HART MAY GET A MAJOR VOICE ON NEW DEMOCRATIC RULES PANEL
description: After a private meeting this morning between Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart, aides to the two Democratic candidates entered negotiations that could give the Hart camp a major voice in rewriting the rules for the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: RETIRED FIND FUN IN SUMMER SCHOOL
description: Willian and Molly Bradfield joined students around a piano in a Pennsylvania State University dormitory and lifted their voices in song to mark the end of another day of learning.

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Norstar Purchase
description: The Norstar Bancorp said it had agreed to acquire Chapdelaine & Company Government Securities Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter included nonrecurring gains of $2,845,000, or 60 cents per share.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Even in our fractured state, all of us count and all of us fit somewhere.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net included foreign exchange translation losses of $290,000 and $546,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, compared with losses of $341,000 and $737,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively. The latest 6 months net included $12,924,000, or $5.57 a share, of capital gains, of which $5.07 a share was attributable to the previously reported Cone Mills transaction. The year-ago period's net included capital gains of $2,506,000, or $1.08 a share.

BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Moon Newspaper Head Dismissed in a Dispute

title: A REFRESHED TOWN HALL WILL MAKE FALL DEBUT
description: The doors were open to the street, and through them one could glimpse the auditorium of Town Hall - gutted, without seats, workmen erecting scaffolding, the secret life of the once- great concert hall laid bare for all the world to see, the psychic vibrations that once carried the voices of Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Joan Sutherland and Lotte Lehmann temporarily stilled.

title: ;  Tempting Offer Seen
description: Joe Theismann , the star quarterback who had suggested that he might want to end his career away from Washington if the Redskins did not come up with enough money, may be getting a two-year contract extension that will keep him with the team through the 1987 season. According to The Washington Post, Theismann, the National Football League's most valuable player last year, will be given the extension shortly. The player and the team declined comment. . . . Clarence Scott , the Cleveland Browns' 35-year-old cornerback and defensive captain, announced his retirement after 13 seasons.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRUCK IS GOING BACK TO SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union decided today to send home unopened a truck that Switzerland refused to accept as a diplomatic pouch.

title: A FEW CLOUDS OVER ROUTE 128
description: For nearly 25 years it has been known as ''America's Technology Highway,'' the ''Golden Semicircle'' or simply ''the Road.''

title: Three to Nominate Mondale
description: Walter F. Mondale today selected a black mayor, a Hispanic Congressman from New York and a Southern woman to place his name in nomination at the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday. Mr. Mondale's office announced that Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles would make the first nominating speech. Ann Richards, State Treasurer of Texas, was named to second the nomination. And Representative Bob Garcia of the Bronx is to make the third speech for Mr. Mondale.

title: PRESIDENCY ISN'T AFFECTED
description: The resignation of a French Cabinet means neither the fall of the regime nor the imminence of new elections.

title: REP. FERRARO'S FINANCIAL STATUS STARTS TO EMERGE
description: Representative Geraldine Ferraro listed herself as an officer and stockholder of her husband's real-estate company in her latest financial disclosure to the House of Representatives.

title: Pacific Telesis Posts Profits
description: The Pacific Telesis Group, a regional holding company created Jan. 1 in the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, yesterday reported second-quarter profits of $211.9 million, or $2.18 a share, on sales of $1.9 billion.

title: No Headline
description: Defense lawyers at John Z. DeLorean's drug trial today called the role the chief prosecutor played in the investigation of the automobile manufacturer possibly ''illegal.'' They said they would renew an attempt to call the prosecutor to testify.

title: STATE ACCUSED OF HALTING TALKS ABOUT HOMELESS
description: Negotiations between New York State officials and lawyers for former mental patients who are homeless have broken off without resolving what services the state will provide, a lawyer for the homeless said yesterday.

title: Court Won't Rule On Hiring Judges
description: The State Supreme Court has ruled it does not have the authority to force Connecticut to spend more money on its court system and hire more judges to handle a backlog of civil cases.

title: Wells Fargo Promotes Officer to No. 2 Spot
description: A year and a half after Carl E. Reichardt moved up a step and became chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo & Company and its major subsidiary, the Wells Fargo Bank, the company once again has a No. 2 man. Paul Hazen, a 42-year-old vice chairman, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the San Francisco company and its bank.

title: INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
