Manatt Rides High
description: Now that he has successfully dodged the dagger wielded by Mondale operatives, Charles T. Manatt, the once and future Democratic chairman, is strutting about the convention in full glory. He has been greeting delegates with cries of: ''Oh, how exciting it is to make history'' and ''Are we having fun?'' Delegates who only a day or so ago had been read the Manatt political obituary now are shouting to him: ''We love you!''

title: OVETT WINNER IN 1,500
description: Steve Ovett of Britain returned to the track to win impressively, but Steve Cram suffered his second loss in five days at the Edinburgh Track and Field Games today.

title: Sikh Sect Begins Repairs On the Golden Temple
description: Amid the chanting of prayers, the leader of a Sikh sect and his followers began repairing damage to the Golden Temple in Punjab today. But other Sikh leaders accused them of colluding with the Indian Government and threatened to demolish the restored structures.

HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE BRUSH At first blush, the 53 Chinese brush paintings and sketches now on view at the Asia Society's Starr Gallery, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street (288- 6400), appear to be old, very old, in the style of Chinese art that we associate with ancient dynasties. Among them are landscapes, fans, hanging screens, birds and trees and cursive calligraphy.

description: An office held by Adrian W. DeWind, whose article ''Yugoslav Repression'' appeared Monday, was misstated. He was president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

description: John Hagan's family started selling highway construction materials from a site in the East Elmhurst section of Queens soon after World War II. Three years ago, the family decided to sell the property and the jumble of antiquated manufacturing and storage facilities on it.

description: ''Believe me,'' said Harvey Bergenholtz, ''I've tried everything.'' He said he had given up smoking, was on a salt-free diet, watched out for those saturated fats and took regular medication - all to control his blood pressure. Then he goes out and drives a taxi in Manhattan 12 hours a day.

title: 'BROTHERS,' HOMOSEXUALITY IN SERIES
description: Homosexual characterizations are hardly new to television entertainment. Can anyone forget the look on Archie Bunker's face when his macho Indian-wrestling opponent revealed his, as they say, sexual persuasion? In the television movie ''That Certain Summer,'' Hal Holbrook and Martin Sheen played a homosexual couple with carefully calculated sympathy. On the weekly beat, the sitcom ''Soap'' and the melodrama ''Dynasty'' featured homosexuals in their large casts of characters. Now, a series called ''Brothers'' is bringing the homosexual directly onto stage center as a major character.

CONVENTIONAL WORDS
description: Midge Costanza, who once advised President Carter on women's issues, was talking after a Democratic meeting here the other day about loaded language. Notice, she said, how often women in politics are called ''outspoken'' or ''feisty'' - in circumstances when men might be described as ''courageous.'' With Walter Mondale's selection of Geraldine Ferraro as his running mate, there's reason to hope for improvement. Language changes to reflect reality, and never more attentively than in politics.

title: MUSICOLOGISTS VS. THE PERFORMERS
description: Can humanism be returning to musicology? The current issue of 19th Century Music, a publication issued three times a year by the University of California Press, has an interesting article by Gary Tomlinson of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Tomlinson, looking at musicological writing in general, makes a plea for a wider sphere of reference. He arrives at a conclusion that older writers on music would have considered a truism: ''We cannot comprehend art works (or anything else) outside of a cultural context.'' Only then can we arrive at ''not only a more profound knowledge of the works we value, but a fuller comprehension of the humanity we embody.''

;  Sather Is Guilty
description: Glen Sather , the Edmonton Oilers general manager, was convicted yesterday of assaulting a 70-year-old retired school teacher during a National Hockey League game, but was given an absolute discharge by the provincial court judge. title: America as Tax Haven
description: The Federal Government has long fretted about Americans who use foreign havens to conceal their income and avoid income taxes. Places like the Cayman Islands, the Netherlands Antilles, Liechtenstein and Macao have been all too ready to assist in the evasion. Unable to beat them, the Reagan Administration is now thinking of joining them, by inviting other countries' evaders to invest anonymously in the United States. Some American investors may also get in on the deal.

title: 'STEPHANE GRAPPELLI IN NEW ORLEANS'
description: STEPHANE GRAPPELLI, the French jazz violinist, has reached that stage of his career at which he is a phenomenon. Now in his late 70's, white-haired and clearly getting a kick out of life, he seems to be busier and more inventive than ever. Depending on the time of year, he can be found playing at a club in Greenwich Village or uptown at Carnegie Hall. He even appears on the Johnny Carson show once in a while. Older fans are never disappointed, and new ones are constantly being recruited. The music keeps flowing and the listeners keep applauding.

title: Joyce Beverages
description: The First Boston Corporation said it had entered into a definitive agreement for a company it organized to purchase Joyce Beverages. The transaction will be structured as a leveraged buyout and it is anticipated that certain members of Joyce management will participate with First Boston as equity investors in the new corporation. Joyce is a closely held company primarily engaged in the bottling and distribution of soft drinks, with sales of more than $200 million.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said it plans employee cutbacks in its telegram subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Corporation, by from 5 percent to 10 percent in an effort to become more competitive. The subsidiary employs 12,500 people nationwide, according to William Anderson, a spokesman for the parent company. ''The work force reduction is required to control costs and maintain efficient operation,'' Mr. Anderson said.

Turkish Deal By ITT Unit
description: Some 3.4 million telephone lines will be installed in Turkey during the next 10 years under a $300 million deal signed by the Turkish Government and a Belgian subsidiary of the ITT Corporation. The ITT unit, the Bell Telephone Manufacturing Company, will deliver equipment for 100,000 lines for early installation and then provide technology to manufacture digital telephone exchanges and related equipment.

title: BIGGER BIG TOPS FOR LARGE CITY GALAS
description: At 10:30 on the night of Sunday, May 13, the audience that attended the centennial benefit performance of the Metropolitan Opera left the opera house for an outdoor supper dance in Lincoln Center Plaza, and it started to pour. The rain, however, did not stop the gala. What was reportedly the largest party tent ever built in New York City - 200 feet by 150 feet and 50 feet high - sheltered the guests, who dined and danced until the early morning.

description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro has repeatedly said that she kept her maiden name professionally to honor her mother. Zaccaro in the summer of 1960 until the eve of her first Congressional campaign in 1978.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DANCE: JUDITH JAMISON
description: Judith Jamison, longtime star of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, made a triumphant return to the company on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The vehicle for her return as a guest artist was Mr. Ailey's ''Cry.'' Created for Miss Jamison in 1971, ''Cry'' is a sentimental and sassy solo set to music by Alice Coltrane, Laura Nyro and the Voices of East Harlem and dedicated to ''all black women everywhere - especially our mothers.'' But ''Cry'' has always been Miss Jamison's star turn, and she filled the stage with her teasing exuberance in the dance's stomp-and-shout finale.

It was the Phillies' first three-game sweep at 14-year-old Riverfront Stadium. Their last sweep in Cincinnati came in July 1956 at Crosley Field.

title: ;  Charger Rookie Hurt
description: Mike Guendline, a rookie linebacker who had been expected to win a starting position on the San Diego Chargers, suffered a severe knee injury during practice Monday and will be out indefinitely. The second-round draft pick from Northwestern prepared to undergo knee surgery yesterday. . . Stanley Wilson , a Cincinnati Bengal running back, dislocated his left shoulder in practice Tuesday and is expected to be out five weeks.

title: HEALTH STRIKE IS HURTING PATIENT CARE, STATE SAYS

title: The Editorial Notebook; Lunch, al Fresco
description: When Simone de Beauvoir visited New York last year, she was struck by the absence of drugstores with lunch counters. ''Thirty years ago,'' she reminisced, ''I'd sit at a counter . . . listen to the chatter, watch the people eat. . . . That strange mixture that was the New York drugstore seems to be gone entirely.''

title: THE REGION Trenton City Hall Invaded by Ants
description: City Hall employees here said today that ants had swarmed over their desks for the last two days.

title: Italian Cyclist in Coma After Collision
description: Carlo Tonon, an Italian cyclist, suffered a skull fracture today and was said by doctors to be in ''a deep coma'' after he collided head-on at high-speed with a bicycle-riding spectator during the 19th stage of the Tour de France. The doctors at Annecy Hospital here said that they would be unable to make any further statement on Tonon's condition for at least 48 hours.

title: SUBWAY TRAIN FIRE IN THE BRONX FORCES THE REMOVAL OF 200
description: A southbound IRT subway train caught fire yesterday on an elevated track in the Bronx, forcing the removal of 200 passengers, the Transit Authority said. No injuries were reported.

description: A man charged with slaying two people hanged himself Tuesday with a bed sheet in his Rikers Island cell while under a suicide watch.

description: An unemployed security guard armed with three guns strode into a McDonald's restaurant in this town on the Mexican border today and killed 20 people and wounded 16 others before a police sharpshooter shot him dead.

title: Israelis Report Seizing Ship Leased to P.L.O.

title: STAGE: 'OEDIPUS REX,' GREEK NATIONAL TROUPE

But reservations are also prompted about whether this highly rhetorical play was the best choice to send to a country where Greek is not widely understood.

title: Thiokol Contract

Thiokol is a unit of Morton Thiokol Inc. In addition, the General Dynamics Corporation was given $25.1 million in Air Force contracts for engineering changes in the F-16 fighter plane program.

title: CITY IS MAKING USE OF INFORMATION ACT TO GET WASTE DATA

'SHOGUN' BACK IN ONE-NIGHT VERSION
description: ''SHOGUN'' had its television premiere about four years ago as a 12-hour mini- series. Then, in 1981, it was released in theaters abroad as a 2 1/2- hour movie. Sunday at 9 P.M., it is back on Channel 4 as a movie that, not including commercial breaks, runs about two hours. In other words, four- fifths of the original production has been eliminated. But as a famous caterer once proclaimed, slice it anyway you like, it's still salami - or in this case, sushi.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Money Supply Up $1.7 Billion
description: The nation's basic money supply rose by $1.7 billion in the week ending July 9, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday. The increase was slightly less than the credit markets expected, but bond prices did not move much in reaction to the report. Trading was very light all day.

title: KERTESZ AT 90: CELEBRATION IN PHOTOS

ART: AMERICAN STILL LIFE WITH ACCENT ON THE LIFE
description: The category of still life in art has become so broad that almost no definition of it really sticks, except maybe that of inanimate objects portrayed in stasis. Where once a still life was a painted arrangement of animal or vegetable matter on a table - literally, ''dead nature'' - today it can take such forms as, say, a canvas by Ralph Goings of a ketchup bottle and a napkin holder; Jasper Johns's bronze sculpture of a light bulb; Saul Steinberg's real drafting table replete with pens and drawings, or the simulated roll of toilet paper carved from Carrara marble by Jud Nelson.

title: Cyclist Suspended
description: Alexi Grewal of Aspen, Colo., considered a top United States men's cycling hope for the Olympics, was suspended from competition for 30 days just before yesterday's race in the Coors International Bicycle Classic, effectively eliminating him from the Games, which begin in Los Angeles July 28. Race officials said that tests taken after earlier Classic races showed a banned substance, Phenylethylamine, in his urine.

title: No Headline
description: Apartheid at the Olympics In the name of protesting South Africa's apartheid, the International Olympic Committee has barred South African journalists from covering the Games in Los Angeles. They happen to include reporters from papers that are outspoken in their opposition to apartheid. But there should be no political test for accrediting journalists, nor is there any for the 8,200 who've been approved. This ban offends the Olympic spirit, American policy and perhaps even American law. It ought to be lifted at once.

Hours, Tuesday through Saturday, are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $2; $1 for students and the elderly. Information: 283- 2420.

description: A remarkable and sentimental reunion will be held at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati tonight when the Mets continue their series against the Reds.

title: G.M. Employees
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had recalled 3,000 hourly employees from indefinite layoff for work at various parts operations. The latest round of recalls reduces the number of workers on indefinite layoff with rehire rights to 37,000, G.M. said, and brings to 94,000 the number called back since the start of 1983. G.M. currently has about 7,600 workers on temporary layoff, a spokesman said.

title: Conrail Net Up 83.9%
description: Conrail, reporting final audited results for the second quarter yesterday, said net income rose 83.9 percent to $178.9 million, from $97.3 million in the 1983 period.

Proving a Point
description: John Henry, the 9-year-old gelding whose earnings of more than $4.5 million are the highest in racing history, may have given signs of finally slowing down lately, at least for him. He finished second to Desert Wine in the Hollywood Gold Cup on the dirt last month, an extraordinary achievement for a horse of his age, but he seemed to lack his old drive and did not fire down the stretch, never really threatening the winner.

title: Britons at Lone Star

Shows will be opened by the 10,000 Maniacs band at 9:15 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: McDonald's Seeks Ad Delay
description: The McDonald's Corporation today asked advertising outlets nationwide to delay broadcast of its commercials after the massacre at its restaurant in the San Ysidro section of San Diego, said Richard Starmann, a spokesman at the fast-food chain's suburban Chicago headquarters. He said: ''We are shocked and grieved by the tragic incident which took place yesterday. We have asked everyone to delay the ads for several days because we feel it is appropriate given the circumstances.''

title: 'DEADLY SUMMER'

She is, in fact, a good actress, whether playing sane or bonkers, but most of her movies these days are duds in which she is drearily type-cast.

Ferraro to the ticket headed by Walter F. Mondale. Party leaders from all regions of the country hailed ''the Ferraro factor,'' coming on the heels of unity declarations from Mr. Mondale's vanquished rivals, as a new trump card that had incalculably altered the prospects for the fall campaign despite the President's sizable lead in recent opinion polls.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 20, 1984 International
description: France's Communist Party withdrew from the new Socialist-led Government, accusing the Socialists of advocating economic policies that eliminate jobs and crush industries. The departure of the Communists raised the possibility of a new political relationship between the Socialists and some elements of France's center parties. (Page A1, Column 2.) Reagan Administration officials say the talks have been focusing increasingly on how to counter the Soviet Union in the region as desired by Washington rather than ''radical'' Arab governments as sought by Israel. title: Campfire on S.I.
description: Families are invited to an evening campfire with story swapping and sing-alongs tomorrow between 8 and 10 P.M. at the Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve on Carlin Street, off Sharrotts Road in Charleston, S.I. The sponsor, the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, says children, musical instruments, marshmallows and blankets are welcome. It's free. Registration and travel information: 967-1967.

description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who stole the show at the last Democratic convention, tonight captivated the delegates at this one in a supporting role by predicting the ''dream we share will live again'' if Walter F. Mondale is elected.

title: Coca-Cola Net Up 15.3%
description: The Coca-Cola Company, citing higher volumes and market share for its soft drinks, said today that its second- quarter earnings rose 15.3 percent from a year earlier on a 5.5 percent gain in revenues.

title: Fire Razes Byrd's Cottage
description: Adm. Richard E. Byrd's log house at his vacation estate here, where he did much of the planning for his polar expeditions in 1939, 1946 and 1955, was destroyed by fire Tuesday.

title: Respite for Auto Team
description: The English racing team headed by Ken Tyrrell was cited Wednesday for consistent cheating and was expelled from this year's world championship series for Formula One cars. But yesterday Tyrrell won an order from a British court that, pending further legal action on his part, allows his team to participate in qualifying trials for the British Grand Prix, to be held Sunday. The expulsion was ordered by the International Auto Sport Federation, headquartered in Paris, after it had determined that the Tyrrell team had repeatedly used illegal fuel and ballast in its cars.

description: Crown Zellerbach Inc. said its board had declared a dividend distribution of one right to purchase a common share for each share outstanding. description: In the hours before dawn this morning, the futuristic fortress that is Communist Party headquarters here became the site of a battle in which six decades of conflict on the French left was compressed into a single meeting.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Blaisdell , a Ranger forward, and John Vanbiesbrouck , a goalie, have signed new one-year contracts with the club. . . . X-rays revealed yesterday that Ozzie Smith , the St. Louis Cardinals' all-star shorstop, has suffered a hairline fracture of his right wrist. Smith, who was struck on the wrist by a pitch last Friday night, was placed on the 21-day disabled list.

title: EQUIMARK SEES A LOSS IN 2D QUARTER AND YEAR The Equimark Corporation, owner of Equibank of Pittsburgh, will report a substantial second-quarter loss, return to the black in the third quarter but still show a loss for the full year, James D. Lowry, president and chief executive, announced yesterday.
description: He said the bank would not pay an $875,000 dividend due Chase Manhattan Bank on $25 million of 14 percent preferred stock it holds. He added, however, that the company might reach agreement with Federal and state regulators by fall on a plan to increase its capital by $100 million from the current $87.5 million.

title: Bid by Fleming
description: The Fleming Companies said it had agreed to buy all of the shares outstanding of United Grocers Ltd. for $73.1 million in cash and Fleming stock. United, a for-profit cooperative, operates five centers to distribute food and related products to 1,500 stores in California and Nevada. Fleming is a distributor of wholesale foods.

title: Dancer Gets Account From Entre Computer
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, which knows its way around franchises and dealer associations, has just become agency for Entre Computer Centers, which says it is the largest publicly held franchiser of computer retail shops. Billings could be from $8 million to $10 million.

title: Precedent for Action
description: The precedent for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's reported plan to keep open the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company appears to date to 1971, when the corporation, acting under legislation adopted in 1950, pumped money into a troubled bank that it hoped to keep open and independent. The financial assistance was given to the Unity Bank and Trust Company in Boston.

Barkum, who was 34 years old on Wednesday, said last night from his home at Gulfport, Miss., that he had spoken to the Giants' coach, Bill Parcells, earlier in the day.

Storer said the sale was in line with its plan to divest itself of certain cable properties to reduce corporate debt and curtail capital spending requirements.

title: A Ray of Encouragement For the Stroke Victim
description: Stroke, a disease that afflicts more than a half-million North Americans each year, was long considered an inevitable ailment of old age that sequestered its victims in a closetlike world with little hope of rehabilitation. But ''Bring Back My Bonnie,'' on Channel 13 at 8 P.M. tomorrow, brings a ray of encouragement into the lives of stroke victims and of the relatives, friends and others who care for them.

title: Seagate Cutback
description: Seagate Technology said it had cut its work force 20 percent. The company said the move reflects measures to offset the effects of lower prices and a lower rate of growth for existing products in the industry, and its ability to switch the manufacturing of high-volume drives to its Far East operations. Seagate said the reduction mostly affects manufacturing employees.

title: KENNEDY CLOSING POSES QUESTIONS ON AIR DELAYS

title: CBS SIGNS TWO CONFERENCES

It was the first agreement made with a major network since the Supreme Court late last month voided the exclusive $34-million contracts that the National Collegiate Athletic Association had signed with CBS and ABC.

title: Diner's Journal
description: During the day this time of year, the shops and restaurants in the Citicorp Center, at Lexington Avenue and 53d Street, are elbow to elbow in tourists and office workers munching on salads, sampling pastries and licking rapidly melting ice cream. But at night, most shops close, and the center is nearly deserted. A few restaurants remain open, however, including a comfortable bistrolike spot that offers one of the better dinner bargains in town.

title: DS-Biochem Tie

DS is a closely held company. Biochem, which makes blood chemistry monitoring equipment, said it has substantial working capital needs as a result of losses during the last five quarters.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Promises Broken, Swindler Is Jailed
description: A Manhattan man finally was sent to prison today because after more than a year of promises to repay some of the people he swindled out of $218,000, the presiding judge lost faith.

title: East-West Troop Talks Recess for the Summer
description: Talks between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact on reducing troops in central Europe broke for the summer today with no tangible progress.

title: Rugged Road Back

''I'm in really lousy shape,'' the 32- year-old veteran said at the Falcons' training camp.

It was the 342- yard 10th where he nearly holed the drive as his ball rolled 10 feet by the pin.

title: MITTERRAND'S CHANGES: GIVING SOCIALISM A NEW, CENTRIST LOOK
description: Within hours of the Communist departure from Government here, President Francois Mitterrand began a campaign that seems aimed at creating the impression of movement toward the political center, an attempt to give French Socialism the look of moderate Social Democracy. Like a judge admonishing a jury, Mr. Mitterrand told Prime Minister Laurent Fabius and his new Socialist-led Cabinet at their first meeting Thursday that ''they represent no political party.'' Then the Government announced cuts in corporate and personal income taxes - not just one-shot deals, Mr. Mitterrand said, but reductions that would become a pattern for the rest of his presidency.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 21, 1984 International
description: Laos agreed to allow U.S. officials to excavate a site to search for the remains of 13 American servicemen whose plane crashed there nearly 12 years ago, President Reagan said. Mr. Reagan made the announcement at a White House ceremony observing National P.O.W./M.I.A. Recognition Day. He affirmed his Administration's determination to recover the remains and press for information on 2,489 Americans unaccounted for from the Vietnam War and 8,177 from the Korean War. (Page 1, Column 4.) Relatives of missing Guatamalans have started to band together in an effort to find their relatives and end the many unsolved disappearances. Such organizations have long been active in other Latin American countries where kidnapping has beome a favorite way of disposing of real or imagined enemies. (2:1.)

title: Letter: On the Surplus City Services We Could Have Had To the Editor:
description: We could not agree more with your July 2 editorial that the ''time for . . . tolerance'' over shoddy public services ''has truly passed.'' The citizens of New York certainly deserve better than they are getting. They also deserve some answers as to why so much of the surplus in fiscal year 1984, which ended on June 30, was prematurely and precipitously rolled over into FY 1985, rather than used to improve services immediately.

title: STAGE:NOMURA KYOGEN THEATER OF JAPAN
description: Every gesture and every sound are timed to the split second in the Kyogen style of Japanese theater. In that, Kyogen (literally, ''crazed words'') is not so different from other kinds of stage comedy. But in Kyogen plays, which were first performed in the 14th century as a light interlude between Noh dramas, actions and dialogue have been analyzed and stylized, their sense of time made elastic. Centuries before videotape, Kyogen exploited slow-motion and something like instant replay, so that ordinary events become ceremonial and, with repetition, comical.

title: DANCE: ALVIN AILEY AT MET, DONALD MCKAYLE'S 'RAINBOW'
description: It is always interesting to see how dances look when performed in different spaces. Donald McKayle's ''Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder'' is a modern dance classic that would seem to require an intimate stage to tell its story of the dreams and pain of men on a chain gang. title: Korea Steel Exports Up
description: South Korea's exports of steel products rose 9.5 percent, to the equivalent of $1.22 billion in the first half of 1984 from a year earlier, the Korea Iron and Steel Association said today. The association said exports of sheets and plates totaled $502 million in the first half of the year, up 9.6 percent from the first half of 1983. Steel pipe exports rose 30.9 percent, to $222 million, and steel rod shipments rose 49.3 percent, to $166 million.

title: YOUR MONEY ; New Risks Of Home Loans
description: Adjustable-rate mortgages have become a way of life for Americans. According to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, 65 percent of the mortgage loans closed last month were adjustable, with the interest rate or monthly payments changing according to a specified formula at specified time intervals. Furthermore, many lenders have either eliminated or de-emphasized the traditional fixed-rate mortgages, making them hard to find.

title: Airline Chapter 11
description: American International Airways, a financially troubled discount airline, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, a spokesman said. The filing involves only the airline and not the parent company, AIA Industries, according to the spokesman, Russell Stephenson. He said the airline, which is based at Philadelphia International Airport and offers discount fares to many Northeastern cities, would continue normal operations and would honor all reservations and tickets.

description: Joseph Walsh, who had been stripped of his duties as Bridgeport Police Superintendent, can resume his work on Monday, a Superior Court judge ruled today.

title: IRAN'S EXPECTED OFFENSIVE: WHY IT HASN'T HAPPENED
description: United States and Atlantic alliance intelligence analysts say they think Iran has put off a major new offensive against Iraq largely because of concern over whether it can provide sufficient air and tank support for its ground troops. United States analysts say Iranian military leaders, most of them from the Revolutionary Guards, have expressed concern that without such support, the assault would be repulsed by well-armed and well-entrenched Iraqi forces, with prohibitive casualties. This argument, the sources say, has been made to leading figures in the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: RENTS CAN PAY COSTS FOR OWNER
description: BUYERS looking for a creative way to buy themselves shelter in New York City often consider purchasing a small rental building. The object is to obtain an apartment or two for oneself while counting on the rent from other apartments to cover all or most of the building's costs. The depreciation allowance permitted on the rental portion of the building acts as a tax shelter.

title: CANAAN WELCOMES A NEW RAILROAD

title: Judith D. Nichols Marries in Maine
description: Judith Dale Nichols, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hart Nichols Jr. of Cumberland Foreside, Me., was married yesterday to Karamjeet Singh Paul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardyal Singh Paul of Bhopal, India. The Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Spurwink Church in Cape Elizabeth, Me.

title: CONSUMER RATES
ISRAEL'S BITTER WEST BANK HARVEST
description: IT IS NOT OFTEN THAT A PIECE OF SOcial science research becomes the symbol of a fateful national debate. That has happened in Israel with a report bearing the disarmingly dry title, ''The West Bank Data Project.'' The author is Meron Benvenisti, former Deputy Mayor of Jerusalem. Benvenisti and a team of researchers dug out for the first time the basic facts of life in the West Bank and Gaza, territories occupied by Israel since 1967: demography, land use, agriculture, industry, law. Their report, published by the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, fills 97 large-sized pages with maps, tables and analysis. But it is much more than that.

title: THEATER
description: ''Blue Window,'' the Craig Lucas play at the Production Company that has recently had its run extended indefintely, is a slice of terribly familiar Manhattan life: Seven reasonably sophisticated and well-off New Yorkers intersect at a dinner party. The hostess doesn't know most of her guests all that well; her party proves to have ''the wrong chemistry.''

title: Robin Roden to Marry Alexis Manice
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Roden 3d of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Halley Roden to Alexis Coster Manice of Bryn Mawr, Pa., the son of Josephine C. McLean of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and the late De Forest Manice of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 15.

title: PARISH TO REBUILD FIRE-SWEPT HYDE PART CHURCH
description: A half-melted church bell sits on the front lawn of the historic St. James Episcopal Church here, a reminder of the fire that destroyed the church's interior last month.

description: To the Editor:

title: MITTERRAND TRIES A NEW PREMIER
description: France's Constitution offers the president two ways out of bad situations. Under the Fifth Republic's hybrid system, he can dissolve the National Assembly and call new elections.

title: International
description: Release of 652 political prisoners in Poland in the next 30 days is authorized by an amnesty bill that was approved by Parliament on the 40th anniversary of Communist rule in Poland. Officials said the amnesty would apply to all political prisoners except those being held on charges of high treason, espionage and sabotage. (Page 1, Column 6. )

title: ON JUDGING A BOOK BY ITS COVER
description: French bookbindings from two of the greatest periods of the craft - the late Middle Ages and the Art Deco era - were among the most important treasures in the auction last month in Monte Carlo of the Florence J. Gould collection. Mrs. Gould, who died at 87 in February 1983 at her villa near Cannes in the South of France, was a bibliophile who cared more for the contents than the covers of her 4,000 books, most of which bore inscriptions or dedications to her from such artists and writers as Andre Gide, Henri Matisse, Jean Cocteau, Marie Laurencin, Francois Mauriac and Salvador Dali.

title: BECKETT'S 'ENDGAME' IS AN INEXHAUSTIBLE PLEASURE
description: Some dogged pedant once counted every sentence of ''Waiting for Godot,'' and found that more than a quarter of them were questions, few of which received satisfactory answers. As far as I know, he didn't go on to apply his mathematical eye to Samuel Beckett's next important play, ''Endgame''; but then he didn't really need to do so. Everything about it is interrogative. Every second sentence teases the mind with new doubts. Everywhere you look, you see evidence of Beckett's conscientious commitment to the uncertainty principle.

title: THE SEASON'S FESTIVALS BEGIN TO WIND DOWN
description: AS the days of July dwindle down, it is already time to say goodbye to several summer festivals around the state. Others continue, however, and at least one major series is about to begin.

title: NEW CALLS FOR TRAIN SAFETY
description: Crisscrossing about 24,000 miles of track carrying some 18 million passengers, the nation's passenger trains had eight collisions, 21 derailments and 154 other accidents last year. That makes Amtrak, the Federally financed corporation responsible for intercity passenger service, one of the safest transporters around - as safe as the airlines and far safer than private automobiles.

title: THE GOVERNMENT TAKETH, AND IT GIVETH BACK5
description: On the surface, it was definitely not business as usual. Congress passed an election-year package of tax increases that will raise some $50 billion through fiscal 1987. Apparently the legislators believed that voters this year were more worried about the yawning size of the Federal budget deficit than about moderately higher taxes through Sept. 30, 1987.

title: Miss Kanter, a C.P.A., To Be Wed to Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kanter of Lake Success, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Kanter to Steven Bruce Jackman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Jackman of Boston.

Now the barn of a former garden center houses all manner of sports equipment - bought at auction or on consignment - and discounted items, accessories and clothing, new and used, are on display in the barn and in a second building.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: -estate) standards, a 10-room farmhouse, furnished down to a Gucci bag on the veranda table, has to be a steal appraised at $5,000.

title: MASS IS SAID FOR SIX SAN YSIDRO VICTIMS
description: More than 700 people gathered this morning at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Catholic Church in nearby San Ysidro for a memorial mass for six people who were killed at a McDonald's restaurant earlier this week.

title: The Dominelli Affair
description: I just read Robert Lindsey's well-written article about J. David Dominelli (''The Dominelli Affair,'' June 3). I am getting fed up with all the publicity this case has been getting.

title: WILL SUCCESS SPOIL NONPROFIT THEATER?
description: At this moment, the Goodman Theater of Chicago may be the most exciting theater in America. In the last six months, it has spawned and sent to New York both ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' for which David Mamet won the Pulitzer Prize, and ''Hurlyburly,'' the David Rabe drama that must be considered a strong contender for the prize next year and meanwhile is one of the choicest tickets in Manhattan. Then there are the less tangible, more private measures of success. French television wants to interview Gregory Mosher, the Goodman's artistic director. Mark Medoff, the author of ''Children of a Lesser God,'' sends his new play to the Goodman, unsolicited. Marvin Hamlisch calls to see if the theater wants to stage his musical ''Jean Seberg.'' To invert the adage, everybody knows you when you're up and in.

title: ...AND TO THESE 4 ATHLETES, IT MEANS MORE THAN A MEDAL
description: IT'S already the Olympics' most anticipated storyline: Carl Lewis's quest for four gold medals in the same track and field events that Jesse Owens won in 1936 at Berlin - the 100-meter dash, the 200-meter dash, the long jump and the 4x100- meter relay. And the scenario was set as early as 1973 at a Franklin Field meet in Philadelphia when Jesse Owens leaned down and shook hands with a little 12-year-old.

title: HELPING FIND THE MENTAL EDGE
description: RON MEYER, one of the nation's top divers, used to be so fearful about performing his reverse three-and-a-half somersault off the 10-meter platform that every time he attempted it, he leaped too far away from the platform's edge to get a good score. A sports psychologist hypnotized him and had him mentally rehearse doing the dive closer to the platform, and after several sessions Meyer could do it physically, too.

description: Kyu-Sung Choi, a Korean immigrant, thought it would be a good idea to open a 24-hour delicatessen at Park Avenue and 75th Street. Many residents disagreed.

title: Margaret Stone Weds Kevin Riley Drewyer
description: Margaret Stone, a daughter of Elizabeth Asbury Stone of Cincinnati and James H. Stone of New Orleans, was married yesterday to Kevin Riley Drewyer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard G. Drewyer of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Robert W. Howard performed the Methodist ceremony at the Thompson Memorial Chapel in Williamstown, Mass.

title: TAKING THE STING OUT OF MOVING DAY
description: In recent years, employers have become increasingly careful about asking their employees to relocate. That's because independent- minded managers won't always go, two-career households find it harder to pull up stakes and, perhaps most important, prime mortgage rates and housing costs make moving a financial question mark for many homeowners. The corporations' general response has not been so much to reduce the number of moves as to enhance the compensation to employees for enduring them.

title: THE QUEST FOR OLYMPIC GREATNESS
description: In the article on Carl Lewis, Jane Gross speaks of the ''easy joy'' that ''lights'' the face of Lewis as he runs and jumps. Having both run and jumped competitively for many years, I couldn't help being surprised by this description. I have seen Lewis compete on several occasions and would describe his expression rather as one of ''determined concentration.'' JOHN J. RICE River Edge, N.J.

title: Swim Mark Set
description: Dara Torres set an American record in the women's 50-meter freestyle swim tonight during an exhibition meet staged by the United States Olympic team. Her clocking of 25.61 seconds came on the opening leg of the 200-meter relay team. The time was also the fastest ever in the world, but the 50-meter race is a non-Olympic event and the distance is not recognized internationally.

title: HOW FACULTY EXODUS CAME ABOUT
description: THE department of microbiology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, part of the medical school, is losing about a third of its full-time faculty members, including its chairman, this fall. Along with the professors go their research laboratories - their experiments, their technicians, their secretaries, their research dollars and most of their graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

title: SOUTHERN LEBANON: OCCUPATION BY ISRAEL TRAUMA FOR ALL SIDES
description: ''God is great,'' the villagers in Borj Rahal cried as they carried the body of Hassan Sahli out of the mosque and down the dusty hillside to his grave. ''Israel is the agent of Satan.''

title: Miss Vaughn Has Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Warner Vaughn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Vaughn of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Lawrence Louis Hlavacek Jr. of Lawrenceville, N.J., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hlavacek of Pennington, N.J. The Rev. Donald G. Stauffer performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside.

title: DIVIDING SACRED AND SECULAR
description: The line separating church and state is a ''blurred, indistinct and variable barrier,'' the Supreme Court said in 1971. That makes crossing the line fairly easy and preventing incursions fairly hard, as the Federal Office of Adolescent Pregnancy Programs is discovering.

title: IT'S ALL HAPPENING IN MY HOMETOWN
description: GROWING up in the Los Angeles of the 1940's, I was tantalized by the remains of what then seemed like the primordial local olympics of '32: My Scout-O-Rama assembled under the Olympic rings of the Coliseum, my high school was on Olympic Boulevard, the white bread delivered to our front door was the official Olympic loaf.

title: ABC TO TELEVISE 20 COLLEGE GAMES
description: The 63-member College Football Association has reached an agreement on a 20-game package with ABC that gives the network exclusive rights to televise C.F.A. games during prime Saturday viewing hours this fall, it was announced yesterday.

title: U.S. STUDY FINDS 8% OF LAND WILL ERODE, HOWEVER TILLED
description: About 8 percent of the nation's cropland is so ''highly erosive'' that no type of careful tillage can keep it from being washed away by rain, according to an Agriculture Department report. One sure way to save such land, the report said, would be to take it out of cultivation.

title: HISTORY OF A STEEL CENTER IN CHICAGO IS PRESERVED IN ARCHIVES AND IN PHOTOS
description: Industrial Southeast Chicago has a heart of rows of lookalike frame houses and well- worn playing fields, owned and used by 100,000 residents. Rising among the houses, Gothic church spires and golden onion domes hint at the rich ethnic fiber.

title: NEW WAVE OF HOLOGRAPHERS WORK TO EXPAND THE ART
description: In a dark, windowless basement below the Quad Cinema on West 13th Street, Dan Schweitzer and Sam Moree go to work long after the last show has let out.

title: MONDALE ENLISTS HART AND JACKSON TO UNIFY FORCES
description: Moving to broaden his appeal, Walter F. Mondale has enlisted Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson to stump for his candidacy and is preparing to draw some of their staff members into his campaign organization, Mondale aides say.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: JIM THORPE IS THE INSPIRATION FOR A NATIVE GAMES FESTIVAL
description: As hundreds of spectators from around the country cheered Thursday, a group of 250 American Indian runners burst into the arena of the Jim Thorpe Memorial Pow-Wow and Native Games, ending a coast-to-coast trek that began in Syracuse, N.Y., in memory of the famed athlete and Olympic medalist.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: ARMY'S USING GOATS TO TRIM FT. DIX GRASS
description: A platoon of Army goats is performing special duty at this military training post, where officials hope to save $2,500 a year by turning loose hungry nannies, billies and their kids to mow a 20-acre tract.

title: G.O.P. REACTION: BIG DEAL

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: UNTIL Interstates 78 and 287 brought a boom in corporate construction to the woodlands of western Somerset County, Franklin Township was for decades a collection of quaint and quiet hamlets in the countryside.

description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Benson To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Elizabeth W. Benson and Thomas J. Tomai has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Benson of Woodbury, Conn. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Tomai Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: PERIL IS SEEN FOR BABIES WHOSE MOTHERS ATE FISH WITH PCB'S
description: The infants of women who ate Lake Michigan fish contaminated with PCB's show subtle, ''worrisome'' signs of problems in their behavioral development such as sluggish emotional responses, a new study indicates.

title: VOICES FROM THE LEFT
description: Irving Howe and Michael Harrington have nothing new to say. They have old answers to out-of-date problems, government subsidization of industry and worker control of economic life.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: -VIEWING JUNKET

title: DEBORAH L. MORGAN MARRIES REV. TIMOTHY STEEVES
description: Deborah Lou Morgan, a daughter of Col. D. P. Morgan Jr., U.S.A.F. retired, and Mrs. Morgan of Pensacola, Fla., was married yesterday to the Rev. Timothy Lister Steeves, a son of Mrs. Frederick Earl Steeves of Frederick, Md., and the late Mr. Steeves.

title: No Headline
description: Malcolm Muir Jr., 68, Ex-Editor

title: Hara Brown Engaged To Kenneth F. Durkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Brown of Edison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hara Sidel Brown, to Kenneth Francis Durkin of New York, the son of Muriel Durkin and the late Kenneth F. Durkin of Valley Stream, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: ISRAEL VOTES AND THEN THE BARGAINING STARTS
description: Israel's 2.65 million voters will elect a new Parliament tomorrow but putting a Government together may take weeks.

title: IN QUEENS, REP. FERRARO PICKS UP GROCERIES, HUGS AND STARES
description: For Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, shopping in Queens yesterday was a little different from other Saturdays.

title: ROME AUGUS-KEEPING COOL

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The United States Army cannot be sustained in combat for any extended period of time.''

title: CONCERT: ALICIA DE LARROCHA AND MOSTLY MOZART
description: Alicia de Larrocha came to Avery Fisher Hall Friday night, played a Mozart concerto, won protracted bravas, and though ever so modest and unassertive, eclipsed everything else on the Mostly Mozart program. So what else is new?

title: QUARRELING WITH REDEMPTION
description: Stephen Koch, who teaches at Princeton University, is the author of ''Night Watch,'' a novel, and ''Stargazer: Andy Warhol's World.'' FLOATERS

title: Elizabeth Slaymaker Wed To D. H. Steckler, Teacher
description: Elizabeth Duncan Slaymaker, a daughter of Samuel R. Slaymaker of Gap, Pa., and Elizabeth S. Slaymaker of London, was married yesterday to Donald Harold Steckler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Steckler Jr. of Purchase, N.Y., and Wilmington, Vt. The Rev. Samuel A. Huffard, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: FINGER-POINTING ON PLIGHT OF HOMELESS
description: It is not often that anyone suggests similarities between Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo. The excitable, often belligerent bachelor Mayor and the philosophical, lawyerly family-man Governor have been in the public spotlight long enough so that even the casual observer knows that, excepting a passion for politics and writing books, they have little in common.

title: Search for an Owner
description: The United States Football League and officials of the Los Angeles Express are looking for a buyer for the California team, but the team's nominal owner, J. William Oldenburg , is not taking part in the search. Oldenburg, a former vacuum cleaner salesman who has called himself a ''self- made billionaire,'' is in a financial bind and the league has stepped in to help find a new owner.

title: EXPANDING MONDALE'S TIGHT CIRCLE OF ADVISERS
description: In the buoyant aftermath of the Democratic convention, Robert G. Beckel, Walter F. Mondale's campaign manager, said on Friday morning that the campaign organization would seek ''the best talent'' in the country to work for the Mondale-Ferraro ticket.

title: Banker Is Fiance Of Miss Zambetti
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank X. Zambetti of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Zambetti, to Scott Spence Davis, a son of Geraldine Spence Davis of Pasadena, Calif., and Robert Ross Davis of South Laguna, Calif. The wedding is planned for Sept. 8.

title: JUDGES LEARN THE VALUES OF VIDEOTAPE
description: If a picture is worth a thousand words, videotape may be worth considerably more.

title: Pamela S. Leslie Plans A September Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard K. Reiss of Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Pamela S. Leslie, to Blair M. Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Bedford Johnson of New York and Weston, Vt.

title: POINTS WEST AND SOUTH
description: Paul Breslin is a poet who teaches English at Northwestern University. NOTES FROM A CHILD OF PARADISE

title: HEADLINERS;
description: The Trail Ends Alton Coleman was suspected of an interstate trail of such grisly crimes that he was recently made the 11th person on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 Most Wanted List. Last week, the list went back to 10. Mr. Coleman, accused of a monthlong spree of murder, rape and kidnapping in six states, was quietly captured in Evanston, Ill. Mr. Coleman, an Illinois native who had fled authorities in June while awaiting trial on charges he attacked a 14-year-old girl, was suspected of subsequent crimes in Wisconsin, Michigan, Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky. Though he and a companion, Debra Brown, were both armed when captured, they offered no resistance.

title: John Holden to Marry Miss Jones on Sept. 29
description: Lanah Lee Jones, the West Coast advertising manager for Ms. magazine, and John S. Holden, a district manager for Business Week magazine, both in Los Angeles, plan to be married Sept. 29, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Lee Jones, of New Canaan, Conn., have announced.

title: A BRAHMS CURIOSITY WILL HAVE ITS DAY
description: A Mass by Johannes Brahms that was discovered recently will be given its American premiere on Aug. 3 by the Cambridge Chamber Choir under the direction of Daniel Melamed at the Harvard-Epworth Church in Cambridge, Mass. Composed around 1856, the Mass consists of a Kyrie, a Sanctus, a Benedictus and an Agnus Dei, and lasts about 15 minutes. The Kyrie is accompanied by organ; the remainder of the work is unaccompanied.

title: Julia O'Neill to Marry Joel E. Bradford
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Sill Burt of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Burt's daughter Julia Kay O'Neill to Joel Everett Bradford, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lester Ezra Bradford of Khartoum, the Sudan. A September wedding is planned.

title: PRINCE CREATES A WINNER WITH 'PURPLE RAIN'
description: While the Jacksons and Bruce Springsteen were busy last spring, putting finishing touches on their new albums and arranging summer tours, the Minneapolis rocker known as Prince was making a few arrangements of his own, Just when the Jacksons' tour was beginning, and attracting near-saturation media attention, Prince's new single, ''When Doves Cry,'' went straight to Number One on the pop charts. And while the Jacksons and Springsteen albums, fueled by their summer shows, will certainly be big sellers, Prince may well top them both. His new album, ''Purple Rain'' (Warner Bros.), sold approximately 1.5 million copies its first week in the stores and is presently giving the Jacksons and Springsteen albums a run for their money. And while Prince has not announced a summer tour, his first film, also called ''Purple Rain,'' has received some exceptional advance reviews and will open in more than 700 theaters, including four in Manhattan, on Friday.

title: WORKPLACE LAW FACING CHALLENGE
description: ANATIONAL trade association of 400 chemical companies is planning a suit to block the implementation later this summer of New Jersey's strict new law designed to protect workers and community residents from exposure to hazardous chemicals and other dangerous substances.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
NOW, A MESSAGE FROM...
description: THERE are two reasons for me not to say how many years I have driven the Long Island Expressway. One is that it would be a clue to my age, which is none of your business; the other is that it would indicate a masochistic tendency that could destroy my image. But from what I see, times are changing on the old L.I.E.

title: DANCE
description: Dance lovers wishing to combine a trip to the ballet with a trip to the country can see two companies this week in attractive summer festival settings.

title: THE MAN AT THE CENTER OF IT ALL
description: PETER VICTOR UEBERROTH was born on Sept. 2, 1937, and to the 46- year-old president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, the date has more than routine significance.

title: Lofty Rails
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER GRAPHICS ENLIVEN THE SCREEN
description: This Friday, ABC Sports will begin 180 hours of television coverage of the Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles. A lot of what viewers will see during that time - that is, when sprinters aren't sprinting, hurdlers aren't hurdling and someone isn't selling beer or radial tires - will be ''graphics,'' a vast array of colorful visual images ranging from the familiar, five-ring Olympic logo (with the letters ABC intertwined) to animated diagrams of the 400-meter medley event in swimming.

title: LEARNING WHO'S MASTER
description: THE graduates sit tall as the ceremony begins. Course work is complete. Exams have been passed. Proud families bask in reflected success. And now the names are being called: ''Sparky, Muffin, Prince, Boots . . .''

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR The Parkway Needs Repair
description: Your article on the Merritt Parkway (''The Merritt Turns a Graceful 50,'' July 1) was inaccurate because of its omissions about the current status of the Merritt. Your writer should have written about the deplorable conditions and the need for resurfacing and drainage repair.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: GREAT CANOE RACES

title: HOW THE IVORY COAST PICKED ITSELF OFF THE CANVAS
description: To those who know Africa, the symptoms that the Ivory Coast was showing looked depressingly familiar.

title: ISRAEL SHUTS ROAD TO SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israel has closed the only access road connecting occupied southern Lebanon with the rest of the country. Officials said the crossing would be blocked until next Wednesday.

title: CABLE TV
description: The San Francisco Opera's production of ''A"ida'' by Giuseppe Verdi continues its current run on the Arts and Entertainment Network this Wednesday and Thursday. Wednesday's presentations are at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M.; Thursday's is scheduled at noon. The performance was videotaped for television in 1981.

title: Botswana Expected to Pick New Parliament Later in Year
description: President Quett K. Masire of Botswana dissolved Parliament Friday to pave the way for the country's fifth general elections, expected later this year, the Botswana radio reported.

title: OPERA RARITIES: FROM MINOR VERDI TOA FRANCH 'HAMLET'
description: Back in the 60's, when the critic Andrew Porter wanted to advance the then rather novel argument that there were no dull works among Verdi's forgotten operas, he was obliged to make one qualification. ''I own that I have heard only excerpts from 'Alzira,' he wrote; ''they are not dull.''

title: HOMINY MEXICAN-STYLE
description: -standing specialty foods in this nation about which the general public knows remarkably little. One of the best of them, to my taste at least, is whole hominy, which is available in several forms - dried and packaged in plastic and ''wet'' to be purchased in cans.

title: Crackdown on Rowdy Fans
description: Football fans who become rowdy or cause disruptions during games at Giants Stadium could lose their season tickets under a new policy approved by the professional sports franchises using the stadium.

title: No Headline
description: Cyanide Powder Spills, Closing I-55 for Hours

title: TWO WORLDS, A FLOOR APART, IN HOSPITAL TALKS
description: In the Roosevelt Hotel's elevators these days, when someone from the striking hospital workers union gets on with someone from hospital management, there are tight smiles and comments about the weather or the Yankees, but the conversation quickly flags.

title: RYTHMS OF TIDES AND LIFE
description: BY this time of the year, the Sound is crowded with boats. From the kitchen I can see into the marina, and the masts that seem to sprout up from nowhere look like empty flagpoles outlined against the sky. Every summer it's the same. Even at night, churning motors interrupt the natural rhythm of the tide against the sea wall to remind me of their presence. I'm not so sure I like it.

title: MISS TOMLINSON IS MARRIED ON L.I. TO W.G. MORAN
description: Deborah Kay Tomlinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander C. Tomlinson of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to William Gerard Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Moran of East Meadow, L.I. The Rev. T. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., assisted by the Rev. Frederick Schaefer, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
EGALITARIANISM AND THE POOL
description: OUR town has a municipal pool. Like many of its ilk, it is a quasi-lake of questionable origin, said by numerous 8-year-olds to be inhabited by dreadful denizens of the deep. Its circular shores veer between sand and grass, and beyond the encircling fence is a playground where children routinely sneak away, leaving frantic mothers to call languid lifeguards into action.

title: Elizabeth Taylor Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar R. Taylor of Valley Stream, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Taylor, to Keith Evan Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Charles Rosen of Rosedale, Queens. An October wedding is planned.

title: U.S. FORCES FOUND TO LACK READINESS TO FIGHT RUSSIANS
description: A comprehensive Congressional survey has concluded that the military's readiness to fight is declining and that American forces could not sustain combat against the Soviet Union or many lesser powers.

title: SOUR NOTES AT THREE CARRIERS
description: Starting about nine months

title: Miss Walker Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Christina Tilghman Walker to Richard Paxton Burks has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mary Paxton Burks of Chicago and Dr. James L. Burks of Kansas City, Mo.

title: THE QUADRENNIAL SPECTACULAR
description: LOS ANGELES OS ANGELES and environs, which have given us Disneyland, Hollywood, Rodeo Drive, the transplanted Dodgers and a right turn on red, are about to present the greatest show ever on this part of earth - the Games of the XXIII Olympiad. For 16 days, starting Saturday, more than 8,000 athletes from 141 nations will offer a sporting festival that will be seen on worldwide television by an audience estimated at more than 2 billion. They will compete in 27 sports, including 2 demonstration sports - baseball and tennis. All those figures are records for this quadrennial spectacular.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HISTORIC VILLAGE BOON TO BROWSER
description: NORTH BRANCH SMALL historic villages, many of them off bustling highways, abound in New Jersey. For example, a few minutes off Route 22 is this quiet Somerset County community on the banks of the Raritan River.

title: Officer, Forced to Quit,Gets New Job With City
description: A former policewoman, forced to resign after marrying another officer, has been hired as the Mayor's secretary.

title: UTILITY PLANS TO LIFT THE LID AT 3-MILE ISLAND
description: Critics of nuclear power generally raised neither eyebrows nor protests last week when they learned that the owner of Three Mile Island nuclear plant is initiating the most important step in its cleanup effort. Removing the top of the facility's damaged Unit 2 reactor vessel - an operation scheduled to start Tuesday - will provide access to the radioactive debris inside.

title: REAGANS MAN IN HONDURAS IS HEARING SOME BACK TALK
description: While American envoys have come and gone in the turbulent Central American countries of Nicaragua and El Salvador, John D. Negroponte has maintained a tight grip on his position as Ambassador to Honduras. Associates say he has brilliantly executed Reagan Administration policy in one of the region's poorest countries. Recently, however, the Hondurans have started to question their close ties with the United States. Mr. Negroponte has come under attack from Honduran officials upset by accusations that they have been lackeys of Washington.

NEW JERSEY OPINION;

title: PACT TO END BRITISH DOCK STRIKE RATIFIED
description: Leaders of the dockworkers' union approved an agreement with port employers today, officially ending a 10-day strike that had paralyzed most of Britain's trade.

title: THE GUN COLLECTOR
description: According to his neighbors and co-workers, James Oliver Huberty didn't like children, Mexicans or the United States. One of the few things he did like was his gun collection.

description: To the Editor:

title: LEISURE BOATING PROVING POPULAR
description: RED BANK

title:
DINING OUT;
GLEN ISLAND: NAUTICAL AND NOSTALGIC
description: A CURMUDGEON dining companion is fond of saying that what people pay for in restaurants is not so much the food but the fantasy. If that's true, The Restaurant at Glen Island is a bargain. For those who knew Glen Island Casino as a showcase for the big bands in their heyday, the refurnished original building will evoke that pleasurable sense of recovered loss. For younger visitors, the great atavistic draw of the surrounding scene will release tides of memory enough - the stuff of fantasy.

title: Irena Ferris, Actress, Marries Harris L. Katleman
description: Harris L. Katleman, president and chief executive officer of 20th Century-Fox Television, and Irena Ferris, an actress, were married yesterday at their home in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Will Kramer performed the ceremony.

title: COURT FINDS THAT SKATEBOARDER IS ENTITLED TO SMOOTH STREETS
description: New York City may be making headway in its campaign to rid itself of potholes. But a state appellate court ruled recently that the city must still worry about cracks, dips, bumps and anything else in its streets that can upend a skateboard.

title: YANKEE ATOM PLANT LEADS IN DURABILITY
description: THE communications links between the Connecticut Yankee nuclear plant in East Haddam and the Governor in Hartford are designed to carry bad news northward. Last week, however, it was good news going south.

title: TOPIC
description: One recent day, I returned to the town on the North Fork where my mother and I were born. I went alone, for there are some memories you just must explore that way. I stopped at the cemetery where my parents and a baby brother lie, within the sight of farm horses grazing on a slope, and the sounds of cardinal- pairs keeping in touch tree to tree. A little pruning around the headstones gives a feeling of caring for their silent treasures underneath. A well-spigot stands rusting and dry; a 12-year-old girl once quenched her thirst there on hot days after a bike ride to lie beside her mother's grave in sweet clover grass.

title: SHAKESPEARE WITH A TOUCH OF COMMEDIA DELL'ARTE
description: The theater is rocked by a violent thunderclap. First, there is utter darkness. Next, in the distance is seen the silhouette of a storm- tossed ship. Draped in billowing blue cloth, the stage has become a wind- lashed sea. Flashes of lightning show the ship coming closer. The effect is both cinematic and operatic. Suddenly, a tall mast rises at center stage, surrounded by struggling sailors. Once again, there is total darkness. It is as though the planet had been engulfed by a tidal wave.

description: July 28 OPENING CEREMONIES: 7 P.M. July 29 BASKETBALL /MEN/GROUP A: Italy vs. Egypt, noon.Yugoslavia vs. W. Germany, 5:30 P.M.Australia vs. Brazil, 11:30 P.M. GROUP B: Uruguay vs. France, 2 P.M. U.S. vs. China, 7:30 P.M. Spain vs. Canada, 1 A.M. BOXING: 2-5 P.M. and 9 P.M.-12:30 A.M.

title: RIVER RAFT RACE A TEST OF INGENUITY
description: STRANGE craft have recently been pushing off from the shores of Connecticut River. Some are propelled by bicycle-driven paddle wheels. Others are moved by oars or handmade sails.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN THE sign reads ''No Dogs Allowed in Park,'' but no dogs can read, and Silver Lake Park was on Hansel's and my morning inventory long before the sign went up. He is an old dog now, like his master, and we both need exercise. The fact that I carry a garden trowel and a Friendly Ice Cream bag along seems to help, if we do encounter a park attendant.

title: EFFECT OF FLORIDA FREEZE ON CITRUS CALLED DRASTIC
description: This is the time of year when citrus trees in Florida normally sprout their new growth and a colorful landscape of blossoms and leaves portends a plentiful fall harvest.

title: COPING WITH RETURN OF RETIREES
description: THE return of the elderly from Florida has been described as a countertrend - a reverse flow of the retirees who 15 or 20 years ago left to settle in a warmer climate. Its impact has been noted in a number of northern states, and its effects are also being felt now in the county. These retirees are now part of the population called the ''old old'' - individuals in their 80's or 90's who are often alone, frail and without a family support system in their retirement community.

title: Yankees Lose to Twins By 5-2
description: The rain that fell early and often during the Yankees' game with Minnesota yesterday did nothing to water down Kent Hrbek's impressive seasonlong performance against the Yankees.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BAGWORM IS A VORACIOUS DESTROYER
description: IT is not uncommon at this time

title: THE NATURE OF NATURE WRITING
description: NATURE writing is a historically recent literary genre, and, in a quiet way, one of the most revolutionary. It's like a woodland stream that sometimes runs out of sight, buried in sand, but overflows into waterfalls farther downstream. It can be easy to ignore, but it keeps eroding the bedrock.

title: 'SECRET' TAX PLAN IS LAID TO REAGAN
description: Walter F. Mondale accused President Reagan today of having a ''secret plan'' to increase taxes if re-elected.

title: Democrats, Democrats and Plutocrats Two words echoed from the San Francisco convention last week: fairness and values. And what they mean this election year is that the Democrats want both their parties back.
description: George Wallace had sent up warnings as long ago as 1972. ''Once the Democratic Party reflected true expressions of the rank-and-file citizens,'' he wrote. ''They were its heart, the bulk of its strength and vitality.'' But then it ''became the party of the so-called intelligentsia and lost contact with the working man and the businessman.''

description: The Food Lover's Guide to Paris

title: POLITICAL FORTUNE COULD DEPEND ON FED
description: M1 is the measure of the money supply that the Federal Reserve uses to keep track of all the cash in people's pockets and all the deposists in checking accounts. By fine-tuning M1, the Fed can try to bring interest rates up or lower them.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
TRADING HOUSES CREATES GOOD WILL
description: AS nearly as my wife and I can figure it, we must have been writing to the Thompsons at the same time they were writing to us on a fine Sunday evening this spring - they from our home in northern Westchester, and we in their home on the edge of England's New Forest in Hampshire that William the Conqueror had appropriated as his own private hunting grounds nearly 900 years ago.

title: THERAPY WITH PETS GAINS IN STATE
description: GESCUED from the Bergen County Animal Shelter, where she faced almost certain death, Blondie was chosen to be the subject of an eight- week experiment involving elderly psychiatric patients.

title: CZECH REACHES SEMIFINAL
description: Unseeded Pavel Slozel gained the semifinals with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over John Alexander before rain halted play in the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships today.

title: RETURNING TO A BELOVED ISLAND
description: There are many places to which I return with pleasure again and again, but none more dripping with remembrance and nostalgia than the island of Martha's Vineyard: seven miles from the mainland of Cape Cod, a million miles from the world in which I do my work. For the island is now my home. Someone once said, ''Home is where you keep your scrapbooks.'' Mine are on Cottage Street in Edgartown.

title: HERSHEY BITES OFF NEW MARKETS
description: HERSHEY, PA.

title: Van Pelt Still Unhappy
description: Brad Van Pelt , the 33-year-old former Giant linebacker who was traded to the Minnesota Vikings last week, has told the Vikings he has no intention of reporting to the team and wants to be traded to another club, preferably one in California or Florida. Van Pelt had made the same request of the Giants, who ignored the request and sent him to Minnesota in exchange for Tony Galbreath , a 30- year-old fullback. The Giants would not discuss the provisions of the trade yesterday, but if Van Pelt does not report to the Vikings, the Giants will presumably have to come up with something else, perhaps a draft choice, to compensate the Vikings for Galbreath.

title: NEW JOB PROGRAM AIDS TRAINEES, BUT SOME SAY THE MORE ABLE BENEFIT MOST
description: Pamela Simmons, who is 26 years old and rearing a 6-year-old son alone, got off welfare last month for the first time in four years. She went to work for $4 an hour as a clerk and bookkeeper at MGM Farms, a dairy in New Bedford, Mass.

title: CRIME
description: There are some rather entrancing types in SLATE by Nathan Aldyne (Villard, $12.95). Take Susie. She is the recording secretary of PUMA - the Prostitutes Union of Massachusetts. She takes her calling and her secretarial responsibilities seriously. She resents being called a hooker and insists on being called a prostitute. As an officer of PUMA, she explains, ''I wouldn't be doing my sworn duty if I didn't stand up for the semantics clause in our constitution.''

title: ELDERLY TEACH YOUNG TO SWIM
description: -haired and smiling, was gently pulling a skinny 7-year-old nonswimmer by her outstretched hands across a spacious Sprain Ridge swimming pool in Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: Chemicals From Derailment
description: A crew from Los Angeles trained in handling hazardous chemicals was called here to help clean up after the derailment of seven Southern Pacific Railway cars early today. A railway spokesman said three cars turned over because of mechanical failure.

title: THE GAMES, SPORT BY SPORT
description: Archery The bow-and-arrow heroics of Robin Hood and Errol Flynn excited a generation of Americans. The bow-and-arrow heroics of Olympic archery are something else.

title: KERTESZ: THE GREAT DEMOCRAT OF MODERN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: 20th century that is nothing but a chronicle of disasters. Indeed, the life work of several distinguished

title: LETTERS
description: AMERICAN SALESMEN ARE NO BUNCH OF LIARS

title: FUGITIVE SURRENDERS TO FACE CHARGES IN KILLING OF 3 IN BONANNO MOB
description: A defendant who was missing for more than two years has surrendered to face racketeering charges that involve the killing of three leaders of the Bonanno crime organization.

title: LETTERS
description: PARADOXICAL ASSAULT ON ABORTIONS ABROAD

title: Anne C. Becker Plans A September Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Valentine Becker of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Campbell Becker, to Gregory John O'Connell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph O'Connell of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: TALKING WITH CUBA
description: The talks between United States and Cuban officials on immigration questions and the possible return to Cuba of some of the ''Mariel excludables'' - Cubans who came to the United States in the large-scale exodus from Port Mariel in early 1980 with criminal or medical records that made them ineligible for entry - were brief and apparently unsuccessful. Nor did they suggest any lasting improvement in relations between the two countries. But that can change if and when both sides realize that it is in their interest to reach a compromise on the fundamental issues dividing them.

title: BANKRUPTCY OF AIR FLORIDAFELT AT AIRPORT

title: Susan Louise De Laney, a U.S. Aide, To Marry Henry Morgan on Sept. 22
description: The engagement of Susan Louise De Laney of Alexandria, Va., to Henry Morgan of Essex, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roger De Laney of Lloyd Neck, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Rear Adm.

title:
LEISURE;
THE SHOWY DAYLILY: A PERFECT PERENNIAL RETAINS ITS POPULARITY
description: Dayliliesylilies are more popular now than ever before. Wonderful plants for the low maintenance garden, they are used in greater numbers in America's landscapes to provide color for foundation plantings, patio gardens and around pools. Nothing could be more pleasing than a spectacular spread of daylilies along a driveway, at an entrance or along a bright woodland path.

title: MOSQUITO INFLUX HAS ITS STING
description: COME the summer, and mosquitoes, as always, are the talk of Long Island. This season that talk has intensified as stagnant waters left by record spring and early summer rains spawned prime breeding grounds for mosquito larvae, particularly in the 90,000 acres of marshes and swamps in Suffolk County.

title: UNDERSTANDING FICTION
description: Robert M. Adams , the author of ''The Land and Literature of England'' and other books, is collaborating on a new edition of Thomas More's ''Utopia.'' READING FOR THE PLOT

description: To the Editor:

ANTIQUES ;
GLSS REGAINS ITS POPULARITY
