title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: OF course, it was just a coincidence. But about the time Walter F. Mondale was naming Geraldine A. Ferraro as his Vice Presidential running mate, Joseph M. Caverly , Commissioner of the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, was naming Mary Davis of Rye as the first female County Naturalist.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Connecticut Nature Conservancy's Board of Trustees has voted to proceed with the purchase of a $1.1 million island off the coast of Norwalk, even though it does not have the money yet.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM FRED ASTAIRE TO CHARLIE BROWN;  Fred Astaire: Change Partners and Dance (Vol. II)
description: RKO Homevideo 60 minutes. $39.95

title: IT'S OFTEN A BANNER DAY FOR SOME PILOTS
description: LOWER TOWNSHIP BEHIND the giant hangar doors, Colleen Pettit, a high school junior, was separating five-foot-high letters and hanging them one by one on a rack.

title: FEWER GRANTS FOR STUDENTS IN PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: Federal and state grants for students at independent colleges and universities have not kept up with inflation in the last two years, according to a study by the American Council on Education.

title: 'THE HILLS' BUYERS: A WIDE MIX
description: IN the historic hills of Somerset County, a private developer is building a new community that is among the first in New Jersey where the Mount Laurel zoning decisions are doing what they were intended to do - produce housing for people who cannot afford market prices.

title: GIRLS TRAIN TO JOIN FRESH AIR CAMP STAFF
description: Sheasaray Carr did not say very much when she first arrived at Camp Anita Bliss Coler.

title: CUOMO PRAISES BROADCASTERS
description: THE day after delivering his impassioned keynote speech before the 39th Democratic National Convention in San Francisco, Governor Cuomo paid an unannounced visit to the county last week.

title: Crew Is Taken Off Freighter On Fire in the Caribbean Sea
description: A cruise ship rescued six crew members from a burning 100-foot freighter Friday after they sent a radio message to a passing aircraft that their vessel was ''engulfed in flames,'' the Coast Guard said.

title: U.S. PROSECUTORS PLAY A TAPE AT BEATTY TRIAL
description: In December 1982, Vander L. Beatty, a State Senator from Brooklyn, and J. Moise Michel, executive director of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Urban Development Corporation, met in a Brooklyn restaurant to discuss serious problems that the nonprofit corporation was facing.

title: HEADLINERS ; The Wrong Gang Seventeen-year-old
description: John Sperrazza suffered a lot more terror than he dished out last spring when Federal agents took him and three friends for members of a militant Jewish organization suspected of planning to attack a Soviet diplomatic residence on Long Island.

title: WATSON TIES FOR LEAD ON A 66
description: Tom Watson made the big move that many had expected in the third round of the British Open today, tying for the lead in his quest for a record- equaling sixth title.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: Cart Michigan 500, at Brooklyn, Mich. Mario Andretti won the pole position with a qualifying time of 211.088 miles per hour for this second leg of the Cart/Indy Car 500-mile Triple Crown. The second qualifier was Tom Sneva (211.051) followed by Bobby Rahal (208.714), who will be driving with a minicamera in his car to help viewers get a better perspective.(Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.)

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: BANKRUPTCY: WHAT IT MIGHT MEAN TO LILCO
description: WHEN the Long Island Lighting Company talks about its future these days, it uses phrases like ''remaining viable'' and ''returning to financial stability,'' polite terms for staying out of bankruptcy. But as the company comes closer and closer to payment deadlines for bills it cannot meet, bankruptcy seems more likely, raising questions about what such an event would mean to customers, employees, executives and shareholders. The timing of a declaration of bankruptcy depends on how much more credit Lilco can obtain from its bankers. Unless the company can demonstrate that Shoreham is virtually certain to operate - an event that would almost assure the company of long-term health - then new loans may only postpone insolvency, with Lilco facing mounting bills in coming months. In recognition of the problem, Moody's Investors Service last week cut the rating of the company's mortgage bonds another two notches.

title: Fall Wedding Set By Wendy Jeffery
description: Mrs. Carleton Jeffery of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Scott Jeffery to Peter B. Hubbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Hubbell of Woodbridge, Conn. A fall wedding is planned.

title: NEW GUATEMALA ARCHBISHOP KEEPS MILITARY AT A DISTANCE
description: Roman Catholic Church officials say that under the leadership of its outspoken new Archbishop, the church in Guatemala has moved away from its traditional support of military governments and asserted the need for major social and political changes.

title: ADJUSTING THE CAPITAL-GAINS TAX
description: CHANGES by the State Legislature in many of the details of the state's capital-gains tax on large real-estate transfers will make the law easier to live with, industry representatives say. But these spokesmen expressed disappointment that they failed to win a key objective, an exemption for new construction.

title: NEW GOLF COURSE IS READY
description: THE sign on the entrance gate read ''Course closed.'' And indeed, the clubhouse area of the Tournament Players Club in Cromwell resembled a construction site approaching the deadline for completion.

title: DANCE: THE AILEY TROUPE IN TWO COMPANION PIECES
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed two of the most exciting dances in its repertory on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Presented back to back, they are provocative companion pieces.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
MORE COVERAGE FOR OLYMPICS FANS
description: For most cable TV networks, the 1984 Summer Olympics, which begin next Saturday and will continue until Sunday, Aug. 12, constitute an endurance contest. The challenge is simply to wait until the Games are over and those viewers who have defected to ABC, which owns the exclusive telecast rights, return.

title: DEMOCRATS' PLATFORM SHOWS A SHIFT FROM LIBERAL POSITIONS OF 1976 AND 1980
description: The Democratic Party has moved away from some hallmarks of its tradition of liberalism in the eight years since Walter F. Mondale's first national campaign.

title: No Headline
description: Mariners 9, Blue Jays 3

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: SPACE SHUTTLE MOVIE, LOUISIANA REVELRY
description: NASA's Hail Columbia' Opens in Florida In the movie business the word colossal sometimes means something less than terrific. But in the case of ''Hail Columbia!'' a new movie playing in Florida in a new theater at the NASA Kennedy Space Center's visitors center - known as Spaceport USA - the word seems merited.

title: ARISTOTLE AND JOLSON
description: To the Editor:

title: HONG KONG AS TERRITRIAL IMPERATIVE
description: China's leader, Deng Xiaoping, has made a show of withdrawing into semiretirement and leaving the affairs of state and party to his proteges, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang and party General Secretary Hu Yaobang. But Mr. Deng, who is 80 years old, has shown no inhibitions lately about rebounding into the limelight when the issue of Hong Kong's future arises.

title: ANOTHER CRISIS ENGULFS THE THRIFTS
description: The nation's savings industry, still reeling from

title: Stabler Holds On
description: He is facing strong challenges from Richard Todd and Dave Wilson , but Ken Stabler says he is going to fight to hold onto his job as the New Orleans Saints' starting quarterback this season, a season, he says, that may be his last. ''It's just something inside says it's time,'' said Stabler, who did not inform Coach Bum Phillips of his decision.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Week in Review on July 15 incorrectly described the positions of Supreme Court Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr. and John Paul Stevens in a case involving the right to travel to Cuba. Justice Stevens agreed with the majority that travel could be limited by the Administration. Justice Powell dissented.

title: Uruguay Grants Asylum To 3 Sought in Bolivia
description: Uruguay has granted asylum to three Bolivian lawyers sheltered in its embassy in La Paz since a coup attempt last month against President Hernan Siles Zuazo of Bolivia, Foreign Minister Carlos Maeso Rodriguez said.

title: ARMED TO THE TEETH, TIRED TO THE BONE
description: ''If Iraq should lose this war,'' a Western diplomat was saying about the nearly four-year- old conflict with Iran, ''it won't be for lack of weapons.'' Lounging behind sandbagged fortifications in the marshlands where the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers join to become the Shatt al-Arab, the Iraqi Army has assembled a massive amount of military hardware.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Barber at Carlyle
description: In 1931, Joseph Miceli opened a barbershop at the Carlyle Hotel on Madison Avenue. For 52 years, he cut the hair of the rich and the famous.

title: CONTINENTAL RESCUE IS ON THE HORIZON
description: Continental Rescue. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's plan to take over about 80 percent of the Continental Illinois National Bank is a dramatic and somewhat drastic step. Under the rescue plan, as outlined by those close to the situation, the F.D.I.C. would assume Continental's problem loans and would allow the rest of Continental to operate as a ''clean'' bank, with a new head to be selected by the F.D.I.C., but with little stockholder equity.

title: NEW BANS IMPOSED ON FLOATING HOMES
description: WARY that restrictions being placed on houseboats ''up-Island'' will force a flotilla of displaced floating homes into East End creeks and bays, the five towns at the Island's end are acting to block an easterly migration before it starts.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER:GUIDE TO RENTING A CAR IN EUROPE
description: Europe is noted for efficient intercity mass transportation, yet many travelers prefer to drive while touring. For them the flexibility that a car affords justifies its cost, which can be considerable when taxes, insurance and fuel charges are added to the rental.

title: FIREHOUSE'S REBIRTH
description: Sometime next year a vacant 60- year-old firehouse in downtown Jamaica, Queens, will be transformed into 18 lofts for qualified city artists.

title: THE SOVIETS ACKNOWLEDGE BALANCHINE'S PLACE IN BALLET
description: This year saw the first public staging of a complete ballet by George Balanchine by a Soviet company in the Soviet Union. Anyone familiar with past Soviet strictures against ''formalism'' in the arts - a charge that could be leveled at Balanchine's work from a Soviet viewpoint - will understand the milestone this event represents. Interestingly, it is the Georgian Ballet (in Tbilisi's Opera and Ballet Theater) that staged the work, which is none other than ''Serenade.'' In other words, this official recognition of Balanchine's place in ballet and, implicitly, of his esthetic, occurred in the land of his paternal ancestors.

title: GIFTS FROM THE HEAVENS; Wet Spell
description: By midsummer New York's trees and flowers have started losing their battle with the heat. But not in this year of the deluge.

title: Susan Camp Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Camp of Dallas have made known the engagement of their daughter Susan O'Hara Camp to Blair Whitney Carpenter, a son of Mr. and Mr. Kenneth R. Carpenter of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The wedding is to be in September.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW: A 'LA CAGE' OF SORTS ON THE BOARDWALK
description: ATLANTIC CITY NO, ''An Evening at La Cage,'' the revue at Bally's Park Place Hotel-Casino, is not a spinoff of the Tony Award-winning Broadway musical ''La Cage aux folles.''

title: DEMOCRATS PUT DIFFERENCES BEHIND
description: SAN FRANCISCO CONNECTICUT'S delegates to the Democratic National Convention, who came here divided, went home Friday seemingly unified and agreeing that Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro would be an asset to the Democratic national ticket in Connecticut.

title: MIXING BUSINESS WITH NONSENSE
description: Businessmen terrify me. I once almost took one for a drive. A friend had brought him to my house. The businessman was visiting from out of state and my friend thought it would do him good to see the countryside. My friend's car had flat tires, so he brought the businessman to me. ''Drive him around,'' my friend suggested.

title: FOUR 'DANCE-THEATER COLLAGES'
description: WHAT does one call Tom Keegan's collaborative creations? Mr. Keegan's own description is ''a multimedia amalgam of dancing and acting; movement integrated with music and dialogue.''

title: ATTICA INMATES END NIGHTLONG PROTEST OF SHOOTING
description: A nightlong protest by 182 inmates in an Attica prison yard over the shooting of an inmate by a tower guard ended just before dawn yesterday when the prisoners went back to their cells.

title: Charles Crawford Weds Anne Hamby
description: Anne Forrester Hamby, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Bruce M. Forrester of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Charles T. Crawford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Crawford of Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. John D. Twiname performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the bride's apartment in Manhattan.

title: A HOME IN THE COUNTY, A PLACE IN THE CITY
description: THE women resemble bag ladies, with their bundles of food and laundry, and the men tuck socks and underwear into their attache cases as they leave for the Monday morning train. They read the long-range weather forecasts avidly but, even so, are often dressed inappropriately. They are part of a small but growing coterie of Westchester residents with two residences - a Manhattan pied- a-terre for use during the week and a suburban house they call home.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NATIONAL COIN SHOW TO OPEN IN DETROIT
description: The 93rd anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association will open on Saturday in Detroit. It is claimed to be the world's largest coin show.

title: Miss Brown Is Engaged
description: Hilary Michaels Brown, a graphics designer, and Charles Hatch Read, a director of Eyecue Productions Inc., a graphics design and consulting company in Princeton, N.J., plan to be married Sept. 8.

title: AUTHOR ON RUNNING WAS 52
description: James F. Fixx, who spurred the jogging craze with his best-selling books about running and preached the gospel that active people live longer, died of a heart attack Friday while on a solitary jog in Vermont. He was 52 years old.

title: FURNITURE MAKER TURNS SCULPTOR
description: ON one wall of Thomas Luckey's workshop in Branford is a model of his latest project for a playground - a 30-foot, glass-enclosed turret with platforms that weave in and out of each other so that even if a child climbs to the top, a misstep will result in a fall of only a few feet.

title: A HOUSE DIVIDED AMONG THE TREETOPS
description: ALL TOO OFTEN, VACATION HOUSES are designed to function primarily as entertainment machines for summertime living, which means that during colder months, when guests are not as eager to visit, owners find themselves rattling around damp, empty rooms that are expensive and difficult to heat. Richard Dattner, a Manhattan-based architect, avoided this pitfall by building a house that is divided - with a guest wing incorporated into the main structure that can be sealed off and left unheated during the winter, thereby saving about half of what it would cost to heat the entire house. Sited in a wooded area on the eastern end of Long Island, the house is oriented on a north-south axis. The architect used several passive solar features to make it even more energy efficient.

title: THE RECORDER HAS ITS VIRTUOSOS, TOO
description: Whatever else one might say about musical life in the 20th century, it has been a time when virtuoso performers have found audiences for the most unlikely solo instruments. Over the last 60 years or so, champions of the guitar, flute, trumpet, French horn, clarinet and oboe have forged paths through a world dominated by pianists and violinists, and early instruments, frowned upon as obsolete less than a century ago, have been revived and mastered. Among these, perhaps the most unusual rebirth has been that of the recorder. A precursor of the flute, the recorder flourished until the 18th century, and then fell out of favor until around 1920, when a circle of British early instrument pioneers rediscovered it.

title: Union Potters
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A recent article on Cedarmere, the former William Cullen Bryant estate near Hempstead Harbor, gave its location incorrectly. It is in the Village of Roslyn Harbor.

title: SARITA LIMBOCKER MARRIED IN OHIO TO DAVID LEMAN
description: The marriage of Sarita Oglebay Limbocker, a daughter of Mrs. Norman Lea Hutchings Frith 2d of Gates Mills, Ohio, and John Limbocker Jr. of Mentor, Ohio, to David Andrew Leman of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club in Gates Mills. Mayor John S. Manuel of Gates Mills performed the ceremony.

title: THE COUNTY'S FARM MARKETS
description: EVERY Friday and Saturday, long before the sun begins to burn the dew off the fields, Knorbert Kohlmaier and his wife, Barbara, have harvested, iced and packed many of the 25 varieties of vegetables they grow on his father's farm in Hopewell Junction in Dutchess County. By full daylight, two trucks are loaded with fresh- picked vegetables and fruit, fresh- baked goods and home-prepared German-style pork and ham, ready for transport.

title: 2 HOTELS RISING ON ROUTE 10; 2 OTHERS FACE CONTROVERSY
description: AFTER several years of fruitless efforts by various developers, the area of Long Island that one hotel executive has termed part of ''the most exciting hotel market in the country'' has two definite hotel starts, controversial applications for two others and nearby construction for yet one more. If each of these development plans comes to completion, this area, which now has no lodging facilities, will have almost 1,500 available hotel rooms.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: RENAISSANCE FESTIVAL

title:
GARDENING;
THE BAGWORM IS A VORACIOUS DESTROYER
description: IT is not uncommon at this time

title: Defrocked Priest Sentenced For Stealing From His Parish
description: A former priest has been sentenced to three years in jail after his former bishop recommended a prison term for his theft of $31,000 in parish funds to buy a car, television and other personal items.

title: VOICES FROM THE LEFT
description: The conversation between Michael Harrington and Irving Howe was right on in terms of socioeconomic analysis. When I saw it, I thought how much we need the voices of liberals, radicals and socialists in times such as these.

title: ; THE DOMINELLI AFFAIR
description: These practitioners of our national pastime of optimism and greed evoke no sympathy from me.
The 1984 auto negotiations pose a

title: LETTERS ;
description: The Cost of Power

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
APPRAISAL OF QUALITY OF LIFE IN THE COUNTY MUST CONSIDER RISE IN THE NUMBER OF POOR CHLDREN
description: WE in Westchester have reason to be proud of our county. All of us who have chosen to live here, who came from other parts of the metropolitan area, other areas of the United States, from Europe and the Orient, have done so because we have heard much about the quality of life here.

title: MIDDLING MOVIES OFFER RELIEF FROM LASER DUELS
description: It could be just a coincidence, perhaps not, but it does

title: DOWN TO THE SHORE, IN ZEELAND
description: People who have lived in the state of New Jersey may know the expression: ''To go down the shore.'' The undertaking was once as rudimentary as the language used to describe it. One threw inner tubes, tennis rackets, swimming suits and a picnic lunch into the car and drove, not more than a few hours, to the ocean. In my recollection of it, the place arrived at was makeshift in its pre-McDonald's, sea-beaten, gray-clapboard wholesomeness. There was the water, there was the beach, there were motorboats bobbing at choppy docks. One played a little tennis, water-skied maybe, got sunburned and went home gritty with sand between the toes and itchy with saltwater on the face.

title: Abigail H. Debevoise Plans to Wed Sept. 29
description: Announcement has been made by Judge and Mrs. Dickinson R. Debevoise of Short Hills, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Abigail Huntington Debevoise to Gerard Francis Byrne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Byrne 3d, also of Short Hills.

title:
ART;
WINNERS' SHOW STRESSES ABSTRACTION
description: MOST of the Island's juried art exhibitions do not offer substantial cash prizes or purchase awards, but there may be other benefits. Those who received the jury's approval in this year's annual at the Islip Art Museum also found themselves eligible for two invitationals, the first of which is on view through next Sunday.

title: THAT MOMENT WHEN A DREAM TURNS INTO GOLDEN REALITY...
description: IT is a moment they all have been waiting for, one they surely will remember the rest of their lives. It was four years in the making, yet after all this time, it will end too soon, exciting but brief, like a roller- coaster ride. Some Olympians prefer not to think about this moment at all. That doesn't include Willie Banks, however. The ebullient triple jumper has been mentally rehearsing for his Olympic moment, choreographing the entire event. But then there is Steve Scott, the top American miler and 1,500-meter runner, a family man and homeowner who has studiously tried to avoid thinking about the Olympics, preferring to dwell on how his garden grows.

title: SOURCES ABOUND NW FOR THE FRESH HERBS OF SUMMERTIME
description: UNTIL recently, about the only source for fresh herbs more exotic than parsley and dill was a flourishing garden. Now, especially in summer, farm stands, greengrocers and supermarkets all have supplies of verdant, fragrant and flavorful fresh herbs. If you can grow them in your garden, so much the better because you can cut them on demand, but a patch of real estate is no longer a requirement.

title: LOS ANGELES
description: IN BOLD BLOCK LETTERS, THE SIGN outside the tiny cafe across from the Los Angeles City Hall proudly proclaimed its specialty: HOME OF THE KOSHER STYLE BURRITO. Behind the counter, Orlando Lucero, who had come to Los Angeles from a remote hamlet in rural Guatemala, slapped down a corn tortilla and, like an artist coloring a canvas, deftly covered it with chili, mustard, cheese, pickles and fat slices of pastrami. Then, folding it over like a thick wallet, he handed it to his customer, a policeman.

title: Voices From The Left
description: In ''Voices From the Left'' (June 17), Michael Harrington and Irving Howe make a very good case for introducing socialist reforms in our economy to gain greater efficiency as well as greater equality. However, no argument for socialism can be convincing unless it can explain why Socialist governments in France, Spain and Portugal have been encouraging private enterprise and emphasizing profits and competition, as well as explaining why Reaganomics has proved so successful in the last two years.

title: LETTERS
description: IN TAXATION, SIMPLICITY AND EQUITY DON'T MIX:

title: IN ARMONK, THE BRITISH ARE COMING
description: Westchester County's office development boom, which has been particularly strong along Interstate 684, has prompted a British- based real-estate development company to construct on speculation a 100,000-square-foot office building on King Street in Armonk.

title: WHY PRESIDENTS CAN BE OLD
description: Not surprisingly, the issue of age has been raised regarding the candidacy of Ronald Reagan. (If re-elected, he will be almost 74 when be begins his second term.) Some people have even suggested, often in the strongest terms, that President Reagan should not seek another term because he is too old. They are entitled to their view, but it is doubtful that many will agree with them.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
SAD VIEW FROM THE TRAIN
description: THE most difficult moments of the work day occur when the train speeds past a cemetery. As a college student making periodic trips to Manhattan, I had never noticed how many cemeteries are located on the route from New Haven to New York. Now, as I ride on the commuter train to the city, I will look up from my reading, confront one of the cemetries that line the railroad tracks and mumble to myself, ''What horrible places cemeteries are. What miserable places to spend eternity.''

title: Thailand and Laos Open Border Talks
description: Thailand and Laos opened talks today on a border dispute triggered by the occupation of three villages by Thai troops in a skirmish two months ago.

title: INDUSTRIAL PARK EXPANDS
description: NEW HAVEN

title: VEHICLE TAXATION STUDIED
description: A NEW law establishes a panel to examine the taxation of motor vehicles. But a survey by one local tax collector shows people like the present method.

title: Alexandra Beatty To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Beatty of Washington of the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Scrivener Beatty, to Bryan Roger Cannon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Cannon of Pendleton, Ore.

title: Dr. Carol Coram Wed to Lieut. Ashland Whitfield
description: Dr. Carol Ann Coram, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Jackson Coram of White Plains, was married yesterday to Lieut. Ashland O'Neal Whitfield, U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Whitfield of San Francisco.

title: LETTERS
description: DISCOURAGING WORDS

title: CHOREOGRAPHY ONICE COMES TO THE METROPOLITAN
description: ''All I have ever wanted to do is create an alternative,'' says John Curry, the Olympic champion whose triumph at the 1976 Winter Games announced figure skating's coming of age. The soft-spoken skating star, who leads his troupe of 18 skaters into the Metropolitan Opera House for an eight-performance engagement this week, explains, ''I've never wanted to destroy the big commercial ice shows. They have their place. But I want to show that skating can be more than that.''

title: THE SHATTERED SHOWCASE

title: IN SEARCH OF A POLICY FOR ARTS FUNDING
description: ''We're looking for a sales hook, right? This is a sales meeting.'' Thus did a plainspeaking participant express the spirit in which more than 50 managers of nonprofit arts institutions, performers and foundation executives came together a few weeks ago to define a public policy for funding the arts.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES ON CAMPUS
description: More than two months ago, a student reporter for The Dartmouth Review, a conservative off-campus newspaper, answered a classified ad to attend a Gay Students Association meeting and secretly recorded it. The Review published excerpts, which included unidentified people discussing their sexual experiences.

description: A Lagos high court has ordered Nigeria's national police chief to pay $13,000 to a Nigerian editor for unlawful detention, the News Agency of Nigeria reported today.

title: A SHORT PRIMER ON THE BASICS OF DIGITAL RECORDING
description: Traditionally,the distribution of knowledge has been even more narrowly channeled than the distribution of other forms of wealth. This still appears to be so in audio. Only 7 percent of the United States population has even the fuzziest notion about digital recording, a recent survey reveals, and more than 80 percent never heard of it.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: Perhaps the single most memorable image of the past theatrical season in New York was an old woman in a rocking chair. She sat there, her face yellow and crinkled above a stately black dress, and, so it seemed, gently swung and floated her way toward death.

title: Open Spaces
description: To the Editor:

title: LISTENING TO THE WOES OF THE VICTIMIZED
description: In the next week or so, two teen-age sisters - both victims of rape - are to go before a hearing officer of the New Jersey Parole Board to testify against their assailant. The rapist, who lived with the girls' mother, is up for parole after having served about one third of a seven-year prison sentence for the attacks. Before the parole board rules, it wants to determine the feelings of the two victims and weigh them against the merits of the rapist's argument that he is fit to be released from prison.

title: Plaudit Deserved
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstate Wedding For Miss Forcey
description: Blythe Forcey, the daughter of Pamela Cottier Forcey of New York and Charles Budd Forcey of Nichols, N.Y., was married yesterday to William John Fitzhenry 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzhenry Jr. of Buffalo. Justice of the Peace Deborah Kislonski performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: AN URBAN LANDLORD'S PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS
description: RUBIN MARGULES enjoys his work. But in public he is reticent about what he does for a living, especially since 1980, when he ran in a primary for the State Assembly and an opponent held up his profession as evidence that he was unfit for public office. Mr. Margules is a landlord. He makes his living by buying, managing and selling apartment buildings. Usually he uses his own money and money from investors, whom he assembles into small corporations each time he spots a good deal. Sometimes, he buys by himself. After a group has bought a building, Mr. Margules (who uses that spelling even though he pronounces his name Mar-GO-lis) manages it for a fee equal to 5 percent of the rent roll. Usually he also supervises major improvements, which raise the quality of housing for tenants and, under rent regulation, allow the owners to raise rents, giving them more income and increasing the value of the building.

title: EXECUTIONS IN UPPER VOLTA SHOCK ITS PEOPLE
description: This former French colony has found stability elusive. But until recently, Upper Volta's internal struggles have been accompanied by a minimum of violence.

title: THE QUEST FOR OLYMPIC GREATNESS
description: At a time when the spread of communism, the threat of terrorism, apartheid rule and the overall proclivities of repressive regimes seem to besmirch the Olympic Games, it is good to know Carl and Carol Lewis's bold quest for glory shall serve as an exemplar for young inheritors of all races and creeds to follow. D. J. CASPI Flushing, N.Y.

title: HART SEES TRIUMPH FOR HIS IDEAS, IF NOT FOR HIMSELF
description: Gary Hart flew off to Hawaii today to recuperate, far from the noisy party convention that had rejected him. His dreams of the Presidency lay dashed against the rocks of reality, but his confidence in his vision appeared unshaken.

title: EMILY M. MEANS BECOMES A BRIDE

The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Jackson Request Denied On Secret Service Guards
description: The Reagan Administration has rejected the Rev. Jesse Jackson's request for continued Secret Service protection following his unsuccessful bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, officials said today.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
PREMIER PASTRIES OF DENMARK
description: Copenhagen is fattening - make no mistake about it. Food in all of its various aspects is vitally important to the Danes. As anyone who has been there can testify, it's hard to get bad food in Copenhagen, whether you're talking about a sausage from a street vendor, an inexpensive meal at a hostel or an expensive nouvelle cuisine repast at an elegant restaurant. Somehow, in this gentle, breezy, Baltic capital, everything tastes delicious.

title: West German Official Holds Talks in Teheran
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany called today for a speedy end to the war between Iran and Iraq in talks with his Iranian counterpart, Ali Akbar Velayati.

title: MIAMI BEACH POLICE DROP THEIR VIDEO VIGIL
description: Video cameras are not as good at detecting street crime as the police here had hoped, officials say.

title: Karin Taros a Bride
description: In the Cole Memorial Chapel at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., yesterday, Karin Margaret Taros, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert V. Taros of Milton, Mass., was married to Roger Martin Antin, a son of Charles M. Antin of New York and the late Leonore W. Antin. The Rev. Charles Forman, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony. The bride graduated from Wheaton and the Suffolk University Law School. Mr. Antin, an alumnus of Lake Forest College, is director of fashion marketing for Bride's Magazine in New York.

title: Mondale to Be Billed By a Minnesota Resort
description: A last-minute change in vacation plans by Walter F. Mondale has cost a northern Minnesota resort some $20,000 in lost business, according to a published report Friday.

title: LETTERS
description: A 'HIGH SEAT' RESERVED BY FRANCIS PERKINS

title: NOISE POLLUTION: CUTTING DOWN THE DIN INSIDE THE HOUSE
description: AS was discussed here last week, acoustical tiles and panels do help to absorb noise and cut down on the amount of sound heard in other rooms, but only when they are installed in the room where the noise originates. Even then, they won't muffle or dampen all of the noise; the rest goes through the acoustical material and causes the studs or ceiling joists, and the wall or ceiling on the other side, to vibrate. This transmits the same sounds to the other side (actually, the vibrations create new sound waves on the other side).

title: LIMITS TO GROWTH, TEXAS STYLE
description: Few American cities are more gung-ho about growth than Dallas. Last year, it was second only to Los Angeles in building activity, according to a Dun & Bradstreet survey, and construction cranes are a permanent part of the skyline. But many residents have sought checks on unfettered development, which, they complain, has caused acute traffic congestion and disrupted their neighborhoods.

title: DUARTE, IN BRITISH TALKS, ASKS EUROPE'S AID
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today and appealed to Western Europe to help promote democracy in Central America.

title: Elizabeth F. Daley Is Wed To John Frederick Lawson
description: At St. George Roman Catholic Church in Jeffersonville, N.Y., yesterday, Elizabeth Frances Daley and John Frederick Lawson, graduates of the State University of New York Agricultural and Technical College at Delhi, were married by the Rev. Edward Greene.

title: Make the Voter Drive Bipartisan Before he went to stir Democratic fervor in San Francisco, New York's Governor Cuomo stirred some Republican ire in Albany. He ordered state employees to help get out the vote this year. The Republicans have taken the Governor to court, charging that he violated the state Constitution's mandate for bipartisan voter registration.
description: Republicans can be forgiven for perceiving the order as the work of Cuomo the political rally master rather than Cuomo the good-government specialist. High-minded though it may be to enlarge New York's electorate, the executive order raises reasonable suspicion of partisanship that it cannot assuage by merely decreeing ''strict neutrality'' in the voter drive.

title: HOSPITAS SEEK COVERAGE FOR LABOR BILLS
description: As the strike by hospital workers against most of New York City's private nonprofit hospitals continued last week, Federal labor mediators reported no progress and hospital administrators began to worry about deteriorating conditions.

title: METS' FERNANDEZ TOPS REDS
description: The remarkable young arms that carried the Mets into first place this season did it again tonight, when Sid Fernandez and Doug Sisk pitched New York to a 2-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: TRAVELER BEWARE
description: Beyond the expected barriers of another language and unfamiliar customs, foreign destinations can present their own characteristic problems - even dangers - for the visiting American unacquainted with the country. These difficulties may range from taxi overcharges in Mexico City to illegal money-changing offers in Eastern Europe to seeming bargains in overnight ''antique'' art in much of Asia. High inflation in Argentina leads to abuses, as well as honest mistakes, and street crime against tourists can happen almost anywhere. Following is a collection of caveats, cautions and inside tips from 17 New York Times correspondents and contributors around the world on the things to particularly watch out for in their areas.

title: STAGE: 'SECRETS,' SPECIAL EFFECTS FROM AUSTRALIA

title:
CAMERA;
ON MAKING PRINTS LAST
description: Experts estimate that a properly processed and stored photographic print should last 3,000 years. To be sure, none but the most finicky of museums buying from the most finicky of photographers will be able to maintain the precise chemical and atmospheric conditions to guarantee such longevity. Still, there's a lot the individual photographer can do to produce prints that will last - at least a lifetime.

title: HEADLINERS ;

title: PROVIDENCE IS LOOKING UP-AND OVER ITS SHOULDER
description: There are barricades and truck-sized piles of dirt in the torn-up streets and plazas of downtown Providence these days. A multimillion-dollar transportation center for Rhode Island's capital is under construction. Nearby, two bank office towers are rising. At lunch time, workers and shoppers fill the Arcade, an 1828 shopping mall recently restored and outfitted with boutiques and bistros.

description: The unpredictability of the alliances on which the American global naval strategy depends became apparent last week after New Zealand elected a Labor government pledged to barring nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed ships from the country's waters.

description: Washington and Moscow agreed last week on faster, if not necessarily better, communications. The so- called hot line they have used for 21 years to exchange messages in times of crisis will be upgraded so that messages now sent at 64 words a minute will in the next two years move at triple that speed.

''I'm really astonished,'' he said. ''I've lived in Connecticut all of my life and I've never been here. This is fantastic.''

''Tragically, there is far less freedom in Nicaragua today,'' he argued, ''than there was five years ago.'' The Somoza family dictatorship was overthrown in 1979 after four decades in power.

The boaters were treated for hypothermia and exposure, said John Mulligan, an assistant fire commissioner. The rescuers - Capt. Michael Dunne of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Firefighter Paul Knapp of the Bronx - were in the White Cross Fishing Club, 750 Clarence Avenue, in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx, when the cries for help began.

Torricelli have made headlines. But far more common around the office of Mr. Torricelli, Democrat of New Milford, are the problems of the ''ordinary'' Bergen County resident.

title: Aaron Tops Oh
description: They may not have the same snap they once did, but Henry Aaron and Sadaharu Oh , baseball's top two career home-run hitters, showed that they can still find the groove. In a 10- swing home-run hitting contest in Tokyo, the 50-year-old Aaron beat the 44-year-old Oh, 4 home runs to 2.

description: At the annual meeting of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters last May, John Kenneth Galbraith presented a $5,000 award for an outstanding work of fiction published during the preceding 12 months.

title: CONFERENCE FOCUSES ON PET-OWNER GRIEF
description: EAST BRUNSWICK WHAT is believed to have been the first meeting of its kind in the state and one of the first in the country - a conference entitled ''Helping Clients Cope With Pet Loss'' - was held here recently by the Animal Hospital Assistants Association of New Jersey.

title: A JAILED MOBSTER
description: Dominic Phillip Brooklier, who was serving a five-year sentence in Arizona on conviction of racketeering in Southern California, has died of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: GIFTS FROM THE HEAVENS ;  The Eagle Has Landed
description: A baby bald eagle whose photograph was published in this newspaper recently didn't look like much. One of 16 flown from Alaska to be fruitful and multiply in New York State, it was small, sparsely feathered, and seemed cranky rather than fierce.

title: VILLAGE POLICY RESTATED
description: American athletes who want to live outside the Olympic Village must have good reasons, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee said today.

title: Allison Ijams Plans to Wed In September
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Edward M. Crane of Princeton, N.J., and Fishers Island, L.I., and Porter Ijams of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Allison Ijams to Thomas Sargent, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sargent of Wellesley, Mass., and Norwich, Vt.

title: JAPANESE GALLOWS: CASE OF THE 'WRONG MAN'
description: In the third recent case of its kind, a man sentenced to death for murder has been freed by a Japanese court after being found innocent at a retrial.

title:
DINING OUT;
SEASIDE DINING: TIDE IS TURNING
description: HAPPILY, the tide appears to be turning favorably on the Shore dining scene. From Doris and Ed's in Highlands down to Restaurant Maureen in Cape May, plus several intriguing spots that are bobbing up in between, it is possible to indulge in some delightful dining along the coast.

title: 'HE PAINTS WHAT IS IN HIS HEART'
description: '' THERE would be no paintings of war if there was everlasting peace.'' Robert Gwathmey, the painter of the rural South, chose his words carefully, slowly. Age and physical condition had nothing to do with it; at 81, despite a bout with Parkinson's disease that has been arrested, he remains active and involved, painting each day in his Amagansett studio.

title: TICKETS WITH MAYO: THE OLYMPIC SANDWICH
description: LOS ANGELES RON AMBROSE wanted to see the Olympics. He did not want to become a ticket broker. But before he ever sets foot in an Olympic stadium next week, he will have earned himself a symbolic gold medal in the latest Olympic event - the Last-Week- Jitters Surplus Ticket Unload.

title: LEARNING FROM THE ENGLISH OPERA VISITS
description: For over a century, the English had to suffer the scorn of the Continent, musically speaking. ''Das Land ohne Musik,'' the Germans sneered - ''the country without music.'' But all that has changed in the past 50 years. British composers easily hold their own, internationally. British orchestras, conductors and singers proliferate on the world's stages. And now, if such proof were needed, we realize that English opera, too, need fear invidious comparisons with no one.

title: Q&A
description: What can you tell me about the interesting building at 484 Broome Street? . . . D.L. Manhattan

title: George Washington Hill
description: Editor:

title: Moon Adjusting in First Day Of Sentence for Tax Evasion
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, leader of the Unification Church, was reported adjusting well to his new regimen during his first full day in prison yesterday as he started serving an 18-month sentence for income-tax evasion.

title: Jets Call Walker Holdout
description: The Jets' quarterback battle between Ken O'Brien and Pat Ryan began in earnest today, but who will catch the winner's passes was in doubt as the team listed Wesley Walker as a holdout.

title: SCHOOLING REVISED FOR THEHANDICAPPED
description: TRENTON

title: Catherine R. White, a Ceramic Artist, Is Married to Warren Alan Frederick
description: Catherine Rose White, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard D. White Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Warren Alan Frederick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Frederick of Westbury, L.I. Justice of the Peace Carla Stevens, who is director of the Human Relations Center at the New School for Social Research, performed the ceremony at Novo Arts, a gallery in Manhattan.

title: SIX NARRATORS IN SEARCH OF AN EXPLANATION
description: C. D. B. Bryan is the author of ''Friendly Fire.'' His most recent novel is ''Beautiful Women; Ugly Scenes.'' IN THE SHADOW OF THE WIND

title: SUPPORT AWAITS MISS AMERICA AT HOME
description: The flowers started arriving at the Williams house on Friday, with cards from friends wishing the family love and courage. The cameras and the reporters came about the same time, and today they were still camped in front of the house with the brass doorplate that reads ''Home of Miss America.''

title: SUZANNE SANTRY AND BANKER PLAN SEPTEMBER VOWS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Santry Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Elizabeth Santry, to Claude Robert Cochin de Billy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillipe Cochin de Billy of Paris. A September wedding is planned.

title: G.O.P. WORRY: WOOING VIEWER
description: For all their problems, stage managers at the raucous Democratic National Convention this week were blissfully free of one big headache plaguing the Republicans: how on earth to make their own four-day convention next month interesting.

title: COLTS STIR 'AWAKENED' CITY
description: INDIANAPOLISFrom his office on the 25th floor of the City-County Building in the heart of downtown, the Mayor of Indianapolis can look out upon his realm and see a rapidly-changing vista. It includes the 40-story American United Life building, the tallest structure in the city; on- going construction of several new hotels and office buildings and, far in the distance, work on a new 250- acre, $200 million park that will include the city zoo, a performing arts center and botanical gardens.

title: A Deficit With a Good Side
description: Given the marketplace's recent penchant for treating good economic news as a portent of higher interest rates and inflation, the good news that's expected to come with next Friday's Government report on the export-import merchandise trade balance for June should upset many investors.

title: A NEO-EXPRESSIONIST SURVEY THAT'S WORTH A JOURNEY
description: The catchall rubric of ''Neo-Expressionism,'' applied to the wild mix of emotive, figural painting styles that began in the late 1970's to succeed the reductive modes of Minimal and Color-Field, takes in a lot of territory. In this country it covers such disparate manifestations as the painterly but laconic imagery of Susan Rothenberg and Neil Jenney, among the first to breach the confines of geometric abstraction; Julian Schnabel's murky tundras of antlers and broken crockery; the life-size, angst-ridden figures of Robert Longo in flat photographic black and white, and the manic Magic Marker ideograms of Keith Haring, your friendly parlor graffitist. We are not considering here the European branches, which include the Germans Anselm Kiefer, Georg Baselitz and Markus Lupertz, and the Italians Sandro Chia, Francesco Clemente and Enzo Cucchi.

title: RETHINKING I.Q. TESTS AND THEIR VALUE
description: Mention I.Q. and most people think of a single score on a test that shows how smart we are. But to psychologists, intelligence quotients are elusive items that may or may not measure a thing called intelligence, which may or may not predict how well people will do in life.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: AMITYVILLE
description: FOR more than a century, Amityville has treasured its spacious colonial homes set amid gently sloping lawns overlooking a network of rivers and canals on the Great South Bay.

title: USED CLOTHES SELL BY THE POUND IN BORDER CITY, OFFERING WAY TO SCRAPE BY
description: The last time you donated a pile of old clothes to the Salvation Army, it may have gone to clothe the local poor or to be sold in a local thrift shop. But chances are very good that it wound up here in Brownsville on the Mexican border, lying in a big heap on the floor in one of Jim Johnson's shops, for sale at 50 cents a pound.

title: A REVIVAL MEETING
description: This year's Democratic Party convention was one of the best of the 21 I have seen in the last 40 years. It almost brought the party together - almost but not quite.

title: KLIMROD IS RICH
description: Peter Andrews is a freelance writer and critic. THE GREEN KING

title: SEEKING SALVATION UNDER THE CZAR
description: Grace Schulman's new collection of poems, ''Hemispheres,'' will be published shortly. IN THE STORM

title: JACKSONS TO HOLD 3 CONCERTS IN JERSEY AND 2 IN NEW YORK
description: Representatives of the Jacksons announced yesterday that the popular singing group would appear at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands sports complex in New Jersey July 29 to 31 and at Madison Square Garden Aug. 4 and 5 - not just at the Garden Aug. 2 to 5, as announced two weeks ago.

title: SEL-POTRAITS MINUS SELF
description: CINDY SHERMAN

title: Radioactive Steel Buried
description: A 10-ton load of potentially dangerous radioactive steel has been successfully shipped cross-country and buried at a Federal nuclear-waste dump at the Hanford nuclear reservation near here, disposal site officials say. The steel, transported from a Waterford, Conn., nuclear power plant to Hanford, was classified as low-level waste. However, the steel was radioactively ''hot'' enough to be fatal if someone came in contact with it, officials said.

title: KORCHNOI MEETS FORMER COMRADES
description: Viktor Korchnoi is getting some inconsistent reactions from his former comrades in the Soviet Union. Even though the Soviet boycott of tournaments that Korchnoi enters ended in January, his defection and residence in Switzerland seem to embarrass some of them.

title: BROADER MEDICAID GAINING SUPPORT
description: A hyperactive little boy in Plainfield requires regular medication. However, his mother recently lost her public assistance and Medicaid coverage when she received a small raise at work. As a result, she cannot afford a full month's supply of her son's medicine. Meantime, his condition has worsened and his schoolwork has deteriorated.

title: WARSAW APPROVES POLITICAL AMNESTY FOR 652 PRISONERS
description: Parliament, marking the 40th anniversary of Communist rule in Poland, approved an amnesty bill today authorizing the release of 652 political prisoners within 30 days.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: Once the home of sheep farmers and whalers, the island of Martha's Vineyard became a summer resort in the 19th century. Vacationers used to boast that there was nothing to do but relax on the lonely beaches, sail or fish on the sounds, dine on fresh lobster and go to bed early.

title: BULLDOGS BACK OFF IN BRITAIN
description: Is the homely English bulldog, that wartime symbol of British pluck, the cartoonist's favorite personification of the national character, in the process of disappearing?

title: ANOTHER YEAR OF UNCERTAINTY FOR SIMMS
description: Phil Simms came out of the morning rain and attempted to sort the turns of his career. He called his career a constant process of relearning, an adapting process, a tedious process. He observed the geese that roam the Pace University campus here, squawking and nudging one another for a few loaves of bread that were thrown their way. And he drew them into his introspection. ''My fight never ends,'' he said. ''I'm always scrapping for my share.''

title: YONKERS TO BALTIC SPEED
description: After a long, controversial night, Baltic Speed captured the opening leg of trotting's triple crown tonight by winning the Yonkers Trot.

title: HEADLINERS ;
description: Doing What One Can Don't think for a moment that Prince Charles doesn't know how tough things are out there.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ONE OF the major environmental and economic challenges of this decade is said to be the preservation of Lake Hopatcong, New Jersey's largest semi-enclosed body of fresh water, which has been succumbing to the ravages of overdevelopment.

title: LAW IS SIGNED TO NUDGE STATES ON DRINKING AGE
description: At first President Reagan criticized legislation designed to force states to raise their minimum drinking ages as just another instance of Washington wanting to meddle in the states' affairs. But last week, as he signed the bill in a ceremony in the Rose Garden, he sounded like a lifelong advocate: Because the problems caused by young drunken drivers are ''bigger than the individual states,'' the President said, he had ''no misgivings about this judicious use of Federal power.''

title: Tully Sets U.S. Mark in Vault
description: Mike Tully broke his own American record in the pole vault and China's Zhu Jianhua cleared 7 feet 7 3/4 inches in the high jump tonight as 78 Olympians competed in the Prefontaine Classic track and field meet.

title: F.B.I. KEPT CLOSE WATCH ON DOUGLAS
description: A longtime friendship between J. Edgar Hoover and William O. Douglas soured in the McCarthy era when the Federal Bureau of Investigation began to question the Justice's loyalty as a result of his views about the rights of Communists, according to F.B.I. documents.

title: A Wedding on Nantucket For Lisa Grotheer, Editor
description: Lisa Karen Grotheer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George John Grotheer of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Frost, a son of Granger Hollister Frost of Nantucket, Mass., and Dorothy Crum Frost of Gordonsville, Va.

title: Drive for Anthony Shrine
description: The Adams Historical Commission has started a search for a buyer for an 1817 house in the northern Berkshires town where Susan B. Anthony was born. The house has been put up for sale for $49,000 and commission members fear whoever buys the building will not maintain its historic character, Commission Chairman Eugene Michalenko said Thursday.

title: A TIMELESS PUEBLO RITUAL
description: BETTY FUSSELL is a writer whose most recent book, ''Masters of American Cookery,'' was published by Times Books.

title: CONVENTION RAISES DEMOCRATS' HOPES
description: SAN FRANCISCO TOP New Jersey Democrats blessed this happily chaotic convention city Friday, optimistic that for the first time in 20 years a Democratic Presidential candidate could win New Jersey and its 16 electoral votes.

title: NEW RULES FOR THE BAR
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court took a step last week toward insuring that lawyers also speak the whole truth, even though it may not always be in their clients' interests.

title: SUPREME COURT FALTERS, ALAS
description: A generation of Americans has come to maturity under a legal system in which the United States Supreme Court has provided sustained protection for individual rights. Many Americans appear to have been lulled into believing that liberty is a natural state of political affairs and that our freedom is etched in constitutional stone. Reality is less sanguine.

title: DUPLEXES ON PARK
description: Demolition has begun at a narrow midblock site on the west side of Park Avenue, between 37th and 38th Streets, for a 21-story apartment house that will consist exclusively of duplex units.

title: No Headline
description: Two Held in Robberies O

title: POLO MATCH EVOKES GLORY DAYS OF OLD
description: '' I'M a member of the fifth generation of my family in the horse business,'' said James Overdorf, proprietor of Gray's of Westbury. He was standing near the entrance of his harness and saddlery establishment, close to a large, framed 1892 photograph of his grandfather, William Overdorf.

title: HISSING THE ORIGINAL SEENEY TODD
description: AUDIENCES are booing and hissing the villains and cheering the heroes in Port Jefferson again, where Theater Three is staging another rarely seen melodrama. This time out, it has chosen ''Sweeney Todd, the Barber,'' the musical melodrama that was a precursor to the Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler Broadway musical of a few seasons back.

title: BANK BUYER OF LAST RESORT
description: There isn't exactly a seller's market in failing banks. In fact, there doesn't appear to be any market for Continental Illinois, which has been foundering under the weight of $3 billion to $5 billion in questionable loans.

title: Hospital to Pay $25,000 In Carolina Baby Mixup
description: The Grand Strand Hospital has reached a $25,000 out-of-court settlement with a couple who went home last year with the wrong baby.

title: TALK THAT ILLUMINATES THE HEADLINES
description: For more than 17 years, a very long time in television, ''Washington Week in Review'' has been a survivor. What it does it does better than anyone, and while public-affairs programs on the networks and on the rest of public television may come and go, ''Washington Week in Review'' carries on, just getting better and better. Its format, meanwhile, could hardly be simpler; some of the boys (there are women, but when a woman is on the program she is one of the boys, too) sit around a table and talk about the news. The talk is not necessarily witty, although always it is informed, and the boys, who are newspaper reporters, seem genuinely interested in what one another is saying. Actually, this is the secret of their success. The boys seem to like one another, and when they have a particularly good night, viewers imagine that they pop across the street after the program to have a few beers and keep the discussion going.

title: THE HARDWARE STORE
description: -thing that I can't buy by mail, I go into a store, ask for it, and if it looks all right, I pay and get out. Shopping makes me edgy, and I've discovered that a lot of men feel the same. We try to stay out of stores.

title:
THE AUTOMATION REVOLUTION;
EASING LABOR'S TRANSITION TRAUMA
description: American society is in the midst of some of the most radical changes in its history. Forces are moving to equalize standards of living throughout the world. In turn, industry in the United States must utilize more sophisticated methods of production in order to remain internationally competitive. This developing revolution in the methods of production is the force that is restructuring our society.

title: A TOUCH OF SPAIN ON L.I. SOUND
description: EXCEPT that its view from expansive plate glass windows is of a municipal parking area rather than the waterfront, Costa de Espana in Port Jefferson is an appealing restaurant, especially in summer. Spanish food, with its refreshing gazpacho, seafood combinations, bright colors of golden rice and scarlet pimentos, pitchers of sangria and the happy informality necessitated by dishes made with seafood in the shell is particularly appropriate at this most casual of seasons.

title: KEAN ALSO GETS INTO THE (TV) ACT
description: TRENTON IT WAS difficult to watch television last week without seeing

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Vanishing Lake
description: For a half century, people went to Tillson Lake to swim, boat, fish or just dangle their feet in the water. Then, last July, Tillson Lake disappeared.

title: Jeanet E. Hardigg Is Married
description: The marriage of Jeanet Ellinwood Hardigg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Sutton Hardigg of Conway, Mass., to John Nichol Irwin 3d took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Greenfield, Mass. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Irwin 2d of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Jane Watson Irwin.

title: CONVERSIONS TO CO-OPS SPREAD WIDELY IN BROOKLYN
description: THE SPREAD of cooperative conversions in southern and central sections of Brooklyn has reached the point where buyers can find cooperatives selling in a wide range of prices, brokers report.

title: Brewers 7, A's 4
description: Jim Gantner's two-out, two-run single highlighted a three-run 10th inning that gave Milwaukee the victory.

title: Bouillabaisse
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIGHTON CLUB BASKS IN BYGONE SUN
description: A happy anachronism, the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club, at 77 the oldest beach club left in the city and the only one remaining of the many that once lined the Brooklyn shoreline, has a lively social life that belies the ages of most of its members.

title: DAY OF KILLING IN CALIFORNIA
description: One afternoon last week, in the California border community of San Ysidro, near San Diego, James Oliver Huberty, an unemployed security guard, put on combat fatigues and told his wife he was ''going hunting humans.'' Armed with a 12- gauge shotgun and two other firearms, Mr. Huberty then walked to a nearby McDonald's restaurant and began shooting. Before a police marksman shot him dead, 90 minutes later, he had killed 21 people and injured 19.

title: GRUMANN'S QUEST FOR ENERGY
description: T HE Grumman Corporation's board chairman, John C. Bierwirth, does not like to be referred to as a pioneer.

title: ; The Quest for Olympic Greatness
description: Carl Lewis - the name conjures up the American athlete ready to take on the Olympic challenge. Jane Gross's article, ''Carl Lewis: The Quest for Olympic Greatness'' (June 17), reaffirms our feelings toward this powerful sportsman, and gives us an in-depth look at him.

title: A PLACE TO SNACK IN STAMFORD
description: DINING out sometimes means ''snacking out,'' stopping somewhere on the way to or from a movie, a pub or a trip to the beach.

title: INDIANS PROTEST ROLE OF STATE POLICE
description: MEMBERS of three of the state's five Indian tribes have told state officials that they do not want the state police to protect their reservations, but the state recently ruled that it has police jurisdiction on one reservation and intends to hold fast to that ruling.

title: EAST VILLAGE PROJECT RAISES ISSUE OF WHAT IS A 'HOTEL'
description: YEARS ago, the difference between a hotel and an apartment building must have seemed so apparent to the drafters of the city's zoning resolutions that they did not bother to include precise definitions.

title: SOURCES ABOUND NOW FOR THE FRESH HERBS OF SUMMERTIME
description: UNTIL recently, about the only source for fresh herbs more exotic than parsley and dill was a flourishing garden. Now, especially in summer, farm stands, greengrocers and supermarkets all have supplies of verdant, fragrant and flavorful fresh herbs. If you can grow them in your garden, so much the better because you can cut them on demand, but a patch of real estate is no longer a requirement.

title: BOARD PASSES PACT FOR U. OF BIRDGEPORT
description: THE State Board of Governors for Higher Education last Tuesday approved its first contract with a private college for an academic program.

title: HELP WANTED IN THE SUBURBS
description: Summer jobs have been scarce for so long that many teen-agers may have given up looking. In the suburbs this year, the long lines of applicants at restaurants, malls, fast-food chains and recreation areas have disappeared and employers cannot find enough young people to fill minimum-wage jobs.

title: HOME VIDEO ; NEW CASSETTES: FROM FRED ASTAIRE TO CHARLIE BROWN;  The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
description: Starring Humphrey Bogart, Walter Huston, Tim Holt, Bruce Bennett, Alfonso Bedoya; directed by John Huston, 1948 Key Video 124 minutes. $59.98

title: THE COST OF POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MTSpingold Bridge Play

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
RIDING THE WIND
description: RYE

title: A NEW TROUPE IS BORN
description: STARTING a local theater company that conforms with complex Actors Equity codes is lofty and chancy enough. Aspiring to the realm of a real repertory setup, wherein the same actors work together consistently, even alternating plays from night to night, is even loftier.

title: Tights Heads Field of 7 In Swaps Stakes Today
description: Tights, the winner of three handicap races this year, heads a field of seven 3-year-olds racing Sunday in the $161,800 Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park.

title:
STAMPS;
AMERICAN CHRONICLER OF SOUTH SEA ADVENTURES
description: Herman Melville, whose ''Moby Dick'' is regarded by many as the greatest novel ever writen in America, appears on a new 20-cent commemorative. First-day ceremony will by Aug. 1 at the Whaling Muweum in New Bedford, Mass. The town was the setting for his masterpiece of the sea and humanity.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM FRED ASTAIRE TO CHARLIE BROWN; An Audience With Mel Brooks
description: Prism Entertainment 55 minutes. $39.95

title: Ad Agencies to Monitor 1984 Campaign Appeals
description: An association of advertising executives will monitor ads in the political campaign to make sure they do not ''prejudicially exploit'' the gender of any candidate. The association says it will publicize the worst offenders.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
'A LILCO BANKRUPTCY IS BEST'
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company, facing serious financial difficulties as a result of cost overruns and delays in the construction of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, seems to be involved in a contest with other electric utilities similarly situated to see who can stay out of bankruptcy court the longest. Unfortunately, the longer the contest continues, the more Lilco customers will lose.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: No Headline
description: Hotel Permit Revoked AtLowerEastSideSite

title: Deborah Brown Plans To Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Brown of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Brown, to Brian Andrew Murdock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Murdock of New Canaan, Conn.

title: A YOUNG DANCER WHIRLS TO THE TOP
description: IT is a world of pirouettes and

title: STUDY OF COURT-APPOINTED LAWYERS TO BEGIN
description: The City Bar Association said yesterday that it would conduct a yearlong study of court-appointed private lawyers and the way they are selected to defend the indigent.

title: MATERNITY LEAVE: IS IT LEAVE, INDEED?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: BRITISH CENTER MONITORS SOVIET ATTACKS ON RELIGION
description: When major Western news agencies reported two weeks ago that the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov was being injected with drugs in a Soviet psychiatric hospital, the source of the unofficial information was an organization here that monitors abuses of religious rights in Communist countries.

title: U.S.-Thai War Games
description: United States and Thai marines will storm a beach in southern Thailand next month as part of five weeks of air, sea and land war games in which nearly 10,000 troops, 35 ships and 62 aircraft are taking part, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
DANELIONS ARE WONDERFUL, JUST ASK THE RABBITS
description: THE rabbits and I seem to be the only ones who like dandelions, and I find the situation perplexing. It seems as if hours and hours of our suburban lives are devoted to nurturing green grass, which must be fed and watered and watched over for signs of disease. There are dangers lurking, some of which are less obvious than others. If crabgrass invades, it blends right into the greenery. None of the neighors will notice. Those pretty ''fairy circles,'' caused by some kind of fungus, don't bother me - I still believe the little people come out at night to dance.

title: SCALPEL, SPONGE, A BACH PARTITA...
description: ''There's a lot of pressure here,'' said Dr. Jackson Coleman, peering through his microscope. His assistant, Dr. Wayne Fuchs, also looking through a microsope focused on the patient's eyeball, nodded. They were working on a cataract in one of the operating rooms of New York Hospital. In the background was music by Bach - ''Sleepers, Awake,'' coming from a cassette machine.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR Improvements For Merritt
description: As a daily commuter between Greenwich and Norwalk on the Merritt Parkway, I greatly enjoyed Pete Mobilia's article (''The Merritt Turns a Graceful 50,'' July 1). Especially appreciated were the information and pictures of several landmarks I pass each day on the way to work: the pond by the Greenwich toll plaza and the ''Pilgrim Father'' sculpture on the Comstock Hill bridge. (There is an Indian chief carved on the opposite side of the arch, though it is hard to see, as it is overgrown with ivy.)

title: UNCOMMON CONTEST
description: A match that was unique in three respects took place in Washington, D.C., 10 days ago between two teams of eight. Many of those concerned had famous names, but only two were famous as bridge players.

title: Geri Ashur, Film Maker, 37; A Specialist in Dubbing
description: Geri Ashur, a film maker and English-language editor of foreign films, died of lung cancer yesterday in the St. Vincent's Hospital hospice.

title: WHAT A PSYCHOTHERAPIST DOES WITH A DREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals , at Shea Stadium, 8:20 P.M. The Mets return home after a successful trip. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:15 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: Dole, in Split With Reagan, Sees '85 Tax Increase
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today disagreed with the Reagan Administration and said taxes would have to be increased next year to help cut Federal budget deficits.

title: Sheik Ordered to Pay $4.5 Million in Coast Suit
description: Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi, who lost an $85.1 million divorce settlement battle with his wife, has been ordered to pay $4.5 million to a doctor who charged that the sheik defamed him.

title: INTEREST RATES SEEN STEADYING
description: Long-term interest rates, which rose sharply through the first half of the year, are likely to remain at or near their current levels for the next six months or so, analysts now predict.

title: OUTDOORS: SALMON IN CANADA
description: DAWSONVILLE, New Brunswick

title: Van Pelt Will Not Return
description: General Manager George Young of the Giants said today that despite Brad Van Pelt's refusal to report to the Minnesota Vikings, there was no chance that Van Pelt could return to the Giants.

title: Microrim's President Cites Management Skills
description: Kent C. Johnson, 40, has been named president of Microrim Inc., the company that in April brought to market Clout, the first artificial intelligence product for microcomputers.

title: CHINA STEEL PLANT FLOURISHES
description: When Zigong's steel-casting plant reopened in 1975, it was so short of funds that the management could not afford to buy some bamboo sleeping mats.

title: Ellen Schwartz Weds Frederick Harris
description: Ellen J. Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd M. Schwartz of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Frederick S. Harris, the son of Mrs. Stephen M. Harris of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Mr Harris. Rabbi Patrice E. Heller performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: FEDERAL SCRUTINY, NO
description: Representative Cardiss Collins, a Chicago Democrat, is puzzled.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JULY 23, 1984

title: Executive Changes At Miller Brewing
description: Late last week there where some major executive changes at Philip Morris Inc.'s Miller Brewing Company, which is in the midst of trying to get a new agency for its troubled Miller High Life brand.

title: LEMOND IS 3d
description: Making it official, Laurent Fignon cruised across the finish line here today to win the Tour de France bicycle race for the second successive year. His victory has been certain for the last week, during which he won four daily stages, including two awesome climbs in the Alps.

title: EDWARD C. REDDING
description: Edward C. (Bud) Redding, a composer and lyricist who wrote ''The End of a Love Affair,'' died July 19 of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: POLAND'S MIXED EMOTIONS: FUTURE OF U.S. SANCTIONS
description: The issue of whether or not the United States should lift the economic sanctions against Poland draws a bewildering variety of responses here, not all of them predictable.

title: FORMER JUDGE AND PROSECUTOR
description: Aaron E. Koota, a former justice of the New York State Supreme Court and a former Brooklyn District Attorney, died Sunday night at his son's home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 78 years old and a resident of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Advertising; Polaroid Shuffles Agencies
description: ALLY & GARGANO has picked up the domestic advertising for all of Polaroid's consumer instant photographic products, which have been handled by Doyle Dane Bernbach for 30 years. D.D.B., however, will continue to do Polaroid's ads in the rest of the world and its industrial and professional photographic systems in North America.

title: People
description: * Richard Villante named general manager of Marschalk, New York, and Kenneth I. Roffe, Eric J. Einhorn and Stephen Bayer promoted to executive vice presidents of the agency.

title: FILIPINO ASSEMBLY MAY TEST MARCOS
description: The newly elected National Assembly is scheduled to meet for the first time Monday, marking the start of what may be the most substantial challenge to President Ferdinand E. Marcos's control of the Government in more than a decade.

title: No Headline
description: The air was clear here this morning, revealing in diamond-sharp detail the corporate headquarters towers.

title: MONDALE ASSERTS RACE IS 'DEAD EVEN'
description: Walter F. Mondale, citing the results of a new poll, said today he believed he and President Reagan were ''dead even'' at the start of the Presidential campaign.

title: OAK PARK, 1984, IS PROUD TO BE HEMINGWAY HOME
description: Today this village was proud to proclaim that Ernest Miller Hemingway was born here 85 years ago.

title: Article 082461 -- No Title
description: Two offerings of shorter-term Treasury issues highlight this week's activity in the Government securities market.

title: G.O.P. Ticket in 1988 May Be a Family Affair
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, a possible contender for the Republican Presidential nomimination in 1988, said today that he had considered sharing the ticket with his wife, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: Body Is Found In Central Park
description: An unidentified woman in her 50's was found dead yesterday morning behind the boathouse at Conservatory Water in Central Park, the police said.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.36

title: Rival Campaign Leaders Trade Partisan Charges
description: Republican and Democratic campaign strategists exchanged political charges today, with President Reagan's campaign director emphasizing Walter F. Mondale's liberalism while his Democratic counterpart called Mr. Reagan a President for the rich.

title: LILCO SEEKS TO USE BILLS AND OIL AS LOAN COLLATERAL
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is seeking to use its accounts receivable and oil it has stored as collateral for new loans to help avert bankruptcy, according to the chairman of the utility.

title: 37,318 FANS SEE STARS BEAT COSMOS
description: In a game in which the players appeared more interested in entertainment than the result, a team of international all-stars defeated the Cosmos, 3-1, tonight in an exhibition soccer match at Giants Stadium.

title: FELIX AUGENFELD
description: Felix Augenfeld, an architect and interior designer in Vienna, London and New York, died Saturday of cancer at his home on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Federal Zoo Inspections Criticized as Inadequate
description: Federal officials charged with monitoring animal care at the nation's zoos have for years overlooked inhumane treatment, a Government report says.

title: CARPENTER BOUNCES BACK
description: A Giant fan watching the afternoon practice today did not have a clear view of Rob Carpenter pushing his head and his body between the elbows of his blockers. But when Carpenter emerged from the crowd, still upright and 5 yards farther along, the fan clapped and commented as though he had seen every move by the running back.

title: SCHLICHTER ENTERS THE NEXT PHASE ALONG THE WAY BACK
description: ANDERSON, Ind.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Getting Familiar With Moore's Sculpture

title: KATHY WHITWORTH EARNS 85TH VICTORY
description: Kathy Whitworth surpassed Sam Snead as the professional golfer with the most career victories by winning a sudden-death playoff today with Rosie Jones in the Rochester International golf tournament.

title: Stewart Wilensky Dies at 57
description: Maker of Documentary Films Stewart Edward Wilensky, a documentary and commercial film maker, died of cancer last Friday in his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 57 years old.

title: Richard Simon, Architect, Married to Alice I. Zendel
description: The marriage of Alice Ina Zendel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myer Zendel of Bronxville, N.Y., to Richard Harris Simon took place yesterday at the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle, N.Y. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Simon of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi James Perman performed the ceremony.

title: YANKS BEAT TWINS WITH RUN IN NINTH
description: Three Yankees who made costly defensive mistakes had a chance to redeem themselves in yesterday's 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins on Old-Timers' Day at Yankee Stadium.

title: THOUSANDS WAIT HOURS IN JACKSON TICKET LINES
description: They did not know if there would be enough tickets, which concert they would be for or even whether they were at the right Ticketron outlet, but thousands of people lined up throughout the New York metropolitan area yesterday to buy tickets to see the Jacksons.
