title: Nissan Profits Down by 29.1%
description: The Nissan Motor Company has reported that earnings fell 29.1 percent in the fiscal year ended March 31, despite an increase in sales.

title: Marine Is Discharged After Fiance Is Tried
description: The Marine Corps will discharge a lance corporal whose fiance was dismissed from the corps for being engaged to her, the woman's commanding officer said.

title: SCHOLARS STUDY MIDEAST ESOTERICA IN A PHILADELPHIA SUBURB
description: On the second floor of an elementary school in this affluent suburb just west of Philadelphia, scholars from around the world have been sifting through a treasure-trove of Jewish history and Middle Eastern esoterica.

title: Liberia Takes Step Toward Civilian Rule
description: The military head of state, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, has dissolved his ruling People's Redemption Council, replacing it with a National Assembly in a step aimed at returning Africa's oldest republic to civilian rule.

title: American Ballet Names Associate Director
description: John Taras has been appointed associate director of the American Ballet Theater. Mr. Taras, a choreographer, teacher and ballet master at the New York City Ballet, will work with Mikhail Baryshnikov, artistic director of Ballet Theater, on the day-to- day artistic administration of the company. The addition of Mr. Taras to the staff will not preclude the rumored appointment of Kenneth MacMillan as an administrative assistant to Mr. Baryshnikov, according to Charles Dillingham, executive director of Ballet Theater.

title: LIFEGUARD FOR EGGS AND TURTLES
description: Jim Hoover, a beach maintenance supervisor in Miami Beach, spends most of his time these days keeping an eye on several plastic coolers lined up against the wall in his office filled with moist beach sand and turtle eggs.

title: No Headline
description: The Education Fund Fumble If New York City is enjoying a healthy budget surplus, why should the school system have to struggle to avert a $14 million budget cut that could adversely affect disadvantaged children? The answer lies in the city's failure to comprehend the educational needs of poor children and a failure of leadership by Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones.

title: JAZZ: ALLEN TOUSSAINT PLAYS SOLO PIANO AT THE PUBLIC
description: ''NEW JAZZ FROM NEW ORLEANS,'' a two-night series at the Public Theater, opened Friday with a double bill that was short on New Orleans's most prized export - strutting second-line rhythms.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; American Stores Realigning Officers
description: The American Stores Company has announced that it is creating an office of the president, consisting of L. S. Skaggs, the chairman of the supermarket chain, and three others.

title: EX-PUBLISHER SAYS MOON CHURCH RAN NEWSPAPER
description: The Washington Times, the capital's unabashedly conservative ''other paper,'' is once again the unwelcome subject of articles on its own front page.

title: ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS FOSTER FALSE HOPES
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR 4 FAMILIES HIT BY THE RECESSION, THE RETURN TO PROSPERITY IS DIFFICULT
description: Two years ago, the recession had pushed James and Toni East onto a detour from their upward path.

title: Venezuelan Debt Talks
description: Venezuela this week begins formal negotiations to restructure its $34 billion foreign debt, with officials optimistic on an agreement within three months. The country is seeking to become the first Latin American debtor to obtain major rescheduling without an International Monetary Fund agreement. The Government is to present its proposals to a 13-bank advisory committee Wednesday in New York.

title: Japan Phone Decontrol Bid
description: Bills to deregulate Japan's telecommunications monopoly, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, have cleared the lower house of Japan's Parliament, in what was seen as a victory for Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: ; Rumanians Walk the Tightrope
description: LOS ANGELES Ever since a sprite named Nadia Comaneci first twirled and tumbled into the consciousness of the world at the 1976 Summer Games, her nation of Rumania has occupied a special place in the hearts of all who saw her and loved her. For another reason, the nation of Rumania will be the focus of world attention at the 1984 Games that begin Saturday. Following the Soviet Union's decision not to attend, Rumania will be the only Warsaw Pact nation to appear at these Games; its athletes and its blue-yellow-and-red flag are expected to be greeted warmly every time they appear, as a gesture from the West to the small Eastern nation that dared to come here.

title: MARIO ANDRETTI WINS
description: Mario Andretti, in a Cosworth-powered Lola, beat Tom Sneva's Cosworth-powered March by 14-hundredths of a second today to win the Michigan 500, the closest finish ever in a race for Indianapolis-style cars.

title: 2D-QUARTER PROFITS VIGOROUS
description: Corporate profits in the second quarter rose less robustly than in the first quarter, offering a new sign that the economy was expanding at a less- frenzied pace.

title: Forest Fire on Aegean Island
description: Firefighters battled for two days to control a fire that destroyed 500 acres of forests on the island of Thassos in the northern Aegean Sea, the police said today. The fire, which broke out Saturday, spread rapidly because of strong winds.

title: FAST 600 A SIGNAL TO GRAY
description: At the start of the year, Johnny Gray was little more than a footnote in track-and-field record books. His 1982 time of 1 minute 45.41 seconds made him the 75th fastest 800-meter runner in history. Now he is co-holder of the American record at 800 meters and the fastest man ever at 600 meters. Two weeks from now, he will be a strong contender for an Olympic 800- meter medal.

title: THE VOTE HAS A MOAT
description: Gov. Cuomo's order directing public employees to register voters at state offices is a sad reminder that the United States has the lowest rate of voting among the Western democracies. Everyone has heard that only 48.5 percent of the potential electorate actually voted in the 1982 Congressional elections; it is perhaps less well known that the performance in New York State was slightly worse, amounting to only 48.2 percent of those who were of age and otherwise qualified.

title: A Season of Change for the Mets
description: 55 victories and 37 losses , the best in the National League. Here are some other milestones on their surprising road to first place in 1984:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida, Jacksonville, Fla., has named to its board Earl B. Hadlow, its vice chairman and general counsel.

title: Rickover Is Praised At Submarine Ceremony
description: An attack submarine named after Adm. Hyman G. Rickover was commissioned Saturday as the man known as the father of the nuclear Navy became the third person to have a Navy vessel named after him while he was alive.

title: AMERICA NEEDS MORE PERSONAL SAVINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial Park Is Urged For San Ysidro Victims
description: Some grieving residents of this Mexican border town where a gunman killed 21 people in a McDonald's restaurant want to convert the site of the killings into a memorial park.

title: ROCK: BY ROGER WATERS
description: MULTIMEDIA spectacle, quadraphonic sound and a virtuosic star-studded band helped to make the first of three concerts by Roger Waters at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Friday one of the year's most imposing displays of rock theatrics and technology. The singer, bassist and principal songwriter for Pink Floyd, Mr. Waters has one of the most portentously gloomy sensibilities in all of rock.

title: Police in Midwest to Seek Links to Murder Suspect
description: Police departments across the Middle West will reopen their files on unsolved crimes and look for possible links to Alton Coleman, suspected in a six-state spree of rape and murder, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: British Hail Sea Missile As Superior to Exocet
description: The British Defense Ministry said today that its new Sea Eagle surface-skimming antiship missile had passed its first major test, damaging a Royal Navy warship so severely that it had to be sunk.

title: Books: White House Press Corps ;
description: White House and the Truth. By James

title: REV. JOHN CROCKER, GROTON HEADMASTER FROM 1940 TO 1955
description: The Rev. John Crocker Sr., headmaster of the Groton School for 25 years, died Saturday morning at his home in North Haven, Me. He was 84 years old.

title: JORDANIANS LEAN TO ISRAELI LABOR
description: Jordan, along with Israel's other Arab neighbors, has been closely watching the political contest between Likud and Labor in hopes that the outcome might open the way for new peace initiatives.

title: The Value in Heroin
description: Heroin is a curse for otherwise healthy addicts. But it is also a potent analgesic, valued by many physicians in treating the pain of terminally ill cancer patients.

title: INJURIES BEDEVIL BRITAIN'S SPLENDID RUNNERSS
description: LONDONOn paper, no other country can match the depth of Britain's talent in the men's middle- distance races. Whether that results in a bumper crop of medals at the Los Angeles Olympics, however, remains to be seen. The entrants preparing for the 800- and 1,500-meter races have been plagued with injuries, inconsistency and controversy - so much so that no one is sure who will be at his best.

title: Washington Watch; A 'Federation' Of Consultants
description: WASHINGTON WITH one convention down, one more to go, and ''For Sale'' signs sprouting around town again, you could swear there's an election on the horizon. No matter who wins in November, Washington's white-collar population will be even more footloose than usual, as political jobs change hands, many at the Pentagon.

title: China Calls Hot Line A 'Cheap Trick'
description: China's leading newspaper said today that the new United States-Soviet agreement to upgrade the hot line was a ''cheap trick'' that would do nothing to reduce the danger of nuclear war.

title: CONGRESS FACING MAJOR WORKLOAD ON RETURN TODAY
description: Congress will reconvene Monday for a three- week session between the Democratic and the Republican national conventions facing an array of unfinished business, including an overhaul of the immigration laws and military aid to Central America.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Fortune and Discover Shifts

title: GENERIC DRUGS IN BIGGER ROLE
description: Many consumers will benefit from lower-priced prescriptions in the next few years as the pharmaceutical industry undergoes a fundamental change. Some of the industry's most profitable drugs will lose their patent protection, opening the way to competition from cheaper generic copies.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Merger Mania
description: For sale: Gulf Oil, Kaiser Steel, Getty, Continental Group, Metromedia, Dr Pepper, Amstar, Shell Oil . . . Not so long ago, brokers peddled stocks and bonds. Now, it seems, Wall Streeters spend most of their time selling whole companies.

title: Market Place; Drug Stocks: Mixed Picture
description: A RECURRING attraction of ethical drug stocks has been their relatively stable earnings power in both bad and good economic times. During the last recession the group performed creditably in the stock market. Moreover, drug equities achieved slight gains during the booming economy of the first half of 1984, while stock prices generally retreated under the competitive pressure of high interest rates.

title: CUBS AGAIN 'CRUCIAL'
description: It was billed last Saturday at Wrigley Field as

title: BUYERS WATCHING NO. 93
description: The elite of the thoroughbred racing world spent this afternoon wandering among the stables at Keeneland Race Course, looking at the blue-blooded yearlings who will be auctioned here starting Monday afternoon at the Keeneland Select Yearling Sales.

title: Oil Imports Seen Rising
description: Oil imports by non-Communist industrialized countries will rise for the rest of the 1980's, mainly because of lower output from the British North Sea sector and the United States, the International Energy Agency said today. But the level of imports should remain below that of the 1970's peak.

title: Pop: Malicorne Performs Songs From France
description: SINCE 1973, Malicorne has been reclaiming a repertory that other folk-rock bands have left untouched - the traditional songs and dances of France. To judge by the sextet's American debut Saturday at Hunter College Auditorium, that music is even starker than the Celtic tunes played by American, British and Breton folk groups; melodies and rhythms are stripped down to short, mournful, insistent phrases.

title: AN UPDATED N.J. TANSIT CELEBRATES FIRST 5 YEARS
description: As N.J. Transit ends its fifth year of operation, officials say the state's mass transportation agency is transforming a decrepit transit system into one of the best in the country.

title: BALLESTEROS TAKES OPEN BY 2
description: Seve Ballesteros of Spain won the British Open for the second time today in an exciting duel with Tom Watson that was settled on the famous Road Hole, No. 17, of the St. Andrews Old Course.

title: Ian Smith Invites Blacks to Join His Party
description: Ian Smith, Prime Minister of Rhodesia before it became the black-ruled independent nation of Zimbabwe, has changed the name of his political group and said it was open to ''all races, colors and creeds.''

title: GLUM MOOD IN HEALTH STRIKE COMMAND POST
description: As telephoned reports about strike- bound hospitals and nursing homes came into the State Health Department's strike command post yesterday, Enid B. McCoy, one of the people taking the calls, put down her telephone and her pen and said, ''I'm feeling very sad.''

title: JAPANESE CITY (ROAR) WANTS U.S. JETS (ROAR) TO GO
description: Every minute or two the sky over this city rumbles, signaling that another fighter jet is about to swoop down and rattle houses and the people inside.

title: Dr. Leah Brasch Wed To D. S. Koch, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Dr. Leah Brasch, the daughter of Beryl E. Brasch of Denver and Jerome F. Brasch of St. Louis, to Daniel S. Koch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Koch of New York, took place yesterday. Rabbi Lewis Bogage performed the ceremony at the Phipps Mansion in Denver.

title: MISS AMERICA DENIES GIVING CONSENT TO RUN NUDE PHOTOS
description: Vanessa Williams, responding to the disclosure that she had posed for nude photographs with another woman and might lose her Miss America title because of them, said today that she had acted out of curiosity and had never consented to having the photographs published.

title: AT HOME ABROAD ; ART OF REALITY
description: ''Cos i Fan Tutte'' has always been thought the most artificial of Mozart's operas. Its 18th-century costumes and contrivances could hardly be more remote from our lives today. Why, then, did a performance here move me and others in the audience so deeply?

title: Latins See Debt Threat
description: Latin American legislators have condemned terms for repayment of the region's $350 billion debt as unacceptable. The Latin American Parliament, which ended a special two-day session on the debt Saturday night, issued a statement saying the repayment terms constituted a threat to the region. About 70 delegates from 15 countries attended the conference, which followed a meeting last month in Cartagena, Colombia, at which 11 Latin American countries agreed to set up a coordinating body on the debt problem.

title: Soviet Oil Output Off
description: Soviet oil production in the first half of 1984 dropped marginally, compared with last year, and failed to reach planned targets for the 10th consecutive month, according to a Central Statistics Board report. The Soviet Union produced 307 million tons of oil in the first six months of 1984, the same figure as last year.

title: GIRL SCOUTS RECOVER FROM COOKIES INCIDENTS
description: The nation's largest Girl Scout council, rebounding from cookie-tampering incidents that cost it $300,000 in sales, has found success in a fund-raising drive for its local camping program and other activities this year.

title: Debt Issues
description: Associates Corporation of North America, part of Gulf & Western's Financial Services Group, said it had agreed to sell $100 million of 13 3/8 percent senior notes due 1987 at a price of 99.90 to yield 13.413 percent, through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The notes are not redeemable prior to maturity.

title: ;  The Right Choice
description: When the Detroit Tiger pitcher Glenn Abbott, a 12-year major league veteran, was given the choice in mid- June of going to the team's Evansville farm club or trying to sign with another team, he decided to stay with the Tiger organization.

title: Dr. Lisa Edris Heimann and Jeffrey T. Jones Wed
description: Dr. Lisa Edris Heimann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fritz Heimann of Westport, Conn., and Mount Desert, Me., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Thomas Jones, a son of Col. Harvey C. Jones, U.S.A., retired, of Pasadena, Calif., and Mrs. William Brandenburg of Vero Beach, Fla. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Heimann home in Westport.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're slowly but surely moving into the 20th century, but by the time we get there, it will be the 21st.'' - Kathleen Shields, supervisor of the Immigration and Naturalization Service's information unit. (A1:3.)

title: ;  Official Poll
description: Players may fight, parents may urge them on and fans may yell for blood, but when it comes to unsportsmanlike conduct on the nation's playing fields, those who officiate at high school sports events think they know just where to point the finger of blame - at the coaches.

title: THERE SHE GOES...
description: This year's Thomas Eagleton I-Guess- I-Should-Have-Told-You Trophy has been presented to Vanessa Williams, Miss America of 1984.

title: IN THE MATTER OF LABELS, A LONER
description: Few of the usual labels have stuck to John Paul Stevens in his nearly nine years as a Supreme Court Justice.

title: SOVIET LETS BONN AIDES PEEK INTO TRUCK
description: An 11-day dispute over whether a Soviet semi-trailer could be considered the equivalent of a diplomatic pouch - exempt from customs inspection - ended today after West German officials were given permission to look inside.

title: MUSIC: 20TH-CENTURY WORKS AT NEW PALTZ FESTIVAL
description: It is often said that 20th- century music is incomprehensible to the general public. If so, nobody told the capacity audience that descended upon the McKenna Theater here Saturday night. As part of the Music in the Mountains Festival, presented annually by the State University of New York at New Paltz, Gundaris Pone led a program of works by Brian Fennelly, Rudi Stephan, Hugh Aitken and Leonard Bernstein. The audience response was enthusiastic in the best sense of the word; not only was there more than polite applause for each of the selections, but also a free exchange of opinions in the lobby during intermission.

title: Miss Sheldon the Bride Of Robert L. Spang Jr.
description: Elizabeth Margo Sheldon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael U. Sheldon of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert L. Spang Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Spang of Naples, Fla. The Rev. Donald W. Poole performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Le Ch^ateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: HOW THE ISRAELI ELECTION SYSTEM WORKS
description: The 26 parties taking part in the Israeli election are competing for the 120 seats in Parliament. Parliament is elected for a four-year term but may dissolve itself earlier and call for new elections - as happened this spring.

title: Long Island Driver, 18, Dies When a Train Hits His Truck
description: An Albertson, L.I., teen-ager was killed today when a Long Island Rail Road train struck his truck after the boy tried to drive through a closed crossing gate, the police said.

title: Duarte Arrives in New York En Route to Reagan Meeting
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador arrived in New York yesterday from Europe en route to a scheduled meeting with President Reagan this morning in Washington.

title: CONTRACT TALKS WITH G.M. AND FORD ARE OPENING
description: The United Automobile Workers and the two largest American automobile companies are scheduled to open negotiations on a new labor agreement Monday morning.

title: CITY IMMIGRATION OFFICE CLOGGED BY CASELOAD
description: The New York district office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service is understaffed, buried in paper work and overwhelmed by antiquated procedures, according to many specialists in the field. Moreover, they say, there will be a torrent of new work if Congress approves new immigration legislation.

title: 'BUDDENBROOKS,' A SERIES WITH A DIFFERENT PACE
description: NOW about halfway through its edited 10 1/2 hours, the West German mini-series ''Buddenbrooks'' has been eliciting two general objections from some viewers. The first, a common complaint about foreign-language imports, is that the dubbed English soundtrack is inadequate and, at best, distracting. But this, I'm afraid, is the price that must be paid for watching a masterly production that might otherwise remain inaccessible as behind-scenes bickering continues over whether American television audiences will accept subtitles. In the end, it's a price well worth paying.

title: PETRY WINS 13TH AS TIGERS TOP RANGERS
description: Dan Petry gave up four hits in eight and two-third innings, and Dave Bergman hit Charlie Hough's second pitch of the game for a home run today to give the Detroit Tigers a 2-0 victory over the sagging Texas Rangers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Science for Children That Is 'Nonthreatening'

title: YEA OR NAY, REP. FERRARO IS TALK OF PLANT IN OHIO
description: The Ferraro factor was the talk of the Colso baking products company's small lunchroom the last few days, and not all the talk has been favorable.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Two Sides Of the Real-Estate Business

title: Key to Moon First In Queen's Plate TORONTO, July 22 (AP) - Key to the Moon, ridden by Robin Platts, beat Let's Go Blue, the 4-to-5 favorite, by half a length to win the 125th Queen's Plate at Woodbine today.
description: Key to the Moon, an entry with Ten Gold Pots, completed the mile and a quarter in 2:03 4/5 to defeat 13 other Canadian-bred 3-year-olds that were vying for a purse of $373,920. Ten Gold Pots finished third.

title: Denmark's Mermaid Loses Arm to Vandal
description: Someone sawed off the right arm of the bronze Little Mermaid overnight in the worst act of destruction against the revered sculpture since it was decapitated 20 years ago, the police reported.

title: ;  Gold Medal Artist
description: Joseph Webster Golinkin was an Olympic champion, but you won't find his feat on the list of Olympic athletic achievements.

title: JAZZ: JON FADDIS QUINTET
description: THE trumpet player Jon Faddis, who arrived in New York in the early 70's amid much acclaim and as the protege of Dizzy Gillespie, organized his own jazz quintet last fall after years as a peripatetic side man and featured guest. But after a debut at the Village Vanguard in October, the group seemed to become a sometime thing. Mr. Faddis appeared frequently around town and out of town in a variety of settings but mostly without his own quintet.

title: JAPANESE FIND 'OH, CALCUTTA!' IS THEIR CUP OF TEA
description: They had seen the World Trade Center. They had meandered through the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And when the 23 Japanese businessmen wanted to see a Broadway show one recent evening, their tour guide plunked down $920 in cash for a row of seats at ''Oh! Calcutta!''

title: JEAN-HENRY LAURENS
description: Jean-Henry Laurens, a former lead tenor at La Scala opera house in Milan, Italy, died last Friday, officials said, in an explosion in his C^ote d'Azur apartment in Nice, France, where he lived after retiring 15 years ago. He was 70 years old. In guest apperances, Mr. Laurens performed with the Metropolitan Opera and, in Brussels, with the The^atre Royal de Monnaie.

title: ; THE BETTER WAY TO PROMOTE YOUTH EMPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: TRISTATE DEMOCRATS AGREE 'FERRARO FACTOR' HELPS
description: As they left this weekend after one of the more peaceful Democratic national conventions, party leaders from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut said in interviews that Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro had added unusual strength to the Democratic ticket in the region.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CENSORSHIP The New York Public Library's continuing five-month ''expose'' of censorship, in the form of exhibitions and forums on the subject, starts covering ''Censorship and Black America'' next weekend. This is the subject of an exhibition through Oct. 15 at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, the modern and attractive complex at 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street (862-4141).

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ENGINEER OF HUMAN SOULS. By Josef Skvorecky. 571 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95

title: Bidders for Conrail Thinned
description: The United States Transportation Department has narrowed to six, from 14, the number of bidders it is considering as prospective buyers of Conrail, the Government-owned rail network.

title: THE DEBATE OVER ALL-DAY KINDERGARTEN
description: Kindergarten: the very word conjures up childhood memories of blunt scissors and construction paper, of half-day sessions led by genial mother-surrogates who eased the imminent passage of 5-year-olds through the halls of learning.

title: METALS GIVE NEW VIGOR TO 2 PORTS
description: A huge increase in steel and copper imports coming through the old and until now declining seaports of southern Connecticut is transforming them into bustling arenas of new economic growth.

title: BRIEFING
description: The High Cost of Advising

title: GAF WINNER PROFITING FROM UNITS HE ASSAILED
description: In the seven months since Samuel J. Heyman won a fierce proxy fight to become chairman of the troubled GAF Corporation, the company's fortunes have brightened. But to those who were listening to Mr. Heyman a year ago, the upturn may seem ironic.

title: ;  Philippine-Owned Bank In New York Gets Chief
description: After 20 months of service, Richard W. Wheeler has stepped down as executive vice president of the Asia Society, a center for Asian cultural programs in New York, to become president of the Asian International Bank, a New York-based commercial bank owned by a group of Philippine banks.

title: Dairy Federation Wins Contract to Push Milk
description: The Dairy Promotion Federation Association, in competition with three of the nation's largest advertising agencies, has won the $50.6 million contract to push lagging sales of milk and milk products.

title: Racquel Morris, a Nurse, Weds Dr. Clifford Hall Jr.
description: The marriage of Racquel Morris, the daughter of Dr. Ramona Whaley of New York and the late Randall Morris, to Dr. Clifford Hall Jr. took place yesterday at the Marina Del Rey in the Bronx. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. Hall of Atlanta and Mae Rose Creque of Charlotte Amalie, V.I. The Rev. Dr. Calvin O. Butts, executive minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, performed the ceremony.

title: Sudan President Reports Success Against Rebels
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry has announced that his forces have regained control of the country's southeastern border and driven rebels back into Ethiopia.

title: Elizabeth Farrington Is Dead; Advocated Hawaii Statehood
description: Elizabeth P. Farrington, a former newspaper publisher and territorial delegate to Congress who advocated the statehood of Hawaii, died Saturday at Straub Hospital. She was 86 years old.

title: Rose Kennedy Turns 94
description: Rose Kennedy turned 94 years old today, still confined to her bed by a debilitating stroke.

title: No Headline
description: Anna Florian a Bride

title: WESTMORELAND REVEALS DETAILS OF HIS LIBEL CASE
description: Senior White House and military officials had abundant evidence of the exact strength of North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces before the 1968 Tet offensive, according to documents made public by Gen. William C. Westmoreland in his $120 million libel suit against CBS.

title: FOR ALIENS, RULES, FORMS AND MORE RULES
description: The ''green card,'' the most important document an alien can possess, is not green, but white with red and blue lettering.

title: MONDAY, JULY 23, 1984 International
description: Victory for Israel's Labor Party in today's election for Parliament was predicted by the country's major pollsters. One of the polls indicated that the Labor opposition would win 48 seats and the governing Likud bloc would get 41. Neither party is expected to win enough seats to form a government on its own. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iran wants to re-establish contacts with the West, West Germany's Foreign Minister said. He said the Government has expressed the ''clear wish'' for reviving contacts, but that it was ''open'' as to whether the Iranians were thinking about returning to speaking terms with the United States. (A1:4.)

title: CONCERT: WAGNER'S RESETTING OF GLUCK 'IPHIGENIE'
description: IN 1847 Richard Wagner presented Gluck's ''Iphigenie in

title: AFTER YEARS OF ABSENCE, DEFLATION CAUSES WORRIES
description: No sooner had economists and Government policymakers begun celebrating the conquest of the stubborn inflation of a few years ago than they spotted a new affliction in the nation's economy - deflation. Now its symptoms have begun to spread.

title: CONTINENTAL CITES LAX LENDING
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company abruptly made public today the results of an internal investigation of the lending policies that led the bank into its current difficulties.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a National Hockey League game, Team A has a one- player advantage and control of the puck when a Team B player commits a minor penalty as his teammate still has a minute remaining on his minor penalty. The referee's arm goes up to signal an infraction, but he delays blowing his whistle for the penalty until Team A loses control of the puck. Before that happens, Team A scores a goal. When play resumes, how many Team B players will be on the ice, how many in the penalty box and for how long?

title: Ex-Olympian Is Backed By Populists in Texas
description: Texas members of the fledgling Populists Party have endorsed Bob Richards, an Olympics gold medalist in the pole vault, as their party's Presidential nominee.

title: Forbes Balloon MakesHard Landing in Race
description: A sphinx-shaped balloon being piloted by Malcolm Forbes, the publisher, deflated and made a rough landing during a race here today, but there were no injuries.

title: Addenda
description: * Conde Nast Publications has acquired 50 percent of Bernard Leser Publications, Sydney, Australia.

title: THEATER: 'BENEFACTORS,' A NEW WORK BY FRAYN
description: On Broadway, Michael Frayn is known as the creator of the theatrical farce ''Noises Off.'' In London, Mr. Frayn is recognized as a Renaissance man: A one- time newspaper humor columnist, he is the author of a philosophical treatise, five novels and roughly a half- dozen widely varied plays. In his spare time, Mr. Frayn also toils as a translator. His version of Jean Anouilh's ''Number One'' is now in the West End; his adaptation of Chekhov's ''Platonov,'' titled ''Wild Honey'' and starring Ian McKellen, has just entered the repertory at the National Theater. Meanwhile, a new all-Frayn play, ''Benefactors,'' is playing across the Strand from the still-thriving ''Noises Off.''

title: 5 Suppliers Vow to Try Satellite-to-Home TV
description: Five companies that want to build high-powered satellites to broadcast television programming directly to American homes have assured the Federal Government that they will go ahead with their plans, company officials said last week.

title: HELPING THE OVER-40 FIND JOBS
description: Mrs. Baussan had been dismissed in June 1983 after 14 years with Charles Scribner's Sons, where she was director of advertising and promotion. She arranged to be interviewed by Len Daniels, president of Placement Associates Inc. of Manhattan, and he consented to be her agent in her job search. The agency places professionals in communications positions in what it describes as major concerns, including some Fortune 500 companies.

title: IN LIEU OF ERECTING A MID-HUDSON PYRAMID
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Wary as Practice Begins
description: The veteran players who thought they would be defending a Super Bowl championship this season instead began the road back toward .500 at the Jets' first workout today.

title: WEAK QUARTER FOR BIG BANKS
description: The second quarter was a poor one for the nation's leading bank holding companies, mainly reflecting reduced earnings on their loans to Argentina and poor results from their foreign-exchange and bond-trading activities.

title: DRUG-IMPAIRED DRIVING IS ON THE RISE, BUT POLICE LACK EFFECTIVE MEANS OF DETECTION
description: The 40-ton concrete truck swerved and smashed into a sedan parked at a curb on the West Side of Manhattan. A 23-year-old woman and her two daughters in the car were killed instantly as the truck crushed its roof.

title: ;  Team of 2 Cities
description: There is still some question as to the correct name of the San Diego/ Los Angeles Clippers. The National Basketball Association has asked a judge to clarify the league's legal standing in trying to prevent the team from moving from San Diego to Los Angeles.

title: EX-SANDINISTA MAY RETURN TO MANAGUA TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT
description: A former high-ranking Sandinista official who has become a critic of the Government, will return from the United States this week to explore the possibility of running for President, according to opposition leaders here.

title: METS WIN ON STRAWBERRY'S HOMER
description: The Mets continued rolling toward some distant and unlikely goal today when they defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7-6, on an eighth-inning home run by Darryl Strawberry.

title: LET SINN FEIN'S CHIEF MAKE HIS U.S. VISIT
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME WORRIES EMERGE ON MEXICO'S PROGRESS
description: While the international financial community holds up Mexico's gains as an example for Latin American debtor nations, economists and business executives here see troubling signs that the country's recovery could be farther away than the Government is acknowledging publicly.

title: Futures/Options; Evaluating Leveraged Contracts
description: But these are hard times for many brokers, despite the continuing rise in trading volume. In fact, the 14 percent increase in volume this year and the 9 percent gain in June alone can be traced to only a few financial and stock index options and futures. And much of this business is handled by discount brokers.

title: REP. FERRARO'S NEIGHBORS DISCOVERING A NEW WAY OF LIFE
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro came home to Forest Hills Gardens this weekend, and the Queens community may never be the same again.

title: GERMAN PUBLISHER WIDENS U.S. ROLE
description: Bertelsmann, the big German publishing company, is looking over the lucrative United States media market as if the company realized that almost any project it undertook there would have greater potential than an investment in Europe.

title: EZER WEIZMAN RETURNS, SEEKING COALITION ROLE
description: First came the break-dance music and a quintet of teen-age singers, then some speeches by local politicians. And finally there appeared the candidate of the fledgling Yahad Party, Ezer Weizman.

title: No Headline
description: A Dangerous Telephone Disorder

title: CENSURED BY HOUSE
description: Former Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California, who was censured and reprimanded by the House of Representatives for ethics violations in the late 1970's, died of a heart ailment Saturday at Southern Maryland Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: KRICKSTEIN GAINS FINAL
description: Aaron Krickstein became the youngest finalist in the 58-year history of the United States Pro Tennis championships tonight when he beat Pavel Slozil of Czechslovakia, 6-3, 6-4.

title: BRIDGE: GOOD NEWS MET WITH ROAR AT NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: A roar of delight from 2,000 bridge players swept the playing area here Saturday night on the announcement of the release of Edith Rosenkranz, who had been kidnapped Thursday night. The sound had sunk to a whisper this morning. For all but a handful of the players, the Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League were in their final day at the Sheraton Washington Hotel.

title: SUCCESS AND GUILT FEELINGS
description: YOUR book has just received

title: DANCE: JAPAN'S AVANT-GARDE SANKAI JUKU ARRIVES
description: THE eagerly awaited first New York performance of Sankai Juku, a leading Japanese experimentalist dance troupe, was greeted with cheers and a standing ovation on Saturday at the Pepsico Summerfare '84 festival at the State University of New York at Purchase. Clearly, the company created the same impact here as it had in recent performances in Toronto and at the Olympic Arts Festival in Los Angeles.

title: 'STAR WARS' PROTECTION, BUT NOT FOR EUROPEANS
description: One of the little- noticed and probably unintended consequences of President Reagan's proposal to build a ''Star Wars'' missile- defense system is that it might very well shatter the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The reason is that the creation of such a defense against Soviet long-range missiles would weaken, if not destroy, the nuclear shield over Europe.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Henderson Out
description: Rickey Henderson, who injured a shoulder on Friday night, will stay home for treatment instead of accompanying the Oakland A's on a road trip.

title: CARLTON MOVES UP ON VICTORY LIST
description: Steve Carlton pitched two-hit ball over eight innings and moved into 11th place on the major league career victory list today as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Atlanta Braves, 6-2.

title: SUSPECT HELD IN KIDNAPPING OF BRIDGE PLAYER WAS IN TOURNAMENT
description: The man who the authorities say directed the abduction of Edith Rosenkranz from a bridge tournament here is an expert bridge player and pianist from Houston who, according to his friends, has experienced financial troubles in recent years.

title: WAVING THE AQUA, PINK AND PURPLE FOR OLYMPICS
description: The streets of Los Angeles have suddenly sprouted thousands of magenta and lavender wings.

title: 3d Suspect Charged In Ambulance Case
description: A third suspect was charged yesterday with robbing city ambulance attendants after summoning them with false 911 emergency calls, the police said.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Airwick Industries Cutting Ad Budget
description: Airwick Industries is not increasing its ad budget for its Stick Ups deodorizers this year but its people feel that it will stay ahead because all its TV commercials will be 15 seconds in length, half of what it used to use.

description: A Government advisory panel has recommended in a major report that the United States consider dumping radioactive waste in the oceans.

ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Commonwealth Edison Bonds
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company priced $200 million worth of first mortgage bonds.

title: Gunmen Tie Up 3 Americans In Robbery at Hotel in Rome
description: Masked gunmen bound and gagged three American tourists and five hotel employees in a raid early today on the Cavalieri Hilton Hotel that netted the robbers up to $170,000 from 46 safety deposit boxes.

title: Treasury Aide Leaving
description: John E. Chapoton, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy, has resigned effective Aug. 1 to practice law with the Washington firm, Vinson & Elkins. Before his Treasury post, Mr. Chapoton had been a partner in the firm's Houston office. Ronald Pearlman, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, will succeed Mr. Chapoton on an acting basis.

title: BSD MEDICAL (CO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ROSS COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNION WARREN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: GEORGE (POP) ALBERT
description: George (Pop) Albert, a successful millinery businessman who became a boxing promoter at Sunnyside Gardens in Queens, died at his Manhattan home Sunday night at the age of 89. Mr. Albert is survived by four sons, including Howie, a boxing manager, and nine grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at 12:45 P.M. today at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th Street.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINGERS HOLDS OFF YANKEES
description: With the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning tonight, Rollie Fingers got Don Mattingly out on a popup and Don Baylor on a fly ball to earn his 23d save of the season. That would have been an exemplary accomplishment for any relief pitcher, but was nearly a miracle for a 37-year-old who missed the entire 1983 season with a career-threatening elbow injury.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $61,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $746,000 for the quarter and $3,499,000 for the year. d-Net loss e-After an extraordinary credit of $576,000.

title: Revises Estimates
description: The Detroit Edison Company said that fuel loading at its Fermi 2 nuclear power plant near Monroe, Mich., would be extended about four months and that the estimated cost of the plant had been increased $300 million.

title: BIG ELECTION ISSUE: STATE OF THE SHEKEL
description: For Ruth Zur, chairman of a polling station in the Katamon section of this city, the story of this year's Israeli elections came when voters pulled their identity cards out of plastic cases.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PARADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Air Florida and Eastern in Deal
description: Eastern Airlines will pay Air Florida $7 million for the right to fly its Miami-to-London route and for 16 arrival and departure time slots at airports in New York and Washington, officials of the airlines said. With the money, Air Florida ''will be in a position to start its operations'' again, said John Fasolino, a spokesman for the troubled airline.

title: Reopening of Restaurant Where 21 Died Held Up
description: The McDonald's Corporation yielded today to a local protest and held up its plan to immediately reopen the restaurant where a gunman killed 21 people last week.

title: Moon Assigned To Prison Kitchen
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon will work in the kitchen of the Danbury Federal prison during his 18-month sentence, a prison spokesman said today.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CINCINNATI BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a possible intrastate rate reduction.

title: A.T.& T.-Contel
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had signed an agreement to supply digital switiching equipment valued at up to $100 million to the Contel Service Corporation. The agreement covers shipments of A.T.& T.'s 5ESS equipment through 1987. A.T.& T. said the first shipment is being installed in Hershey, Pa. Contel is based in Atlanta.

title: Walker Has Surgery
description: Herschel Walker, the Generals' multimillion-dollar running back, had surgery on his left shoulder yesterday in what the club described as an effort to tighten the muscles. A team spokesman said that the operation had taken 90 minutes and been performed by Dr. Mark Schottenfeld, a team physician, at University Hospital in Newark.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $61,100,000 for plant closures and other nonrecurring items.

title: Candidates To Receive $40 Million for Campaign
description: Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, now is eligible for $40.4 million in Federal money to help pay for his general election campaign, an election official has confirmed.

title: U.S. to Train Kuwaiti Fliers And Upgrade Arabs' Missiles
description: The Pentagon told Congress today that it intended to provide training to Kuwaiti pilots and to sell kits to upgrade Hawk anti-aircraft missiles already used by Jordan and Egypt.

title: THE EFFECT OF LOTIONS
description: Suntan oils, creams, lotions, and perfumes can all increase the chance of being bitten by a mosquito, according to repellent manufacturers.

title: Article 085575 -- No Title
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is planning to make a $4.5 billion investment in the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company to keep the giant Chicago bank from failing, sources in the banking industry said yesterday.

title: IN CHINA, ISLETS OF CAPITALISM
description: Oh, to be an entrepreneur in China now that the state is encouraging the opening of privately owned shops.

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AVOIDING TEACHER DROPOUTS
description: ONE reason many new schoolteachers quickly leave the profession, according to experts, is that they feel overwhelmingly isolated, receiving only the most minimal help as they struggle to cope with the rigor and unpredictability of the classroom.

title: Tax Policy Expert to Leave
description: Assistant Treasury Secretary John E. Chapoton, one of the Reagan Administration's leading policymakers on taxes, will leave his job to return to private law practice, it was announced today. Mr. Chapoton has served as assistant secretary for tax policy since 1981. He plans to return Aug, 1 to the Houston law firm of Vinson & Elkins, where he was a partner before joining the Administration.

title: BALANCING THE LAW AND LIFE'S HURDLES
description: The steeplechase is all about clearing obstacles, which means that life and the steeplechase have a lot in common. Henry Marsh, America's finest in this race and a favorite to win an Olympic gold medal, has had his share of hurdles to clear off the track.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH AT HIGH 7.5% RATE IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The nation's economy grew at a surprisingly strong 7.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the Commerce Department announced today, and inflation eased when it might have been expected to increase.

title: WHEN 150,000 LAWYERS SUE
description: For legions of law school graduates, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. provided essential help at a critical moment. Faced with state bar examinations that had to be passed before they could become licensed attorneys, they turned to the company's special bar exam cram courses.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses including tax credits of $5,965,000 for the quarter and $13,505,000 for the 6 months.

title: Director of Operations Is Appointed at Genrad
description: Genrad Inc., a maker of computer- controlled automatic test equipment, based in Concord, Mass., has created a position to oversee day-to-day operations, naming W. Douglas Hajjar to the post.

title: Carling O'Keefe
description: Carling O'Keefe Ltd. said it plans a $175 million (Canadian) expansion program to increase the capacity of five of its seven Canadian breweries by the end of 1985. The company said that the expansion was necessary because of ''steadily improving sales and market share,'' and that it would allow it to supply more beer for export. A $74 million expansion of its Toronto brewery and the addition of a new fast-bottling line will be complete by May 1985 and increase capacity at that plant 50 percent, Carling O'Keefe said.

title: LATINS OFFER A SALVADOR MEDIATION PLAN
description: The four countries trying to find a peaceful settlement to the conflicts in Central America have offered to help El Salvador's new Government begin negotiations with the country's leftist rebels, according to a Latin American diplomat in the region.

title: BLUE BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,835,000 from discontinued operations.

description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $56,109 for the quarter and $321,714 for the year. c-Net loss including extraordinary gains of $6,274 for the quarter and $216,069 for the year.

title: JAMES FIXX: THE ENIGMA OF HEART DISEASE
description: THE first symptom of heart disease is sometimes sudden death. Never was that fact made clearer than in the ironic death last week of James Fixx, whose best-selling book ''The Complete Book of Running'' led tens of thousands to take up jogging and made him a guru of the running world. Mr. Fixx, whose transition from a heavy young man who smoked two packs of cigarettes a day into a trimmer, middle-aged nonsmoking athlete seemed to insure a healthy life, died at the age of 52 while jogging in Vermont.

title: PHOENIX STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAPAN'S SPACE RACE STRUGGLE
description: Typhoon season is coming and the Japanese weather agency is in a bind. Japan's meteorological satellite broke down in January and is providing only half the usual number of cloud photographs, which are vital for spotting typhoons as they form.

title: A NEW CATEGORY OF CANCERS FOUND
description: Scientists are searching for more cases of a newly discovered category of cancers that arise because of the loss of normal genes, according to a report here today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SNAP JUDGMENTS There is a world of difference between the various exhibitions now on display at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street (860-1777) - which is often what this museum of pictorial recording wants to show as it exhibits the pictures of worlds that are miles and years apart.

title: 'CITZEN: THE POLITICAL LIFE OF ALLARD K. LOWENSTEIN'
description: ''CITIZEN: The Political Life of Allard K. Lowenstein'' is an homage to the activist, slain by a disturbed former associate four years ago. It traces Mr. Lowenstein's involvements, and finds they were all connected by his concern for human rights. The one-hour documentary will be shown on Channel 13 at 11:30 tonight.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

182 Attica Inmates Charged in Protest
description: Charges were filed today against 182 prisoners in the Attica state prison after a weekend standoff that began after a tower guard shot an inmate, state officials said.

title: Trammell Still Out
description: Although eligible to come off the disabled list today, Alan Trammell of the Detroit Tigers will remain on it until Friday, in what Manager Sparky Anderson describes as a precautionary measure. The all-star shortstop has been suffering from tendinitis of the right shoulder. . . . The Milwaukee Brewers have lost the right-handed pitcher Chuck Porter for the season. Porter, who suffered a torn ligament in his right elbow in a game Friday night, will undergo surery Aug. 2.

title: Conrail Stake for Workers
description: Employees of the Consolidated Rail Corporation will take about a 30 percent stake in the railroad as part of the Federal Government's plan to sell Conrail to private investors, Fred A. Hardin, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives' Association, said yesterday. His association is representing the employees in the negotiations.

description: The viewer is troubled. With

2d Kunkel Arrives
description: The last-place Texas Rangers called up Jeff Kunkel, a shortstop who is the son of the American League umpire Bill Kunkel from their Class AA farm club at Tulsa and said he would go into the starting lineup immediately. To make room for him, the Rangers plan to move another rookie, Curtis Wilkerson, from shortstop to second and turn their regular second baseman, Wayne Tolleson, who is hitting only .226 and has committed nine errors, into a utility player.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. The 1984 results include an unusual pre-tax charge of $38,000,000 in the second quarter to reflect Asarco's recently announced decision to close its Tacoma, Wash., copper smelter by June 30, 1985. The company said it had foreign currency exchange gains of $15,500,000 in the latest quarter compared with $21,800,000 in the year-ago quarter. For the 6 months periods exchange gains were $9,100,000 for the latest 6 months compared with $36,500,000 for the year-ago 6 months.

title: Singer's Earnings Soar
description: The Singer Company, aided by strong gains in aerospace electronic systems and domestic consumer products, nearly tripled its second- quarter profit to $15.3 million, or 80 cents a share, from $5.8 million, or 26 cents a share, a year before, the Stamford, Conn., company said yesterday. Revenues slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $603.2 million, from $608.2 million.

title: CONSTANCE HOGUET, PRESIDENT OF THE PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY
description: Constance Hoguet, a leading figure in the musical life of New York City, died of cancer on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 65 years old.

Penn Central Bid
description: The Penn Central Corporation said 8,123,000 shares of its common stock had been tendered under its self-tender offer, and that it had amended the offer to allow it to buy all the shares tendered for $47 each.

title: DISTORTED WEBS SIGNAL WATER POLLUTION
description: RESEARCHERS have found that caddis flies, whose larvae weave microscopic underwater webs to trap food, will manufacture misshapen nets and exhibit erratic pupation behavior when the water in which they live is even mildly polluted.

title: SEARS NET UP 14.4% IN QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter rose 14.4 percent, to $356 million, or 99 cents a share, from $311.2 million, or 89 cents a share, a year ago. The increase came despite a $22.7 million loss in the company's Dean Witter Financial Services subsidiary.

description: AS recently as a decade ago the thought of computer books occupying a major section in every bookstore, large or small, would have been a strange one, as would the idea of romance novels reaching their present exalted status in publishing. Yet these two apparently opposing categories seem currently - one hopes not for long - the printed word's best hope.

Alfred Taubman and certain companies controlled by him. title: ABOUT THE RETURN OF GEORGE FOSTER
description: George Foster earns $2 million a year, goes to work in a long, gray limousine driven by a chauffeur and lives in fine condominiums in Greenwich, Conn., and on the Hawaiian island of Maui. He is the most accomplished and highest-paid player on the young Mets, also the most private, the least appreciated and the most frequently booed.

title: Hometown Hero
description: Through most of his seven and one- half years as a pitcher for the Detroit Tigers, Dave Rozema has been hampered by physical problems. He won 15 games as a rookie in 1977, but then a sore arm limited him for the next four years.

title: YEARLING BRINGS $8.25 MILLION
description: A yearling son of Northern Dancer sold for $8.25 million and a yearling son of Seattle Slew sold for $6.5 million tonight at the Keeneland Select Yearling Sales to become the second and third most expensive horses ever sold at public auction. A daughter of Seattle Slew later sold for $3.75 million, a world record for a yearling filly.

title: U.S. BASE IN ATHENS BESIEGED

title: SUTCLIFFE OF CUBS WINS 5TH IN A ROW
description: Ron Cey hit a three-run homer in the sixth inning tonight to lift Chicago to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and give the Cubs' right- hander Rick Sutcliffe his fifth straight victory.

title: DIAGHILEV STAR AND TEACHER
description: Vera Nemtchinova, a star of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes who became one of New York's best-known ballet teachers, died Sunday in New York Hospital. Miss Nemtchinova, who suffered a stroke on June 28, was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORPORATE TAX LAW'S UNEVEN HAND
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMY'S SHIFTING BEHAVIOR
description: In some important ways, the American economy is behaving differently from how it used to, elating the White House, disturbing Democrats and dumbfounding analysts who have careers and reputations as the economy's weathermen. It is growing faster and with less inflation than it has for two decades. Experts think the colossal Federal budget deficits, of almost $200 billion a year, proved far more stimulative than they expected. With hindsight, some also suspect that the recession was unusually harsh on consumers, producing an orgy of post-recession spending that has continued all through the recovery.

title: Now Try a Carrot for Poland

The choice, the analysts say, will be between redeploying Israeli infantry and armored forces farther south - moving from the present line along the Awali River to the Zahrani or Litani rivers - or remaining in place.

In disclosing his intentions Saturday, the 28-year-old Father Williams added that he hoped for a transfer to a different diocese.

TUESDAY, JULY 24, 1984 International
description: Israel's labor alignment was winning slightly more votes than the ruling Likud bloc but the Likud and its allies were in a somewhat better position to form the next Government, according to computer projections based on about 93 percent of the votes counted in parliamentary elections. The projected results were seen by Israeli political analysts as an upset by the Likud, which almost every pollster had predicted would lose decisively. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow says it has proposed to Washington that the two sides issue a joint statement to demonstrate their readiness for serious negotiations on banning weapons in space. A Soviet spokesman said Washington's response would show whether it is serious about accepting a Soviet offer for talks in September or intends to continue what he called its ''deceptive game'' about the issue. title: Fire in South Africa Kills 13

title: VALUE OF MEDIATION AGAINST STRESS NOW QUESTIONED
description: DOES meditation relax your body any more than ordinary rest? Hundreds of cardiologists and psychotherapists think so. Glad to have a nondrug weapon against anxiety and stress, they added meditation techniques to their clinical repertories in the 1970's on the basis of scientific studies that described a profoundly restful ''hypometabolic state.''

description: THE California license plate on Fred Hargadon's convertible reads simply, ''ADMITS.'' The label is well-earned. As dean of admissions at Stanford University for the past 15 years, Mr. Hargadon has admitted thousands of high school seniors. In the college admissions business he is viewed by many as the dean of deans.

Yesterday's trading in the credit markets was light.

description: Alexi Grewal of Aspen, Colo., the cyclist whose 30-day drug suspension had threatened to keep him out of the Olympic Games, was reinstated today by the United States Cycling Federation. He will ride in the 108-mile road race Sunday, the first day of Olympic competition.

title: ABORIGINE EVOLUTION ASSUMES A MAJOR ROLE
description: ANTHROPOLOGISTS studying ancient bones say they have divined reasons for a major re-interpretation of the origin and evolution of the Aboriginal people of Australia. According to the new thinking, the Aborigines are much more ancient than assumed and more venturesome, probably the world's first intercontinental sea voyagers. In their evolution may lie important clues to the effect of migrations on the course of human life.

Alcan, based in Montreal, is Canada's leading aluminum producer. Caisse, with assets of $18 billion, was created by the Quebec Legislature and oversees the province's pension fund investments and other governmental funds.

title: OPERA: 'A QUIET PLACE' BY BERNSTEIN, IN WASHINGTON
description: The Leonard Bernstein opera ''A Quiet Place'' has not had an easy first year. Its troubled premiere 13 months ago in Houston took the form of a double bill - the new piece as a gloomy sequel to ''Trouble in Tahiti,'' a briefer, brighter opera that Mr. Bernstein wrote in 1951.

title: S.E.C.: NO SUPERCOP
description: In 1932, Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank of New York, suggested that stock and bond quotations be renamed ''quotations of risks and hazards.'' ''To call them securities,'' he commented, ''is ironical.'' His observations echoed the mood of the nation's investors, whose stocks has lost 83 percent of their value in less than three years. Trading was light and new issues of corporate securities were offered in only nominal amounts.

title: Byrd Sees Ticket Helping Senate Races
description: Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the Senate minority leader, said today that the Democratic ticket of Walter F. Mondale and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro will improve the party's chances of retaking the Senate in November.

6 DIE AND 22 ARE HURT IN REFINERY BLAST NEAR CHICAGO
description: An explosion rocked a Union Oil Company refinery this evening, killing at least six people and injuring 22 others as it knocked out power, shattered windows for miles and ignited a fire that raged out of control, the authorities said.

title: TUESDAY, JULY 24, 1984 The Economy
description: The economy grew at a surprisingly high 7.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter, paced by strong consumer spending. The growth in the G.N.P. was well above the 5.7 percent that the Commerce Department had predicted. In addition, inflation fell to a 3.2 percent rate from 4.4 percent in the first quarter, at a time when it could be expected to increase, further confounding analysts. But they noted that the continued strength increased the risk that an eventual slowdown would be jolting enough to cause a recession. The second-quarter results meant that the past 18 months have marked the strongest start of a recovery since 1949. (Page A1.)

title: Renewal of Conviction Asked for Von B"ulow
description: Buoyed by United States Supreme Court decisions that relaxed the ban on use of illegally seized evidence, Rhode Island's Attorney General today asked the Court to reinstate the attempted murder conviction of Claus von B"ulow.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Keith Hernandez gets another shot at his old teammates, whose manager, Whitey Herzog, has not always been kind in recent references to the trade that brought Hernandez to New York last year. Meanwhile, Met fans continue looking for answers to their questions about Bruce Berenyi, who gets the start and whose intermittent brilliance since arriving from Cincinnati last month has been punctuated by a couple of dreary outings.

description: Vice President George Bush said today that Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro shared records that are ''way over on the left spectrum of American politics,'' but that they were trying to avoid the liberal label.

title: HATFIELD DEFENDS AID TO FINANCIER WHO WAS WIFE'S BUSINESS CLIENT
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield acknowledged today that he helped a Greek financier seek Federal endorsement of a privately financed trans-African oil pipeline at the same time that the businessman was paying $40,000 in real estate fees to the Senator's wife.

title: Israel Reports 3 Bodies Are Not of Its Soldiers
description: Three of five bodies handed over to Israel by Syria during an exchange of prisoners of war June 28 are not the bodies of missing Israeli soldiers, an army spokesman said today.

title: 'SOVIET GIRL' AN AMERICAN HOAX

His company, a subsidiary of Shearson Lehman/American Express, manages $6.5 billion, divided about equally between individual clients and institutional investors.

title: AL GREEN AND SHIRLEY CEASAR TOGETHER IN PERSON
description: AL GREEN and Shirley Caesar, who are performing with their bands at the Beacon Theater Saturday night, recently recorded a duet, featured on Miss Caesar's new album, ''Sailin','' on the Myrrh label, for which both singers record. The song, ''Sailin' on the Sea of Your Love,'' has a gentle, rolling rhythm, and the singing is joyous and playful, with Mr. Green weaving vocal arabesques behind Miss Caesar's more straightforward delivery.

title: September Trial Is Set in Penn Square Case
description: A former vice president of the defunct Penn Square Bank pleaded not guilty today to 34 counts of misusing bank funds, actions that reportedly helped lead to the institution's demise two years ago.

description: Buoyed by ticket sales that already have almost sold out the Luciano Pavarotti concert scheduled for Aug. 16, Madison Square Garden yesterday announced that the famous tenor would repeat his recital there on Nov. 16. There will be no change in the program.

description: Senate leaders said today that they were seriously considering urging the Senate to accept the House version of a comprehensive immigration bill so the House would not have to vote again on the legislation.

BANKERS: ROBBIN' HOODS
description: Some leading international bankers have turned themselves into Robin Hoods in reverse: They have figured out a way to take from the poor and give to the rich. The bankers say they did not develop this talent deliberately - they just stumbled on it. That their defense contains an element of truth, however, only worsens the indictment: They weren't even clever enough to realize they were outsmarting the rest of us until they outsmarted themselves.

description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration has denied Eastern Airlines' request that it be allowed to buy 16 takeoff and landing slots from Air Florida, which has filed for bankruptcy protection. In identical letters to chief executives of the two airlines, Donald D. Engen said the F.A.A. does not permit slot sales at present but noted that a review of this policy is under way.

title: New Study of Women In Broadcast News
description: Women are holding more responsible jobs in broadcast journalism, but the number of female news-staff members at radio and television stations is no longer growing, according to a new survey released today.

title: Schoolhouse Free-for-All
description: Bending itself out of shape to accommodate the pressure for prayer in schools, the Senate has now acted to admit a little prayer before or after classes, but in a perversely liberal way: it would also admit some atheism, politics and perhaps even homosexual agitation on an equal basis. And in thus maneuvering around the constitutional issues raised by prayer in schools, the Senate exposes the underlying question of whether Congress has any business defining the rights of high school students.

description: Workers dredging Livorno's Royal Canal found two stone heads today that they hope are long-lost sculptures by Amadeo Modigliani, which the 20th century master discarded in dispair before moving to Paris.

title: PROPERTY SALE IS KEY TO PLAN TO RENEW LOWER EAST SIDE
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it intended to help restore the Lower East Side by selling some city- owned property there and using the proceeds to rehabilitate low-cost housing.

title: Bradshaw Retires, Joins CBS
description: Terry Bradshaw, the quarterback who led the Pittsburgh Steelers to four Super Bowl championships before a persistent elbow injury brought his career to an end with a frustrating final season last year, turned in his football jersey for a broadcast blazer yesterday, formally announcing his new career as a television analyst for CBS.

title: CONTINENTAL RESCUE IS QUESTIONED
description: The Treasury Department confirmed today that it had raised questions about the legality of a rescue plan devised by Federal agencies to keep the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company from failing.

title: Editor Suspended

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball

A successful outing by him would give the Mets a chance to put some more distance between themselves and the second-place Chicago Cubs, who arrive for a four-game series this weekend.

The company said it would build a plant adjacent to its Wilmington, N.C., plant, increasing employment there by 300. It said the existing plant would also be expanded.

title: MUSIC: MOZART CONCERTO FOR 3 PIANOS AT FESTIVAL
description: -piano concerto (K. 242) is not played frequently, for several reasons. There's the bother of moving a piano (most halls have two). Once it's there, the third pianist has almost nothing of consequence to play. And there's a faint air of silliness about it: Three big, shiny, potent concert grands lined up together, with sweet, tinkly, not-profound music coming out of them; a pianist who starts frantically waving his arms whenever he picks them up from the keyboard (one of the soloists always conducts), while the orchestra plays on as it was doing perfectly well without him.

title: Start Talking About Hospital Pay
description: Despite the strike of hospital employees, the managements of New York City's voluntary hospitals take satisfaction from spotless wards and timely meals. The union, meanwhile, taunts the managers by publishing lists of their six-figure salaries. But nobody will discuss issues that matter: wages and time off. That's inexcusable.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 25, 1984 International
description: Israel's parties began negotiating for coalition partners after an indecisive parliamentary election Monday that gave the two major political alignments nearly equal strength. With 98 percent of the votes counted, the Labor alignment had 44 or 45 seats and the ruling right-wing Likud bloc had 40 or 41. (Page A1, Column 1.) Jose Napoleon Duarte, although embroiled in a civil war at home, has spent much of his first seven weeks as President of El Salvador working to improve his country's standing abroad. Mr. Duarte has met with some success in two visits to the United States and one to Western Europe. (A1:2-3.)

title: AN ENGLISH SUMMER PUDDING
description: THE English have always been good at puddings. The dessert course (with the exception perhaps of tapioca pudding) has a generosity, an exuberance and a luxuriousness that you often don't find elsewhere in English life. And this is particularly true of summer desserts. While American summer desserts - fruit compotes, sherbets - grow increasingly austere under the influence of nouvelle cuisine and the new health consciousness, English desserts are voluptuous: cream, custard, liqueurs, fruit and berries all mixed in together. No purist talk here of letting the flavors speak for themselves: the English let them sing in concert. And best of all, most of these desserts are easy to make.

Although the reviews were mixed, ''Starlight'' has been sold out since opening in March. Even theatergoers who haven't seen the show are familiar with its most spectacular conceits. They know that the performers, who play railroad cars, are all on roller skates. They know that the designer, John Napier, has transformed the vast Apollo Victoria Theater into a three-level roller- rink that makes the environmental setting for ''Cats'' look like Meow Mix by comparison.

title: 'IN THE BLACK,' SPECIAL ON JOBS FOR THE YOUNG

It talks about jobs and economic opportunities, and although it is directed in a general way at black youths there is absolutely nothing in its approach, format or style that rules it out for young whites, too. Weinberger on Monday on the grounds that its judgments were ''dangerously wrong'' and its publication could endanger national security. But it was only the latest doubt raised by military and civilian skeptics.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Freddie Solomon , the San Francisco 49ers' star wide receiver, ended his holdout and signed a two-year contract that will reportedly bring him $375,000 a year. . . . Bob Kuechenberg, the 14-year veteran fighting to keep his starting spot on the offensive line of the Miami Dolphins, has been hospitalized after complaining of nausea and dizziness. Kuechenburg, a former Notre Dame all-American, has been fighting off a challenge from Ray Foster , a Southern California lineman who has been rated highly by the Dolphins' coach, Don Shula . . . . Kenny Fields, the high-scoring former U.C.L.A. forward who was the first draft choice of the Milwaukee Bucks, has signed a four-year contract, the club announced. In addition, the Bucks said they had retained the rights to their 7-foot forward, Paul Mokeski, by matching an offer made for him by Kansas City Kings.

title: Peking Reports Crime Down
description: The number of criminal cases in Peking decreased 51 percent in the first half of 1984 because of the Government's strict campaign against lawlessness, the Public Security Bureau said today. Posters plastered outside the municipal court building said that at least 26 people had been executed in July.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene, in front of the Russian Tea Room, where Julie Kaplan is taking a photograph of a friend, a recent visitor from Florida. Exiting the restaurant, a well-dressed, bearded man who offers to take a photograph of Miss Kaplan with her friend. As he is doing so, a second man leaving the restaurant observes the impromptu photo session and says that he would be glad to take a picture of Miss Kaplan, her friend and Man No.1. Just as Man No.2 is clicking the shutter on the trio, a man walking along 57th Street stops so as not to spoil the picture. Then he asks the tiny - but steadily enlarging - troupe if they would like

title: COURT ALLOWS DEFENSE TO CALL EXPERTS ON BATTERED WOMEN
description: Expert testimony on the behavior of women who have been subjected to sustained abuse from husbands or lovers is admissible to help establish claims of self-defense in murder cases, the New Jersey Supreme Court held yesterday.

title: Louisville Bonanza
description: The way officials at the University of Louisville tell it, every year some school or other offers the head basketball coach, Denny Crum , a pile of money to leave Louisville, and every year Louisville has to make a counteroffer to keep him. Now, fed up with the annual negotiations, university officials have offered - and Crum has accepted - a retroactive 10-year agreement designed to keep the 47- year-old coach at the school through the 1993-94 season by making it very expensive for anyone to lure him away.

title: Hanover Bank Gets D.&P. Rating
description: Duff & Phelps, a Chicago-based rating agency, assigned an initial rating of D.&P. 5 to the senior debt of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. D.&P. 5 corresponds to a rating of high single-A.

ONE YEAR AFTER HEARINGS ON POLICE BRUTALITY, CRITICS REPORT SOME PROGRESS
description: Several weeks ago, the Rev. Lee Johnson recalls, he was invited to Brooklyn's 79th Precinct to speak to police officers at one of the ''sensitivity sessions'' now held routinely at the city's station houses.

title: APARTMENT TOWER IS PROPOSED IN SEAPORT DISTRICT
description: A 43-story apartment tower would rise at the north end of the South Street Seaport Historic District under a proposal made yesterday to the city's landmarks panel. The plan immediately ran into local turbulence.

title: Eldest Son of Loretta Lynn Drowns While Fording River
description: Loretta Lynn's eldest son, described in the country singer's autobiography as ''the one I feel most sentimental about,'' drowned trying to ford the Duck River on horseback, the authorities said today.

title: Norris Loses Case
description: Bruce Norris , former owner of the Detroit Red Wings, has been ordered by a court to pay $1.7 million to a development company. The case stemmed from Norris's backing out of a 1977 deal to move the Red Wings to a new arena that had been planned for a site near the Pontiac Silverdome.

description: The board of directors of the North American Philips Corporation yesterday elected Cees Bruynes, the president and chief executive officer, to the additional position of chairman. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

title: Tribune Co. Net Jumps

title: Manville Net Drops
description: The Manville Corporation, which sought Federal Bankruptcy Court protection two years ago because of mounting asbestos-related health claims, said today that its second-quarter profits dropped 28.7 percent, to $18.1 million, from a year earlier. The profit represented 49 cents a common share, down from $25.4 million, or 66 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1983. Revenues rose 2.6 percent, to $466 million, from $454 million.

title: Maternal Feeling
description: ''When the runners get ready for the women's marathon at Los Angeles on Aug. 5, I'll have a maternal feeling about all of them,'' says Kathy Switzer. ''Getting the marathon for women into the Olympic Games affirms an old faith and gives me hope for humanity.''

Neil Leaves Camp
description: Kenny Neil , the defensive lineman traded by the Jets to San Diego after last season, has left the Charger training camp because of continued personal distress over the accident that killed two passengers in his car last March, according to team officials. ''Kenny has some real pressing problems he has to take care of,'' said Coach Don Coryell , who said he didn't know if Neil would return. Neil, who has also been concerned about the illness of his mother, dislocated a shoulder in the accident, which occurred near Kennedy International Airport less than a month after the trade had been announced.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Calls For Punjab Unity
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appealed in the Indian Parliament today for reconciliation between Hindus and Sikhs in Punjab and declared that army troops would not be withdrawn from the area until both groups felt safe from Sikh terrorist threats.

title: Pavelich, Allison Sign
description: Two centers, Mark Pavelich, who led the Rangers in scoring last season, and Mike Allison, who missed 28 games because of injuries, have signed for next season. Pavelich, in his third year in the National Hockey league, had 29 goals and 53 assists for 82 points, and finished second on the team to Pierre Larouche with 12 power-play goals. . . . A former Ranger, the defenseman Ed Hospodar, has signed with the Philadelphia Flyers.
