description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government announced today that it had approved a $333 million private bank loan to East Germany, which it said had promised to ease restrictions on contacts between people in the two Germanys.

title: U.S.C. Post to McGee
description: Mike McGee , a former all-America tackle and football coach at Duke who has spent four years as athletic director at the University of Cincinnati, has been named to take over the troubled athletic department at the University of Southern California. He succeeds Richard Perry , who announced his resignation in May after seeing the school's athletic fortunes decline dramatically during his nine years in the post.

Partisan Speech on the Public Air
description: What limits on constitutional rights may Government impose on those who accept its subsidy? May it limit the opinions expressed by tax-supported radio and television stations? Before its summer recess, the Supreme Court held that public broadcasters receiving public funds may air editorial opinions. The 5-to-4 decision was a reaffirmation of free press and speech rights, but it should be received with great caution.

title: West German Trade
description: Citing the metalworkers' strike, West Germany said today that its trade surplus slumped in June to 1.3 billion marks, or about $456 million, from a May surplus of 4.82 billion marks. The figure compared with a surplus of 3.86 billion marks in June 1983. The Federal Statistics Office said exports fell 14.6 percent in June from May while imports declined by 6.8 percent.

Congressman Hurt in Crash
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski suffered a broken nose in a two-car accident Tuesday, but he was listed in good condition today at St. Mary of Nazareth Hospital. Mr. Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, was making a turn when his automobile was struck by an oncoming vehicle, the police said. The second driver was listed in fair condition at a hospital. The police said no tickets were issued.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -IT-YOURSELFERS who want to make painting easier will find that the so-called airless sprayers can perform efficiently in a wide variety of situations. The paint sprayers, a vast improvement on the traditional type requiring a supply of compressed air, are used not only for relatively small objects - the wicker chairs and toddlers' bicycles that have long been the canvas for the spray-paint artist - but also for dwellings, inside and out, including shingles and siding as well as window frames and doors.

title: Rich Pact for Lomax
description: There had been overtures from the Denver Gold, but it was St. Louis cash that won the battle for Neil Lomax , the 25-year-old Cardinal quarterback. He signed a four-year contract that will bring him $2.875 million and make him the highest-paid Cardinal ever.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about a wide receiver for the New York Jets misidentified him. He is Bobby Humphery.

title: Jaguar Set to Go Public
description: The Government's sale of Jaguar, the luxury car maker, to the private sector will take place on Aug. 3 and should raise $392 million, according to the prospectus issued today by the bankers handling the deal.

title: Danish Price Increases
description: Danish consumer prices rose six- tenths of 1 percent in June from May and were up 6.9 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. Wholesale prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June and were 9.7 percent higher than a year ago, the Government said. It added that fruit and vegetables topped the list of increases in consumer goods.

These computerized payment systems, often referred to as Electronic Funds Transfer Systems, transfer funds and related financial data from one account to another. The cashless society is a reality. Just as real, however, is the threat of cashless crime.

description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the nation's central bank, at its policy meeting last week, decided not to tighten its monetary policy, a move that was welcomed by Wall Street and could mean that interest rates will hold steady, instead of rising, for the next several months.

description: Ronald Baron, president of Baron Capital Inc., said he had reached a settlement with Woodward & Lothrop Inc. on a lawsuit. Woodward & Lothrop, an operator of department stores in the Washington, D.C., area, has agreed to dismiss with prejudice its lawsuit against Mr. Baron without finding any violations of law by him, and he has agreed to vote his shares in favor of the proposed acquisition of the company by A. Alfred Taubman, Mr. Baron said.

title: A Napoleon Arrives in Egypt
description: Prince Louis Napoleon, 70 years old, a descendent of the French emperor, arrived in Egypt today to supervise efforts to salvage relics of Napoleon's flagship, L'Orient, which was sunk in 1798 near Alexandria. Divers have been searching through the wreck since June. The ship was one of four sunk by Nelson's fleet in the Battle of the Nile.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT seems that every time one turns

title: Fire Hits Pentagon Offices
description: A fire damaged three offices on the second floor of the Pentagon tonight, with the loss estimated at $50,000, the authorities said.

The drop reflected the profit squeeze afflicting most of the industry's refining and marketing operations.

title: President Is Chosen For Ziff-Davis Division
description: Harry T. Chandis, 50, with 30 years in the airline business, has suddenly turned up in the magazine publishing business as president of the Business Publications division of Ziff-Davis Publishing.

title: U.S. NOW PRAISING SYRIA AS'HELPFUL'
description: A senior State Department official told a Congressional subcommittee today that Syria was playing a ''helpful'' role in restoring stability in Lebanon. He said this stemmed from a decision by Damascus ''to shift course'' and be more cooperative.

description: So Ronald Reagan will settle for being the candidate of high deficits if he can paint Walter Mondale as the candidate of high taxes.

title: SISTER CALLS CASTRO A TRAITOR
description: Juanita Castro, brother of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, denounced him as a traitor today for breaking his promise to restore democracy to their homeland.

title: RUSSIAN ASTRONAUT BECOMES FIRST WOMAN TO WALK IN SPACE
description: A Russian astronaut, Svetlana Savitskaya, became the first woman to walk in space today, the Tass press agency reported.

CARTER HAWLEY'S COSTLY FIGHT
description: The bitter six-week war in which The Limited Inc. sought to acquire Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. cost both companies about $23 million, diverted top executives from their regular work and led to the involvement of three Federal agencies and the New York Stock Exchange. It may even have reached into the White House.

title: TEXACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BETHLEHEM STEEL POSTS A PROFIT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, yesterday reported net income of $24 million, or 40 cents a share, for the second quarter - its first profit since the fourth quarter of 1981. Bethelehem had a loss of $70.7 million in last year's second quarter.

title: Guadeloupe Explosions Kill 4 Who May Have Been Bombers
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, July 25 (AP) - Four people were killed when two cars exploded in the main towns of this French Caribbean island, the police said today. They said the dead may have been terrorists whose bombs exploded prematurely.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Settlement Is Reached In Chicago Spying Case
description: A Federal judge approved a $335,000 settlement today for 25 civic groups and individuals, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who accused the police of violating their rights by spying on them.

title: THE HOT CARS COMING OUT OF DETROIT
description: The new Chrysler mini-van drives like a car but has the storage space of a small pickup truck and the roominess of a van. But customers do not seem to mind its hybrid nature - far from it. They have been waiting for months to buy it, and analysts say the mini-van has created an entirely new market, one that may well overshadow the all-American station wagon.

title: SOUNDS THAT SNARE

A LAST RESORT?

Five law lords were hearing argument on a question familiar to the Americans: the right of the press to keep its sources confidential.

title: STUDYING THE CRAFTS WITH PROFESSIONALS

title: Vote on Fuels Agency
description: The House voted today to consider an effort to take back most of the $20 billion the Synthetic Fuels Corporation got four years ago to wean the nation from foreign oil. On a 261-to-148 vote, the House overturned its Rules Committee, forcing a floor vote on amendments to recover somewhere between $9 billion and $10.25 billion of the $13.2 billion in uncommitted Federal subsidies for squeezing oil and natural gas from shale, tar sands and coal.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; American Express Sets New Preferred Shares

The company plans to sell up to $300 million of the preferred shares through its Shearson Lehman/American Express unit.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Angling for President
description: The best candidate running for President is the person who gets the most votes. It's harder to pick the best fisherman running for President, which Walter Mondale now claims to be. Surely the best can't be the idle candidate who has time to catch the most fish or tell the tallest stories, though that talent might come in handy. Perhaps the crucial qualification for best candidate-fisherman is an air of philosophic resignation.

title: REACTOR RADIATION LEVELS FOUND LOW

title: DECREASING A BURGLAR'S CHANCESE OF SUCCESS
description: OFFICERS of New York City's Crime Prevention Bureau who spend their days listening to experiences of burglary victims compare each home to a box of Cracker Jack candied popcorn. Criminals rarely choose a target for the prize that lies inside, they say, because it is impossible to know what any given home contains before it's entered. Instead that choice is often based on the outside. If one ''box'' seems tougher to open than another, the decision is an easy one.

title: VANESSA REDGRAVE IN 'SNOW WHITE'

Under the sensitive guidance of Shelley Duvall, the actress, the project has been able to attract an unusual lineup of star performers and, furthermore, to use them well. The latest instance, being shown tonight at 8 and at various other times in the next few weeks, is ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' starring Vanessa Redgrave as the Wicked Stepmother, Elizabeth McGovern as Snow White and Rex Smith as the Handsome Prince. Vincent Price is the narrator and, his face encased in a wooden frame, the voice of the mirror, mirror on the wall.

title: Iran Executes Drug Dealers

The Iranian Islamic republic has been cracking down on drug dealers since it came to power in 1979.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 27, 1984
description: The Continental Rescue The Government announced a $4.5 billion package of support for Continental Illinois, in an extraordinary intervention into the banking business. The plan, which includes $1 billion of fresh capital, gives effective control of the bank to the Government, which also assumes $3.5 billion in delinquent loans. (Page A1.) The move shows that Washington is willing to accept responsibility for the success of individual enterprises, as well as the economy in general. (A1.) Named to breathe life into the bank were John Swearingen, former chairman of Standard Oil of Indiana, and William Ogden, former vice chairman of Chase Manhattan. (D17.)

The rest of his time was devoted to chess.

Hang On to Immigration Reform
description: These are bleak days for immigration reform. The Democrats' national candidates, pandering to Hispanic leaders, parrot the unjustified claim that the Simpson-Mazzoli bill fosters discrimination against Mexican-Americans. Vice President Bush, joining the panderers, promises that President Reagan wouldn't sign anything discriminatory. The bill's sponsors have reason to fear that the necessary compromise between Senate and House versions won't survive a second close House vote.

title: ROCK TO POP IN CONCERTS UNDER THE SKY
description: Music can't help changing when it hits the open air. Sprung from the confines of clubs and theaters, it floats in all directions, battling ambient noises and transforming activities wherever it carries. In earlier days, outdoor concerts called for specially designed music - loud, rousing stuff with a heritage that stretches from Handel's ''Royal Fireworks Music'' to Tchaikovsky's ''1812'' Overture and Messiaen's ''Et Exspecto Resurrectionem Mortuorum.'' The amplifier changed that, but not completely; the outdoors are still no place for subtlety or brooding. With a celebratory tune and a high-powered beat, however, an outdoor concert can make the whole city seem to be rocking in rhythm.

description: July 5, 1982: Penn Square, an Oklahoma City bank, collapsed, and Continental, which had Penn Square holdings, placed $220 million in its loan-loss reserve to cover Penn Square loans. Aug. 30, 1982: In a management shake-up, Continental dismissed several executives, including John R. Lytle, a vice president in charge of the division that worked most closely with Penn Square, and stripped George R. Baker of his authority over domestic lending operations. Feb. 27, 1984: David G. Taylor was promoted to replace Roger B. Anderson as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Anderson retired under pressure from independent directors. Edward S. Bottum was promoted to president, succeeding John H. Perkins, who took early retirement.

title: LUXURY HOMES SPROUT ON STATEN ISLAND
description: For a long time on Staten Island, the ''Hills'' had something of a monopoly on luxury, high-cost housing. Their names were a roll-call of prestige and privilege: Fort Hill, Ward Hill, Grymes Hill, Todt Hill, Emerson Hill, Lighthouse Hill. Their tree-lined roads wind gently upward to a point 409 feet above sea level at the top of Todt Hill, bound by estates and lavish homes with views of New York Bay.

title: READYING CONVERSION
description: If the Democrats or Republicans tried to freeze the arms race, they would find economic roadblocks in the way. A path around the roadblocks is available. It should be a central focus in the Presidential campaign.

title: ELECTION FIZZLE-GIGERY
description: Governor Cuomo of New York recently deplored the ''hyperbolic negativism'' of the Presidential campaign. But he was engaging in hyperbole himself. For the 1984 contest has been fairly genteel thus far. Walter F. Mondale, it is true, once called Gary Hart ''a cold-hearted wretch'' and Mr. Hart accused Mr. Mondale of having been Jimmy Carter's Vice President. President Reagan also blasted the ''do-nothing Democrats'' recently and Mr. Hart called Ronald Reagan the ''Babe Ruth of the big spenders.'' But this is pretty mild stuff. In the old days, campaigners were much nastier.

title: S.E.C. Move On Bank Plan
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to seek public comment on a proposed new plan that would help commission officials get around foreign bank secrecy laws.

title: Cuomo Says Republicans Stay Away From Issues By The Associated Press
description: Governor Cuomo charged yesterday that the Republicans did not want to discuss the issues in the Presidential race and were calling the Democrats names instead.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest year's net increased by $377,000, or 2 cents a share, due to the extinguishment of $5 million principal amount of convertible debentures during the year. The year-ago fourth quarter net increased by $259,000, or 2 cents a share, due to a litigation settlement.

ROBERT STERN TO DIRECT CENTER AT COLUMBIA

Sovern, president of the university, has announced. Mr. Stern, who is 45 years old, is an architect of international reputation who has taught at Columbia since 1970.

title: Grey, Lyon & King Losing U.P.S. Account
description: United Parcel Service of Greenwich, Conn., with an ad budget of about $10 million and increases a prospect, is leaving Grey, Lyon & King, its agency of two years, the agency confirmed yesterday.

Opening a Door for Latchkey Kids
description: Maybe it does indeed foster independence for a child to have his own key to the front door. But opening it upon emptiness can't be less than disheartening.

title: 3 FACTORS HELP BROKER GAIN
description: MOST publicly owned brokerage firms wrote their second-quarter results in red ink this week. Contrary to its advertising slogan of being ''a breed apart,'' Merrill Lynch & Company, parent of the world's biggest brokerage, kept company with its competitors.

description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: FORD PROFIT JUMPS AT 67.7% IN QUARTER
description: Confirming the financial recovery of the auto industry, the Ford Motor Company today reported second- quarter earnings of $909.1 million, or $4.95 a share, 67.7 percent more than the $542.2 million, or $3 a share, earned in the same quarter of 1983. It was the second consecutive record quarterly profit for the company.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Heat Wave Added $10 To Cooling Bills in June
description: The June heat wave raised air-conditioning costs $10 above normal for families in the Middle Atlantic states, and cooling took extra money from most American households, the Government reported today.

title: IN CHICAGO, THE GLOOM LIFTS
description: At the headquarters of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company today glum faces had vanished, replaced by smiles, and the conversations were punctuated by laughter after Federal regulators announced management changes and a multibillion-dollar rescue plan.

title: CURBS SET ON PHONE COMPANIES
description: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene moved yesterday to slow the diversification by former Bell telephone companies into nonregulated ventures, telling them to concentrate on providing local telephone service, at least for now.

'BORING' MONOLOGUE IS TOUR DE FORCE
description: None of the women in Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company were particularly eager to play Darlene in Lanford Wilson's ''Balm in Gilead'' when it was first staged in Chicago four years ago.

title: CHOICE OF DANCE SITES: STAGE, LAWN OR SAND
description: Suspended in mid-air, 30 feet above the stage, members of the Multigravitational Aerodance Group will be pirouetting and spinning at the Prospect Park bandshell in Brooklyn this weekend. Along a 50-foot runway of a sculpture, downtown at the Battery Park City landfill, Lisa Kraus and Dancers will be performing an art-dance collaboration. Outside Washington Irving's home, Sunnyside, in Tarrytown, N.Y., lessons in 19th-century social dance will be offered.

title: Timberjack Sold
description: Sequoia Associates, an investment partnership, said it had purchased Timberjack Inc., a timber harvesting equipment subsidiary of the Eaton Corporation, in a leveraged buyout for about $26 million. Also participating in the acquisition are individual and corporate investors. Eaton, based in Cleveland, said the sale completed the last major step in a program of restructuring and realigning its businesses that it began in January 1983.

title: Casper a Raider Again
description: Dave Casper , the tight end formerly with the Los Angeles Raiders and just waived by the Minnesota Vikings, has rejoined the Raiders. Although the Super Bowl champion Raiders have built something of a reputation for ''rehabilitating'' castoff veterans, they may have had a special reason for picking up the 32- year-old Casper.

description: Argentina will repay a $300 million loan from Mexico, Brazil,

title: Carter Holders Approve Changes
description: Shareholders of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. took action that appeared to be the final step in fending off a takeover bid by The Limited Inc. By lopsided votes announced at the company's annual meeting today, shareholders ratified the sale of a 37.5 percent stake in the company to the General Cinema Corporation and approved Carter Hawley's reincorporation in Delaware instead of California.

description: b-Net loss.

Thrift Unit to Sell Half Its Branches
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said it would sell as many as half of the 74 branches of its subsidiary, the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association, as part of a plant to rebuild its capital base. ''Although we do not yet have any final agreements, we are currently talking to prospective purchasers,'' the concern's chairman, David L. Tilton, said.

title: SOVIET UNION STRIPS STAGE DIRECTOR OF CITIZENSHIP
description: Yuri Lyubimov, the outspoken former director of Moscow's Taganka Theater, has been stripped of his Soviet citizenship for ''systematic hostile activities'' damaging to the prestige of his country, a Soviet official said today.

Bribe by Pension
description: An inspired election-year maneuver - and ghastly public policy. That's the only fair judgment of President Reagan's proposal to break the bipartisan agreement he himself encouraged to limit cost- of-living increases for Social Security beneficiaries. Maybe it's not too much to hope that Democrats in Congress will resist the temptation to outbid the President by offering pensioners even more money.

description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced that it had appealed a Federal court ruling that it had violated due process in ordering a two-year suspension of the Nevada- Las Vegas basketball coach, Jerry Tarkanian , after an investigation of recruiting violations in 1977.

title: WALL STREET OPTIMISTIC, BUT QUESTIONS PERSIST
description: The Federal rescue package announced yesterday for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company should lead to stability, and quite possibly prosperity, for the troubled Chicago bank, Wall Street analysts predicted yesterday.

description: As more and more couples turn to unusual methods of adoption, traditional adoption agencies are redoubling their efforts to find homes for the harder-to-place children - older, disabled and members of minorities - who are left behind.

title: Money Funds Continue Rise
description: For the third consecutive week, the assets of the nation's money market mutual funds have surged more than $1 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The assets of the 334 funds advanced $1.26 billion, to $181.01 billion, in the week ended Wednesday.

description: A 63-year-old retired carpenter from the Bronx, whose income had been ''less than $1,000'' a month, claimed New York's $20 million Lotto prize yesterday.

title: Iran Reports Downing Iraqi Plane Over Gulf
description: Iran reported it shot down an Iraqi plane over the Persian Gulf today, and both sides said they inflicted heavy casualties in ground fighting.

description: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its 55-story headquarters building downtown to a major institutional investor for $300 million. The company said it planned to keep its world headquarters in the building.

description: The foreign trade surplus of the Netherlands grew to $684 million in May from $373 million a year before, the Government reported today.

description: The president of Amtrak said today that an error by a signal operator probably caused last Monday's fatal train crash in Queens.

description: Bond prices rose sharply for the second consecutive day, as investors and speculators became more convinced that inflation will stay low, and that the Federal Reserve will not raise short-term interest rates.

description: Planning Minister Ant^onio Delfim Netto was quoted today as saying that debt- ridden Brazil would end 1984 with sizable reserves and would cut its need for new loan money almost in half.

HOUSE BACKS BROADER TRADE CURBS
description: The House of Representatives, in a step toward protectionism, today approved an Administration-opposed bill that would broaden the reach of the nation's laws against unfair trade. The bill passed in a lopsided 259-to-95 vote.

description: Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi today characterized James Timothy Hoffman, the Government's informer and star witness in John Z. DeLorean's trial on narcotics charges, as ''a hired gun.''

ALLIGATOR, ROTISSERIE AND CHARCUTERIE
description: In the colorful and inventive parlance of food lovers, ''swampy'' isn't an adjective that gets bandied about too often - at least not in polite circles. But how else to describe the house specialty at Bon Temps Rouler, a new Cajun restaurant at 59 Reade Street - alligator sausage? Actually, the terms lean, spicy and smoky are more salient when describing this exotic appetizer, which is a good palate- teasing starter, served with chopped fresh tomatoes and parsley ($4).

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Georgia-Pacific Issues $100 Million in Notes
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation became the second high-grade industrial company to enter the bond market this week with a 10-year issue of fixed-rate notes. The company's $100 million issue of 13 1/2 percent notes due in 1994, rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's, was offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

description: The Chinese economy advanced in the first six months of 1984, but workers making more money had trouble finding consumer goods to buy, the official Statistical Bureau said today.

description: President Reagan dined on church pasta tonight, then bitterly denounced his Democratic opponents for claiming compassion while tolerating abortion and not accepting the Pope's view of Central America.

description: Some went fishing. Others went swimming or golfing. And still others just stayed around the house. The first- place Mets, with a day off before the start tonight of a four-game weekend series with the second-place Chicago Cubs, spent yesterday's scheduled respite anywhere but at Shea Stadium.

title: STAGE: ITALIAN 'TEMPEST' OPENS AT SUMMERFARE
description: To watch Giorgio Strehler's ''Tempesta'' is to become a child again, listening to a wonderful story told by a wise old man. As related by the Italian director of Piccolo Teatro di Milano, Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' becomes a magical allegory of power and submission, revenge and forgiveness, and the struggle of the artist to affirm goodness in a world where there is little cause for rejoicing.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POLICE SEEK ESCAPED SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF JERSEY GIRL, 11
description: Scores of police officers patrolled the roadways of a sparsely settled section of northwestern New Jersey today, searching for a murder suspect who dove through a closed window and fled from police headquarters here Wednesday night.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 27, 1984 International
description: Fidel Castro would welcome steps to decrease bitter tensions between the United States and Cuba. In a speech marking the 31st anniversary of the birth of the Cuban Revolution, President Castro said he would seriously consider ''any efforts at decreasing tensions in our area and in the rest of the world.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) Final results in Israel's elections were announced and they seemed to strengthen chances that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir would be asked to form a new government. The army vote showed that the right-wing faction of Parliament had gained a seat at the expense of Labor. (A4:1-3.)

title: NEW EFFORTS TO CURE DISEASE BY GENE THERAPY PREDICTED
description: New attempts to treat incurable human genetic disease by transplanting genes will probably be made within three years, an expert said here today.

title: U.S.-China Copter Deal

title: New Leader Is Elected With Ease in St. Vincent
description: Election officials said today that the New Democrats, led by James Mitchell, had routed the incumbent Labor Party and replaced Milton Cato as Prime Minister in elections held Wednesday. The New Democrats won 9 of the 13 seats in Parliament, they said.

title: CHICAGO CONFIDENT FOR THE SERIES
description: The Chicago Cubs came into the clubhouse right after the game and assaulted the buffet lunch in the middle of the room as if they had just emerged from hibernation.

title: Liberia Lifts Ban On Political Activity
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian President, lifted a four-year ban on political activity today in a step toward a return to constitutional rule.

title: PORTS OF CALL FOR SAILBOAT CHARTERING
description: The night lights of New York City are just beginning to go on when the sloop Ventura pulls out from Pier 11 at the foot of Wall Street. The sun has started to set, and the neon signs, the street lights and building lights, seem one by one to find a place against the graying sky. The Ventura, with its mast rising and its weathered sails pulled tight against the wind, moves out into the harbor.

title: THE AGGRESIVE NEW TEAM
description: A businessman whose authoritarian presence cast him as the defender of the beleaguered oil industry in the 1970's, and a banker who commands the respect of the international financial community were named yesterday to tackle what may be the toughest jobs in banking. The appointment of John Eldred Swearingen, former chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), and William Sterling Ogden, former vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, to breathe life into the ailing Continental Illinois Corporation was part of the huge rescue package put together by the Federal Government. The businessman and the banker, as the team has been dubbed by the financial community, bring to Continental a reputation for tough, aggressive management and a record of success.

The target, a British company, had run into a financial trouble after establishing itself as Europe's most successful mainframe computer maker.

Citing a conflict of interest, the judge said he planned to accept a V.I.P. season-ticket offer. He has named a panel of judges from surrounding counties from which one will be selected to hear the cases.

title: ; Variation on a theme from France.
description: One classic French theme, in literature, plays and films, involves the young man and the older woman who teaches him the arts of love. Colette's ''Cheri'' and two post-World War II movies come immediately to mind: ''Le Ble en Herbe'' and ''Le Diable au Corps.'' More than 20 years ago, another French movie, called ''Sundays and Cyb ele'' in this country, turned the convention shockingly on its head.

title: Jacobs Acts to End Disney-Gibson Tie
description: A group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had asked Walt Disney Productions Inc. to terminate its agreement to buy Gibson Greetings Inc. Disney has offered slightly more than $300 million in cash and stock for Gibson, a greetings-card company.

title: Owens to Return
description: Paul Owens , who moved from the Philadelphia front office into the job of manager last year and led the Phillies to the World Series, has made up his mind: He will return to manage the club in 1985. ''I think there are still things I can do for this team,'' Owens said yesterday in Philadelphia. ''I've got the people around me that I want, and we've got excellent players.'' After the World Series, Owens signed a one-year contract to return as manager. At age 60, he is the oldest manager in the league. The team president, Bill Giles , said he was pleased with the job Owens had done and had decided to make the announcement now because he had been getting questions about Owens's role next year. THE HOLLYMPICS OF UEBERROTH
description: LOS ANGELESUntil the first gold medal is won tomorrow, the Olympic ideal is show biz. In the opening ceremony today, a mystery guest will dip the Olympic torch into a metal birdbath, lighting the Olympic flame that will burst toward the smog above for the next two weeks. President Reagan will return to the scene of some of his worst movies, take his cue and declare the Games open for the 140 national teams on parade. And out on the Coliseum grass, 12,000 dancers, musicians, flower girls, drill teams, gospel singers and placard bearers will have shown an estimated 2.6 billion television viewers around the world that Hollywood is alive and well and living in Peter Ueberroth's imagination.

title: 51,102 SEE GOODEN SET BACK CUBS
description: The Mets are finding out more and more about themselves as each day passes. Last night, on the way to a 2-1 victory over the Cubs that increased their first-place lead to four and a half games in the National League East, they found that their most promising pitcher can succeed when not at his best. Before a crowd of 51,102 at Shea Stadium, the Mets' biggest since July 10, 1982, Dwight Gooden struggled with his control. He allowed seven walks - but only four hits - on the way to his ninth victory in 15 decisions. His fastball was good enough to collect eight strikeouts and increase his league-leading total to 162, but the rookie right-hander won more through his sheer determination and persistence than his 90-mile-an-hour fastballs or darting curves. ''I had a tough time early,'' said Gooden, who gave up six walks in the first five innings, after averaging about three a game in his previous 19 starts. ''Finally, I started to get command of my pitches more and more. I was below average early. I guess that's part of the game.'' For the Mets, clutch hitting was also part of the game. Wally Backman, with the score tied at 1-1 in the seventh, delivered the winning run with a line single to center that scored Rafael Santana. The victory, the seventh straight for the Mets, lifted their record 22 games over .500 (59-37). They have won 25 of 35 one-run games and, for the month of July, they have are 21-4, an .840 winning percentage.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  SATURDAY, JULY 28, 1984 International
description: The Soviet Union was dissatisfied with the latest United States response to its proposal for talks on space weapons and said the talks were now impossible. Deputy Foreign Minister Viktor G. Komplektov said ''the current American position makes impossible the conducting of the kind of negotiations we are talking about,'' but he appeared to leave the door open to change of position based on what he called ''the development of diplomatic contacts.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) The White House sharply denied Moscow's contention that the Administration's stand was making it impossible to hold talks on space weapons. Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said, ''We have accepted the Soviet proposal for discussions in Vienna in September without preconditions,'' and that the Administration's preparations for the talks ''are continuing vigorously.'' (4:1.)

title: NEW VARIABLE NOTES VIE WITH LOANS
description: Wall Street has devised a new form of bond financing that competes directly with bank loans. Since late June, five companies have come to market with the new instrument - called a subordinated exchangeable variable-rate note. And investment bankers are scrambling to put together similar deals.

description: The New Orleans pianist Allen Toussaint will play solos tonight at Tramps (777-5077), 125 East 15th Street, near Irving Place. Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

description: Alcon Laboratories of Fort Worth, an eye-care company owned by Nestle S.A., said yesterday that it had terminated its $513 million offer to buy Coopervision Inc., an eye-care company based in Menlo Park, Calif.

description: An interior roadway through the Marriott Marquis, connecting 45th and 46th Streets, will help relieve traffic congestion on Broadway when the giant Times Square hotel opens next year, according to those involved in the project.

description: The nation's trade deficit grew slightly, to $8.9 billion, in June, despite a 16 percent drop in automobile imports, the Government reported today.

NOMINATION FOR CABINET;
description: President Reagan today appointed Charles Baker, a Boston businessman, to the No. 2 post at the Health and Human Services Department, succeeding John Svahn, who became the President's chief of domestic policy. The 56- year-old Mr. Baker is chairman of Harbridge House Inc. in Boston. He served as Deputy Under Secretary of Transportation and Assistant Secretary for policy in the Nixon Administration.

title: SHE DIDN'T FISH
description: This picture of Geraldine Ferraro has been puzzling me all week. Taken right after her return from San Francisco, it shows her emerging from a Queens supermarket carrying one of those gigantic boxes of laundry detergent.

House Is Said to Vote Covert Aid for Afghans
description: The House Appropriations Committee has approved $50 million in 1984 covert aid for Afghan rebels and the Senate is likely to follow suit, Congressional sources said today.

title: PATENTS ; Isolating an Enzyme To Test for Cancer
description: Prof. Stuart G. Gordon of the University of Colorado Health Center in Denver was granted a patent this week for a method of isolating and purifying an enzyme associated with human cancers.

title: FOR THE RIGHT PRICE, SCALPERS AVAILABLE
description: ''It's like Beverly Hills - if you have to ask the price, you can't afford the ticket,'' said Howard Von Gough, who sat at a makeshift booth across the street from the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum today, trying to sell two tickets to the opening ceremonies of the Games for $500 each. The face value of the tickets was $200 each.

title: Katharine Blair and Albert F. Beringer 2d Marry
description: Katharine Blair, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney Blair of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Albert Frederick Beringer 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Marshall Beringer of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Martin and the Rev. Michael Drake performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church.

description: A Japanese fishing boat captain was shot and his ship and crew were apparently captured off the coast of North Korea, a fishing cooperative spokesman said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photo caption with an article last week about the department of microbiology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook incorrectly identified four professors. They were, clockwise from top left: Thomas Shenk, Arnold Levine, James Broach and Eckard Wimmer.

title: Angry at Cardinals
description: Everett Glenn, the agent for Clyde Duncan, top draft pick of the St. Louis Cardinals, says he will file a grievance suit against the club with the National Football League Players Association. Glenn said the Cardinals had ''violated various provisions of the collective bargaining agreement, including the failure to bargain in good faith,'' with his client, a wide receiver from Tennessee.

Not only did he find its form and story problematic, but its accumulated production traditions seemed to have created an impenetrable carapace around the work. ''Talk about warhorses!'' exclaimed the director recently. ''This is

title: STAGING THE CLASSICS IS NOT SO SIMPLE AS IT SEEMS
description: Virtually everyone who saw it this spring agreed that American Ballet Theater's production of ''Swan Lake'' needs refurbishing. Not only did the decor look shabby, so did some of the choreography. However, before Ballet Theater commissions a new ''Swan Lake'' it had better ponder what sort of a production it wants. Similarly, all other companies that seek to revive familiar 19th-century classics ought to think long and hard before hiring someone to stage them.

title:
ART;
ABSTRACTIONISTS STAR IN EAST END SHOW
description: THE high standard of this season's exhibitions in South Fork art galleries, inaugurated by Elaine Benson's pair of ''Then and Now'' shows celebrating the 20th anniversary of her residence in Bridgehampton, is being maintained by several of the area's showcases. Among those holding must-see exhibitions this summer are five that now feature outstanding works by abstractionists.

title:
DINING OUT;
THREE-STAR FARE IN ROCKLAND
description: THERESA'S small, sophisticated dining room might lack the sweeping luxe of some other fine restaurants, nevertheless every inch contributes to making dining here a special event: serene lighting, efficient, understated service and beautiful, lovingly chosen table appointments. Frank Miraglia, the warm, tactful host, knows when to chat with customers and when not; and Theresa Miraglia, the sorceress of the kitchen, sends forth delectable evidence of her potent art in carefully wrought creations emphasizing the market's best. Since our last review, Theresa's menu has been tightened to eight entrees, three pasta dishes and five desserts, a small selection, but every item choice.

title:

PROBLEMS AT MIDSUMMER
description: NOW that most flowering annuals and vegetables have been planted and are well on their way to maturity, one observation is worth noting. Those plants that were yellow, stunted and excessively hardened off when planted have not performed as well as their dark green, vigorous counterparts. Even at season-ending bargain prices, they were no bargain.

title: G.M. WORKERS ARE NOT EAGER TO STRIKE

SPIRIT-THE KEY TO OUR EQUALITY

Few nations in the history of the world have had the courage to strive for the ideals inherent in these words, so simply stated, but, in reality, a difficult dream to achieve. title: Honduras Anti-U.S. Protest
description: Hundreds of workers marched here Friday to demand the withdrawal of United States forces from Honduras in a demonstration organized by the country's major labor unions. Many Hondurans have become alarmed by the growing United States military presence here, and Honduran officials have complained about the country's low return for being Washington's staunchest ally in Central America.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 IN THE CHAMBER
description: A staple of the winter concert circuit, chamber music, isn't taking a vacation this summer. Starting with a performance of Beethoven and Brahms by the Minnewaska Chamber Music Society at 2 P.M. today at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale (parking costs $1.50 an adult, but the concert is free), chamber musicians get their licks in on the week's musical schedule.

title: Only One Political Statement
description: FOR more than an hour in the Olympics' opening ceremonies yesterday, hundreds of dancers whirled, 120 trumpets blared, 84 baby-grand pianos tinkled and thumped in a Hollywood musicale that turned the Super Bowl halftime shows into high-school plays. Then the Olympic athletes of 140 nations paraded for more than an hour in the Coliseum along the red clay-colored artificial track and gathered on the grass where the Super Bowl champion Raiders play football.

title: VICTIMS' FAMILIES SUING
description: The families of 10 young women believed kidnapped and murdered by Christopher Bernard Wilder have filed claims totaling more than $50 million against the man's estate. he family members, the Internal Revenue Service and six other people filed requests in Palm Beach County court for shares of Mr. Wilder's Boynton Beach estate, valued from $449,000 to $1.8 million. Mr. Wilder was shot to death near Canada by officers seeking him for a series of rapes, murders and kidnappings.

title: THE MALTHUSIAN TIME BONB IS STILL TICKING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. TEN years ago, when 138 countries met in Bucharest, Rumania, to talk about controlling population, China bitterly inveighed against family planning, charging that it was a tool of the capitalist West to subjugate the third world. As the world's nations meet in Mexico City to continue their discussion the week after next, China has embarked on an ambitious effort to reduce population growth. Indeed, what should quickly be apparent at the gathering is the extent to which third world suspicion of population planning has been replaced by a near consensus on its necessity that brings together East and West, North and South. ''Ten years ago, you couldn't find people knowledgeable about population,'' said Rafael M. Salas, Secretary General of the Mexico City conference. Now, he went on, virtually every government in the third world has developed its own corps of experts and programs.

title: Urban League Leader Calls Black Vote Ignored
description: President Reagan's refusal to speak before the National Urban League's conference this year suggests that the White House does not ''believe the black vote is critical'' in the November election, said the group's president, John Jacob.

The Summer Games in Montreal that year prompted a revival in amateur and professional boxing in this country, and set a standard by which future United States Olympic teams would be judged.
