title: GIVE AND TAKE IN AUTO TALKS
description: Two and a half years ago, with the American auto industry's profits plunging, the United Auto Workers grudgingly made unprecedented wage concessions. But last week, as contract negotiations got under way with Detroit's profits at record highs, it was labor's turn to argue the connection between the bottom line and the assembly line.

title: Helen Dutch Anderson Plans to Wed Arthur Osgood Phinney 3d on Sept. 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Anderson of Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Anderson's daughter, Helen Dutch Anderson, to Arthur Osgood Phinney 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Phinney Jr. of Farmington, Conn. Miss Anderson is the daughter also of the late Frances Brooke Anderson.

title: Cumulative Effect of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Holds War Games In and Around Capital
description: The Government announced today that it was carrying out large-scale military maneuvers using live ammunition in and around Tripoli, the Libyan capital.

title: PROTECTIONISM; Anything to Declare?
description: President Reagan proposed recently that goods manufactured by American companies in outer space be permitted to enter the country duty free. There aren't any factories in orbit yet.

title: DISPUTE OVER INDIAN SITE INVESTIGATED
description: IN the Town of East Hampton,

title: PRIVATE OR PUBLIC WATER?
description: A DEBATE is boiling between neighbors in the western section of Mattituck over who should pay for potable water.

title: AN 'UNASHAMED ACCOMPANIST' TURNS 85 TOMORROW
description: One of the century's most beloved musicians, the unashamed accompanist Gerald Moore, turns 85 tomorrow, his wit and vigor undiminished even though his fingers ''are rather like clothespins lately.'' The pianist who played for most of the important concert singers from the legendary Feodor Chaliapin to Dame Janet Baker, with John McCormack, Kirsten Flagstad and Hans Hotter along the way, opened a telephone interview from his Buckinghamshire cottage with an expression of pleasure that his 21st birthday should attract such attention; Moore would not be Moore without a

title: Jeanne Dooley Weds WG. R
description: Jeanne Mary Dooley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Dooley of Auburn, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Grady Reynolds, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Reynolds of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas O'Keefe performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: THEY MAKE THE STAGE SPEAK WITHOUT WORDS
description: Eleanor Rachel Luger is program director for Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts.

title: JOBS FOR TEEN-AGERS GO FOR THE ASKING
description: ONE afternoon last week, 40 teen-agers arrived at Town Hall to conduct important business with Salisbury officials.

title: SOME STONES ARE LEFT UNTURNED IN RAILROAD SAFETY EFFORTS
description: John Riley, the Federal Government's chief rail safety official, grimaced a little as he insisted that Amtrak was having ''the worst of times in the best of times.'' It was a difficult argument to make in a week punctuated by Amtrak's fourth and fifth fatal accidents of the month.

title: AGAINST INTERVENTIONISM
description: Martin F. Nolan is the editor of the editorial page of The Boston Globe. ENDLESS ENEMIES

title: A U.S. COURT CURBS RACKETEERING LAW
description: An appeals court has ruled that civil suits cannot be filed under the Federal racketeering law unless the civil charges are based on prior criminal convictions.

title: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: RUSSIA: THE PEOPLE AND THE POWER, by Robert G. Kaiser. (Pocket Books, $5.95.) The Washington Post's Moscow correspondent from 1971 through 1974, Robert G. Kaiser won the Overseas Press Club's 1974 prize for best foreign correpondence. His approach is ''outstanding,'' Phillip Knightley wrote in The Book Review. ''Russia'' describes how people in the Soviet Union feel about the country, its Government, cars, homes, schools, premarital sex, crime, sports, drink, prices, food, war and peace. ''For the first time,'' Mr. Knightley wrote, ''I now know something about todays's Russians as a people.'' Originally published in 1976, the book has been updated. THE FREE STATE , by V. S. Naipaul. (Vintage, $4.95.) This collection - which earned V. S. Naipaul England's Booker Prize in 1971 - consists of two stories, two frag ments of a travel diary and a short novel. The last prompted our reviewer, Nadine Gordimer, to write, ''I know of no other contemporary novelist who can deal so devastatingly yet quietly with the sensation and terror at the core of ordinary encounters.'' She added, ''This (book) is not his best work, but it is part of an achievement that I believe in the end will show him to have been a great writer.'' Vintage has also just issued two other Naipaul collections:

title: GOING AFTER THE ICEBERG, NOT JUST THE TIP
description: HOUSTON

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WHEN SUMMER WAS ENDLESS
description: DRIVING to work on a steamy morning recently, I noticed a group of children, maybe third and fourth graders, climbing aboard a bus marked, ''Holiday Day Camp.'' I began to think about children in summer and my mind went back almost 50 years - to an era when all mothers were home, all day, and so were the children. Home with their mothers - mothers in summer dresses.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
NOT EVERY YOUNG CAMPER HAS TO LEAVE HOME
description: A S my son readies for yet another camping season, his thoughts turn not to L. L. Bean equipment or designer tents but to bug spray and flashlight batteries. He is of the ''low-camp'' school, and we have taught him well.

title: 45 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 45 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: Sept. 8 Wedding For Miss Miklas
description: Alexandra Anna Miklas, a legal assistant in the Washington office of the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, plans to be married Sept. 8 to James Gavin Dannis, an associate with the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THANK YOU FOR NOT SMOKING
description: THERE has been talk recently about enacting antismoking ordinances in Suffolk County, N.Y., and municipalities around the country have considered or tried similar measures for offices, public places and restaurants.

title: THE VIKINGS FALL IN AT A NEW COMMAND
description: HE is 38 years old, the youngest head coach in the National Football League, a former Marine lieutenant who spent a year with a combat unit in Vietnam and a major in the Marine Corps Reserves. He has a boyish face, a warm smile, a trim physique and a friendly manner. But don't let that pleasing demeanor fool you.

title: UNDERRATED WORK BY SIMON OFFERED
description: WEST ORANGE A warmly produced ''I Ought to Be in Pictures'' at the Mayfair Farms Dinner-Theater here should establish this work in the legitimate theater business for real.

title: WHAT DOCTORS CAN SAFELY SAY ABOUT EXCERCISE
description: went as far as James F. Fixx.

title: BRIDGEPORT WANTS SUBURBS' AID
description: BRIDGEPORT B RIDGEPORT Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta says that people in the suburban towns surrounding Bridgeport do not appreciate his city and all that it does for them. He says they should not just appreciate his city, but should show it with donations from their local budgets.

title: Republicans Express Resentment of O'Neill
description: House Republicans opened an attack on Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today, saying his sharp comments about President Reagan damage the House and ''poison national politics.''

title: Jackson Taking Steps For Carolina Residency
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today he has taken steps to transfer his legal residence from Chicago to Greenville, S.C., giving him the option of running as an independent against Senator Strom Thurmond, a Republican, in November.

title: BOOTY FROM WOBURN ABBEY RECOVERED
description: Two workmen making a routine inspection of an isolated water substation Friday stumbled across $6.6 million worth of silver and heirlooms stolen last March from Woburn Abbey, the Duke of Bedford's stately home, about 20 miles away, the police said today.

title: U.S. EXPLICITY PUTS SPACE ARMS IN TALKS PLANS
description: The United States today proposed an opening statement for arms talks with the Soviet Union this fall that would explicitly include space weapons on the agenda, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the previous American proposal for an agenda had not mentioned the issue.

title: SALVADORAN TO TAKE CASE ON NICARAGUA TO THE WORLD COURT
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte says he will file a complaint with the International Court of Justice accusing Nicaragua's Government of smuggling weapons to leftist rebels in El Salvador.

title: JOBS IN SPACE CAN'T BE LEFT TO MACHINES
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL URGES RESEARCH
description: IT is not the poor pay and long

title: CONGRESS CHALLENGED ON BUDGET
description: IF YOU share my disgust with the obscene growth of

title: Egypt Says Soviet Link Won't Affect U.S. Ties
description: Prime Minister Kamal Hassan Ali said today that a decision to exchange ambassadors with Moscow would not affect ties with the United States and would not lead to greater Soviet influence here.

title: Clare K. Miller Married to Wayne A. Hoeberlein
description: Clare Kristin Miller, a daughter of Dorothy Dawe Miller of La Mesa, Calif., and John Thomas Miller Jr. of Washington, was married yesterday to Wayne Arthur Hoeberlein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Hoeberlein of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Charles Vogeley performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour Lutheran in Manhasset.

title: 1949 BOOK ON ABUSE TO BE PUBLISHED
description: MORE than 30 years ago, Francelia Butler of Mansfield wrote her first novel, ''The Lucky Piece,'' a tale about an 5-year-old girl, abused by her parents, who ultimately murders her mother.

title:
ANTIQUES;
DAY IN COUNTRY HAS ITS REWARDS
description: ANTIQUES shows cast a lure to collectors on many levels. They are, of course, a prime showcase for the wares of established dealers whose shops, once known to the public, can be visited long after a show.

title: F.B.I. ARREST DATA FOUND INACCURATE
description: A study has found that the local arrest statistics published each year by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, one of the most widely used measures of the nation's effort to fight crime, are highly inaccurate.

title: FOR LAZAR, 'FRINGE' AREAS AFFORD INVESTMENT CHANCES
description: MICHAEL J. LAZAR, a former New York City Transportation Administrator who left city government in 1976 and turned real-estate investor and entrepreneur, is establishing a reputation for taking creative risks.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WAITING FOR THE SILENCE OF PUMPKINS
description: IT'S summer again. And everyone can see

title: Krickstein and Tulasne Win
description: Aaron Krickstein and Thierry Tulasne earned berths in the semifinal round of the $200,000 D.C. National Bank Tennis Classic by registering convincing victories tonight.

title: THE MAN WHO 'CONSTANTLY PROSPECTS'
description: BOSTON

title: THE OLYMPICS NO PLACE FOR AMATEURS
description: As competition begins today in the Olympic Games, the monument of amateur athletics, more than 8,000 athletes are preparing for contests in 27 sports. How many of the athletes are amateurs is debatable. Worse, from the standpoint of the venerable tradition of amateurism, hardly anyone cares.

title: 'Something Out There'
description: GREAT white sharks, killer bees, werewolves, devils, alien horrors bursting from the chests of movie spacemen: The popular culture of our fearful times has provided us with so many variations on the ancient myth of the Beast, the ''something'' lurking out there that hunts us and is hunted by us, as to make it one of the defining metaphors of the age. In the jungle of the cities, we live among our accumulations of things behind doors garlanded with locks and chains, and find it all too easy to fear the unforeseeable, all-destroying coming of the Ogre - Charles Manson, the Ayatollah Khomeini, the Blob from Outer Space. Clearly, many of these forebodings are the product of affluence and of power. The haves and the powerful, fearing the uprising of the have-nots and the powerless, dream of them as monsters.

title: CAR COMPANIES AND UNION RESIST CONFRONTATIONS ON CONTRACTS
description: The United Automobile Workers had just demanded a seat on the board of directors, double pay for overtime work and union approval before any work now done in company plants could be shifted to outside suppliers.

title: Credit Vendors
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS ENJOYED SPOTLIGHT
description: TRENTON THOSE people who watched the Democratic National Convention on television saw the New Jersey delegation put former Vice President Walter F. Mondale over the top in his bid for the Presidential nomination. That brought to mind another convention nearly a quarter of a century ago, when the state missed the chance to do the same for then-Senator John F. Kennedy.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: FRENCH HIGHWAYMEN STALK TOURISTS BY NIGHT
description: The highwaymen are riding the moonlit roads of southern France this summer, and the French police are not entirely sure who they are or how to catch them.

title: THE THIRD PARTY IN U.S. ELECTIONS: MOSCOW
description: For both Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale, relations with the Soviet Union loom as an important campaign issue. Each candidate wants to portray himself as better able than the other to preserve peace, to negotiate arms control accords and to stand firm against Soviet aggression.

title: No Headline
description: Queens Storm Victims Eligible for FederalAid

title: SISK IS DISMAYED AFTER HIS COLLAPSE AGAINST THE CUBS
description: Doug Sisk's assessment was on target, even if his pitches weren't.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
'PRIVATIZING' EDUCATION WON'T HELP
description: SOME contemporary writers have a penchant for converting nouns and adjectives into verb forms. One such example that has attained a state of popularity in the early 80's is ''privatization.'' It has been used to mean changing what has been a public or governmental function to a privately supported activity. The critics of ''big government'' and supporters of privatization are reacting to what, indisputably, is a significant increase in the tax burden in recent decades.

title: SLAYING OF HOMOSEXUAL MAN UPSETS CONFIDENCE OF BANGOR, ME.
description: When Thoreau visited this city in the mid-19th century, it was the roisterous logging capital of America, a place, he wrote, ''like a star on the edge of the world, still hewing at the forest of which it is built.''

title: Elyse B. Kremer Bride Of Michael C. Spalding
description: Elyse Betsy Kremer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Barry Kremer of Newport, R.I., and Michael Clarke Spalding, a son of Edward Spalding of Tequesta, Fla., and Blowing Rock, N.C., and Jean Scharin Spalding of Somerset, Va., were married yesterday. The Rev. Peter Heinrichs performed the ceremony at Channing Memorial Unitarian Church in Newport.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Lots of Leather Goods At Clearance Prices Marvin's Luggage, in the PathMark-McDonald's Yonkers shopping center called High Ridge just north of Tuckahoe Road, is a source for luggage, handbags, leather accessories, gifts and umbrellas at 20 to 50 percent off suggested retail prices. A summer clearance now reduces former prices further and fall colors and styles are arriving weekly for sale at discounts.

title: THE PACKER'S PREDICAMENT
description: DAVID EAMES is a writer who lives in Cambridge, Mass.

title: LONDON CHEERS THE DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM
description: Michael Billington writes frequently about the arts in England.

title: GET READY FOR PLENTY OF DEJA VU
description: With August rolling around this week, the commercial networks are locked into their schedules for the new fall season and trend sniffers are likely to suffer a dizzying attack of dej a vu. Police shows, it seems, are this year's hot item, jumping to a total of 14 on the prime- time schedule from a mere seven last year. For the statistically minded, that's a rather startling increase of 100 percent. Not surprisingly, given the successful return to CBS of the once-canceled ''Cagney & Lacy,'' several of the new police shows will feature an assortment of female detectives. When something is on a roll, goes the old industry adage, copy, copy, copy.

title: ENGLISH ECCENTRICITY
description: THERE ARE THOSE FOR whom the quintessential English interior will always be the grand country house with its enticing clutter, its well-worn upholstery and its enviable patina of time. These are the rooms that result from years, if not centuries, of accumulation, layer upon layer of heirlooms and mementos collected from a family's myriad experiences and travels abroad. These interiors can be read as if perusing a novel, with the objects representing multifaceted characters whose different roles contribute to the history of a room, even though they may be of little current significance on their own.

title: AN INTERESTING EAST END MENU
description: HENRY'S ON THE CANAL in Hampton Bays, conveniently situated just off the Montauk Highway where it crosses the Shinnecock Canal, is a pleasantly understated restaurant. Dark wood paneling and beams contrast with stretches of white walls, sheer curtains float lazily in the open windows, and ceiling fans circulate the summer air in the high-ceilinged dining room.

title: SAVORING SEATTLE'S SALMON
description: SUSAN HERRMANN LOOMIS, a writer who specializes in food, is based in Seattle.

title: POLITICS TILTS THE DEBATE ON DEFENSE PLANS
description: WASHINGTON SENATE and House negotiators struggled last week to strike a compromise on one of the major issues still facing Congress, an authorization bill outlining the Pentagon's budget for the next fiscal year. By week's end, the talks seemed to be bogging down, and one of the negotiators, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, muttered, ''I'm discouraged. The deal now is not looking very good.''

title: MOSTLY MOZART: HOGWOOD CONDUCTS
description: Friday night's edition of the Mostly Mozart Festival was marred by some peculiar programming. The British conductor Christopher Hogwood, who may be our era's pre-eminent Mozartean, was in town, having temporarily forsaken his own Academy of Ancient Music to lead the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: THE MAN WHO DRESSED THE FILM STARS
description: -FIVE years ago, for his first solo assignment as a costume designer on a feature Hollywood film, Earl Luick created 3,000 outfits for 124 chorus girls, 24 showgirls and such then-unknown Warner Brothers contract players as Myrna Loy, Loretta Young and Ann Sothern. Along with John Barrymore, Frank Fay and Rin-Tin- Tin, they had all been assembled before the sound cameras to prove that the Brothers Warner could talk, sing and dance, and partly in Technicolor at that.

title: 'Problem' $8 Million Colt
description: The $8.25 million sale of a yearling half-brother to Devil's Bag last Monday night has been held up because of what sales officials describe as a ''problem'' with the colt's physical condition. The son of Northern Dancer and Ballade, consigned to the Keeneland Select Yearling Sale by Windfields Farm and purchased by Robert Sangster and partners, was given a rigorous series of veterinary examinations and X-rays by the purchasers.

title: Lawmaker, in Disguise, Checks on the Homeless
description: A Congressman grew a beard and lived as a street person on $5 a day, sleeping in church foyers and taking his meals at a mission house to write about problems of the homeless.

title: SWIMMING: MOFFET HAS NEW CONFIDENCE
description: Eleven members of the United States Olympic swimming team took part in a news conference the other day. Then the swimmers spread out for individual interviews.

title: Bernardine Dohrn
description: Bernardine Dohrn, a former leader of the Weather Underground who spent 11 years as a fugitive, passed New York's bar examination this year. But to practice, Miss Dohrn, who graduated from law school in 1967, had to be approved by the Committee on Character and Fitness of State Supreme Court.

title: DANCE: LIMON COMPANY IN SARATOGA
description: Saratoga Springs is best known in dance as the summer home of ballet. But modern dance reared its unruly head Thursday at the Little Theater of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center with a provocative program by the Jose Limon Dance Company.

title: HIGH-TECH FACES
description: -AGE TECHnology, as it has done in so many areas of modern life, has created the potential for dramatically altering beauty analysis. Through computers and video-display terminals, it is now possible for women to experiment with a seemingly endless number of facial looks without so much as altering a speck of their own mascara.

title: MUSIC VIDEO'S UNCERTAIN PAYOFF
description: The images flash, glow and then

title: WOMEN, POWER AND POLITICS
description: It amazes me that Jane Perlez and leaders of organized women's groups would even attempt to

title: Sara Glover, Peter Tucker Plan to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Harvey Glover Jr. of Locust, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Sara Ann Glover to Peter James Tucker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Duane Tucker Jr. of Pelham, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Sept. 15.

title: WILL CRITICS OF A LATER DAY GIVE INGE HIS DUE?
description: Miller, Williams, Inge. Only 25, 30 years ago people thought of them as a triumvirate, and the triumvirate seemed pukka and permanent, the theatrical equivalent of the kind of firm you'd trust to invest your money, or mount an advertising campaign for you, or take your enemies to court and win. Unluckily, time has not been equally friendly to all three partners. Words like ''classic'' and ''masterpiece'' were pretty liberally bandied about when ''Death of a Salesman'' and ''The Glass Menagerie'' came high-stepping onto Broadway this past season. But Inge's first great success, ''Come Back, Little Sheba,'' was far less rapturously received when it slipped into a rather less prestigious address downtown the other day. The impression given by one or two of my more eminent colleagues was that they'd have had a better time counting the hairs on the back of their hands, or maybe pulling them out.

title: WHERE IS THE ESTHETIC PULSE IN THIS PORTRAIT OF THE 70's
description: WASHINGTON

title: WHERE TENNYSON SHOUTED STANZAS
description: TOM PRIDEAUX, a former senior editor of Life magazine, is the author of several books on theater and art.

title: Composer Is Wed To Cece Critchley
description: Cecelia Jane Critchley, a daughter of Mrs. James J. Critchley of Forestville, Conn., and the late Mr. Critchley, was married yesterday to Clarke Kimberly Oler Jr., the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Oler of Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin and the bridegroom's father, the head of pastoral care at All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: THE HEAT IS STILL RISING ON NUCLEAR REACTORS
description: There was good news about the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania last week and bad news concerning the Grand Gulf reactor in Mississippi. Once again, however, the issue that emerged was less the nuclear plants themselves than it was their regulator, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: July 29, 1984
description: Fiction1 17 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam, $19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932. 2 26 LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $19.95.) Fictionalized account of the Civil War Presidency. 3 421 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.) A lawyer is caught in a conspiracy to seize the Western world. 4

title: WASTE INQUIRIES SET AT CHEMICAL PLANT
description: TOMS RIVER THE state's Division of Criminal Justice and the Department of Environmental Protection have begun separate investigations into the waste-disposal practices of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation's chemical plant here.

title: Raymond Carver's Reality
description: Thank you for giving us some insight into one of this century's greatest writers, Raymond Carver (''Raymond Carver: A Chronicler of Blue-Collar Despair,'' by Bruce Weber, June 24).

title: NADIA COMANECI STILL GLOWS AS IMAGES OF 1976 RECEDE
description: SHE is 22 years old now. The child whose fiery acrobatics electrified much of the world eight years ago is very much a woman. And, most surprising of all, Nadia Comaneci now smiles a lot.

title: Esther Pennacchia Weds
description: Esther Pennacchia, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mauro Pennacchia of New York, was married yesterday to Lieut.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL LOOKS LESS LIKELY
description: As Congress settled in for a brief between-conventions session last week, there were mounting indications that the much-fought-over immigration bill might not make it to President Reagan's desk after all.

title: No Headline
description: IN the last four weeks they have talked with little-known playwrights and a network theater critic, worked with stage lights and studio cameras, got plenty of advice and little sleep.

title: MAJESTY'S PRINCE WINS AT BELMONT
description: Majesty's Prince, an honest and consistent old millionaire, has made a career of often settling for the minor awards in thoroughbred racing's biggest grass races. But when the turf is soft, it moves the 5-year-old up a few lengths, which is what happened yesterday at Belmont Park and led to his easy score in the $249,700 Sword Dancer Handicap.

title: CHILD PRODIGY BECMES JAZZ VITUROSO
description: HAD Phil Markowitz been around in the 19th century, the young pianist and composer would have charted his career along the then traditional course. A child prodigy who began playing the piano at the age of 4 and composing at 8, he probably would have followed in the footsteps of Chopin and Liszt, performing his own compositions in pursuit of what he called the ''visceral experience that occurs when a composer-artist brings his work to life in public.''

title: Data Bank; July 29, 1984
JAZZ REACHES A MILESTONE ON L.I.
description: LIKE many crusaders for uncommon causes, Kathy Roberson speaks of her field of devotion with a sort of level-headed ardor. There is a job to be done, but it must be approached thoughtfully as well as enthusiastically.

title: STATE WRITING RENT RULES
description: THE State Division of Housing and Community Renewal is in the final stage of writing new regulations and procedures for an alternative method under which owners of rent- stabilized apartments may apply for hardship rent increases.

title: CUB 8-RUN EIGHTH ENDS METS STREAK AT 7
description: The Mets' seven-game winning streak came tumbling down yesterday when the Chicago Cubs scored eight runs in the eighth inning and buried them, 11-4.

title: LOCATION PUTS THE CLIFF IN A CLIFFHANGER AND THE GLOW IN ROMANCE
description: Seth Cagin is co-author of ''Hollywood Films of the Seventies.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
DRINKING AND DRIVING AND OTHER BAD MIXTURES
description: I APPLAUD the increased awareness of the

title: GIANTS' CAMP IS A COSTLY 'FACTORY'
description: To keep the Giants going this summer takes, among other incidentals, 4 cases of bananas, 200 pounds of beef and 30 dozen eggs daily; 400 towels and more than 500 footballs.

title: Impasse on Van Pelt
description: Brad Van Pelt, acquired July 12 from the Giants for Tony Galbreath, has accumulated $3,500 in fines for failing to report to the Minnesota Vikings' training camp and is talking about retiring to make ends meet. ''If worse comes to worse,'' said the five-time all-pro linebacker, ''I can always announce my retirement and get my severance pay.

title: MUSIC: WELSH CHOIR
description: A hearty blend of church and pub singing traditions has given Wales a special standing in choral music recognized throughout the world. Some of its choirs make their way round the globe to keep that tradition audible, and one of them, the Pendyrus Male Choir from Rhondda, South Wales, made a stop Thursday evening at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: A SIGNAL FROM CASTRO
description: President Fidel Castro's tone has become noticeably softer, more conciliatory toward the United States in recent weeks. On the 31st anniversary of his revolution and in the midst of economic trouble, the Cuban leader last week held out an olive branch that might extend as far as Angola, where he has between 25,000 and 30,000 troops.

title: DELAYS FEARED IN ROAD PROJECTS DURING INQUIRY ON BID RIGGING
description: ALMOST $30 million worth of road repair projects remain on hold in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, threatening the Island's $662 million, five-year highway improvement program.

title: SWEATING THE DEFICIT
description: The Government reported last week that consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in June, just as they did in May, for a compound annual rate of a mere 2 percent. Some economists warned that the low inflation rate, unusual in combination with the high growth rate reported earlier in the week, might have been a signal that the economy has been knocked off kilter by big Federal deficits.

title: JAZZ SWINGS BACK TO TRADITION
description: My experience with jazz, and with music in general, contradicts some of the statements made by Wynton Marsalis. He says, ''If you don't sound like someone else, you sound like nothing.''

title: Flip Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Sense of Fiscal Health Found Positive in Poll
description: Forty percent of the American public feels it is better off now financially than it was a year ago and a majority of Americans think they will be even better off a year from now, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title:
ANTIQUES;
175 DEALERS IN GLASTONBURY SHOW
description: LOCATED on ''Ye east side of ye great river,'' as old histories of Connecticut described it, the center of Glastonbury is a picture-book village of attractive and well-kept 18th-century homes.

title: LONG BEACH PLAN CRITICIZED
description: LONG BEACH'S move into the 80's is a tale of two cities: of a time in 1975, when city officials cringed in the face of bankruptcy, to the present, when a new administration can look over a city in the throes of economic revitalization and chart an ambitious master plan to further polish this ocean gem.

title: GETTING HELP BEFORE LEAVING ON A U.S. TRIP
description: PAUL GRIMES writes the Practical Traveler column.

title: Activists Free Animals From Pennsylvania Lab
description: Animal rights activists have destroyed valuable research by raiding University of Pennsylvania laboratories, abducting animals and stealing records, university officials say.

title: F.C.C. RAISES STATION-OWNERS' STATION LIMITS
description: As much as the Federal Communications Commission and public advocacy groups agree that diversity in broadcasting is a good thing, they disagree on how to achieve it.

title: OFFICE PICK-UP IN SIGHT FOR JOURNAL SQUARE
description: IN ITS look, feel and function as a public

title: THE MAGIC OF ZIA
description: The recent Reisinger Team final in New York had four remarkable features. The first was the manner in which the match began. In the initial segment of 14 deals the defending champions, headed by Peter Leventritt, were overpowered 74-1 in terms of international match points. This was the most convincing start in the 55-year history of the event, and virtually decided the issue. The Leventritt sextet fought back bravely and was within striking distance going into the final quarter but lost by 29 points.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HOW sick is the Long Island Lighting Company? Very, said Suffolk County in a motion before the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. And not very, according to the county in an argument in a hearing on the company's request for a rate increase.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: As a photogenic subject, she has few peers. She never moves, never blinks, never gets tired. For nigh on 100 years, until she was recently corseted in scaffolding, the Statue of Liberty has withstood the onslaughts of millions of Kodak-toting photographers.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection will receive a $1 million appropriation from the Legislature to improve one of its pollution- monitoring programs, but the sponsor of the appropriation bill still wants an investigation of the agency's administration of the entire program.

title: ILLINOIS HEAD ASSAILS N.C.A.A.
description: Chancellor John Cribbet, admitting that rules were broken - some intentionally - vowed today that the University of Illinois was committed to obeying National Collegiate Athletic Association rules but said some were outdated and should be changed.

title: HOW THE DEMOCRATS CAN WIN
description: At the risk of being promptly dispatched to the loony bin on a warrant sworn out by the conventional- wisdom dispensers, I can't get over the idea that the odds are shift- ing to the Democrats for November.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Imitation of life is what entertainment is all about and that's what Rich Little, man of miens, majors in. Tonight (July 29) from 8 to 9, Mr. Little, with his own all-star cast, does the latest in a string of shows he's been doing for Home Box Office, this one called ''Come Laugh With Me,'' direct to you direct from the Sands Hotel in Atlantic City.

title: TWO PIANISTS, ONE CONCERTO ADD UP TO A CASE OF OPPOSITES
description: When two pianists trained in Moscow play Chopin, the listener expects similarities - the same technical command we associate with Russian pianism, the emphasis on big sound and Romantic gesture, the seriousness and severity. Bella Davidovich and Ivo Pogorelich - quite the contrary - offer us recordings of the Chopin Concerto No. 2 in F minor which stand at opposite ends of the interpretive spectrum.

title: CHESS ; TALE TOLD BY TWO MASTERS
description: One of the most difficult psychological hurdles to get over is created by the slippery defender who seems to lead a charmed life. There is an unfortunate tendency to ascribe his capacity for survival to luck - and to let that rankle.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Bicycle Fines
description: An outcry was heard in New Jersey last year over a new state law under which youths 7 years old and above accused of violating vehicular laws no longer appeared in county juvenile courts. Instead, they had to appear in municipal courts, as do adults.

title: A RIGHTS MANUAL FOR NURSING-HOME PATIENTS
description: The rights of nursing-home patients - from the right to receive uncensored mail to the right to refuse medication - have been detailed in a new booklet published by a coalition of New York nursing-home patients.

title: FLACKING FOR THE KING OF KINGS
description: IN THE SERVICE OF THE PEACOCK THRONE

title: THE FAMILY ELEMENT
description: In Britain, and in those former colonies that still exercize some form

title: CHINA CALLS FOR NUCLEAR CUTS
description: A Chinese official said today that Peking would reduce its nuclear arsenal if the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to do the same. He added that China wanted to resume its ties with the international peace movement.

title: STALKING THE BIG TICKET - AND ITS COMMISSION
description: Mary Ellen Kay of Becker Paribas Inc. is cool and elegant. When she discusses the stock market, she speaks in even tones, her head tilted slightly and her eyes squinting knowingly. Making a new acquaintance, she says, ''I tend to keep people at arm's length.''

title: Susan Silverberg Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Silverberg and Louis J. Salerno 2d were married yesterday at the Wampus Lake American Inn in Armonk, N.Y., by Walter Lawton, leader of the Westchester Humanist Society.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WORLD FOOD DAY MEDAL
description: The resurgence of United States medallic art will be underscored Oct. 16 when the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) releases its annual World Food Day Medal.

title: CONECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MERIDEN city and police union officials were preparing briefs last week to put before a panel of arbitrators that is to resolve an unusual, 18- month-old contract dispute.

title: OLYMPIC DREAMS THAT GOT AWAY
description: MY dream of participation in the Olympic Games began some 24 years ago. With the lighting of the Olympic flame at the opening ceremonies yesterday in Los Angeles, it symbolically ended.

title: Sari Gay Bodi Married To E. A. Montgomery
description: Sari Gay Bodi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis J. Bodi of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric Alden Montgomery, a son of Robert L. Montgomery of Daytona Beach, Fla., and Martha K. Montgomery of Ormond Beach, Fla. The Rev. Francis R. Lewis performed the Methodist ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

title: COMPANION FOR A CHILDREN'S CLASSIC
description: For 44 years, ''Pat the Bunny'' has been one of the first books in a toddler's library. It has invited children to feel the softness of a bunny's fur, to smell flowers and to look at themselves in a mirror - all provided in a small ring- bound book.

title: OTHER WOMEN SEEKING NO. 2 SPOT SPEAK OUT
description: Andrea Gonzalez and Angela Davis admit to a trace of annoyance sometimes when they hear Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro toasted as the first woman in the nation to be a Vice- Presidential candidate.

title: John Crowe Ransom
description: To the Editor:

title: KIPS BAY PRICES RISE 40% AFTER MORATORIUM
description: -month moratorium on sales, sponsors of the condominium conversion at Kips Bay Towers say they have increased apartment prices to outside buyers by 40 percent.

title: Drinking and Driving: A Personal Experience
description: I am a recovering alcoholic. The recent article ''Drinking and Driving Can Mix'' (Opinion Page, June 3) and the responses (Letters to the Long Island Editor, June 17) prompt this, my second letter to a newspaper on the subject of drinking and driving.

title: Lisa Whitmore Wed to C. M. Mavrikis
description: Lisa Hughes Whitmore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Delano Whitmore of Los Angeles, and Constantin M. Mavrikis, the son of Mavrikios C. Mavrikis of Athens and the late Calliope Lazarou Mavrikis, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral in New York.

title: Argentina's Hidden Assets
description: In the article, ''Defending Argentina's New Democracy'' (June 10), Edward Schumacher points out that ''Argentine bankers and financiers have some $40 billion in personal assets stashed abroad.'' The financial pages of The New York Times in recent weeks have devoted many stories to the problem of Argentina's $43.6 billion foreign debt, owed largely to international banks - presumably most of the same banks in which Argentine bankers and financiers have stashed their assets.

title: THE BENEFITS OF AN UNBIASED ADVISER
description: The following excerpt is from an article written in 1970 by the late Arthur M. Okun.

title: THE SAME COMMUNISTS, ONLY WEAKER
description: In a nearly forgotten municipal election in Tours in the mid-70's, the French Communist Party ran a strange campaign. It offered potential voters neither red flags nor specific identification as Communists, but a symbolic green dot that, long before West Germany's ecolo-pacifists grabbed the idea, was supposed to signify youth and generosity. The test-market campaign flopped, and the French Communists went back to doing business the old way.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
PA'S BALLOON AND OTHER PIG TALES
description: Written and Illustrated by Arthur Geisert. 96 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Ann L. Fischhoff, A Teacher, Weds Graphic Designer
description: Ann Louise Fischhoff, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Fischhoff of Detroit, was married yesterday to Anthony Spagnola, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Spagnola of Woodbury, Conn. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the Unitarian ceremony at a loft in Manhattan.

title: AFFIRMATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Demolition Crew Razes San Diego Massacre Site
description: A demolition crew today razed the McDonald's restaurant in the border community of San Ysidro, where a gunman killed 21 people 10 days aago, leaving it an empty shell in preparation for the wrecker's ball.

title: WTAER SEEPAGE IN THE BASEMENT
description: MANY homeowners who have not had trouble with a damp basement before, or at least have not had trouble for years, have had problems with water in the basement after the heavy rains of spring and early summer. Although the first thing that many think of when trying to prevent this from happening again is to apply some type of sealer or waterproofing to the inside of the basement walls, the real problem almost always lies around the outside of the house.

title: Laura S. Kaynor Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Laura Smith Kaynor to William Fuller Powers has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Bull Kaynor of Darien, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Powers 3d of Barrington, R.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Mildred Burns to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Burns Jr. of Havertown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mildred Hammonds Burns to Denny Brereton Cutler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Cutler of Chestnut Hill, Mass. A fall wedding is planned.

description: Richard Reeves is a syndicated political columnist whose next book, ''Passage to Peshawar,'' will be published in September. THE NEOLIBERALS

description: Golconda, Nev.

title: SUMMER FARE IS JUST AT HAND
description: THE great thing about summer food is its immediacy. What is better than a salad made with fresh vegetables and herbs brought in from the garden (or farmers market) and dressed with a good olive oil? Even on the hottest days, whether it is a plate of ripe tomatoes with fresh basil, or young leafy greens sprinkled with orange or yellow nasturtium flowers, such a dish is tempting.

title: SITE WITH 2 LONG HOUSES FOUND IN MOHAWK VALLEY
description: One day in 1981, Donald Rumrill, a retired steamfitter and an amateur archeologist, discovered a fire-cracked rock, some beads and two flint arrow points in a cornfield overlooking the Mohawk River here.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: COPING WITH AIRPORT DELAYS
description: To many travelers, the frustration has become familiar. You are flying from Los Angeles to Kennedy International Airport in New York. Kennedy, however, is closed because of a severe thunderstorm and your flight lands at Newark instead. You look to the airline for help, but none is forthcoming. Your car is parked at Kennedy, but how and when you ultimately get there is up to you.

title: 'SPRING AT MARINO' IS A BOLD MOVE FOR IVORYTON PLAYHOUSE
description: IN ''Spring at Marino,'' the director William E. Hunt has come

title: THE LURES OF LONG BEACH ISLAND
description: SURF CITY TWO Long Beach Island craft establishments that have moved from one store to another in past summers are now permanently settled in this Ocean County community.

title: Manatt Says His Power In Party Is Undisturbed
description: Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic Party chairman, says he has seen no reduction in his power as a result of Walter F. Mondale's decision first to seek his removal and then not to do so, but he said he was not going to seek another term as chairman.

title: Boy, 7, Gets New Liver; Girl Has Heart Surgery By The Associated Press
description: A 7-year-old boy underwent a second liver transplant operation yesterday, while doctors said a 2-year-old girl released from a hospital after receiving a new heart could soon live a normal life.

title: Who's in Charge?
description: Kyle Petty, like his father, Richard, will leave Petty Enterprises and look for another ride on the Nascar Grand National Circuit next year.

title: STRETCHING THE CLARINET
description: ''Oh, if only we had clarinets,'' the peripatetic Mozart wrote to his father from Mannheim in 1778; ''you can't guess the lordly effect of a symphony with flutes, oboes and clarinets.''

title: Miss Murray Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., have announced he engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Galvin Murray, to Kevin Michael Livesey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Livesey of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. An October wedding is planned.

title: WRONG MAN WAS SLAIN IN PLANNED KILLING, DETECTIVES BELIEVE
description: Shortly after midnight on July 11, Anthony Williams, a 25-year-old pianist and organist, left his brother's apartment in the Wakefield section of the Bronx to return to his home in New Rochelle. Earlier that evening, Mr. Williams, who accompanied church choirs, had been at a rehearsal of his new gospel-music group, which had just recorded its first album.

description: To the Editor:

BUSINESS FORUM;

description: President Reagan exhorted American athletes, ''Set your sights high.'' The 93,000 seats in the Memorial Coliseum were filled, and parking spaces nearby cost as much as $75.

title: TOUCHING GESTURE Canadian
description: Prime Minister John M. Turner probably will be modifying his version of the glad hand.

description: -ON-HUDSON IN the final tally, the people

title: Withdrawal of Libyans From Games Is Official
description: Just hours before the opening ceremonies today, Libya officially withdrew from the Olympics.

title: Yankees Win, 3-2, After a Scary Ninth
description: Dave Righetti took a routine game, part of the other New York-Chicago baseball series this weekend, and made it exciting today by loading the bases with three straight walks after retiring the first two White Sox batters in the bottom of the ninth inning.

title: REAGAN DELIVERS A PEP TALK
description: President Reagan opened the Games of the XXIII Olympiad tonight with a brief formal declaration, then minutes later pronounced the Soviet Union the ''losers'' for having boycotted the games.

title: Jersey Youth, 15, Sentenced To Life for Killing Invalid, 83
description: A 15-year- old youth has been sentenced to life in prison for the beating death of an elderly invalid.

title: ELECTION-YEAR RHETORIC WORTH LISTENING TO
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPICS FOR THE OLYMPIANS
description: Alot of teeth have been unavailingly gnashed over the Soviet and Eastern Bloc boycott of the Olympic Games. The boycott is, of course, a major problem, but there is far more than that to worry about. The Olympic movement and the International Olympic Committee, or I.O.C., must rapidly come to grips with a host of key matters that simply will not go away: the absurd contradictions in determining amateur eligibility, the role of athletes themselves in charting the future of the games, the long-overdue enlargement of opportunities for women. Regrettably, the I.O.C. is out to lunch.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Gypsy Starring Rosalind Russell, Natalie Wood, Karl Malden; directed by Mervyn LeRoy, 1962 Warner Home Video 149 minutes. $59.95

title: PRODUCTION RECALLS RADIO SHOWS OF OLD
description: MONTCLAIR REMEMBER radio? Not the compact, automatic digital kind that awakens one in the morning to the tune of the traffic report or the portable ''big boxes'' that blare in the streets.

title: ON THE STREETS OF BRAZIL: PEDDLING UP, SALES DOWN
description: When Brazil's economic crisis began to bite deeply into urban employment last year, many of the newly jobless were forced to live off the streets, peddling everything from candies to water colors.

description: -school officials made a tour of the city's summer programs last week, but Dr. Columbus Salley, executive superintendent of the school system, the state's largest, was not among them.

description: As demolition of the 80,000-square-foot site of the former S. Klein department store nears completion, a clearer picture has emerged of what William Zeckendorf Jr. and Elie Hirschfield have planned for their their million-square-foot commercial and residential project at Union Square East.

description: John W. Hinckley Jr. last week told a Federal court in Washington that he was ready to seek a release hearing.

description: FREE pistol competition, which calls for ferocious concentration, launches the Olympic shooting events today.

description: LOS ANGELES Above all, the Israeli elections

description: WHEN will agriculture learn? An article in The New York Times last May 6 was headlined: Bumper Wheat Crop in Prospect Could Signal Problems for Reagan

title: Synthetic Gas Enters U.S. Commercial Market
description: Synthetic ''natural'' gas from the nation's first large-scale coal gasification plant began flowing into the interstate pipeline system today, the first time the fuel has been sold commercially in the United States.

title: Victoria McCain Wed To Andrew D. Carson
description: Victoria Hutchinson McCain, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hutchinson McCain of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Point O'Woods, L.I., and Andrew Doyle Carson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Doyle Irvin Carson of Dallas, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Daniel M. Young, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church at Point O'Woods.

description: St. George's, Grenada

description: Cape Cod, like most of the country's resort areas, is struggling to preserve vestiges of its rural character against an onslaught of development.

title: MEADOWLANDS ACTS TO CURB ROWDYISM
description: EAST RUTHERFORD THE New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has taken steps to curtail spectator violence and offensive behavior during contests at Giants Stadium here.

title: PRINCETON U. PLANS TO EXPAND PROFITABLE RESEARCH COMPLEX
description: Princeton University has announced major expansion plans for the Forrestal Center, a residential, research and corporate office park it owns in Plainsboro.

title: LONGEVITY IN A CONTRARIAN WORLD
description: At 87, Philip L. Carret is one of the grand old men of the investment business. In 1928 he started the Pioneer Fund. Today that Boston-based mutual fund has assest of $1.5 Billion and the parent company, the Pioneering Corporation, has almost $4 billion in individual and institutional assets.

title: Fueling the Fires Of Racial Polarization
description: Isn't it a shame that a person whose mother, together with her housekeeper, joined the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; whose daughter ''belongs to every liberal cause she can find'' and who keeps her business in crime-ridden Newark is still victimized by racial hatred?

title: Nuptials Planned By Lisa Emmons
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Emmons of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Lehren Emmons to Peter Landahl Thoren, the son of Mrs. Thomas A. Callaghan Jr. of Brussels and Washington and Arne Thoren of Baghdad, Iraq. A December wedding is planned.

title: GERMANYS TRAFFICKING IN PEOPLE
description: Two decades ago Erich Mende started buying political prisoners from East Germany. He wanted it kept secret.

title: Sarah L. English Marries Leonard Michael Mellon
description: Sarah Lucile English, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Winfield English of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Leonard Michael Mellon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Mellon of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Rates After Continental

title:
DINING OUT;
SEAFOOD IN A LANLOCKED SETTING
description: RESTAURANTS known for their ''all you can eat'' specials tend to be viewed by lovers of fine food in the same light as Bloomingdale's customers might view the corner ''five and dime,'' the premise being that, if you can eat as much as you like for a fixed price, then you're buying quantity but not quality.

title: 6 SAID TO DIE IN HINDU-MOSLEM VIOLENCE IN INDIA
description: A week of fighting between Hindus and Moslems in Hyderabad has left six people dead and 150 wounded, it was reported today.

title: NEW GALLERY OFFERS A DIFFERENT VIEW
description: JACQUES KAPLAN had no sooner opened the door to his little red caboose in Kent on a recent Saturday morning when a trio of visitors came marching up the stairs, waving their arms in a gallant military manner and singing ''La Marseillaise,'' the French national anthem.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: EVOKING THE SPIRIT OF MR. B.
description: WHEN Frank Ohman's New York Dance Theater performs next Saturday in Heckscher Park in Huntington, it will be more than an average summer outdoor night of ballet. The evening will hold special meaning for the company director, who this month has retired from the New York City Ballet after a career of 22 years.

title: September Wedding For Susan Coulehan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coulehan of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Diane Coulehan, to Peter R. Porcino, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Santi J. Porcino of East Norwich, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: OZONE PARK
description: Many a horse-racing fan knows Ozone Park as the home of ''the Big A.'' Just west of Aqueduct Racetrack is a community of some 70,000 residents, one of the most stable neighborhoods in New York City.

title: Canadian Tennis Star Ill
description: It looks as if Carling Bassett will miss the Olympics. The 16-year-old, ranked No. 1 in tennis among Canadian women, was forced to withdraw from the Canadian national championships with what has been diagnosed as infectious mononucleosis.

title: FOR 5 WEEKS, IT'S A VILLAGE
description: THE green-glistening fields of the campus at the State University of New York here stretch for acres in every direction, and rising monolithically and starkly in their midst are the bare purple-brown brick and stone buildings of the college's Center for the Arts.

title: THE UNTOLD STORY OF THE LODZ GHETTO
description: In two weeks, on Aug. 12, about 4,000 Jews who once lived in the wartime ghetto of the Polish city of Lodz will gather at the Concord Hotel in New York's Catskill Mountains. Many will be seeing each other for the first time since they were ''resettled'' from the ghetto to one of the Nazi death camps.

title: RELIGION FINDS A WAY TO GO TO SCHOOL
description: AFTER the Democrats served notice that they intended to carry the banner of traditional values in the Presidential campaign, the Republicans wasted no time in responding to the challenge. The first showdown in the battle over which party can claim to represent the side of church, family and patriotism came last week when the House of Representatives voted on two bills that sought to give religion a more prominent place in the schools.

title: Dorothy A. Clark Becomes a Bride
description: Dorothy Alice Clark, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Warner Clark of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Michael Simon Mickiewicz, a son of Mrs. Edward Mickiewicz of Springfield, Mass., and the late Mr. Mickiewicz. Canon David B. Lowry performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation.

title: OF GUN POSSESSION AND A MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY DECISION FOR ISRAELI COALITION
description: Ezer Weizman, whose party won three seats in Israel's parliamentary elections, was reported tonight to be leaning toward joining an effort by the Labor Party to form a coalition government.

title: Anette Hoegh Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Anette Hoegh to Philip Goelet has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ove Hoegh of Oslo, parents of the future bride. Her fiance, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Goelet of New York, is a research scientist at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: BEST OF TIMES
description: Except for politicians, election years are almost always the best of all possible years, and 1984 has been particularly outstanding.

title: AMATEUR TEAM IN ITS 46th YEAR
description: BILL SAVITT of Hartford remembers the days when his semi-pro baseball team, the Savitt Gems, drew crowds of more than 4,000 to the city's old Bulkeley Stadium in the 1930's, 40's and 50's.

title: AN ARTIST WHO TURNS CLOTH INTO SOCIAL COMMENTARY
description: Though Faith Ringgold, artist and activist, has traveled everywhere, she's never really left Harlem. She was born at Harlem Hospital (in 1930), grew up in the areas known as the Valley and Sugar Hill, and lives today on West 145th, in Dinah Washington's old apartment. She studied art at City College, whose nearby Gothic buildings she views affectionately from her apartment window. She and her second husband first met as kids in the neighborhood; together they brought up in Harlem, too, her own two daughters by an earlier marriage. To Mrs. Ringgold, who smiles at ''a sort of backwardness'' in herself that keeps her there, Harlem is a small town that radiates warmth and a sense of shelter, and its life and people loom very large in her art. So it's only fitting that this summer a local institution, the Studio Museum in Harlem, is devoting its main exhibition galleries to a Faith Ringgold retrospective, celebrating 20 years of her art (through Sept. 4).

title: Margaret Ijams Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Margaret Ditson Ijams to Wayne Alan Josephson has been announced by Alexandra Ainsworth Ijams of New York and Maitland Tabb Ijams of Barneveld, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Josephson of Arlington Heights, Ill.

title: Article on Lawyers Is Challenged
description: The New Jersey Weekly of July 1 included an article concerning women attorneys in New Jersey. The reporter interviewed me, an associate with the firm of Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch of Morristown, and 14 other women attorneys from various law firms.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION ;
SPEEDING REMAINS NO. 1 KKILLER
description: I APPLAUD the recent efforts to stiffen

title: Sandra Casber Is Wed To Rep. Robert Wise
description: Sandra Casber, a staff member of the House Ways and Means Committee, was married yesterday to Representative Robert E. Wise Jr., Democrat of West Virginia. The Rev. James E. Ford, Chaplain of the House of Representatives and a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in his office at the Capitol.

title: POLAND WOOS THE WEST AND HOPES FOR BENEFITS
description: A week ago Poland began to appear, if not all sweetness and light, considerably more conciliatory than it has been since it cracked down on Solidarity and imposed martial law in December 1982. The Government declared an amnesty for political and other prisoners, and President Reagan, who has been insisting on such moves, suggested last week possible rewards like the dropping or easing of sanctions.

title: HIGH-TECHNOLOGY BOND ISSUE ON JERSEY BALLOT
description: Governor Kean signed legislation this week that places on the November ballot a $90 million bond issue that would help finance the expansion of high-technology industries in the state.

title: PRESCRIBING AGAINST TERROR
description: Taylor Branch, a Washington writer, is at work on a biography of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. MISSILE ENVY

title: Virginia Groton Weds Thomas Goelz, Broker
description: Virginia C. Groton, a daughter of Calvert C. Groton of Providence, R.I., and the late Mary Jane Clark Groton, was married yesterday to Thomas Goelz, a son of Charles V. Goelz of New York and the late Sally Scannell Goelz. The Rev. Alexander Ogilby performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Weekapaug Chapel in Rhode Island.

title:
STAMPS;
TRIBUTE FOR THE ROLE OF JUNIOR ACHIEVEMENT
description: Horace Moses, industrialist and philanthropist, founded a movement called Junior Achievement. It enabled teen-age boys to learn about business through doing. This enterprise won Horace Moses a place on a new 20-cent United States commemorative which comes out Aug. 6 in Bloomington, Ind.

title: VIRIGINIA WOOLF: GREAT MISERIES AND GREAT JOYS
description: Excerpted from ''The Diary of Virginia Woolf,'' Vol. 5, by Virginia Woolf, edited by Anne Olivier Bell. Diary copyright c 1984 by Quentin Bell and Angelica Garnett. To be published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc.

title: WOMEN, POWER AND POLITICS
description: With Indira Gandhi running India and Margaret Thatcher Prime Minister in Britain, what's so ground-breaking about a woman on the Democratic ticket for Vice President of the United States? Traditionally, that's where a good woman should be found - beside every great man. MALVINE COLE Jamaica, Vt.

title: STATELY RIVALRY
description: PHYLLIS LEE LEVIN is completing a biography of Abigail Adams.

title: FEELING RIGHT AT HOME, IN SHEA AND NEW YORK
description: WHEN I was hit with the news of my trade to the Mets, I thought for sure June 15, 1983 would be my personal day of infamy. Of course now, in the summer of 1984, in the midst of our quest for the pennant, I have a totally different perspective on that day. The infamy has turned to ecstasy and I couldn't be prouder to be a New York Met.

title: NEW PAGE IN BRIDGEPORT'S POLICE STORY
description: In 22 years as Bridgeport's Police Superintendent, Joseph A. Walsh has accumulated plenty of admirers and detractors, but even they could agree on one thing: Dull he is not.

title: DUARTE GAINS ON FOREIGN FRONT
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte may be no closer to peace in El Salvador than he was June 1 when he took office, but last week he continued to gain support abroad. After winning a West German pledge to resume $18 million in aid and a welcome from the hitherto standoffish French Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, Mr. Duarte got reasons for encouragement on his second visit to Washington.

title: JAZZ: THE SURVIVIORS BAND
description: Ramsey McLean and the Survivors are an avant-gutbucket band, New Orleans-style. Mr. McLean, a bassist, writes and selects tunes that give the band leeway to improvise yet maintain a bluesy foundation - and plenty of New Orleans's second-line swing.

title: CITY TRIES TO SAVE CRIME INSURANCE
description: Mayor Koch and a bipartisan group of members of Congress from New York State have called for the extension of a Federal program to provide insurance for homes and small businesses in high- crime areas.

title: Bartenders Postpone Strike
description: Bartenders in the Irish capital postponed a strike today that threatened to close 700 pubs. Six hours before the normal pub opening time of 11 A.M., the union and the pub owners' association issued a statement saying the walkout had been deferred pending new talks next week.

title: BASKETBALL: 2 GOLDS ENVISIONED FOR U.S.
description: The teams have little in common when they consider where they've come from and where they're headed after the last Olympic basketball games are played. But while they're here, competing at the Forum, the United States men's and women's basketball teams share both the expectations of a gold medal and a strictly defined plan to reach the victory stand.

title: 'SHE WINDS ME UP'
description: ED BURKE remembers the day his hammer crashed through the window of his car, hitting his wife, Shirley, on the side of the head.

title: CAN MONEY AND TIME MAKE CALIFORNIA A GREAT ART CENTER?
description: Ever snce Nathanael West blew the whisle on Los Angeles in 1939 in his novel ''The Day of the Locust,'' and ever since Evelyn Waugh in 1948 blew another sharp blast in his long story ''The Loved One,'' people on he Eastern Seaboard have had trouble taking Los Angeles quite seriously. In Particular, the cultural scene in Los Angeles has often been discounted as erratic, ill-informed, sometimes nonexistent and in any case much too far away. The museums, in particular, never seemed to get their act together. The Pasadena Museum, a stronghold of contemporary art in the 1960's, later lost that position altogether. The Los Angeles County Museum, at one time bulked out with massive loans from the Norton Simon collection, suddenly found that those loans were walking out the door.

title: OPERA: PUCCINI DOUBLE BILL IN PARK
description: With Metropolitan and New York City Opera ticket prices spiraling ever higher, we owe a debt to any organization that provides free performances. Still, Thursday night's presentation was a frustrating affair.

title: Death on the Windy Dunes
description: THE first question is, Did Tim Madden, drunk and drugged, murder Jessica Pond? If not, who did? And in any case, how did Jessica Pond's severed head turn up in Madden's marijuana patch in Truro?

title: No Headline
description: Claire McCabe Affianced

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival turned to chamber music at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday night. The featured instruments were the recorder - that most accessible of wind instruments - and the French horn, whose technical vagaries have defeated otherwise able musicians for centuries.

title: STEPPARENTS AND DIVORCE: KEEPING TIES TO CHILDREN
description: When Kate Gerwig, a magazine editor in Washington, was divorced two years ago she fully expected to feel all the pain normally associated with the breakup of a marriage.

title: RAISING SIGHTS BY RAZING SITES?
description: Mayor Koch said last week that he might have to sell some of the Lower East Side in order to save it. Mr. Koch said that he and city housing officials think they can stimulate a restoration of the blighted neighborhood by auctioning off some vacant city- owned property to developers and then using the proceeds to renovate city-owned apartments.

title: The Majority's Voice
description: George Gallup, who died last week at 82, belonged to a generation of entrepreneurial pollsters who sought to learn what ''the common man'' was thinking. He also developed a deep commitment to reporting those views, lest they be trampled by powerful special interests.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The British series ''Family Classics,'' currently being carried on WNET/Channel 13 on Saturday evenings at 7, turns this week to a rebroadcast of a six-part adaptation of Noel Streatfeild's ''Ballet Shoes.'' A distinctive tone of no-nonsense bluster saves this popular children's story from tumbling into sugary depths.

title: Jane K. Baumgardner Plans Nuptials
description: Jane Kohl Baumgardner, an assistant vice president in the North American division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, plans to be married Sept. 22 to Walter Granruth 3d, an associate in the corporate finance department at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York.

title: Judith Francis and Daniel Landes, Lawyer, Marry
description: Judith Ann Francis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Francis of Isla del Sol, St. Petersburg, Fla., and Chestertown, N.Y., was married at the First Reformed Church in Hasting-on-Hudson, N.Y., yesterday to Daniel Adam Landes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack S. Landes of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerald Koster, interim pastor of the church, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman.

title: ASIANS GALVANIZE SALES ACTIVITY IN FLUSHING
description: A VACANT lot on 41st Avenue just west of

title: A CHEMICAL KEY TO DEPRESSION
description: Mania or serious depression may affect 10 million Americans at any given time. These illnesses were long considered purely psychological, but in recent years many have come to believe there is a physical component - an inherited abnormality that predisposes some people to suffer from depression, for example, when subjected to stress.

title: MORRIS BEATEN ON ERROR
description: A throwing error by the third baseman Howard Johnson allowed two runs to score in the eighth inning and the Boston Red Sox went on to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 3-2, tonight.

title: METHODISTS ELECT 19 TO LEADERSHIP
description: The United Methodist Church, usually considered the church body most representative of American society, has chosen a new group of bishops that includes an unusual diversity of women and members of minority groups.

title: Arafat Visiting Baghdad
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived here today for talks with Iraqi leaders on the Iran-Iraq war and on Palestinian ssues.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SCOOPS
description: ANDY HEARN remembers the big old Buick. In the days before such flavors as bubble gum and banana marshmallow, he and his brothers and sisters and cousins would pile into the family car, drive to the nearest ice cream stand and liven up the summer evening with chocolate and vanilla cones.

title: ALL THOSE VIBES
description: Any fan of Lionel Hampton - and who isn't? - will be passing up a bargain Thursday evening if he doesn't make a pilgrimage to New Brunswick. That's where the elder statesman of jazz will be leading his orchestra and playing the vibraphone in a free outdoor concert.

title: Henry Clay Huth Jr. Marries Barbara King
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday Barbara Huntington King, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Austin King of Riverside, was married to Henry Clay Huth Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Huth of Elkhart, Ind. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Philip E. Perkins, assisted by the Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Calzone Chez Brooklyn
description: After reading ''Getting to Know Calzone'' (Food column, July 8), I must ask whether Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey have ever visited the humble neighborhood of Bensonhurst, in Brooklyn. Ah, well, perhaps it's not on their gustatory map.

title: A SEVERE CASE OF FRUSTRATION IN HOSPITAL STRIKES
description: Efforts to resuscitate talks to end a strike against 41 New York City hospitals and nursing homes failed again last week, as the walkout - now in its 17th day - became the longest health-care strike in the city's history.

title: Airline Meals
description: To the Editor: The Travel Section has run articles in which information on obtaining special diets for airplane travelers has been included. An im

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The arrival of Horace Silver in New York is not quite as predictable as the arrival of the seasons. You can depend on it happening, but you can't be sure when Mr. Silver is going to make his visit. In 1979, he came in April; in 1981, in February; in 1982, in May. And this year, here he comes in July - the very tag end of July, opening on Tuesday at the Blue Note for a six-day engagement.

title: NEW JERSEY COURT DOESN'TKEEP ITS OPINIONS TO ITSELF
description: In a dissent written in 1950, Arthur T. Vanderbilt, the first Chief Justice of New Jersey's newly revamped Supreme Court, captured what was to become the tribunal's operating credo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no longer East nor West Beirut. It's now a united Lebanon with a united capital.'' - Brig. Gen. Mohammed Al-Hajj, of the Lebanese Army. (1:6.)

title: APPETIZERS WITH A BITE
description: I STRONGLY SUSpect that if you asked the average American - even one who is keen on, and relatively conversant with, the cooking of Mexico - to name more than four Mexican appetizers, you would be hard put for a reply. The answer would probably be guacamole, seviche, nachos and carnitas.

title: DAUM GLASSWARE TO THE FORE
description: For more than 25 years New York has been a leading sales center for the glasswares of the major Art Nouveau and Art Deco producers, with one notable expection - Daum, the French glass factory founded more than a century ago in Nancy. Throughout its history, Daum has been upstaged by such giants as Emile Galle and Rene Lalique.

title: DRIVERS FUME OVER DELAYS ON LICENSES
description: WHEN she received notice that her driver's license was due for renewal, Geraldine Longo of the Camden County community of Berlin chose the middle of the day, in the middle of the week, in the middle of the month to take care of the chore at the Division of Motor Vehicles' agency here.

title: GLOBAL STUDY SAYS HEALTH CARE LAGS
description: Primary health care procedures, clean drinking water and sanitation could save the lives of 7 million children a year in the poorest countries at relatively little cost, according to a paper produced for a Washington research organization.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: DEEP SEA DIVERS REPORT FINDING EXOTIC LIFE
description: Scientists said today that they had found exotic marine life surrounding hot water vents a mile below the surface of the Pacific Ocean off Oregon.

title: GYMNASTICS: HOPES FOR U.S. ARE HIGH
description: Americans have improved dramatically in gymnastics in the past decade, so dramatically that this year's United States Olympians are expected to win medals for the first time since the men won several individual medals in 1932. The American women have never won any medal, team or individual, in the history of the Games.

title: SANDINISTAS SEEK TO WIN CREDIBLY
description: Opposition leaders, who thought they had a standard-bearer for the November presidential election, were euphoric last week at the long-awaited return of their most prominent champion, Arturo Jose Cruz. The American-educated Mr. Cruz, an economist who quit his job at the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington to campaign against the ruling Sandinista Front, was mobbed by several hundred cheering supporters at Augusto Cesar Sandino airport. Police stood by unobtrusively as the crowd chanted ''Democracy yes, Communism no!''

title: Women, Power and Politics
description: In less than one year, the idea of a woman on the Presidential slate has gone from feminist fantasy to political reality; from the advocacy of women's groups to the support of party and elected officials of both genders (''Women, Power and Politics,'' by Jane Perlez, June 24).

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; State Insect
description: The Karner blue butterfly and the ladybug were locked in battle in recent years to see if either would become New York's official insect.

title: HOW MUCH CONFIDENCE IN THE BANKS WILL $4.5 BILLION BUY?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Racing Without Wheels
description: His father is the only four-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, but Tony Foyt has been succeeding on a different track. The son of A. J. Foyt is the second-leading trainer at Churchill Downs this summer.

title: VOLLEYBALL FINALS AT PLAYLAND TODAY
description: RYE MARINE Lieut. Dave Sammel of Yorktown obligingly agreed last Sunday to check in the players scheduled to compete at Playland in the opening session of the Westchester County Beach Volleyball tournament.

title: THE LURE OF A HEFTY DOLLAR
description: With the dollar spurting to record highs against most of the world's major currencies, Americans overseas are enjoying a salary windfall: In many Western countries, housing, food and travel are, at the moment, substantially cheaper than at home.

title: STATE CRACKS DOWN ON DRIVERS WITHOUT INSURANCE
description: The State Department of Motor Vehicles has begun a computerized crackdown on uninsured motorists in an effort to remove 500,000 illegally operated vehicles from the state's roads.

title: BUILDING A FORTUNE OUT OF A WINDFALL
description: PENSACOLA, FLA.

title: SEAFOOD AT A FAIR PRICE
description: THE Chello Oyster House in Guilford, whose sign is visible from Interstate 95, has been beckoning travelers with a choice of fresh seafood at modest prices for almost 50 years. Still run by the Chello family, the no-frills restaurant is well worth a detour for the hungry, seafood-loving traveler.

title: Mason Funeral Tuesday
description: The funeral of James Mason, the British-born actor who died Friday of a heart attack, will be held Tuesday at the All Saints English Church in Vevey, the Rev. Alex Ross, pastor of the church, said today. He said the service would begin at 11 A.M. and that he believed it would be open to the public. He said he had no information about burial plans.

title: LONGER KINDERGARTEN DAYS
description: LONGER kindergarten days this fall in a number of county school districts have prompted new concerns about planning effective programs. A group of kindergarten teachers from Westchester and Putnam Counties recently attended an intensive institute in Manhattan at Columbia University's Teachers College that was designed to help them successfully prepare and carry out all-day kindergarten programs in their communities.

title: HINTS ON TAPING CD'S
description: As compact disks proliferate among the progressive wing of the listening population, many audio fans are dubbing these CD's onto cassettes, just as they used to do with ordinary LP records. Leaving aside those aspects of duplicating copyrighted material which are matters of law or conscience, there may be many reasons for such dubbing. You may want to make a cassette copy from your CD to play in the car, or perhaps to share the music with a friend who - like most listeners - does not yet have a CD player.

title: NEXT EDUCATION DEBATE: QUALTITY OF TEXTBOOKS
description: With debate still raging over such issues as merit pay for teachers and stiffer graduation requirements for students, political and educational leaders across the country are moving to sharpen the quality of textbooks.

title: SYMPOSIUM TO AIR MUSICIAN TENSIONS
description: PRINCETON FOR performing artists, wrestling with the problems of physical and psychological tension is a serious business, and for most performers one major challenge is achieving a balance retaining the positive elements of performing energy without entering the debilitating range of tension.

title: A Bank Held Up by Government
description: Continental Illinois Bank is being nationalized. Much as it must pain the Administration to find that free-market remedies aren't always best, Government is taking over. Thanks be for Government.

title: A FREE GUID TO ARM'S
description: Adjustable-rate mortgages account for nearly 60 percent of home mortgages being written, according to the Federal National Mortgage Association, popularly known as Fannie Mae.

title: THE METHOD AND MAGIC OF THE SUPERBROKER
description: They are a breed apart. Superbrokers: an elite
