description: Question:

title: COUNTRY FAMILY EMBRACES CITY GIRL IN FRESH AIR FUND
description: With one hand holding her nose, the other over her heart, 10-year-old Nila Spence nervously sat on the edge of the diving board, swinging her legs and waiting for it to happen.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Coach Bill Walsh of the San Francisco 49ers certainly did not sound as if it were his money that was going to help make Ronnie Lott the highest paid defensive back ever in the National Football League.

title: THE FEAR OF BORING LEADS TO NONSENSE AT THE OPERA
description: Lurking inside every artist's breast, admit it or not, is a terrible, cold anxiety: the fear of boring. It is like some monster from the deep that must be constantly beaten back and kept out of view so as not to horrify the public. More than any other single factor, I have come to think, the fear of boring audiences accounts for the rash of desperately contrived productions that have disfigured the face of opera in recent years. It has been suggested, with some reason, that the scarcity of important singers has forced opera houses to let stage directors to take over the asylum. However, there obviously is more to it than that. Even on those rare festive occasions when starry casts can be assembled, the singers are often treated as props in a vaudeville show. Trying to hear the music in some opera performances has become a frustrating game.

title: DRIVER WHO RAMMED PEDESTRIANS, KILLING ONE, WAS ANGRY AT POLICE
description: The man who drove a car onto a crowded Westwood sidewalk, killing a teen-ager from Queens, injuring 54 people and scattering others in a festive crowd on the eve of the opening of the Olympic Games here, has told the police the incident had nothing to do with the Games.

title: COUNTRY ROADS GET CITIFIED
description: WHEN Lyn and Mark Murphy of Goshen, a small rural community northwest of Torrington, used to give directions to their home, they would say: ''Go north on Route 63 from the rotary to the fifth house on the right. It's a white colonial with yellow shutters.''

title: JACOBSEN, WITH 64, LEADS TOURNEY
description: Peter Jacobsen called the back nine of the new Tournament Players Club of Connecticut ''awkward,'' even though there was nothing awkward about his game today. He shot an 8-under-par 63 to take a one shot lead in the 33d annual Sammy Davis Jr. Greater Hartford Open at 14-under- par 199.

title: TO PRESERVE THE BIG DITCH
description: Jose A. Cabranes, former General Counsel of Yale University and an international lawyer, is a Federal district judge for the District of Connecticut. PANAMA ODYSSEY

title: POLL SHOWS CANADA'S LIBERALS ARE STILL IN THE LEAD
description: Canada's governing Liberal Party continues to lead opposition parties in the campaign for the Sept. 4 general election, according to a Gallup Poll issued Friday. But developments since the poll was taken three weeks ago suggest the opposition Progressive Conservative Party may be closing the gap.

title: JOBS IN SPACE CAN'T BE LEFT TO MACHINES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: A NEW JERSEY artist, Esther Rosen of Teaneck, is packing up a piece of New York City and taking it to Tokyo.

description: To the Editor: I read with great inter

title: 2 RACE TRACKS IN COMEBACKS
description: THE notion that horse racing in New Jersey is in a decline has seemed nowhere more apparent than in the fire-ravaged condition of two of the state's oldest tracks, Garden State Park and Freehold Raceway.

description: To the Editor:

title: PRESSURE TO CHANGE BANKING BUILDS AFTER A NEAR DISASTER
description: The near-collapse of one of the nation's biggest banks and the resulting $4.5 billion Government rescue last week has convinced many bankers, business people and economists that profound changes are needed in the world banking system to prevent even more serious disasters.

title: FESTIVALS FILL SUMMER AIR
description: UNLIKE virtually all other summer concerts in the county, the Estherwood Festival programs in Dobbs Ferry are linked, Tanglewood-style, to a summer school of music. Many of the artists at the open recitals are also on the Estherwood faculty, and students will dominate the performing ensembles at the two final programs of the festival, Aug. 12 and 19.

title: The Last Non-Olympics
description: ''I declare open the Olympic Games of Los Angeles,'' the President proclaimed, and so the XXIII Olympiad began. Despite the Russians' bruising boycott, the Games bring the most contestants ever. But let these be the last of the modern non-Olympics.

title: IN THE ARCTIC, JEWELRY INSPIRED BY THE LAPPS
description: RUTH ROBINSON is an editor in the Style section of The New York Times.

title: SCALPERS ASKING $100 OR MORE FOR TICKETS TO JACKSON SHOWS
description: A variety of scalpers, capitalizing on the popularity of the singer Michael Jackson and his brothers, are charging $100 or more for a ticket to the Jacksons' Victory Tour, which arrives at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands tonight.

title: Diane Fisher and Bruce Johnson Wed
description: Diane Randolph Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Rowe Fisher of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruce Kenneth Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Kenneth Johnson of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: 'SOMEBODY'S GOT TO HANG ON'
description: INDIAN COUNTRY

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS AT MIDSUMMER
description: NOW that most flowering annuals and vegetables have been planted and are well on their way to maturity, one observation is worth noting. Those plants that were yellow, stunted and excessively hardened off when planted have not performed as well as their dark green, vigorous counterparts. Even at season-ending bargain prices, they were no bargain.

title: CHILDREN'S EXPRESS ON THE TRAIL OF NEWS
description: the adult press, that is - laughed when Bob Blumenfield, a 16-year-old Scarsdale resident, decided to play a hunch in San Francisco during the Democratic National Convention.

title: U.S. IS INSTITUTING A PLAN TO REDUCE HOSPITAL DEATHS
description: The Federal Government has set up a program intended to force doctors and hospitals to eliminate ''avoidable deaths'' and ''substandard care.'' The American Hospital Association and other national medical organizations say the program is unreasonable and unrealistic.

title: WORLD'S SURGING BIRTHRATE TOPS THE MEXICO CITY AGENDA
description: Below, a sampling of views on population and its consequences from experts and leaders around the world. Robert S. McNamara

title: BIG CHALLENGE FOR SALVADOR: ITS ECONOMY
description: Fidel Chavez Mena, the Salvadoran Planning Minister, has a problem. How does he encourage investment, employment and production in a country in the midst of a civil war?

title: TENNESSEE LAW JAILS 150 FOR DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: More than 150 people reported to jail Friday evening to begin serving 48-hour sentences under Tennessee's toughened drunken driving law.

title: MORE SPARRING OVER NAMBIA
description: The path to independence for South-West Africa or Namibia, the continent's last colony, continues to be a tortuous one. Last week for the first time, the two main adversaries - South Africa, which administers the territory against the will of the United Nations, and the South-West Africa's People's Organization - met alone in official talks in the Cape Verde Islands.

title: Eric L. Lewis to Wed Elise Hoffmann
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Arthur K. Hoffmann of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Elise Jordan Hoffmann, to Eric L. Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Lewis of Brooklyn.

title: Teenoso Wins at Ascot In $210,000 Stakes
description: Teenoso, ridden by Lester Piggott, today won one of Europe's richest horse races, the $210,000 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Diamond Stakes.

title: CONGRESS PUSH ON REAGAN PLAN IS SET BY G.O.P.
description: Republican leaders in Congress are planning an aggressive effort in the coming weeks to promote the legislative agenda outlined by President Reagan at his news conference Tuesday and in political advertisements being broadcast across the country.

title: Q&A
description: We own a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan that has fallen into major disrepair. It recently became vacant and instead of simply making cosmetic changes, we have decided to make major renovations including creating a new entrance, replacing a window with french doors to the garden, adding windows, remodeling the kitchen and bath and adding new closets and hallways. Would this apartment qualify for fair-market rental? If not, can we add these costs to the next tenant's rent? . . . M. G., Manhattan

description: IN these days of high summer 70 years ago, the major European powers plunged into World War I. Austria declared war against Serbia on July

title: PAST PAIN MAKES GRENADIANS WARY OF POLITICIANS
description: Grenada's appointed interim Government, which sees itself largely as a caretaker, has said elections for a new government will be held before the end of the year. But many Grenadians say they wish the elections would be delayed.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SCULPTURE GARDENING

title: BOARD WEIGHS NEW RENTS AMID ATTACKS
description: THE Westchester Rent Guidelines Board, working at two-thirds strength, was moving toward a decision last week on rent levels for 62,500 apartments. At the same time, it was under attack by landlords because of the current rent freeze while waging its own attack on its parent state agency for what the board sees as a pro-landlord position.

title: James Agee
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS GET UNDER WAY
description: HARTFORD WITH no primary election challenges to interfere, the campaigns for Connecticut's six seats in the United States House of Representatives began in earnest last week, with the last of the district nominating conventions.

description: Transformation Scene

title: 2 U.S. TELESCOPES TO BE THE LARGEST
description: After almost a quarter century of debate, final designs have been chosen for two optical telescopes, each of which will be far larger than any now in existence.

title: Miss Phillips Wed In College Chapel To a Psychiatrist
description: Katharine Anne Phillips, a summa cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College and a student at its Medical School, was married in Hanover, N.H., yesterday to Dr. Ralph Stephen Albertini, an assistant professor of clinical psychiatry at the Dartmouth Medical School. The Rev. Richard Hyde, a Church of Christ minister and an associate chaplain at Dartmouth, performed the ceremony in the Rollins Chapel on the college campus.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Betty Boop NTA Home Entertainment 90 minutes. $39.95

title:
ABOUT MEN;
SON OF A WRITER
description: PEOPLE OFTEN ASK ME if it is difficult being a writer, and a writer's son. Like so many important questions, this one has no easy answer. Being anybody's son is a formidable task. The fathers and sons of this world are ever in conflict, giving love and doing battle. As for the profession of the writer, it has driven countless men to drink, madness and suicide.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SEAT BELT LAW BRINGS 'BIG BROTHER' CLOSER TO HOME
description: satisfaction this year because we have looked around and realized that George Orwell's predictions have not come true. Big Brother is not watching us after all. We rejoice in our good fortune to have been born when and where and feel relatively safe in our surroundings.

title: OPERA: 'CAVALLERIA' AND 'PAGLIACCI'
description: Friday night at the State Theater the New York City Opera put on ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''I Pagliacci,'' in productions directed several years ago by Frank Corsaro, who returned to supervise their revival this season.

CAMERA;
BASIC RULES FOR TAKING PORTRAITS IN SUMMER;
description: Frederic W. Rosen is a freelance photographer and writer.
