description: Nina Auerbach , who teaches at the University of Pennsylvania, is the author of ''Woman and the Demon: The Life of a Victorian Myth.'' u DOUBTING CASTLE

title: RECALLING THE HALCYON DAYS OF THE LUXURY LINERS
description: The remnants of an era are scattered.

title: BURFORD CRITICIZES COMMITTEE
description: Anne McGill Burford, who resigned under fire last year as head of the Environmental Protection Agency, was critical this weekend of opponents of her appointment to a Federal panel and called the advisory committee ''a nothing-burger.''

title: SUBWAY-ACCESS DISUTE SETTLED
description: Plans to renovate 50 New York City subway stations took a significant step forward last week, while efforts to maintain existing equipment on the region's subways, buses and commuter railroads continued to backslide.

title: STANDOFF DIMS ISRAELI HOPES FOR CHANGE
description: JERUSALEM '' IT'S still like Eastern Europe, with every rabbi surrounded by his own group,'' said a former Labor government official who was disgusted with the confusion created by Israel's latest election, the multiplicity of political parties and Labor's own weaknesses. '' 'If you don't like my synagogue,' '' he said, quoting the imaginary rabbi, '' 'go start your own.' ''

title: Burundi's President Wins a New Term
description: President Jean-Baptiste Bagaza of Burundi has been re-elected for a second term as leader of the ruling United Party for National Progress, allowing him to remain leader of this central African country for five more years, officials said today.

title: HOW THE NORTH LOST THE PEACE
description: THE ROAD TO REDEMPTION

title: EXPRESS TRAIN MAKING IT EASIER TO GET TO THE SHORE
description: NEWARK THERE aren't too many ways of beating traffic jams to and from the Jersey Shore on summer weekends - the Garden State Parkway is notorious for its bumper-to-bumper lines of buses and cars - but NJ Transit has come up with what may be one answer to the problem: Express train service, which began on Memorial Day weekend and will continue through Labor Day.

title: 2 Tons of Hashish in 40 Bags Found Along Coast of Spain
description: The Spanish police have picked up more than two tons of hashish floating in the ocean or washed up on beaches in plastic bags near this resort on the east coast, officials said today.

title: BIG PISTOL CAPTURES HASKELL BY A NECK
description: Big Pistol held off a late charge by Birdie's Legend today to win the $200,000 Amory L. Haskell Invitational Handicap by a neck at Monmouth Park. Locust Bayou was third, nine lengths farther back.

title: THE CANDIDATES COMMENCE FIRING
description: If the rest of the Presidential campaign maintains the tone of its first week, it's going to be a rip-snorter. Promises were tossed out, gauntlets were thrown down, accusations flew and fears arose.

title: MONEY SMOOTHS GERMAN TIES
description: Whatever the state of East-West tensions, the two Germanys seem determined to get along with each other for practical and sentimental reasons. Last week, the West German Government approved $333 million in private bank credits to cash- hungry East Germany in exchange for easing travel between the two ideologically split states.

title: CONTEMPT FOR ACADEMICS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harness Racing In Its Own Right
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Adelene Hall Has Nuptials
description: Adelene Dean Hall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Crane Hall of Cranford, N.J., and Grafton, Vt., was married in Grafton yesterday to Harold Eric Reindel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Reindel of St. Davids, Pa. The Rev. Patrick McLoud performed the Protestant ceremony at the White Church.

title: WELCH WINS ON 2-HITTER
description: Bob Welch overcame early wildness to pitch a two-hitter, retiring 24 of the next 25 batters he faced, as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 1-0, today.

title: 'SUNDAY IN THE PARK' ILLUMINATES SONDHEIM'S ART
description: The cast album recording of Stephen Sondheim's musical, ''Sunday in the Park With George'' (RCA HBC1- 5042), is an altogether admirable achievement. It satisfies the needs of those who have already seen the show for an aural refresher, not just documenting the musical numbers but knitting them together with key bits of dialogue to make a more effective sonic equivalent of the show's multimedia experience. And it serves as a compelling musical statement by itself, testifying to Mr. Sondheim's skills not just as a musical dramatist but as a composer in the abstract and, even, as an esthetic theoretician.

title: SCHOLARS SEEKING NEW HORIZONS
description: RON GROSS graduated from Syracuse University in 1956 and took a job at Simon & Schuster. Shortly afterward, Max Schuster, one of the company's founders, called the young man into his office for what had become the standard homily for new employees.

title: Topics Protectionism
description: Fish Story

title: WHEN TO AMEND AN OLD TAX RETURN
description: Most taxpayers breathe a sigh of relief on April 15, when the unpleasant task of preparing the annual tax return is completed. But last year, two million people - voluntarily - filed amended returns as well, long after tax time was behind them.

title: No Headline
description: Jersey Legislature Sets A Midsummer Session

title: AS ROBOTS' WAR ON THE U.S. WORK FORCE INTENSIFIES
description: To the Editor:

title: SORTIES IN THE ILE-DE-FRANCE
description: JACK BEECHING lives in Paris. His most recent book is ''The Galleys at Lepanto'' (Scribners).

title: AUTOMATED TRANSLATIONN IS NOW SOME SENSE MAKING
description: When computers started proliferating on college campuses and in corporate offices in the 1950's, they held the promise of providing the quick translation of letters, documents, perhaps even literature from one language to another. It was not yet to be. Even the translation of a simple note from English into French proved to be too inaccurate, too slow and, when computer memory space and processing power were at a premium, too expensive.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: MYSTERIES MANSION, RACE TO ATHENS
description: Ghostly House That Guns Built Offers Tour Shrouded in legend and filled with such oddities as hidden passageways, staircases leading to nowhere, doors opening onto blank walls, a window built into a floor and a chimney that rises four floors but stops just short of the ceiling, the 160-room Victorian mansion under construction for 38 years of 24-hour days would seem to justify its name.

title: JETS FARE POORLY AGAINST THE REDSKINS
description: Speaking through clenched teeth after the Jets were shaken up, 45-10, in a scrimmage against the Washington Redskins today, Coach Joe Walton contended, ''We've got a lot of work to do.'' He singled out a need for ''organization of our offense.''

title: LETTERS ; Taking Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: A Harder Look At Horse Deaths
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NO ONE IS EVER SAFE
description: SOMETHING OUT THERE

title: No Headline
description: Susanne Hand Is Bride

title: BLACK BOXES AND MOVIE POEMS
description: John Gross is an editor of The Book Review.

title: Yarborough and ElliottHead Talledega Field
description: Alabama International Motor Speedway's Talladega 500 has produced 14 different winners in 15 races, and chances are good a new name will be added to the list Sunday.

title: TWO NEW VHS RECORDERS DELIVER A SUMPTUOUS FEAST OF SOUND
description: Until now, hi-fi video cassette recorders (VCR's) operating in the VHS format had been literally showpieces - seen only at trade shows, press demonstrations and similar quasi-official occasions. But lately a few vanguard models have appeared in less formidable settings. They are beginning to arrive in the shops, where customers can get their hands on them, try them out and - with the aid of hefty checks - lug them home.

title: No Headline
description: Electric Fences Altered To Save Hummingbirds

title: FROM FARM, FIELD, AND ZOO, ANIMALS IN ARTISTIC LANGUAGE
description: IT sure is the month of the animal in Connecticut, what with

title: CONTINENTAL'S $4.5 BILLION RESCUE
description: Rescued. The F.D.I.C. finally set forth its $4.5 billion rescue package last week for Continental Illinois. The plan - the largest intervention ever by the United States Government into private business - calls for a $1 billion injection of new capital plus assumption of $3.5 billion in delinquent loans by the F.D.I.C. In return, the agency will control 80 percent of Continental's stock and current shareholder value will be virtually wiped out. The top management will also change. John E. Swearingen, former chairman of Indiana Standard, and William S. Ogden, a former Chase vice chairman, will hold the top jobs. Wall Street was encouraged by the bailout, while Treasury Secretary Regan accused the F.D.I.C. of exceeding its regulatory authority. Meanwhile, Continental reported a $1.1 billion second-quarter loss.

title: SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS FACING FUND SHORTAGE IN CONNECTICUT
description: Finding funds to keep shelters open and set up new ones is the biggest problem that Connecticut faces in trying to take care of its homeless, according to members of a state panel studying the issue.

title: Marino Is Injured
description: Dan Marino, the second-year quarterback of the Miami Dolphins, suffered a dislocated finger on his throwing hand during a scrimmage against the New Orleans Saints.

title: ALL THIS JAZZ
description: Jazz books seem to come in clusters, and the current bunch reflects a variety of approaches to the subject. There is a biography and an autobiography, each covering the life of a bandleader. Anthologies are represented by ''Jazz Guitars'' and oral history by ''Jazz Voices,'' which is mostly about singers. Finally, there is ''The Freedom Principle,'' a critical survey of jazz since 1958, concentrating on musicians who have experimented with new forms. As these books demonstrate, the global vigor and myriad styles of jazz continue, unruffled by Arthur Schlesinger's recent statement: ''Film . . . is the only art to which the United States has made a difference.'' THOSE SWINGING YEARS.

title: Reagan Calls Rescue Of Bank No Bailout
description: The White House insisted today that the Continental Illinois transaction did not constitute a Government bailout.

title: Dr. Daryl O'Brien Becomes a Bride
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Mendham, N.J., yesterday Dr. Daryl Helen O'Brien and Thomas Carey Palmer were married by the Rev. Thomas Robinson. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick O'Brien of Mendham.

title: Serious Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith A. Kinnard Is Wed to Kenneth A. Schwartz
description: Judith A. Kinnard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Kinnard of Moorestown, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth A. Schwartz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Schwartz of Pittsford, N.Y. Justice David Boehm of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: THE TERMS OF PLEDGES MAY VARY
description: RENTERS in buildings being converted to cooperative or condominium ownership frequently must decide whether or not to sign a ''no-buy'' pledge, a contract under which tenants promise not to buy their units until a majority of those who signed the pledges agree that the best deal has been reached with the sponsor.

title: CHARTREUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRONZE CASTING: LITTLE CHANGE FROM THE BRONZE AGE PROCESS
description: TRENTON ART foundries are not art events, but perhaps they should be. The procedure and paraphernalia of casting - from the molten metal itself to the perpetually churning vats of slurry - make a more-dramatic spectacle than any objects they may yield. And where bronze casting is concerned, the process has remained relatively unchanged since the Bronze Age.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing

title: POST-MORTEM ON A COUPLE OF FLOPS
description: At 1 P.M. on Thursday, July 19, in the Criterion 1 Theater, a vast, enclosed space containing 1,300 seats, there were, by my count, exactly 21 paying customers when the lights went down for the showing of ''Rhinestone,'' a failed dream of a summer box-office blockbuster starring Sylvester Stallone and Dolly Parton. I'd had to run to catch the movie, for this was the last day of the kind of disastrous four-week first run that sends producers back to their palm readers.

title: CUBA TIME FOR A THAW?
description: Wayne S. Smith, a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, headed the United States Interests Section in Havana in 1979-82.

title: EAST EUROPEANS CRITICAL
description: Hungary and Czechoslovakia, two nations that joined the Soviet Union in a boycot of the Summer Olympics, criticized aspects of the Games today as they officially began in Los Angeles.

title: THE NEW COMEDIENNES
description: Phil Berger is the author of ''The Last Laugh: The World of the Stand-up Comics.''

title: SIKH PARLEY: 'WE ARE UNITED, WE ARE ANGRY'
description: About 2,500 Sikhs gathered in New York City yesterday to formalize the creation of an international organization to defend their rights and identity.

title: International
description: Neutralization of Beirut's Green Line was begun by the Lebanese Government in the second stage of its peace plan for the capital. Bulldozers were leveling the remaining barricades of the Green Line that separates the Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital. The line is a 10-mile stretch of shattered buildings, wreckage and snipers nests. Lebanese Army units with both Moslem and Christian soldiers are to be stationed along the line, while the Moslem Sixth Brigade remains in West Beirut and the the mostly Christian Fifth Brigade stays in the East. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: THE COPPER MINERS MAY BE AT THE POINT OF NO RETURN
description: In 1953, the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers assembled actors, actresses, copper miners and members of their families in the New Mexico desert to make a movie, ''Salt of the Earth.'' It was a controversial project, but the film, which dealt with, among other things, a miner's attempt to keep his wife from mixing in the affairs of striking miners, was completed and is regarded by many authorities as a classic social drama.

title: HEADLINERS ; END OF THE REIGN Promenading in a swimsuit is one thing, but officials of the Miss America pageant were mortified when it became known recently that, courtesy of Penthouse magazine, millions of Americans would soon be seeing
description: Vanessa Williams in considerably less. They gave Miss Williams, this year's winner and the first black woman to hold the title, three days to resign.

title: NEW TWIST IN CYCLING RIVALRY
description: HER introduction to the bicycle was fairly typical: Rebecca Twigg started on a tricycle, followed by a two-wheeler with training wheels. Her rite of passage to the sidewalks and streets of Seattle was completed when the training wheels were removed, a memorable day in the life of any kid. And when Miss Twigg entered her first race, she didn't ride a souped-up model with fancy trim but a common bicycle picked from a Sears catalog.

title: LOOKING AHEAD: OTHERS SEEKING A SILVER MEDAL
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Helping the Driver Get From Here to There

title: LAWS ON SAFETY BELTS ARE THE BEST SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Governors, in Nashville, Open Annual Convention
description: The nation's governors opened their 76th annual meeting today, talking about the states' role in attracting jobs.

title: Peruvian Calls Rebellion Nation's Biggest Threat
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry says guerrillas backed by drug traffickers may pose the biggest threat ever faced by Peru.

title: Market Place; Earnings Lift Stocks Of Airlines
description: AIRLINE stocks, after being depressed for weeks, finally caught the attention of investors after many major carriers reported second-quarter earnings that surpassed Wall Street's expectations.

title: DR. HAROLD SYRETT, HISTORIAN AND HAMILTON PAPERS EDITOR
description: Dr. Harold C. Syrett, executive editor of the papers of Alexander Hamilton and a former president of Brooklyn College, died of hepatitis yesterday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Craryville, N.Y.

title: END IS SEEN SOON IN DELOREAN TRIAL
description: Only one more defense witness was expected to testify in John Z. DeLorean's trial on cocaine trafficking charges, with the case headed toward a close this week in Federal District Court.

title: Big Turnout Reported In Zaire Election
description: Zairians were reported casting ballots in large numbers today, the second day of voting in a presidential election in which President Mobutu Sese Seko, the only candidate, is seeking a third term in office.

title: JAPAN'S PUSH IN FIBER OPTICS
description: Posters of pinup girls dot the walls, and a giant picture of a Playboy bunny is painted on the side of the Van de Graaf accelerator.

title: IRAN SAYS IT FOUGHT REBEL KURDS IN HEAVY BATTLE NEAR IRAQ BORDER
description: Iran has reported fierce fighting with Kurdish rebels in a mountainous region near the northwest border with Iraq, an indication that a major new drive against the insurgents may be under way.

title: GUILLERMO DIAZ PLAJA
description: Guillermo Diaz Plaja, the Spanish literary historian and author, died in a Barcelona hospital of cancer of the kidneys, doctors said.

title: 'SANTA BARBARA,' NEW DAYTIME SERIAL
description: ''SANTA BARBARA'' has good trashy fun and Dame Judith Anderson, too. Let dramaturgists record that the first words by the distinguished actress on NBC's new daytime serial, which makes its debut at 3 P.M. on Channel 4 today, are ''Ambrose, why have we stopped?'' Then, on being told by Ambrose, her chauffeur, that some ''news people'' are blocking the road at the Capwell house, Dame Judith, tapping Ambrose lightly on the shoulder with a riding crop, says: ''The Capwells are mad about the headlines. Ambrose, home.''

title: ARMAGEDDON? HO-HUM.
description: Dead ends force one to look again, to retrace one's steps. I feel that for the past five years I have failed to notice the markers, but si nce I was headed toward an almost invisible impasse, how could I have known that moral torpor is one of the principal obstacles in the United States, as well as in England, France and the Soviet Union?

title: BOND SWING REFLECTS OPTIMISM
description: The roller-coaster pattern of Treasury bond yields recently has confounded the forecasts of traders and economists, and shown the importance of investor psychology in the nervous bond market.

title: TWO SPRINTS, TWO TRIUMPHS
description: She had prepared all year for this race, knowing it would be her last, but with 50 meters left, she was coming up short on the 79-kilometer road race. Connie Carpenter was a few centimeters behind Rebecca Twigg, all the difference between gold and silver.

title: Income Is Ahead of Inflation
description: The rebounding auto industry helped Delaware and Michigan post the largest personal income gains of the year's first quarter, while Alaska was the only state to lose ground, the Government reported today.

title: AT BAYREUTH, TROUBLES IN THE VALHALLA OF OPERA
description: The Japanese journalist pocketed his free press tickets for the festival and made a beeline for the gaggle of agitated Wagner fanatics gathered outside the barnlike red-brick theater. He was immediately enveloped by a score of tense, hard-eyed individuals.

title: GROMYKO PREDICTS SPACE ARMS TALKS WILL NOT BE HELD
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko was quoted today as saying he did not expect negotiations to be held in September on banning weapons in space.

title: Italy Takes Lead
description: Carlo Massullo and Daniele Masala got two of the five perfect equestrian scores today in the modern pentathlon to carry Italy to the team lead after the first event.

title: Libya Issues Complaint About U.S. Planes
description: Libya has complained to the United Nations and other international organizations about the presence of American planes over the Gulf of Sidra on Thursday, the official Libyan press agency said today.

title: No Alternative
description: When the United States men's basketball team took its place in the University of Southern California village and completed its preparations for its opening game against China, Chuck Person went home.

title: India Tops U.S., 5-1
description: India, eight times gold medalists in men's field hockey, defeated the United States, 5-1, today as competition began at East Los Angeles College. In other games, Australia beat Malaysia, 5-0, and West Germany defeated Spain, 3-1.

title: HELMS AND HUNT DEBATE IN CAROLINA SENATE RACE
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. tonight asked Senator Jesse Helms to join him in a pledge to accept no more out-of-state campaign contributions in their United States Senate race, already the most expensive in American history.

title: BRAZIL WILL SEEK FLEXIBLE DEBT PLAN
description: Brazil has decided to follow Mexico's example in seeking to postpone all principal payments coming due on its debts for the next several years, according to officials here. The request is expected to be made when Brazil resumes debt negotiations with foreign banks in New York this week.

title: U.S. Wins Opener
description: The United States beat Argentina, 15-6, 15-7, 10-15, 15-8, tonight as men's volleyball competition began at the Long Beach Arena.

title: Washington Watch; Action Is Seen On Export Bill
description: WASHINGTON

title: A BUTTERFLY AFICIONADO STALKS THE SNOUT
description: Lambert Pohner has seen the snout. The small butterfly, named for what looks like a long, skinny nose protruding from its head, is rare in New York City, and urban butterfly watchers speak of it reverently as ''the legendary snout.'' Mr. Pohner says he has sighted eight snouts so far this summer, all in Central Park.

title: FRED WARING, CONDUCTOR, DIES AT 84
description: Fred Waring, one of the last great conductors of the Big Band era and inventor of the Waring Blendor, died yesterday after suffering a stroke at his summer home in State College, Pa. He was 84 years old.

title: MUSIC: AT TANGLEWOOD, A RANGE OF VITAL STYLES
description: The 1984 installment of the Berkshire Music Center's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood got under way officially on Thursday night with a recital by Joel Krosnick of the Juilliard String Quartet of the sort of 20-century American cello music he is presenting in his own series in New York all this year.

title: Chinese Gets Gold
description: Zeng Guoqiang of China captured the gold medal in the 114-pound weight lifting class today and his countryman Zhou Peishun took the silver medal.

title: CAMBRIDGE GETS OLYMPICS TOO
description: A sellout crowd of 25,000 got its taste of the Olympics' excitement here tonight without going to California,

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report July 20 about plans for a new housing development on Roosevelt Island misidentified the president of the Roosevelt Island Residents Association. He is Kenneth R. Kimbrough.

title: Lockridge Stops Llerena in Sixth
description: Rocky Lockridge, the World Boxing Association junior-lightweight champion, used his bob-and-weave style to perfection today and knocked out Julio Llerena of Colombia in the sixth round of a scheduled 10-round nontitle fight.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Ratings

title: Dealers Awaiting Word on U.S. Sale
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, though securities dealers expect the Government to announce on Wednesday a major note and bond financing for next week.

title: HEAD OF URBAN LEAGUE URGES A FULL-EMPLOYMENT SCHEME
description: Warning that ''jobs are the single central, burning issue on the black agenda,'' the president of the National Urban League tonight proposed a partnership among public and private leaders to create a national full employment program.

title: A SOCCER OFFICIAL BLAMES HYPROCISY
description: Soccer's international leaders have been accused of opening the door to professionalizing the Olympics, by allowing professional players in the 1984 Games. But today the president of F.I.F.A., the international soccer federation, said that the organization was simply avoiding hypocrisy.

title: TALKS INTENSIFY IN EFFORT TO END HEALTH WALKOUT
description: Talks aimed at settling New York City's hospital and nursing home strike intensified yesterday.

title: Colombian Oil Found
description: Oil companies have found new reserves of oil, gas and condensates in eastern Colombia, the Ecopetrol Company said on Friday. The company, associated with Elf Aquitaine, Houston Oil and Louisiana Land, said the exploratory Norichal 1 well near the city of Yopal yielded 3,630 barrels of oil a day, 14 million cubic feet of gas and 1,300 barrels of condensate. It said that the well showed commercially exploitable reserves in an area where previous exploration had met little success.

title: EVADING THE SALES TAX BY NEW YORK STORES UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: Some of New York City's leading retailers of jewelry, furs and other luxury merchandise have systematically joined their customers in evading the sales tax, according to city and state officials. Investigators say they are pursuing civil and criminal penalties against the stores and their officers.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who Will Help Andres Delgado?
description: Birth defects left Andres Delgado stone-deaf and mildly retarded. His efforts to communicate don't go beyond grunts and gestures. Yet the 19- year-old New Yorker is hardly a total loss to society. He knows how to cook, clean the house, do the laundry and run errands for his mother. For a time he even held a job in a grocery store.

title: CUBS' PITCHERS SILENCE METS' BATTERS
description: The Cubs may be the best run-scoring team in the National League, with 491 runs thus far this season. But make no mistake, says their catcher, Jody Davis, it isn't hitting that has brought the Cubs within one and one- half games of the Mets in the National League East.

title: Computer Games
description: When it comes to cutting costs and increasing efficiency, computers have proved an irresistible investment for modern businesses, and it should come as no surprise that in preparing for the Games, the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee relied heavily on computers and computer technology.

title: Tennessee Drivers End A Sobering Experience
description: Most of the 160 people released today from the Nashville jail, where they served a 48-hour sentence for violating Tennessee's toughened drunken driving law, vowed that they would not return.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: BIGGEST TV PRODUCTION EVER: 180 HOURS
description: More than 250 cameras will be rolling and about 660 miles of cable and four helicopters will carry their output. Nearly 1,300 hours of footage are to be shot with 3,500 people working on the production.

title: CONCERT: JACKSONS AT GIANTS STADIUM
description: Can Michael Jackson compete with his own idealized video image? That was the question that brought more than 44,000 people, paying $30 each, to Giants Stadium tonight for the first of three sold-out shows by the Jacksons. That question and, of course, the promise of hearing Mr. Jackson sing and dance songs that have pleased some 35 million record buyers of ''Thriller'' alone.

title: BUDD COVERS GROUND WITH PRESS, TOO
description: The biggest revelation might have come before the start of today's news conference when Zola Budd entered the dining room above the hotel restaurant wearing a Brooks T-shirt and a pair of running shoes by the same company. Thus, without saying a word, the barefoot girl from South Africa had answered the question: Which brand of shoes does she prefer not to run in during the Olympic Games?

title: MARJORIE RAND WEDS Dr. David Katzka
description: Marjorie Rand, a daughter of Dr. Jacob S. Rand of Floral Park, L.I., and the late Zelda E. Rand, was married yesterday to Dr. David A. Katzka, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Katzka of Old Westbury, L.I. The ceremony was performed at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York by Rabbi Seth L. Bernstein and Cantor Norman Belink.

title: Bonn Says It's Checking Sale Of Nerve Gas Facility to Iraq
description: At Washington's request, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has ordered a full investigation into reports that Iraq is buying equipment from West Germany capable of producing nerve gas and other chemical weapons, the Government said today.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: With the powerful Soviet, East German and Cuban teams boycotting, the United States figured to dominate the Games of the XXIII Olympiad, and the home team did not waste any time when the competition began yesterday, capturing five of the eight final events for a total of six gold medals.

title: Another Pentagon Fire
description: The control booth of a steam generator caught fire at the Pentagon heliport Saturday, causing about $20,000 in damage but no injuries. The cause appeared to be accidental, Arlington County fire officials said. A fire Wednesday night inside the Pentagon, the Defense Department headquarters across the Potomac River from Washington, did $50,000 in damage to National Guard offices, and three firefighters were injured.

title: JUNE TOOL ORDERS 40% BELOW MAY
description: Machine tool orders plummeted 40 percent in June from the strong levels in May, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said yesterday.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 30: MONDAY Airborne FreightKoppers CoArmstrong World IndNorthwest AirlinesFoster WheelerUnifirst CorpGeorgia-PacificWackenhut CorpKentucky Utils

title: AQUINO DEATH CHILLS TOURISM IN PHILIPPINES
description: Tourism in the Philippines, once the object of grand designs here, has slowed to a trickle in the year since the assassination of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Colgate Profits Decrease 3.6% By The Associated Press The Colgate-Palmolive Company has announced that its net income in
description: the second quarter, hurt by increased marketing costs, price

title: PROF. NANCY RASH WED TO PROFESSOR
description: The marriage of Nancy Batson Nisbet Rash, professor and former chairman of the department of art history at Connecticut College, to Frank Miller Turner, professor of history and director of British studies at Yale University, took place yesterday in the Dwight Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven. The Rev. David Robb, chaplain at Connecticut College and a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: DR. STILLMAN WED TO YARON HEFETZ
description: Dr. Judith Lynn Stillman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Stillman of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday to Yaron Hefetz , a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mordechai Hefetz of Herzliya, Israel.

title: THE LUCK OF AN IRISH VILLAGE: REAGAN STEPPED HERE
description: It has been almost eight weeks since President Reagan paid a two-hour visit to this drowsy village in the shadow of the Knockmealdown Mountains, but things have still not returned to normal.

title: RIVAL LEFTIST MILITIAS BATTLE IN BEIRUT
description: A gunbattle between rival leftist militias erupted today in the center of West Beirut. It was the first major outbreak of violence here since the Government's peace plan went into effect early this month.

title: BENJAMIN MOORE'S PLACE IN COLUMBIA'S HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: TODAY'S EVENTS
description: Basketball United States vs. Yugoslavia, women, at noon. Cheryl Miller and Pam McGee of Southern California lead an American team that is favored to win the gold. Australia vs. China, 5:30 P.M.

title: Haji-Sheikh Sets High-Kicking Goal
description: Ali Haji-Sheikh leaned against a brick wall at the Giants' camp one day last week and considered the dizzying events of the last 12 months.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.19

title: Gunmen Hijack Plane To Trinidad and Aruba
description: Two gunmen hijacked a Venezuelan jet carrying 87 people today and forced it to fly to Trinidad and Aruba.

title: ;  The Runner-up
description: If Edwin W. Steidle is not a household name in your household, and if you don't know exactly what he's been up to for the past five years, there is an explanation: Back in March 1979, when the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee was electing its president, Peter V. Ueberroth got 9 votes and Steidle got 8.

title: MONDALE RENEWS ATTACK ON REAGAN'S RECORD
description: After a weeklong fishing trip along the Canadian border, Walter F. Mondale returned to the political fray today and said the Reagan Administration had the ''lousiest'' environmental record in the nation's history.

title: APPAREL TAKEOVER BIDS MOUNT
description: Apparel makers, cash-rich after record earnings in 1983 but with stock prices still depressed, have become a target of investors looking for undervalued takeover candidates.

title: A LIST LACKING F.D.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: A STUDY OF BLACKS IN WHITE SUBURBIA
description: New research on the social and psychological world of middle-class black families living in predominantly white suburbs has found that family members feel accepted in their neighborhoods while maintaining strong ties in the black community. Black children in these families have many white friends, feel at home living in white society and grow up with a positive self-image about being black, according to the study.

title: CROWDS IN POLAND ACCALIM ACTIVISTS
description: Labor movement activists freed from prison under an amnesty were hailed today by 7,000 people at a special church service here.

title: GREATER WOES LIE AHEAD FOR CITY'S TRANSIT RIDERS
description: New York City's subway system, starting to undergo its most extensive overhaul since it was completed 50 years ago, is inflicting on its riders a catalogue of miseries that promises to get worse before it gets better.

title: U.S. MEN TAKE TEAM LEAD
description: Mitch Gaylord and Peter Vidmar became the first Americans to score 10's in Olympic gymnastics history here tonight, and their performances helped boost the United States into the team lead after the men's compulsory exercises, ahead of the current world champion, China.
Old Song, New Politics

title: JETS GAMBLE ON CHOICE OF 2 UNTESTED QUARTERBACKS
description: WHEN Joe Walton decided that the Jets were going to begin this season with a quarterback who had never started a regular-season game, that put the team in an unusual category. According to the National Football League, no other team will go into the season without a quarterback who has not started in the league. In fact, no one did so last year, either.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: THE NEW ISRAEL
description: Because the Israeli election produced no clear mandate for either of the two major parties, some dismissed it as meaningless. It was far from that. With all the indecisiveness of the result, it conveyed a graphic picture of a changing country.

title: Bridge:A Triumphant Partnership Of Fry and Frey Is Recalled
description: Half a century ago, the national bridge scene was suffering from a chronic ambiguity. Anyone who heard an expert's name that sounded like ''fry'' had to find out more. Was it Richard L. Frey? Or Sam Fry Jr.?

title: EUROPE'S COMPETITOR FOR SHUTTLE
description: If all goes according to plan, a white rocket named Ariane 3 will blast off from the Kourou launching ground in French Guiana next Saturday, putting two civilian communications satellites into orbit 22,500 miles above the earth.

title: 10 Indicted in Fraud Inquiry
description: Ten people, including a doctor and four chiropractors, were indicted in a reported $10 million insurance fraud involving Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan, the insurance company has announced.

title: ADVICE FROM ALI IS AN AID FOR BRELAND
description: trimmed blue letters, ''Mark Breland'' is written across the back of his hooded white terrycloth robe. He's a skinny 21-year-old welterweight from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, a three-time world amateur champion and a record five-time New York Golden Gloves champion who is reputed to be the best boxer in this Olympic tournament.

title: Cambodia Refugees Flee Vietnamese Shelling
description: Vietnamese troops shelled a refugee camp in Cambodia with heavy artillery today, forcing more than 2,000 civilians and 500 rebels to flee into Thailand, Thai military officials said.

title: Tanzania Protects 2 Species
description: Tanzania has banned the commercial export of cheetah and leopard skins, in keeping with international moves to protect the two species, the Government announced this weekend. The ban does not affect skins of animals shot by foreign hunters licensed by the Tanzania Wildlife Corporation.

title: CHINESE ATHLETES GAIN FIRST MEDALS
description: Xu Haifeng of China won the first gold medal of the Summer Games of the XXIII Olympiad today when he placed first in the men's free pistol competition. He and his teammate Wang Yifu, who earned the bronze, became China's first Olympic medal winners ever.

title: A U.S. Wrestler Hurt in Accident
description: A member of the United States wrestling team suffered minor injuries in a traffic accident adjacent to the Olympic Village at Southern Cal late Saturday, police said.

title: The Great Dam Power Steal
description: Ohio's Senator Metzenbaum is fighting a last- ditch battle to stop Congress from giving away billions of dollars' worth of hydropower from the Hoover Dam. He deserves, at the very least, a hearing from his colleagues and the public.

title: STUDY SAYS U.S. FACES A DIFFICULT CHOICE ON SPACE BUSINESS
description: Amid mounting international competition, the United States faces a difficult choice on whether private industry should take over most commercial space launchings, a Congressional study says.

title: Gasoline Prices Decline Again LOS ANGELES, July 29
description: Gasoline prices have

title: Boxer Returns to His Home A Hero Before His First Bout
description: LOS ANGELESSometimes, the reminders of his childhood are all too frightening and real, and Paul Gonzales appreciates again his great escape from the seamy Los Angeles barrio. It was approximately two months ago that the American Olympic boxer was visiting his mother and went jogging in nearby Hollenbeck Park. He had stopped to pick up a book that was in his path when he was startled by sound he has heard before.

title: DIANE SIEGEL MARRIED TO THEODORE DANOFF
description: Diane Joyce Siegel and Theodore Marc Danoff were married yesterday at the Marriott Hotel in Stamford, Conn. by Rabbi Samuel Silver. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Siegel of Stamford, and her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jascha Danoff of Greenville, N.C.

title: Morning Sickness, Legal Miscarriage
description: Merrell Dow, the maker of the morning sickness drug Bendectin, has agreed to pay $120 million to settle claims that the drug causes birth defects. For that money - more than was paid even in the case of thalidomide - you'd think Bendectin had been proved some kind of a hazard. But it hasn't.

title: Accounts
description: * Majestic Marine, Freeport, L.I., boat builder, to Gianettino & Meredith of Mountainside, N.J.

title: MEASURE TO ADMIT ALIEN FARM WORKERS
description: Both houses of Congress have passed comprehensive immigration bills, but they differ on whether to create a special program to admit aliens as agricultural workers.

title: NEVADA TO MOVE AHEAD ON FORCING CASINOS' SALE
description: With a crucial Federal court victory behind them, Nevada gaming control officials are pressing their campaign to force the sale of two hotel-casinos here.

title: NETWORK AFFILIATES GAINING, REPORT SAYS WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) - The television stations that are owned directly by the three major commercial networks enjoyed profit margins of at least 30 percent last year, according to a broadcast industry trade publication.
description: As for the network operations themselves, ABC continues to enjoy higher pre-tax profits than its two rivals despite the fact that it has lost the prime- time ratings race to CBS over the last four years.

title: Canadians Ban 2 for Drugs
description: The Canadian Weight Lifting Federation, rocked last summer by the disqualification of two competitors at the Pan American Games, has sent two Olympians home because drug tests administered two weeks ago showed traces of a banned hormone.

title: AMERICANS ARE OFF TO QUICK START WITH 6 GOLD MEDALS AT OLYMPICS
description: Competition began today in the Summer Games of the XXIII Olympiad, and the United States quickly won four gold medals in swimming and two in cycling.

title: MONDAY, JULY 30, 1984 International
description: Andrei A. Gromyko was pessimistic about the prospect of Soviet-American talks being held in September on banning weapons in space, according to former Senator George McGovern, who is on a private visit to Moscow. Mr. McGovern, who had a three-hour conversation with the Soviet Foreign Minister, quoted Mr. Gromyko as saying he does not expect the talks to be held. (Page A1, Column 6.) Mr. Gromyko's reported pessimism about the likelihood of arms talks with the United States did not discourage the Reagan Administration. Officials said they had detected several indications that the Soviet Foreign Minister might be less warm to the Vienna negotiations than the Soviet leader, Konstanin U. Chernenko. They said the Administration was continuing to assess whether the Soviet Union was serious in its June 29 offer to discuss limits on space weapons. (A6:1.)

title: Malawian Is Winner at 125
description: Mark Breland's surprisingly tough opening bout drew most of the attention as the Olympic boxing competition began at the Sports Arena today, but the winner of the first bout of the day was Ali Faki of Malawi, who scored a 4-1 decision over Stamatios Kolethras of Greece in the 125-pound class.

title: UNCERTAINTY ON SOVIET GRAIN TIED TO VOLGA BASIN'S DRYNESS
description: With Soviet grain going through one of the most vulnerable phases of its growing season, Western agricultural experts here are focusing their attention on the Volga River Basin, where hot, dry weather poses a threat to the crop.

title: Joel W. Solomon Dies at 62; Carter Administration Official
description: Joel W. Solomon, a millionaire real estate developer who served as General Services Administration chief in the Carter Administration, died today of heart failure at his home after a lengthy illness. He was 62 years old.

title: CABARET: COLLAGE OF DAVID VAN TIEGHEM
description: DAVID VAN TIEGHEM, the virtuosic percussionist whose score for Twyla Tharp's ''Fait Accompli'' evokes an ominous, murky cityscape, is a suavely wacky stage comedian as well as a talented composer. And at the Bottom Line on Friday, Mr. Van Tieghem presided over a witty performance collage involving video, film, mime and a mixture of live and recorded music.

title: THE WALL IN CHINA ISN'T ALL THAT GREAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Muller's Chic Drive For Cohoes
description: FIVE years after its purchase by

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHICH ROAD TO THE PAST? Two Views of History. By Robert William Fogel and G. R. Elton. 136 pages. Yale University Press. $14.95.

title: CABARET: 'TEXAS GUINAN'S'
description: ''A NIGHT AT TEXAS GUINAN'S,'' a cabaret revue that opened last weekend at Jason's Park Royal, 23 West 73d Street, is an attempt to catch some of the flavor of night life in the Roaring Twenties that does remarkably well in its individual performances even while it sags in its more generalized aspects.

title: PROGRESS IN HONG KONG TALKS IS MADE BY BRITAIN AND CHINA
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said today that he had achieved substantial progress toward a Chinese- British agreement on the future of Hong Kong in two days of talks here.

title: PRAYERS HELP SOME TO BEAR THE PRESSURE
description: On Capitol Hill, a three-story brick structure with a white cross above the door awaits lobbyists tired of lobbying and Congressional aides in need of aid. They enter to pray.

title: Kobs and Mithun Unit
description: In another out-of-town acquisition, Kobs & Brady Advertising, a Chicago direct-marketing agency with $44.3 million in billings, has acquired the year-old direct marketing unit of Campbell-Mithun in Minneapolis, which bills about $3 million. This gives Kobs & Brady a Minneapolis office, which will serve Campbell-Mithun clients with direct marketing skills when needed, the same as Kobs & Brady's New York office does for clients of Ted Bates Worldwide, Campbell-Mithun's parent company.

title: ; A SPACE TREATY APPROACH MOSCOW WON'T GO FOR
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OPERA: 'ARIADNE'
description: This tiny town, roughly midway between Albany and Syracuse, swells sufficiently in the warm months to yield a fair- sized and enthusiastic opera audience. The Glimmerglass Opera has been cultivating that audience with small-scale, English-language, ensemble-oriented productions of which the singers involved often speak highly back in New York City. This season, comprising 18 performances of three operas in the 611-seat Sterling Junior High School auditorium, marks the company's 10th anniversary.

title: U.S. Cyclists Win
description: Two Americans, Mike Baldwin and Fred Merkel, won the Suzuka World Eight-Hour Motorcycle Endurance Race before 143,000 spectators today.

title: More Shifts at Time
description: Last week's Time Inc.'s musical chairs game in the magazine division starred E. Patrick Lenahan, Carl Jaeger, James B. Hoefer and James B. Hayes. This week the younger crowd on the ad sales director level gets to play. Charles Rubens 2d moves his ensign to Money, while his job at Life goes to Alan T. Wragg, formerly eastern sales manager; John Jay, formerly manager of the Detroit office of Sports Illustrated, is moving to Discover and into the job formerly held by R. Timothy Leedy, who moves to Fortune.

title: Robert Hellman, 65, Is Dead;Was a Writer and Translator
description: Robert Hellman, a writer and translator, died July 26 of a heart attack on a boat between Germany and Denmark, friends in New York reported. He was 65 years old and lived in Copenhagen.

title: DOWNWARD PRESSURE ON OIL PRICES
description: The Soviet Union's decision last week to lower its oil prices by $1.50 a barrel during August, analysts say, will greatly increase pressure on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other oil producers to lower their prices. Some cuts could come as early as this week.

title: RICHARD L. BLUME MARRIES DR. BALIN, OPHTHALMOLOGIST
description: At Ohev Shalom Synagogue in Wallingford, Pa., yesterday Dr. Nancy Anne Balin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Balin of Wallingford, was married to Richard L. Blume, a son of Judge and Mrs. Herbert L. Blume of Palo Alto, Calif.

title: REAGAN AIDES NOT DAUNTED BY THE GROMYKO FORECAST
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were not discouraged by a report that the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, is pessimistic about the possibility of arms talks between Washington and Moscow in September.

title: MAKE US A MATCH, CHINESE LONELY HEARTS ASK
description: ''Twenty-eight- year-old miner, good looking, healthy, interested in literature and calligraphy, earning $44 a month, no family burdens, seeks kind-hearted, healthy unmarried woman of similar looks and age. Please send recent photograph.''

title: CHARLES E. GOETZ
description: Charles E. Goetz, an inventor credited with perfecting techniques to desalinate ocean water and cool railroad cars, died here Wednesday.

title: Record Month On Mortgages
description: Savings institutions issued a record $17.8 billion in mortgages in June, the United States League of Savings Institutions said.

title: THEATER: 'CARLA'S SONG,' A DRAMA ABOUT CHILD ABUSE
description: ''CARLA'S SONG,'' Michelle Morris's harrowing play about child abuse, is the sort of drama that turns the theater into a mixture of personal therapy and textbook psychology. Adapted from Miss Morris's novel, ''If I Should Die Before I Wake,'' it tells the story, in unblinkingly graphic language, of a teen-ager who has been sexually abused by her father from a very early age. Jay, an unsavory real estate salesman, kidnapped his daughter when she was 6 years old after his wife discovered him abusing her and kicked him out of the house. Late in the play we learn that Carla's mother has since died in a mental hospital. And when the drama begins, Carla is a disturbed teen-ager making her first steps toward asserting her independence.

title: Lending Up Worldwide
description: International bank lending grew in the first quarter of 1984, but the rise was chiefly confined to borrowers in major industrial nations, where the economic recovery has been strongest, according to a report published today by the Bank for International Settlements.

title: OFFSHORE LEASES: CONGRESSIONAL EFFORTS TOWARD A BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL PARKS FACE THREAT FROM CIVILIZATION THEY SERVE
description: Despite a $1 billion refurbishing job under the Reagan Administration, the National Parks, crown jewels of the vast Federal land holdings, face an increasingly uncertain future.

title: OUTDOORS: PRESIDENTS AS ANGLERS
description: A FEW Presidents and Presidential candidates have been anglers, and, because that is not a usual pastime for those who hunger for power, one wonders if they have been fully aware of the political implications of the various forms of the sport.

title: Marijuana Growers Arrested
description: The state police said today that they had uprooted five acres of marijuana plants in western New Hampshire and arrested four Massachusetts residents.

title: Jackson Due to DecideOn Carolina Senate Race
description: Jesse Jackson, who has taken steps to change his legal residence to South Carolina, arrived here today for a voter registration drive.

title: HERO OF RESISTANCE IN WARTIME FRANCE
description: Gilbert Renault, organizer of the Free French intelligence network in German-occupied France and one of France's most decorated heroes of the Resistance, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the Breton town of Guingamp. He was 79 years old.

title: WESTCHESTER MAN, 20, IS FOUND DEAD IN YARD
description: A 20-year-old Yorktown man has apparently become the ninth young person to die a self-inflicted death this year in the suburbs north of New York City.

title: Savannah, Ga., Braces For Mosquito Invasion
description: Billions of mosquitoes headed downwind toward Savannah today, but officials said the full impact of the invasion was delayed by two days of rain.

title: WHAT THE WORK IS WORTH IS KEY TO POSTAL TALKS
description: Gerald F. Merna expects to have 750 job openings over the next year in the workroom of the Merryfield postal center, where the mail of northern Virginia is choreographed through six acres of chutes and conveyor belts.

title: METS LOSE DOUBLEHEADER TO CUBS, GET ONLY ONE RUN
description: The Mets took their grandest tumble of the season yesterday before 50,443 fans in Shea Stadium when they scored only one run in 18 innings and lost a doubleheader to the Chicago Cubs.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Officer Is Promoted At General Electric
description: The General Electric Company has announced the promotion of Lawrence A. Bossidy to vice chairman.

title: STEPHANIE SIEGEL MARRIED TO JEFFREY BLAIR WHALEN
description: Stephanie Siegel , a daughter of Susan Silver and Dr. Barry L. Siegel, both of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Blair Whalen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Whalen Jr., of Windham Center, Conn. Rabbi Harold S. White performed the ceremony at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society of Central Atlantic States in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: A Fever for Elephants Descends Upon Dallas
description: Elephant fever has descended on Dallas as the city prepares to play host to the Republican National Convention.

title: Mrs. Inkster Rallies For 1-Shot Victory
description: Juli Inkster shrugged off her 75 on Saturday and shot a 67 today for a one- stroke victory over Ayako Okamoto in the $330,000 du Maurier Classic golf tournament.

title: Injured Marino To Miss 3 Weeks
description: Dan Marino, the second-year quarterback for the Miami Dolphins, suffered a dislocated index finger on his throwing hand in a scrimmage Saturday against the New Orleans Saints and will be out for at least three weeks.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report July 20 about patient care at Mount Sinai Hospital during the current strike by hospital workers misidentified the song ''She Works Hard for the Money.'' It was featured not in a movie but on a record album by the singer Donna Summer.

title: Killer of Six Alaskans Gets a 634-Year Term
description: Louis Hastings, a failed computer programmer who methodically hunted down six people and killed them at a remote Alaska village last year, has received a 634-year prison term.

title: Study Finds Asbestos Risk In Kilmer Library at Rutgers
description: Asbestos at the Livingston College Kilmer Library at Rutgers University presents a serious health problem and should be removed or enclosed as soon as possible, according to a study commissioned by a group representing professors.

title: THE CITY ; ;  No Pop Concerts Set for City Parks
description: There will be no major pop music concerts this summer in the city's parks because producers have refused to meet the city's demands, the Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, said yesterday.

title: DR. JACK BARABTARLO WED NAN HOPE MARKS IN JERSEY
description: Nan Hope Marks, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold D. Marks of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Jack Barabtarlo. He is theson of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Barabtarlo of Mexico City.

title: LAWS ON SAFETY BELTS ARE THE BEST SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FERRARO FITS IN A GAME
description: Like many couples with free time on a Sunday afternoon, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, put on their tennis whites yesterday and played a few games.

title: Bonn Sees 2.5% Growth
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he expects real growth of 2.5 percent this year for the gross national product, despite recent strikes by the West German metalworkers union.

title: TRAFFIC AND CROWDS NO PROBLEM SO FAR
description: As the first Olympic events began today at 12 venues in the Los Angeles area, city officials and representatives of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said that the Games were going smoothly and that major traffic and crowd control problems had not yet materialized.

title: Looking Ahead
description: Six - count 'em - six regions in the United States have citizen groups organizing to bid for future Winter Olympics, according to the trade publication Ski Area Management. While this might seem a trifle early, consider the fact that the drive for the 1980 Games at Lake Placid, N.Y., began officially in 1954 and was stirring long before that.

title: WOMEN IN THEIR 20'S FORM NEW CAREER NETWORK
description: Tracy M. McDonald, 24 years old, and Karen A. Page, 22, friends, roommates and interns at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, spend their days learning about investment banking, their early-morning hours training for the New York Marathon and their evenings getting in touch with other ambitious young women.

title: 'JERUSALEM BILL': A LOSER
description: The so-called Jerusalem bill, which by law would require moving the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, and which is coming to a head in the House, is a loose cannon. Constitutionally unable to reach the target it aims at, it is likely to blow up backward, causing enormous damage.

title: Dutch Open Won By West German
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany shot a two-over-par 74 today and won the 65th Dutch Open golf championship by four strokes.

title: CITY ENROLLS STUDENTS IN PREP SCHOOL TO HELP THEM IMPROVE SKILLS
description: Like a rich parent with children who need help in their studies, New York City has sent some of its underachieving public high school students off to private boarding schools.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which players hit the first and last home runs at Ebbets Field, the home park of the Brooklyn Dodgers?

title: BODDICKER WINS, 3-1, ALLOWING 2 SINGLES
description: Mike Boddicker allowed two singles in 8Z innings and Gary Roenicke contributed a solo home run to help the Baltimore Orioles defeat the Cleveland Indians, 3-1, today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bradford National Corp., a wholesaler of computerized financial products, has appointed Michael H. Mindlin to the new position of senior executive vice president in charge of coordinating operations of the subsidiary companies.

title: PUBLISHER TO WITHDRAW A BOOK ON POPE'S LIFE
description: The president of a company that recently published a controversial book about Pope John Paul II said that he will withdraw the book because it is ''fraudulent'' and will sue to recover the $60,000 advance from the author.

title: Jacobsen Beats O'Meara by 2
description: Peter Jacobsen, who is a popular attraction on the PGA Tour when he mimics other golfers, acted out the role of his favorite golfer today - a winner - as he took the $72,000 top prize in the Sammy Davis Jr. Greater Hartford Open.

title: U.S. TROUNCES CHINA, 97-49
description: That the opponent was not expected to present a challenge was not important to Bobby Knight, the United States men's basketball coach, before his team's first Olympic game late this afternoon. What was important was that the game, against China, presented even Knight with first- game uncertainties.

title: Albion in the Falkland Fog
description: Think about anything, said the mother to the child, but don't think about white elephants. In much this spirit, Britain has agreed to informal talks with Argentina about the Falkland Islands. Britain wants ''to start a dialogue,'' but only if the one subject Argentines care most about - sovereignty - is not discussed. When delegates met in Switzerland, the forbidden topic arose and the British huffily stalked out.

title: JAZZ: HAMIET BLUIETT CREATES A STRUCTURE FOR 'PAPERWORKS'
description: HAMIET BLUIETT'S ''Paperworks,'' presented last weekend at the Public Theater, brought improvisation into a symphony-length structure. At Friday's concert, Mr. Bluiett led 19 musicians in two readings of the same themes - one poised and romantic, the second sprawling.

title: SARATOGA TIME, AND THE LIVIN' IS EASY
description: The notion that horseplayers are a callous breed that responds only to the whirring of parimutuel machines and not to the esthetic delights of a track like Saratoga will be given a thorough workout beginning Wednesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JULY 30, 1984

title: GOING FOR THE JUGULAR ON PAC MONEY
description: Philip M. Stern, a Washington writer, philanthropist and longtime liberal activist, says the whole point of his new campaign against political action committees is to make people mad. It seems to be working.

title: WHITE SOX HALT YANK THREAT, 5-4
description: The theme of the day was wasted chances and, while the White Sox may have wasted more, the one that counted most was the Yankees' failure in the ninth inning.

title: POP: JAZZ BABIES TRIO SINGS
description: DURING the past decade the singing style and the arrangements of the Boswell Sisters, the ground-breaking jazz vocal trio of the early 1930's, have turned up in the repertory of several singing groups, culminating in a short-lived Off Broadway musical about the Boswells three years ago. That seemed to finish the Boswell revival for the time being.

title: Consolidating Domestically at Wells
description: Atari Inc., under new ownership, has decided to consolidate domestic advertising responsibility for both its computers and video games at Wells Rich Greene, which had been handling just the computers.

title: Futures/Options; Buying Frenzy For Gold Bugs
description: ACCORDING to experienced bullion dealers, gold bugs view the world in two ways. One, an improving economy can only lead to a resurgence of inflation followed by economic and social chaos. Two, if conditions are not good, then the economy can only get worse with the same results.

title: Sabin Triumphs In Matchmaker
description: Sabin beat Doblique by 1 1/4 lengths Saturday night to capture the $300,000 Matchmaker Stakes at the Atlantic City Race Course.

title: Moscow Urges Revival Of Mideast Conference
description: The Soviet Union called today for revival of the Geneva conference on the Middle East, with participation of the United States, the Soviet Union, Israel, its Arab neighbors and the Palestine Liberation Oreganization.

title: LANCE ROLE IN DRIVE SEEN AS LIMITED
description: Bert Lance has been general chairman of Walter F. Mondale's Democratic Presidential campaign for two weeks, but some Mondale strategists say his role in the campaign could be far more limited than originally envisioned.

title: PROTESTS AGAINST KAHANE RISING IN ISRAEL
description: The new political prominence of Rabbi Meir Kahane and his anti-Arab policies drew expressions of concern and calls for action today from a variety of officials and labor leaders.

title: GOMEZ REACHES FINAL
description: Andres Gomez defeated Guillermo Vilas, 6-1, 7-5, today and reached the final of the $200,000 D.C. National Bank Tennis Classic.

title: Talks Underway On Disputed Sale
description: William C. Greely, general manager of Keeneland, said today that he hoped that Robert Sangster, the British sportsman, and Charles Taylor, president of Windfield Farm, can work out an $8.25 million problem over a prize colt with a sore foot.

title: Marsh Takes Run
description: Jerry Marsh of San Diego outsprinted Gerald Kane of Garnerville, N.Y., in the final 50 yards yesterday to win the Heights-Inwood 10-kilometer run in 31 minutes 24 seconds.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees, returning home after a week on the road, send Dennis Rasmussen against Mike Caldwell.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Great Debates

title: STRUCK HOSPITALS AIDED BY CORPS OF VOLUNTEERS
description: Gladys Messinger and Lillian Friedman arrived at the Beth Israel Medical Center on Saturday, signed the volunteer book and assumed their posts at the information desk. They spent the day answering questions from callers about such things as a grandfather on the fifth floor, a friend on the seventh floor and whether the strike had been settled yet.

title: ECONOMISTS PLAN WAYS TO SWAP IDEAS FASTER
description: In a world of new markets and proliferating financial services - with rapid changes in banking, accounting, financial theory, government regulations and marketing - academic economists are saying that the publishing of research can no longer keep pace with the times. They complain that the latest and best ideas of researchers are unknown to their colleagues and the business community.

title: CABARET: LONI ACKERMAN PERFORMS SONGS OF THE 30'S
description: LONI ACKERMAN, who appeared in the Broadway productions of ''Evita'' and ''No, No, Nanette,'' made her cabaret debut at Freddy's last week with an act that, at one point, seemed to be a parody of itself.

title: ADVERTISING ; Fahlgren & Swink Adds Nucifora of Atlanta
description: -oriented agency executive in Parkersburg, W. Va., is welcoming a new agency in a new city to his sphere of influence.

title: GREWAL, CARPENTER GIVE U.S. 2 GOLDS
description: Alexi Grewal, only days after having been reinstated from a suspension, and Connie Carpenter ended a 72-year-old United States shutout in cycling today as they won Olympic gold medals in men's and women's races.

title: Two Democrats Drafting Bill to Tighten Primaries
description: Two Arizona Democrats, Senator Dennis DeConcini and Representative Morris K. Udall, are drafting legislation to tighten the primary season.

title: Dr. Robert M. Lincer Weds Deborah Cohen
description: At Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Deborah Rose Cohen, the daughter of Sheila Kirshner and Jerome Cohen, both of Great Neck, was married to Dr. Robert Mark Lincer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Lincer of Plainview, L.I. Rabbis Robert Widom and Julius Goldberg officiated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everything I have done this last year was cool and calculated for this race, to ride the best race of my life.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY IS LICENSE PROBLEM
description: His first client was Howdy Doody. Since then he has handled the licensing for James Bond, Tarzan, Superman and the Three Stooges.

title: Robert Bockman Dies at 47; ExecutiveandExpertonAsia
description: Robert H. Bockman, director of corporate affairs for Philip Morris Asia and a former instructor at Yale and Syracuse Universities and Oberlin College, died of cancer Friday at Memorial Hospital in Manhattan. He was 47 years old and lived in Hong Kong.

title: The U.N. Today
description: July 30, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Here's Mud on Your Arm

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SIGHT OF MUSIC It's one of the nicest places for a vest-pocket museum, off to one side in the friendly, open reaches of the indoor public space that constitutes the ground floor of the Philip Morris Building, 42d Street and Park Avenue. It's a cheerful lobby planned to give the wayfarer a lighter and more cheerful rest stop than is the traditionally austere and gloomy waiting room of Grand Central Terminal across the street.

title: People
description: * Yolan Toro joins Wells, Rich, Greene as senior vice president, corporate media director.

title: FOR YOUTH, THE VALUE OF JOBS IN SUMMER
description: ABOUT two and a half million

title: A SURGE OF PRIDE, PATRIOTISM
description: The middle-aged men and women, most of them dressed in red white and blue, crossed a busy downtown street singing ''God Bless America.'' They finished and one suggested ''America the Beautiful.'' They burst into song again and continued their way to the opening of the Games.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Richard J. Goeglein has been elected president and chief operating officer of Holiday Inns Inc.

title: MARYLAND WELCOMES CRAWFISH
description: None of the watermen of Worcester County on Maryland's Eastern Shore see Bruce Nichols as a competitive threat to the state's large seafood industry, but if the project he and his research partner are conducting continues to thrive, Marylanders will have another crustacean to harvest.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Celebration Of Spanish Heritage

title: FURY ETCHES STRIKERS' LIFE IN CRUMBLING FIGHT AT ARIZONA MINES
description: The 3:30 P.M. whistle blows, signaling the shift change, and in the glaring sun on the side of the mountain a bitter ritual begins.

title: REAGAN AS PANDORA
description: WASHINGTON

title: NO-HIT BID FAILS BUT HERSHISER WINS, 1-0
description: Orel Hershiser retired the first 23 batters he faced before Nick Esasky ruined his bid for a perfect game with a two-out single in the eighth inning today, and settled for a two-hitter as the Dodgers defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 1-0.

title: EARNHARDT WINS RACE AT TALLADEGA
description: Dale Earnhardt was confident heading toward the finish line today, knowing he had the Talladega 500 well in hand.

title: HOMES GO UP AND DOWN IN DAILY CAPE TOWN WAR
description: Just before dawn today, Susan Jezile, like other squatters outside this city, rose early from her bed and tore down the shelter of black plastic and brushwood that had been her home, exposing her sleeping children to the wintry winds of the Cape of Good Hope.

title: A FRIEND RETURNS FROM OVER THE BORDER
description: The basketball season never ended for Bill Wennington. He merely headed north from St. John's University, back across the Canadian border to another team that wears red and white. He also discovered that there are indeed places on his body that had not been injured during the junior season that ended last March.

title: British Court Fines Miners
description: A judge fined the South Wales branch of Britain's striking coal miners' union $66,000 today, warning that unless the union paid by Wednesday, its entire assets of $4 million would be seized. But strike officials said after the ruling that the branch would carry out national union policy of ''total noncooperation with the courts.''

title: MERCURY SAVINGS A FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TUESDAY, JULY 31, 1984 International
description: A shift on aid to El Salvador has been occurring among members of Congress since the May election of Jose Napoleon Duarte as the Salvadoran President. Representative Clarence D. Long, the Maryland Democrat who is chairman of a House subcommittee that exerts major influence over foreign aid spending, said he was now prepared to approve almost all the military and economic assistance sought by the Reagan Administration for El Salvador next year. (Page A1, Column 6.) Americans' success in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad continued with two more gold medals in swimming and one in shooting. In swimming, Mary Wayte of Mercer Island, Wash., won the women's 200-meter freestyle, and the men's 800-meter freestyle relay team captured a spectacular final from West Germany by four- hundredths of a second, or no more than 3 inches. World records were broken in the three men's finals. In shooting, the American gold medal came from Ed Etzel, of Morgantown, W. Va., who won the small-bore rifle competition with a near-perfect score of 599. Michael Gross of West Germany won the 100-meter butterfly by a foot from the favored Pablo Morales of Santa Clara, Calif. (A1:1-3.)

title: TURNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BIG U.S. SALES SPUR 35.4% KODAK GAIN
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, continuing its turnaround effort, reported yesterday a profit increase of 35.4 percent in the second quarter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cheaper Than a Permit

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Transactions
description: Assigned Keefe Cato, pitcher, outright to Class AAA Wichita, Kan., farm team in American Association. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Announced that Cecilio Guante, relief pitcher on disabled list, would be sent to Class AA farm club in Nashua, N.H., for rehabilitation. YANKEES (AL) - Sent John Montefusco, pitcher, to Columbus of International League for 10-day rehabilitation program. BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Signed Steve Colter, guard, from New Mexico State, and Tom Scheffler, center, who has played in Europe for the last seven years. COLLEGE BENTLEY - Named Paula Mullen assistant athletic director. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Cut Curtis Brown and Timmy McCray, running backs, and Judson Flint and Alford Marshall, safeties. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Signed Pete Koch, defensive end from University of Maryland, reportedly to a three-year contract. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Released Larry Davis, fullback; Randy Hawkins, quarterback; Rik Pearson, kicker, and Chris Sigourney, punter. DENVER (AFC) - Waived John Wristen and Mike Fisher, quarterbacks; Bobby Jenkins and Jeffrey Patterson, running backs; Capus Robinson and Melvin Simmons, wide receivers; Mike Whetstone and Paul Taeleifi, tackles; Ben Wise, linebacker; David Scandrett, nose tackle, and Bret Felknor, defensive end. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Cut James Capers, defensive end; Kevin Kreig, guard; Myron Lapka, nose tackle; David Stransky, wide receiver, and Bobbie Thompson, tackle. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived Eric Mack, wide receiver; Mike Newman, safety; John Conway, punter; Rick Farris, place kicker; Kedrick Hogans and Clarence McDade, linebackers; Cary Smith, offensive tackle; Eddie Stinnett, fullback, and Greg Jones, defensive end. Placed Lafayette Fletcher, running back, and Dereck Gwinn, guard, on the injured reserve list.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said the expansion of its Easylink electronic mail service will depress 1984 earnings by more than $1 a share. The company, which has about 24 million shares outstanding, said that it has approximately 65,000 Easylink users. It said the service ''is growing in line with the accelerated schedule'' approved by directors earlier this year.

title: French Hold Basque Leader
description: The man thought to be second- in-command of the military wing of the Spanish Basque separatist movement was arrested near here today, according to police sources. They said Eugenio Echeveste was picked up at a police road block.

description: Lawyers for the city urged a Federal judge today to rule that there should be a new exception to the First Amendment's protection of speech: pornography that discriminates against women.

title: THE SOFTWARE PIRACY BATTLE
description: When the Lotus Development Corporation received a report from an informant that Rixon Inc. had made unauthorized copies of a Lotus financial spreadsheet computer program for use in its branch offices, Lotus filed a $10 million copyright complaint. Rixon promptly settled for an undisclosed sum.

description: A $50 million issue of Squibb Corporation extendible notes with a final maturity in 1993 was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes have an initial coupon of 12 7/8 percent and were offered at a price of 99.934 to yield 12.90 percent to 1987.

title: The Silence in Gorky Andrei Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner, were last seen alive by a friend on May 4, in a fleeting encounter on a street in Gorky. Before the police intervened, Dr. Sakharov said he was in the third day of a hunger strike to protest the authorities' refusal to let his wife seek medical treatment abroad.
description: Since then there's been no independent word of the Soviet couple - only a few sentences by Tass and other official sources insisting the eminent scientist and dissenter is in good health.

title: LAST MARINE COMBAT FORCE QUITS BEIRUT
description: The last Marine combat troops from the multinational force in Beirut began pulling out of the United States Embassy compound before dawn today.

title: SPACE ARMS: AGENDA KNOT
description: The side that determines the negotiating agenda shapes the negotiations. That is the diplomatic reality that Reagan Administration officials find themselves contending with as they seek a formula for starting the Vienna talks on space weapons. If Moscow gets its way on the agenda, officials believe, the Administration will lose on two counts.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PROMOTION There was a time when the poster was the best way to let people know that something big, particularly a circus, was coming to town. Advance men had them in their luggage and gained space by lavish distribution of free tickets. The circus poster is a distinct art form of Americana, and that's good enough reason to post 40 of these colorful advertising devices in an exhibition on the third floor at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street (534- 1674).

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Helmsley Places Banker in 2d Spot
description: James O. Boisi, former vice chairman of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, has been named to a new post that places him second in command at Helmsley Enterprises Inc., Harry B. Helmsley, chairman and president of Helmsley, has announced.

description: Walter F. Mondale, seeking to broaden his support among black voters, today appointed Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan to be co-chairman of his Presidential campaign.

title: NEW FALL TV SHOWS' CHANCES RATED

Four shows, two each on ABC-TV and CBS-TV, have a ''good'' chance of becoming hits, based on the agency's annual season analysis.

title: MINDING THE STORE FROM A DISTANCE
description: President Reagan is on vacation in the quiet of his mountaintop ranch outside Santa Barbara, Calif. Vice President Bush is on vacation in the quiet of rustic Kennebunkport, Me. title: CUBS TOP PHILLIES, BY 3-2

Davis cracked a two-out, tiebreaking double in the sixth inning, and Ryne Sandberg tripled in a run in the seventh to help Dennis Eckersley and Chicago to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Broken Hill Goal
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company said it hopes to acquire an American oil company and a direct interest in a North Sea oilfield within two years. Russell Fynmore, executive general manager of Australia's largest publicly traded company, told a group of reporters and analysts that the company planned to spend about $250 million to $415 million to purchase a United States oil company. He said Broken Hill, which has interests in natural resources and produces steel, would merge any acquisition with its Denver-based exploration operations.

title: CHESS: LEV ALBURT IS THE WINNER OF THE U.S. CHAMPIONSHIP
description: Lev Alburt, a New York grandmaster, won the United States Championship with a scorching 12-4 score. The Russian emigre has one more round to play, but no one can overtake him. He has now qualified for the interzonal tournament for world championship aspirants.

description: Sport magazine increasing its advertising rates 9.7 percent with the December issue.

title: NEW BACTERIUM LINKED TO PAINFUL STOMACH ILLS
description: TWO Australian researchers have discovered what seems to be a new spiral-shaped bacterium living in the human stomach. The finding of one more microorganism among the thousands known might have been no more than a curiosity if the Australian bacterium were not now being tentatively linked to some of the most painful ailments known: gastritis, peptic ulcers in the stomach and duodenum, and perhaps other problems as well. Several million Americans have these ailments whose origins are often unknown.

title: Volvo's Earnings Rise
description: Volvo Personvagnar A.B., the passenger car division of A.B. Volvo, said today that its profits in the first six months of 1984 were ahead of the record pace of last year. Roger Holtback, president of the division, said Volvo sold 55,902 cars in the United States - its biggest market - in the period, up 18.8 percent from the 47,054 cars sold a year ago.

title: Jewish Archive to Show Terezin Music Special
description: On Thursday, Aug. 16 at 8 P.M., the Jewish Museum will show ''There Shall be Heard Again,'' a 1971 special CBS News broadcast of music composed and performed in Terezin, a Nazi transit camp in Czechoslovakia during World War II.
