title: MUSIC: AN EVENING OF MINIMALISM AT TANGLEWOOD
description: When Paul Fromm, the new-music patron, and Gunther Schuller, the composer and director of the Berkshire Music Center's Festival of Contemporary Music, came to their parting of the ways last year, one of the key issues between them was Minimalism. Mr. Schuller, using the narrow meaning of the term, felt that Mr. Fromm wanted him to program Steve Reich and Philip Glass - in other words, the sort of repetitive, motoric ''process music'' that those two composers epitomize.

title: G.M. Adjusts Prices Of Some '84 Models
description: The General Motors Corporation increased the price of two of its better-selling models today and announced price reductions for the slow-selling diesel- engines option and domestically made economy cars.

description: Jury selection in the retrial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas will begin here Tuesday. The jury in Judge Claiborne's first trial failed to agree and Federal District Judge Walter E. Hoffman declared a mistrial in April.

title: U.S. WEATHER SATELLITE FAILS

title: FRAUD. GUILT. QUIET.
description: Benumbed, perhaps, by constant exposure to crime and scandal in the media, the public seems unable to react to subtler but no less outrageous actions. title: MEDICAL TEXT REVIVES LOST SKILL: COMPASSION
description: ''AS a group, freshman medical students are very authoritarian, submissive and eager to fit in. They grope desperately to find out what the prevailing ethos of physicianhood is.'' These observations were part of a letter from Dr. David E. Reiser, director of Psychosocial Medicine at the University of Rochester Medical Center, in response to an article about Harvard president Derek C. Bok's criticism of medical education.

title: IN ISRAEL, NOBODY WON
description: As the final results of Israel's legislative elections materialize out of the slow and anti- quated vote-counting center, the bitter truth becomes apparent. The next Knesset is going to be what the British call ''a hung parliament'' - the outcome of a national draw in which there is no winner.

title: STUDY REVEALS A MYTH IN ATHLETIC TRAINING

Super Freddie was third, a neck back. Nearly Perfect finished fourth.

Franklin, a civil rights leader and the father of the soul singer, Aretha Franklin, a family member said. ''He and my father were great friends,'' said Mr. Franklin's daughter Erma. She said the funeral would be held Saturday with a memorial service Friday. Mr. Franklin, 69 years old, pastor of New Bethel Baptist Church, died Friday after more than five years in a coma he suffered when he was shot by burglars.

FATAL DISASTERS ON THE RISE
description: THE death toll caused by the world's natural disasters - floods, droughts, earthquakes, hurricanes and volcanic eruptions - is on the rise. A new report, analyzing data from the United States Government and the international Red Cross, found that in the 1970's the average number of natural disasters recorded per year was 75, a 50 percent increase over the previous decade. But, comparing the same two decades, the estimated deaths caused by these events climbed fivefold, to 114,000 per year. During the average year of the 1970's, disasters caused disruptions, often costly and wrenching, in the lives of an estimated 44 million people.

title: SHEDDING LIGHT ON UTILITY PROGRAMS
description: THE word ''utilities'' brings to mind a number of things. To a historian it may suggest Samuel Insull. To a Wall Street aficionado it is apt to signify a sedate but these days possibly questionable investment. To others it calls forth the terrifying idea of a nuclear accident. To computer users just the other side of being novices, however, the word conjures up convenience. In their eyes, utilities are timesavers and even, on occasion, lifesavers, for they are programs designed to help one operate and use one's computer more efficiently.

Facts and Figures for the President Denouncing the ''demogoguery'' of his critics, President Reagan asserted last week that there wasn't a ''single fact or figure to substantiate'' the claim that his budget cuts had harmed the poor. Perhaps this is just campaign talk to defend against Walter Mondale's effort to paint the President as the special friend of the rich. But maybe Mr. Reagan has become too remote from even nonpartisan analyses of his policies. Recall that a year ago he pronounced himself ''perplexed'' by well-founded reports of hunger in the United States.
description: There are plenty of facts and figures that show the poor to have lost ground in the Reagan years. And these figures don't come only from Democratic partisans.

title: ABC SEEKING FEE CUT
description: The president of ABC News and Sports has indicated in a published interview that he is hoping to reduce the network's payments to the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee by as much as $30 million. However, the network received strong ratings from its telecasts of the first two days of the Games last weekend, and if they continue that way, it is less likely ABC will win a significant reduction in its two remaining payments, which include $30 million due on Wednesday and $15 million in September. The ABC executive, Roone Arledge, said in an interview published in the July 30 issue of the magazine Advertising Age that ''every dime of any reduction made'' would be passed on to advertisers of the Games. He said that the rebate was not expected to exceed $30 million. A spokesman for ABC Sports, Thomas G. Osenton, said he was unable to confirm the comments attributed to Mr. Arledge. A cut of $30 million would make it much more difficult for the organizing committee to end the Games with a surplus, as it has vowed to do. Money left over from the Games was to be distributed to youth athletic clubs. A Surplus Projected The nonprofit organizing committee was projecting a surplus of $12 million of a total budget of $510 million, assuming that ABC would pay the $45 million balance remaining of the $225 million it agreed to pay when it acquired the television rights to the Games.

title: Cronin's Condition Fair
description: Joe Cronin, the Hall of Fame shortstop for the Washington Senators and the Boston Red Sox who went on to enjoy a successful tenure as the American League president, was listed in fair condition at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, where he was admitted July 21. At the request of the 77-year-old Cronin's family, hospital officials would give no details of his ailment.

title: GRAY QUITS CAMP IN CONTRACT DISPUTE
description: Earnest Gray, the wide receiver who enjoyed his finest season as a pro last year and in the process set a Giant club record for receptions, abruptly left training camp this afternoon in what the team characterized as a contract dispute.

title: CODE OF ETHICS
description: From its beginnings, the Code of Ethics for Political Campaigns of the American Association of Advertising Agencies has warned advertising agencies against preparing any materials that unfairly or prejudicially exploits the race, creed or national origin of any candidate. Then on the eve of the Democratic Party's nomination of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Four-A's added ''or gender'' to the prohibitions. And not a minute too soon.

description: b-Net loss.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRENCH ARMY'S NEW LOOK DRAWS PRAISE
description: A recent reorganization of the French Army has cut its strength by 22,000 soldiers, according to French officials. But Western military analysts say this has been more than counterbalanced by an increase in the quality of the army's units and the introduction of more flexible tactics. Political and military leaders of the North Atlantic alliance are said to regard the army's reorganization as one of the most significant recent military developments in Western Europe, one that should improve France's effectiveness against any aggression by the Warsaw Pact.

title: CARNEGIE IMPRESARIO OF TALENT
description: Scaffolding enfolds Carnegie Hall. Work is being done on the roof and facade of the 93-year-old building. But that is nothing compared to what will be going on in 1986, when the hall will be closed for six months, from May through Thanksgiving. At that time the lobby will be renovated to double the space outside the auditorium. Elevators will be installed and provisions made for the handicapped. Backstage facilities will be expanded. But no work will be done on the auditorium itself; the acoustics of Carnegie Hall are considered sacred.

title: WORK IN TENNIS AND LOVE
description: LIVINGSTON, N.J.

title: THE NO-SHOW 10'S
description: LOS ANGELES Under the dozens of Olympic pastel banners hanging from the ceiling at Pauley Pavilion, voices were chanting, almost demanding, ''10! 10! 10!'' And down below the blue-carpeted platform used for the floor exercises in women's gymnastics, 16-year-old Mary Lou Retton was smiling and waving as she put on her blue United States warm-up suit over her red and white leotard.

title: PROFITS UP AT UNOCAL, CHEVRON
description: The Unocal Corporation, formerly the Union Oil Company of California, yesterday reported a 33.2 percent profit increase for the second quarter. The Chevron Corporation, formerly the Standard Oil Company of California, said its net income rose 3.3 percent in the quarter.

title: A.J. M'ALLISTER SR. OF TUG FLEET DIES
description: Anthony J. McAllister Sr., former president and chairman of the board of McAllister Brothers Inc., the towing and marine transportation company, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

Pan Am Cuts London Fares
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday reductions in its off-season airfares on the New York- London route starting Nov. 1. The reductions go further than price cuts announced two weeks ago by British Airways. Minutes after the announcement Trans World Airlines, a major competitor on the route, matched the lower fares.

title: BILL ON HOOVER DAM POWER ADVANCES
description: The Senate voted 60 to 28 this evening to limit debate on a bill to give three Western states low-cost electricity from Hoover Dam for 30 more years.

title: New Offer Made For Lionel's Dale
description: The Lionel Corporation said it had received an offer from a ''substantial party'' to buy its 82 percent interest in Dale Electronics Inc. for $28 a share. Lionel, a toymaker that is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said it owns 2,950,000 Dale shares, with the remaining 650,000 held by the public.

title: GROWTH FUND'S FLEXIBILITY
description: DURING the second quarter, the Scudder Capital Growth Fund took advantage of its broad charter, which allows for flexibility in investing in different sectors of the market. ''Our two principal changes consisted of liquidating about half of our Japanese holdings and taking new positions in smaller, rapidly growing domestic companies,'' said Andrew H. Massie Jr., portfolio manager of the fund, with $223 million in total net assets.

title: 3 Ships Reported Damaged By Explosions in Gulf of Suez
description: Three ships were damaged over the weekend in the Gulf of Suez by explosions, Pentagon sources said today, and the blasts may been caused by mines.

High Tech
description: Bela Karolyi, who coached Nadia Comaneci, the 1976 Olympic gymnastics champion from Rumania before defecting to this country, now coaches the two top American female gymnasts, Mary Lou Retton and Julianne McNamara.

title: U.S. INCREASES ITS LEAD
description: The United States increased its lead at Santa Anita Park after three rounds of the three-day equestrian competition.

title: Vote on Gas Tax Gains in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Assembly unanimously agreed today to ask voters to approve a constitutional amendment that would dedicate 2.5 cents of the state's 8-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax to a new transportation program.

title: RETURN OF THE SAMURAI (OR HOW TO RELAX IN JAPAN)
description: Around noon today, 480 horsemen in Japanese medieval armor galloped across a broad field in a swirl of color and history.

title: National Steel Labor Move
description: The National Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of National Intergroup, announced yesterday that it is withdrawing from the coalition of major steel companies that bargains with the United Steelworkers of America.

title: TRUMP SAYS HE WANTS TO BUILD WORLD'S TALLEST TOWER AT EAST SIDE RIVER SITE
description: New York City plans to fill in and develop a 26-acre underwater site near the South Street Seaport, and one of several builders, Donald Trump, said yesterday that he hoped to construct the world's tallest building there.

description: this September because of hypertension, for which he is currently undergoing treatment. However, both the Islanders and their team internist said yesterday that they expected Potvin to be fit in time for the Islander training

title: TUESDAY, JULY 31, 1984 Companies
description: St. Regis and Champion International plan to merge, according to industry insiders. The deal, reported to be worth $2 billion, would thwart the attempts of Rupert Murdoch to acquire St. Regis. The publisher has proposed two separate offers to acquire the paper company. Champion also has paper operations. (Page D1.)

description: Sometimes, along the back roads of this rolling farm country, modernity measures itself in simple colors of orange and gray.

description: The euphoria that permeated the French haute couture shows was grounded in the hard fact that sales have been on an upswing for the past three years, a period coinciding with the Socialist regime of Francois Mitterrand.

description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said it will spend about $200 million for installation of a new fine-paper machine at its Port Huron, La., pulp mill and for related costs. The machine is expected to be operational in the third quarter of 1986.

description: More than 500 homeless and unemployed people marched downtown in the fourth annual Hobo Parade Sunday, urging others like them to register to vote and increase their political influence.

He will fly to Mexico City on Aug. 12 to attend the final meetings of the international conference there on population problems, which opens next Monday.

irst Chicago Sale

The company, which declined to disclose other financial details about the assets and real estate, said the transaction will have no significant effect on third-quarter earnings.
